The portion size of the accompanying cole slaw with a half sandwich was minuscule, rendering it nearly invisible, which was disappointing given its commendable taste. The corned beef sandwiches were satisfactory but lacked exceptional quality, despite their substantial size, which seemed to be the primary focus. The restaurant's entrance presented a chaotic atmosphere, with various sections including check-in, registration, takeout, and merchandise display, while the seating area appeared unremarkable. In summary, this establishment fails to meet the standards of a genuine Jewish deli, despite its attempts to emulate one, and falls short in both appearance and flavor, although it does have an advantage over other places outside of the coastal regions. However, my overall satisfaction was compromised by the disparity between its self-proclaimed identity and the actual experience.
"Subpar service experience with prolonged waiting periods for both food and server assistance, despite satisfactory culinary quality."

This theater does not evoke the fear that people tend to associate with it; rather, it can be perceived as an antiquated remnant from the early 1990s when Mills malls were prevalent throughout the nation. Its aged appearance and outdated ambiance may deter some individuals, but it primarily attracts a distinct clientele.  
I was reluctantly accompanying my companion to this cinema on a Thursday evening, anticipating a lackluster comedic experience in front of a meager audience. Unfortunately, my expectations were met, as there were merely five other individuals scattered throughout the theater. The time spent there seemed irretrievable, and the possibility of obtaining a refund appeared unlikely, given the theater's policy of directing customers to a self-service machine that might potentially malfunction.  
During the process of purchasing tickets, Melinda encountered difficulties with her card at one of the machines, necessitating our migration to an alternative device. Although the transaction was successfully completed, the tickets and receipt failed to print. Consequently, we were compelled to visit the box office, which the automated machines were intended to circumvent. Surprisingly, the manager displayed leniency and allowed us entry without requesting any evidence. It is conceivable that we could have fabricated this narrative, and perhaps we shall attempt to do so in the future.

I used to love this place when they were located at von's shopping center. Then they moved to Food4Less shopping cnter, I still like it. The business closed for several months, don't know why. Now they're back and I'm so excited. Today I came back for my favorite, pad thai. It doesn't taste as good and they no longer have lunch special.

Website does not reflect accurate stock levels, company fails to inform customers of out of stock items and processes the order short, when you call to address the matter, they very rudely talk over you and hang up. I take that as a sign they don;t want my business, I will be happy to oblige.
They have gone severely down hill. Have gone here for a couple years for close by chinese. I wouldn't go back.

"Positives: The waitstaff member exhibited a pleasant demeanor and accommodating attitude, while the establishment remained operational on December 24th, albeit with limited hours of operation. Negatives: The waitstaff member lacked proficiency in her duties, as evidenced by an extended delay in serving our party, during which time we were forced to consume beverages that had been subjected to an unacceptable degree of oxidation, rendering them undrinkable; furthermore, the fries, which required an unreasonable amount of time to prepare, arrived lacking the customary golden-brown hue and crispy texture associated with this staple side dish, their deficient temperature rendering them unpalatable."

Do you want to die shortly after being slapped in the face with a cover charge that shouldn't be charged and then having your girlfriend gang raped on the dance floor?

It receives two stars simply because I used to like the place.  Pool, good music, dancing, reasonable drink prices.  But, after a couple of tense situations, witnessing fights on a near weekly basis, and a parking lot shooting....I'll pass these days.

I don't do karaoke so that side of the establishment might be okay.
Nothing special here. Average tacos and below average service. If you are drunk and hungry this place might suite you.

After indulging in an extensive exploration of South Phoenix's culinary landscape for an hour on a Sunday, in pursuit of a delectable breakfast burrito from a quaint Mexican eatery, and experiencing the unfortunate symptoms of a hangover and exhaustion, I inadvertently arrived at Fili B's.

Their breakfast menu boasts an impressive array of options, available throughout the day, which is indeed a remarkable feature.

However, had I not been subject to such an extended and arduous quest for a suitable establishment, and had I not been overcome by an insatiable hunger, I might have opted for a more familiar Mexican drive-thru, such as the ones located at 5th Avenue and Camelback Road or 40th Street and Indian School Road, all of which offer a satisfying variety of breakfast burritos.

Regrettably, my experience at Fili B's fell short of my expectations, as the dish did not provide the satisfaction I had hoped for. The excessive amount of cheese and undercooked, fatty bacon detracted from the flavor, while my companions' chorizo burritos lacked zest and were excessively oily. Generally, I tend to avoid Fili B's and instead prefer to visit its sister establishments or similar eateries, such as Rollberto's, Eriberto's, Armando's, and so forth.
Meh. The location and the venue is great, but the food is only okay.  I liked the drinks, though! CREATIVE!!

I ordered lasagna, dinner salad and soup.  The Italian wedding soup tasted just like Italian dressing.  It used to be so good. I was so disappointed in it that I saved it for a week to get a refund since I only took two bites but never found the time to take it in and deal with the manager I spoke to that seemed hesitant to provide a refund vs. a replacement product. All the herby delicious flavor was gone and sweet, sweet, sweet took over. Don't they know not to mess with a good thing. Either they changed the recipe or they have a lazy cook.

The lasagna was good but also really sweet. The portion for the price was disappointing. For that much money, I will just make a pan at home and freeze some portions.  

The dinner salad was fantastic. Full of yummy, crispy veggies. If the lettuce had been drained and the dressing didn't come out of a bottle with so much sugar it could gag you, I would get that salad twice a week. 

I won't be returning for anything BUT the salad, and only if I have my own dressing.

Bummer update.

I had pants hemmed here and, while the guy did a decent job (though they still ended up too long even though he pinned them while I had them on?) it was absurdly expensive and took A WEEK.  \n\nCome on now.

"The culinary offerings were merely adequate, akin to those available at a standard Italian eatery, whereas the hospitality was truly exceptional, characterized by an extraordinary level of cordiality. My spouse and I were commemorating our first anniversary, and while the ambiance was not optimal for such a momentous occasion, the staff's eagerness to expedite our departure was manifestly evident, as they removed our plates before we had completed our meals. The establishment was not particularly crowded on this Sunday evening, yet the sense of urgency they conveyed was palpable, making for an unfortunate dining experience that precludes any future visits."

"I requested a mozzarella and tomato sandwich, a diminutive order of pasta salad, and a beverage, and the total cost amounted to $13. For such an exorbitant price, I could have easily dined at a full-service restaurant, thereby obtaining a more comprehensive culinary experience. While Paradise Bakery boasts an impressive selection of delectable cookies, their other edible offerings are, regrettably, egregiously overpriced."

Great for the beer but not for the food... You get what you pay for food wise. Great prices on beer and decent selection.

I had the fried macaroni brick and it was mostly forgettable.

The big plus is the very nice and large flat screen tv's all over the place.

We visited this establishment and our experience was utterly underwhelming.  My spouse had the vegetarian skillet, which was unimpressive, to say the least, as the vegetables were unpleasantly chilled and were crowned with a lackluster melted cheese.  I opted for pancakes, which, quite frankly, were subpar in both taste and texture, and failed to surpass the quality of those produced by Bisquick, a widely available pre-mixed baking solution.  Needless to say, we shall not be patronizing this establishment again in the future, particularly given its proximity to our place of residence.  Indeed, the whole experience was a profound disappointment.

I had the pleasure of patronizing this establishment on a recent Tuesday evening, and while the service provided by my nail technician was satisfactory, the overall ambiance left much to be desired. It appeared that there was an individual present, who from what I gathered was a hairstylist, and she seemed to have little qualms about allowing her offspring to roam freely throughout the salon as she worked. This lack of decorum was particularly bothersome to me, as I had been seeking a tranquil environment in which to indulge in some much-needed self-care. Furthermore, the audible nature of the hairstylist's telephonic conversation only served to further detract from my ability to relax. When questioned about these issues, my nail technician informed me that such behavior was commonplace and that the children in question were frequently present in the salon, engaging in boisterous activities. Needless to say, I do not plan on returning to this establishment in the future, as I prefer not to have my personal time interrupted by the unbridled energy of youth.

"Complimentary carbonated beverages were provided, a pleasant gesture, albeit, the sole notable attribute encountered during my visit. Pervasive fumigation permeated the interior (even by casino standards), resulting in an unpleasant experience upon returning home, enshrouded in pungent smoke. Furthermore, participation in the rewards program proved somewhat vexatious, as the complimentary $10 slot play was restricted to specific, sparsely dispersed, crown-marked machines, often occupied by individuals with no apparent intention of relinquishing their seats in the near future. Overall, this establishment ranks among my least preferred gaming venues in the greater Phoenix area, thereby rendering it unlikely that I shall revisit in the forthcoming days."

We indulged in a delectable brunch at this establishment this morning; however, our culinary satisfaction was significantly diminished by the subpar service we received. Furthermore, we were taken aback by the presence of a steak knife perched atop the toilet paper dispenser in the ladies' restroom, an unsettling discovery that elicited relief that no young child had accidentally encountered it. Consequently, we are left feeling disillusioned and compelled to seek an alternative venue for our future brunch endeavors. This establishment must expedite efforts to ameliorate their organizational proficiency and rectify the issues that hamper their ability to provide optimal service to patrons.

"Rating: 2.5 stars, albeit subjective, yet rounded down deliberately for pragmatic reasons, as my expectations, admittedly elevated due to online reviews proclaiming this particular buffet as one of Las Vegas' finest, were not entirely fulfilled, despite its novel concept of a globally-inspired smorgasbord featuring an array of culinary outposts showcasing diverse regional specialties such as Chinese, American, Mexican, Mediterranean, and possibly Japanese fare, unfortunately limited by the meager offerings at each station, ultimately leading to a sense of underwhelment; specifically, my spouse expressed disappointment regarding the crab legs, deeming them undercooked, and their seafood selection unimpressive, though it must be acknowledged that this establishment does not purport to be a seafood-centric buffet, while my personal experience involved a succulent roast pork, yet lacking that extra je ne sais quoi to render it truly remarkable, leading me to suggest that patrons consider dining at an independent restaurant instead."

The lunchtime smorgasbord offers a subpar culinary experience, at best, with superior gastronomic options available elsewhere. My personal preference for this eatery is restricted to their delectable chaat, which, regrettably, was unavailable on the day in question due to an alleged surfeit of tasks in the kitchen, much to the dismay of my dining companion and myself, despite the fact that certain privileged patrons managed to procure takeout containers of the coveted delicacy, presumably via prior arrangements.

Very disappointed!Heard so much about this place so we were very surprised! Walked in and immediately greeted... Very good service.\nThe place was dead!!! It was after 9 so drinks weren't on special.. But 8 for a corona!? No thanks!

"My recollection of the 'wichcraft in Bryant Park several years ago is one imbued with affection, and it is my conviction that the experiential delight was attributable, in no small part, to the tangible ambiance of al fresco dining, an atmospheric quality that, in conjunction with the culinary offerings, rendered the venue an especially memorable luncheon destination. It is unfortunate that the Las Vegas location has undergone a transformation that has resulted in a diminution of its erstwhile excellence. 

Upon arriving at the establishment at 4 pm on a Saturday, I was met with a queue that extended to the entrance, a phenomenon that, while unexpected, did not particularly surprise me, given the tendency of temporal considerations to become irrelevant within the confines of a casino. Notwithstanding the fact that the preparation of the sandwiches involved merely reheating pre-assembled components, the process seemed to consume an appreciable amount of time, though, as I was not particularly pressed for it, I did not regard it as a significant inconvenience. 

I placed an order for a ham, cheddar, and apple sandwich on pumpernickel bread, opting to take it with me rather than consuming it on the premises. My eagerness to partake of the delectable treat I had remembered from my previous visit prompted me to unwrap and sample a few bits of it in the automobile, but, unfortunately, the texture proved to be disagreeably soggy, almost as if the moisture content of the fruit had surpassed an optimal threshold, rendering approximately half of the sandwich unpleasantly mushy. The remaining portion, however, retained its structural integrity and offered a satisfactory, albeit somewhat lackluster, taste experience, which I attribute to the selection of cheddar cheese, a choice that, in my opinion, detracted from the inherent flavors of the apple and ham components, resulting in a relatively uninspiring gustatory encounter that could be rivaled by certain offerings from a Subway restaurant."

Sadly disappointed

Not sure if it was an "off" night for this 4 star yelped restaurant but I was quite surprised.  Someone needs to tackle quality control.

Nothing seemed fresh, the food looked as though it was presented well, but tasted like stale leftovers (I hate leftovers).  ALL the cut  meats were completely dried out and tough (yes.. Ribs, prime rib, turkey.. Dry and tough).  The Asian cuisine made me sick.. Seriously the only things worth eating 1) pizza was editable, and 2) the ice cream was yum.

I will not be returning!

It was indeed one of the initial pleasant weekends in Montreal, and we had become cognizant of the fact that certain rooftop restaurants within the vicinity were offering brunch services. Subsequently, we arrived at the establishment and took a seat, only to be taken aback by the revelation that brunch was not being offered, with lunch being the sole available option. The elevator's signage suggested that brunch was served between the hours of 11 am and 3:30 pm, yet this was seemingly applicable to the restaurant situated below us. Frankly, I remain uncertain about the veracity of this claim. Notwithstanding, we opted to partake in the culinary offerings, as our hunger was quite pronounced. 

We procured some beverages and placed an order for an appetizer, which, upon its arrival, proved to be exceptionally delectable. Unfortunately, this was the sole highlight of the repast, apart from the favorable weather conditions and panoramic view. My vegetarian burger, in particular, bore a strong resemblance to a mass-produced patty, both in terms of its appearance and taste, which was rather unfortunate. 

Following the consumption of our meals, we waited for what seemed like an interminable period of time, amounting to at least thirty minutes, before our bills were presented to us. The establishment was bustling with activity, and our server appeared to be overwhelmed, leading to our table being neglected, much to our dismay. Eventually, our server returned, exhibiting remorse, which was, to some extent, reassuring. In conclusion, I would not advocate for a revisit to this establishment, owing to the subpar quality of the cuisine and the unsatisfactory nature of the service provided.

"The densely populated drinking establishment we visited on a Sunday left me feeling utterly overpowered. Our excursion commenced with the consumption of margaritas at the Hefe on Mill, followed by a convenient Uber ride to the sister venue situated in the historic district of Old Town Scottsdale. \nIt is my conviction that if this bar were located in a less populous urban setting, it would provide a more enjoyable experience; unfortunately, the sheer volume of patrons within the confines of a relatively diminutive space rendered the atmosphere oppressive. Alternatively, management may wish to consider implementing a restriction on the number of individuals allowed to congregate at any given time... The scenario was nothing short of absurd."

I cannot stand this DMV. I refuse to ever go to inside again unless absolutely necessary and will use the kiosk outside.
I was able to go at 2:00 AM this morning and renew the registration on my car at the kiosk outside without having to deal with any worker on the inside rolling their eyes and disliking being there. It took seriously 2 minutes and it spit my registration right out. That was convenient! With the kiosks popping up all over town, I hopefully can just use those for renewals. 

I don't like how the employees treat the customers. They know that we have no other company to go to and have no choice but to use the DMV. 

This location is always to packed with lines at times wrapping around the building outside. There is a snack bar LOL. If you want a hot dog and nachos while you wait then you are in luck!

"Upon entering the expansive eatery for an evening repast, it was conspicuously devoid of patrons, a circumstance that did not augur well for an establishment purporting to serve culinary delights. Furthermore, the menu, a tome of gastronomical proportions rivalling that of the fabled Cheesecake Factory, only served to heighten my skepticism. In light of the overwhelming array of options, I opted for the relatively unremarkable chicken tender plate, while my companion selected a Thai-inspired dish and her maternal figure chose a salad. It is worth noting that the dearth of clientele did not abate the prolonged duration between our order and the receipt of our meals, which exceeded three quarters of an hour. My poultry, though hardly exceptional, was not as unpalatable as I had anticipated, yet it fell short of the mark set by other establishments specializing in fried avian cuisine, such as Bojangles. Lastly, the selection of beverages available at this establishment was woefully inadequate, a fact that only served to further diminish my overall satisfaction with the dining experience."

Visited this place on a night when they had some bands. Had a very difficult time getting attention of wait staff. Finally walked up to the bar and ordered two draft beers which ended up being close to 10 bucks. Several people - including us - tried to flag down a server and finally after about 40 minutes our orders were finished. The appetizer (an italian burrito?) was served to us still frozen inside. Soups were nothing special. Ribs were pretty good but unless you like LOTS of sauce, ask for it on the side. Bands were very good on this night. I ended up only drinking three drinks that night because that seemed to be all they wanted to sell me. Couldn't seem to get anyone's attention for more. Seems like if you are going to pay a band you want to sell the food and drinks a little better.

We walked in for happy hour... took a look around... smelled like a funeral home...

Walked out....

Maybe this place is good if you are retired....

"The personnel were amicable and hospitable, facilitating an arrangement for my grandmother. Subsequent to my departure, I scrutinized the floral arrangement and noticed that certain rose petals exhibited desiccation and necrosis. Considering the cost, I surmised that the flower arrangement was overpriced in relation to the quality and quantity of blooms provided."

This was our first experience at this location.  We had been to other place and the pizza was amazing but service was beyond horrible.  Had some friends in town and good pizza seemed like the common thought, we came here to get a good pizza that wasn't a 'normal chain' type place.  We ordered two pizza's and they were both just ok, and the staff here was not as bad as the other location but it amazes me in such a small place such as this that your drinks being empty for extended periods of time as well as the one waitress not being seen in the dining room for extended periods of time.  I will order to go from the other location before I do this stop again.  I'm assuming the drinking and the proximity to UNLV is what keeps this location open.

"What in the name of culinary excellence has transpired at this establishment?!? The pace of service is sluggish, the fare served is unremarkable, the quality has diminished significantly, the dining area is unkempt and appears to have been neglected for an extended period of time... This venue was previously considered an affordable substitute for the illustrious PF Changs; however, it now pales in comparison to even the most middling of dining experiences offered by Denny's. It would appear that the management of this eatery has strayed considerably from its erstwhile commitment to providing a satisfactory dining experience for its clientele."

In today's stringent economic climate, I am reluctant to express dissatisfaction with an eatery unless it truly merits censure. However, my recent dining experience at this establishment left much to be desired, despite the fact that I was the sole patron present. Not only did I have to procure my own condiments, but I also waited an inordinate amount of time for a water refill while consuming my meal. On a positive note, the baba ganoush was palatable and reasonably priced, while the salad was fresh and crisp. Unfortunately, the kafta kabob was somewhat arid and could have benefited from the addition of a tangy tahini sauce to enhance its flavor. Although the woman who served me was polite, her attention to detail was lacking, as she failed to ensure that I had all the necessities required for a satisfying dining experience. Based on my assessment, three stars seems rather generous; nevertheless, I may consider returning in the future, particularly given the presence of appealing lunch specials available between 11 am and 3 pm.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

Went there with some friends. Our server was borderline creepy--- when we asked for more time to view the menu, he responded with sarcasm, inquiring if we would be prepared by the following day. Umm, okay? The food was average. I shared three dishes with three companions. Eggplant parmesan from the appetizer menu, Caprese, and formaggio ravioli (I forget the pretentious name they gave it). The eggplant parm was unremarkable and extremely oily... I've had superior versions from coffee shops. The ravioli was decent but lacked filling. They were quite flat. The sauce accompanying them was somewhat thick, but it tasted acceptable. The best part of the meal was the Caprese. Extremely fresh and attractively presented. The only item worth the cost that we sampled. 

Furthermore, after dining, we inquired whether we could view the collection of vehicles adjacent to the eatery, which is one of the location's "draws." Sorry, there's an entrance fee. Forget about it. In summary, avoid this location. It is an overpriced tourist trap with too much repetition.

"A severely confined parking area is associated with this Walgreens location, and it is emphatically advisable to exercise vigilant surveillance of your surroundings while traversing the distance between the store and your vehicle. The parking lot is indeed remarkably compact, presenting a significant challenge for maneuverability. \n\nDuring my most recent visit, I opted to utilize the drive-through service, and I must say that the clerical staff member who attended to our prescription was truly exceptional. Her proficiency and dedication were thoroughly impressive, warranting a singular accolade. Notwithstanding, the overall experience would have been significantly less satisfactory without her diligent efforts, thereby necessitating a rating of only one star."

Attente atrocement longue 
Chocolat chaud à la limite du buvable (et clairement en poudre, pour quelque chose annoncé comme "chocolat noir 56% blablabla"
Erreur dans une des commandes

Ma cassolette n'était pas assez bonne pour rattraper tout ça.

Déçu

I visited this establishment in the company of some colleagues for a post-work social gathering and was left feeling underwhelmed. Despite its advantageous location overlooking Market Square, the eatery's culinary offerings and hospitality fell short of expectations. We capitalized on the happy hour special featuring margaritas and found them to be satisfactory. Everyone partook in these potent potables and relished them. 
  During this promotional period, appetizers were available at a reduced price, prompting us to order multiple dishes to share among ourselves. My sampling of sopecitos consisted of four substantial corn tortillas, each topped with a distinct protein - chicken, steak, carnitas, and chorizo, respectively. While the meat was passable, the tortillas lacked freshness and arrived at our table merely lukewarm. 
  My attempt at the empanadas yielded a mediocre experience, as the beef filling failed to impress. This dish was unremarkable and forgettable. A few other items we ordered were similarly unimpressive. However, the flautas proved to be the exception, as they were the only dishes that garnered universal acclaim from our group. If only we had opted for multiple orders of these delectable treats instead! 
  Our experience was further marred by subpar service. It took nearly an hour for our appetizers to arrive, and one dish was incorrectly prepared upon its eventual arrival. Following my request for a correction, the mistake was rectified, yet the faulty dish remained listed on my bill. After having it removed, the entire ordeal proved bothersome.

Pretty much meh.  It wasn't terrible, but nothing worth making a special trip for.  I tried the al pastor and lengua tacos.  The pastor was a little dry and lacked the usual sweetness.  The lengua was tender, but didn't have enough seasoning or something... just kind of bland.

"The staff member's comportment was adequate, with the exception of a singular individual. During the lunchtime hours, as we were preparing to assemble our meals, one of the establishment's employees vociferously exclaimed, 'You can't be back here!' The staff member's remark was uttered in a discourteous manner, and it pertained to the spatial area situated between the dual self-service vegetable and meat stations. Notwithstanding the fact that one of the bars was temporarily inaccessible, it was somewhat arduous to extend my reach to procure an item positioned at the rear of the counter. Consequently, I opted to traverse to the opposing side, thereby facilitating my accessibility to the desired item. However, the aforementioned staff member chose to vocally reprimand me from a distance, rather than approaching me and issuing a warning in a more civil manner. Such behavior was utterly disrespectful and unbecoming! It is pertinent to ponder the underlying purpose and aspirations of this particular eatery. Should they not strive for excellence and grandeur, rather than settling for mediocrity?"

After my friend had been super excited and raving about this place, I was disappointed that it's really not that great for vegetarians or vegans. The burger I got just didn't have a tasty flavor. Just kind of sour and sickly sweet. I actually got sick of eating it and stopped..which HARDLY EVER happens to me.

The gastronomical experience afforded by the veggie omelette was utterly deficient in terms of culinary quality, as it exhibited an egregious excess of doneness, rendering it arid and unyielding to the palate, which was particularly disconcerting given the establishment's previous reputation for serving delectable fare; indeed, my dining companion's omelette suffered from a similar dearth of flavor and texture, thereby substantiating my recommendation that patrons exercise caution when perusing the menu, especially in light of the premium pricing associated with such an underwhelming gustatory encounter.

I must confess that my predilection for Mexican cuisine has rendered me somewhat fastidious when it comes to indulging in such culinary delights. My penchant is for diminutive, unpretentious eateries that serve authentic fare, the kind of places that are often overlooked by those who prefer more ostentatious establishments.

In this particular instance, I opted for the quintet of miniature chimichangas, accompanied by a serving of both beans and rice. While the total cost of ten dollars may strike some as rather exorbitant for a meal of this caliber, I must admit that the quality of the ingredients utilized did justify the expense to a certain extent.

The aforementioned chimichangas were stuffed with an amalgamation of cream cheese and shredded beef, the former being slightly more prevalent than the latter. Furthermore, the pastries themselves seemed to possess a subtle sweetness, almost as if they had been crafted from a flaky pastry dough. Although the rice was relatively unremarkable, the refried beans served alongside them were truly delectable. It is worth mentioning that I would have greatly preferred the option of procuring chicken-based chimichangas instead.

My exploration of their salsa bar revealed that the assortment of condiments available failed to impress my palate, striking me as rather bland and lacking in flavor. However, the combination of avocado and salsa verde did manage to capture my attention, boasting a singular uniqueness and tantalizing taste that set it apart from its counterparts.

Upon entering the establishment, I was immediately struck by its pristine state of cleanliness. The staff's enthusiasm for ensuring a warm welcome was undeniably commendable, yet I couldn't help but feel that their repeated expressions of hospitality throughout my dining experience bordered on excessive. As a native of the southern United States, I find that a simple acknowledgement or courteous greeting suffices in most situations.

One item that did pique my interest was their fried ice cream milkshake, which I would love to sample on a future visit. Unfortunately, the aforementioned dessert constitutes the sole reason for my potential return, as I do not foresee myself frequenting this establishment with sufficient regularity to warrant further exploration of its menu. In conclusion, I must assert that this restaurant falls short of the standards set by similar eateries that I hold in high esteem, such as Carolina's or Los Dos Melinos.

"Flying into this location is exceptional. It embodies the essence of Las Vegas. Upon arrival, one experiences an unparalleled sense of excitement, eager to indulge in frivolous pursuits...

However, one's financial resources are rapidly depleted due to excessive gambling, rendering it impossible to cover the cost of an evening meal, gain entry into exclusive nightclubs, and ultimately leading to feelings of disappointment and the desire to return home forthwith.

Upon arriving at the airport, one is met with an extensive queue, stretching back to the walls, which would typically remain unoccupied. Following a prolonged waiting period of approximately one to two hours, one finally clears security protocols, albeit with considerable relief...

Subsequently, one becomes cognizant of the necessity to proceed to the D gates. Unfortunately, the sole means of conveyance, the tram, is nonoperational. Thus, one must undertake a brisk, mile-long trek while burdened with cumbersome luggage exceeding the recommended weight limit for checked baggage (a consequence of excessive purchases during one's stay in Las Vegas). 

Upon reaching the designated gate, one discovers a two-hour delay, further exacerbating the already trying circumstances...

In summary, this airport experience has been particularly unsatisfactory, marred by an interminable security line, the malfunctioning of the tram, and a protracted delay prior to departure."
Enjoyed my veggie burger with fries. Service sucked the last 2 times. We had to flag down a waitress to get our refills. Next time we'll do take out to avoid tipping poor service

"A pleasant ambiance and hospitable personnel notwithstanding, my experience at this establishment fell short of my expectations, as the therapeutic session itself left much to be desired. Despite the therapist's cordial demeanor and willingness to address specific areas of discomfort, they inadvertently created an additional knot that has persisted since the massage, which I had not experienced prior to the treatment. While the facilities were clean and well-maintained, and the front desk staff exhibited a welcoming attitude, the cost of services rendered was somewhat prohibitive and may deter potential patrons seeking comparable quality massages at more reasonable prices elsewhere. Although I was referred to this spa by a satisfied acquaintance and harbored elevated expectations, my experience did not live up to my standards, leaving me uninspired and unlikely to return. In essence, nothing extraordinary or remarkable distinguished this spa from others in its class, which is precisely what I seek when investing such sums of money."

Okay, unfortately SW Airllines needs to train their employees better.\nSW Airlines can only issue to a passenger two (2) boarding passes in a travel day. Example: Travel day 12/1; traveing from PHX to GEG with connecting flight in OKL (changing airplanes), got two boarding passes; got to GEG did my business and got an boarding pass at GEG with stop in LAS (no change of planes). It's frustrating because GEG was a full (over booked) flight.

The individual had the pleasure of consuming a slow-cooked pork dish, specifically cochinito pibil, which was advertised as a specialty of the establishment and cost $20. Unfortunately, the dish did not live up to its billing, as it was found to be lacking in both flavor and presentation. Specifically, the pork was over-salted and slightly dry, with an abundance of spices that overpowered the palate. Furthermore, the sauce that accompanied the dish was carelessly drizzled around the rim of the plate, creating an unappealing appearance that detracted from the overall dining experience. In contrast, the $7 Modelo beer was quite satisfying and provided a welcome respite from the disappointing meal.

I must confess that my contributions to Yelp are minimal, however, my dissatisfaction with The Haymaker warrants an expression of discontent. Previously, I held this establishment in high regard, frequently indulging in their culinary offerings and introducing them to my acquaintances visiting from afar. Unfortunately, my recent experiences have been marred by a discernible decline in quality. It appears that my glass is no longer replenished with the same alacrity as in times past, and the once-present garnish of lettuce has metamorphosed into an unappealing shredded form. Moreover, the complimentary to-go iced coffee, formerly imbued with a rich, toasted almond flavor, has vanished from their repertoire. Furthermore, during a recent Saturday afternoon visit, I was dismayed to discover the absence of marinara sauce for the mozzarella sticks. In spite of these shortcomings, the Happy Hour special featuring $2 Bud Light drafts remains a notable highlight. However, my "medium" burger arrived with a solitary tomato slice, which, regrettably, was positioned at the terminal end of the patty. Additionally, my request for an onion slice was fulfilled with a singular, somewhat limp ring of onion. Until I am apprised of improvements, I fear that my patronage of The Haymaker shall remain suspended.

We actually dine at this establishment with reasonable frequency, and thus, it may come as a surprise that my rating is not higher, as I have come to expect more from this venue. Upon closer examination, I have come to realize that the primary draws for me are the complimentary chips and salsa, which are undoubtedly delectable. Additionally, their margaritas are typically quite impressive. Furthermore, I have developed a fondness for their newly introduced pretzel stick appetizer. Most importantly, the servers have consistently displayed exceptional friendliness and attentiveness. However, the culinary offerings remain the sole area of concern, as I have yet to experience a thoroughly satisfying meal. Despite attempting a wide variety of dishes, I have found that certain components of each dish are occasionally palatable, but a uniformly excellent meal has proven elusive. Specifically, the margarita chicken is passable, but the accompanying sides tend to be lackluster and appear somewhat stale. Similarly, the burger is adequate, but the fries are often subpar. The children's meals are regrettably inadequate, prompting me to seek alternative dining options for family gatherings. Typically, my visits to this establishment are limited to luncheons with my spouse, during which we opt for the unlimited chips and salsa with soup and salad. Unfortunately, even these aspects have become less impressive over time. In spite of these shortcomings, I will likely return to partake in the aforementioned attractions, though for a well-rounded dining experience, I would recommend exploring other options.

I have been here a few times now, and just not been impressed. The stylists are OK, nothing great. There prices are decent, but I think a little on the high side for the quality you get. My biggest complaint comes from the customer service. I have called after hours or on Sundays when they are closed several times and left a message. They will NOT call you back. If you are going to have an answering machine then use it and call people back. I guess business is good if they can afford to not return calls and go else where. I will not be returning here.

"This establishment represents the quintessence of mediocrity, as it is the fourth Hawaiian barbecue restaurant I have had the displeasure of dining at, and it falls short in numerous aspects. Firstly, the absence of teriyaki and katsu sauces, which are fundamental components of any respectable Hawaiian barbecue, is a glaring omission. Furthermore, the substitute condiments provided, specifically soy sauce and an overly sweetened, processed, and glowing red sauce, fail to enhance the flavor profile of the dishes they accompany. The macaroni salad, a staple of Hawaiian cuisine, is unacceptably prepared with overcooked noodles, an unappetizing seasoning akin to pepper, and an insufficient amount of carrot shavings, resulting in a lackluster presentation. The barbecue chicken, purportedly marinated, exhibits a striking lack of moisture and flavor, rendering it unpalatable. The bed of vegetables, comprising tired, desiccated cabbage, resembles imitation grass often found in Easter baskets, further detracting from the overall quality of the meal. The menu's confusion between Hawaiian barbecue and what could be described as 'ghetto Chinese food' of South Phoenix only serves to exacerbate the disappointment. Although the elderly Asian couple who own and operate the establishment are quite cordial, the service, while prompt, does not compensate for the culinary shortcomings. Despite the eatery's cleanliness, surpassing its nearby competitors, its location amidst a plethora of fast-food options makes it readily forgettable. Regretfully, I cannot envision a scenario where I would return to this establishment, unless, perhaps, I find myself in the vicinity with a strong yearning for something Hawaiian."

"Greetings, I shall embark upon a nostalgic escapade to the year 1990, whereupon I shall regale you with an account of my experience at a certain establishment known as 'Milano.' Alas, it pains me to divulge that this erstwhile bastion of conviviality has succumbed to the vicissitudes of time, transforming it into a mere shadow of its former self. A dearth of clientele, an ephemeral and capricious staff, an excess of cacophonous melodies, and an atmosphere that militates against effortless conversation and relaxation have all contributed to its decline. Moreover, the proprietors, in a seemingly futile attempt to mitigate the purported inconvenience posed by external disturbances, have elected to seal the windows, thereby necessitating the perpetual operation of the aged, diminutive climate control system, which, in turn, has rendered the ambiance within the premises stifling and oppressive. Furthermore, the odor emanating from the cigarette smoke permeates the atmosphere, imbuing both the staff and patrons with an unmistakable aroma redolent of neglect and abandonment. A sole redeeming feature, if one may be so bold as to label it as such, resides in the tables situated outside, affording a modicum of respite from the stultifying environment within. In conclusion, my foray into yesteryear has yielded a melancholy revelation: that even the most venerated institutions are susceptible to the ravages of time and the inexorable forces of change."

This is one of my regular stops for breakfast. Normally a great breakfast joint but not today. The greeter wasn't friendly and the food was average. This place has been around for a long time with a good reputation. The kitchen needs to try harder and they need a friendly, happy greeter. It will be a while before I go back.

"The personnel within the establishment exhibit amicable demeanors, however, subsequent experiences deteriorate precipitously from such an auspicious beginning. Specifically, Room 1122 should be avoided at all costs if a restful slumber is desired, as the confluence of a nearby train, an ice machine, and an antiquated AC/heat wall unit renders sleep an unattainable luxury. Furthermore, the peeling wallpaper in shared spaces and outmoded decor detract from the overall ambiance. Additionally, the culinary offerings served during the midday repast were unacceptably chilly, and a dearth of accessible power outlets hinders the charging of electronic devices."

"As an ardent devotee of second-hand shopping, I must confess that this specific Goodwill establishment fails to impress, exuding an unpleasant odor reminiscent of a deceased feline relative upon entrance, which unfortunately permeates the ambiance. However, for those seeking vintage furniture to refurbish or repaint, the selection appears adequate. Nonetheless, I would recommend visiting the location on 20th Street and Indian School, boasting a newer construction and a more pleasant atmosphere, replete with an array of superior quality items."

we came here for lunch I ordered the sweet Deal pick 3 for 4$ just had a regular cheeseburger ,onion rings, and a drink . The food came out quick a little too quick cause they did a poor job making the cheeseburger had way too much Mustered and Ketchup and was all over the wraper just oozing out the sides the onion rings were pretty good

Not really very good.  The place seemed nice and other reviews mentioned good pizza.  We ordered a large thin crust with tomato, mushrooms, pepper, cheese, and pepperoni.  The crust was not thin at all--and was just a touch doughy.  Lived in Italy for 4 years and this is not a \"Palermo\" crust.  Mushrooms tasted like that out of a can.  \n\nThe young guy taking the order was stone-faced and didn't even say hello.  On the way out another guy (owner?) was cheerful and seemed courteous.

I heard many good things about this place and so was excited to try it out.

My friends and I ordered the Thai Beef Salad, Asian Chicken Salad, Monsters Meatball and Spaghetti, and Grilled Salmon. We were extremely disappointed. I don't even know what the meatballs tasted like. The spaghetti and salad dressings were BAD. The rice was hard. The salmon was a-ok, but the portion was small compared to other dishes.

On the bright side, I tried their famous frozen hot chocolate, and I loved it! We all loved it! Totally made my experience better. 

I don't know if we didn't order the right food, but I'm definitely not coming back here for their food, ONLY FOR DESSERT!

"We waited for an interval of ten minutes for the presentation of both the menu and water, and it must be noted that the ambient temperature at the time was approximately one hundred degrees Fahrenheit. Our server's demeanor was perfunctory, as he persistently avoided eye contact during his visits to our table, opting instead to survey the surrounding area with an air of distraction. The wine list was summarily removed from our possession prior to our having the opportunity to peruse it, and when queried about beverages, our response was met with an abruptness that bordered on incivility. It was patently evident that any minor infraction or misunderstanding would have been sufficient to trigger a defensive and unprofessional reaction from our server. Moreover, the culinary offerings were unimpressive, with the Caprese salad being merely adequate and the calamari manifesting a remarkable lack of flavor and an unpleasant texture that could be described as rubbery. Furthermore, no expression of gratitude or well wishes was extended to us upon our departure, which contributed to an overall atmosphere that can only be characterized as decidedly inhospitable. Needless to say, we shall not be inclined to revisit this establishment in the future, and it might be suggested that a modification of their moniker to Luna Grossa would be more apropos."

"My expectations were not adequately met, as the culinary offerings were merely palatable, and the dearth of gastronomic diversity was patently evident. The so-called'sushi' dishes, comprising chiefly of rice and vegetables, were a prime exemplification of this shortcoming. Consequently, I shall not be inclined to revisit this establishment in the future."

"Two stars, owing to an appreciable level of service quality, yet, alas, the sushi rice persistently manifests a deplorable tendency towards excessive moisture and disintegration, much to my dismay and disappointment, especially when compared to the superior offerings of Kabuki in California, which, I must say, never fails to impress in terms of sushi quality. Indeed, I have endeavored to provide this establishment with multiple opportunities to rectify this unfortunate shortcoming, only to be met with consistent disappointment. Therefore, I implore the sushi chefs here to take a cue from their West Coast counterparts and elevate the quality of their Alaskan rolls. Furthermore, the ambiance leaves much to be desired, with grimy table booths, unsightly walls, and an overall lack of cleanliness that extends even to the sunshades and table lights. One cannot help but wonder what factors contribute to such a state of affairs at this particular Kabuki location in Las Vegas."

Blah!  This was my 2nd visit to Bravo, 1st time I got a grilled chicken salad & had to send it back b/c the chicken was pink.  This time we started w/ the sangria rosa, way to sweet & was more like a daiquiri.  I got the chicken caprese & the chicken was very thin & like rubber, I could barely cut it, the orzo had zero seasoning.  So disappointed & we will not be going back!  Only reason for 2 stars instead of one was because we had good service.

This place use to be my go to\nFavorite bargain store however things have changed. Word got out and the eBay sellers have taken over this place. They are crazy!!! Trying to compete with them is impossible as they clearly are \"friends\" with those that work in the store in order to get first dibs. Last time I was there one of the eBay sellers had brought the store employees lunch, I mean come on where are your morals? I'd rather pay full price at Nordstrom.

\"Tourist trap\" pretty much sums up this restaurant with mediocre food, service and atmosphere. I don't mind paying more money for quality, but things were far from exceptional. A 12oz beer was $10, and steak and fries was $30. The girls were nice to look at, but nothing more.

Recently visited this establishment and was somewhat dismayed by the perceived diminution in the quality of the sushi offered, specifically in terms of its freshness; thus, I am rather ambivalent about the prospect of returning.

Do NOT order the wings. For $14 you get scrap parts of the wings, which they call \"lollipops\" and their way of trying to convince you that they make it easy for you to eat...YA, because there is no more meat for you to eat to even get messy. They basically strip off all the meat and leave you with the bone and the driest parts. There are no drums(middle pieces). Literally there is no meat. I had ordered the General So wings. Anyways I would assume the flavor will be amazing but it was terrible. It was too salty and tasted like sweet and sour sauce out of a packet from Panda Express. What does it take to be a good chef? Just making the food look pretty rather than taste good or even filling? I was basically served chicken bones cleaned up and presented to me on a plate with some sauce on the side. I am so offended that they could get away with serving this garbage and charging for it. What do they do with the actual meat? I don't know if I would be more upset if they threw it away or used it on another dish, which means they get paid twice for it.

"Although it possesses some appeal, I surmise that this establishment has plateaued in quality, as my experiences over the past several years have indicated a gradual decline in the culinary excellence of its offerings, despite the continued proficiency of its staff. Furthermore, I have noticed that the facilities are not consistently maintained, particularly during early morning hours. Notwithstanding, I have contributed substantially to this business and anticipated enhancements, but unfortunately, they have not materialized. My apologies to the proprietors."

This is a painful review as I really used to like this place.  Echoing most of the other reviews as well as mine, the service here is still horrible.  The portions  have gotten smaller and the prices higher.  The quality of the food, DOWNHILLL..

The Wor Wonton Soup, compared to what you get in ANY other place, it was the smallest pot I have ever seen not to mention they use imitation crab meat.

This is the second time in a row I have ordered the Spring Rolls and they are cooked on the outside but still cold/frozen on the inside.

Like I said I used to really like this place but after this visit with continued CRAPPY POOR service, NO communication between the staff and overall they just don't seem to really care about customer service or quality of the food any more.  The portions have gotten smaller and the value for the price along with the service, this place is NO LONGER a place I can recommend.

WORST PEDICURE EVER. I was just there this morning for a full set and a pedi. The man that did my full set was patient... he had to pry off an old set as I wanted a new fresh one... and I had just gotten a fill so it took a little bit of work. My only complaint with him is that he cut me pretty good with the drill and if it hurts this much now, boy is it gonna smart tomorrow. But I do love how my nails look. Thin and shaped perfectly. The pedi however is where things really head south. She did an ok job on the scrubbing, cutting and filing but that's where it ends. When it came time for the best part, the massage, it's like she was a zombie. She barely rubbed my feet, she rubbed my shins a little bit and my knees (???) but would NOT rub my feet. Thats the part that hurts after being on them all day!!  She squeezed them, pinched my toes, slapped the bottoms of my feet but still no massage. It was like she had no clue what she was doing. Definitely the strangest experience at a salon ever. The polish job was sloppy, polish on my cuticles that she didn't clean up. WEIRD WEIRD WEIRD.  Won't be going back.

"Arrived at this establishment subsequent to a disappointing dining experience at Mill's, whereupon we opted for the souvlaki, specifically one beef and one lamb variant. Unfortunately, the lamb offering lacked sufficient seasoning, resulting in an uninspired flavor profile, while the beef iteration, although boasting a more satisfactory taste, presented a rather chewy and difficult-to-consume texture. A portion of the beef required ejection into a napkin, much to our dismay, and we did not perceive the cost to be commensurate with the quality of the cuisine. The vegetables accompanying the meal also suffered from an absence of adequate seasoning, yielding an unremarkable gustatory experience. Observing the preferences of fellow patrons, who predominantly favored appetizers such as hummus, we cannot help but wonder if we overlooked a crucial aspect of the menu. Nonetheless, the service provided by our server was quite impressive and cordial, thereby earning an additional star in our assessment. However, considering the abundance of alternative dining options in the vicinity, we harbor doubts about our willingness to revisit this establishment."

Bouchon, an eatery which has secured a prominent position amongst my preferred dining establishments in Las Vegas, served as the setting for a regrettable incident during my most recent visit in March, an occurrence which left an indelible mark on my culinary experience; following my submission of a comment via their website, which, much to my dismay, remained unacknowledged, I have opted to voice my grievances on this platform as well. It is worth mentioning that Bouchon boasts a menu featuring delectable fare, albeit at a cost which may be considered somewhat elevated; however, the true source of my consternation stemmed from the exorbitant fee associated with their house water, specifically $7 per carafe, amounting to a staggering $21 for a mere three glasses. My incredulity at such an egregious attempt to exploit their clientele knows no bounds; needless to say, I did not request any extraordinary variety of water, merely articulating my desire for tap water when queried about my beverage preference. A modicum of solace was derived from the fact that the management elected to reconsider the cost, yet the entire episode proved nothing short of mortifying in the presence of my esteemed business associates.

Slow service. Waited over 2 hours for oil change. Watched others come and go. Clean place, friendly service but mismanaged. I will take my business elsewhere.\n\nSlow service. Waited over 2 hours for oil change. Watched others come and go. Clean place, friendly service but mismanaged. I will take my business elsewhere.

"It is worth recalling the instance when Pomo previously occupied a particular tourist-frequented, faux-Mediterranean space in the most affluent area of Scottsdale, where they offered an exceptional Napoletana pizza within an atmosphere characterized by pretentiousness and snobbishness.  I am delighted to convey that my experience at the downtown Pomo was vastly dissimilar.  

Following a brief walk from Cibo, where we enjoyed a passable pie (although, I remain unconvinced that Cibo lives up to its extensive acclaim), we entered Pomo, anticipating an ambiance permeated by stucco, affected accents, and photographs of Florence.  To our astonishment, the establishment manifested a contemporary aesthetic, complete with hipster-esque waitstaff.  A remarkable transformation had transpired!  

The primary issue I had with the original store had been effectively addressed.  This dining experience was shaping up to be quite satisfactory.  We subsequently placed our order for a pie, expecting the identical quality we had relished from the original Scottsdale oven.  

Alas, our expectations were not met.  The pizza lacked the appropriate level of soupiness.  Moreover, it failed to showcase the extraordinary flavor and meticulous attention to detail that rendered it marginally tolerable to endure Scottsdale's most self-absorbed clientele.  Regrettably, it was an underwhelming encounter.  

Subsequent to departing from this location, we continued our stroll down the street to La Piazza Locale (which also boasts VPN certification), where we savored our third and most satisfying pie of the evening.  I strongly advise you to follow suit.  La Piazza Locale has adopted a modern vibe, which harmoniously coexists with a superior Napoletana pie."

This establishment offered an adequate experience, primarily due to the presence of my convivial companions, with whom I celebrated a milestone anniversary. Our group's effervescent nature and enthusiasm facilitated an enjoyable evening, despite the somewhat unremarkable ambiance of the venue. However, I must emphasize that our delightful demeanor played a crucial role in our ability to relish ourselves, as the bar's aesthetic left much to be desired. In fact, the dimly lit passageway leading to the pizza parlor, replete with vintage arcade games and pinball machines, proved far more captivating than the main bar area. My attention was briefly diverted from the underwhelming surroundings by the novelty of the hidden eatery. Moving on, the multilevel bar featured a competent staff of mixologists, who presented a modicum of refinement amidst the generally lackluster atmosphere. A gleaming crystal fixture suspended above the spirits selection added a touch of elegance, yet the sprawling, shimmering curtain descending from the ceiling struck me as rather kitsch. The ornamentation resembled an oversized, tawdry version of the Mardi Gras trinkets dispensed for exposed bosoms, which unfortunately evoked a sense of dive-like quality. While Las Vegas offers numerous alternatives with unique charm, this particular establishment seemed tired and outdated. Despite my predilection for vintage appeal, the plastic, almost-iridescent adornment fell short of even a hint of glamour, leaving me unimpressed and eager to vacate the premises.

"MENU CHANGE: As an ardent devotee of the flatbread tapas during happy hour, I recently assembled a group of companions for a full-price dinner at this establishment, only to discover that the flatbread has been supplanted by what appears to be unaltered Matzoh Ball CRACKERS. Such a substitution would be readily apparent to any toddler familiar with the fundamental differences between crackers and bread. Furthermore, charging $10 for a few crackers accompanied by minuscule portions of hummus, bruschetta, and tapenade strikes me as rather exorbitant. However, upon observing my companion's struggle to consume the flatbread pizza due to the inability of CRACKERS to support the combined weight of pizza toppings and sauce, I realized the true extent of this transformation. A fellow patron politely inquired about the crackers, prompting the server to divulge that this alteration was, in fact, irreversible. In response, I have decided to permanently alter my dining habits by frequenting one of the numerous other exceptional gastro pubs in the area or simply crossing the street to savor the delectable cuisine at Firefly. Moreover, the freshly brewed beer available here fails to impress; many of the varieties possess a cloying, syrupy quality reminiscent of honey, which I find utterly unappealing."

1st time there, went to buy a toy helicopter for my child.  Didn't hold charge so we had to take it back for exchange and manager took care of us since I didn't save receipt.  While he was helping us he took on another task or decided to take a call rather then finishing our transaction.  The whole process took about 15 minutes since I had to wait for him to actually help but the actual exchange took 1 min.  He was still on the phone the entire time and customer service wasn't actually priority there.  Bad quality in toy helicopters and not very good customer service. Not a good 1st time experience.

"UPDATE: 

The proprietor exhibited a remarkable level of cordiality and affability in their interactions with me. 

Notwithstanding the fact that the estimate presented to my insurance provider was the most substantial among all the bidders, I was left with no choice but to decline the offer, as it entailed a comprehensive substitution of every exterior surface of my domicile, which, regrettably, was not covered by my insurance policy. 

Consequently, the corporation failed to secure my patronage due to the insurer's refusal to underwrite the entire replacement of the dwelling's siding."

Unless you procure a "Go Room", you are destined to encounter an unkempt, unhygienic environment. The establishment displays an utter lack of concern towards providing cleanliness and maintenance. We were compelled to relocate thrice due to the deplorable conditions. Upon voicing our grievances, another guest was allowed to check-in prior to our complete evacuation, sans any tangible resolution to our concerns.

The carpet was in a state of extreme soiling, exuding an unpleasant odor and exhibiting prominent stains and dirt throughout. The mere act of stepping into the bathtub after walking on the carpet resulted in visible black footprints. There exists no reasonable justification for such squalor, nor for disregarding it and introducing subsequent guests to these unsanitary environs.

The hotel boasts an aged ambiance, accompanied by an unmistakable musty scent. Efforts are underway to modernize and enhance the facilities; however, substantial progress remains to be made. In light of the abundance of appealing hotels in Las Vegas, it is perplexing why anyone would opt to patronize this particular establishment. This experience marked both my initial and final encounter with the Flamingo. The quality of service I received was appalling.

Notwithstanding, a solitary aspect of the Flamingo merits commendation. Junius Johnson, Jr., a dedicated server within the buffet, has devoted thirty years of service to the organization. His exceptional dedication to customer satisfaction warrants recognition. He exemplifies the epitome of excellent clientele service, and his expertise would greatly benefit the remainder of the staff. My sincere admiration is extended towards this individual.

"May 29th - A utterly abysmal experience ensued, characterized by an unpleasant throng and a dearth of suitable seating arrangements, with the sole exception being the picturesque panorama. It is abundantly clear that the ambiance was subpar, as evidenced by the minuscule dance floor and the absence of any semblance of comfort. Furthermore, the fact that entry was gratis serves as the sole redeeming quality of this woeful excursion."

" Allow me to preface my remarks by expressing my unwavering admiration for all things characterized by an abundance of cheesiness, as well as my increasing fascination with culinary establishments housed within mobile vehicles. Following several weeks of diligently monitoring Chedda's whereabouts via Instagram, I was ecstatic to finally have the opportunity to sample their offerings in person, particularly when they visited my local vicinity on record day. My expectations were elevated, to say the least. Unfortunately, the dining experience failed to meet my lofty standards, leaving me utterly disillusioned and questioning the wisdom of my decision to part with hard-earned currency to the tune of $19. The 'dirt bags' (a name which, in hindsight, proved to be a portent of the underwhelming nature of the meal) that my spouse and I independently ordered, were, to our chagrin, devoid of any discernible flavor profile and woefully lacking in the cheesy essence that I had eagerly anticipated. Akin to a culinary travesty, the burgers were of generous proportions, yet the buns were unpalatably dense and exhibited telltale signs of excessive browning, while the accompanying 'tots' (a designation that presumably alludes to their diminutive size) were unremarkable in taste and texture, and the sauce served alongside them was decidedly peculiar. In light of these shortcomings, I would be remiss in recommending this establishment to others."

"Upon my return to this establishment subsequent to my previous assessment, I opted to procure fuel for our leased vehicle, thus prompting me to pull up to a designated dispenser and alight from the automobile. Subsequently, I entered the building and approached the attendant, requesting $120 worth of regular gasoline on pump number two. The attendant confirmed the availability of the requested amount and further informed me that, in the event that I required either change or a receipt, I should return indoors. Following her instructions, I proceeded to insert the nozzle into the tank and elevate the nozzle holder on the pump. During the process of refueling, I engaged in conversation with my fellow travelers within the vehicle. Upon the cessation of the pump's operation at the $100.10 mark, I elected to return inside the building to obtain the remaining balance of my change. The attendant, upon presenting my change and receipt, informed me that the car wash located on the premises would be undergoing renovations and reopening in approximately one month's time, during which period they would also be installing updated gas pumps and an additional gas island. Expressing gratitude for her assistance, I conveyed my approval of the forthcoming improvements and indicated my intentions to visit the establishment on two more occasions."

I suppose when it's Gordon Ramsay's restaurant you expect more or better than average.
Like everyone else I have watched his shows and he seems to be a passionate chef.
There was a 45 minute wait to get a table- that's fair it was a Friday night so we went and killed some time until our text message informed us the table was ready. The staff uniforms are RIDICULOUS, so blatantly inappropriate, ill fitting and unflattering. Please change them- what a joke they are. The umbrella girls at motorpsorts events are wearing more clothes than the poor girls working at BURGR.
The burgers took another 45 minutes to come out and they were okay but not great. My husband got the truffle fries with the truffle aioli, which frankly all just tasted like garlic and not much else. I cook for my family most nights so the burgers were not earth shatteringly good or something I couldn't whip up in 15 minutes. i just expected more.
Well I did get more when the bill came $150 for 2 adults and 2 kids for a burger meal. 
We won't go back to BURGR, but there certainly is a slew of Gordon Ramsay restaurants to choose from in Las Vegas. He seems to be a hard worker and he's making hay while the sun shines.

Tequila Bar, I came here after reading reviews on yelp. I was looking for a cheap bar with decent drinks. When I saw they had a 128oz Blue Fishbowl for $20 I YELPed! But was disappointed to hear they had no 
"fishbowls" and would service it in two large cups. The two cups turned out to be 64oz Plastic pitchers, which was pretty fun. What wasn't fun was that 1. It has no "fishies" in it (like the picture) and 2. It was 90% Soda. Boo! But hey, for the novelty- the price wasn't bad!

The Nacho's at the next table did look pretty delectable, but I just came from a big dinner so I just ordered the "southwestern corn on the cob". I was curious. What made it southwestern? I should have known when I ordered it and the waiter said, corn- you want the corn? ok. And Corn is exactly what I got. Just boiled corn with a square of butter... for $3 - FAIL

"Four stars for the two appetizers (calamari and spicy shrimp), both of which were thoroughly enjoyed. The salad was also of superior quality. However, a solitary star must be assigned to the main entrees, as both mine and my spouse's were subpar. Specifically, my tilapia with asparagus suffered from an unfortunate combination of overcooked asparagus and a distinct lack of moisture in the fish. My spouse's pasta dish, unfortunately, did not meet expectations either. Although the children's meals were adequate, the overall atmosphere of the establishment was marred by various areas of disarray in both the waiting area and the dining area adjacent to the fireplace. Furthermore, the service was inconsistent, with our server displaying a regrettable lack of attention to detail while the waitress at the adjacent table demonstrated a commendable level of dedication to her patrons, necessitating our request for refreshments of bread, salad, and beverages from her as our own server was conspicuously absent. In conclusion, it is recommended that potential patrons seek alternative dining options in the Concord Mills area."

I have had the occasion to visit this dental facility on multiple occasions over the past year, and my experiences have been eerily reminiscent of those described by Joan C. in her scathing review. It appears that the hygienist has adopted an unscrupulous modus operandi, whereby they endeavour to coerce patients into acquiring supplementary dental services and routine cleanings, which are often superfluous and not necessarily conducive to their oral health. My personal experience with the deep-cleaning procedure, performed only two months prior, serves as a case in point; my gum health has ostensibly deteriorated since undergoing the treatment, leaving me feeling dubious about its efficacy. Furthermore, my sole encounter with the dentist was cursory, at best; she merely glanced at my X-rays, divulged the necessity of fillings, and displayed a marked lack of interest in engaging with me on a personal level. Her conduct was perfunctory, to say the least, and I have resolved to seek out a more personable and competent practitioner to address my future dental needs.

Dos Gringos is unquestionably reviving the trashy ambiance, and it appears that the entire trailer park concept has profoundly influenced them. Two notable examples can be used to illustrate this point. Firstly, the drinks provided by the establishment were conspicuously lacking in potency; despite the generous glassware, the alcohol pours were remarkably scanty. This prompted us to speculate that perhaps the vodka was the root cause of the issue, so we opted to switch to rum. However, it became apparent that the trailer park theme was merely an excuse for parsimony on the part of the establishment. Secondly, the pervasive stench of vomit emanating from the men's restroom exceeded the bounds of acceptability, taking the trailer park motif to an excessive extent. Following my notification to the staff regarding the presence of vomit on a men's urinal, it remained unattended for an hour, which was quite disconcerting. These factors evoke a sense of nostalgia for the carefree days of yore. Admittedly, the atmosphere was enlivened by the DJ and the crowd, rendering the venue an ideal spot for daytime revelry and canine companionship. However, the prevalence of regurgitated matter and mediocre beverages somewhat dampened the spirits. As an aside, I must confess that the combination of these factors rendered me less than eager to sample their acclaimed tacos.

"While our experience at this establishment was by no means extraordinary, we did encounter certain aspects that left much to be desired. Specifically, our server, though adequate in their duties, failed to exhibit the warmth and attention to detail that one might expect from a truly exceptional dining experience. It appeared that their primary focus was on catering to the male patrons who were engrossed in the sporting events being broadcast, which unfortunately resulted in a lack of consideration towards our table. Furthermore, the gratuities seemed to be allocated in a manner that was disproportionate to the level of service provided. As for the culinary offerings, we were underwhelmed by the quality of the crispy tacos, which were merely passable. In light of the numerous superior dining options available in the surrounding area, it is unlikely that we will return to this restaurant in the future."

One of the most unfortunate coffee establishments I have had the misfortune of visiting is this particular Crazy Mocha location. Convenience played a significant role in my decision to patronize this establishment, as it was situated in close proximity to the Cultural Trust, where I had a class. Unfortunately, my experiences at this coffee shop were marred by a series of unpleasant encounters. Firstly, the chai tea was excessively sweet and lacked the depth of flavor that one would expect from a well-crafted chai. It was almost as if they had merely added milk to black tea and neglected to incorporate any discernible spices. This was a profound disappointment, as I had been eagerly anticipating a flavorful and invigorating beverage. Furthermore, the coffee was consistently brewed to a weakness that bordered on insipidity. I suspect that the coffee had been left to sit for an extended period before I received it, as it lacked the rich, bold flavor that I have come to expect from a freshly brewed cup of coffee. In fact, the second time I ordered coffee from this establishment, it was so unpalatable that I was compelled to discard it after only a few sips. The service at this coffee shop was adequate, but it fell short of being exceptional. While the staff was not unfriendly, their pace was somewhat leisurely, and they failed to demonstrate the kind of attentive, personalized service that one might hope to encounter at a reputable coffee shop. However, I must admit that the Wi-Fi connection was quite reliable, which proved to be a welcome consolation in light of the subpar quality of the beverages.

Was a huge fan of subway but they got rid of my favorite sandwitch chicken pizziola. I was able to still get it but they said that they couldnt anymore. I had to find a new fav but would like it more if they would bring it back. Most the subways in las vegas favor their own people or if you speak the language. Other than that could be better.

I will eat here when a friend insists, but I think almost every time I've eaten here, I have gotten diarrhea.  And the food isn't worth the diarrhea.  Its kind of bland.  And its overpriced.  Just my opinion though.  I know lots of people are ga-ga over this place.

They must have erroneously placed the refrigerated poultry intended for the grilled chicken salad within my sandwich, while the fries were merely lukewarm, bordering on unpleasantly tepid, in one of the two meals; however, the service was amicable and I do appreciate the novel choices that align with the contemporary inclination towards gourmet fast food, such as brioche buns and pretzel buns, as well as the availability of a purported "fresh lemonade" and various salad options.

Had fried tofu, fried pork, peanut butter dumplings and eggplant. The fried foods were dry and tough. Pretty much every dish here can be found in a much better version elsewhere in Montreal. Only try this if you're desperate for Chinese. (The pickings are admittedly slim in this neighbourhood.)

"Underwhelming experience, to say the least, characterized the visit to this establishment, situated in Casa Grande, on a Thursday evening, when, allegedly, the premises were slated to remain operational until the witching hour of midnight. However, it appeared that the management had chosen to cease operations ahead of schedule, as the server informed us that it was 'last call' at approximately 9:30 PM, despite the fact that our party had only recently arrived and had every intention of lingering for an extended period of time. This turn of events was, to put it mildly, rather vexing. Furthermore, the selection of beers available left much to be desired, with only a scant few offerings managing to surpass the threshold of mediocrity, which, regrettably, catered to the unrefined tastes of the predominant patronage. As an individual whose predilections do not necessarily align with those of a hophead, I yearned for a more diverse array of options to slake my thirst."

"MONTE CARLO, a prestigious name brand, conjuring images of luxury and refinement. However, our experience was anything but satisfactory. Despite requesting a non-smoking room, we were erroneously assigned a smoking room, which furthermore, had an evident fissure on the carpet adjacent to the window. The state of the room was also subpar, with evident signs of neglect and disrepair. The ambiance of the hotel was uninviting, exacerbated by its advanced age and apparent lack of maintenance. I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this establishment, as it failed to meet even the most basic expectations. The customer service we encountered was also inadequate, prompting me to question the quality control measures implemented by MGM Mirage. If you seek a less than satisfactory lodging experience, and a taste of what can be described as 'BARFED OUT EUROPE', then perhaps the Monte Carlo might suffice. However, I must emphasize that this hotel falls short of even the most lenient standards, and its sub-par quality is reflective of a deeper issue within the organization."

This was the first groomer we tried out in the Phoenix area. They had good reviews on yelp and good prices so we gave them a try. I was not impressed and left really missing our groomer back in CA. I asked for my dog's tail to get special attention. She was given back to me with matts still in her tail and her face hadn't been cleaned thoroughly. Pretty disappointed will not be returning.

I really hate cold buffet food. Nd today all items were cold. Maybe we arrived too soon after opening but we had to leave and I asked for a refund. I was given a gift card for a return visit which was nice.
