The thermally-administered peanut butter and jelly cake, characterized by its conspicuously fluid peanut butter and arid, dense texture, was presented at an elevated temperature. Consequently, the inherent viscosity of the peanut butter rendered it somewhat challenging to consume, while the cake's desiccated nature made it rather difficult to chew. Furthermore, the flavor of the jelly, which was situated at the core of the culinary creation, was only accessible upon penetrating the center of the cake. It is worth mentioning that the warm grape jelly, owing to its unremarkable taste, did not contribute significantly to the overall gastronomical experience. Lastly, the latte, with its unexceptional flavor profile, proved to be unremarkable in the grand scheme of things.

I usually like this place but was a little disappointed this last time. I tried the eggs Benedict and did not like their own made hollandaise sauce. Next time I'm sticking with my usual blueberry pancakes. Boyfriend liked his meal (he had the wolf pack). Service was good. We got in quickly for a busy Memorial Day Monday morning. Unfortunately we both got sick later in the day and it was the only meal we had eaten so I'm going to be a little hesitant next time I think about going to over easy.
The new owners are wrecking this place. Just returned to Montreal for a short vacation and the staff are way overworked. Won't be going back - it's better in my memories. The food has gone down hill.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
 That's how I would summarize my visit to Portillo's. Despite the high expectations built up by the extensive promotion, the actuality fell short in multiple aspects. Firstly, the robust exterior of the hot dogs did not align with my personal preference, and the flavors failed to impress me as well. It is my conviction that Portillo's reputation plays a more significant role in its popularity than the culinary quality itself.

"I have had the privilege of partaking in the culinary offerings of this esteemed establishment on two separate occasions, with the initial visit being particularly enjoyable due to the exceptional quality of the service and the delectable Macaroni and Cheese dish. Unfortunately, my second experience was marred by a series of unfortunate events, beginning with a telephone conversation at 5:54 PM, during which I inquired about the availability of happy hour specials and was misinformed by an employee that they were indeed available until 7:00 PM. Upon arriving at the establishment merely ten minutes later, I was dismayed to discover that this information was incorrect, and that happy hour had already concluded. This sequence of events has led me to deduce that the quality of service and communication within this establishment is inconsistent, thus warranting a rating of two stars."

"It is patently evident that this establishment does not serve the optimal brunch experience in Charlotte, owing to its diminutive size and location within a commercial complex teeming with families accompanied by their dual-stroller conveyances and vociferous progeny. Despite the culinary offerings being passable, my sentiments align with disappointment and regret regarding the considerable distance traversed specifically for this meal."

I was definitely not impressed with this restaurant. There wasn't enough variety and my street noodle dish was subpar at best. It lacked any wow factor. The only dish I would recommend is the steamed pork bun. Literally the only thing I will go in there for. Otherwise, I would not suggest going here. It is overhyped.

I went to Caramel because I heard that it was great. It was a nice, simple, very small lounge. I was surprised at how small it was. I had the Oreo martini, which cost $20. I could care less about drink prices, and don't mind paying a lot for drinks in Vegas, but $20 was a bit much for a so-so martini with Oreo crumbs at the bottom. Or possibly Hydrox - who knows?\n\nLove the Bellagio, not wild about Caramel. Take the ten steps to the Sports Bar, put $20 in the video poker machine and get a free martini instead. The bartenders were much friendlier at the sports bar, too.

"I visited this establishment on a Saturday evening, anticipating an enjoyable experience, particularly since Kaskade was slated to perform. However, upon arriving, I encountered an extensive queue for those who possessed tickets, which proved to be quite frustrating. After waiting for approximately an hour and thirty minutes, I finally reached the entrance, only to discover that the club had already reached its maximum capacity. Consequently, the dance floor was closed, and there were no available tables. This led me to ponder the reasoning behind allowing additional patrons to enter when there was no sufficient space or accommodations for them. Security personnel continued to urge individuals to proceed forward, yet there was no obvious destination. The club's diminutive size was another contributing factor to the overcrowding issue. Moreover, the entryway was situated beneath a narrow staircase, which added to the overall unpleasantness of the experience. Despite these drawbacks, Kaskade's performance was impressive, albeit brief."

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are of satisfactory quality, however, my overall assessment of this restaurant would be significantly higher if it were not for the consistent negative interactions I have had with the staff during my two visits. Specifically, the service has been subpar, with prolonged waiting periods for food delivery and an absence of attention to detail in terms of ensuring a satisfying dining experience. Furthermore, despite expressing my concerns to the manager and receiving assurances of a complimentary gift card for a future visit, such a gesture never materialized. Therefore, while the food may be adequate, the poor service and lack of follow-through on commitments made by the staff preclude me from patronizing this restaurant again."

"I have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment, as well as the one situated in Phoenix, off Ray and the 10. My companion possesses a membership at this facility, thus we have become gym companions and are striving to motivate one another to attend more frequently. Occasionally, an individual requires an additional stimulus to propel them towards their fitness objectives! 

This gym offers a fundamental, no-frills atmosphere for those seeking a straightforward workout experience. The cost is approximately $10 per month, or for a slightly higher fee of $20 per month, patrons can enjoy access to multiple locations and bring an unrestricted number of guests. 

I am experiencing some difficulty in determining whether to assign a 2-star or 3-star rating to this venue. As a member of 24 Hour Fitness for several years, I am accustomed to their basic amenities, which are sufficient for my needs and offered at a reasonable price. However, my current gym features a sauna, basketball court, various classes, a pool, and other amenities that Planet Fitness lacks. The absence of a sauna is particularly bothersome, and the presence of a loud, flashing alarm that sounds when a heavy weight is dropped, grunting occurs, or significant effort is exerted seems counterintuitive to the gym's purported judgment-free environment. The questionable necessity of this feature remains a mystery to me."

Very RUDE management- we had to wait over an HOUR to get our car out of valet while we watched people leave left and right...we mentioned this to several people - we were offered many excuses to find out in the end that they completely misplaced our CAR! I would have been satisfied if they had offered us a drink- our table spent over $200 on our dinner- we didn't even get an apology...I wrote a letter and everything!\n\nThe waitstaff was friendly- the meal was ok - nothing special considering Charlotte has plenty of great restaurants . Restaurants have a lot to do with relationships- and they killed mine with this one.  Bottom line the food wasn't THAT good to warrant my return...

"I hereby retract my previous statement regarding II Vinao's alleged mismanagement, as it appears that the establishment was merely experiencing an isolated incident of subpar service; the proprietor has since reached out to me in quest of specifics to facilitate the rectification of any issues, demonstrating their commitment to providing exceptional patron experiences. Consequently, we intend to revisit the restaurant in the near future and bestow upon it a well-deserved five-star evaluation. Rest assured, I shall keep all interested parties apprised of any developments."

Should change the name to Lobster Mehhh. I felt like I was at the food court in the mall when i saw how this place was set up. It would have been better if it were since the mall has more seating.\nHad the lobster roll combo that came with fries and a drink. The Lobster roll was not a traditional one in my eyes. It was filled with plenty of lobster but was not tossed in the mayo/scallion mix a Maine lobster roll would have. It seemed to have a vinegar based medley that overwhelmed any on the natural flavors. The item that was the best was the fries, theses were actually very tasty. The lobster mac and cheese was so-so. A few lobster chunks on top but none throughout, not worth the $9.95. Definitely not returning!!

"Culinary offerings at this establishment are satisfactory, albeit with some caveats. Specifically, hot dishes tend to arrive at one's table at a temperature that is less than optimal, which can be somewhat disappointing. Furthermore, management has seen fit to remove certain items from the menu, a decision that is lamentable as said items were of superior quality. Additionally, the ambiance is not conducive to a tranquil dining experience due to an excessive level of noise pollution, both from the televisions and patrons gathered at the bar area, who often engage in boisterous conversations. Moreover, there appears to be a lack of seating arrangements designated for those seeking a more serene repast. According to our server, this state of affairs is a common occurrence, which unfortunately precludes us from frequenting the premises."

I guess I just don't get it.

It's advertised as a Madison favorite.  I hear people talking about going there all the time.  But the food just didn't leave me with a great impression.

The chips and salsa are great.  I suppose that's one thing that's pretty tough to get wrong.  But my burrito came out rather bland, as did my daughter's quesadilla.  Unless there was a kitchen mixup, my "hot" salsa sure did taste like mild.  

The service was good, the bar selection is solid, and the atmosphere is a neat one.  The food, however, just doesn't do anything for me.

"In the event that you were oblivious to its location, you would undoubtedly overlook it. The dining area is rather meager, comprising of unadorned tables and booths, with an open layout reminiscent of a deli. 

Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the chicken parmesan sub, as it had been enthusiastically endorsed by various Yelp reviewers. Although my particular specimen was slightly arid, it still qualified as a passable sandwich. However, I harbor some skepticism regarding whether I would opt to order it again in the future. The fries served alongside it adhered to the conventional crinkle-cut template. 

In summary, this establishment serves as a suitable alternative to adjacent fast-food restaurants, yet it does not quite warrant a special trip."

SAD! Wanted to like this place! Just got back from my first (and probably) last time to Elliot & Co. . . . . NOT worth the money - even with yelp discount!
  Services Recieved :  Haircut and a Shave Package  (getting rid of my beard!)
     First off let me say the haircut was/is very good (hence the chance, albeit slim, of a return) However,
 SHAVE LEFT MUCH TO BE DESIRED.....LIKE A CLOSE SHAVE FOR INSTANCE!!!  When i got home girlfriend and i noticed 1/4 inch hairs in spots on neck (must have missed it with razor?!) and stubble that i was able to remove with a simple disposable razor (which cost A LOT less).  All the fluff was nice; the towels and oils but at the end of the day the shave just wasn't there.

Bottom Line: Nice People, nice environment, good haircuts TERRIBLE SHAVE!

"Sally's Beauty Supply, an establishment purveying an array of products catering to the beauty and personal care needs of its clientele, boasts a considerable inventory of merchandise. However, it is unfortunate that the quality of customer service provided by the staff does not align with the abundance of goods available for purchase. While the manager demonstrated a welcoming demeanor and acknowledged my presence, the remaining personnel appeared to lack a sincere enthusiasm for assisting me in a courteous and friendly manner, their countenances bereft of the warmth and geniality that a simple smile or display of passion for their work could convey."

"Today, I partook in a culinary excursion to a local establishment with my kin, whereupon my sister-in-law, an ardent devotee of this particular venue, insisted on dining there, owing to its reputation for serving delectable fare. Despite its diminutive size, an extensive queue had formed outside, which we dutifully joined. Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the mixed plate, a medley of disparate proteins, comprising a beef, chicken, and fish. Although the beef, enrobed in a rich sauce, lacked discernible flavor, the chicken, a de-boned thigh, was cooked to perfection, boasting tenderness and moisture. The fish, however, was somewhat underwhelming, prompting me to crave additional poultry. The serving size was generous, surpassing my capacity for consumption, leaving me with a lingering sense of dissatisfaction. Notwithstanding, I am inclined to sample their Mami or Udon noodles during a future visit. I offer a tentative endorsement of this eatery, without enthusiasm, as it does not warrant a special journey, but I would not rule out a return engagement."

I stayed at the Excalibur the last time I was in Vegas because I was meeting friends and this is where they chose to stay. Ugh. I do not know what is wrong with them. This hotel/casino is not cool. It was very expensive (160$ a night... what?) and the first room we went into smelled like someone poured water all over the floor and let mold grow for a few weeks. After over an hour, they gave us another room which was fine, but still overpriced. The casino is in a bad location, so far from the central strip. Who wants to go to New york New york? cuz that's about the only place that is close to this hotel, oh and the MGM. All of the food in this casino is bad. Overall, I was not happy that we had to stay at this hotel. Never again.
Not very impressive ... tables and floor dirty .. I spilled accidentally and staff watched as I cleaned up with no offer of help.   Left sticky residue and nobody would wipe down properly

"The ambiance was aesthetically pleasing and striking, fostering an environment conducive to culinary indulgence. I opted for the Chicken Meatloaf, which proved to be a delectable selection, boasting a rich, savory flavor profile. In contrast, my companion's Chicken Royale failed to meet expectations, lacking zest and leaving much to be desired in terms of gastronomic satisfaction. Notably, the accompanying vegetables, specifically the green beans and carrots, demonstrated superior taste and appeal. 

Although the server exhibited attentiveness upon delivery of the meals, his presence prior to that was regrettably lacking. 

Given the inconsistent quality of the dining experience, it is unlikely that I shall return."

What a dissapointment when you see such an exciting menu, unable to make a choice then you are served frozen hashbrowns and low quality ingrediants.  The chicken fried steak was consumed by a porky/ smoke flavor. The service was friendly and charming but I can't get over the dissapointment in food quality.

It is partially attributable to my own culpability, stemming from my failure to peruse the midday repast menu prior to my arrival, that I experienced such profound disenchantment with the meal; however, I must confess that my expectations were unquestionably elevated due to the effusive endorsement I received, which prompted me to visit this establishment with great anticipation, particularly since it offered an array of delectable delights, including tapas, bouillabaisse, Spanish, Italian, and French cuisine, all of which I eagerly anticipated savoring. Alas, my enthusiasm was quickly extinguished upon beholding the menu, which featured an uninspired assortment of sandwiches, a far cry from the sophisticated fare I had envisioned. My family and I opted for a Cuban and chicken sandwich, selections that, quite frankly, struck me as rather pedestrian given the restaurant's reputation for gastronomic excellence. My disappointment was further compounded by the fact that Las Vegas purports to be a city that never sleeps, where one can ostensibly find sustenance at any hour. Consequently, I felt not only disheartened but also somewhat embarrassed for having brought my loved ones to this particular dining establishment, which, in my opinion, failed to live up to its potential by neglecting to include even a few of its hallmark dishes, albeit in diminutive portions, on its luncheon menu.

We have recently acquired a residential property in Mesa, Arizona, which features an evaporative cooling system, and we have been informed by the previous proprietors that the construction of Tempe Town Lake has significantly diminished the duration during which the cooling apparatus can be effectively utilized, specifically owing to the augmented humidity levels in the surrounding atmosphere, and furthermore, the barrier that facilitates the impoundment of water has become compromised, resulting in the absence of a lake at present, which constitutes a negative aspect.

"Although my expectations were elevated due to the favorable reviews I had heard, my dining experience at this establishment ultimately fell short of my lofty standards. Despite the prolonged delay in being seated, which seemed to be a recurring theme, I opted to partake in their morning repast. While the cuisine was certainly passable, it failed to elicit any particularly remarkable sentiments on my part, and the atmosphere was regrettably characterized by overcrowding. In light of these factors, I would have to say that my preference would lie with the comparable venue situated nearby, specifically the Gilbert House."

Sunday brunch, is just average, nothing special. As for the selection I felt it lacked in variety...basic breakfast foods and flatbread pizzas. (Upstream set the bar high for brunch) the food wasn't cold but  could've been hotter. Previous reviews said the beer was watered down, it must be a theme w/their alcohol selections b/c the Bloody Mary was watered down as we'll, I'm not sure if it's the mix they used...have definitely had better.  The atmosphere is cool and it was packed, but just don't see what all the hype is about.

Located within the esteemed Golden Nugget on Fremont Street in the historic downtown district of Las Vegas, this establishment purports to offer an array of delectable beverages and culinary delights. However, upon personal inspection, it is my duty to reveal that the quality of the fare served herein leaves much to be desired. Despite the palatable nature of the potations, the comestibles unfortunately failed to meet expectations, with the fish and chips being excessively oily and the so-called 'tempura' lobster bearing a striking resemblance to a funnel cake. In light of these findings, it is my recommendation that discerning patrons seek alternative dining options in the vicinity, which not only offer superior quality but also present a more economical choice. Indulge in the extravagance of Sin City, my friends, for the experience is fleeting and the memories shall linger forevermore!

"My affection towards their burgers is nonexistent, as my culinary preferences are not adequately fulfilled by their offerings. Although I do appreciate the diversity of sauces and the quality of their French fries, my satisfaction with the dining experience is significantly diminished due to the prolonged waiting period for the food to be prepared and served, as well as the fact that my burger, which was cooked to a medium level of doneness, was unfortunately overcooked. Furthermore, my expectations for a superior dining experience were not met, as I have previously enjoyed more delectable burgers at other establishments, such as Serendipity, which does not specialize in burgers. Therefore, I must conclude that the restaurant's burgers are not worth the high price, and instead, I would recommend purchasing a frozen turkey patty from a local grocery store and heating it in a microwave oven for a more satisfying and cost-effective meal. However, I do acknowledge that the restaurant offers a diverse selection of flavors and cuts for their fries, which may appeal to certain individuals with unique tastes."

"My experience at Buraka fell short of my expectations regarding the quality and variety of Ethiopian cuisine. Although the menu offered a reasonable selection of vegetarian options, which I appreciated, the overall scope of dishes was limited. Furthermore, the absence of individual sampler platters, with the exception of a pricey two-entree combination, was disappointing. 

 My order consisted of a combination of misir wot and black beans, both described as spicy. However, upon emphasizing my preference for pungent flavors to the server, I was assured that the dishes would deliver an adequate level of heat. Unfortunately, they did not live up to my expectations in terms of spiciness or flavor profile. In fact, the injera, typically a highlight of my Ethiopian dining experiences, was unremarkable. 

 Midway through the meal, the server offered hot sauce as a means of enhancing the flavor, but I believe that the dishes themselves should possess inherent flavor without relying on supplementary condiments. 

 While the ambiance was pleasant and outdoor seating was available, my underwhelming experience at Buraka leads me to conclude that it is not worth revisiting in the future."

"Well, for starters, I must admit that I am not particularly fond of the Beatles (Yes, we do, in fact, exist), and thus, I did not have high expectations for this performance. Furthermore, our seats were only moderately decent, and the sheer magnitude of the venue, coupled with the 360-degree configuration of the stage, made it challenging to fully appreciate the experience. Additionally, Cirque's attempt to compensate for this by incorporating supplementary elements on either side of the primary stage only served to create an overwhelming sensory assault. While the soundtrack was undoubtedly impressive, given its ingenious reinterpretation of timeless classics, the acrobatic feats themselves were merely adequate, failing to live up to the exceptional standards set by other, more remarkable productions. My companion, however, appeared to derive some measure of enjoyment from the spectacle, although my own assessment yielded a less than enthusiastic verdict; hence, I would recommend this show primarily to ardent Beatles devotees, while those who are fervent admirers of Cirque's artistry might find superior alternatives."

This is a review of the meeting facilities, and NOT the rooms.  I have no experience of the guest rooms at this location.

I attended a two-day training here and was largely disappointed by the meeting facilities lack of power outlets in the space we were using.  The training was a computer-related course and all of the attendees were forced to fight over probably five power outlets. 

Additionally, the first day of our training there was some sort of awful plumbing problem occurring in the building that caused the entire place to smell of sewer gas and sewage.   The property was not able to combat the smell and we all just had to endure it until the cause was resolved.  Gross.

"Underwhelmed by the dining experience, we opted for the kare-kare, only to be dismayed by the lackluster quality of the vegetables, which were unfortunate soggy, despite the tenderness of the meat. However, the lechon kawali proved to be a saving grace, as it was accompanied by a delectable gravy dip and steaming hot rice. Notwithstanding, we may consider giving them another opportunity, taking into account the unfavorable circumstances of the air conditioning malfunctioning on an exceptionally sweltering day, with temperatures soaring to a record high of 122 degrees Fahrenheit."

Now that I have successfully captured your undivided attention, allow me to elaborate upon and provide clarification regarding the 2 Star accolade that was bestowed upon this particular lodging establishment. Firstly, it is imperative to acknowledge the truly exceptional quality of the guest rooms, which boast impressive design elements and offer breathtaking panoramic vistas. Furthermore, the architectural style of the building itself is undeniably captivating and aesthetically pleasing. Additionally, the tariffs associated with these accommodations are deemed reasonable and accessible to a wide range of patrons. Nonetheless, it is crucial to scrutinize and investigate the purported complimentary airport shuttle service, as its utility and practicality are called into question. Specifically, the scheduling of these pickups appears to be quite sporadic and unpredictable, often resulting in extended periods of waiting time for arriving guests. In fact, it is not uncommon for individuals to endure delays of two to three hours, which can be particularly problematic for those with tight travel itineraries. Moreover, the alternative transportation option of hailing a taxi cab comes with a substantial price tag of $40, exclusive of gratuity. It is essential to exercise caution when encountering any advertised freebies or special offers associated with the resort, as they frequently come with strings attached or prove to be misleading. For instance, the supposed complimentary breakfast buffet is, in reality, a severely limited 2 for 1 arrangement, hardly justifying the prolonged wait times. Similarly, the pool area, touted as a serene and picturesque oasis, is inaccessible to guests during the months of March, rendering it unavailable for a significant portion of the year. Lastly, the Hostile Grape wine bar, an establishment that ostensibly offers a diverse selection of vintages, is regrettably closed three days a week, further limiting its appeal to potential patrons. Those seeking a more fulfilling and convenient shopping experience would be well-advised to consider renting a vehicle, as the resort's remote location makes it challenging to access nearby retail centers without one. In light of these factors, it may be wise to explore alternative accommodations such as Green Valley Ranch or South Point, which seem to offer a more comprehensive array of amenities and services.

"My desire is to confer an increased number of celestial bodies upon this establishment, as I harbor a profound fondness for it.  The quality of the service was adequate, while the carne asada tacos possessed a certain je ne sais quoi that rendered them quite palatable.  Furthermore, the cost was reasonable, and they offered an array of fermented beverages.  The ambiance was agreeable, with a well-appointed interior and a prime location.  However, my enthusiasm was somewhat tempered by the state of disarray that permeated the premises.  If one cannot or will not uphold the cleanliness of the dining area and restrooms, it is reasonable to assume that the kitchen, where food is prepared and cooked, may also be subject to a similar lack of attention.  Alas, our visit did not coincide with an anomalous day for the restaurant, which made the experience all the more regrettable."

Hash House A Go Go in the Plaza is a family friendly diner with portions meant for sumo wrestlers and competitive eaters.  The food pile is truly a spectacle in a place where quantity seems more important than quality.

We tried the Fried Chicken and Bacon Waffles, the Andy's Sage Fried Chicken Benedict, and a House Salad.  

The Fried Chicken and Waffles was average.  The chicken was crispy enough, but wasn't juicy and didn't have a lot of seasoning.  The waffles didn't have a bacon-y flavor, we wished they had just given us some strips of bacon instead.

The Fried Chicken Benedict was like three separate dishes piled into one--literally stacked right on top of each other.  One dish would be fried chicken and mashed potatoes, another would be a biscuit with gravy, and the last would be an eggs and bacon scramble with spinach, tomato, and mozzarella.  With all that on one plate you can't really distinguish one flavor from another, but you can make every bite different.

The House Salad was the standard bag mix of iceberg lettuce, nothing special.

If you do want to try Hash House A Go Go split a plate with someone and come for a true diner experience.

My second most unpleasant crepe experience thus far has been had at this establishment. Upon ordering a cheese and prosciutto crepe, I was presented with a remarkably thick and doughy specimen, bordering on the consistency of a pancake. While I generally enjoy doughy crepes, these particular ones seemed to lack the delicate, flaky texture that I have come to expect from such culinary offerings. Furthermore, the temperature of the crepe was not particularly warm, which only served to exacerbate my disappointment. The prosciutto, too, was problematic in its excessive thickness and overpowering flavor. The utensils provided, flimsy forks that they were, proved woefully inadequate in facilitating the cutting of said prosciutto, making for a most frustrating endeavor. 
 My significant other fared slightly better with their vegetable crepe, consisting of mushrooms and spinach, yet even this offering was afflicted with the same unfortunate doughiness as my own. While not utterly devoid of redeeming qualities, this crepe was largely forgettable, save for the fact that it served as a welcome respite from the otherwise underwhelming experience that was had at this venue. 
 The coffee, regrettably, lived down to my expectations, being quite unimpressive in both taste and quality. Suffice it to say, I shall not be returning to this establishment in the future. 
 Notwithstanding the dearth of parking options in the vicinity, this location does boast the advantage of a sizable parking garage, situated within close proximity to the eatery itself. On our initial visit, the crowd was relatively sparse, though upon our return, the scene had transformed into one of considerable bustle and activity. The reasons behind this sudden influx of patrons remain something of a mystery, though it is conceivable that the novelty of the staff's stereotypically Parisian attire may play some part in the restaurant's enduring popularity.

"It has been a year since I first visited this establishment, accompanied by two acquaintances, and we opted for the walk-up counter due to the approximately sixty-minute waiting period for a table indoors. We ordered modest servings of frozen hot chocolate. Upon sampling the beverage, I must admit that I was underwhelmed by its quality. It had a flavor reminiscent of a chocolate shake with sprinkles, which led me to speculate whether the experience might have been enhanced had we placed our order from within the establishment itself. My second visit took place in the company of associates who were partaking in a meal. Their food appeared appetizing, and the portions seemed adequate. During my third visit, in the presence of my sibling and other acquaintances, we sampled frozen hot chocolate and frozen white hot chocolate. Unfortunately, my recollection of the portion sizes and quality of these beverages was inadequate, prompting my sibling to order a large serving of frozen hot chocolate, which proved to be excessive. The service during this visit was satisfactory, yet the cashier demonstrated some sluggishness in processing transactions and placing orders on the rail. Moreover, the personnel preparing the drinks seemed overburdened throughout our stay, perhaps indicating that the establishment was understaffed. Notwithstanding, I may return and persevere through the delay to partake in a meal inside."

Should have never changed the recipes. I have been back twice since new ownership. I have to say I will give them one more shot. The place has lost the touch of service that was given. I feel while talking with workers that they can do better since everyone was really nice.

The Peking duck was good- but it's hard to mess that up. The walnut prawns should be labeled dessert as it's so sweet- likely can cause a diabetic to go into shock. The crab was like licking an ashtray full of garlic and was overdone. 

Service was nice. Gentlemen. Too bad they got stuck at a crap restaurant. 

This morning I'm paying the price for eating this stuff.

"Following an annual subscription to Bountiful Baskets, I have reached the conclusion that a downgrade is imperative. While the quality was never exceptional, there has been a noticeable decrease in the overall standard of the produce provided. A significant portion of the fruits and vegetables included in the baskets have been found to spoil rapidly, often within a mere couple of days. Furthermore, I have grown weary of the consistent inclusion of subpar items such as unripe apples and wilted romaine lettuce. Notably, a recent purchase of a case of honeycrisp apples, offered at a discounted rate, proved to be a disappointment. The apples were diminutive in size and exhibited signs of spoilage after only a few days, which may have resulted from my failure to promptly remove them from their packaging and inspect them for any defects. It appears that Bountiful Baskets prioritizes quantity over quality, which aligns with their fundamental philosophy. However, I have become disenchanted with this approach and am now compelled to explore alternative options, such as a Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) program."

"A protracted waiting period of sixty minutes ensued before we were able to secure a table, during which time we had the opportunity to appreciate the picturesque surroundings and relish the welcoming ambiance. Unfortunately, this was where the positive aspects of our experience came to an abrupt conclusion. The blueberry muffins, while visually appealing, were regrettably overcooked and lacking in moisture. The biscuits and gravy, although palatable, would have greatly benefited from the addition of either sausage or bacon to elevate them to a truly satisfying level. The Carne asada burrito, a dish that typically boasts bold flavors, was disappointingly unremarkable. However, the sandwich crafted from French toast, while not exceptional by any means, was the most enjoyable aspect of our meal. Despite these shortcomings, we shall return to the Perch, albeit with tempered expectations."

Ok this place just wasnt funny.  The only good thing about it was the opener.  If it hadn't been for him I might have walked out.  It was also $39 for a one hour show, which seems steep.  In new york its $25 and is more like 2 & 1/2 hours.  The worst part about it was the waitstaff.  Maybe if they had let me get a slight buzz I would have had a better time.  Most comedy clubs have a 2 drink minimum, but I swear this place seemed to have a 2 drink MAXIMUM.  The waitress gave us the first round and didn't come back anywhere in sight for at least 40 minutes.  Plus, we were paying cash and she wanted us to pay each time she brought the drinks, then stood right in front of us so we couldn't see the show while she was demanding the money.  I mean, it was a wednesday night so maybe I shouldn't have expected much, but for this kind of experience I would say the ticket should be more like half of what we paid.  my advice is to wait for a weekend for comedy in this town

Moe's culinary offerings can be described as unremarkable and uninspired, failing to differentiate themselves from their competitors such as Qdoba and Chipotle. The fare provided was fresh and palatable, yet lacked any extraordinary qualities or distinguishing characteristics. The burritos were diminutive in stature, with meager fillings that left much to be desired. 
  The pricing of their menu items was patently disproportionate to the quantity and quality of the food served. Specifically, the cost of an original-sized burrito, which was excessive in relation to its modest proportions and scant contents, was $7.50. Furthermore, the price of a small soft drink was $2.50, which seemed exorbitant given the absence of complimentary refills. 
  Notwithstanding these issues, each order did come with an accompaniment of chips and salsa. The chips possessed an agreeable texture and flavor, while the salsa was merely adequate. 
  Another anomaly that perplexed me was the packaging of my wife's Triple Lindy burrito, which arrived in a white box. However, when attempting to dispose of the container, its unusual design rendered it impossible to fit into the trash receptacle. This seemed like a curious oversight. 
  The names assigned to some of the burritos, such as Homewrecker and Art Vandelay, elicited my amusement. Nonetheless, Moe's generally underwhelming experience and unimpressive cuisine precludes it from ranking highly on my list of preferred dining establishments. In the vicinity of Jobing.com, there exist superior alternatives that warrant greater consideration.

Food is really good but Damn the service is really terrible. This is my 3rd time here and I thought they were just busy before but as much as I enjoyed the food, I wouldnt recommend it to anyone. Wait time for your food is crazy  then they bring you food you didnt order, so u wait, only to tell you that your food was probably laid on someone else's table so u wait some more. Food came, you asked for a bowl and took another century to come and had to physically tackle the server on the other table. You wait some more and the bowl was probably still in the factory. Worst part, Nobody even apologized. Another incidence, ordered food and never came in so you cancelled it coz the appetite just went away, check came in and they still charged you for it and they even fight you and say they delivered it.. OMG. I guess have your food to go? Wheres the management here?

Dirig\u00e9 par les m\u00eames propri\u00e9taires que Sushi crescent et Sushi st-denis, je dirais que cette succursale est celle que j'aime le moins. Service presqu'inexistant (ce qui est probl\u00e9matique dans un all you can eat!), le poisson ne goute pas frais et les employ\u00e9s ne pourraient pas \u00eatre plus b\u00eates. Tant qu'\u00e0 avoir envie de sushi \u00e0 volont\u00e9, marchez un 5 minutes plus loin et allez vous remplir l'estomac au Sushi crescent. Je sais que ce sont les m\u00eames propri\u00e9taires, mais je n'ai jamais eu de probl\u00e8mes \u00e0 cet autre succursale.

We arrived punctually at the appointed hour of our reservation on July 4th, several minutes ahead of schedule, eager to partake in the culinary offerings of this esteemed establishment. However, upon entering the premises, we were met with an unexpected scene; numerous patrons were already present, patiently awaiting their turn to be seated, while a considerable number of tables remained unoccupied. Perplexed by this anomaly, we inquired as to the cause of the delay, and were informed by the hostess that the restaurant's computerized system dictated the order in which guests were to be seated, irrespective of the chronological order of their arrivals. Consequently, we endured a protracted wait of over twenty minutes before being escorted to our designated table, situated outdoors, adjacent to table number 108. Furthermore, a significant lapse of time ensued before we received our initial glasses of water, while other parties, who had arrived subsequent to our reservation, were promptly served their beverages and bread. The quality of the fare provided was merely satisfactory, as my spouse's seafood dish contained a portion of unopened clams, indicative of inferior quality, and the absence of pasta as an accompaniment was conspicuous. My own dish, consisting of lemon chicken, was compromised by the excessive fat content of the poultry. Additionally, despite our request for breadsticks, they were never forthcoming. Moreover, the powerful emissions from the outdoor steamers created visual obstructions and resulted in an uncomfortable dining experience for my daughter, who was also subjected to an unintended shower.

"Underwhelming gastronomical experience with too much repetition in the menu options and an unimpressive presentation of flavors, coupled with lukewarm beverages and an excessively oily texture in the dishes, culminating in a lackluster and overpriced culinary encounter that fails to justify a second visit."

Last weekend, I had an unfortunate experience while lodging at this establishment, which failed to meet my expectations as a loyal Marriott Rewards member. Despite my repeated attempts to request assistance through room service, the room remained unkempt and unsanitary. Furthermore, the light switches were defective, presenting me with the inconvenient option of having all the lights on or off simultaneously. In addition, the elevator access system, which required the use of my room key, was frequently malfunctioning. This resulted in numerous frustrating delays during my stay. To further compound the issues, I did not receive my bill portfolio via email, even after placing several calls to rectify the situation. The process was plagued by technical difficulties, ultimately leading me to leave a voice message on an alternate contact number. Based on my disappointing encounter, I would advise potential guests against selecting this hotel for their accommodation needs.

This particular Post Office branch boasts the advantageous feature of an Automated Postal Center, which enables patrons to expeditiously procure postage or dispatch packages with minimal effort, thereby streamlining the process for both the consumer and the postal worker. Unfortunately, the designated receptacle for depositing packages often becomes overfilled, rendering it inaccessible to patrons, much to their chagrin. Despite the convenience afforded by the APC, numerous attempts to alert the counter staff via ringing the bell or knocking on the door have been futile, leaving patrons exasperated and frustrated. On one occasion, the APC experienced technical difficulties on a Saturday morning, resulting in a lengthy queue of customers eager to utilize its services. Upon finally being attended to, the worker was oblivious to the malfunction and expressed surprise at the unusual volume of patrons, highlighting the lack of communication and coordination among staff members. Eager to maintain a positive relationship with the United States Postal Service, I endeavor to provide constructive feedback in the hope of improving the quality of service, as even a modicum of attentiveness and responsiveness would greatly enhance the overall experience for patrons.

"Having been apprised of the exceptional culinary offerings purportedly proffered by Rossario's, a reputed gastronomic haven in Monona, my expectations were unquestionably elevated. Alas, my recent nocturnal dining experience proved utterly disparate from such laudatory accounts, prompting me to express my profound disenchantment with the establishment's ostensible shortcomings. Specifically, my order of portabello mushroom lasagne, comprising an amorphous mixture of flaccid noodles, copious amounts of cheese, and mushrooms submerged in sauce, failed to resemble any semblance of authentic lasagne. Similarly, my spouse, a native Italian, was equally disillusioned with his selection of chicken Puttanesca, as evidenced by his desultory demeanor and palpable dissatisfaction following a mere two bites. Furthermore, even the humble salad proved underwhelming, further contributing to our collective discontent. In conclusion, my succinct assessment of Rossario's can be summarized thusly: 'Ugh, ugh, ugh.'"
This 24 Hour location is really busy and the equipment is worn out. I did not like this particular 24 Hour.

I had high hopes that this place was on the same level as Salt River in feel and character but I sure did not have that after visiting it last night.  Maybe as I never have been at Wrigley I am missing some of the customized elements.

By far the biggest issue, minus the stupid prices for t-shirts and concessions, is the exceedingly poor scoreboard.  We sat in the lower level of the first base side and had a heck of a time reading the scoreboard.  Here are my gripes on the scoreboard:

Too small to be useful
At night it is not very well lighted so seeing the non-lighted sections is impossible
About 1/3 was being used for advertising
No stats provided for the batter (take a lesson from Salt River)
The line up on the left side did not highlight the batter but with the letters so small it would not be of much use.

By the way the parking lot lighting but there was no signage as to how to exit and the entrance was blocked off!  

I never have been to a ballpark above a crude kids field that did not have the distances from home plate to the outfield fence shown with signs hanging on the fence.

I went on the indoor ride and we shared a gondola with random people. This was a slight mistake because they were silent the entire time and weren't up for having fun, plus the guy had a huge disgusting wart on his temple that I couldn't stop staring at. Um.\n\nThe gondolier was wonderful. He was really nice, really talkative, had a great voice. He made it fun. But the gondola ride itself, enhhhh. I go in for cheesy fun touristy ripoff stuff like this all the time, but I wouldn't recommend this. It looks way more fun than it is and costs far too much for the level of fun that you have. When you reach the turnaround point, you'll think to yourself, THAT'S IT?? And yes, that's it. Seriously. It's nowhere near as exciting as you'd think it would be. Outdoor one is supposed to be better, so maybe go for that instead. The indoor one can be skipped.

This grocery establishment earns a paltry two stars solely due to its protracted operational hours, which afford customers the convenience of shopping at ungodly hours when all other nearby grocery stores have ceased their operations for the day; however, I only deign to patronize this establishment during such late hours, as the exorbitant prices and irksome security personnel who relentlessly tail me throughout the store render it an unappealing option during conventional shopping hours.

You know, I don't venture in to chain restaurants often, and even less often a chain steakhouse.  So how did I find myself at Outback Steakhouse?  It was a quick business trip to @Vegas.  I was treating for dinner and they asked for steak and convenient.  We were both staying at hotels well south of the strip so this limited the choices - nothing on the strip is convenient.

Didn't I see an Outback by the Outlet Mall?  Yes.  Weary business traveler settles for dinner...

I must say I have not been to an Outback in probably 6 years.  It was not as bad as I remember.  That would not make a great advertising slogan, by the way.

My 6 oz sirloin was fine.  The salad was fine.  The service was fine.  By fine I don't mean "fine dining" I mean "ok dining".

See you in another 6 years, Outback.

Average food for average prices.  I came here with a $30 for $15 deal from Groupon and if I was actually spending the listed price on the menu, I would definitely not be satisfied.  Since my meal was basically half off, I would say that the food was okay and well worth it, but I would not spend more than that. 

I ordered in total about 6 dishes worth $90 that I paid $45 dollars for, and out of all of them I only liked the calamari.  Every other dish was either meatless, tasteless, or overcooked. 

The restaurant was absolutely stunning and nicely decorated.  The lights were dim and perfect for a date, if the food was better.  

The server was very attentive and friendly, one of the better servers I have ever interacted with.

The airport is in need of an update.  It is very lack luster, there are very few healthy options for food (although this is common for airports) and there are still random Oxygen bars (do people still use these?).  The bathrooms are pretty dirty.  They have some corporate sponsored \"charging stations\" but they are typically crowded and you can see people up and down the terminals either sitting on the floor or hustling to grab spots when they open.  Unless you are coming to or leaving LV, there are much better spots to have to lay over.

"The culinary offerings were merely adequate, while the hospitality we received was utterly disappointing. Specifically, we had reserved a table for the evening of December 24th through the online platform OpenTable, which indicated that the establishment accepted reservations at either 11:00 PM or 11:30 PM. Upon our arrival, however, the server informed us that they would be closing their doors at midnight, thus prompting us to hastily consume our meals in an attempt to avoid any potential inconvenience. Unfortunately, this decision proved ill-fated, as the waitstaff exhibited remarkable impatience and discourtesy throughout the duration of our dining experience. Furthermore, a significant portion of the menu items failed to meet the standards lauded by previous patrons, leading us to question whether the quality of the cuisine was adversely affected by the holiday season."

This restaurant was horrible. We ordered the special murg tikka and the chicken tasted as though they threw a frozen chicken packet into the oven, sprinkled some salt and pepper and served it to us. We also ordered the paneer makhani and it was sub standard.\nThe naan was tasty, so if you're up for some naan and pickles.. go for it. Otherwise i'd steer clear of this place.

"One star for the culinary offerings and an additional star for the exceptional bartender, Emmanuel, whose proficiency in customer service ameliorated the unfortunate dining experience I had on both occasions. I have visited this establishment twice, and on both instances, Emmanuel was manning the bar, exhibiting remarkable hospitality and an innate ability to ensure patrons are enjoying themselves. His warm and engaging demeanor is laudable, and if the option to redirect the gratuity designated for our server to him were feasible, I would have seized it. Emmanuel provided more attentive service during the brief time we spent at the bar than our server did throughout the prolonged period we occupied our table. 

It is comprehensible that not everyone relishes their work daily, but when interacting with clients, feigning enthusiasm and avoiding behavior that suggests their presence is a burden is crucial. Unfortunately, our server seemed oblivious to this principle, and his indifference bordered on negligence. He visited our table a mere three times: once to take our beverage orders, again to accept our food orders, and finally to present the check. The manner in which he inquired about our interest in settling the bill conveyed a sense of urgency for us to vacate the premises. The busser demonstrated greater dedication to ensuring our needs were met, checking in on us more frequently than our server did. 

Given the lackluster service and uninspiring ambiance, venturing out of one's way to dine at this establishment is not recommended. However, if you find yourself at Yard House, opting to sit at the bar may enhance your experience."

When the proprietor arrives to offer regretful sentiments, the nocturnal experience tends not to be optimal. The sluggishness of the service, coupled with the unremarkable nature of the culinary offering, which fails to distinguish itself within a municipality boasting several superior pie establishments, contributes to an ambiance that is not only disappointing but also peculiarly clamorous.

"For the purpose of attending a respiratory convention, I have opted to procure accommodations at a hotel that would not necessitate my presence for the entirety of the day. While the rooms themselves are clean and well-appointed, featuring comfortable beds, I cannot help but notice the pervasive odor of cigarette smoke emanating from the supposedly non-smoking area. It seems rather ironic that such a situation should arise in a city renowned for its laxity regarding gambling and other vices. Furthermore, I must express my discontent with the addition of a resort fee, which, quite frankly, strikes me as an egregious attempt to extort additional funds from unsuspecting patrons. Suffice it to say, my experience at Treasure Island has been somewhat tarnished by these unfortunate circumstances, leading me to dub it 'Pirate Island' due to its seemingly predatory business practices."

"Come for the boundless array of BBQ, remain due to an inability to arrive at a conclusion. Recognize that the selection of sides is equally extensive, and simply seat yourself while consuming biscuits accompanied by apple butter until an individual informs you that it would be advisable to obtain the tri-tip sandwich complemented by a side of cornbread. 

I comprehend the reasoning behind individuals expressing their discontent regarding the exorbitant nature of the prices, however, come now, my fellow human beings; it is entirely plausible to partake in a meal alongside another person and depart feeling satiated (providing you consume your biscuits.) At present, at this moment, I am cognizant of the notion that you may harbor reservations concerning the sharing of meals within this particular geographic location, yet set aside your implements of war, since the proportions are, in fact, reasonable when considering their cost. 

Lucille's earns two stars due to its exceptional biscuit and cornbread offerings, respectable tri-tip and peanut slaw, and unsatisfactory brisket and mac 'n' cheese. Within a different region, I might award Lucille's an additional star, but within this town, where BBQ reigns supreme, only the finest will succeed in capturing my stomach's favor."

"For the sake of indulging in an ephemeral experience characterized by a blend of nostalgia and tackiness, this establishment may serve its purpose. Boasting an array of diversions and a merry-go-round bar, as well as a medley of cheesy circus performances, it manages to create a fleeting illusion of entertainment. However, upon closer inspection, one cannot help but notice the pervasive squalor, dilapidated state, haphazard planning, and overall lack of appeal that permeates the premises. Needless to say, I would not recommend prolonged stays here, even in the face of dire circumstances. In fact, I often advise those who seek my counsel to refrain from being swayed by the ostensibly affordable tariffs offered by this venue and its neighboring counterpart, the Tropicana; there exists a logical explanation for their economic pricing, which is not exactly a testament to their quality or value."

I have used irrigation with SPR for over 30 years. They have really dedicated people who go out of their way to be helpful. The Zanjeros were always available and  ready to work out some water issue, and they  are varied and frequent (like a neighbors dead animal in a canal) . So for many years I have been a big fan of SRP.

Until today!

I needed to pay my water assessment so I went to the main office.
1. Now a security guard tells you you are in the wrong place, no more receptionist.
2. The payment  center was closed and turned into  a closet with some machines in it.
3. Customer service is now a telephone on a brown wall with a sign over the phone saying call for customer service.

Zanjeros are now computer baby sitters for the nee Water Master system. Getting a consistent flow is a real challenge now. They are ready to add time but after you get shorted 20 minutes you have to move to a new user and it really does not work to then get 20 minutes delivered the next day. The person responsible  for the Water master needs to be required to meet users at 2am when the order gets shorted by the system.

When I called today I spoke to an old style SRP person but you might as well visit the prison as use this facility, So no matter what the literature says SRP is now just another big faceless utility doing their level best to isolate the customer.

"I experienced an intense yearning for delectable BBQ cuisine, which unfortunately, was not satisfactorily fulfilled by my recent dining excursion. Upon ordering $35 worth of culinary delights, my expectations were not adequately met, as the quality of the fare failed to impress me. Specifically, the pulled pork was merely passable, while the brisket proved to be unremarkable. Furthermore, the chicken lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, and the beans, regrettably, were undercooked and rather unpalatable. Consequently, I felt compelled to discard them. However, I must admit that the assortment of sauces available did possess a certain degree of palatability. Ultimately, my quest for succulent southern-style brisket remained unfulfilled, prompting me to seek out alternative sources, including soliciting the culinary expertise of my father-in-law. Notwithstanding the eatery's commendable cleanliness and hospitable staff, the diminutive proportions of the dishes served left me feeling underwhelmed."

As someone from the Philly area, driving by had me pretty excited. Pop's looks like Pat's! However, I got a cheesteak, with whiz, onions, and peppers- but they forgot the flavor.  Everything about it was bland.  I couldn't differentiate between the meat and the onions. It was weird. And the bread was awful- it was soft and did not taste like an Amoroso. Looks were most definitely deceiving. That said, the patio is great! And so were the sweet potato fries.

This marked my maiden experience at Culver's, and I must say that my expectations were not particularly elevated, as I had already formed a mental image of what to anticipate based on my previous encounters with establishments of a similar ilk, such as Wendy's and other fast-food burger joints; in essence, it was not especially remarkable or unique, but rather fell within the realm of the mundane and ordinary.

"Upon entering the establishment to retrieve an item from the ship-to-store department, I observed that the register was unattended, despite the presence of a sizable queue of patrons awaiting assistance. The gentleman manning the adjacent register informed me that the alternative lane was unavailable, which prompted me to request that he summon support staff to address the situation. In concert with two fellow patrons who shared my sentiment, I emphasized the need for expedited service, given that we were not present for layaway purposes. Fortuitously, our proximity to the employee entrance afforded me the opportunity to alert a staff member of the predicament, resulting in the timely arrival of reinforcements. Although the pace of service remained somewhat sluggish, it marked a considerable improvement from the previous state of affairs. Ultimately, it required approximately half an hour from the moment of my arrival to procure my items and secure permission to collect them from the rear of the store, owing to their bulkiness and the necessity of transporting them via a flatbed cart."

"It appears that my culinary expectations were not adequately met, as the sandwich I ordered failed to live up to the lofty standards portrayed in the numerous endorsements it had received; specifically, the Italian variant I chose did not seem to justify the acclaim it had garnered, as it was composed of only a meager portion of meat and a solitary slice of cheese, accompanied by a generic Italian dressing. My underwhelming experience compels me to revisit the establishment and sample an alternative menu item, as I am determined to comprehend the source of the widespread enthusiasm surrounding this particular eatery."

I am a resident of the surrounding area and have been frequenting this establishment for an extended period of time, indulging in both takeout and dining in. Unfortunately, over the past six months, I have noticed a gradual decline in the quality of the cuisine, to the point where I question whether it is worthwhile to continue patronizing this restaurant. Specifically, the refried beans appeared to be from a canned source, which is unacceptable given my familiarity with the distinction between homemade and canned variants. Furthermore, the Cheese Crisp was subpar and excessively oily, while the shredded beef taco contained an abundance of fatty cuts. It is unfortunate that this establishment, which once prided itself on serving high-quality Mexican fare, has allowed its standards to slip. Consequently, my dining companions and I have decided to seek alternative options, such as Sylvia's La Canasta or Macayo's, which offer superior culinary experiences without relying on prefabricated ingredients.

I thought it was over-hyped for what  I spent and received service wise. I was overall very disappointed. i went there to celebrate my BF's birthday and told the hostess it was his birthday, then told the waitress, and even told the water guy....and my BF still DID NOT receive the birthday dessert. :( I ordered sweet potato tempura and a king crab California roll and could not believe how dry the rice was. I get a better California roll at my local place back home for a quarter of the price. When we finished eating, it took them 30 mins to bring us the check!? I was so annoyed at this point. I always tip, but in this instance i did not. I did explain on the receipt why I didn't tip too. For how much hype this place gets I am sad to say I was not impressed.

"Ambivalence permeated my sentiments regarding this establishment, as my spouse and I ventured into Las Vegas after an extended hiatus, eager to discover novel culinary experiences. Prior to attending a performance, we chanced upon this eatery during our meandering excursion, and our fondness for sushi prompted us to halt and partake in their offerings. Although the quality of the cuisine was undeniably superior, the minuscule portions left my wife feeling famished, compelling us to expeditiously seek sustenance elsewhere before the show commenced, resulting in an unexpected financial burden of $72, inclusive of gratuity."

During our initial visit, we opted to be seated at the bar, whereupon we were immediately bombarded by an excessive amount of attention from the waiting staff, specifically two individuals who appeared to be endeavoring to provide assistance with an unparalleled level of diligence. However, as time progressed, it became increasingly arduous to procure the attention of any staff member, resulting in an interminable delay of approximately twenty minutes merely to obtain our bill and effectuate our departure. Despite the fact that the establishment was experiencing a high volume of patrons, my companion and I elected to sample a beverage, only to be ultimately dissuaded from doing so due to the absence of any semblance of attentive service.

Very disappointing.  The evening started off well when I noticed they had foie gras on the menu and it wasn't just a foie gras pate, but the whole foie gras seared.  It was pretty good, although the radicchio didn't go well with it.  It also could have used another 30 seconds of searing.  

Everything was downhill from there.  I have never seen a smaller or eaten a blander ceviche.  Ever.  If you're going to call something ceviche, it should be served in Peruvian fashion and taste something like ceviche.  

The lobster risotto was pretty good and had a nice little kick to it..  All three bites of it.

The black bass was forgettable.  The prime rib eye is misnamed.  If you aren't going to include the eye, which is the best part, then call it something else.  It was ok.

Even with the complimentary soup and appetizer, we left unfilled and went to Smashburger around the corner for our second dinner.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition of unpalatable flavors and questionable presentation!"
The text is: "I ordered a burger, but they brought me a sandwich. I sent it back and waited for my burger. They brought me another sandwich. I asked them to make sure it was a burger and not a sandwich. They said they would, but they still brought me a sandwich. This happened three times before I finally got my burger."
The modified text is: 
"A series of unfortunate events culminating in an unsatisfactory dining experience due to recurring mistakes in food delivery and inadequate communication among staff members."

"If you seek a culinary experience characterized by exceptional quality, copious portions, and economic pricing, it would be judicious to avoid this establishment. The fare provided can barely be considered within the parameters of a genuine delicatessen. The level of service is subpar, the selection limited, and the flavors uninspired (particularly the chicken soup, which is excessively salty, and the sandwiches, which are disappointingly bland). Furthermore, the desserts fail to impress, lacking both originality and freshness. Despite their 24-hour availability, it is advisable to allocate your time more effectively by seeking sustenance elsewhere. In essence, this eatery is an inconsequential sideshow at Circus Circus, unworthy of your patronage."

"Prospective advantages: Punctual arrival time. \n\nConsiderable drawbacks: Extended duration of operational execution, specifically 5.25 hours for loading personal portable storage devices, which, considering the extent of pre-existing preparation, should have required no more than 3 hours; additionally, supplementary fees amounting to $446 were incurred for requisite resources, thereby resulting in a total financial loss of $1150 for the day. Caveat emptor."

"Little Darlings, a purportedly adult entertainment venue, boasts an unadulterated nudity policy; thus, it is devoid of any alcoholic beverages. Although situated slightly removed from the Las Vegas Strip, its location does not pose significant challenges for those seeking to locate it. However, if one harbors expectations of experiencing a genuinely exceptional strip club adventure within the city limits of Las Vegas, they might wish to reconsider their choice of destination. The interior ambiance exudes an unmistakable aura of shabbiness and seediness, potentially arousing feelings of unease or discomfort in certain patrons. Furthermore, the physical appearance of the female performers falls short of the conventional standards associated with strip clubs. A considerable number of them exhibit visible signs of aging and/or lack of physical fitness, which may prove underwhelming for some spectators. Considering the abundance of alternative options within the city's nightlife scene, it seems judicious to bypass this establishment altogether."

"I am experiencing a state of ambivalence regarding the superior quality of the product and the subpar nature of the service and internet connectivity.  The coffee, indeed, possesses an exceptional flavor profile, but the entry fee, which involves navigating a series of obstacles in the form of a pretentious demeanor, is somewhat prohibitive.  As someone who occasionally partakes in countercultural activities (such as Burning Man), I have occasional moments of being perceived as part of the 'in-crowd,' but more often than not, my attire, which leans towards business casual, renders me an unremarkable figure, thereby failing to elicit any particular attention or recognition from the staff.  
Furthermore, the sluggish pace of service and the prevailing attitude of indifference among the employees only exacerbate my frustration.  The WiFi, unfortunately, is also woefully inadequate, relying on a signal borrowed from a nearby company's (Wet Paint) router, which leaves much to be desired.  I would gladly offer my assistance in setting up a dedicated router and Cox connection for the establishment, and judging by the enthusiastic response from patrons at the bar, a WiFi tip jar would likely be well-received.  While I find the location and product appealing, the service and internet connectivity leave much to be desired, and it is my sincere hope that these issues will be addressed in the near future."

I had heard from several people the food here was good.  As I travel to Italy often I'm fairly picky about Italian food but am willing to make allowances for Italian-American restaurants.

I had the lobster bisque which wasn't terrible but not great either.  A little too peppery and some pieces of what seemed to be dried fish.  I had ordered what I thought was the crab/shrimp cake appetizer but was brought the meal.  Since I hadn't actually looked at that part of the menu I didn't realize it wasn't the appetizer until I got the bill.  The crab/shrimp cake was adequate but there was too much filler for my taste.  The grilled potatoes and vegetables that came with the crab/shrimp cake were not warm.  Completely over-priced.

The service was glacially slow.

I will not return.

I think this place can do for a cleaning, some say it adds to the appeal, but you can get the same \"vibe\" without feeling like needing extra soap when leaving. Drinks are cheap and pretty strong for the price or at least what I expected. I went out on my own looking for chat with some new people to have drinks with and shoot the breeze but it seems like this place is full of groups of people not really into expanding outside of their clicks. Dive bar that will get a group of people drunk reasonably quickly. No music going on the night I went, so maybe I missed a lot of the appeal of it, I will re-visit and update if I feel it's needed.

The sentiment of satisfaction was conspicuously absent, as the culinary offerings failed to meet expectations, despite the establishment's convenient delivery options and extended operating hours. Although the front desk staff demonstrated proficiency in the English language, the gastronomical experience was disappointing, with dishes exhibiting an unfortunate lack of flavor and questionable preparation methods. Specifically, the pot stickers were overcooked and excessively crunchy, resulting in an inadequate filling-to-dough ratio, while the lo mien noodles presented an unpleasant texture, with some strands bunched together, others overcooked or undercooked, and vegetables displaying an unnatural waxiness. Furthermore, the beef in the lo mien was overcooked and insufficiently seasoned, rendering it unremarkable. The general's chicken, though not entirely unpalatable, fell short of expectations, failing to distinguish itself from other, superior iterations. In conclusion, the overall experience was unsatisfactory, prompting the abandonment of leftovers, typically considered a highlight of an otherwise satisfying Chinese meal.

Stopped by here for lunch and started off with the crab mozzarella appetizer and the mushroom morel soup.  The crab mozzarella was pretty good and the mushroom morel soup was also very good.  The soup reminded me of the Cheesecake Factory mushroom soup but I still prefer the one from the Cheesecake Factory.  No reviews on the beer for now but if I ever go back and I'm off the meds I'll be sure to give it a go.

The baked seafood combo consisted of a couple of clams, a mahimahi fillet, scallops and stuffed shrimp.  I was not excited about the gooey imitation crab stuffing on the shrimp and both the mahimahi fillet and the scallops lacked seasoning.  The clams were OK.

For dessert we had the nutter butter ice-cream cake which was good.  Nothing too exiting about the food here.

Close to my humble abode, I opted to investigate this establishment once more. Upon entering, I was met with an underwhelming experience, as the bartender seemed to prioritize his personal electronic device over providing adequate customer service. Despite my eagerness to indulge in their offerings, I found myself having to plead for a beverage, the cost of which was $45. Perplexed by the lack of attention from the staff, I decided to depart, questioning whether any improvements would be made in the future. Unfortunately, based on past experiences, I harbor doubts about the likelihood of change.
The flavors and toppings were okay.\nI was a little disappointed how few non-fat options there were.\nThey have an okay selection but all were of similar tastes.

"Hailing from the Midwestern region of the United States, I had never had the pleasure of indulging in the culinary delights offered by Del Taco, a fast-food establishment that ostensibly specializes in Mexican-inspired dishes; however, based on my recent experience with their fare, I cannot say that I have been missing out on much in terms of gastronomical satisfaction, as the flavor profile of their offerings seemed to be largely overshadowed by the unremarkable nature of their fries, which were not only lacking in texture but also failed to deliver any discernible taste, and the so-called 'chicken' tacos, which were essentially little more than an amalgamation of wilted lettuce and unmelted cheese, did not exactly tantalize my palate."

"Upon perusing the reviews, I had anticipated a superior dining experience at this establishment. Unfortunately, my expectations were not met, to say the least. The ambiance was not conducive to a pleasant dining experience, as it was a smoking environment, which proved to be a significant disappointment, particularly during dinner. The service was sluggish and lacked warmth, which further contributed to an unpleasant dining atmosphere. Our order consisted of cheese sticks, which were unimpressive and lacking in flavor, beer-battered pickles that were excessively greasy, and a BBQ chicken sandwich that was unfortunately overcooked, resulting in an inedible batter that was nearly burnt. Despite our attempts to salvage the sandwich by cutting and removing the batter, it proved to be a futile endeavor. The garlic Parmesan fries failed to deliver any discernible traces of garlic flavor. Ultimately, the dining experience was a disappointment, with my boyfriend opting not to consume his sandwich. The lone redeeming quality was the beer, which was quite satisfactory."

We went for sunday brunch , i like the fact they open at 7am, i figure everyone still sleeping nursing late night hangovers. I was right at 7 am only a handful of us old folks in line. . The buffet was very limited and not many items. For about 25 bucks a head you should get more. The hot foods were mostly breakfast items what happend to the lunch part of brunch. Very sad. Everthing was fresh as it should be since we were their early. Still can't believe a beautiful casino , ' upscale\" would have a brunch that was so simple. Spend a few more bucks and go to wynn, or bellagio.  Service was fine.

"A further gem in the Fox culinary diadem, boasting an extraordinary appearance and sensation, yet accompanied by exorbitant prices for fare that, while undeniably delectable, fails to justify the cost. In a recent visit, a member of our party opted for the prime rib French dip, to which the server inquired whether they desired mushrooms, peppers, or onions, to which my acquaintance responded affirmatively. Subsequently, they had the audacity to impose an additional fee of $2 per item, totaling $6, for what can only be described as meager embellishments. It is utterly preposterous; I could procure ten pounds of onions for a mere $2... Ultimately, I chose to share a chicken club and a minuscule cheese platter, accompanied by iced tea, amounting to a staggering $24. To compound the disappointment, the server exhibited a discourteous demeanor. In light of this experience, it is improbable that I would voluntarily frequent a Fox establishment again, unless presented with the occasional gift card."

My husband and I were so excited to see a trendy and family friendly restaurant pop up near our neighborhood we couldn't wait to try! We gushed over the decor for the entire time it took to get our wine (15 mins) which was sub par and room temperature. The menu was good, but only if you were on a \"cheat day\".  We ordered the only 3 healthy options on the menu and were VERY disappointed. The hummus app was the smallest portion of hummus we've ever encountered, but the stale pita chips were enough for a portion 10x the size.  My Caprese salad didn't feel fresh and his garden salad was blah.  Again we pondered, \"maybe we ordered wrong\" but come on, you shouldn't have ANYTHING on your menu if you don\"t stand behind it.  It was so disappointing that WE WENT TO ANOTHER RESTAURANT  AFTER ON A WORK DAY THAT CRAZY!!!    This place makes me soooooo sad because its the first trendy thing within 7 miles of our house! PLEASE PLAESE FIX THIS WE WILL BE REGULARS!

The dining experience was subpar, characterized by a tardy service and a burger presented on an unpalatable, moist bun. Despite requesting a novel bun, its procurement was delayed substantially, thus compelling us to consume the patty sans the bun. Furthermore, the ambient temperature within the establishment was excessively elevated, causing discomfort for all individuals seated at our table, who were perspiring profusely. Considering the overall unsatisfactory nature of our visit, we would not consider returning to this venue in the future.

"Prior to engaging in a cinematic experience, my spouse and I opted to dine at this establishment due to its proximity to the theatre. Upon entering, we were greeted by an accommodating staff who expedited our seating and ordering process with efficiency. The beverage selection boasted an intriguing watermelon margarita, which we found quite delectable. However, the culinary offerings failed to meet our expectations, as the dressing accompanying my chopped salad was excessively piquant, rendering it inedible. In response, the courteous server proffered a quesadilla as a substitute, which, while unremarkable in taste, did alleviate the discomfort caused by the spicy dressing. My husband's rancho burrito fared slightly better, yet still fell short of our gastronomic standards. Considering our underwhelming experience, we would not recommend this venue to any individual seeking a satisfying dining experience prior to a cinematic excursion."

It is 7:30 am, and the time has come for me to partake in the first meal of the day. As I ponder my options, I find myself faced with a dilemma; shall I opt for a plate of savory sausage gravy, or perhaps indulge in some turkey sausage? Or, maybe, just maybe, I could treat myself to both the gravy and the sausage, thus satisfying my morning cravings. Furthermore, I must consider whether to accompany my meal with a banana that has been ripening for approximately two weeks, adding a touch of sweetness to my breakfast.
