After deliberating for a span of ten minutes, during which time I observed Magdelina ensuring an abundance of froot loops to complement the overripe bananas, sausage gravy, and turkey sausage, I decided to proceed with my morning routine, grabbing a cup of coffee before embarking on my day, feeling somewhat peckish. It is worth noting that Las Vegas boasts an extensive array of hotels, numbering in the hundreds, and it may be advisable to consider alternative accommodations.

"Spacious accommodations, luxurious linens, and a sumptuous sleeping surface replete with an abundance of cushionsâthese are but a few of the amenities that contribute to my unalloyed satisfaction whenever I embark on a journey. However, this particular establishment appears to be plagued by a trifecta of deficiencies, beginning with its inconvenient proximity to a shopping center that offers little more than a plethora of chain restaurants; continuing with the seemingly apathetic demeanor of the hotel staff, whose indifference extends to everything except the cursory friendliness displayed by the woman responsible for our check-in process; and culminating in a series of egregious oversights on the part of housekeeping, including an inadequate supply of towels and a failure to replenish the complimentary bottled water that was erroneously charged to my bill at a rate of $30 per diem, despite my Hilton Honors membership entitling me to said "amenities" gratisâall of which, taken together, serve to profoundly disappoint and undermine my overall satisfaction with this hotel, particularly given the exorbitant nightly tariff of over $200."

When you walk in and view the menu, you think you are in \"Chicken Heaven\". There are a variety of flavors and various seasonings you can choose for your fries. However, I was not impressed. I ordered the chicken wing and chicken strip meal with a side of fries. The chicken was cooked to a golden crisp and served hot. I ordered the garlic Parmesan, and thought it was waay too salty. Also, a few of my pieces of chicken were undercooked. The restaurant is small, so I had to get my food to go. I have heard mixed reviews and though my experience was not the greatest, I am willing to give Chicken Shack a second chance.

"My acquaintance and I opted to utilize the recent $25 for $50 Groupon to experience Pewter Rose on a Saturday evening. Honestly, I considered the pricing to be somewhat steep for the ambiance presented, thus I was grateful for the voucher. Although the atmosphere was agreeable, I felt that the plastic tablecloths were incongruous with the menu prices exceeding $20 per plate. Notwithstanding this, the venue was teeming with patrons; we had booked a table for 8 pm and arrived punctually, and the hostess promptly seated us within five minutes. Our server, however, immediately intimated that we should anticipate a prolonged wait for our cuisine, given the high volume of clientele that evening. As we were not pressed for time, we acquiesced to the delay. Our server was attentive and maintained our hydration, but despite placing our order without delay, we did not receive our initial course until well after 8:30 p.m., and indeed, it was closer to 9:20 p.m. before we were served our main dishes. While the restaurant was bustling, it is not particularly expansive, which made the extended waiting period slightly unexpected. Personally, I relished the seafood risotto and would certainly partake of it once more. My companion had the herb-encrusted lamb, which was palatable, albeit a tad too salty for our taste. I might consider returning to sample their brunch, yet I would hesitate to pay the full tariff for an evening meal."

Not the first time and only because it's a party. Horrible service waiter picks up my salad plate take the knife off of it and places it on the table with a big wad of lettuce still on it. Appetizers where horrible I'm hoping I don't get sick from the mushroom caps, drinks where watered down. Main course wasn't so bad steak was ok but potatoes where cold and veggies had a horrible taste.  So many great places to eat in town and they pick this dump.

It took me more than 20 minutes to get my single to-go order at this location. On a thursday night when there was hardly anyone there this was ridiculous. The food was OK, I've had better Hawaiian BBQ in the valley for less money. At almost ten dollars for the whole meal, it was not worth the money. Fortunately they do have a smaller, less expensive portion that would fill most people up for lunch.

I like Durant's out of principle, but this is by no means a great restaurant by my estimation. The three separate times I've been were riddled with lackluster service, improperly prepared seafood, and meat with the wrong temperature (medium means medium, right? or has beef fallen into the \"rare is the new medium\" fashion continuum?). \n\nI remain altogether unimpressed. I would, however, hide here if the law was looking for me. It's just that kind of place.

"Although our dining experience at this establishment did not necessarily qualify as unpleasant or subpar, there are undoubtedly superior alternatives in the vicinity for individuals seeking a satisfying culinary excursion, particularly if they wish to concurrently indulge in sports entertainment.  Given the underwhelming nature of our solitary visit, we have opted not to return."

My manager requested a recommendation for an interior designer to embellish our new corporate facility, so I sought assistance from the Yelp community, which led me to Neilsen. I promptly forwarded all relevant contact information to my manager, who expressed gratitude for my expedient provision of a referral. However, upon further evaluation, Nielsen's proficiency in time management and follow-through proved to be subpar. He displayed a reluctance to return my manager's phone calls, necessitating numerous messages, and his proposal submission was delayed by two weeks. Additionally, he would frequently depart for extended periods of time without notifying my manager, leading to significant inconvenience. While I acknowledge the possibility of miscommunication or unforeseen circumstances, my experience with Nielsen was regrettably marred by these issues. Although I typically refrain from giving low ratings, I felt compelled to provide an honest assessment of my disappointing encounter. It is crucial to carefully assess your situation prior to recommending this company, as their artistic talent may be considerable, but their reliability and responsiveness are subject to variation.

I get really annoyed with these "fancy" hotels who don't offer the refrigerator and microwave in their standard rooms, which I can get at a Holiday Inn Express or a Comfort Inn for probably half the price.  

Also, for the love of all things holy, don't charge people for WiFi in 2011 after they already paid you an arm and a leg for a room that isn't worth it.  That is RIDICULOUS.

There's at least a half-mile walk (without a sidewalk) to anything except a small convenience store.

The room was comfortable enough, but no greater than any 3-star hotel I've ever stayed in.

I recently consumed a grilled cheese sandwich that was utterly devoid of any semblance of culinary expertise, with a solitary slice of cheese haphazardly placed upon the bread, failing to extend its melted tendrils to the edges of the bun, thereby creating an unfortunate visual representation of the lackluster quality of the dish; I must express my profound disappointment at the stark contrast between this uninspired creation and my previous experiences at this establishment, where the fare was not only palatable but indeed tantalizing, leading me to surmise that the current preparation of comestibles within these walls lacks the fervor and dedication that once characterized the culinary endeavors of the kitchen staff.

I must confess that my expectations for Tex-Mex establishments in the Burgh are unyielding, and my perpetual pursuit of an eatery that serves palatable tacos has been consistently frustrated. My gripe with the local taco scene can be distilled to a fundamental misunderstanding of the intrinsic nature of the taco; specifically, the tortilla, which serves as the primary point of contact between the food and the consumer's taste buds, is often overlooked. In my opinion, a freshly crafted tortilla, be it from corn or flour, is the cornerstone of an exceptional taco experience. During my tenure in San Antonio and various regions of Mexico, I had the pleasure of indulging in straightforward yet delectable tacos, sporting minimal toppings and a succulent, fresh tortilla. Unfortunately, Verde appears to prioritize the accompaniments rather than the foundation of the dish, ultimately yielding an unremarkable, mass-produced tortilla that fails to elevate the overall taste experience. Thus, I find myself disheartened by the fact that I must spend $5 on a taco that falls short of my expectations.

I liked the menu a lot and can tell that there is some serious potential here, but had a really bad experience. 

They couldnt help the obnoxious, loud, drunk group that came in, so I will give them a pass on that. 

But when my 1 pound burger came out, the fries were already cold. They seemed like they may have tasted pretty good if they had come out about 10 minutes earlier. 

Unfortunately they also forgot my biscuit until I mentioned it. They then brought it out and it was reallly dry. Again, seemed like it could have been better if it had been quicker. 

Again, I reallly wanted to like this place and was hoping to try a breakfast here before I left, but I'm really not sure I should risk it now. Bummer.

Alas, this place seems to be getting worse and worse over the years. I tried it again last week because it was Monday and Saigon Noodles was closed. I just wanted soup. I ordered the Tom Yum. 
It comes with a little salad. It was fresh and good but the dressing was pure sugar. My daughter had the chicken satay. The peanut sauce barely resembled peanuts. It was also really, really sweet and had a few peanuts in it. My soup was sour-- not that nice sweet/sour mix that is typical with Tom Yum-- just sour. It was edible though so I ate it.
To get in and out for under $20 was nice and the service was pretty good.
Bottom line: if you are on the West Side of Madison on a Monday and want soup... lower your standards and eat here. Otherwise, go to Saigon Noodle or (if you really, really need Thai food) head to Ha Long Bay on Willie Street.

"As numerous reviewers have previously stated, this establishment masquerades as a luxury hotel while offering amenities and services akin to those of an economic motel.  The shower's water pressure was so excessive that it overflowed, flooding the bathroom floor to ankle depth, and there was no means of regulating the water pressure.  This occurrence was particularly problematic given the current global water scarcity issues. Following the assumption that the shower malfunctioned, I requested a room transfer, only to discover that the subsequent room suffered from the identical issue, leading me to conclude that this was a common phenomenon among guests.  Furthermore, the absence of high-end television channels and the requirement for a wired connection to access the internet in the room, accompanied by an exorbitant fee of $15 for a mere 15 minutes of usage, further contributed to my disappointment.  To exacerbate matters, the customer service was appalling, with staff members displaying an evident reluctance to assist me, exemplified by their tendency to disregard my queries and behave as though I were invisible.  Although suitable for gambling activities, the lodging failed to meet expectations, prompting me to reconsider my decision to stay there. In fact, I have encountered superior hospitality at various budget-friendly motels.  The sole factor preventing me from awarding a single star is the fact that the room was properly sanitized."

If I were at the helm of an M&M store situated on the famed Las Vegas Strip, I would have implemented various innovative and attention-grabbing elements to create an immersive experience for patrons, including but not limited to:  

1. Complimentary samples of the iconic candy to entice passersby and lure them into the establishment.  

2. Life-size, huggable M&M characters strategically positioned throughout the store to engage customers and foster an atmosphere of whimsical delight.  

3. An interactive demonstration showcasing the unique attribute of M&Ms candies, specifically their ability to melt in one's mouth and not in their hands, even in the sweltering heat of the Las Vegas desert climate.  

4. A sleek and modern bar/lounge area, offering an assortment of candy-colored cocktails and specialty beverages, further enhanced by the novel incorporation of M&Ms as a visual element within the drinks themselves.  

5. A collaboration with Cirque du Soleil, featuring acrobats adorned solely in M&M-inspired attire, performing breathtaking feats amidst a visually stunning backdrop, all while maintaining a playful and lighthearted tone consistent with the M&M brand.  

6. High-stakes poker games, presided over by the aforementioned life-size huggable M&M characters, serving as both dealers and ambient decor.  

7. A section dedicated to adult entertainment, catering to diverse preferences and interests, with a subtle integration of M&M-themed elements to maintain a cohesive atmosphere.  

However, it appears that the current management of the M&M store on the Strip has chosen to adopt a different approach, focusing on more traditional merchandising methods, such as offering four levels of M&M-branded products for sale, a 3-D movie experience, and a guided tour, but regrettably omitting complimentary samples, which seemingly contradicts the essence of the M&M brand's playful spirit. This disconnect prompts me to ponder the rationale behind the store's presence on the Las Vegas Strip, as its offerings appear to diverge from the expectations typically associated with this famed destination.

"Four overcooked shrimp on a whole shrimp po boy for 12 dollars?!? It's utterly inconceivable how they could possibly serve such an unimpressive dish without any semblance of embarrassment or shame. The red beans and rice were merely average, lacking the authentic flavor and zest that one would expect from a genuine Cajun culinary experience. As for the gumbo, it was utterly forgettable and unremarkable, devoid of any distinguishing characteristics or nuances that might have made it stand out from the myriad of other lackluster establishments purporting to serve 'authentic' Cajun cuisine. \n\nHowever, it must be acknowledged that the service was somewhat above average, although this fact was ultimately unable to compensate for NOLA's egregious failure to deliver an even remotely passable representation of Cajun cooking. In point of fact, it's highly unlikely that such an establishment would survive for even a brief period of time in New Orleans, where authenticity and richness of flavor are paramount and sacrosanct aspects of the city's culinary tradition."

"Positioned along the continuum of burgers, these offerings can be classified as relatively satisfactory. It is conspicuously superior to the fare offered by McDonald's or Burger King, although I Love Burgers might prefer their experience to be differentiated from that of fast food establishments, and thus, I shall refrain from drawing such comparisons. When evaluated against other upscale burger restaurants, however, I Love Burgers falls short of exceptional standards.

Commencing with the service, a brief delay ensued before securing a table, despite an abundance of unoccupied seats. While it is true that the venue was bustling with activity, a judicious allocation of seating and efficient management of waiting times could have facilitated a more comfortable dining experience. Moreover, the omission of fries from our order, despite their inclusion in the meal, necessitated a request for their delivery, exemplifying a lapse in attentive service.

Regarding the culinary aspects, the burgers, while palatable, fail to transcend mediocrity. My selection, the 'I Love Bacon Burger,' composed of a sirloin and applewood-smoked bacon patty, surmounted by crispy bacon, bacon mayo, gouda, and onion strings, satisfied my hunger, but its unremarkable quality precludes any compelling reason for future visits."

Been here 3 times. I must admit it is not so great and over priced. The service lacks but they are open late. On a sunday night when I rip off a nail before a big dinner meeting, they are open for a quick fix. I give them props for the crazy late hours but there would be no reason to visit them otherwise.  Last resorts and emergencies only.

"The culinary offerings at this establishment all possessed a subtle yet discernible essence of Italian seasoning, which, while unconventional, was not necessarily appealing to our taste buds. Specifically, the vegetarian enchilada dish was replete with an abundance of zucchini, a fact that was not explicitly indicated on the menu and led to a certain degree of disappointment, as we had been expecting a more diverse array of vegetables such as bell peppers and onions. Furthermore, the absence of these ingredients rendered the dish less palatable for my personal preferences. Notwithstanding the shortcomings in the gastronomic department, the ambiance and hospitality of the venue were quite pleasant."

"It is patently evident that this establishment enjoys immense popularity, as it was teeming with an abundance of clientele during the entire duration of our visit, many of whom appeared to be habitual patrons.  We elected to partake of the vegetarian offerings, and while the seitan appetizer was indeed delectable and generously proportioned, the remainder of the repast was unfortunately lacking in quality. \nThe hospitality we received was somewhat erratic, as our server, though affable, was conspicuously absent, leaving us to fend for ourselves for extended periods, while the remaining staff members seemed overwhelmed and flustered."

"My significant other and I opted to partake in a nocturnal repast at Hash House, whereupon we encountered ambivalent hospitality; specifically, the hostesses exhibited cordiality and warmth, yet their propensity for lingering near the host stand proved somewhat bothersome.  Compelled to select our victuals from the truncated late-night menu, I opted for the grilled cheese sandwich, which, while palatable, suffered from an overabundance of tomato and a meager portion of avocado, rendering its presentation haphazard and challenging to consume.  Our server, Mike, provided adequate, albeit sluggish, attention, requiring approximately fifteen minutes to procure my strawberry lemonade margarita, a beverage that, despite its delayed arrival, proved quite satisfying, if not particularly pricey at eight dollars.  In conclusion, while the evening's culinary excursion yielded mixed results, we harbor hopes for improved service and fare upon our future visits."

"I have vivid recollections of visiting this establishment with my family during our previous excursions to Las Vegas, seeking an affordable and delectable dining experience. Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the half roasted duck, which, while palatable, was diminutive in proportion compared to similar offerings at California's Sam Woos. In addition, I sampled the barbecued pork and chicken rice, which elicited nostalgic sentiments of home cooking, and a medley of seasonal vegetables that were merely sautÃ©ed with garlic and salt, a culinary simplicity that cannot be disparaged. However, the cost of our repast proved to be somewhat prohibitive, amounting to approximately $50, and it is worth mentioning that payment by cash was the sole acceptable method. Notwithstanding these factors, I am inclined to attempt Capital Seafood, situated upstairs, during my subsequent visit."

We revisited the establishment this past weekend to acquire additional white balsamic vinegar, which we deemed to be of exceptional quality, and decided to partake in a meal on this particular occasion. The younger patrons divided a kids' grilled cheese sandwich and expressed satisfaction with their selection. My spouse opted for the antipasto, which she found enjoyable, albeit the portion size was somewhat diminutive for the cost of $12, and the accompanying bread consisted of three baguette slices that lacked both toasting and warming. I chose the Abrequine, advertised as a roast beef panini, but regrettably, this particular sandwich did not come into contact with a panini press; it was modest in size and sorely needed some form of spread to enhance its flavor profile. The potato chips possessed an agreeable crispiness, yet they were also rather oily. The children relished the gelato, and I sampled a portion, finding it pleasant. Additionally, I purchased a bottle of Mexican lime olive oil, but unfortunately, its fragrance and sweetness seemed overly synthetic. My partner approved of the spicy green beans, while the feta-stuffed olives were merely adequate. This excursion qualified as a delightful family outing, suitable for occasional visits, but not necessarily a regular destination.

Because I opted to lodge in Luxor, the pragmaticity of dining at this establishment was unavoidable, thus I indulged in their culinary offerings for three out of four days. Generally, the quality of the sandwiches, soups, and salads was satisfactory, albeit it being typical cafÃ© fare. Nonetheless, on the final day, the beverage server inadvertently poured an excessive amount of water into my teapot, resulting in a precarious situation where the liquid swished around and splashed onto my leg upon minimal movement. Miraculously averting disaster, I managed to safely place the scalding teapot on the table without any further mishaps. 

As I was experiencing the aftermath of a hangover and fatigue while attempting to consume sustenance prior to my impending flight, I did not feel inclined to voice my dissatisfaction. Instead, I politely requested an ice bag from another waitress, who subsequently sought assistance from our absentee waitress. The latter then contacted the manager, who in turn summoned security personnel. Upon the arrival of the latter, I conveyed my desire for a bag of ice, which could have been readily obtained by conveying my grievances directly to the drink server and requesting her to procure said item from the kitchen. Hindsight being 20/20, a more efficient approach would have been to address the issue with the server herself, specifying that she had filled the teapot to its maximum capacity, thereby avoiding the unnecessary involvement of additional staff members.

I have had the privilege of visiting this establishment on three separate occasions, with the most recent visit being motivated by my desire to sample their taco offering, thereby enabling me to provide a comprehensive assessment of the restaurant's culinary prowess.  Upon ordering, I was somewhat dismayed to discover that the taco in question was rather diminutive in stature, measuring a mere 3-4 inches in length, and lacking the crispy shell option which I had been anticipating.  Notwithstanding this initial disappointment, I must admit that the shredded beef utilized in the taco's composition was indeed of superior quality; however, considering the paltry sum of $2 requested in exchange for this item, I cannot help but feel that its value was not entirely commensurate with its cost.  During a subsequent visit, I opted to sample the fried fish dish, and I must confess that the end result was utterly unsatisfactory.  The fish itself was presented in an unfilleted state, with only half of the meat remaining attached to the bone, and the method of preparation employed seemed to consist merely of placing the fish in a fryer, sans any semblance of finesse or attention to detail.  Furthermore, the ambiance of the restaurant struck me as decidedly juvenile and aesthetically unpleasing, with certain aspects of the dÃ©cor bordering on the offensive.  In conclusion, while the service at this establishment may be deemed passable, the prices charged are hardly reasonable, and the cuisine, with a few notable exceptions, falls short of expectations.

"Although I am unable to provide extensive feedback at this time,one aspect that has captured my attention and sparked consternation is the requirement for online payment of certain school-related expenses through the institution's website.It appears that the school administration places a high premium on monetary transactions with parents,as evidenced by the conspicuous presence of personal information on their platform.Furthermore,an additional 90-cent surcharge is incurred for the convenience of online payment,which strikes me as both puzzling and dubious.If this fee is indeed intended to compensate for the convenience afforded by digital transactions,I would propose an alternative arrangement whereby parents could opt to remit a fixed sum of $15 to the school.However,this option is unfortunately unavailable,and parents are instead compelled to incur the recurring 90-cent charge each time they engage in online payments.This raises questions regarding the recipient of such fees and the potential cumulative impact on parents who frequently utilize the online payment system."

Visiting Phoenix and cognizant of the effusive acclaim bestowed upon this establishment, we opted to experience its offerings en route to our lodging. Arriving promptly at 8:30 PM on a Friday evening, we encountered merely a single couple preceding us, thereby ensuring a relatively expedient service.

However, upon entering the premises, we were immediately acknowledged by a lone staff member, fostering an impression that a definitive knowledge of our preferences was expected at the onset. The sole employee tasked with attending to our needs exhibited a reserved demeanor, potentially attributed to the culmination of a protracted work shift or other factors.

In regards to the frozen delights, my spouse selected the TC^2 and salted caramel flavors, while I opted for the almond buttercrunch and apple cinnamon varieties. Additionally, I sampled the honey blue cheese and sugar and spice options. Unfortunately, the almond buttercrunch failed to showcase a discernible almond essence, although the remaining flavors proved satisfactory. Notably, the texture presented a rather icy consistency, lacking the anticipated creaminess, given the extensive praise surrounding this venue.

The pricing, however, proved reasonable and, if seeking unique ice cream flavors at a fair cost within close proximity, a visit may be warranted. Nonetheless, based on our personal preferences, augmented by exposure to exceptional ice cream in the San Francisco Bay Area, we departed feeling unimpressed. Ultimately, our experience at this establishment fell short of our expectations.

"My sentiments regarding this establishment are rather unremarkable, to put it mildly. As an ardent advocate for small businesses, my expectations were unfortunately not met. While Sonic boasts superior flavored hotdogs and buns, their lemonade, regrettably, leaves much to be desired. Specifically, the'special' variety, purportedly rendered unavailable due to a malfunctioning machine, was nothing short of revolting - overly diluted and lacking any semblance of flavor. Suffice it to say that, after numerous occasions of driving past this eatery, my recent experience has solidified my decision to never patronize this business again."

"The culinary experience was satisfactory, and the ambiance was engaging; however, upon consuming a single draught of my beverage, I detected an unpleasant metallic flavor and subsequently discovered an unsettling crunch between my molars. Upon further inspection, it became apparent that the beer contained shattered fragments of glass, which understandably elicited my indignation. Despite my attempts to bring this issue to the attention of the manager, he displayed a dismissive demeanor and implied that I was being dishonest, citing the lack of visible damage to the container as evidence. Notwithstanding the replacement of the contaminated bottle, no additional measures were taken to address the unfortunate situation or alleviate my discomfort."

"In the absence of the delectable turkey crepe and cookies, a solitary star would have been the maximum rating I would have bestowed upon this establishment. The service was abysmal, the decor was ostentatious, and the cupcake desserts were, I assure you, comprised of an alarming proportion of icing (utterly reprehensible). Our server, though not a novice, appeared to be overwhelmed by the sheer volume of patrons, her sluggish pace rendering her incapable of recalling our order in a timely manner. She did, however, display commendable candor in acknowledging her oversight some twenty minutes later. By the time our culinary offerings arrived, the pasta had succumbed to the chill of the atmosphere, yet our ravenousness precluded us from returning it. It is my recommendation that potential patrons limit their indulgence to the carry-out desserts."

"I profoundly detest the subpar quality of the tint applied to my automobile. In contrast to my previous vehicle, which was tinted several years ago and effectively mitigated the temperature inside to a relatively comfortable level, my current car's tint has failed to provide any discernible difference in terms of heat reduction. Despite opting for an identical shade of tint, my vehicle remains unbearably hot on a daily basis, rendering the substantial financial investment utterly futile. My dissatisfaction with this situation is exacerbated by the notion that the tint might as well be non-existent, thereby nullifying its intended purpose and rendering the entire endeavor a colossal waste of resources."

The Flamingo is one of the few surviving hotels from the old Vegas days...and it shows. 

There is nothing flashy about the Flamingo. Short of the presence of the casino, it doesn't even feel like Vegas. The Flamingo has become an institution unto itself, and short of getting a free room for my visit, I rarely ever even step foot inside the hotel.

However, you cannot justify destroying one of the few remaining icons from old Vegas. Visit the Flamingo if you've never been to Vegas...heck, stay there even. The rooms are decent, but I had a problem with cell phone reception with a pool view room. 

No great restaurants inside of the hotel, but it is close enough to every other hotel that it makes walking the Strip an easy task.

"This hotel's offerings fail to surpass mediocrity, with accommodations that exhibit visible signs of deterioration and a staff whose level of assistance is comparable to that of a typical government agency, such as the Department of Motor Vehicles. It appears that the employees opt to perform their duties, but any notion of providing aid or support beyond the bare minimum is nonexistent. The establishment's overall quality has significantly declined over the past decade and a half, rendering it unsuitable for any purpose other than serving as a venue for a conference, which was the sole reason for my temporary residency. I shall not return."

This has been my all time favorite restaurant anywhere for years, since I lived here in very early 2000s, but this time it was a disappointment.

They didn't have the usual Cuban Bread on the menu but they said they could make it anyway... but it wasn't at all the same.  They used a different bread that was way too thick and not even toasted.

I got the bacon and cheese burger but the burger wasn't very good, I didn't finish it.  The fries were just blah.

Smoothie King is like a broke Jamba Juice! When I came here it was packed with loads of people and the staff here are far from good customer service. The way it is set up makes no sense what so ever. When it was time to pay the guy ringing us up got our order wrong and wanted me to $18.00 for two smoothies..overall smoothies were good but don't think i would go back ever again.

Came here for lunch. Masaman curry had tomatoes in it, so I ordered it without tomato (cause who has ever heard of masaman curry with tomato).

Order medium spice. It tasted bland. Dish had a lot of chicken, but barely any vegetables. I would have liked a better balance.

Soup was okay, as was the spring roll that came with the lunch special.

Peanuts in the masaman were raw. I had ordered extra peanuts, as I have had Masaman curry at a lot of places, and I love the cooked peanuts. The raw peanuts were a raw deal.

If you have time, head over a few miles to Chanpen Thai Cuisine. MUCH better quality food.

If you work nearby and need a quick bite to eat, the prices were reasonable and service was good. But there are better Thai places close by.

Had a decent enough experience buying the car, but the service department was another story when I went to get my accessories installed.  They forgot to tighten a hose after a routine install, and my car died while merging onto the freeway immediately afterwards, putting me into a dangerous position.  I was not offered any kind of compensation for my time since I live an hour away and had to make a second trip, the inconvenience, or the danger they put me in due to their complete negligence.  Not even an apology.   This doesn't bode well for my trust in their mechanics.

Quite expensive for such a small bowl of food that isn't all that great. I had the Dan Dan noodles ($12 + tax/tip). The spice from the sauce overpowered the shrimp and the noodles -- I could barely taste them! You can get better Asian food in the strip, but if you're stuck at the Venetian, this is your best bet for something quick.

If I had to sum up my meal in two words: odd brunch. I started the meal with a kugel & strawberries based on another yelper's review - ate almost the whole thing! Would def order it again or serve it for guests at a brunch. Yum. The matzo soup tasted OK, felt like it was surrounded by canned chix noodle (ala Cambell's) though. Entre was holishkes (bland cabbage rolls with chunky marinara sauce), the sides seemed like random afterthoughts and portion size was enormous. My daughter ordered the kid's mac & cheese with a side of applesauce (which is always served in a ridiculously tiny cup). The wait staff were friendly and accommodating. It can be overwhelming and claustrophobic on a busy night but Sunday night was as chill as it gets. Next time I'm sticking with my fave dish there: open-faced tuna melt. Can't go wrong there.\n\nThe menus just kill me... I have learned over the years how to navigate them quickly but seriously Restaurant Impossible needs to come in and revamp here! A simplified menu featuring well made dishes to compliment some home made ice cream would have an immediate positive impact. That and some cleaned up, contemporary, functioning decor would really breathe some life into this place! We'll never stop coming here but will enjoy it MUCH more with some improvements. I'm rooting for ya Ella's!

I have had the dubious pleasure of visiting this establishment on two separate occasions, and I must say that my experiences have been less than satisfactory. During my initial visit, I opted to situate myself at the bar and indulge in a few alcoholic beverages accompanied by a serving of nachos. While the service provided by the bartender was relatively prompt and amicable, the quality of the nachos left much to be desired, falling squarely within the realm of mediocrity.  
Upon my return, I was unfortunately subjected to an utterly disappointing dining experience. Our server, a veritable space cadet, displayed a complete lack of attentiveness and competence. Following a prolonged wait, she finally arrived with our water, only to disappear for extended periods of time, reappearing at irregular intervals to check on our progress. Furthermore, her ignorance regarding our beer order was nothing short of astounding. The food we received, arriving tardily, was also unimpressive, with the temperature being rather chilly, rendering it utterly unpalatable.  
It is worth noting that the same group of regular patrons was present during both my visits, their boisterous behavior and visible intoxication detracting from the already unpleasant ambiance. In light of these experiences, I would strongly advise against frequenting this establishment, instead opting for one of the numerous alternative bars in the vicinity.

"My culinary preferences do not incline towards seafood, thus it requires a considerable amount of quality to persuade my taste buds; however, my experience at Original Fish Market fell short of my expectations. I sampled a few of their offerings, specifically the lobster bisque, halibut, and pork chops accompanied by coleslaw. Unfortunately, the lobster bisque lacked flavor and warmth, while the halibut was merely adequate. The pork chops were particularly disappointing, possessing an unpleasant bitterness and dryness. The ambiance of the establishment exuded an air of aloofness and was devoid of hospitality. Moreover, it required an inordinate amount of time to capture our server's attention, and when we finally succeeded, her responses were terse and conveyed an attitude of annoyance, as if our presence was an inconvenience. In light of these factors, I would opt for sushi instead of expending additional funds at this venue."

We went wIth a Groupon for our anniversary 11/11. Wanted Texas but it was booked. Thought we would try this one since its close to home. Salad bar was sad. Very small and food looked like it was out of cans and had been sitting out for awhile. Nothing like Texas and Via. My husband prefers meat well done, they offered to cook a little more. Meat came back just as rare. We asked for a coke, they brought a can with a glass of ice. Meat selection was limited and was ok. Got the bill, couldn't believe Coke was $3!! Prices for meal are pretty much the same as other places. We will make the trek to Via or Texas.

"Culinary delights are satisfactory, yet the quality of service is deplorable. On two separate occasions, we experienced considerable delays in receiving attention from the servers, who appeared indifferent to our presence and failed to exhibit adequate attentiveness in addressing our needs. Moreover, the prolonged waiting period resulted in the dissatisfying experience of having our dim sum conclude before we could savor its full flavor. In light of these circumstances, it is our recommendation that patrons seek alternative dining options, such as Chang's on Decatur, where the cost-benefit ratio is more favorable and the quality of service is superior. We strongly advise against visiting this establishment, as the prices are exorbitant and the culinary offerings fall short of expectations."

So thank you groupon for saving me some money as this place is not worth the admission fee.  

I grew up in Seattle so aquariums and sealife are something I really enjoy and usually when traveling I like to go to them to see different regions sea creatures.  

Well that's the first problem Phoenix is a desert and I should know better than to go to an aquarium here but I was intrigued as it was new and I got a good deal on tix.  

The tanks were small and too many people in too much of a confined area for my liking.  I felt people were angry for you taking more than 30 seconds to look at something or take a picture.  

The talk times were a waste as they were all too crowded and you couldn't see anything.  There was one cool tank that had a second level to go above and look down on it which gave the best view in the place.  

Overall I say drive to California go to a real coastal aquarium and save your money.  Heck even go buy a DVD or something.

First of all, I REALLY want to like JJ's. They have a great concept, a cool and clever menu, and a good atmosphere. They seem to be really involved in the community and use and sell a lot of local products (Local Beer, King of Pops, etc.) 

We have been 3 times now, and really just find it to be sub-par for our expectations. We have tried various dogs and sandwiches. Most recently, we both had the "signature dog" with Chili, onions, beans, bacon, jalapeños and mustard. We found the Chili and beans to be lacking in any flavor whatsoever. The bun and hot dog were high quality, and the hot dog gave that nice "snap" when you bit in. Despite all of those delicious sounding ingredients, we found it to be a bit pedestrian. 


We also split a side of onion rings, which were greasy and flavorless. We each took a bite and decided to throw the rest away. 

Overall, just disappointed.  I hope in time, JJ's becomes the Charlotte institution that it could be.

"The Excalibur Roundtable buffet elicited a sense of familiarity akin to that of a cafeteria-style eatery, which served as the backdrop for my critical assessment of its offerings, specifically pertaining to the morning repast. Frugality being a virtue, we opted to capitalize on a dual-benefit coupon, thereby reducing the tariff to a mere $9 per person. 

My consternation regarding the edibles was rooted in their lackluster quality, as they exhibited an unfortunate tendency towards desiccation and an unpleasant soddenness. The culinary selections, encompassing the customary breakfast items, were regrettably devoid of freshness. Such deficiencies precluded me from partaking in additional helpings. A dedicated area showcasing sweet treats, including pastries and donuts, proved underwhelming, inspiring a dismissive attitude. 

A silver lining emerged in the form of our server, whose endearing efforts to elicit mirth proved successful. 

In response to a remark posted below, it is indeed true that large-scale food production does not inherently imply mediocrity. Numerous buffets excel in providing exceptional cuisine. It is advisable to explore such establishments and avoid this particular venue."

"Encountered a predicament pertaining to the return of a gift item received during the festive season, specifically pertaining to the absence of a price tag, which led to a refusal by the retail staff to offer in-store credit, despite the fact that the identical item was prominently displayed on the shelf, thereby necessitating the involvement of the customer service department, whereupon the issue was successfully resolved through the diligent efforts of the corporate customer relations team, thereby warranting a positive rating, albeit with a slight deduction due to the initial inconvenience caused by the price tag-related debacle."

This establishment evinced an atmosphere of melancholy, which was further accentuated by the dearth of patronage during what was ostensibly the peak period of the week. Notwithstanding the assertion that our presence was requited without any pecuniary obligation, we opted to partake in the ambiance, albeit briefly. Upon entering the premises, our attention was drawn to a group of individuals engaged in an activity known as go-go dancing. However, this spectacle proved to be the sole source of diversion, prompting us to expedite our departure in less than half an hour from the time of our arrival, while consuming a single beverage.

*bed bugs* Stayed here for a conference this week. The place is big and they seem to have nice pools and lounge areas, however, our room smelled bad... Like musty and also like smoke. I really was unhappy with the smell. My girlfriends and I stayed in two separate rooms. After the first night one of my gf's woke up with 6-7 bites and was left uncomfortable and itching the entire trip. The second night of our stay ( i was staying in a different room) I was also bit! I went to sleep fine and woke up with two bites on my ankles. Just a side note, we never had the doors open and we were in two separate rooms.  We both sleep with the blankets covering us as well so I have determined that this is most likely a bed bug issue. My last night I was bit again twice and now I'm home and happy to be here. I am frustrated though that I am itching like crazy, just felt dirty yuck! I gave two stars because the facility is nice, but I don't think getting bit is acceptable.

First and foremost, it is imperative to acknowledge that this particular establishment is not a traditional Costco, but rather a specialized "business center." This distinction is crucial, as it significantly impacts the products and services offered, and thus, it is essential to emphasize this point to avoid any potential disappointment or confusion among patrons.  

In light of this, it is relevant to highlight that this specific Costco does not sell alcoholic beverages, which may come as a surprise to some individuals who are accustomed to purchasing such items at other Costco locations. Furthermore, there is no food court available on the premises, which may also be a departure from the typical Costco experience that some customers are familiar with. However, it is worth noting that this absence is compensated by the abundance of exceptional dining options and buffets in the surrounding area, which can easily satisfy any culinary cravings.  

This particular Costco focuses primarily on providing an extensive selection of snacks and beverages, intended for the purpose of restocking vending machines. In fact, they even offer vending machines for purchase, which speaks to the unique nature of this business-oriented store. One redeeming quality of this establishment is the diverse array of beverages available, ranging from juices, sodas, sparkling water, cider, and more, which is undoubtedly impressive.  

Unfortunately, this Costco falls short in terms of staffing, with relatively few employees present, and those who are on duty often appear uninformed about various aspects of the store's operations. For instance, upon inquiring about the availability of coupon books, a staff member incorrectly directed me to the guest/member service desk, only to discover that they do not, in fact, accept coupons at this location.  

In conclusion, given the distinct characteristics of this Costco "business center," it is advisable to carefully consider one's shopping needs before visiting, and perhaps opt for a different location, such as the Costco in Los Angeles, before embarking on a trip to Las Vegas.

"What an exasperating experience!"

Best aspect of today's midday repast was the hospitality - Anthony, a native of Astoria, Queens, New York City, who has been resident here for eight months, possessed a dialect that was reminiscent of his origins, which was utterly fitting given his occupation as a server in an Italian eatery!  His demeanor was helpful, attentive, interactive, and one of the most exceptional examples of fine service I have encountered within this metropolis.  Moreover, he presented a sample of the soup du jour for our perusal before we placed our orders.  Exceptional hospitality indeed - bravo, Anthony!

The comestibles, however, garnered decidedly mixed critiques.  The tilapia special was devoured with relish by both individuals at our table who opted for it.  Culinary staff, please take note: the portions varied conspicuously between the two plates, despite the fact that the lesser quantity happened to be consumed by the individual who customarily indulges in less food; thus, it did not pose a problem.  When identical dishes are concurrently presented to two patrons seated at the same table, it is imperative that the plates appear identical!

I initiated my repast with the minestrone soup (a staple offering on the menu), and although its flavor was palatable, it was served at a disappointingly tepid temperature.  This elicited a feeling of melancholy.  Furthermore, my meatball sandwich was somewhat lacking in warmth and excessively salty.  Alas, it failed to possess the freshness I had anticipated.

Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the concluding segment of our meal, comprising lemon cookies adorned with two striking candles, served as a pleasant conclusion to our dining experience.  Moreover, the cookies themselves were delectable - possessing an adequate degree of sweetness, a discernible lemon essence without being overpowering, and sufficient sufficiency to facilitate sharing among the assemblage at our table.

A notice posted on the entrance indicates that as of February 1st, this establishment will adopt a smoke-free policy.

--lost its traditional feel through the remodel. where has the personality gone?
--bulky dark wooden chairs need cushions, the whole place needs more fabric. great potential with lots of light and high ceilings. More bright mexican ceramics please. stark wall of crosses and exposed wood and wrought iron takes me straight to Nathan Lane's Birdcage apartment. LOL.
--remodel great for small (150ppl) wedding parties with dance floor in the center of the room.

--rice dry and unflavorful, no savor. beans again with no flavor.
--table salsa is canned tomato sauce with pepper seeds and BASIL and the touch of sugar you get from Ragu! It's salsa, not marinara, people!
--guacamole has cottage cheese as a thickener! ew!
--chili colorado is just thick, no flavor.
--service is slow and unhelpful, but prices are high high.
--$9 for the cheese crisp is worth it. great crispiness and good cheese blend.

Staying at the Sunset Station, which by the way was much better than I had expected it to be.

Well Gus had some folks to meet for dinner and I was on my own. Figuring I would get something and take up to the room I walked around a couple of times and decided on Fatburger.

The young lady was quite personable with each who approached. She took my order of a burger with whatever it is they put on them and since the sign said the onion rings were the best you know one always believes signs I too had an order with a shake. And I wonder why I am a fat old man. 

It took very few minutes to get my order and off to the room I go. Well the burger was a mushy mess of no distinct tastes, I truly hated it and the onion rings were bland at best. The shake... ok.

It was mentioned that we should stop at a fatburger the other day and this memory popped up and I shuddered, never again...

Not what I expected.  Food was good, but nothing special.  Portions seemed small.  I really did not expect the stand in line to place your order, go find a seat and wait for someone to bring your food, and then you never get spoken to again. Reminds me of McDonalds.  We got Thai Dynamite, which sounds spicy, but was bland, and sesame chicken, which was so so.\nWhile we were there, we saw someone spill a large amount of salt or sugar on the floor right by a door.  Saw a server going out the door about fall, and then 4 employees walk by it before it got cleaned up around 5-10 minutes later.  Lawsuit waiting to happen.\nDon't think we'll go back :(

I decided to visit this establishment due to its favorable rating on Yelp, as my companion and I were craving Mexican cuisine. Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the green chili plate, while my companion selected the carne asada burrito, which we supplemented with an order of menudo to share. Unfortunately, upon consuming our meals, we found them to lack the authentic flavor we had anticipated, and instead, they were rather uninspiring and lackluster. Considering the abundance of superior dining options in the vicinity, specifically Filiberto's, we felt our experience was subpar. The sole redeeming aspects of our visit were the promptness with which our food was prepared and served, as well as the cordial demeanor of the staff member who attended to us. Ultimately, our expectations were not met, leaving us feeling disappointed and disinclined to return.

"Prior to our arrival, I articulated to my companion that we should brief respite from our culinary excursion, but alas, we opted to persevere. Upon ingress, the eatery appeared tidy and welcoming; however, our server, though industrious, was the sole representative of hospitality during the luncheon hour. My culinary selection, a fish burrito, materialized approximately fifteen minutes subsequent to our order placement. Alas, it proved to be an unfortunate choice, as the dish contained scant vegetation, mediocre rice, and a breaded, fried fish fillet reminiscent of a shoe sole. In point of fact, I have previously enjoyed a superior fish burrito at Del-Taco, situated directly across the street. My comrade's chicken sizzling fajita, while promptly delivered and emitting an appetizing aroma, regrettably lacked gastronomical depth and featured undercooked rice and a venerable salad as accompaniments. Notwithstanding, the accompanying guacamole and sour cream were fresh. It is worth mentioning that the establishment's salsa exhibited commendable flavor, striking a satisfactory balance between piquancy and palatability. Thus, if seeking merely a snack of chips and salsa accompanied by a brew, this locality may suffice. Nevertheless, a visit to this restaurant for a fulfilling dining experience is not recommended."

We had their special Tomahawk steak $98, Glazed Sea Bass $39, sides with asparagus $14, and hand cut fries $12. We don't eat our food bland, in fact slightly on the salty side, but all the food here was just a bit too salty. It will definitely spike your blood pressure. The best part of this experience was the ambiance. Definitely chic and their bathroom is really different.

"My affection towards the apparel offered by this establishment is juxtaposed by my utter disdain for the service provided by its employees. It appears that an inordinate number of errors occur during my visits, with today's experience being particularly egregious. Upon presenting five items at the checkout counter, I discovered upon returning home that one item was missing. This managerial malfeasance was perpetrated by a junior manager who, after a ten-minute duration of fumbling and blatantly disregarding my queries, ultimately managed to process the transaction. My ire towards the necessity of revisiting this store is palpable."

"The prices for the services offered by this establishment are reasonable, however, the duration of time allocated for the cleaning process, specifically pertaining to the washing and vacuuming of my vehicle, is somewhat excessive, amounting to a total of 45 minutes, which raises some reservations regarding the efficiency of the service, thus leaving me uncertain about the prospect of becoming a repeat customer."

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are merely adequate, with the exception of the Red Jade Chicken, which truly stands out as a gastronomic masterpiece. My initial visit was characterized by a sense of excitement and anticipation, owing to the innovative concept that underlies the menu. Unfortunately, the execution fell short of my expectations, with the majority of dishes failing to impress. The Red Jade Chicken, however, was a notable exception, boasting an complexity of flavors and textures that elevated it to a status worthy of praise."

"Extremely sluggish, even in the absence of an abundance of patrons, and utterly chaotic, this establishment exhibits a palpable lack of efficiency, rendering it arduous for clientele to effectuate transactions expeditiously; furthermore, the utilization of the Starbucks application as a means of payment is unfeasible, as staff members are compelled to manually input the requisite numerical information, thereby exacerbating the already prolonged duration of the purchasing process."

I came here with my parents before going to see Zumanity because it didn't have a wait time. I should have just waited the 30 minutes to be seated somewhere else.

DRINKS:
I ordered a glass of Sangiovese. I normally love Sangiovese, but I didn't even want to finish the glass.
My mom got a cocktail with limoncello, which wasn't too bad.
Overall: B

FOOD:
I ordered soup and their salad special that day (cucumbers, "fresh" tomatoes, onions, red vinaigrette, and feta). The salad was terrible. I thought it had marinated tomatoes at first, but then realized it had just been sitting pre-made in a fridge for awhile -- the tomatoes were that ice-cold. I ended up picking at it, but not eating it.
My mom got the rare veal ($30+), and she also ended up barely eating it because it was just way over-marinated. It still had a vinegary taste to it. I normally love all red meat, and even I didn't like it, so she wasn't just being picky.
Overall: D

SERVICE:
Our server didn't come ask us how the meal was until we were pretty much done picking at it 30 minutes later. Admittedly, when she realized we didn't like the food, she did have one of her superiors come talk to us, who offered to get us something else. We didn't have time for something else, so they didn't charge us for the salad or the veal. 
Overall: C

"The culinary offerings were merely adequate, while the service provided by our server was utterly subpar. In our group of four individuals, three of us enjoyed reasonably satisfying repasts, whereas my son's Philly cheesesteak dish was unfortunately a saturated disaster. We pondered returning it, but the server's absence and subsequent lackadaisical approach to her duties rendered that option moot. Upon her return, she displayed a complete lack of interest in her profession, mechanicaly going through the motions with an air of indifference. My son requested water, which she neglected to provide... I shall not patronize this establishment again during future visits to Las Vegas."

Slow service and 15-20 for mediocre philly cheese steaks.  Sandwiches and fries do not have a lot of flavor.  Also the televisions are blaring loud, if you have sensitive hearing beware.  Seating is limited.

"Avenue Q was utterly captivating; nevertheless, it is imperative to acknowledge that the production features a touring cast. Furthermore, my experience at the Gammage Auditorium was less than satisfactory, particularly in terms of accessibility. While the exterior appearance may be visually appealing, albeit with some broken light fixtures, the interior design leaves much to be desired in terms of modernity and functionality. Specifically, the facilities for people with disabilities are woefully inadequate, rendering it challenging for individuals with mobility impairments to fully participate in the theatrical experience. Upon inquiring about the location of the elevator, I received a brusque response informing me that none existed, and that accessible seating options were only available at a premium price point. As someone who walks with a cane and experiences fatigue easily, navigating multiple flights of stairs proved to be an arduous task that left me feeling distressed and marginalized. Moreover, the lack of empathy displayed by staff members towards my plight only exacerbated my frustration. It is unfortunate that a venue hosting a satirical examination of prejudice would itself perpetuate ableism and classism through its architecture and customer service."
Waited an hour and was disappointed by the food.. I had banana pancakes and a breakfast skillet.  The pancakes were chewy.  The skillet had no flavor.

"Mid Town Pub has been a regular haunt of mine, but due to recent events, I will be compelled to seek an alternative venue. On a previous occasion, I requested the chicken cordon bleu sandwich, but what I received was a culinary abomination; a dish consisting of chicken smothered in an excessive amount of jalapeÃ±os. Upon bringing this to the attention of the server, they hastily replaced it with a similar dish, albeit devoid of the aforementioned jalapeÃ±os, but regrettably, the poultry was still infused with an overpowering essence of said peppers. I did not partake in its consumption, yet I was still charged for it. 

Despite this unfortunate experience, I opted to grant the kitchen a second chance during a subsequent visit. Unfortunately, the sandwich I was presented with was equally inedible. The bread was saturated with an excess of salt and pepper, rendering the initial bite an utter disappointment. 

It appears that this kitchen requires some semblance of direction and refinement. Farewell, Mid Town Pub."

During our brief sojourn at this establishment, my spouse and I had the pleasure of occupying a luxurious suite that offered a panoramic view of the interior courtyard. Unfortunately, our stay was marred by the cacophony generated by the delivery trucks and tour buses that converged on the premises at an ungodly hour, creating a racket that was nothing short of deafening. Moreover, we were dismayed to discover that the suite was bereft of even the most basic utensils, including spoons and bottle openers, which made it challenging to enjoy our complimentary continental breakfast. However, the piece de resistance was the nightly happy hour that took place in the expansive breakfast room from 5:30 pm to 7:30 pm, during which time complimentary cocktails and light beer were served to a motley crew of mostly elderly patrons who seemed to be taking advantage of the libations to medicate themselves for the evening ahead. The scene was both amusing and surreal, as my wife and I observed the throngs of seniors shuffling around the pool table with their tiny plastic cups of cocktails or light beer, creating an atmosphere that resembled a nursing home on steroids.

I concur with a previous reviewer that the establishment boasts a well-intentioned concept, which is reflected in its decor and atmosphere that exudes a sense of cleanliness, comfort, and warmth. While the service was not exceptional, it was adequate. Unfortunately, the culinary offerings did not meet my expectations, thereby precluding the possibility of a future visit. 

As a family that adheres to a gluten-free diet, we were thrilled to learn that the restaurant offered an array of gluten-free options. We ordered the Vegetarian Antipasto, Flatbread Trio, Chicken Caesar Salad, and two pizzas, all of which were gluten-free versions. Alas, our excitement was short-lived, as the gluten-free crust and flatbread were unpalatable due to their rigid texture and lack of flavor. In fact, my homemade gluten-free pizza crust and packaged versions purchased from Whole Foods far surpassed the quality of those served at this establishment. Additionally, the pizza sauce was excessively sweetened, the salad was overpowered by dressing, the Antipasto was devoid of taste, and the flatbread was unimpressive. The dips served alongside the meal were merely average. 

It is regrettable that our dining experience did not meet our expectations, and we hope that subsequent visits will reveal notable improvements. We eagerly await the opportunity to revisit and sample their menu again, as we wholeheartedly support the proliferation of healthy and organic restaurants in Henderson.

I am a vegetarian and was eagerly anticipating dining at this establishment, which had been highly recommended. However, upon perusing the menu, I was dismayed to discover that they offer genuine animal flesh, which is antithetical to my dietary preferences. Despite this, I must admit that my unsweetened iced tea, which I had mixed with mango lemonade (a concoction that I had created myself), was quite delectable. The side salad that accompanied my pannini was also impressive, boasting an array of fresh, crisp ingredients. Unfortunately, the pannini itself was rather unpalatable, as it lacked the rich, savory flavors that I have come to expect from such a dish. Moreover, the fact that it contained tofurky, a plant-based meat substitute, made it seem like a poor imitation of a true pannini. The highly recommended red velvet cake was somewhat redeeming, as it possessed a satisfying texture and flavor profile, despite its relatively low caloric and fat content. However, my overall experience was marred by the sluggish pace of the service, which, combined with the limited number of patrons, made for a rather underwhelming dining experience. Thus, I must express my disappointment and reluctance to return to this establishment in the future.

The waitress we had here was horrible.  The bus boy gave us more attention than she did.  I say give him her job!  The food was OK nothing spectacular, a little over priced, but you are paying for the ambiance I guess.

The food was perfect.
The ambiance was perfect.
The service was really REALLY bad.

We got to the restaurant, the hostess girl just seemed not to care. I think that's really the best way to put it, she just didn't care, like she's worked there for too long and she just doesn't care. When we got there she told us that the table was being setup, and the silverware must have been flown in from China while we waited, because we waited for 30min for that setup.

Out server was even worse. After we got seated it took 20min for him to come by and give us the menus, then another 20min until he stopped by again to take out drink orders and we ordered food as well getting the sense of their pace. Then another 20min for HALF our party to get their drink orders.

We had to chase the waiter down for round x2 drinks that were promised and of course came only after another 20min of waiting.

Beginning of the night the waiter told us that Vintner is Strip quality food off the Strip. Well on the Strip, Strip quality food also tends to come with Strip quality service.

What a shame really. The food was good and the ambience was fantastic. But the wait stuff was so bad it's stupid.

I would not recommend this restaurant.

"My initial acquaintance with Buffalo Exchange transpired subsequent to my return from Santa Barbara, and my profound disappointment at having missed the opportunity to visit the store was palpable. Upon discovering the presence of a branch in Las Vegas, my expectations were elevated, as I anticipated securing high-quality, pre-owned designer items at reasonable prices. However, upon entering the establishment, my hopes were promptly dashed, as the atmosphere and inventory bore an uncanny resemblance to Plato's Closet, a business I have previously expressed disdain for. The abundance of undesirable attire and the apathetic demeanor of the staff left me feeling underwhelmed and disinclined to peruse the merchandise further. After a cursory examination of the premises, I concluded that it was not worthwhile to expend time and effort at any of their locations."

We were meandering along the strip with a couple of acquaintances when we chanced upon this establishment. Our attention was drawn to its boisterous ambiance, with the music being quite captivating. Although we had no intention of halting, a companion opted to acquire some beverages from their bar due to the reasonable price of two for the price of one. As we awaited his return, one of the gentlemen stationed outside endeavored to entice us to enter for a fee of $15 per individual, which we respectfully declined. We continued to move away, only to have him pursue us and offer a reduced price of $10 each. We maintained our stance and continued to depart, leading him to approach us once more and propose an entry fee of $5 apiece. We remained steadfast in our decision and eventually gained admittance gratis following a brief negotiation. Upon entering, we lingered for approximately half an hour to an hour, during which time we appreciated the vigorous atmosphere and melodious tunes, while finding the beverages to be reasonably priced. However, our experience was somewhat marred by the unremarkable quality of the female patrons and the presence of males who exhibited characteristics commonly associated with fraternity members who had been expelled from their respective organizations. Consequently, we elected to vacate the premises, and I personally would not consider returning.

"A paltry serving of three diminutive poultry strips, precariously positioned atop a heap of limp, sodden potatoes. The audacity to proffer such an uninspired dish at an exorbitant price point of nine dollars is truly astounding. Needless to say, I shall decline this unappealing offer with extreme prejudice."

I recently underwent a comprehensive examination of my vehicle's mechanical condition, accompanied by a routine maintenance procedure involving the replacement of lubricants, and I must say that the experience left much to be desired in terms of the quality of service provided by the sole individual responsible for attending to my automotive needs. His manner of communication, characterized by a remarkable lack of articulacy and an unfortunate tendency towards primitive, grunted utterances, did little to inspire confidence in his abilities or foster a sense of trust between us. Suffice it to say that I shall not be returning to this particular establishment for any future automotive requirements.

There is absolutely no reason to dine here for Mexican food....it is non descript...no pride in preparation or presentation.  It is just bland food.  Service is very good but that does not make up for bad food....from the chips to the finale'....bad...and very noisy with screaming and misbehaving children.\n\nTry Lindo Michoac\u00e1n on Desert Inn...is was good but hope we can even find one that is better...it is an easy 3 star

I waited for an awesome meal at a place I visited over a decade ago.  I remember the prime rib, crab and seafood from before but I was disappointed in the selection this time. It had more Chinese, Mexican and fruits than I remember.  I saw no real potatoe dishes other than mashed.  Sushi wasn't good.  However the prime rib as great, crab was abundant and calamari excellent.  Pre-made salads were not good.  My husband is a meat and potatoes and he barely found stuff to eat.  I would like to see a price that matches the lack of selection.  I would like to see more sushi that tastes good and more hot crab than cold crab.

"I thoroughly enjoyed the culinary offerings of the previous establishment, specifically their delectable burritos, flavorful fondue cheese dip, and savory steak salads, accompanied by an array of refreshing cocktails, including the quintessential margarita, available during their happy hour. However, upon visiting the new location, I was dismayed to discover that certain aspects of the dining experience did not meet my expectations. Despite the novelty of the setting, I was taken aback by the absence of a frozen margarita machine, which I deemed a crucial component of the ambiance. Furthermore, there were noticeable inconsistencies in the quality of the food, particularly with regards to the texture and flavor of the rice, beans, and chicken in both the burrito and fajita dishes I ordered. Additionally, I requested hot sauce on the side, but it was incorporated into the dish instead. To compound matters, we failed to receive our subsequent round of beverages, despite having ordered them. While the service was adequate, I cannot help but feel a sense of nostalgia for the former establishment, and thus, I implore the management to consider reviving the essence of the original Salty Senorita, which, in my opinion, would greatly enhance the overall dining experience."

"Despite the amicable demeanor of the personnel, the financial investment required to partake in the culinary offerings of this establishment far surpasses the tangible value of the consumables served, particularly in reference to the pastrami sandwich, which, regrettably, failed to meet expectations. Furthermore, while the eatery possesses inherent potential, my personal inclination is to avoid revisiting it in the near future."

Their chips and fries are good.  We could've had more to choose from if the menus were all in the same spot.  One is by the door, the other is behind the counter.  Where one would figure a menu should be.  It was our first time there so we ordered.  Then saw a hotdog,...asked the girl at the counter where it was on the menu, and she said it was behind us.  Hmmm... of course the menu would be behind us.

Also, when we were there, there was no ice.  I asked the girl if there it just needed to be refilled, but she said just to wait until it makes more ice.  What the heck???

Cashiers could be a little friendlier.

"Not suitable for every individual. Despite the fact that children might experience a moderate degree of enjoyment, two adults seeking a meaningful and engaging experience may find Rawhide lacking in substance. Following the payment of $5 for parking, we invested approximately 30 minutes of our time exploring the faux town and captured several photographs. However, it is highly debatable whether the visit was truly necessary. Thus, it is not recommended to prioritize Rawhide on one's list of must-see attractions in the region, unless one harbors an exceptional fondness for Western themes and finds the artificial town captivating."

Great yogurt place and close by!!! Also .35 per ounce great price!!!\nBut we went there yesterday  7:25p, dark and closed!?! I called number on door and VM said open Sat til 9.....I left a msg: Where are y'all!?!?! Don't understand how a business thinks they can run with this kind of behavior!!

"Refrain from visiting this establishment, as it is plagued by an array of issues that detract from the dining experience. Firstly, patrons are subjected to an interminable wait for seating, with a prolonged delay of approximately 45 minutes. Furthermore, the staff appears to be remiss in their responsibilities, as evidenced by the lack of table clearing. The cuisine, while adequate, falls short of expectations, with the beef short rib being particularly disappointing due to its extreme toughness and grisly texture, rendering it nearly impossible to cut with a knife. In light of these deficiencies, it is advisable to avoid this venue altogether. Notwithstanding, the buffet does offer some palatable options, but the extended wait for a clean table unfortunately negates any potential enjoyment."

Poor service by the wait staff is my biggest complaint. We were there at 5:00 (and it wasn't busy yet), and it took probably 15 minutes to place our order. \n\nFinally, $16.95 for a fish fry. Yowzers!

"My spouse and I ventured to this establishment with the intention of procuring sandwiches. Our initial inclination was to visit Quizno's, but upon observing this venue, we opted to sample its offerings instead. Following my placement of an order for a Chicken Gyro, Chicken Kabob, and Baba Ghanouj for takeout, my thoughts began to wander aimlessly, drawing an association with the television program "Kitchen Nightmares" for reasons unknown to me. Upon the completion of our order, we retrieved it and returned home. The Chicken Gyro featured generous portions of poultry, yet the slices could have benefited from being more slender. Unfortunately, the pita bread used for our "to-go" order became partially saturated with the juices emanating from the tomato and onion components. My kabob proved to be a letdown, consisting of thick, dry strips of chicken that did not align with my expectations of chunky meat. Eating it presented a challenge, prompting me to consume only the chicken. The Baba Ghanouj, on the other hand, was utterly unpalatable, resembling a watery mixture overpowered by olive oil. We found it unbearable, limiting ourselves to a single bite. In contrast, the most delectable Baba Ghanouj I have had the pleasure of savoring was at Sabuddy, an Israeli restaurant that regrettably shut down due to the proprietor's return to New York. As for the sandwiches, the pita bread demonstrated exceptional quality, and I intend to enjoy it on the premises during my next visit, forgoing the "to-go" option."

I went here due to the price and word of mouth. It is walk-in only, NO APPOINTMENTS! I had to wait 90 minutes. I was not offered a choice of male or female, good thing since I don't have a preference. I told him to focus on my neck, between shoulder blades, and mostly my sciatica. He asked me how long to work on each section, what a sciatica was, and what trigger points to work on for the sciatica. He didn't use time management skills, didn't know terminology or anatomy, and fussed with the sheets and draping a lot. It took 5 tries each time he moved the sheet to get it right. After he finished, he didn't get me any water or recommend anything like stretching or aromatherapy or epsom salt baths. I would go here with caution....

"My anticipation to experience this establishment was piqued by the copious acclaim it received during my sojourn in New York; however, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled upon my visit. Specifically, I was disheartened by the unremarkable culinary offerings presented before me, despite the expedient service and generous portion sizes. Furthermore, I found the prices to be somewhat exorbitant in relation to the quality of the fare provided. Notwithstanding, my taste buds did derive some satisfaction from the sweet potato fries, which served as a solitary bright spot amidst an otherwise underwhelming dining experience."

"Disappointing encounter with in-room dining ~ 

Previously, we had contacted the establishment to inquire about the cost and portion size of their chicken wing offerings. Initially, we were informed that six wings would be provided for $16 during the daytime, while 12 wings would be offered for the same price after 10 pm. However, upon placing our order around 11 pm, we received only six wings, which prompted us to contact room service again. Upon doing so, we were told that we should have received 12 wings, and the representative proceeded to place me on hold to investigate the matter further. 

Upon returning to the line, the representative revealed that the menu had been altered, which resulted in the reduction of wings provided for the same price. This revelation was accompanied by an apology, but it failed to mitigate our frustration with the subpar service we had received. It is unacceptable for a business to use a menu change as a pretext for poor customer service. 

We purchased two orders of chicken wings, amounting to 12 wings for $41, which we would not have done had the hotel not misled us. Moreover, the order did not leave us feeling satiated in the slightest. 

As frequent users of in-room dining services, this experience was particularly disconcerting. 

Despite this unsatisfactory encounter, our overall experience at the Delano remains adequate. The hotel's relatively low occupancy rate and elegant ambiance contribute to its appeal, and the daily quotations displayed near the elevators have become our favorite aspect of the establishment."

This establishment serves as an exemplary illustration of a tourist trap, boasting a picturesque location merely a short distance removed from the primary thoroughfare of Old Scottsdale, a visually appealing edifice, and an intricately designed layout.  While the margaritas are undoubtedly palatable, their prices are considerably higher than warranted, ranging between $2 and $3 for each diverse style.  My satisfaction was further diminished upon discovering that the complimentary chips and salsa commanded a price premium of $5, only to be met with disappointment upon sampling the stale flavor of the chips.  As a venue sporting both 'tortilla' and 'factory' in its moniker, it is reasonable to expect fresher chips.  My assessment of the tortillas themselves was neutral, neither exceptional nor deplorable.
