Unfortunately, the carne fuego, or whatever alternative the wait staff recommended, proved to be unsatisfactory.  Bite-sized pieces of fire-roasted steak were thoroughly spoiled by a syrupy sweet and spicy sauce, accompanied by unremarkable vegetables and a peculiar sweet potato-filled chile that fell short of excellence.  Absent any culinary novice relatives visiting from out of town, it is advisable to avoid this eatery altogether.

Apparently, when one opted to expend $185 to engage in recreational activity on the golf course, it seemed utterly impractical to eliminate the grass clippings from the fairways by means of a sudden gust of air. I do not intend to convey the notion that I am an elitist individual, as I am undoubtedly not; however, upon residing in Scottsdale for nearly a decade and experiencing the course for the initial time with such a substantial price attached to it, one would anticipate a level of excellence that sadly did not manifest itself. The greens presented a sluggish pace, and the overall state of the course was merely average. Although I acknowledge that every establishment is undergoing or has recently completed their overseed process, charging such a fee for the condition it was in appeared somewhat comical. Personally, if I were to invest such capital, I would greatly prefer to partake in recreation at We-ko-pa or Troon North.

**Updated Review-
Based on my last experience - the service here is so-so at best.  The "kids" behind the counter are unattentive.  I had to literally shout to get them to notice that they had a guest in the lobby.  If it weren't for the fact that this location is at the bottom of the hill of Las Sendas - I probably would not return and instead opt for a different location.

Store Manager/Owner - This is YOUR opportunity to make this right.  I am pretty generous/fair on my reviews and this location is by-far the weakest of all in the Mesa Valley.

**********

It's Rosatis.  True nothing will ever taste as good as Pizza (incl. Rosatis) that you actually get IN Chicago because of the water quality west of the Mississippi is fair at best, this Rosatis does a really good job.

The kid that took our order was pretty cool-chill.  Brought it out to us in ~15 minutes - piping hot!  The sausage at Rosatis is awesome.

We visit this location every time we come to visit Dad/Mom since they live in the adjacent neighborhood.

Tip - order extra cheese - it is so worth it...the grease dripping all over - esp. from the pepperoni.

"THE GOOD: Ridiculously economical lodging options, with rooms available for a mere $35 per night. FAT TUESDAYS offers large quantities of alcoholic beverages at a relatively low cost, specifically their signature giant Everclear drinks, which may have contributed to my temporary memory loss. The sleeping quarters were exceptionally comfortable, boasting cleanliness and superior bedding. Hairdresser Elvis was an additional amenity. 

THE BAD: The quoted price failed to include the mandatory $5 per night resort fee, which was an unpleasant surprise. Only two members of the hotel staff displayed courteous behavior towards us, with one staff member even laughing at our friend over the phone when she requested additional towels. Although situated far from the strip, the hotel's proximity to downtown Las Vegas was a welcome advantage. 

THE HIDEOUSLY UGLY: The rooftop pool, reserved for patrons who preferred to sunbathe sans clothing, was an unsightly spectacle. The absence of a bar and the prevalence of imposing, muscular men and large, voluptuous women donning minimal attire made for an uncomfortable atmosphere. While body confidence is commendable, this setting did not foster a welcoming environment.

In conclusion, while the hotel offered some positive aspects, I would opt for a more luxurious establishment, with a greater emphasis on customer satisfaction and a more reasonable pricing structure, thereby avoiding the need for a costly taxi ride."

P.S. The question remains, why do parents choose to bring their offspring to Las Vegas, a city renowned for its adult entertainment and indulgences?

"It is truly perturbing to encounter establishments purporting to specialize in a particular geographical area's gastronomical delights, yet failing to deliver an authentic representation of said cuisine, which, in my opinion, is a grave injustice to the rich culinary heritage of the region in question. 

As an individual with limited familiarity regarding the intricacies of Greek gastronomy, I must admit that my expectations for an genuine Hellenic dining experience have been disappointed on multiple occasions, leading me to surmise that there exists a discrepancy between the quality of the ingredients utilized in the preparation of these dishes and the standard of freshness I have come to expect from a reputable eatery. 

In a city such as Las Vegas, where the restaurant industry is highly competitive and susceptible to the fluctuations of the economic climate, it is imperative that establishments prioritize the quality of their offerings, lest they risk falling prey to the perils of financial decline."

"Indubitably, this particular route serves as the most feasible means of accessing the city of Las Vegas, which has evolved into a preeminent tourist destination boasting an array of extravagant casinos, luxurious hotels, and elaborate entertainment venues. However, it is worth noting that the once-luminous appeal of this city has diminished somewhat over time, with certain areas adopting a more tawdry ambiance, while the convenience of navigating its streets has become increasingly challenging for visitors. Moreover, it is uncertain whether alternative methods of transportation exist that would facilitate a more enjoyable excursion, given that the nearby airport may not necessarily constitute the pinnacle of one's travel experience."

Went in today to check out the home visit prices and see what all they had to offer. 

Walking into the place you got hit by a wall of odor.  I know having lots of dogs in a small space won't make any room smell like roses, however I would like to think that they clean the place every once in a while.

I then asked about a service listed on the flyer and the website and was told that they don't do that.  Then why list it???  I also didn't like how from the front office you couldn't see into where they kept the dogs, though I could hear them all going crazy.

On my way out I realized that you could see in through the side from broken blinds.  There were a ton of dogs in a small space with no one in sight.  Also, side note from looking at the pictures on yelp...Yes, they have couches instead of cages but those couches look dangerous since they are so broken. I wouldn't wan my dog sitting on or running near that.

Since I haven't actually used the service I won't give it only one star, but from what I've seen I will not be back or calling for home service thats for sure.  It would have been perfect too, since I live only a mile away.

Well, this place is good.  The food is kind of that outdated tropical fare and lacks any sort of innovation.  The atmosphere has that TGI fridays chain feeling to it, but instead of shit on the walls its upscale tropical.\n\nI wouldnt really go back unless i was invited by someone else.

Knocking you guys down a star. The place has become a rather hit & miss as of my latest visit. Broth used to be richer, portion more generous, service has gotten a bit more prompt not enough to warrant the 3star.\n\nTime for a new backup pho place?

This particular specimen of a cupcake, which I have had the misfortune of sampling, must unequivocally be designated as the most unpalatable and insipid exemplar of its genre that I have had the displeasure of encountering thus far in my existence. Furthermore, it is utterly reprehensible that such an exorbitant price tag would be attached to this mediocre culinary creation, especially considering the plethora of superior alternatives available at a fraction of the cost at local supermarkets. However, I must admit that the milkshakes served here do possess a certain je ne sais quoi that sets them apart from their peers in terms of sheer gustatory satisfaction.

Finally, I had the opportunity to visit Greenberg's and indulge in their renowned Pastrami Sandwich; as I observed the skilled woman expertly slice the meat, I couldn't help but notice the generous portion she was allocating onto each sandwich. My mouth began to water uncontrollably at the prospect of consuming such a delectable meal. When she presented it to me, the pastrami was overflowing from the confines of the rye bread, much like an overstuffed sausage casing. My anticipation was palpable. However, upon taking my first bite, I was taken aback by the lack of the distinctive pastrami flavor that I had been expecting. I added salt and mustard in an attempt to enhance the taste, but to no avail. The peppery essence that I had been eagerly anticipating was nowhere to be found. Furthermore, there was an unusual lingering sensation of fat in my mouth, which only served to further perplex me. Upon inspecting the meat, I noticed that the usual amount of marbling was present, leaving me utterly baffled. It was almost as if I had encountered a singularly unremarkable cut of meat that particular day. Despite my disappointment, I am willing to give Greenberg's another chance, if only for the sheer value of the substantial quantity of meat offered for a mere ten dollars.

"My culinary experience at this establishment was somewhat disappointing, as the fare provided was slightly too oleaginous for my taste. Furthermore, the epidermis of the poultry dish I ordered was separating, which I found rather peculiar. Considering the tariff, I expected a higher quality of cuisine. Frankly, I have visited numerous more affordable restaurants that serve genuinely authentic Asian-Fusion dishes, which were far superior to what I was served here."

"Indifferent sentiments permeated my demeanor as I reflected upon the culinary experience that had recently transpired, with a profound sense of mediocrity having been conveyed through the offering of comestibles that failed to elicit any semblance of enthusiasm or satisfaction, thereby rendering the entire episode as utterly forgettable and unremarkable in its totality; furthermore, the absence of straws for the beverages served only exacerbated my consternation, as I have an inherent aversion to imbibing liquids directly from containers in establishments that purport to provide sustenance and hospitality, and thus, this particular aspect of the dining experience proved to be a significant source of annoyance and discontent for me; additionally, the egg rolls presented a peculiar and unpleasant flavor profile reminiscent of fragrances commonly associated with personal grooming, while the chicken chow mien, though palatable, was somewhat overpriced at $5.95 for the lunch special offered on weekdays, and ultimately, the lack of attention accorded to our preferences regarding dessert left a lingering sensation of disappointment and dissatisfaction."

There were no fewer than 15 people working here the day that I went with very few people in all of Tivoli Village. I wasn't greeted by the two women who were enjoying their conversation upon my entrance, and then the same two women greeted the people behind me warmly. Then some other women who worked there were watching me like a hawk as if I had sticky fingers and was pilfering everything that I touched. So I was either totally invisible to the staff or I was a 14 year old with a couple of friends seeing how much I could throw in my bag and up my sleeves.\n\nBasically they sell H&M or Forever 21 accessories for higher prices. I'm not confident that paying more for their products would make my skin green less quickly. It's still a cheaply produced product. You could find some good stuff on clearance or as-is here, but I wouldn't ever buy anything full price here because it's definitely not quality goods.

I ardently desire that I had perused the Yelp reviews prior to reserving a room at this establishment, as my experience was marred by various inconveniences and deficiencies. Firstly, the bathroom was diminutive in size, which would not have been an issue if the entrance had opened outward; however, this was not the case. Furthermore, the power outlets in the bathroom were loose, and there were none whatsoever in the remainder of the room, rendering it challenging to charge my electronic devices. 
  During our two-night stay, the room was not serviced once, despite my efforts to notify the front desk of our absence to facilitate cleaning. I contacted them twice on the same day, but my attempts were futile. 
  Moreover, I had sent some garments to be dry cleaned, and they were expected to be ready by 9 am the following morning. However, they were not available until 11 am, causing us to be two hours behind schedule. Additionally, it took an additional 45 minutes to retrieve them and complete the check-out process. When I called the front desk to inquire about the delay, the woman who answered was as unpleasant as possible. 
  In light of these experiences, I am unlikely to return to this hotel in the future.

"Optimize your culinary experience by selecting the chicken teriyaki bowl, thereby circumventing the necessity of sampling the remaining menu items. I recently had the opportunity to partake in their tempura and teriyaki combination platter during the luncheon hour. The tempura consisted of a singular carrot and what appeared to be a zucchini, although I cannot verify its exact identity with certainty. Furthermore, there was an extended, cylindrical entity adorned with a shrimp tail, the dimensions of which led me to question whether said crustaceans are indeed of a comparable magnitude to writing utensils. Notwithstanding these observations, the two California rolls accompanying the dish were merely adequate, a fact made all the more disappointing by the absence of both ginger and wasabi, two crucial condiments that would have undoubtedly enhanced the flavors of the meal. Considering the cost of $10.82 for a midday repast, I must conclude that the establishment's offerings do not provide commensurate value. In light of this assessment, I recommend the implementation of additional lunch specials to entice prospective patrons and elevate the dining experience to a satisfactory level."

We had the privilege of hosting a family gathering at this esteemed establishment, and unfortunately, our experience was marred by certain shortcomings. Specifically, while the quality of the entrÃ©es was merely average, the service we received was subpar and left much to be desired. Despite having reserved a table well in advance, it appeared that the staff was ill-prepared to accommodate our group, resulting in an extended wait before our orders were taken. Moreover, numerous requests for wine and water had to be repeated multiple times before they were eventually fulfilled, prompting my spouse to take matters into his own hands by proceeding to the bar to procure beverages for our party.

On the southwest corner of Sandy Porter and Tryon, you'll find this Food Lion in the strip mall. I've not shopped at many FL's, so I can't tell you if this is bigger or smaller than average. What I can tell you is that the prices here seem higher than Harris-Teeter, Bi-Lo, Wal-Mart and Super Target. While they have everything you need for a full grocery shop, including frozen, dairy, produce, beer, wine and meats, it's not going to be cheap.\n\nIf you do decide to shop with the Lion on a regular basis, pick up one of their MVP shopper loyalty cards - this will save you a good bit.

"The gastronomical experience was satisfactory, however, the overall dining encounter was unpleasant and marred by numerous anomalies. Specifically, certain items were omitted from our repast, and the server failed to accommodate my specific request. Furthermore, subsequent attempts at procuring beverages proved futile, as the server disappeared for an extended period, compelling me to personally retrieve refreshments from behind the counter. Notably, this occurrence transpired without notice or intervention from the restaurant staff. Following an interval of approximately sixty minutes, a novel waitress appeared and proffered replenishments, albeit neglecting to remove the used crockery. Throughout the duration of our visit, which exceeded two hours, no inquiry was made regarding potential additional orders. Finally, the ladies' lavatory featured two stalls devoid of tissue paper, contributing to an already unsatisfactory culinary excursion."

"During my temporary sojourn at the Tropicana, I had the occasion to visit this on-site snack bar on multiple occasions. While it does offer the expected assortment of delectable treats, I couldn't help but feel that the prices were slightly exorbitant. For instance, a meager serving of gelato can set you back a hefty $7, and the quality of the gelato leaves much to be desired. In fact, a more budget-conscious option can be found at the Bellagio, where one can acquire a greater quantity of gelato for a lower price point. \n\nHowever, the self-serve frozen yogurt station presents a more economical alternative, with each ounce priced at a reasonable $0.49. Furthermore, the diverse selection of flavors available, ranging from coconut to peanut butter and even cake batter, may pique the interest of those with adventurous palates. Personally, I have always found the fro-yo trend somewhat perplexing; whenever I indulge in it, I find myself yearning for the richness and creaminess of genuine ice cream instead."

I detest this aerodrome.  It appears that my antipathy towards O'Hare was eclipsed by my abhorrence for the 'Nati (CVG) airport, which, in turn, pales in comparison to my utter disdain for Atlanta's airport.  McCarran, however, has established an unprecedented nadir in my travel experiences.  The multitude of queues, invariably extending beyond a hundred and fifty individuals, persistently plagues both the security checkpoint and taxi stands, rendering the entire process not only arduous but also exasperatingly slow.  Furthermore, the dim-wittedness of the TSA personnel at this particular airport seems to be positively correlated with the cacophony generated by the ubiquitous slot machines, thereby transforming an otherwise chaotic and ear-piercing environment into an utter nightmare.

So all this hype about Tao Beach... Got there, it was nothing like I imagined. It looked liked kiddie pools compared to the other places. \n\nIt was free cover for girls, and open bar (well drinks) until a certain time, so I can't complain. But for the guys that do have to pay cover, I think you would find it more worth it to pay cover to the other pools like Wet Republic and such.  Less cramped, and probably nicer pools too.

"Well, it's edible sustenance!! That's about all I can remark regarding The Smithfield Cafe.  
I had the so-called "daily special," an appellation that essentially encapsulates the notion of 'two eggs, bacon or sausage, and toast,' albeit in a somewhat more concise manner. The sausage was merely lukewarm, the eggs were passable, and the greasy home fries, saturated with the residual essence of the previous meals prepared that morning, exuded an unpleasant, stale quality that was by no means appealing. The coffee, while copious, lacked any discernible depth of flavor. 
The waitresses, their countenances weathered and timeworn, seemed to embody the quintessential attributes of their vocation.  
In conclusion; meh..."

Here is a succinct synopsis of our culinary experience at this establishment:

It is our considered opinion that the prices charged at this eatery are somewhat exorbitant, especially considering the fact that it is an Americanized Chinese restaurant. The average cost of a single dish was in the range of $15 to $20, which we found to be a tad steep. 

However, they do offer some unique beverages, such as Vietnamese coffee with boba, which arrives in a generous portion and is not only delightful but also quite potent. Additionally, they serve soy milk with boba and various fruits, including watermelon, and the prices for these drinks fall somewhere between $5 and $7. 

The menu selections are rather limited, comprising primarily of beef, pork, soup, rice, and noodle dishes. Notably absent from the menu are certain signature dishes commonly found at authentic Chinese restaurants, such as pan-fried noodles or combination plates like chow fun. 

We must say, however, that the ambiance of the establishment is quite pleasant, boasting attractive white and orange hand-blown glasses and stylish dÃ©cor. The service we received was adequate, and the food was prepared fresh. Particularly noteworthy were the noodles in our chow fun, which were handmade and our favorite among all the dishes we sampled. Furthermore, the salt and pepper shrimp were quite delectable. 

It is worth mentioning that while the servings are 'Ã  la carte,' or family-style, the portions are somewhat smaller than what one might expect at a traditional Chinese restaurant.

I stopped coming here when I realized I could afford to pay more than $99/night for a room in Vegas.

You're stuck at the end of the Strip, the casino is meh, the rooms are straight out of 1997, and the whole place smells vaguely of that wet towel at the bottom of your hamper that you forgot about for two weeks.

2 stars based on price and the fact that a girl once approached my group and tried to pick all of us up before stumbling away drunk....with a man's shoe print clearly visible on her left calf.

Reading some of the other reviews, I feel like I must have eaten at a different restaurant. I order two spicy tuna rolls with brown rice. Both had zero flavor and could have been molded from Elmer's paste instead of fish. \n\nMaybe I ordered the wrong thing. Seems like a good concept.

"For the price, this lodging alternative constitutes a remarkable value proposition, offering a plethora of amenities and services that cater to the diverse needs of its guests. The accommodations are clean, comfortable, and modern, boasting an impressive array of features that enhance the overall experience. The location is optimal, providing effortless access to various points of interest while affording visitors the opportunity to immerse themselves in the vibrant ambiance of the surrounding area. The guest services are truly exceptional, with a team of dedicated professionals committed to ensuring a seamless and enjoyable stay. Complimentary wireless internet access and a well-equipped fitness center further contribute to the appeal of this establishment. Of particular note is the captivating outdoor fire pit, which serves as a popular gathering spot for guests and adds to the charm of the property. The menu at the on-site restaurant merits special mention, showcasing an extensive selection of culinary delights that cater to discerning palates. However, it is important to note that the proximity of this establishment to nearby nightclubs may result in disturbance to guests, particularly those who prioritize restful slumber. This was evident during a recent visit, when the thumping bass and raucous revelry emanating from adjacent venues proved disruptive, even on a typically quieter weeknight. As such, it is crucial to consider this factor before selecting this hotel, especially for those whose sleep is paramount."

"Having been born and raised in San Diego, I possess an unwavering fondness for all things Mexican, particularly the delectable fish tacos. However, my experience at this establishment has left me feeling underwhelmed and disappointed. Despite my initial excitement, the fish tacos failed to meet my expectations. Upon receiving my order, I noticed that the fish appeared to be breaded at the restaurant, which begs the question: why bother breading the fish in the first place? The quality of the fish itself was passable, but the fact that it was served in pieces left much to be desired. Typically, when fish is cut correctly, it does not result in pieces. Furthermore, the batter lacked any discernible flavor, reminiscent of store-bought frozen fish sticks. It seemed as though the chef had taken great care in presenting the dish visually, but ultimately, it felt like leftovers. In light of this experience, I shall seek out alternative establishments for my fish taco cravings in the future. For those visiting San Diego, I recommend trying Rubio's, a fast food fish taco chain that appears to understand what the customer desires and what not to serve them. Unfortunately, Cabo's did not share this philosophy, leaving me feeling overcharged for a subpar meal."

"The culinary offerings were satisfactory, with a focus on the delectable bibimbap dish; however, the quality of service was subpar and left much to be desired, evoking a state of utter dismay and incredulity in this patron. Furthermore, the imposition of an 18% gratuity charge on the bill was deemed unreasonable and nonsensical, contributing to an overall ambiance that discourages future visits."

I went on 28th of December 2014. Everything is Okay except the STEAK. It was not the good steak I expected. I love steak and been to many steakhouses but this place is clearly overpriced. I liked oysters though.

Im rewriting my review on this place for 2 reasons. First, because the first time I came here was back in 2009. Second, when I came here the most recent time, it was not like my first. Im gonna make this short and simple for you non readers. The burger was tasteless. I understand the reason for the unlimited amount of toppings you can add to your burger. But even A-1 steaksauce, chipotle sauce and banana peppers cant hide the taste of dry ground beef. Come on Cheeburger, even Chili's has their own flavor!!! I was very disappointed when I came back here, but im over it now since I wont be back again.

In the area this afternoon on biz.  Surprisingly, I've never been to this place.

Hit the buffet - with soda it cost $8.50 give or take a few dimes.

It reminded me a little bit like Shakey's bunch 'o lunch but not quite to their  " high" standards.  Also reminded me a little of the old chuck e cheese days with my daughter but this place is a cut above chucky's 

salad bar - basic stuff - liked a few slices of peperoni on my salad !

pasta - spaghetti and elbow macaroni with two sauce options - can you say....ragu  ( actually a smidge better ) 

chicken and potato wedges - both coated the same ...hmmmm...tasted the same, too.

pizza - well....first round, THERE WAS NO PIZZA 

2nd round - pizza - had a slice of sausage and pepperoni - nothing special here - my guess is the pre-cooked, SYSCO sausage; the pepperoni had no flavor but alot of grease ! 

If i had a few young kids, i can see coming back for post-sporting events, otherwise, sorry, no return planned.

I just arrived in Madison and was pooped from a long day + travel. I was really hungry and excited for a low key, hot meal. I had a bunch of work to catch up on so searched for a vegetarian friendly place that would also deliver. I was excited to find veggie Nepalese food that was close to the hotel. Every dish, even things that seemed like sides seemed pretty expensive so I assumed the portions would be enormous. I don't want enormous portions but I also didn't want teeny portions with a high price tag. I ordered a soup and it was basically a cup of soup for over $10. I didn't order anything else sadly and am left feeling pretty hungry. Wahh. Haha. \n\nShould have read more of the reviews!!!

Updated: Echo Canyon renovation. Echo Canyon used to be my favorite trail but after this new renovation it sucks.

Parking is worse than before if that's even possible. I went on a typical Thursday afternoon and the park rangers still had to turn people away. 

As soon as you turn into the lot there is a barricade with a park ranger letting people in one at a time as soon as there is a spot available. This would be a good idea but the barricade is so close to the road that only about 5 cars can wait for a spot and not be blocking the main road.  This is very poor planning in my opinion.

As for the trail itself: they took out the stairs in the beginning and made it very steep with compressed gravel. This is actually harder than the stairs and I could definitely see people slipping off more easily.

I would not bring anyone that is out of shape to this trail. Also our furry friends are no longer welcome (no dogs allowed).

Once you get past the parking and the "improvements" to the  beginning of the trail, it is the old Echo Canyon that we all used to know and love.

Good chinese takeout here, seems to be hard to find.  This is the Hoho Cherry House.  The Hoho China Bistro is no more, but I heard it moved here.\n\nThe lunch specials are a good value, but the food here is right about average.  General Tso's is OK.  This is more along the lines of a Panda Express, but mom and pop owned.  For that, I expected more.  Nothing to rave about, but not terrible either.

"It is not customary for individuals to assess chain establishments unless they have encountered an exceptionally favorable or unfavorable occurrence. Unfortunately, this particular visit falls into the latter category. I had been eager to sample the pumpkin spice latte, but the beverage I received lacked any discernible pumpkin flavor. My companion, who has previously indulged in that specific variety, corroborated my observation after partaking in a sip. While I did not detect any significant issues with the drink itself, the conspicuous absence of pumpkin flavoring constitutes a substantial drawback, given that it is a seasonal special. My apologies, establishment."

Terribly slow drive thru and they always make my drinks wrong! Great location and a few nice baristas, but they don't make up for a poorly made $5 latte. I'd rather go out of my way to Sbucks on Trop and Fort Apache.

Food was excellent, it is summer and the bar had about 6 customers, 2 of them regulars and drunks. The lady talked at full volume to everyone in the building.\nI got the impression these people go there ever night and feel the world is better because of it. I for one will not be returning until the birds come back and there is enuf ambient noise to drown these people out. Not sure what V's should do differently other than stop serving drunks.

I hate writing this update because I used to really love Apple Spice, but the last three times we have ordered lunch there have been multiple mistakes. For a place that does catering, getting 10 lunches right doesn't really seem like too much to ask.

Today, two people ordered bread bowls. They received a very small container of soup with a slice of bread. That is not really a bread bowl.

Me and one of my vegan co-workers ordered the southwestern salad, sans cheese. It came with chicken, and on the menu it states you have to pay an additional $1 for chicken, so it would definitely be something someone needed to ask for.

One of the lunches came as a sandwich instead of a wrap, and Heather W. was missing her cookie and her juice with her meal.

Apple Spice was nice enough to replace the mistaken items (brought corrected salads, brought the actual bread bowls - although, not with new soup, brought the wrap) and bring us an extra plate of cookies, but like I said, this is the third time this type of mistake has happened. 

It's pretty expensive, the Southwestern is not even very good, and once the order comes back wrong it delays my eating for an hour + and it is just frustrating.

I'm sorry Apple Spice... you guys are great but you need to get it together.

"Upon discovering that Yalla was establishing a new location in close proximity to my residence, I experienced an elevated level of excitement, as the locality had been lacking a reputable Mediterranean cuisine establishment, and the fact that it was owned by Khoury's, my preferred dining destination, further augmented my enthusiasm.  Upon visiting the restaurant, we opted to sample a variety of dishes, including the roasted chicken sandwich, Fatoush salad complemented by chicken, and beef kabobs. The culinary experience was largely satisfying, as the rice presented a delightful combination of crispy, thin noodles and a subtle application of oil. Additionally, the hummus and Fatoush exhibited notable flavor. Although my spouse expressed no dissatisfaction with the sandwich, a few unfortunate incidents occurred. Firstly, the order was erroneously tallied, resulting in an inflated cost to myself. Furthermore, the cashier, despite displaying apologies, settled for charging me a higher amount instead of rectifying the error, which I deemed inadequate. Moreover, the pita bread failed to meet my expectations, possessing an unpleasantly stale taste. Despite these setbacks, I remained willing to give the establishment another chance. 

However, upon my return, I encountered an extended delay, waiting behind another patron for ten minutes at the counter, during which time the cashier neglected to acknowledge us or offer any form of assistance. Ultimately, we departed without placing an order, choosing instead to dine at Osaka, situated across the street."

I went with a Chinese friend who ordered in Chinese.  When one of the dishes arrived and she didn't like the look of it she then shouted a lot at the waiter (in Chinese).  After that the food was exceptional.  Easily the best Chinese food I've had in Central Illinois.  (I admit, that's a low standard.)

However, I've never been able to recreate this experience.  And how I've tried!  I ended up asking my Chinese friend to write me a note in Chinese ordering these same dishes from the Chinese menu.  I show the crumpled and worn note to the waiter when I go by myself.  But the food is never as good.  I expect it was the shouting.  Now that my friend has moved away, I expect it will never be that good again.

Without my friend to help us, this is a mediocre place.

"Pros: 
* Rapid and accommodating provision of requested items, facilitating an optimal guest experience
* Beds characterized by exceptional comfort, contributing to a restful slumber
* Aesthetically pleasing soaking tub, albeit with limited capacity

Cons: 
* Lackluster demeanor exhibited by check-in staff, detracting from the overall welcome sentiment
* Absence of convenient power outlets near sleeping areas, necessitating the utilization of extension cords for medical equipment
* Misinformation regarding the availability of a freezer, leading to disappointment and inconvenience
* Limited options for purchasing beverages, resulting in reliance on overpriced in-room refrigeration
* Byzantine nature of room switches and illumination controls, hindering effortless navigation
* Bathroom sink design, seemingly intentionally engineered to maximize moisture dispersal and compromise the integrity of personal belongings

Comparative analysis: While both hotels offer palatable attributes, The Hotel enjoys a slight advantage in terms of overall quality and guest satisfaction, eclipsing Aria's drawbacks."

I had the pleasure of visiting a Brazilian steakhouse previously, in Dallas, and it was utterly sublime. Unfortunately, my expectations were not met at Braza's, as the quality of the food did not live up to its predecessor. While some of the meats were satisfactory, such as the flank steak and chicken, others like the sirloin were unimpressive and lacked flavor. Additionally, the ambiance of the restaurant was underwhelming, resembling more of a casual buffet than the upscale dining experience depicted on their website. Furthermore, the strong scent of Indian cuisine permeated the air, detracting from the authentic Brazilian taste we were anticipating. Notwithstanding, the customer service was quite commendable, as the staff exhibited warmth and enthusiasm towards ensuring our enjoyment. At approximately $40-45 per person, the cost seemed somewhat excessive for the caliber of the establishment, leaving me with the impression that there were superior options available for the price.

Staff manager isn't that friendly or helpful, and they never have what I want in stock. It is closer to my house than PetsMart, but after three unsuccessful trips I will just head to the competitor spot to get what I need.

"Well, I had held high anticipations for the culinary offerings at this establishment, subsequent to perusing the laudatory critiques. 
We were accommodated with remarkable celerity, yet our server, from the onset, comported himself in a manner suggestive of our presence being an imposition upon him. 
I opted for the scampi, which, alas, was somewhat overcooked, resulting in a regrettable incineration of the tails; however, the pasta and sauce accompanying it were quite palatable; my acquaintance, on the other hand, requested the cod, which, unfortunately, was excessively overcooked, prompting her to seek a fresh portion. 
As we approached the conclusion of our repast, we became cognizant of his lamentations, addressed to his colleagues (this was a decidedly vociferous conversation, as the staff members were situated behind the preparation area, en route to the kitchen), wherein he attributed our dissatisfaction with the fare to our own capricious nature. 
I, as well as my companion, shall not be returning, and we shall endeavor to dissuade our associates from patronizing this establishment, owing to the unremarkable cuisine and unprofessional demeanor of the staff."

I was compelled to dine at this establishment due to the temporary closure of Island Style, a restaurant I frequently visit, for renovations. Upon entering, I was struck by the unassuming ambiance, which did not augur well for an exemplary culinary experience. However, I chose to reserve judgment, focusing instead on the quality of the fare and hospitality. Unfortunately, my expectations were not met, as the service was merely adequate, and the cuisine left much to be desired. Specifically, my spouse and I had to request the midday menu, which was not readily available. My primary grievance concerned the food, which lacked the robust flavors and vibrant hues characteristic of Sino-Asian delicacies. The pork and tofu hot pot was unremarkable, with an abundance of pork and a conspicuous absence of dynamic vegetation. Similarly, the shrimp pan-fried noodles were insipid and failed to impress. As a culinary expert myself, I can only surmise that the chefs at this venue have become complacent in their craft, resulting in an uninspired and unappetizing offering. In conclusion, my experience at this restaurant was thoroughly underwhelming, with nothing exceptional about the service and little to commend the food. It is unlikely that I shall return.

"The gastronomical offerings at this establishment are of satisfactory quality, however, our dining experiences have been marred by the evident lack of knowledge exhibited by the servers regarding the menu items and their constituents. Specifically, upon inquiring about the nature of Kenyan cuisine, our server was unable to provide a coherent response, offering instead an awkward and unhelpful comparison to American fare. Furthermore, when queried about the composition of Menudo, our server displayed a marked dearth of understanding, leading one of us to speculate that it might contain stomach, thereby underscoring the need for more effective staff training in order to enhance the overall dining experience and foster a truly informed and welcoming ambiance."

"When encountering an establishment promoting an 'All You Can Eat Sushi' option for a mere $19.95, one cannot help but harbor certain presuppositions regarding the quality of the culinary offerings. Specifically, the expectation is that the fare will be inferior and unremarkable. Unfortunately, this proved to be the case during my recent visit, as the sushi presented itself as lackluster and characterized by an excessive proportion of rice relative to the actual fish content within each roll. Therefore, it is advisable to avoid this particular promotion if gastronomical satisfaction is a priority. 

Conversely, my companion elected to sample the miso soup, which, at a cost of $4.50, delivered an unexpectedly generous portion. This was indeed a pleasant surprise. However, my own decision to eschew the sushi due to reservations about its quality led me to opt for the Ah Sin Fried Rice instead. Unfortunately, this alternative failed to impress, as it lacked discernible flavor. An order of Har Gow (shrimp dumplings) followed, which, while not exceptional, managed to surpass expectations. Notably, a pot of hot tea, intended to serve five individuals, carried an exorbitant price tag of $8.  

In conclusion, while certain menu items may prove satisfying, the overall experience falls short of expectations due to the underwhelming nature of the sushi and excessive pricing of complementary beverages."

La Condesa, I relinquish my expectations of satisfactory dining experiences at your establishment. Despite our persistent attempts to justify and overlook the shortcomings in the quality of service, it has become patently evident that such indulgence is no longer feasible. The sluggish pace and inattention to detail exhibited by your staff, coupled with an apparent lack of concern for the satisfaction of your clientele, have rendered the dining experience at your restaurant unworthy of further financial investment on my part. In light of these factors, I elect to redirect my resources elsewhere.

On this particular visit, we were disenchanted with the culinary offerings as well. We requested the return of our horchata due to its deficiency in both flavor and viscosity, only to be presented with new glasses after the completion of our meal. Furthermore, the aesthetically pleasing crema that you graciously bestowed upon my torta (or, as some might refer to it, lonche) posed a practical challenge in terms of its consumption, as it was impossible to discern a suitable method of lifting and consuming the dish without compromising its structural integrity.

While it is true that your cochinita pibil once brought us immense gastronomical delight, it unfortunately does not compensate for the multitude of shortcomings that have come to characterize the dining experience at your establishment. Indeed, the ambiance and cleanliness of your restaurant have been problematic in the past, yet we were willing to overlook such issues given the exceptional quality of certain menu items. However, the subpar service we have consistently encountered has reached a point where our tolerance can no longer be stretched.

"It is indeed a fortuitous circumstance that this establishment offers exceptional promotions on their protein-based products, as it serves as an inducement for me to frequent their premises, despite my reservations regarding the quality of their produce. The dairy products, in particular, appear to be consistently available at a reduced price point, which is a significant factor in my decision to procure them from this location. Furthermore, the meat and seafood departments often feature buy-one-get-one-free or buy-one-get-two-free deals, which present an opportunity too advantageous to ignore. However, I must express my dissatisfaction with the level of customer service provided by the staff, who often display a lack of cordiality and an apathetic attitude towards acknowledging patrons' presence. Moreover, the checkout process is unacceptably sluggish, consuming thrice the duration required at alternative retailers I visit. Notwithstanding these grievances, I shall persist in perusing their advertisements and taking advantage of their occasional bargains, while simultaneously maintaining my preference for alternate sources of grocery supplies."

Not my \"cup of tea\" -- too Yuppie for me!  Atmosphere way too \"sanitized\", and servers have little or no personality.  The food is fair but not worth the price IMHO!  What ever happened to pasta or pizza with RED sauce?  Seems they have every color and concoction known to man except red (well maybe one or two)- being of Italian descent I need red!!  I ordered from  the \"Small Bits Menu\" because I wanted a light lunch - believe me - it definitely was \"Small Bits\",  good thing they gave out bread because I needed a second helping of that just to let me know that I ate something!  My suggestion is to order from the dinner menu if you want a full meal - of course most folks are much more sophisticated than this old country boy and can figure out what most of the fancy California stuff is on the menu - sorry!

My morning repast and my paramour's culinary experience was utterly insipid. We had procured the waffles and the blueberry lemon pancakes, but unfortunately, the pancakes failed to exhibit even a hint of lemony flavor, while the waffles were merely average in quality. Despite the aesthetically pleasing presentation, I shall not be returning to this establishment.

Asthma and respiratory sufferers avoid this place like the plague.  It stinks to high heaven of cheap teen cologne.  The merchandise is still over priced and staff is dumber than a box of rocks.  On the plus side, it's a great place for decent men's sweat pants.  Just make sure you don't pay full price.  Also wash the clothes when you get them home,  they will stink like their cologne.
Do you have any idea how frustrating it is to cut a $50 ribeye with a dull steak knife?  My only memory of this place is having to saw my steak.

"My visit to this establishment was predicated upon my desire to sample their signature tamales, but unfortunately, my expectations were not met, as the culinary offerings were subpar and lacking in both flavor and temperature, with the additional disappointment of perfunctory and unengaged service."

Every time I play here something makes me angry. Today was slowness. Usually it's service and miserable people but today all staff I encountered were very nice. We played 13 holes in 3 hours and waited at least 5 minutes if not more per hole. Don't go here if you want to play a quick round and don't use the vending machine on the 4th hole. Wasted half my day waiting so we just left. I will say the greens were in excellent shape which is why I gave 2 stars not 1! I am a self proclaimed golf snob so I may be a little bit dramatic but when I pay $30 and barely get through half a round, this is what I have a problem with.

Good service...Not so much for the food...

Two steaks ordered Medium rare...One arrived med/med-well...The other was blue rare at best...Pretty much raw

Noisy and busy but our server was great. I'm sure of we were not pressed for time she would have done the best to mack our food right too!

"It is rather perplexing that, irrespective of the hour at which one arrives, a waiting period of no less than 20 minutes invariably ensues. This phenomenon suggests that the establishment would benefit from augmenting its staff complement, thereby enabling a more efficient and expeditious service delivery to patrons."

I wholeheartedly concur with a significant portion of the reviews I have perused on this platform; regrettably, the Wahoo's in question does not resemble the one I frequented during my formative years in California; the fish exhibits an unfortunate lack of moisture, and the green sauce they provide bears a closer resemblance to an unpalatable combination of watery sour cream and herbs. 
  I have visited this establishment on several occasions, primarily for beverages, and have had the misfortune of encountering a particularly inadequate bartender (whose name escapes me); upon entering the bar during a lull in patrons, she proceeded to adjust the television's volume and switch the channel to a reality program, ignoring my request to restore the previous broadcast. 
  Moreover, I have experienced subpar service from this individual on multiple occasions, as she appeared preoccupied with engaging in conversation with a customer, neglecting her responsibilities and leaving us waiting for our bill, ultimately prompting me to inform her that we would be departing without settling our tab in order to receive her attention. 
  In light of these experiences, I would strongly advise against visiting this location, as the quality of the fish tacos falls short of expectations, and the service is less than satisfactory.

This supermarket, a Best of Las Vegas recipient since its opening, serves breakfast on the weekends so that was our destination on a recent morning. I found the market to be comparable to Whole Foods with more moderate pricing. We ordered at the counter and then retired to a table in the piano room where the food was delivered. Our easy over eggs came with bacon, wheat toast and home fries. The ingredients were good, but pricing was high and execution left much to be desired. The toast wasn't crispy, the bacon was limp, the potatoes tired and the egg whites watery.

"Upon entering this establishment, I experienced an eerie sensation of familiarity, which was subsequently revealed to be a result of my previous visit to the identical buffet during its tenure at the Aladdin. The ambiance and layout of the restaurant were unremarkable, with a standard array of culinary stations offering a variety of international dishes. However, the absence of a considerable wait time, which I initially perceived as a positive aspect, ultimately proved to be an ominous portent. The cost of the buffet was exorbitant, the cuisine was merely passable, and the service we received from our server was abysmal, as she failed to attend to our needs subsequent to her hasty delivery of our orange juice. My experience at this buffet served as a stark reminder of the importance of conducting thorough research prior to selecting a dining establishment, as well as the potential consequences of neglecting to do so. In conclusion, I cannot in good conscience recommend this buffet to anyone seeking a satisfying dining experience."

Well as usual the rolled tacos lacked the quality of my first visit.  They were mushy in the middle and some parts of the tacos appeared maybe to not even been dipped into the fryer. The guacamole quality also not impressive this time and the cheese on the rolled tacos was not melted at all. Very concerned about prices for this item too as in most places you can get 5 of these for under 5 bucks always,  but they are 6.50 here with tax. Not worth it based on quality and not even a healthy dose of alcohol helped either.

"Ah, Aureole, an establishment boasting an ambiance of unparalleled elegance and a culinary experience that is nothing short of sublime. However, it is unfortunate that the service we received during our visit was utterly disappointing and borderline reprehensible. Our reservation was for 9:30 PM, and upon arriving, we were promptly seated. Yet, our waiter, after presenting us with a defective tablet wine list, vanished without a trace, leaving us to linger for nearly twenty minutes before his eventual return. His reappearance was accompanied by a notable display of irritation, as if it were our responsibility to ensure the proper functioning of the aforementioned tablet. Furthermore, he saw fit to remind us on four separate occasions that the establishment would be closing imminently, as if we were oblivious to the fact or had intentionally planned our visit to coincide with the late hours. Suffice it to say, the exquisite quality of the cuisine was thoroughly eclipsed by the unprofessional conduct of our server and the overbearing sense of urgency he conveyed, rendering any future visits to this establishment highly unlikely."

This particular establishment, known as Terrible's, happens to be situated in close proximity to my humble abode. Consequently, I have opted to visit this location on multiple occasions, primarily for the purpose of acquiring beverages of an alcoholic nature, specifically beer, upon my return home.

On a singular occasion, I availed myself of their car washing services, only to be left with an unsettling sensation that the cost incurred was disproportionate to the quality of the service rendered. Moreover, I have refrained from utilizing their fuel pumps due to the prices being somewhat elevated in comparison to those of neighboring gas stations.

Notwithstanding the aforementioned reservations, I must concede that the convenience store within the premises boasts an impressive array of merchandise, available at a reasonable tariff. Furthermore, the beer cellar, renowned for its exceptionally low temperature, is indeed a remarkable feature of this establishment.

Unfortunately, the parking facilities provided do not exactly qualify as expansive or straightforward, rendering ingress and egress somewhat arduous, particularly when the lot is congested and parking spaces are scarce. It is worth mentioning, however, that the staff members at this establishment, though remunerated at a rate commensurate with the minimum wage, generally exhibit a level of professionalism and dedication to their duties that is, at the very least, adequate.

Despite certain drawbacks, I shall continue to frequent this establishment, provided that the prices remain competitive.

Always have had good experience here but not tonight, dinner with group of friends had abysmal service. First waiter forgot our table and second waitress had a poor attitude when asked about very late food. Food was OK but definitely not as good as in the past.

This place serves Werner Enterprises truck drivers. I know cause I'm one of them. It's just the basics for what we need. I've stayed in worse places. So if you like a 5 star hotel, go somewhere else. It's a 2 star maybe a soft 3 star hotel. But there are plenty of food places within walking distance.

"There is nothing particularly distinctive or exceptional about this establishment, as it offers a culinary experience that is merely satisfactory and unremarkable in terms of quality, while the pace of service is leisurely and unhurried, which may be perceived as sluggish or tardy by some patrons, and the physical layout of the seating arrangements is such that there is an absence of sufficient spatial separation between tables, thereby creating an atmosphere that is reminiscent of sharing a meal with adjacent tables, which may engender a sense of discomfort or inconvenience for certain individuals."

The gastronomical experience was merely adequate, with the victuals being passable but by no means exceptional. My last visit to this establishment occurred approximately one year ago, and upon settling the financial obligation for the repast, I was reminded of the reason behind my prolonged absenceâthe exorbitant cost of a single glass of orange juice, which exceeds two dollars and forty cents, and the lack of complimentary refills. While the comestibles were satisfactory, there are undoubtedly superior options available.

"I was experiencing an intense desire for chicken wings, which compelled me to embark on a somewhat lengthy excursion to acquire them. Upon arriving at the establishment, I sampled two varieties of their offerings, specifically the Louisiana and Parmesan Garlic options. While the former was palatable, I found the seasoning of the latter to be excessively saline, bordering on unpalatability. Notwithstanding, I opted to consume only the former variety, eschewing the latter due to its unpleasant aroma, which closely resembled that of a soiled dishrag, a scent that is likely familiar to most individuals. Subsequently, the pungent odor permeated the interior of my vehicle throughout the duration of my return journey, prompting me to discard the remnants of the meal in the nearest waste receptacle. In light of this experience, I must express my skepticism regarding the staff's ability to perceive and distinguish between diverse olfactory stimuli."

This was my first buffet experience since my departure from Las Vegas several years ago, and unfortunately, it proved to be a regrettable choice. My sons and I were eager to indulge in a buffet meal prior to our evening excursion in the city of sin, and this particular establishment appeared to be the most convenient option, boasting a relatively short queue. However, upon arriving at the cashier, I was taken aback by the exorbitant cost associated with an individual buffet dinner. In fact, for the price we paid, we could have acquired a 24-hour buffet pass, granting us access to multiple hotel buffets.  

Following payment, we waited briefly for our table to be prepared. Once seated, our server took our beverage orders, and after ensuring that everything was in order, we set out to explore the array of dishes available. Unfortunately, the selection was quite limited, with certain stations remaining unrestocked. Given the circumstances, I made a concerted effort to derive maximum value from my $47 dinner by opting for grilled meats such as kobe beef and prime rib, short rib tacos, various sushi and sashimi options, and beef Wellington. For dessert, I selected mini churros and vending machine-dispensed ice cream.  

A summary of the experience would include the following advantages and disadvantages:  

Advantages:  

* Short rib tacos  
* Sushi and sashimi  

Disadvantages:  

* Grilled meats were excessively dry, including beef Wellington  
* Mini churros were overcooked and stale  
* Vending machine-dispensed ice cream possessed an unremarkable flavor reminiscent of that found at typical buffet establishments  

While our server displayed helpfulness, they unfortunately misinterpreted our beverage requests. Ultimately, I departed feeling satisfied but disappointed.

I was told to check out this buffet while in Vegas, and I kind of regret I did.  I think there are two types of people: those who like buffets and those who don't.  I'm of the latter sort, and buffets remind me of eating in college mess halls more than enjoying the food.  But still, we went here for a Saturday brunch.  \n\nThe variety seemed pretty good - asian, italian, seafood, pizza, breakfast, etc.  I had an omelet which was probably the highlight of the meal.  Everything else that I tried was fine, but I was definitely limited by not being able to have the meat here.  The desserts looked nice but I didn't really like any of the ones I tried.  My fiance was more experimental, but he thought that most of the food was kind of pedestrian or mediocre.  Ultimately, both of us would have preferred eating less at a better restaurant in Vegas, but then again, I guess we're not buffet people.

So I heard a lot if rave reviews and its always crowded so I said hey what the hell....yeah what the hell indeed.
Pros:
-cheap 
Cons:
Food was subpar
Pork wasn't cooked all the way
Enchiladas had fake cheese product
Marshmallows tasted like they were circa 1987...bad year for marshmallows apparently

Did I mention all the freakishly obese people...seriously woman that was your 5th cotton candy.

In person, the staff members appear to be amicable and accommodating; however, their behavior drastically alters when communicating via telephone. They have displayed a blatant disregard for punctuality by summoning me to arrive prematurely, only to arbitrarily assign a different physician. Furthermore, the office environment is noticeably unkempt. Despite my fervent hopes to avoid revisiting the facility, I was compelled to do so in order to resolve an issue regarding my prescription refills, as the staff failed to respond to my requests in a timely manner. Initially, they stipulated that I would need to present myself for an examination every three months in order to obtain my medication; however, upon being queried about this policy, they promptly relented and provided me with my prescription. It appears that their primary objective is to coerce patients into undergoing unnecessary treatments and procedures, thereby augmenting their financial gain through the exploitation of insurance providers. Consequently, I find myself once again wishing to avoid returning to this establishment.

I tried this takeaway for the first time last Monday. I had the Kung Po chicken, but won't be having it again. The chicken was breaded, and the sauce was sticky like a sweet and sour sauce, definitely not authentic Chinese that I was hoping for and it costs more than I expected.  :( Head to takeaway shops on Leith Walk instead.

"Although Pancho Villa's has been in operation for an extended period, it appears to garner sufficient patronage to remain in business, albeit I am uncertain about the precise factors contributing to its enduring success...I have had the pleasure of indulging in superior chili at various establishments and Illegal Jack's, which were not only more flavorful but also more economical. The enchiladas and fajitas, unfortunately, failed to impress my palate, lacking that extra je ne sais quoi that would have elevated them to a truly satisfying culinary experience. A acquaintance did mention that the restaurant excels in crafting exceptional margaritas, yet if the sole means of enjoying the cuisine is through alcohol-induced impairment, then I struggle to comprehend the rationale behind paying premium prices for a dining establishment. In light of the description provided by Yelp, my sentiments regarding Pancho Villa's can be succinctly summarized as'meh', as I have undoubtedly encountered superior dining experiences."
The pizza wasn't horrible,  but the deal was awful.  The prices are extremely high at Dominos in general,  and their medium 2 topping is a rip off.  Low rating is for price vs.  Quality,  and value.

The facility is clean and architecturally beautiful.  

BUT why would they concrete the decking of a pool in 100+ degree days in AZ?!?!?  It's slippery and hot on your feet.  Saw someone slip and hit their head - an ambulance was called to take her to the hospital for a concussion. 

The ratio of pool guest to lifeguards seems to be 3:1.  

Each time there is an injury instead of taking the person up to the first aid room all 50 guards blow their whistles and corral every single guest out of the pool and the entire pool area.  You are not allowed to find your children or grab your towels or even a water!  It's an absurd practice.  I will not return.  I agree that if the guards are dealing with an emergency people should get out of the pool but to corral everyone off the grounds is a bit much.

"My sentiment regarding this eatery is that it is egregiously overvalued relative to the financial investment required to partake in its offerings. While the server was indeed courteous and professional in their demeanor, and the culinary fare was of satisfactory quality, albeit not extraordinary, the exorbitant cost of the meals, coupled with the dearth of exceptional service and the underwhelming temperature at which the dishes were presented, unfortunately precludes me from endorsing this establishment wholeheartedly. Furthermore, the absence of dedicated male and female restrooms, compounded by an extended waiting period to access the sole available facilities, prompted numerous patrons to seek alternative venues for their personal hygiene needs, thus detracting from the overall dining experience. Aesthetically, the presentation of the food was indeed impressive, yet, regrettably, this attribute proved to be the sole distinguishing feature of this restaurant, rendering it merely average in my assessment."
Register service was not pleasant. I'm not sure if the girl who rang me up just didn't like me, but she was nice to everyone else until I got up to her.

We placed an order for a supplementary dish of Macaroni and cheese, which we intended to consume prior to our primary courses, in observance of the tradition associated with the fifth day of the week. Both of us opted for seafood dishes, specifically fish, and accompaniments of leafy greens. Additionally, we requested a bowl of the broth du jour, specifically clam chowder, to initiate our culinary experience. Our salads were presented initially, followed by a brief interval during which we partook of a few bites, and then the soup arrived. Shortly after, the Macaroni and cheese was delivered to our table. We couldn't help but remark that the term "appetizer" appeared to be problematic for the majority of servers. Subsequently, our main courses were served, much to our incredulity. The sheer volume of crockery on our table prompted a humorous observation from our server, to which we responded with a perplexed expression. Throughout the meal, we encountered multiple servers and food runners, necessitating repeated requests for water replenishment. Moreover, we had to seek assistance from a staff member to obtain condiments and settle our financial obligations. Despite the cordial demeanor of the staff, it became apparent that there was a lack of managerial guidance and coordination among the team members. The ambiance and cuisine were satisfactory, however, we shall endeavor to patronize the establishment once more, granting them an additional opportunity to address the glaring deficiencies in their service protocols. A point-of-sale system with advanced features should enable servers to track the timing of food delivery, thereby mitigating misunderstandings between servers and cooks, ultimately attributable to inadequate management.

We were formerly enamored with this establishment as an optimal initiatory halt in Las Vegas; however, it has unfortunately deteriorated significantly - almost entirely downhill, in fact.

It required a staggering 27 minutes - indeed, 27! - for our server to extend a cursory greeting and merely accept our beverage orders. Subsequently, we hastened to request our entire meal and checkout simultaneously, thereby ensuring we wouldn't miss his fleeting presence once more.

The menu has been considerably truncated, offering fewer options and omitting certain items I previously relished. My dinner companion and I opted for the barbecue chicken flatbread, which regrettably featured an abundance of unpalatable, fatty chicken parts, rendering half of it inedible. While their burgers may still be passable, this particular dish fell short of expectations.

Evidently, this venue suffers from managerial issues, leading to staffing difficulties and ultimately resulting in subpar customer service and interminable waiting periods. We shall not return, but we sincerely hope that improvements are implemented for the benefit of future patrons. Nonetheless, we extends a solitary star in recognition of their commendable beer selection.

I asked for delivery. Ok, they did it with no problems and quick enough (30-40 mins). 
I chose just rolls. 
The salmon one was pretty flat, no taste. Californias were ok-ish.

When I gave money to the woman who delivered she took them and left without saying a goodbye or thank you

Meh

Doesn't even taste like pho, nor smell like it.

I had asked for extra veggies in my vermicelli, and it looked like they put in less than most places normally would if i had not asked for extra. This plate was ok.

My seat had a bunch of rips in it, and when you sit on ripped leather it kinda hurts if you wear a dress/shorts.

This eatery, which appears to be a run-of-the-mill Mexican cuisine establishment, is unfortunately rather unimpressive in its culinary offerings. Upon entering the premises, my companion and I were immediately struck by the dearth of patrons, despite the fact that it was a Friday afternoon. The ambiance was lackluster, with nary a soul in sight, save for a few staff members and a small child who was frolicking about the rear of the dining area. The menu options were uninspired and failed to excite our palates, with the enchiladas, in particular, being rather unremarkable. The chicken and beef variants, respectively, were unexceptional and lacked any semblance of flavor that might have elevated them above the mundane. Furthermore, the dark brown sauce accompanying the dish was unappetizing in both appearance and taste, resembling a beef-based gravy of sorts. Our server, though friendly, seemed somewhat disinterested in our experience, and the overall atmosphere was eerily hushed, almost to the point of being unsettling. Suffice it to say, we shall not be revisiting this establishment in the future.

We have had the misfortune of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, and each time, the subpar service has failed to deviate from its consistent lackluster quality. It remains unclear whether the root cause of this inadequacy stems from an insufficient number of employees or an inefficient allocation of staff members between indoor and outdoor seating areas, leading to an excruciatingly sluggish pace of service. Furthermore, the culinary offerings are unremarkable and fail to justify a repeat visit, especially considering the superior alternatives available at neighboring establishments. Despite these shortcomings, the potential for a first-rate drinking establishment exists, awaiting the implementation of crucial improvements to surpass the competition.

"Culinary artisans who harmoniously blend their vocal talents with their gastronomical prowess invariably ensure an unparalleled epicurean experience, as the hospitable service staff fosters an ambiance reminiscent of a convivial family gathering. While the interior design may appear somewhat lackluster, this establishment possesses inherent potential. 

--The made-to-order Pico de Gallo boasts freshness and a piquant flavor, although its sodium content tends to overpower the palate, particularly when paired with corn chips. 
--The melodious strains emanating from the culinary domain serve as a harbinger of excellence, signaling that a delectable feast is forthcoming. 
--Although delivered, the flour tortillas feature only six ingredients, which is suboptimal. 
--Guacamole should never contain additives such as milk, which would compromise its authenticity and texture. 
--The rice, regrettably, is too minute, resulting in rapid desiccation and disappointment. 
--The cheese crisp, unfortunately, lacks crunch, while the green chili strips display freshness. 

DECOR REQUIRES REFURBISHMENT 
--The presence of extended beer flags suspended from the ceiling does not automatically create a festive atmosphere, especially when they fail to flutter in the breeze. 
--Mounted mariachi hats and diagonally positioned multicolored throw rugs do not contribute significantly to the overall aesthetic appeal. 
--While caballeros and damas are certainly commendable, the juxtaposition of McDonald's-style Men and Women signs beneath them seems incongruous. 
--Mirrored walls, reminiscent of the 1980s, are aesthetically displeasing. 

It is crucial to preface my assessment by acknowledging my corn intolerance, which limits my capacity to sample a significant portion of the menu. 
--This venue exudes a genuine local ambiance, which could benefit from a revitalizing transformation."

It is utterly preposterous to expect consumers to pay such an exorbitant price for a paltry double shot of espresso, truly it is. My recent visit to the Handsome Roasters Cafe, where I was served a double pulled by one of the proprietors themselves, only solidified my conviction that the prices at JPH are unreasonable, as the cost was significantly lower. Furthermore, my experiences at other esteemed establishments, such as Barista in Portland Oregon, where I was served by an award-winning barista, and at Coava, Stumptown, and The Refinery, all renowned for their high-end offerings, only further reinforced my belief that JPH's prices are unjustifiably steep. While I do appreciate the occasional indulgence in a premium coffee experience, I cannot help but feel that JPH's pricing strategy is pretentious and unreasonable, particularly given the plethora of more affordable options available. Perhaps the exorbitant rent or the prevalence of affluent clientele who are either trust fund beneficiaries or burdened with substantial student loans might explain the coffee shop's seemingly inflated prices. In any case, a dose of rationality would greatly benefit JPH's pricing model, in my humble opinion. As an aside, I must express my delight at the fact that LADRO is served at JPH, a pleasant surprise indeed.

"My personal belief is that individuals who provide evaluations in Phoenix tend to overestimate the quality of dining establishments, perhaps with the intention of creating the illusion of a greater abundance of exceptional culinary options, or possibly due to a lack of familiarity with genuinely superior gastronomic experiences. In my opinion, Blue Wasabi does not rank among the truly outstanding restaurants, despite the favorable reviews it has received. I have come to the realization that it is unwise to rely heavily on the opinions of those who lavish praise upon eateries serving merely adequate fare. 

There are certain aspects of Blue Wasabi that I find appealing, such as the attentive service, respectable beverages, and distinctive ambiance. 

However, my primary objection to this establishment lies in the fact that the sushi, while not necessarily inexpensive, fails to meet expectations in terms of freshness and quality. Specifically, the sashimi fares slightly better, but the overall quality of the sushi and sashimi falls short of my expectations, considering the prices charged. Moreover, when compared to alternative dining options such as Sushi on Shea or Kyoto, both of which offer superior quality at a lower cost, Blue Wasabi does not measure up. It appears to be more of a trendy gathering spot, rather than a restaurant focused on providing exceptional cuisine. Nonetheless, I am unwilling to compromise on my desire for excellent food, and therefore, Blue Wasabi disappoints me."

"I had the pleasure of partaking in a culinary excursion to this establishment on a recent Friday evening, arriving promptly at 9:00 PM.  Upon entering, I noticed a dearth of patrons, which seemed to be reflected in the staffing, as there was an absence of a hostess and only two servers present to attend to the needs of the clientele in this expansive venue.  My server, however, proved to be quite adept at his duties, earning high praise for his efforts.  Unfortunately, the same could not be said for the culinary offerings, as my meal failed to meet expectations. 

Opting for the lemon sole, accompanied by a side salad, I was dismayed to discover that the fish was not prepared in accordance with my expectations.  Despite the tangy, citrus-infused charm of the lemon caper sauce, the sole itself was overcooked, resulting in a texture that was simultaneously crispy and tough.  As sole is inherently a delicate fish, it requires minimal preparation to achieve optimal tenderness; sadly, this dish fell short of that standard.  Coupled with the fact that the price point for this meal exceeded $20, inclusive of tax and gratuity, I would not advocate for this particular selection.  

While Mimi's does boast an impressive array of bread offerings, the remainder of their menu leaves much to be desired.  In light of these factors, I would suggest exploring alternative dining options."

"It is truly perplexing to comprehend the rationale behind the ostensibly favorable evaluations bestowed upon this establishment, as my personal experience has led me to conclude that it is, in fact, quite unsanitary and antiquated. The ambiance is hectic, the service is excruciatingly sluggish, and the culinary offerings are merely lubricous and unpalatable. 

The prevailing sentiment among patrons appears to be that of a superlative dining experience, with particular emphasis on the purported affordability and quality of the Mexican cuisine served herein. However, I must respectfully disagree with such assertions, as my own taste buds have failed to detect even a modicum of gastronomical excellence. 

The salsa presented was conspicuously lacking in freshness, while the guacamole was devoid of any discernible flavor profile. Furthermore, the practice of placing packaged shredded cheese atop tortilla chips and salsa, rather than allowing it to melt, struck me as decidedly incongruous. 

My attempt to consume a taco salad was, regrettably, abortive, as I found the ingredients to be utterly unappetizing. 

In conclusion, if one's culinary preferences lean towards hastily prepared and inferior Mexican-American fare, then, perhaps, this venue may prove satisfactory. Nevertheless, I would strongly advise against entrusting one's dining experience to this establishment, as the likelihood of disappointment is, in my opinion, unacceptably high."

When I overheard my immediate supervisor express his intention to indulge in a personal treat by dining at Blueberry Hill, I nearly collapsed from surprise. Had he perused my previous critique of the establishment on Flamingo Avenue? Appalling! Miserable! Such an experience would be more suitable for a used automobile salesperson or perhaps even Lucifer himself. 
  Nonetheless, my manager maintained that a visit to the location on Green Valley Parkway was imperative, boasting that it was vastly superior - allegedly 10,000 times better, to be exact. My response was a half-hearted "meh," and I promptly returned to my duties. 
  Today, however, I found myself in need of some inspiration to stimulate my creativity. Thus, I decided to put my manager's claims to the test. Upon arriving at the Blueberry Hill on Green Valley Parkway, I was promptly greeted and seated. To ensure a fair assessment, I placed an order for the identical dish I had tried at the previous Blueberry Hill: Mexican-style chilaquiles accompanied by a Diet Pepsi. Unfortunately, the culinary experience was identical to the previous establishment - an unremarkable plate of mediocrity. It baffles me how such establishments garner widespread acclaim when my experiences have consistently yielded unimpressive results. 
  On a positive note, the service was marginally expedited. While the staff remained relatively stoic, I didn't have to wait an eternity for a replenishment of my beverage. 
  Regrettably, my reservations regarding these eateries persist. If I require comfort food in a timely manner, my allegiance lies with Denny's.

Sauce variety is so so. Ribs are tiny, even for babybacks. Other meat accompaniments include brisket (too dry for me), pulled chicken, p[ulled pork, and smoked sausage. The waitress claimed they make the sausage on site but it tasted very generic, like it came out of a hillshire farms packet from costco. The steak fries were the only side I ate and they appeared to have some skin on them but still tasted so so. There is much better BBQ to be had in the NW Phoenix area.

Located on Fremont Street, and relatively proximate to the illustrious Golden Nugget, this establishment appears to have experienced more favorable days in the past. The sole motivation behind my visits to this venue is the affordable deep-fried Twinkies, which are available at an economical price point of 99 cents. Despite being cognizant of the fact that such culinary indulgences are not particularly beneficial for my health, I cannot resist the allure of deep-fried Twinkies. However, the cleanliness of the deep fry station and the quality of customer service could be improved.
