Specifically, the comment made by a staff member, "Don't forget my tip," struck me as somewhat brusque and unwarranted, thereby diminishing the likelihood of receiving a generous gratuity from me. In fact, the tip I left was a paltry 10% of the total bill.  

The ambiance of the establishment itself leaves much to be desired, with outdated slot machines that frequently malfunction and an overall atmosphere that seems to be in disrepair. Were it not for the antiquated gaming devices and the less-than-friendly demeanor of the staff, this venue might have garnered a more positive appraisal from me. As it stands, I would advise individuals who are interested in gambling or utilizing slot machines to avoid this location, as the wait times for assistance can extend up to 30-60 minutes. Nonetheless, the slushy drinks and deep-fried delights available at the rear of the establishment remain a redeeming feature.

"The coffee concoction is fabricated according to prescribed protocols, yet the associates manifest a conspicuous lack of enthusiasm and warmth in their interactions with patrons. As a regular patron over an extensive period, I have visited this establishment on numerous occasions throughout the day, endeavoring to initiate dialogue with the barista. However, their responses are typically terse and cursory, precluding any meaningful exchange. Notwithstanding, the beverages and comestibles available conform to the standards one would anticipate from a Starbucks franchise."

"We had the opportunity to indulge in the seafood buffet this evening, and our expectations were not entirely met. Despite the extensive variety of dishes available, the quality was inconsistent. The steamed crab legs were somewhat disappointing, lacking the succulent texture we had anticipated. However, the crab legs roasted in a sweet chili sauce were a notable exception, showcasing a delightful balance of flavors. Unfortunately, the cold crab legs situated near the cold seafood section had an unpleasant saltiness. The lobster tails, though visually appealing, were regrettably small and exhibited a slight rubberiness in texture. Nonetheless, the application of garlic butter enhanced the flavor of these dishes. 

The genuine highlight of the meal was undoubtedly the assortment of desserts. The green tea cheesecake demonstrated a pleasing lightness, while the creme brulee struck the perfect balance between sweetness and richness. The bread pudding, accompanied by a vanilla spice sauce, was truly exceptional. Unfortunately, the red velvet cupcakes failed to impress, as they were unpleasantly dry and lacking in flavor. 

Based on our experience, we would advise against selecting this establishment for a buffet. While the service we received was indeed commendable, the overall quality did not live up to the reputation preceding it. We award one star for the abundance of options and a second for the excellent service, but the remaining aspects fell short of our expectations."

"Underwhelmed experience. We entered the establishment at approximately 4 pm and found only a single table occupied. The exterior's unique charm was inviting; however, upon entering, I felt as though I had intruded upon a tattoo artist's personal space. 

It took between five to ten minutes for a staff member to emerge from the kitchen and greet us, which left an unfavorable initial impression. The salsa bar presented an assorted selection, yet its presentation was subpar. The miniature containers designated for 'to-go' salsa were insufficient, rendering it impossible to accommodate a single tortilla chip. Consequently, we were compelled to utilize a plastic spoon to transfer salsa onto our chips due to the absence of metal utensils on the table. Additionally, we did not receive small plates, resulting in a cluttered table setting before we began placing orders. 

Upon the arrival of our tacos, conspicuous cracks were visible on both my husband's and my plates. The similarity to flea market crockery was unavoidable. My selection was the smoked marlin taco, which possessed the texture of canned tuna complemented by a minestrone-like vegetable mixture above, while the shrimp tacos were passable. Unfortunately, the corn tortillas lacked substance, resembling store-bought El Paso brand products. 

The service was unsatisfactory, as our queries regarding the tacos were met with gestures toward the menu and vacant expressions, indicating a lack of familiarity with achiote rojo. 

In conclusion, the sentiment that we would have fared better at Chipotle encapsulates our disappointing experience."

When I first started frequenting this place's Sunday night happy hour, I loved it.  I would go with a group of friends, and it was always a great time.  Over the last few months, I have seen a decline in the quality of food, service, and an increase in prices.  Happy hour is still pretty decent prices, and the food hasn't been bad, it just isn't as good as it used to be, unfortunate really.

"Individual, verily, consider the expedited procurement of consumable comestibles, if you comprehend my inference.  I surmise that this establishment might be somewhat sensationalized and the culinary offerings are merely mediocre."

"The ambiance of this establishment did not possess any remarkably memorable qualities. Admittedly, my level of hunger was not as pronounced as it ideally should have been, and I was in the process of recuperating from an alcohol-induced blackout the previous evening...therefore, one should perhaps take my appraisal with a slight grain of salt.^_^.  

I opted for the breakfast buffet, which cost approximately $15, a price point that appears to be customary for Las Vegas. While nothing particularly extraordinary about the buffet stands out in my memory, they did offer pizza, which elicited considerable excitement on my part during the morning hours. The remaining items were fairly standard fare, including eggs, slightly stale bacon and sausage, hash browns, et cetera. I managed to consume roughly three-quarters of a plate before feeling utterly satiated and failing to obtain adequate value for my money.  

However, the quality of service was quite impressive! My server presented me with two large glasses of orange juice, thereby eliminating the need for me to request additional servings later on. Her thoughtfulness was much appreciated.  

In conclusion, if you are lodging at Planet Hollywood, it does not harm to enjoy breakfast at this venue. Nonetheless, I would personally advocate for breakfast at Le Village Buffet, located within the Paris hotel, instead. *wink wink*."

Cockroach crawled out of sprout plate... Killed it, hesitated to stay but did. They apologized, replaced food, charged me every cent for my food n to-go dinner. Used to come here every week, my fav pho diner, but I think I'll drive a little farther to Chinatown from now on...

"It was patently evident that the comedic endeavors of the male exotic dancers were the source of immense hilarity, albeit their attempts at seduction were futile, as we were not remotely interested in engaging in any form of terpsichorean interaction with them. Moreover, it was abundantly clear that one particular individual, whose moniker was Chili, was persistently offering discounts in a vain attempt to coerce us into accepting a performance from him, which we categorically refused. However, certain male dancers did display a modicum of affability, such as the gentleman hailing from San Jose, California, who regaled us with amusing anecdotes. Nonetheless, the absence of seating arrangements in the primary chamber for female performers was nothing short of perplexing, prompting us to decline the invitation to join the gentlemen celebrating their friend's last night of bachelorhood. Furthermore, we were witness to a rather unseemly spectacle involving a patron receiving a manual stimulation from a decidedly unattractive stripper, which elicited a response of mirthful incredulity from us."

"The pinnacle of culinary excellence at Pasqual's unquestionably lies within the realm of their delectable salsa, available in an array of piquant flavors ranging from mild to hot, all of which evoke an unparalleled gastronomic experience that transcends mere taste and borders on the spiritual. It is no surprise that at one point in the annals of history, Pasqual's boldly proclaimed itself a'salsaria,' for the sheer quality and depth of its salsa offerings are nothing short of sublime. The salsa is so exceptional, in fact, that it has been known to inspire an uncontainable urge to engage in impromptu bouts of salsa dancing, despite the fact that neither the author nor the majority of patrons possess any discernible aptitude for the art form. Alas, such is the profound impact of Pasqual's salsa on the senses. Regrettably, however, this once-illustrious establishment appears to have fallen victim to a precipitous decline in standards, as evidenced by the paltry serving of salsa accompanying the nachos, measuring a scant tablespoon or thereabouts in a miniature cup. A travesty compounded by the fact that repeated requests for additional salsa have yielded identical, meager portions. While the chicken, beef, nachos, and tacos at Pasqual's may be of respectable quality, it is indubitable that the salsa remains the veritable cornerstone of the dining experience, rendering the recent parsimony displayed in its distribution nothing short of calamitous. In conclusion, an imploration is hereby issued for Pasqual's to rectify this grievous oversight and restore the salsa to its rightful place as the crowning glory of the menu, lest the reputation of this erstwhile culinary haven suffer irreparable damage."

This evening, I had the privilege of dining at this establishment with a close acquaintance, and we opted for the dual-person meal priced at twenty dollars. As an amuse-bouche, we selected the guacamole appetizer, which consisted of their signature tortilla chips accompanied by a creamy guacamole dip infused with corn kernels, as per the wait staff's description, devoid of jalapenos and lacking any potency. Upon delving into the initial bite of the guacamole, my taste buds were met with an unexpected explosion of fiery flavor, saturated with an abundance of jalapenos and other pungent elements. Subsequently, we received the six-ounce sirloin steak, which, albeit cooked to my requested level of doneness, displayed a notable degree of charring on one particular surface. This cut of beef was complemented by a serving of loaded mashed potatoes, which exhibited remarkable quality, and a side of broccoli whose unpleasant and rancid taste was unfortunately accentuated by an unknown substance incorporated into its preparation. It is worth mentioning that the service encountered during my previous visits has been subpar, and today's experience served only to reinforce that notion, ultimately leading me to conclude that future patronage at this venue would be unwarranted.
Horrible Service. Extremely slow to seat us... and feed us... and water us... and bill us... slooooow.\nWe won't be going back.

"Deplorable. With an uppercase 'B'. 

Based on the pizza we obtained, I find it challenging to believe that the individual responsible for its preparation has ever stepped foot in a pizza establishment within the NY/NJ region, let alone possess any familiarity with the culinary traditions of New York-style pizza. 

We placed an order for a half meatball, half pepperoni pizza, anticipating a product that at least vaguely resembled the depiction on the menu. However, what we received was a pizza that barely qualified as a distant cousin of the iconic Domino's franchise, albeit at a significantly higher price point. The crust was thick and doughy, the sauce more akin to a concentrated tomato paste than an actual sauce, and the cheese was overcooked to an unpleasant degree. Furthermore, the'meatball' topping consisted of ground beef haphazardly scattered across the cheese, rather than sliced meatballs as advertised. 

In short, a truly regrettable experience. My expectations were high, hoping to discover another authentic NY-style pizzeria in our town. Unfortunately, this particular establishment falls woefully short of meeting such standards. We shall continue to patronize our established favorites, leaving this disappointing venture to those who are less discerning in their culinary pursuits."

Decided to run through the drive thru....first mistake.  The poor girl working the window was unfamiliar with the menu.  After she finally handed the menu to me, I was able to point to what I wanted.  Ordered.  Was asked to pull ahead.  After a wait...it finally came. 

Drove off....time to head home....with shear anticipation.  

On the drive home I could smell onion rings.  Unable to figure out what it was...until I got home.  It was my bag of ice cream.  The bag and all of the containers smelled of grease.  And...the flavor came through to the ice cream.  No bueno!

What was salvageable of the ice cream was so icky sweet.  Had to stop, for fear of a diabetic coma.  And quickly down water.  

Meh...never again.

Food can be iffy some times. 
I usually order piccatta, and the one and only time I had their veal, it was very tough. 

Food is over priced, the atmosphere is the only thing going for this place.

Staff needs to be upgraded and trained all around.
In personality, service, and knowledge. 

Went to the bar and asked for a mojito. Bartender said she "couldn't" make it. When the manager (I believe his name is Mike or something... blonde.... light complexion.) came around and asked how we were doing, I had brought up the bartender not having the supplies to make drinks... Like a full bar should. He challenged me, by letting me know that they have fresh mint and it is capable.

Well, I got my 'mojito'. 
Makes me wonder if the bartender was telling me she couldn't make it because of the mint.... or that she COULDN'T make it...... because...... gag.

Last June, I set up a birthday of about 16 for my husband's birthday. I made a reservation at least a week in advance. Waiter / busser would throw the bag of bread on the table, and then hide. They could barely be found. Had to beg for refills.


We have had one great waiter in the 3 years we have been eating there, and that is only because I took my pregnant self and spoke to the manager and complained hardcore. He told me to make a reservation with him, he comp'd our meal, and I'm sure that is why we were treated so nice.

"Regarding the customer service aspect of our visit, I must say that upon entering the establishment, I did not receive a warm welcome from the staff. In fact, despite being acknowledged by one of the employees with a fleeting glance, no verbal greeting was extended in my direction. Furthermore, the other staff member merely uttered a cursory 'hello' after I had been perusing the menu for an appreciable amount of time, and then promptly departed without offering any assistance or recommendations. It is worth mentioning that this lackluster service was in stark contrast to the pleasant ambiance that the restaurant exuded. Moving on to the culinary aspects of our excursion, I opted for the second option on the lunch special menu, which comprised of a slice of cheese pizza, a garden salad, and a fountain beverage, all for the reasonable sum of six dollars. While the pizza's sauce was unfortunately too saccharine for my taste buds, the dough was regrettably over-saturated with moisture. However, the salad proved to be a refreshing delight, consisting of a simple yet satisfying medley of fresh lettuce, succulent cherry tomatoes, and crunchy carrots, all dressed with a tangy balsamic vinaigrette."

decent place. tvs, outside seating, and a roll of paper towels hanging on every table! i'm definitely a fan of pizza and beer, only you have to drink the beer there (draft- pretty good!), so take out doesn't afford that combination.  they have wine too.  their appetizers seem good, but i just had the pizza (with veggie toppings) which was just ok.  nothing too special here... maybe its location.

I originate from the San Gabriel Valley, thereby, my expectations for dim sum are considerably elevated beyond those of an average individual. In light of this, the culinary offerings presented by this establishment were utterly disappointing. Upon observation, it became apparent that certain dishes were of the microwaveable variety, and none of them exhibited any semblance of robust flavor or freshness. The texture of the Har Gow and Shau Mai was unpleasantly soft and prone to disintegration, while the white rice cake dessert I hold in high regard was similarly afflicted with an unfortunate lack of cohesion. The taste was overpoweringly bland and devoid of any discernible flavor, leading me to surmise that an excessive amount of steam or cooking time was responsible. For individuals residing in Las Vegas and seeking dim sum, this restaurant may serve as a viable option. However, I do not intend to return.

Unfortunately my apartment complex caught fire, and I was forced to stay here temporarily.  My daughter, I and two cats came here. I asked for a \"handicap\" room, as my knee had gone out. While the neighborhood isn't the greatest, the train noise can be bothersome.  However, I loved the safety bars installed throughout the bathroom as I had troubles walking. \n\nOverall if I had to do it again, I'd stay at the Scottsdale location.

"The establishment boasts an alluring exterior and interior ambiance, which we had the pleasure of experiencing firsthand on a Friday evening, albeit with a moderate level of noise that prompted us to opt for the comparatively tranquil outdoor seating area. Our culinary excursion commenced auspiciously, with a satisfying bread basket and crisp salads that set the tone for a promising start. However, the subsequent dishes failed to maintain the initial quality, leading us to conclude that scaling down portion sizes while elevating the caliber of the fare would be a judicious strategy.

We initiated our gastronomic journey by sharing a spanakopita appetizer, which arrived in the form of three generous pieces, thereby rendering it suitable for two individuals. Although visually reminiscent of a pocket pizza, the dish was marred by an excess of cream cheese, detracting from the authentic flavor profile associated with feta. Moreover, the absence of delicate phyllo crust layers was conspicuous.

Our primary courses consisted of a customary beef gyro and its poultry counterpart, accompanied by potatoes and rice. Unfortunately, the potatoes were prepared in a manner akin to french fries, which rendered them unappealing to my taste buds due to their high fat content. Consequently, I merely sampled a few pieces, feeling somewhat let down. The accompanying rice was unremarkable, and the chicken gyro proved underwhelming as well. My spouse, however, seemed to appreciate the meal relatively more, possibly due to his exposure to prior reviews that tempered his expectations. The service we received was quite satisfactory, and the meal's tempo was well-maintained. Notwithstanding, my underwhelming experience precludes the likelihood of my return visit."

They are somewhat covertly positioned within the confines of Scottsdale Quarters, specifically situated on the upper level adjacent to the esteemed establishments of Tanzy and iPic, thus it is imperative that one does not relinquish their pursuit of discovering them.

I was disenchanted with this venue, not due to the therapeutic massage, which was satisfactory, but rather owing to the dearth of personnel at this establishment. The individual responsible for administering the massage also assumes the roles of receptionist, manager, and custodian, leading to an absence of seamlessness in the experience. Each time a novel patron enters, my masseuse would abandon their duties to accommodate the new customer, resulting in an extension of the originally scheduled duration of 60 minutes to 90 minutes. It is worth mentioning that we chanced upon this establishment subsequent to partaking in an all-you-can-eat sushi meal at the conclusion of the strip mall, yet I do not foresee myself returning.

Peanut butter jelly time?  I think not!  Not sure why the PB&J is only part of the lunch menu, but if you want one for your child before 11 am, don't count on it.  The two employees were unwilling to convey anything to management (which we believe was utilizing the nearby couches for leisure activities) that it is more practical to prepare a PB&J rather than a smoothie.  The employees only knew to state that it was against company policy to create a PB&J before 11 am.  Anyway, I requested an egg sandwich with tomato and turkey and it was a rather unremarkable sandwich in that I could have easily prepared the same dish at home, but with superior quality due to the availability of Tobasco.  I inquired about Tobasco but was instead offered their homemade "chili" sauce, which possessed a flavor profile akin to pureed sundried tomatoes combined with chili powder.  While it was not unpalatable, I do enjoy the piquant sensation of Tobasco when consumed in conjunction with eggs.  Anywhoo, if that was indeed management relaxing on the couches, then shame on them for not defending their stringent PB&J policy and investing in a bottle of Tobasco!

I really wanted to like this place, since it has such good reviews and nice happy hour prices...but I just didn't. 

The decor is rather lacking and the booths were uncomfortable. The service was decent, not great. 

We ordered Gyoza, which was ok. It's pan fried instead of deep fried, so it's not very crunchy. We also ordered a volcano roll and a rainbow roll, the rainbow roll wasn't that good, the shrimp on it was chewy and the avocado tasted a bit old. They brought us a thunder roll instead of a volcano roll. I'd been debating between the two so I thought I'd ordered the wrong thing and didn't make an issue of it, but when we got the receipt it said we had, in fact, ordered the volcano roll. The thunder roll was, again, just ok. The Tea and Miso soup were good. 

All in all we just weren't impressed and we won't be going back.

"The sole reason for this establishment garnering a rating of two stems from my previous dining experiences here, whereupon the culinary offerings proved to be exceptional. However, on this particular visit, the service was subpar, to say the least. Upon entering, we were greeted promptly, yet the subsequent seating process transpired with a palpable sense of normalcy. As the restaurant gradually began to fill with patrons, our server seemed to vanish without a trace, leaving us to await her return for an interminable duration. Our initial beverages arrived in a timely fashion; the French press, in particular, was a delight to the taste buds. Nevertheless, the ensuing delay in service became increasingly pronounced, with five, ten, and ultimately fifteen minutes lapsing without any discernible attention being bestowed upon our table. My expectations for a more attentive experience remained unfulfilled, as the waitstaff continued to engage in leisurely conversation amongst themselves, oblivious to our presence. Ultimately, I elected to terminate my dining experience prematurely and depart the establishment, feeling disappointed and underwhelmed by the stark contrast in quality between this visit and my previous encounters with Postinos. It is with regret that I must conclude that I shall not be returning to the central location in the future."

I am an ardent devotee of Cirque du Soleil, having had the privilege of witnessing no less than six of their extraordinary productions, including the captivating O, the enthralling Ovo, the mystifying Mystere, the enchanting Quidam, the spellbinding Zarkana, and the mesmerizing Dralion. My curiosity was piqued by the notion of Zumanity, as the prospect of experiencing the sensual aspect of Cirque du Soleil resonated with the adult-themed ambiance of Las Vegas, which I was encountering for the first time since attaining the age of majority. Admittedly, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as I did not find the acrobatic feats to be as awe-inspiring as those showcased in many of the other Cirque shows. Furthermore, the choreography and musical accompaniment did not strike me as particularly memorable. Nonetheless, I must acknowledge that the comedic talents of the "clown" hosts of Zumanity did succeed in eliciting laughter from the audience, especially through their engagement with the crowd. The experience afforded by Zumanity diverges significantly from that of its Cirque counterparts, boasting a far more intimate atmosphere. For instance, the theater's diminutive size and the performers' warm greetings upon entry serve to create a sense of proximity and familiarity. It is worth noting that premium seating in the front row can ensure a heightened level of interaction during the performance, making it a factor to consider when booking tickets for Zumanity.

I liked the bar tops and the fact that it was nicely lit at this pub...that's about it.  Wait, the fries were pretty good...

My bf's brother got the fish sandwich with a side of wilted salad.  Yes, wilted because they had put the salad on the same plate as the fish sandwich, and the plate must have been placed under the heat lamp for quite some time prior to making it to our table.

I had the fish and chips, and again, I must admit that the garlic fries were pretty good.  The fish however, was not as good as I had hoped it to be.  The batter did not hold to the fish.  It was not fluffy and airy with the crisp to it.   

My boyfriend had the Bangers, bean and mash.  All three of us came to the agreement that the bangers tasted like breakfast sausage.  Very underwhelmed.

Will I be coming back to this Firkin place (which is a chained pub btw), highly doubted.

The food was excellent but it was very expensive for the portion sizes. For three of us at lunch, the bill before tip was $105 & we didn't even have drinks. Service was good too but again I can't justify the price.

"Peruse the critiques and it was a close call, albeit an unsuccessful endeavor, as we opted for the New York steak and veal scaloppini, in addition to a few mixed drinks...The steak, priced at thirty dollars per plate, was replete with excess fat and gristle, while my veal, which was cooked in a manner that did not resemble the traditional preparation of scallopini, was similarly marred by an unpalatable sauce that was overly reminiscent of gravy and brown in color...My martini, recommended by our server, possessed a saccharine quality, yet lacked the depth of flavor one would expect from such a beverage...Although the service was commendable, it is unlikely that we would revisit this establishment, given the plethora of alternative dining options available."

Sat at the bar for a quick glass of wine and to order some food to go. I ordered A glass of red wine. It was good, i don't know if it was worth 9$ a glass though. The bartender seemed a little mad I wanted half spinach, half romain on my Cesar salad. I'm picky, but I am nice about it. We ordered the spinach pear Gorgonzola pizza. It came out cold, and wasn't that amazing. Probably wouldn't come back.

I had been lodging at the Hilton Grand Vacations, situated across the thoroughfare and at a slight remove from the main road, and it so transpired that I found myself frequenting the Riviera on a daily basis, indulging in games of chance; the majority of the mixologists stationed at the poker bar were quite affable and accommodating, while a considerable number of the croupiers exhibited a demeanor that could be described as unpleasant or even surly, with James and Bruce standing out as particularly exceptional in their cordiality and proficiency; after suffering significant financial losses at the hands of Tang, an individual who remained impassive and unsmiling throughout the ordeal, I couldn't help but ponder why anyone would persist in patronizing the establishment for purposes of engaging in 3 card poker, and if I weren't in the company of my kin, I would have been highly unlikely to participate in such activities within these premises.

"I am utterly dumbfounded by my decision to expend in excess of thirteen dollars for a duo of frothy beverages, which, while palatable, did not possess any extraordinary qualities that would have justified such an exorbitant price tag, particularly in light of the fact that similar products are readily available at a fraction of the cost in other establishments within the vicinity of Gilbert."

I had the privilege of visiting this establishment in the recent past, accompanied by a group of four associates, subsequent to attending a performance at the Overture Center.  While the culinary offerings were generally satisfactory, albeit a tad overpriced, there were certain aspects of our dining experience that left much to be desired.  Specifically, on multiple occasions, our server removed plates containing unfinished food, which we found rather perplexing.  However, the true nadir of our encounter was our server himself, whose demeanor and communication skills left much to be desired.  A member of our party, who happens to be in the advanced stages of pregnancy, placed an order for a non-alcoholic mojito, only to be met with a quizzical expression and a query regarding her desire for vodka from our server.  After considerable effort, she managed to convey her intentions and eventually received her beverage, albeit at an exorbitant price of $11, ostensibly to compensate for the cost of mint leaves and labor involved in its preparation.  When we brought this discrepancy to our server's attention, he claimed that the absence of a specific button for such a request on the menu rendered it impossible to adjust the charge accordingly, and no managerial representative bothered to grace our table with their presence despite a ten-minute wait.  Ultimately, we elected to settle our bill and depart, feeling utterly dissatisfied with the overall experience.

We parked here and validated the ticket ourselves at the machine by the cashiers. When we left, we were told that parking was $3 and the validation was only for 3 hours. What? Boo.

I got propositioned by a weird tattoo shop owner outside the bathrooms. He had some silicon implants shaped like stars in his forehead. Weird.

We were gonna go to this "College Night" at the Canyon Club since one of our friends didn't have an ID and it was 18+ but they were charging a $10 cover. What the HECK? For underage people? What a rip-off, man. We just left.

"Greetings to an exceptional exemplification of the reasons behind a premium property in a coveted, high-traffic locale being more than half unoccupied during the evening hours. Exhibit A: Three vacuous hostesses engrossed in frivolous repartee amongst themselves, oblivious to my presence for a duration exceeding two minutes. Exhibit B: A glass of Pinot Grigio, its taste suggestive of having been opened during a previous calendar year, prompting my comment to the bartender, who responded with a dismissive assertion that it had been freshly opened, rather than offering a substitute. Furthermore, a Happy Hour characterized by a meager discount of one dollar, raising questions about the establishment's ability to maintain fiscal sustainability. Notwithstanding, the dinner portions were generous, yet the culinary offerings were merely average, with the exception of the superlative croissants, which, while delightfully warm and delectable, were unfortunately scarce and insufficient to compensate for the balance of the underwhelming experience. Considering the abundance of superior alternatives in Scottsdale, it is unlikely that this establishment will continue to operate successfully beyond the next twelve months. Therefore, it is advisable to allocate your financial resources elsewhere."

This marked my second visitation to Tee Pee Mexican Food, and the experience proved to be somewhat analogous to the initial encounter, with only minor divergences. It is worth mentioning that this establishment boasts a rich history, having been in operation for an extended period of time. Upon arriving during the lunch hour on a weekend preceding Christmas, the waiting time was not excessively prolonged. The service provided by our server was quite expeditious and cordial. The salsa presented was replete with flavor, yet the vessel containing the complementary chips (while still hot) housed some of the smallest and most fragmented examples of such culinary delights. My green corn tamale was regrettably served at a temperature that could be described as suboptimal, bordering on frigid. The accompanying rice and beans were merely average in quality. In contrast, my spouse's carne asada burrito displayed slightly more promise, although it would not require an excessive amount of effort to reach such a level. If one finds themselves in a state of extreme craving, this venue may be worthy of consideration for its salsa, margaritas, or perhaps even a refreshing cold beer. However, it is advisable to temper expectations regarding the remaining aspects of the dining experience.

"It is strongly advised against visiting this establishment on a Thursday evening, as the management elects to operate solely the rooftop sector of the club, thereby restricting access to the prime observation points and optimal Vegas-style experiences for those opting not to indulge in bottle service; such an arrangement proved to be a profound disappointment, particularly given the city's reputation for exceptional nightlife offerings, and in comparison to superior alternatives found in Austin, Texas, on even a typical Thursday night, the XS nightclub on a Friday evening offers a vastly superior experience, rendering a visit to Pure on any other night than Saturday, when entry can be obtained gratis, utterly unnecessary."

We visited this establishment on a previous occasion with our family while vacationing in Las Vegas and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves; thus, we were eager to return and partake in their culinary offerings once again. Upon our arrival, we opted for the all-you-can-eat option, and my father even overindulged to the point of experiencing discomfort. Needless to say, we were excited to revisit this restaurant and sample their delectable dishes.

Upon our return, we decided to commence our meal with alligator tail as an appetizer, which proved to be a delicious choice. However, the all-you-can-eat platters we customarily order were not as satisfying, particularly towards the beginning of the meal. It became apparent that the oil utilized for frying our fish and shrimp was not fresh, leading to an unpleasant taste. Fortunately, as our meal progressed and new batches were brought out, the quality of the food improved, and we were able to enjoy our dining experience.

In light of the above, I inquired about the oil used and was informed by our waitress that the chef did indeed replace the old oil with fresh oil towards the end of our meal. While this was reassuring, it was disappointing to note that the salad bar was not well-maintained and lacked attention to detail regarding cleanliness. Additionally, it would be beneficial to have identical items on both sides of the buffet to facilitate navigation and minimize spills. Nonetheless, we appreciated the fact that the plates were kept chilled.

Despite some drawbacks, our server provided adequate service, fulfilling her responsibilities effectively. Unfortunately, our enthusiasm for this restaurant has waned due to the inconsistency in the quality of the food and ambiance. It is worth noting that this establishment opens at 5 pm, so patrons should plan their visits accordingly to avoid disappointment.

I only ate here since I was staying at the W. 

I will admit. hot waitresses. 
but then again, u are in montreal. so nothing new there.

welp. thats all that this restaurant has going for it. They really try to go for fancy french-inspired dishes but they end up just trying too hard. The flavors don't reaaaally work. 

can't really say much more.. 

breakfast is okay though. pass!

When we arrived at McCarren and went to get the rental car, I initially thought \"hey, I made the right choice.  Look at these 5-6 people ahead of me in line while either one person or no one was at the other rental car sections all around\".  Not the case.  Why?  Later in the weekend I needed a car again, and went with Budget that time.  Budget's price was just as good as Dollar's, and Budget had nicer cars available.  Meanwhile, in this first experience, Dollar only had two people behind the counter.  I don't think I've ever waited in a 5-6 person line for soooooooooooooooo long.  It became painfully frustrating to the point that I considered trying to cancel the reservation on my smartphone and schedule a whole new one at one of the other car rental agencies there.  Not cool Dollar!
Atmosphere is great! Food is not. Had the pasta w meatballs which consisted of a bowl of gummy flavorless pasta w 2 small meatballs for $15.00. I left hungry and went home and ate a PB&J sandwich.

Shopping in a mall has become a thing of the past for me, but I have a gift card that has been burning a hole in my pocket so we decided to do some good old-fashioned shopping in a department store. The store is pretty outdated and I was little disappointed by the lack of inventory to choose from. \n\nI was pretty sad by how little enjoyment I had in this shopping trip. It felt like more of a chore than anything.

Like a lot of the other yelpers on here, I visited because I saw it on Man Vs Food. 
We arrived about 11am, and although it didn't look busy we had to wait 10 minutes to be seated.

I can't fault our server, she was attentive, knowledgeable, and very friendly. 
We both ordered French Toast, and just had coffee to drink.

Yes the portions were huge, and they had loads of pecan nuts on top, but the toast itself wasn't anything amazing, and costs a lot more than Denny's!

I wasn't that impressed - if I did go again I think I'd try one of the Hash dishes.

Slightly better than dominos/pizza hut/little Caesars but the price doesn't pay for quality and amount of pizza. Save your money instead for another pizza place. Seriously 20 bucks for a medium sized pizza?

Don't go.

The lamest buffet I've ever participated in.

If you're staying at the Gold Coast, just walk accross the street to the Palms buffet.

At least the food didn't hurt me belly. For that, I give it two stars.

It's a "UPS" store.... you bring in a package... they take it... you wave goodbye to it... you leave.

Sometime after that a big Brown Truck arrives and wisks said package off to its destination. 

This UPS Store was unremarkable... the guy behind the counter did his job... nothing more nothing less.

I went in one day for a Orange Julius and the machine was not working. A week later stopped in with some coworkers and chocolate cone wasnt available. A number of workers but awkward ordering and delivery system. I could not identify a supervisor/manager on duty during either visit.

I love going out for breakfast, but there are a couple of reasons I won't go back here.  First of all, too expensive.  My girlfriend and I each had eggs benedict and coffees, and it was 40 bucks!  Second reason, the portions are huge.  I am always disappointed to see such huge portions coming out of a professional kitchen, because I realize how much food is headed toward the trash bin each day.  If you must serve such huge portions, please advise on the menu ahead of time.  \n\nThe most important reason I won't head back here...  unripened fruit as a garnish on my plate.  Just serve me what's in season please.  If it is in season, a tomato in summer for example, please make sure it's fresh, local, and ripe.  I was shocked when the waitress asked me if I wanted to add tomato to my dish and then she served me a hard, barely pink slice of tomato.  It's in season people!  Where did this tomato come from, South America?

I am an ardent devotee of Nordstrom's Rack, and my fervor for the brand is invariably piqued whenever a novel location is inaugurated within a 2 state radius (California/Nevada). My unwavering dedication prompts me to venture forth and experience the nascent retail establishment firsthand. Throughout my extensive peregrinations to upwards of 15 Nordstrom Racks, I have discerned that certain venues excel whereas others fall short of my expectations. However, this particular store surpasses them all in terms of its paltry proportions and woefully inadequate array of masculine attire. The Men's Department, in particular, is risibly diminutive, and the selection on offer is utterly deficient. My futile quest to unearth even a solitary item worthy of purchase left me feeling despondent and disillusioned. In an attempt to assuage my disenchantment, I opted to visit the Rack in Henderson, whereupon I acquired two sweaters. Despite my initial enthusiasm, I now harbor doubts regarding the likelihood of my return to Summerlin solely for the purpose of patronizing this specific store. My disappointment knows no bounds.

After a night out and skipping dinner, we were starved! We really wanted to try the Mexican restaurant in Aria but they were closing (boo!). After asking which restaurants are still opened we chose Lemongrass. 

The decor is pretty and modern. The booths are hard to get into though! You cant just slide in. On the table they have a cup with wooden/bamboo chopsticks. I personally think if it was an upscale Asian restaurant they'd be pretty and reusable but that's my opinion. 

We ordered Tom Kha Chicken to start which was awesome. They didn't spoon the soup into individual bowls which I thought was odd. I guess I'm just use to Asian restaurants doing that. For our main course we had black pepper prawns, sweet and sour chicken, some kind of curry, and I think Chow Fun. All tasted good but weren't outstanding. I guess I've had better Thai/ Chinese food with better service for cheaper back home. But then again I have to give them credit for being open so late. 

After adding some sodas, beers, and white rice the total was well over $100. Overall I doubt I will return even for late night grub.

This venue has the potential to evoke feelings of slight discomfort and confinement, particularly for individuals who have previously visited the LV North Premium Outlets and are accustomed to a more spacious and open atmosphere. A comparison of the two locations reveals several key differences:  
* While parking may be less challenging at this location, the absence of adequate stop lights may result in delays when attempting to exit the premises due to heavy traffic.  
* The indoor setting provides a welcome respite from the sweltering temperatures during the summer months in Las Vegas; however, the layout and design of the interior space may contribute to a sense of claustrophobia and discomfort.  
* Although the variety of stores at this location is impressive, it falls short of the extensive selection available at the North outlets, which cater to a broader range of consumer preferences and demands.  
* The presence of numerous dining options within close proximity provides convenience for shoppers seeking sustenance; nevertheless, the overall ambiance and appeal of the North outlets remain unmatched.  
* Notwithstanding the drawbacks associated with the North outlets, I maintain a preference for shopping at that location, as the ability to navigate the outdoor spaces without difficulty and conveniently access the primary stores of interest makes for a more enjoyable and efficient retail experience. Our excursion, unfortunately, did not yield the desired results.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
The atmosphere at this establishment exudes an aura of sterility and positivity, however, the staff's demeanor could be perceived as lacking in warmth and cordiality. Prices are reasonable, yet not particularly competitive. My manicure, unfortunately, was marred by an abundance of air bubbles, detracting from its overall appearance. A paltry array of hues is available for selection, rendering the experience even more unremarkable. As a recent transplant to this locality, my quest for novel experiences has led me to conclude that a return visit to this salon would not be forthcoming."

"The allure of a home-cooked turkey and roast beef proved irresistible, enticing me to indulge in a culinary experience that, unfortunately, did not live up to expectations. Upon entering the establishment, I was met with a disappointing sight - the once-promising dish had been reduced to a state of disarray, resembling a canine's haphazard repast. As Mr. Ramsey would aptly put it, 'it was a dog's dinner, indeed!' Despite the setback, I opted for the bobby, primarily motivated by the desire to sample both the savory roast beef and the delectable bread. Alas, the latter proved to be the highlight of the dish, as the stuffing was unpleasantly cool to the touch and the meat itself was parched, evoking an unfortunate comparison to sawdust in both texture and flavor. It is conceivable that the unshredded cuts of meat, when paired with the satisfying bread, might have yielded a more enjoyable experience; however, the underwhelming nature of the dish left much to be desired. Adding insult to injury, the manager boasted openly about his lack of involvement in the daily operations, instead choosing to focus on micromanaging tasks, a fact that only served to further exacerbate my disappointment. In conclusion, a more attentive approach to food preparation and management would greatly benefit this establishment."

I would of gave this buffet a 3 star than I thought to myself I really experienced better...also if i wanted to eat a buffet like this place, than I could of stayed in Cali and ate a buffet that would of been cheaper. \nThe whole appearance does look beautiful though.

I went to The Keg last night for the first time, and I was a little disappointed.  I ordered the filet and lobster tail, and everything on my plate came out over-cooked.  I asked for the filet to be cooked medium rare, and it came out unevenly cooked -- half was well done and the other half was medium well.  The asparagus was so over-cooked that it resembled the pressure cooked stuff that comes out of a can.  I couldn't eat it.  The lobster was the best thing on the plate, but even it was a bit rubbery.  Even if they had cooked my food correctly, I'm not sure the experience would have been much better.  The food quality is only marginally better than Outback, but the price is much higher -- more like an upscale steakhouse. If you are looking for something that's a little better than Outback, then this might be the place for you.  However, since your already paying upscale prices, I would prefer to go to somewhere like Morton's, Ruth's Chris, The Palm, or Donovan's.  At places like these, you pay for quality and you actually get it.  I'm not sure I'll go back to The Keg.

This place used to be great, but it's sad to see what it has turned into. One of their selling points was a variety of classes that were available from 5 am to 11 pm. Now they have very limited classes that are jammed packed with signs stating that's tips are mandatory. Very low class! They no longer offer shampoo or conditioner in the locker rooms and have no place to hang a towel while in the shower. The staff is very unorganized when it comes to class cards and often forget to pass them out. I recently renewed my membership after taking a few months off and needless to say....had I taken a few classes before renewing, I wouldn't have renewed. The only reason I keep coming back is because the instructors are awesome.
So the last couple reviews I've done have been kind of negative. So, I've decided to keep this one positive.\n\nThey have a really nice patio! That is all.

"Our recent experiences at this establishment have been utterly disillusioning, as the culinary offerings have consistently fallen short of our expectations. Specifically, the potatoes have been unacceptably desiccated and the eggs have been cooked to an unpalatable doneness. Furthermore, the overall gustatory experience has been subpar, with the sriracha sauce exhibiting an egregious deviation from its intended hue. We cannot help but suspect that the sauce has been subjected to some form of adulteration, perhaps via the nefarious activities of a charlatan seeking to pass off an inferior product as the genuine article. In light of these findings, we have decided to sever our relationship with this restaurant, as it has become abundantly clear that the issues plaguing it are not merely temporary or superficial, but rather indicative of a deep-seated incompetence or lack of concern for quality on the part of its management."

On a graduated scale of culinary satisfaction ranging from a meager one to an impressive ten, I would confer a mediocre rating of five on this particular dining experience. The flavor profile of the burger patty itself was unremarkable, lacking any discernible depth or complexity, while the bun was utterly forgettable in its blandness. Furthermore, a flagrant mistake in our order resulted in my receiving an unsolicited side of french fries instead of the onion rings I had explicitly requested. Although the staff did offer profuse apologies and eventually brought out the correct item several minutes later, the onion rings proved to be merely passable, failing to impress my palate with their uninspired seasoning and texture. In addition, I found the portion of fries I sampled while awaiting the correction of the error to be thoroughly unexceptional, neither remarkable for their crispiness nor distinguished by any unique flavor component. Considering the price point of ten to twelve dollars for a fundamental burger and fries combo, I must aver that such an exorbitant tariff seems patently disproportionate to the actual value offered by this establishment. However, I must admit that the beer selection redeemed the dining experience somewhat, boasting a pleasing array of choices that were both refreshing and well-chilled. Alas, the quality of service remained stubbornly average overall, leaving much to be desired in terms of attentiveness, responsiveness, and general hospitality. Given the dearth of clientele on a Friday evening, it becomes apparent that discerning gastronomes would be well-advised to seek out more satisfactory options for their hard-earned dining dollars.

The first time I came here was awesome.  The second time.. not so much.

Can't remember the girl's name, but after 30 seconds of starting she stopped to use the phone.  Then, she stood in front of me (while I was leaned back in the chair) for a good 15 minutes just gabbing on the phone.  Three other workers were standing around me as well.. none of them had the decency to finish my brows.  Also, throughout her conversation, she kept holding her finger up and telling me to "wait," even though I wasn't saying anything.  

When she finally got off the phone, she finished my brows.  At one point she yanked really hard and my eye watered.  She then called me a crybaby.  Thanks?

When I went to the register to pay, she asked me how much I was leaving her for a tip.  Wow.

2 stars because both times I've been here, my brows looked pretty good.  However there are a million other places I'll go to instead who can do just as good of a job without the rude service and horrible location.

"Although I consumed a sizable burger, I found the culinary experience to be merely adequate. I would have preferred a smaller portion size with increased gastronomic excellence. Unfortunately, this dining establishment does not warrant a repeat visit. Following a partial consumption of approximately one-third of my meal, I felt underwhelmed. However, the presence of a vintage tractor did generate a modicum of interest."

My maiden encounter was such a sensational and extraordinary experience that I felt an ardent desire to return and partake in the culinary delights once more. I presumed that the pinnacle of service, an exquisite selection of wines, delectable fare, and an ambiance that exuded elegance and sophistication would be the norm. However, my expectations were not merely surpassed but utterly eviscerated during my second visit. A complete reversal of fortunes, if you will.

I must emphasize that the quality of service provided by our server left much to be desired. His inattentiveness and lack of acute listening skills were glaring deficiencies that marred the overall dining experience. It is worth noting that during my previous visit, each dish was meticulously portioned and presented with precision. Alas, that was not the case on this particular occasion. The steak, once a crown jewel of culinary excellence, was unceremoniously hacked into at the table, thereby obliterating the presentation and rendering it utterly unappetizing.

Furthermore, the steak knives arrived belatedly, only after the steak had been served. Needless to say, this is an unprecedented occurrence in any reputable steakhouse. Our server's tardiness in addressing our concerns was only exacerbated by his lackadaisical attitude when he finally did arrive. By the time he bothered to acknowledge our plight, the food had become frigid, rendering it inedible.

To add insult to injury, the waiter had the temerity to suggest that had the chef sliced the steak in the kitchen, an additional fee would have been incurred. I implore him to locate the corresponding button on the POS system, for I am convinced that no such charge exists. The icing on the cake, if you will, was the waiter's persistent and intrusive presence at our table, likened to a shark circling its prey. Suffice it to say, this experience was not about commemorating our special occasion but rather about our waiter's ineptitude and overzealous attempts to salvage the situation.

Not a fan.

Went here upon my sister's recommendation but she also said she hadn't been there in about 10 years. So I chanced it because I live really close.

We sit down and the first question our server asks us rather abruptly is, do you have a Groupon? I was like, uh no. Is there a Groupon? So I look on my phone and sure enough there was so I bought one -$19 for $30.

I was not impressed with the food at all. Every roll had cream cheese and krab mix in it or some variation of that. So not a great selection. Wasn't especially fresh and definitely flavorless. And the rice to fish ratio in the rolls was way off. They were like all rice no fish.

On top of that, our food took forever. Sigh.

Not a great value. Without the groupon our bill would have been close to $60 for some mediocre sushi.

So I guess a lot of people come here for their $20 all you can eat special. We decided not to because of all the rules and conditions. No sharing. If you don't eat it all, you pay for what you don't eat...seriously?

One bright spot was the service was pretty good.

Overall, won't be back :/

The store is amazing and the chocolate fountain is awesome. This review is for the customer service. 
I have never been here before and asked the cashier "how sweet are your iced mochas?" The response "well it's chocolate." Great! I know that. Are we talking one pump? Two pumps? Am I going to walk away diabetic?! 

I know you are hating your life as every child in Vegas wants a gelato but for those of us who want coffee, AND don't want to drink a milkshake, put on a smile and pretend to give a sh*t about customer service. 

Thanks!

If you relish copious amounts of unremarkable to subpar cuisine accompanied by a nonexistent attention to customer satisfaction, then this establishment may appeal to your sensibilities.  I am conflicted between conferring one or two stars upon this venue; however, I shall bestow upon it the benefit of the doubt and assign it a rating of two stars.  This recently inaugurated eatery boasts a pristine ambiance, surpassing that of Hometown Buffet.  My culinary experience was marred by a succession of disappointments, including a lean, overcooked steak that necessitated an interminable wait in line, unpalatable popcorn shrimp, and a tough, fried fish.  The fried chicken, barbecued chicken, and rotisserie chicken were uninspired, yet edible.  It is worth noting that certain menu items were mislabeled.  The dessert selection was meager, offering limited options for a buffet-style restaurant.  The staff's organizational skills left much to be desired, as evidenced by their sluggishness in clearing used plates and the prolonged wait we endured before our drink orders were fulfilled.  Furthermore, the practice of requiring patrons to retrieve their beverages prior to settling their tabs significantly impedes the efficiency of the queue.  Additionally, a surcharge of $1.99 is applied to each drink, and an exorbitant fee of $5 per pound is levied on takeout orders.  While it is undeniably fascinating to observe the ravenous patronage that frequents this establishment, I shall decline to partake in this indulgence in the future.

They indubitably harbor benevolent intentions within these walls, yet there exists an excessive quantity of aspects worthy of lamentation. To begin with, the interior design exudes an uninspired and melancholic ambiance, prompting one to ponder whether aesthetic considerations were truly given due diligence. Moreover, on a balmy day in Las Vegas, where the mercury rises to a comfortable 75 degrees Fahrenheit, the ambient temperature within this establishment proved to be oppressively sweltering. Indeed, my spouse, who customarily remains impervious to fluctuations in temperature, found it conspicuously warm. The furniture, comprising tables and sofas, appears diminutive and uninviting, respectively. Furthermore, the prolonged preparation time for our smoothie orders seemed to suggest that the fruit utilized in their concoction had been cultivated on site, such was the interminable delay before their arrival. Although the final product proved satisfying, albeit belated, the portion size accompanying the \"hummus delight\" appetizer proved insufficient, rendering the experience somewhat unsatisfactory. Notably, the absence of feta cheese in my wife's Greek salad bordered on the inexcusable, transforming an otherwise palatable dish into a mediocre offering. My spicy beef panini, while flavorsome, exhibited evidence of culinary tribulations, manifesting as charring and the presence of extraneous ingredients upon its surface. 
 In conclusion, although the edibles generally met expectations, the sluggish pace of service and unfortunate presentation, in conjunction with the dismal surroundings and elevated pricing, precludes the possibility of a future visit.

This establishment does not possess an adequate level of quality, as evidenced by the inconsistency in the preparation of their signature dish, sesame chicken, which, on occasion, can be deemed satisfactory, but more frequently, falls short of expectations. Furthermore, the remaining menu items have been described as either mediocre or unpalatable. Additionally, concerns regarding food safety have arisen due to the presence of an insect fragment discovered within the plastic wrapping encasing the meal container. Consequently, it is not advisable to consume food at this location.

"Our sojourn at this establishment was marked by a succession of contrasting experiences, wherein each positive aspect was promptly succeeded by an unfortunate counterpart. The accommodations, while commodious, were also noticeably unkempt and unsanitary. The sleeping quarters, though well-appointed with a comfortable bed, were accompanied by pillows that lacked adequate support and were generally unsatisfactory. Furthermore, the room's decor, while featuring some aesthetically pleasing elements, was overall outdated and reminiscent of a dystopian, futuristic setting. Additionally, our particular room was designated as a 'robo-cop' space, which added to the overall ambiance of the stay. In terms of connectivity, the hotel offered wireless internet access; however, the policy regarding device pairing was exorbitant, with each additional device incurring a daily fee of $14, which we found to be utterly preposterous. The pool area, while expansive and featuring an interesting gaming facility outside, was offset by the modest size of the pools themselves, which were further subject to a rental fee for seating. This, coupled with the unexpected resort fees and taxes tacked onto the final bill upon checkout, made for a questionable value proposition. The quality of service throughout the hotel was inconsistent, with moments of excellence juxtaposed with instances of mediocrity. Taking into account these factors, it is our recommendation that potential patrons consider alternative lodging options that offer a superior overall experience."

Eh! This place looks promising after looking at reviews and the menu, but don't be fooled it's not great!  

We started by ordering the fries sampler with zucchini, Mac n cheese and pepper jack shots (just fried cheese). This was delicious!' Then we ordered burgers and shakes and beer. The burgers didn't come out as ordered and at the end we were charged for everything we ordered that wasn't on the burger. The burgers took a while. The shake and beer we ordered with our appetizers didn't come out until halfway through the burgers! We also had to remind her twice about them!!  

The burgers weren't very good. The pepper bacon was sweet... Shouldn't be! The burger meat was mealy. I would only go back for the shake (Nutella with Godiva chocolate liqueur) and the pepper jack cheese shots. Don't go in with high expectations!

"My experience at China Poblano was a regrettable error in judgment, precipitated by my elevated expectations due to its affiliation with the renowned culinary virtuoso, Jose Andres. Upon perusing the menu, I was dissuaded from immediate departure by the promise of Mr. Andres's reputation, leading me to indulge in an overpriced dim sum serving at $11.00. Mr. Andres is celebrated for his expertise in tapas, which prompted our group to order several tapas servings to share. Unfortunately, the offerings were merely satisfactory, failing to elicit a profound culinary experience commensurate with the price point. A miniature pork sandwich, priced at $8, fell short of my expectation of a mind-blowing experience. The standout dish was an eggplant entrÃ©e, yet it lacked sufficient appeal to warrant a future visit. In an attempt to enhance the dining experience, I experimented with consuming Chinese and Mexican dishes simultaneously, but this endeavor proved futile. The restaurant's concept of fusing two distinct menus under one roof only served to confuse my palate further. While the ambiance was stylish and fashionable, it failed to compensate for the deficiency in flavor satisfaction relative to the cost. Consequently, I shall seek alternative establishments that provide a more harmonious balance between taste and price."

Fairview Grill has opted to metamorphose its moniker to Lucky Louie's, a transformation that, quite frankly, has failed to generate any profound impact or excitement. In point of fact, the quality of the culinary offerings and beverage selection remains subpar and unimpressive, respectively. My recent dining experience at this establishment, accompanied by a companion, proved to be an utter disappointment, as the fare served was not merely unpalatable but also induced nausea, necessitating the utilization of antacid upon returning home. 
  An examination of the menu reveals the following:  
  Wings: It is advisable to avoid the jerk sauce, as it lacks flavor and is generally unappealing. The barbecue sauce, conversely, exhibits some degree of palatability.  
  Sides: The buffalo fries, accompanied by a side of ranch dressing for dipping, demonstrated a certain appeal, specifically in terms of taste.  
  Burger: The bacon cheeseburger, while falling short of my personal preference for a well-done cooking style, was only partially consumed due to the absence of crispiness in the bacon and the lack of A1 sauce.  
  Notwithstanding the aforementioned deficiencies, Lucky Louie's does possess several redeeming characteristics, including:  
  1. A commendable Golden Tee and Silver Strike Bowling Machine  
  2. Pool tables for patrons to engage in recreational activities  
  3. A prominent projector screen positioned at the forefront, complemented by numerous flat-screen televisions strategically placed throughout the establishment  
  4. Access to the NFL Network, catering to sports enthusiasts  
  Given the unsatisfactory dining experience and the unremarkable nature of the food and drinks, it is unlikely that I will return to Lucky Louie's, except under duress.

I've been to Panchero's, and I probably won't go back.  If I ever find myself in that center again, I will be at either Jersey Mike's, Starbucks or Yogurtland!  The flavor of the food was decent.....but they were so stingy on everything that it pissed me off before I even got a chance to taste the food!\n\nGet this...they measure out the cheese in this little scoop....are you kidding me!?!?!  It was probably an ounce of cheese, which if you are like me, is not nearly enough cheese to go around.  Also, when I said that I didn't want the rice, just beans, I still got the same amount of beans that a person who ordered rice got....beans are like the cheapest food on the planet....don't be so stingy!  The carnitas was pretty tasty, but I just felt like I was being so jipped as far as the value and the portions went that in order for me to return...a mass destruction of all the Rubio's, Chipotle's and Baja Fresh's would have to occur...and even then...I would probably still pick taco bell....you just can't beat 89 cent bean burritos!

"Tusca's interior ambiance was satisfactory, but the service was subpar, as the staff displayed a lack of enthusiasm in assisting us.  Prices were consistent with our expectations, and the cuisine was unremarkable but adequate.  Unfortunately, Tusca's proximity to superior tapas establishments and the prevalence of middle-aged women seeking younger, upwardly mobile males as clientele detracted from our dining experience.  This observation was based on our limited visits to the restaurant."

I had such high hopes based upon the recommendations but was sorely disappointed. The wait staff seemed distracted or else just not interested in our table. It took forever just to place our orders, which were not complicated: one crepe, one brownie, one petite pot. Unfortunately, we got two crepes and no brownie. Considering the brownie were for our small children, both of which had had it promised for good dinners,  just compounded the disappointment. We tried and tried to flag a wait person to correct the error to no avail. When we eventually did have someone respond, it was getting too late for us to wait any longer. We received an anemic apology at best. The food was delicious, and we do like supporting local businesses, but this location's service is in need of a reboot.

"It is with profound dismay that we must convey our utter disappointment with the recent dining experience at Xinh Xinh, a restaurant that once held such promise and esteem in our culinary excursions. The precipitous decline in the quality of their offerings has rendered us incredulous and disillusioned, prompting us to reconsider our future patronage. Our previous visits had been characterized by an abundance of delectable options, generously portioned and expertly prepared. However, our most recent foray proved to be an unmitigated disaster, with dishes that fell woefully short of our expectations. The banh mis, once a staple of our dining experiences, arrived with paltry amounts of meat, rendering them decidedly lackluster. Furthermore, the bubble teas, once a proud hallmark of their menu, have now become a shadow of their former self, bereft of the rich flavors that once distinguished them from their competitors. It is with great reluctance that we must concede that our loyalty has been betrayed, and our faith in the establishment shaken. In light of these developments, we feel compelled to explore alternative venues and culinary endeavors, including the possibility of creating our own renditions of beloved Vietnamese dishes."

"Recall, if you will, the venerable advertisement for Wendy's featuring an elderly woman querying, 'Where's the beef?' Indeed, we would be remiss not to draw a parallel between that particular televisual promotion and our own experience with the green chili beef chimichanga at a certain establishment, whereupon, upon splitting said dish, we discovered a paltry quantity of beef, barely sufficient to satiate a geriatric canine, let alone a hungry human, and a scant few green chilies, rendering the entire ordeal a rather underwhelming experience, leading one to surmise that, much like the aforementioned matriarch, we, too, might be inclined to pose the inquiry, 'Where, pray tell, is the beef?' and, in light of such glaring deficiencies, offer a prognosis of approximately six months, barring any substantive enhancements to the culinary offerings."

"The meager serving proportions ostensibly justify the elevated price point, rendering the establishment's pricing strategy somewhat dubious. Moreover, the absence of the signature dish, sisig, during our visit within the initial two weeks of operation raises concerns regarding the restaurant's operational efficiency. Furthermore, the asynchronous arrival of our orders magnifies the perception of subpar service, which is further compounded by the server's seemingly adequate yet unremarkable performance. It appears that the staff's primary focus is on maintaining a tidy dining area, rather than prioritizing customer satisfaction. Ultimately, our experience was marred by numerous shortcomings."

Hardly utopian for this beer fan. Nice ambiance, on hip lower rue Crescent, and a nice mix in the crowd.

Ordered the IPA on the recommendation of the very good bartender. What a disappointment -- virtually flavorless. Not what I'd expect of an IPA at all. Probably should have tried something else, but I just moved on.

Oh, and like other independent brewpubs in Montreal - cash only. Boo for the business traveler.

"Mediocre at best" does not adequately convey the subpar quality of the culinary experience we endured at this purported Peruvian eatery. Upon arriving on a Saturday afternoon in search of a midday repast, we were met with an utter lack of the grilled fowl advertised by the establishment's moniker. It is indeed a curious phenomenon when a restaurant, self-proclaimed as a specialist in Peruvian cuisine, fails to provide the very item that gives its name. One might liken it to a hot dog stand devoid of its titular offering. 

Perusing the menu, we opted for the Tacu Tacu, a dish ostensibly comprising a substantial heap of rice and beans, accompanied by a modest portion of grilled flesh. Alas, the presentation was found wanting, with nary a vegetable or pickle in sight. For such a meager offering, one would expect a more reasonable tariff than the ten dollars demanded. 

The Antichuchos, slices of meat impaled upon a skewer, were served with an unimpressive medley of corn and undercooked potatoes. While the meat proved passable, the accompanying sides fell short of even the most minimal gastronomic expectations. 

Lastly, we sampled an appetizer, referred to as pappas a la huancaina, which consisted of three lackluster boiled potato slices, haphazardly arranged upon a Styrofoam platter, smothered in a tepid, cheesy sauce. For five dollars, one could hardly deem it a bargain.

"Although I had anticipated a positive experience at this establishment, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as I failed to discern any truly exceptional qualities; the burgers and fries, in particular, were merely average, and the prices, while not exorbitant, were still somewhat elevated relative to the culinary offerings of other eateries within the city limits; nevertheless, the convenience of its round-the-clock operations did somewhat mitigate my disappointment."

Went on a Sunday morning about 10am. It was clearly busier than the staff and kitchen crew are able to handle. The place was packed but the tables were not full. It took a while to order and then the order was not correct when it came to the table. The appetizer cinnamon roll never came, my drink was not refilled and my pancake was burnt (black). The hash browns needed some love and my french toast seemed old. I hope they get their act together, it has the right ingredients to make it happen.

Our quartet was eagerly anticipating experiencing this establishment, predicated upon the favorable critiques we had perused. Upon arriving at 4:00 PM, we were disheartened to discover that the venue only offers a morning repast on weekends, specifically Saturdays and Sundays, and that their evening fare does not commence until 5:30 PM. This rendered it impractical for us to partake of their culinary offerings at such an unconventional hour, particularly given our Monday through Friday work schedules, which precluded the possibility of us ever savoring their midday cuisine. Notwithstanding, we shall endeavor to revisit the premises at a later time for an evening meal.

"Gosh! This establishment's service speed left much to be desired. Upon entering, it became apparent that no host was present to accommodate us; thus, we proceeded directly to the bar, anticipating a more expedient experience. Unfortunately, this was not the case, as there were merely two couples and an additional table that the bartender was attending to, resulting in an extended delay before we received a greeting. Moreover, the bartender professed that she needed to locate mint for my mojito, further exacerbating the wait. Eventually, we obtained our beverages, yet menus were not offered to us. I had to personally retrieve them from the host stand. To my chagrin, I had to request water twice, first from the bartender and subsequently from someone who delivered our meals, as the initial request was ignored. The culinary offerings were unremarkable and typical of what one would expect from an Applebee's. Our appetizer, drinks, and entrees were consumed, but the table was not cleared until the server collected our credit card for payment. What truly incensed me was that a group of three individuals entered the bar subsequent to our arrival and received prompt attention and beverage service from the bartender, who seemed to recognize them. Such disparity in treatment was utterly unacceptable. In light of this experience, I am unlikely to return to this establishment, even considering its proximity to our lodging."

Disappointed. Was recommended, was expecting so much. Was a bit dirty, waited ages to get served, so long we nearly walked out. Looked like loads of managers, no staff. Staff looked bored and poorly trained. What a let down.

Philly cheesesteak not good. Cheap dried up luke warm meet. Not served as described on their menu. My husband got a turkey sandwich, which was ok but nothing to write home about. This place may be good if you're drunk and hungry at 2AM, but if you're just looking for a good quick bite for lunch SKIP THIS PLACE.

"I have had the opportunity to sample a few of their vegetarian curries, and unfortunately, they failed to impress. The flavors were subpar and the quality was inferior. Perhaps their non-vegetarian options fare better...\nIt is my understanding that due to their proximity to the academic institution, they may be able to get by with offering less refined cuisine, but that does not preclude the fact that I would not advocate for anyone seeking delectable Indian fare to patronize this establishment."

"The quality of service at this establishment has significantly deteriorated! The admission cost for two individuals amounts to $120, in addition to which a Platinum Flash Pass, purportedly designed to curtail waiting periods in lines, costs an extra $140. However, the efficacy of this pass is highly dubious, and many would argue that it constitutes a scam. For instance, the description provided on the official website, http://www.laronde.com/larondefr/flashpass.asp, appears to be intentionally misleading. Furthermore, the regulations pertaining to the Platinum Flash Pass seem to be arbitrarily modified at will, which is particularly annoying given that I had allocated a total of $400 for an enjoyable excursion with my child. Not only were the passes falsely advertised as limited, but I was also compelled to stand in line for certain attractions despite possessing a Platinum Flash Pass. Moreover, not all rides are covered by this pass, which raises questions regarding its validity. 

In addition, I requested a beer, for which I paid $6.50. Considering the price, I expected a properly poured beverage, consisting of three-quarters liquid and one-quarter foam. However, the drink was prepared by a 16-year-old, which is problematic considering the legal implications. As someone familiar with the food industry and aware of relevant laws, I intend to file a formal complaint with the RÃ©gie des alcools, des courses et des jeux (Quebec's liquor, racing, and gaming board). It is unacceptable for minors to be serving alcohol, and it appears that Provincial regulations do not apply to Six Flags in Quebec."

This production offered subpar artistic value, with an exorbitant admission price and a dearth of genuine choreographic displays, instead relying heavily on juvenile and sexually suggestive gestures, as well as mimetic comedy that fell short of sophisticated humor. Throughout the entire performance, my companion and I anticipated the arrival of a truly captivating and polished show, but unfortunately, such an event failed to materialize. With the exception of a solitary routine, the remainder of the program lacked the artistic merit and finesse exhibited by the troupe on the televised dance competition. Furthermore, upon exiting the venue, a member of the audience proclaimed the show to be "sooooo good," prompting my spouse and me to speculate whether we had attended the same event, as the production seemed tailored to a younger demographic.

"My affection for Kirkland Signature frozen yogurt notwithstanding, I have been consistently subjected to a conspicuously hollowed-out serving whenever I opt for it at this particular food court establishment, leading me to surmise that such a practice may be an intrinsic component of the employees' training protocol. Furthermore, the pepperoni pizza served here is characterized by an excessive amount of grease, necessitating the procurement of an abundance of napkins to effectively address the issue prior to consumption. Indeed, the grease in question is not only present at the base of the pizza but also dispersed throughout the plate, rendering it a veritable challenge to enjoy without considerable preparation."

While in Arizona, I presumed that any Mexican eatery would be satisfactory, but unfortunately, my expectations were not met. My husband's uncle and his spouse highly recommended this particular establishment, so we accompanied them for an evening meal.
