The restaurant is situated within a plaza, and upon entry, it becomes apparent that the interior design is aesthetically pleasing, boasting Spanish-inspired elements and an inviting ambiance. Following our arrival, we were required to wait momentarily for the staff to prepare a suitable table, during which time we escorted our offspring to the lavatory facilities. The restrooms were impressively maintained, exhibiting a high level of cleanliness. Subsequent to our completion of the necessary tasks in the bathroom, we were seated, and our server promptly emerged to take our beverage and salsa requests. The restaurant offers a selection of salsas, but unfortunately, their primary offering did not meet my expectations - typically, I would consume salsa and chips without hesitation, but in this instance, the salsa was not palatable. The accompanying chips were also subpar. Opting for the cheese dip instead, I found it to be relatively satisfying. However, my experience with the chimichanga was disappointing, as it lacked both cheese and flavor, leading me to return it uneaten. Furthermore, I was unimpressed by my family members' dishes, which further reinforced my dissatisfaction with the culinary offerings. Despite the pleasant ambiance and commendable service, this establishment only merits a rating of two, primarily due to its shortcomings in accurately representing authentic Mexican cuisine.
Pizza tastes good. But delivery is horrible. Pick it up yourself unless you want to wait 1.5 hours to eat.

I am a habitual patron of Kabuki, primarily for professional luncheons during the week, but today, I opted to indulge my spouse and progeny in a culinary excursion featuring sushi, alas, the quality of service I experienced was utterly deplorable. It is conceivable that my perception may have been skewed by the contrast between the proficient and expeditious lunch staff and the sluggish and inattentive server assigned to our table, Andy, who appeared to be juggling an excessive number of tables, his attention being diverted by frivolous conversations with fellow servers and the hostess, rather than focusing on ensuring that our dining experience was satisfactory. To illustrate the extent of the poor service we endured, our appetizers and salads arrived belatedly, after we had already devoured our sushi rolls, beverages remained unfilled, and it took Andy approximately twenty minutes to retrieve my payment and verify the check, rendering the entire ordeal a regrettable and frustrating experience. It is unfortunate that Kabuki failed to secure staff members who demonstrate a modicum of enthusiasm for their work, thereby jeopardizing the satisfaction of their clientele, hence, potential patrons should exercise caution when considering dining at this establishment, as the cuisine, though passable, cannot compensate for the deficiency in customer service.

"Concurring with the plethora of individuals expressing their dissatisfaction with this particular Walmart location, I must confess that my experiences over the past year have led me to migrate my pharmaceutical needs to an alternative store within the same chain, primarily due to the pervasive squalor that has rendered it increasingly challenging to patronize this establishment. Although I generally hold Walmart in high esteem, this specific branch has unfortunately earned a reputation that precludes me from unreservedly endorsing it among my acquaintances, anecdotally reinforced by a friend whose brief visit was marred by an unsettling auditory encounter in the adjacent lavatory, thereby irrevocably tainting her impression of Walmart and precluding future visits."

"Friday Happy Hour Menu: A culinary delight featuring an assortment of delectable dishes, including Steak and Cheese at a reasonable price point of $6, accompanied by a savory Neopolitan Milkshake for a mere $4. However, we regret to inform that the Gyro will not be available for subsequent visits. Nevertheless, the Panini remains an acceptable option at a comparable cost of $6. It is worth noting that the service tends to be sluggish, even when the establishment is nearly vacant. Ultimately, this venue serves as a suitable destination for individuals experiencing acute hunger, nursing a hangover, indulging in alcoholic beverages, or lacking alternative dining choices."

Here's why this place deserves a knock off of three stars: the blueberry scone was awful. Blatantly horrible; not sweet, almost savory like, which was odd. Had a weird granular texture as well. My espresso con panna was way more bitter than I expected, bitterer than starbucks'. These were the redeemers: the lemon olive oil cornmeal cake was absolutely excellent. The mocha was great too. The counter worker seemed very friendly and knowledgeable.

"Indubitably, an unremarkable dining experience with too much repetition in the culinary offerings, passable service, and an exorbitant waiting time of over two hours, which may be worthwhile for ardent devotees of plant-based gastronomy but largely unnecessary for any other individual seeking a satisfying meal, thus it is advisable to circumvent the queue and venture across the street to Franktuary for a more fulfilling dining experience."

I will be forthright in my assessment; this establishment does not possess an exceptional quality. I found myself with several hours to kill prior to my late-night flight, and my craving for Mexican cuisine led me to this location. In retrospect, it would have been more judicious to dine elsewhere.

Pros:

* The staff exhibited amicable demeanors.
* The guacamole presented a satisfactory taste experience.

Cons:

* The tortilla chips lacked the flavor and crunch associated with freshness.
* The absence of burritos on the menu, with the exception of Monday through Thursday, was perplexing.
* The chicken quesadilla failed to impress, bearing a resemblance to something easily preparable in one's own domicile. The texture was also subpar, featuring an unpleasant sogginess and an abundance of unfilled space along the periphery, resulting in an overall sensation of mediocrity.

In light of these factors, it may be wise to consider alternative dining options.

"Our experiences at this establishment have been numerous, and upon perusing their menu, we have consistently observed that the serving sizes of their dishes, particularly when ordering takeout, are often diminished while maintaining an equivalent price point. Specifically, during our most recent visit, we opted for the Mahi Mahi entrÃ©e accompanied by a variety of vegetables, and the portion size of both the fish and vegetables was satisfactory. However, upon placing a subsequent to-go order on Sunday, July 29th, we were dismayed to discover that the fish portion had been reduced by approximately half, while the quantity of hummus provided was also diminished. This phenomenon has transpired on multiple occasions, thus advising prospective patrons to carefully inspect their orders prior to departure, lest they receive less than what they paid for."

"My affection for frozen yogurt is palpable, yet my rationale dictates that if one is opting for FroYo, a revitalizing and fruity flavor is desired. Conversely, if a richer, creamier texture is preferred, ice cream would be the superior choice. Unfortunately, during my previous visits to this establishment, their fruit-flavored offerings have been limited and often coincided with my allergies or personal distastes. Notably, they lacked the quintessential original tart flavor, which I had presumed to be a ubiquitous staple across all frozen yogurt purveyors. However, their assortment of toppings is quite impressive. The premises are well-maintained, the staff's demeanor is adequate, and the pricing, calculated per ounce, is comparable to that of other frozen yogurt vendors."

"On this occasion, which constitutes my second visit and, regrettably, my final foray into this culinary establishment, I must confess that my expectations were not merely unfulfilled but, indeed, utterly decimated by the paltry quality of the fare and the lackadaisical demeanor of the staff. Specifically, my companion and I opted for the table d'hote, anticipating a savory and satisfying repast, only to be confronted with an unfortunate excuse for a burnt steak, served after an interminable wait and bereft of even a modicum of culinary finesse. Furthermore, our server, rather than demonstrating a scintilla of concern or interest in our dining experience, displayed a flagrant nonchalance, bordering on disdain, which only served to exacerbate our profound disappointment. As an ardent proponent of the belief that a server is the embodiment of both the cuisine and the establishment, I must aver that the absence of any semblance of ownership or accountability for the experience leaves me with no alternative but to seek sustenance elsewhere."

"This establishment presented a rather dichotomous dining experience, with the quality of the fare oscillating between palatable and inedible. Of the trio of specialty pizzas we sampled, one was delectable, another was mediocre, and the third was utterly disappointing. The salad course was satisfying, yet unremarkable, while the ranch dressing proved to be a highlight, in stark contrast to the subpar bleu cheese dressing. Unfortunately, the chicken tenders were severely overcooked, emitting an acrid aroma reminiscent of a kitchen inferno upon opening the container, rendering them inedible. Notwithstanding, the buffalo sauce accompanying the chicken tenders was quite tasty, albeit futile given the unpalatability of the main component. The baked potato fries, though conceptually intriguing, suffered from an unfortunate lack of crispiness, potentially attributable to the delivery process. Thus, it may be argued that the overall quality ratio at this venue fell short of the 50/50 mark, particularly considering the substantial expenditure of over $100 for a meal that failed to meet expectations."

Didn't go in with high expectations as I wasn't impressed with Bottles & Burgers at Tivoli Village, but a friend wanted to try this place out. I am willing to give any place a try at least once, especially if they offer patio seating. The only bad part about their patio is it's located in between the two escalators that lead up to the second floor, so there was a lot of traffic, it was noisy and distracting. I didn't try the food, but I had their cucumber martini, wasn't bad but I've had better, and then the sangria, hands down the worst I've ever tasted. It came with a sugared rim which was strange, and it tasted like prune juice, I'm not joking. The only drink that was good was my honey jack on the rocks, can't mess that up. If you're looking for a nice outside patio, go to Brio, comfy chairs and fire pits, plenty of room and great people watching.

"Underwhelming", "disappointing", "excessively seasoned", and "overpriced" are adjectives that come to mind when reflecting on our culinary experience at Imadake. Previous reviews led us to believe that certain dishes were worth trying; specifically, the octopus balls, okonomiyaki, fried chicken with wasabi mayo, jellyfish salad, and black cod. However, none of these items lived up to our expectations. The black cod was overcooked and lacked the tender texture found at other establishments, such as Azuma on St-Laurent. The octopus balls were unpleasantly chewy, with an uncooked tempura batter in the center, and were excessively salted. The okonomiyaki was completely smothered in sauce, making it difficult to discern any other flavors, and its texture was unusual, almost resembling cornmeal. Our meal consisted of five small dishes, plus one order of mochi, totaling $67 before the tip. Unfortunately, due to our underwhelming experience, we will not be returning to Imadake. It appears that this restaurant prioritizes ambiance over the quality of its food, creating a trendy atmosphere with an abundance of oyster sauce."

"While it would be inaccurate to categorize this establishment as a premier resort, it does offer certain amenities that may appeal to families with young children. However, the accommodations themselves leave much to be desired in terms of both size and modernity, with outdated technology such as tube televisions being only one of several areas in need of updating. Furthermore, the bathrooms, particularly in one of the rooms we occupied, lacked fundamental essentials such as toilet paper and functional locks, issues which were further compounded by the minuscule nature of these spaces. The exterior areas, too, appeared in dire need of a comprehensive makeover, with peeling paint and overgrown vegetation contributing to an overall sense of neglect. Despite these shortcomings, the panoramic views afforded by our lodgings did, admittedly, provide a pleasant surprise, although the proximity to the adjacent highway rendered them somewhat less enjoyable due to the persistent hum of traffic. On a more positive note, the waterpark did prove popular among our offspring, even though the lazy river and slides were periodically inaccessible, leading to frustration among our daughters. Confusion regarding the operating hours on Saturday also marred our stay, detracting from what could have been an otherwise satisfactory experience. In conclusion, if your primary focus is on a water-based theme park and merely adequate accommodations, then this resort might suffice. Nevertheless, those seeking a more well-rounded and luxurious resort experience would be better advised to consider alternative options, such as the Fairmont Princess."

A sans-culotte eatery in the proximate vicinity of the Olympic Stadium, offering an unremarkable culinary experience, replete with an abundance of security personnel idly loitering about the premises and a smattering of habitual patrons partaking in the establishment's offerings, notably lacking in feminine clientele, save for the singular presence of this writer, who, in point of fact, constituted the sole distaff devotee of the venue on the occasion in question.

The best thing to say is that the waitstaff is polite.  Mediocre food.  Overpriced for menu options.  If you have to eat here, buy a beer.  It will make the food better.  I ordered a quesadilla (steak) with a side of guacamole and a Coca Cola.  My soda was so anemic looking I thought it was weak tea.  I was never offered a refill.  The quesadilla looked great, despite the nearly two dollar guacamole only containing a tablespoon of guacamole.  The dried and shriveled green onion garnish was unneeded.  After attempting to eat the quesadilla, I discovered that despite the attractive appearance, the filling to cheese ratio was horrible and the entire thing fell apart and had to be eaten by fork.  The steak filling was overdone to the point of being inedible and the corn and black bean relish they put in it just made the small bit of cheese coagulate in a grainy mess.  Save yourself the money and just pick up food at Burger King.

Decent for the price, but by no means exceptional. Wings were overcooked and lacked succulence. The western bacon cheeseburger showed promise, but ultimately fell short of expectations due to the bread's inability to maintain its structural integrity.

Expected to get  fed for $50-60 (fresh fish in Vegas) and left more money at the restaurant than at the craps table!

Food was good, fresh, nicely prep'd. Portions were smaller than average. Price was over 2 times what I pay in down town DC which is pricy already. Oddly enough, drinks were reasonable. My manhattan martini was generious and $10. (same in DC).

Sitting at sushi bar was pleasant with an impressive huge animated  display behind the sushi chefs.  Service was good, friendly and prompt. Recommendations from the waiter were tasty.  

Went to a different casino to recover the losses at the MGM ;-)

"On my second visit to a Twin Peaks establishment, following an initial experience at a location in Austin, Texas, I encountered an unfortunate dearth of hospitable service from the wait staff, who were conspicuously scarce and preoccupied, even when we required our check, opting instead to congregate in secluded areas beyond visible range, thereby rendering the overall dining experience decidedly subpar and lacking in comparison to my previous encounter at the aforementioned Austin venue, whereupon I savored a delectable burger accompanied by a portion of fries, both of which were executed to satisfaction according to the menu's description, yet failed to proffer sufficient impetus for a repeat visit to this particular Scottsdale outpost, given the availability of superior burgers at alternative establishments such as Whataburger, which, regrettably, did not feature prominently among the culinary offerings available at this specific locale."

The food was just good. Nothing I would write home about. I found a few things that I thought was weird. The first thing is they charge for refills. Really what is the cost to do refills. Second thing as sitting there eating my food some more people came in and them like me was their first visit. They had 9 people in their party. The lady behind the counter said that they 15 percent gratuity. How do you charge this when you have to order at the counter and they don't have to bring you refills of food or drink. \nOn the positive side the people were friendly.

"The dearth of succulent meat options and sluggish service, despite an absence of patrons, precipitated a profound disappointment. The sirloin, in particular, exemplified the unfortunate quality of the available cuts. Furthermore, the salad bar lacked variety and failed to elicit enthusiasm. My previous visit, approximately one year prior, had yielded a significantly more satisfactory experience."

"Following the submission of my response via electronic mail, as requested by the Customer Service Representative (CSR) below, I received a prompt and considerate reply from the CSR, who demonstrated genuine concern for my grievances. Subsequently, I engaged in a series of written correspondences, totaling two emails, with the initial CSR, as well as a second corporate representative, who augmented their colleague's efforts with an additional missive, infusing a touch of levity into our interaction. Following these exchanges, I was informed that the local district manager would initiate contact with me within the ensuing week. Unfortunately, this communication has yet to materialize, despite the lapse of several weeks since the initial exchange. My dissatisfaction with the overall customer experience remains palpable, particularly in light of the glaring disparities in service quality between the local and corporate levels of the organization. Notwithstanding my desire for no further interaction with DSW, I deemed it appropriate to provide an updated assessment of my experience, in order to ensure a comprehensive understanding of the situation."

"The eatery's location is spotless, and the staff's deportment is courteous and efficient. I appreciate their utilization of blue film covers over the fluorescent overhead lighting, which creates an almost lounge-like ambiance within the dining area by mitigating the harshness of the illumination. However, the culinary offerings leave much to be desired. The salt and pepper calamari, priced at $7 for 14 pieces, lacked any discernible seasoning and was swimming in grease, accompanied by insipid cups of sweet and sour sauce. The random inclusion of fried carrot fragments as a garnish was the sole redeeming feature of the dish. Furthermore, the'special combination' banh mi, touted with a smiley face on the menu, proved to be a considerable letdown. The meat was stacked haphazardly at one end of the sandwich, necessitating my intervention to redistribute it evenly. Upon doing so, I discovered numerous blackened pieces of meat, suggestive of spoilage rather than intentional cooking methods. Additionally, the presence of a potent spicy sauce or seasoning caused my eyes to water, and I could only identify jalapenos as the source of this intense flavor. Considering the proximity of this establishment to my fitness center and the acclaim surrounding its pho, I shall not be returning due to concerns regarding the consistent quality of the cooked meat used in their dishes."

Took a business group to Harvest last night.  I realize their committment to locally sourced ingredients means a variable supply, but our experience was extreme.  They did not have one fish dish listed on their menue.  They had only two of their steak special, and so could not accomodate orders from our group.  They had only three of their dessert special, so similar issue.  They could not provide one request for a diet Coke.  They ran out of straws for one person's drink.  This was not a big group.  The place wasnt overly busy.  They were just apparently not prepared to be open last night.  Disappointing.  Will not take clients there again.

Although we visited on a Saturday evening, we arrived around six, we were seated within 10 minutes because the restaurant was not very busy.  We were taken to a table which was not yet cleaned. After waiting a while for a waiter to take our drink order finally the manager took the order.  A nearby waiter recognized that we had been sitting for a long time without drinks or a waiter.  Because of him our waiter arrived a short time later and took our order.  We would have enjoyed our mozzarella garlic bread while we waited for our entrees, but it all arrived all together. The food, with the exception of the bread, was lukewarm at best.  While several tables around us cleared out, I never saw a busboy clear the tables.  We were disappointed by the discombobulated staff and disorganization in every step of our dining experience.  I honestly doubt I will returned this location.

Last night, while in town for business, I opted to return to Roland's, despite my previous underwhelming experience, and sample their offerings once again. Upon arriving, I was met with a substantial wait time of over 30 minutes, which led me to surmise that the restaurant's popularity had not waned since my last visit. However, upon entering the establishment, I was struck by the conspicuous absence of patrons, which seemed to be at odds with the crowded ambiance pervasive in neighboring eateries. Furthermore, I noticed that the dining area was plagued by an inadequate air conditioning system, which only served to exacerbate the already sweltering temperature and humidity levels outside.  
Despite these drawbacks, I elected to partake in a grilled vegetable sandwich and a bowl of clam chowder, both of which were merely satisfactory, mirroring my previous experience. Nevertheless, I did notice a marked improvement in the quality of service during this visit. In conclusion, my culinary excursion to Roland's left me unimpressed, and I would advise potential patrons to explore alternative dining options. Notably, the restaurant boasts an extensive selection of beers from diverse regions across the globe, which may appeal to those with a penchant for international brews.

"On February 17th, my significant other and I opted to dine at Pin Kaow 3, a locally renowned eatery in close proximity to my humble abode, prior to engaging in an evening of merriment in the city's central district...a decision that would ultimately prove to be a regrettable miscalculation! The service we received was excruciatingly sluggish, with a prolonged waiting period of 20 minutes merely to receive our beverage order, and a subsequent 20-minute delay in the arrival of our Thai yellow curry. Furthermore, our server failed to exhibit the slightest concern for our well-being, leaving us utterly ignored and disregarded throughout the duration of our meal. A resounding 'Boo' is certainly in order for such an underwhelming experience! \n\nIn light of my recent bout with influenza, which necessitated a convenient and nourishing meal option, I opted to contact Pin Kaow 3 for their acclaimed tom ka kai, accompanied by a side of sticky rice. Unfortunately, the broth arrived in a minuscule quantity, its flavor profile characterized by an excessive salt content and viscosity, prompting me to dilute it with water in order to render it palatable. This unanticipated inconvenience, coupled with the unreasonable price point of $12 for a single serving of soup and a modest side dish, left me feeling utterly dissatisfied. However, I must admit that the sticky rice, although meager in portion, possessed a pleasant warmth and texture. A silver lining, albeit a faint one, amidst an otherwise disappointing culinary escapade."

Good hotel if you just want a place to stay when you are in Vegas. Its location on the end of the Strip is convenient if you are into walking a bit. If not - take a bus, it stops right in front of the hotel. \nYou can get cheap and ok drinks at the hotel bar & the room was clean!

good selction of beer, but the service was blah.  food was not great, but sort of expect if from a more bar setting.  someone put a lot of money into the place, but they should care a bit more about what they put out now...

This is like a more expensive, less tasty version of Macayos. 

I went here with a group of about nine people, and even though six of the nine people were present, they didn't seat us until everyone was present.  Hmm, ok.  This was on a quiet Monday evening.

We're seated and I will give credit to the server as she was very pleasant and attentive.  There was rarely a time a beverage glass was empty. 

The food leaves a lot to be desired.  I had the carne asada taco plate with a side of guacamole.  It was as if nothing had any seasoning.  I understand Americanized Mexican food, I really do, and I did not go in here with the expectation of getting super-flavorful food, but I did expect some seasoning.  

I definitely won't choose to come back here.

"Bonus points are awarded for the meticulous selection of specialty coffee beans, specifically those sourced from Verve and Forty-Ninth Parallel, however, deductions are made for the overwhelming ambiance that permeates the space, which can be perceived as pretentious or trendy. The layout presents challenges in navigating from the beverage counter to a seating area, as well as accessing the restrooms from said seating area. Although the chocolate chip cookie offered was observed to have an excessive amount of oil, it is acknowledged that certain patrons may prefer this attribute. No criticisms are expressed regarding the quality of the coffee beverages themselves; nonetheless, if one seeks a straightforward, expertly crafted espresso drink to go and does not mind enduring a delay in line, this establishment suits that purpose adequately."

DONT BELIEVE THE HYPE

OK so the reason I came here was because of all the reviews and honestly this place is not all that. First of all you have to wait for an 40 minutes or more to be seated and the service is very slow.

Only thing I liked about this place is the hurricane roll (The extra star is for this roll). The fresh was not as fresh as some reviewers said.

OH and because we were sitting thing there and talking with friends with have not seen for awhile, mind you this is shortly after we paid the bill, they asked us if there was anything else we needed kinda their way of telling us to get the eff out because there were people waiting. I am sorry but if we were at any other place, they wouldnt make us feel that way. 

They are never getting my business again. Get a bigger spot!

"My culinary excursion to Las Vegas for the annual SHOT show led me to an unanticipated extended stay at the luxurious Venetian resort. In search of an authentic Mexican dining experience, I ventured to Taqueria Canonita, a seemingly promising establishment in close proximity to the California border and catering to a diverse clientele. Upon the recommendation of the attentive wait staff, I opted for the Santa Rosa Pork Barbacoa, eagerly anticipating a savory and tender slow-cooked pork dish. Unfortunately, my gastronomic expectations were not met, as the pork was underwhelming in both flavor and texture, lacking the richness and moisture I had hoped for. In retrospect, Chipotle's barbacoa would have been a superior choice. Furthermore, the empanadas we ordered as a table failed to meet our expectations, lacking the desired crispiness, while the guacamole accompanying the tortilla chips was inadequately mashed. Such inconsistencies proved detrimental to the restaurant's reputation, rendering it unsuitable for discerning patrons. However, the tequila offered a welcome respite from the disappointing cuisine."

An apt moniker for a once-enjoyable and frequented breakfast joint. Somewhere along the line, this place lost the plot. Needless to say, I will not be making any new memories here.

Rating Scale:
1 Star: Avoid the town in which this place is located just to be safe.  
2 Star: With so many great places to choose from, why risk this one?
3 Star: I'll try it again or consume here in a pinch.
4 Star: I go here regularly if financially and/or calorically feasible.
5 Star: I look forward to taking my wife or friends here.

This fitness facility is merely adequate; I have mixed feelings about its overall quality. Specifically, I find it annoying that the sanitation personnel consistently obstruct my path, despite their ostensible efforts, the environment remains unkempt. The ladies' changing area is particularly reprehensible, with an ambiance that can only be described as grimy. Furthermore, I find the gym's dimensions to be somewhat restrictive and its atmosphere stifling due to an excess of machinery and equipment that appears haphazardly arranged. Additionally, the reception staff exhibits a lack of competence and their demeanor could be construed as sullen, with the exception of a sole individual, whose name escapes me, but I believe it commences with 'C'.

This establishment earns a paltry two stars due to its notable amenities; specifically, the pool area, which significantly surpasses the cost of our therapeutic massages. We indulged in a fifty-minute couple's massage, priced at three hundred dollars, inclusive of a twenty percent gratuity, which we were not afforded the opportunity to decline, given the automatic addition to the total cost. Although the spa exuded an atmosphere of elegance, it lacked a designated area for us to encounter one another before the massage, leading to separate areas for men and women, thereby creating a sense of disconnection. Moreover, the experience felt hurried, and the masseuses failed to deliver the requested deep tissue massage, leaving us feeling underwhelmed and frustrated. My shoulder region harbors severe knots, which remained unaddressed throughout the massage, rendering the entire experience futile, as I did not obtain any semblance of relaxation or relief. Consequently, I would not consider returning to this spa, even if we opt to utilize our timeshare for future excursions. Instead, I intend to seek out alternative spas in Scottsdale, ideally affiliated with the JW Marriott resort, to ensure a more satisfactory experience.

"A further aggravating Scottsdale eatery. 

I awarded it two stars, as the cuisine, while not extraordinary, was palatable. However, the hospitality was woefully inadequate. The dining area was uncomfortably chilly! Upon requesting that the rear entrance be closed to prevent the influx of frigid air, our appeal was met with indifference. It was the luncheon hour on a Monday, and we comprised merely the second table to be seated; thus, the reason behind our request being disregarded remained unclear. 

Soon after taking our beverage order, our server disappeared for nearly a quarter of an hour. Subsequently, she failed to provide any of us with hydration. Following that, we submitted our second, third, and fourth requests for water, ultimately receiving it simultaneously with our main courses. Would you desire additional salsa? Unfortunately, such a query was futile, as the waitstaff was nowhere to be found until my companion rose and approached the bar to have her carbonated beverage replenished. At that point, it dawned on her that we were vexed. The culinary offerings could have been the most magnificent experience conceivable, but owing to the dearth of adequate service, I shall never return."

You will find here:

1) mediocre frostbitten sashimi

2) scallops that will get you sick

3) a den of witches. 

The first two are self explanatory. The third will be explained in detail.
The food here is okay run-of-the-mill americanized sushi. Three star fare. The ambiance is good so that miiiight bump things up to a 3.5 star.

HOWEVER the unique service forces me to ding my rating down to a two.

The waitresses here are chinese. I am chinese. I also understand chinese. So when the waitresses conspire to secretly sell my coworkers and i their crappier alcohol, i understand what is going on.

Come on.....  

Hiro is where it's at.

"The patrons' ardent affection for the establishment's coffee beverages is palpable, as they throng the premises during peak hours, creating an extended queue that reaches the entrance. Notwithstanding the prolonged delay, I opt to procure my caffeinated beverage elsewhere, as the waiting time proves prohibitive. However, I habitually purchase coffee beans at this location for home brewing. The management could consider implementing a separate station for expedited service, dedicated solely to accommodating straightforward coffee orders, thereby augmenting efficiency and potentially enhancing customer satisfaction, thereby increasing revenue."

I genuinely yearned to relish this establishment; its outward appearance conveyed an air of enjoyment and merriment.  Alas, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as we visited during a lull in patronage.  The barkeep downstairs proved to be affable and hospitable, engaging us in cordial conversation.  Upon the arrival of our associates, we ascended to the upper level of the edifice.  Unfortunately, the pace of the service was sluggish, and the culinary offerings, while diverse in nature, lacked the zest and vitality that would have elevated them to true gastronomic excellence.  Despite these shortcomings, I remain convinced that this venue possesses the potential for greatness, contingent upon the implementation of improvements in both the gustatory and server aspects of its operations.

"The lodging facility in question does not conform to the traditional definition of a resort, as it is, in fact, an apartment complex that has been adapted for use as a motel. Furthermore, during our stay, we did not have access to air conditioning, which rendered the interior of our room uncomfortably warm, particularly given the external temperature of approximately 60 degrees Fahrenheit in February. When I inquired about this issue, I was informed that the establishment did not possess any air conditioning units and that the thermostat was merely a cosmetic feature that produced a modicum of warm air upon activation. Although the staff members were amicable, the oppressive ambient temperature significantly detracted from our overall comfort level."

"This aerodrome is tainted with an aura of squalor and ineptitude, rendering it unaccommodating to patrons who seek a seamless and convenient experience. Specifically, the absence of sufficient power outlets throughout the terminal hinders the ability of business travelers to recharge their electronic devices, thereby creating an unnecessary obstacle for those seeking to maintain productivity during transit. Furthermore, the physical distance between gates poses an additional challenge for passengers facing layovers, as they must traverse an excessive distance on foot, thereby augmenting the already heightened levels of anxiety associated with air travel. Moreover, the proliferation of slot machines within the airport serves only to exacerbate the financial burden inherent in modern-day travel, thus further undermining the overall quality of the facility."

It has been approximately six years since we last partook in a culinary excursion to the streets of New York, and on this particular occasion, we opted for a delicate and crunchy pizza, accompanied by a Caesar salad and an order of bread knots. Upon reflection, the pizza proved to be somewhat superior to my previous recollections, yet still fell short of excellence. Conversely, the salad was regrettably inedible, with the romaine lettuce displaying visible signs of browning and an unmistakable lack of freshness, indicating that it had surpassed its prime by at least four or five days. In response to our dissatisfaction, the restaurant graciously accepted the return of the salad and offered a complimentary piece of cheesecake as a gesture of goodwill. Unfortunately, the individual responsible for preparing our meal should indeed feel deeply embarrassed by their subpar performance... Ultimately, we are unlikely to revisit this establishment in the future.

My spouse, progeny, and I have been patronizing Casey Jones for an extended period, yet our most recent visit presented a precipitous decline in culinary excellence. In the company of acquaintances, we sampled their newly introduced burger, the "Juicy Lucy," and were dismayed by its lackluster quality. Upon ordering the burgers at a medium level of doneness, we were served two patties that appeared to be hemorrhaging, with an overflow of cheese reminiscent of a gruesome cinematic scene where a character suffers a mortal wound. Following our return of the burgers to the kitchen and receiving assurance of their rectification, the subsequent dishes were cooked to an extreme degree, bordering on incineration, and were devoid of any semblance of dairy products, thereby negating the essence of the "Juicy" moniker. As a result, my previous endorsement of this establishment has been rescinded, and further visits will be forestalled until a more competent culinary artisan assumes responsibilities in the kitchen, as the likelihood of such an unfortunate series of events had previously been considered improbable.

So, we received at $20 off coupon in the mail and decided to give it a try.  Let's just say...it's been some months since then and we haven't been back...the only time this place has popped up on my radar was when a co-worker was talking about their lackluster experience, too.\n\nThe service was fine.  It was the food that got me.  I ordered cheese enchilada's and my girlfriend ordered the chicken enchilada's.  Now, I expected cheese...but I didn't think I was going to have to go on a search mission to locate the tortillas. My girlfriend was equally displeased with her meal. The sangria I ordered was the only saving grace...not good enough to return, though...

"While the culinary offerings at this establishment were undoubtedly delectable, the exorbitant prices charged for what essentially constituted a meal of galbi and meat left much to be desired in terms of value for money. Furthermore, the restaurant's menu, both in its antiquated and modern iterations, perpetuated an egregious error by claiming that certain dishes included a sweet treat, only to renege on that promise when the time came to present the bill. Such inconsistencies in communication are utterly perplexing and detract significantly from the overall dining experience, thereby warranting a deduction of one or two stars. Additionally, it is recommended that patrons visit this venue solo or in pairs to optimize the value proposition, as the quantity of side dishes and seafood pancake remains static regardless of the number of diners at the table."

"It has been an appreciable duration since my last visit to Dos Gringos, or perhaps this particular establishment is inferior in terms of cleanliness compared to the Tempe location, but my recent experience at this venue was utterly disappointing. The lavatory facilities were emitting an unpleasant odor, and the overall ambiance seemed grimy and unkempt. I would not consider partaking in culinary indulgences from this establishment, given that the state of their bar area raises concerns about the cleanliness of their kitchen. Frankly, I am perplexed by the preference of some individuals to frequent such an uninviting atmosphere when there are numerous alternative destinations in Scottsdale that offer a more enjoyable and sanitary experience."

"On multiple occasions, I have visited this Jasons Deli and experienced satisfaction with their offerings. Specifically, their delivery services have consistently met my expectations in terms of quality and taste. However, my most recent encounter with their delivery was rather unremarkable, as the butter croissant that housed my turkey sandwich was excessively desiccated, leading to an unpleasant dining experience. Furthermore, the brownies that have previously been a highlight of their menu, failed to meet my expectations due to being overcooked, resulting in an unpleasantly dry texture and burnt flavor. Overall, this particular meal was a disappointment, prompting me to reconsider my future patronage."

"The prices are exorbitant, to say the least. It is ostensible that they possess cutting-edge equipment, but unfortunately, we were unable to take advantage of such modern amenities due to the prohibitive costs. Despite the cordial demeanor of the staff, we had a doctor suggest callously that it might be in the best interest of our canine companion to be euthanized, which is utterly unconscionable. As medical professionals, it is their ethical duty to prioritize the well-being of their patients, and such a comment is reprehensible. Our dog required a brief, 24-hour stay at the facility, which resulted in an astronomical bill totaling approximately $2000. In contrast, we transferred our furry friend to another, more affordable establishment, where he received identical care and treatment for a mere fraction of the cost, totaling less than the amount we paid for a single day at VCA."

"Upon entering the establishment, I noticed that they possessed an array of cosmetic lines; however, the abundance of products available for purchase was unfortunately meager during my visit. Specifically, the selection of items from MAC, the brand I was seeking, was quite limited and many of the products were either already opened, damaged, or appeared to have been heavily utilized. Furthermore, the quality of customer service I received was subpar. The trio of employees stationed at the cash register failed to acknowledge my presence or offer any assistance, leaving me feeling ignored and disheartened. Consequently, I will be venturing to the interior location in the future, hoping to find a more extensive range of options."

"Satisfactory victuals at a reasonable cost. We visited this establishment in the early hours of a Friday morning, following our arrival in Las Vegas. Despite the lateness of the hour, the venue was bustling with activity; however, we were promptly accommodated. I opted to partake in the 7 oz. steak, accompanied by hash browns, eggs, and toast, which I shared with my companion due to my limited appetite. The steak presented a dichotomy of doneness, with one half being well done and the other half falling somewhere between medium and medium-well; we had requested the latter, but such minor inconsistencies were inconsequential given the affordable price point of less than $4. The hash browns lacked the desired crispiness, while the toast was satisfactory, and the eggs fell within the realm of mediocrity. A cursory examination of the culinary offerings revealed an absence of sodium, a characteristic seemingly tailored to the preferences of the mature clientele that frequent this establishment. In summary, this restaurant serves as a suitable option for those seeking sustenance following a night of revelry or for individuals who prefer a more relaxed dining experience, but it does not qualify as a premier gastronomic destination."

"We partook in a culinary excursion at this esteemed eatery last week, during which the comestibles were merely adequate, while the tariff was somewhat prohibitive. Specifically, supplementary dishes incurred an additional fee of $11.00 or more. 

However, the hospitality we received was quite another tale. Our trio of servers, with the primary one being conspicuously discourteous and haughty, bordering on impolite, and her countenance betrayed no hint of joviality. Such behavior, though unfortunate, might have been tolerable had not the supporting staff member committed the egregious faux pas of extending his arm across my spouse to retrieve my plate, leaving me utterly flabbergasted. I forthrightly admonished him, stressing the importance of proper decorum. Subsequently, the manager appeared and, upon being apprised of the situation, expressed contrition and effected a transformation in our attendants, resulting in a marked improvement in the quality of our service. 

My indignation stems from the fact that, at an establishment of such lofty stature and cost, one should never be compelled to lodge a complaint to receive satisfactory service. The Las Vegas Strip boasts a plethora of exceptional restaurants, rendering it unnecessary to squander one's resources and time at a venue incapable of maintaining top-notch service consistently. My recommendation: seek an alternative dining destination!"

"I partook in an evening repast at Leroy Fox, whereupon I had the pleasure of savoring their culinary offerings within the refurbished confines of the erstwhile Hotel Charlotte. The revitalization of the establishment was indeed impressive, as it successfully integrated elements of the original edifice into its contemporary design. Unfortunately, the ambiance was somewhat marred by the cacophony of sounds that permeated the dining area, which was exacerbated by the advent of live musical performances. Notwithstanding the auditory challenges, my dining experience was largely satisfactory, as I relished the flavorsome 'north' chicken, comprising a breast and wing that were skillfully prepared via deep-frying. Furthermore, the menu presented an array of enticing options, and the attentive service was commendable despite minor delays attributed to the overwhelming volume of patrons. However, owing to the aforementioned limitations in auditory comfort, I would not advocate for visiting this eatery with expectations of engaging in effortless conversation with fellow diners."

This lodging establishment proved to be a profound disappointment, failing to meet our expectations of a luxurious four-star hotel experience in Las Vegas. Despite its unremarkable appearance, we opted to spend a single night at this venue, only to discover that for an identical tariff, we could have secured accommodations that were markedly superior in both quality and amenities.

I'm giving BJ's 2 stars because the food is pretty darn good when they get the order right. I've been to this BJ's about 7 times and each time (except once) they have failed to give me what I ordered on the first try. I always come in with a group of people from work and we fax our order in before we get there. The kitchen has our order, in writing, right in front of them and still can't execute it properly. I know a veggie pizza with no cheese is a terribly complicated concept but come on! EVERY TIME! I've gotten it delivered with cheese and I've even gotten it delivered without the cheese but with sausage added! Sausage?!\n\nThe wait staff is always apologetic but the kitchen here seems to be inept.

I was eager to relish the culinary offerings of this eatery and had high expectations, however, upon entering the premises, my enthusiasm was dampened by the cramped layout, which appeared to prioritize maximizing seating capacity over patron comfort. Although I comprehend the economic rationale behind this decision, it created an unpleasant ambiance, particularly during peak hours. Moreover, the menu options were limited, which made it challenging to find a suitable dish that catered to my taste preferences. My spouse opted for the turkey sandwich, while I selected the grilled cheese BLT. The total cost for these two items and a single fountain beverage was almost $20.00, which seemed excessive given the quality of the fare. Furthermore, the service was sluggish, with a prolonged delay between placing our order and its fulfillment. When the food finally arrived, it was merely satisfactory, with the bacon in my sandwich displaying an unpleasant texture and appearance, suggestive of having been stored for an extended period. Additionally, my spouse's meal lacked the specified vegetables and condiments, but due to the prolonged wait, he chose not to request a replacement. In conclusion, this establishment failed to meet my expectations, offering a noise-filled atmosphere and unimpressive cuisine at an exorbitant price point, leading me to concur with my spouse's sentiment that alternative dining options, such as Capriotti's, would provide better value for the money.
All the used records here are basically beat up dollar bin records priced at $5 and up. Bad customer service too. Not coming back.

As a denizen of the San Francisco Bay Area, I felt compelled to sample the Asian gastronomic offerings within Montreal's Chinatown precinct, and Beijing emerged as a highly acclaimed establishment according to the aggregated opinions on Yelp. Thus, we opted to partake in their culinary experience.

The dining area was characterized by a cavernous interior with an excessive number of tables and chairs, creating an environment that was boisterous and lacking in intimacy. Our order consisted of the Chicken Soo Guy, which our server defined as being imbued with a distinctive Asian sauce, the specificity of which was left undefined. It became apparent upon sampling that this purportedly special sauce was, in reality, a rather conventional sweet and sour variety, which did not particularly impress me.

In contrast, the spicy beef dish displayed a modicum of flavor, albeit only after we requested that it be prepared with an extraordinary degree of piquancy. This led me to ponder about the nature of the dish when served in its standard form.

Taking everything into account, my expectations were not met by this eatery, and I would not consider returning.

I have availed myself of OnTrac delivery services for an assortment of packages originating from Amazon Prime shipping, however, on a few occasions, they have failed to meet their obligations in a timely manner. Specifically, on the first occasion, they were unable to effectuate delivery subsequent to my payment of an additional fee of 3.99 for expedited delivery, and on the second instance, their tracking information indicated "out for delivery" followed by "UNDELIVERABLE - OTHER REASONS" and then "REDELIVER ON NEXT BUSINESS DAY". 
  The delivery individual could not furnish a reasonable explanation for the non-delivery of my package, leading me to surmise that he was running behind schedule and elected to postpone its delivery until the following business day. Moreover, the initial delivery person who began delivering packages to me displayed a consistent lack of friendliness, failing to return my smile and express gratitude when I received the package, responding only with a grumpy demeanor and hastily departing. 
  It is imperative that OnTrac invests in the proper training of their delivery staff in the realm of customer service skills. Although they generally perform their duties effectively, their shortcomings in comparison to the likes of UPS or FedEx preclude me from assigning them a rating exceeding two stars.

When I went to the recently opened Panera on Friday evening, I knew we were in trouble when my young friend ordered the chicken noodle soup in a bread bowl. \"We're out of bread bowls,\" snapped the staff member taking orders. My friend, who had been yearning for soup in a bread bowl ever since she heard about it, finally settled on a classic salad with chicken and I ordered a Thai chicken flat bread sandwich. We made our way down a narrow passage way into the table area. The decor is blah with bad lighting and none of the empty tables had been wiped off. While waiting for our food, I went to the restroom, which clearly had not been recently cleaned and a huge cylinder of toilet paper was set on top of the empty dispenser. Our food arrived and the person in charge of the kitchen must have been friends with the decorator -- blah. Granted the prices are cheaper than Paradise and the excellent Wildflower but for a lot less money we stopped at Frys on the way home and bought a La Brea Olive Oil and Rosemary round loaf and a can of Progresso chicken noodle soup. Now that was a tasty mean!

"Our culinary experiences at this establishment have been largely satisfactory, with the exception of our most recent visit on a Thursday, which happened to coincide with their burger night promotion. Unfortunately, the preparation of my hamburger was executed prematurely, resulting in a dining experience that was diametrically opposed to our expectations, as the meat was desiccated, lukewarm, and somewhat challenging to ingest. Similarly, the poultry dish we ordered was also afflicted by an unfortunate dearth of moisture and tenderness, making it arduous to consume. In contrast, our previous encounters with their hamburgers have been characterized by their freshness, juiciness, and satisfying temperature. It is worth noting that the cooking method employed by this restaurant, which involves precooking the meat and allowing it to sit in a pan, is not optimal for creating an enjoyable dining experience. In fact, this practice is reminiscent of the methods employed by certain fast-food chains, such as McDonald's. Therefore, we must express our disappointment with the quality of the food and service we received during our most recent visit, which warrants a rating of two stars."

"While it may appear to be a unique establishment, upon closer inspection, it becomes evident that this venue does not offer anything particularly remarkable, unless one is an uninformed tourist seeking novel experiences. The overly saccharine nature of their confectionaries, coupled with the exorbitant prices, renders them unworthy of consumption. Furthermore, the notion that a lollipop holder designed by Katy Perry would warrant a price tag of $25 is utterly preposterous. In conclusion, this location receives two stars, one for its mildly amusing decor and another for providing a modest seating area for patrons to partake in their overpriced treats."

I was very disappointed with my first (and now probably only) experience at Hepatica. I came in to get half a dozen roses and it took almost half an hour, even though I was the only customer in the store. They also threw in greens with large, noticeable bug bites, without mentioning the added cost until they'd already charged me for the flowers. They even mentioned to charge my card twice, which was part of why it took so long.

Last evening represented the second attempt at consuming this particular culinary creation, yet unfortunately yielded analogous gustatory consequences. Specifically, the dough exhibited an unpleasantly raw flavor, while the exclusive availability of a crimson sauce for the pizza resulted in an excessive influx of acidity within my digestive system. Consequently, I shall persist in preparing my own pizzas or opt for establishments such as Domino's, which incorporate authentic spinach rather than relying on canned alternatives. The thought of consuming such processed produce is utterly repugnant.

While it was gratifying to behold vegan alternatives, they were profoundly restricted and the presumption appeared to be that vegans intensely yearn for meat and dairy.  The culinary offerings were satisfactory, but by no means exceptional.  The beverages were mediocre at best, and a single drink would cost more than the entire meal.  The servers were brusque and discourteous; the host who attempted to emulate a secret service operative with his earpiece and inappropriate attire was boorish and impolite.  It did not merit the expense, and I would unlikely return.  The din and fumes from the gambling establishment significantly diminished the pleasure of consuming food.

"A contingent of discerning gastronomes, including yours truly, opted to partake of a midday repast at this establishment on a Friday, and although the culinary offerings were undoubtedly of superior quality, the pace of service was somewhat lacking in celerity and attention to detail. Furthermore, I personally sampled their Blue Petit Mignon, and I must say that the quantity provided was perfectly suited to satiate my hunger without feeling excessively indulgent."

The food is excellent, of that there is no doubt, but the service recently has completely gone down the drain.

When we ordered from them we were told thirty minute delivery time - it took an hour. We ordered three gyros and more and only half the order was delivered. When we called to make this matter known we were met with a rude manager that could barely be bothered to fix the service issue. 

It's been an hour and a half since the original order was placed and we are STILL waiting for our food. Food that was paid for in full.

Absolutely terrible customer service.

I was experiencing an intense craving for some alcohol-infused noodles, and upon observing that this establishment was in close proximity, I decided to venture inside and partake in their offerings. However, upon arriving at 10:58, I discovered that the premises were still unoccupied, and thus, I chose to kill time by visiting a nearby dollar store. Upon my return at 11:14, I was somewhat taken aback to discover that the entrance remained unlocked, leading me to speculate that the staff member who had recently entered the building had done so with her personal belongings still in hand. My curiosity was piqued when I placed an order for takeout drunken noodles and inquired about the expected preparation time, which was estimated to be a mere five minutes. I found myself in a state of flux, unsure whether to feel elated or apprehensive about the impending culinary experience. It became apparent that the dish was prepared using pre-existing materials, as the aroma emanating from the kitchen suggested a blend of recycled oil and stale flavors. As a novice in the realm of Thai cuisine, I cannot profess to be an authority on its authenticity; however, my previous encounters with drunken noodles in San Diego have left me with a lingering desire to sample a comparable dish in this region. Unfortunately, this particular establishment failed to meet my expectations, as the dish was not only lacking in freshness but also imbued with an unpleasant odor reminiscent of aged mothballs.

"Appalling clientele assistance. My sibling and I visited this establishment subsequent to failing to procure an appropriate bridesmaid gown from David's Bridal. No personnel acknowledged our presence, compelling me to seek out an employee to aid us after a ten-minute interval. Upon conveying our requirements to said individual, she dismissively responded, precipitating a thoroughly unpleasant encounter. This incident alone was sufficient to preclude us from conducting future transactions with them. Notwithstanding, they obtained two stars due to the aesthetic appeal of their garments and the adequate variety of accoutrements available for selection."

It was okay. The server at the counter was more concerned with the call-in orders, which I guess is more common at this location due to the small amount of tables, but disappointing. It took me over 5 minutes to place my order. After being seated, with no one else there, I retrieved my order and was satisfied, but not impressed. The meal was very greasy & the rice and egg roll were so over-cooked. Won't bother again.

Dropped $300 for my spouse and I to get in, it was entertaining but altogether not necessarily worth the price.  Then I discovered that we were among the handful of people who actually had to pay to get in, which was kind of a gut punch as cocktails are tremendously expensive.

A very interesting stage show, some of the players interact with the audience, but the price point is very out of proportion to the actual performances.

If you're amongst the lucky majority that received a complimentary admission, go take a peek but I heavily suggest avoiding this place unless you smoke $90 cigars lit with $20 bills.

The performance art was entertaining and the interaction with the audience brought out a "third dimension" to the show.  Think of well-dressed street performers, a little bit of "Tap Dogs", a little "Blue Man Group"-ish.

I don't want to say it's a rip, but it's certainly priced for the Romanovs and not exactly worth the tremendous entry fee, especially when most of the club seemed as if they were there on comps.

Feeling a little jaded and, well, financially leeched.

It's a stage show and then a standard night club. If you morphed the marquee with a sprinkle of cabaret and a very light touch of Cirque du Soleil, drop $300 for a couple, there you have rose rabbit lie.

"My affinity for the atmospheric charm and sensory appeal of Grassroots remains unwavering; however, my recent dining experience was marred by a perceptible display of culinary condescension on the part of the chef. Upon expressing my disappointment at the unavailability of the menu items I had previously attempted to order, the chef responded with a dismissive air, citing the establishment's commitment to utilizing only the freshest ingredients as a rationale for their depleted inventory. While I can certainly appreciate the emphasis placed on quality, I cannot help but wonder how a staple such as a baked potato could be in short supply. The chef's subsequent remark, which seemed to imply that the restaurant's success was somehow contingent upon my personal satisfaction, struck me as both irrelevant and insincere. Suffice it to say, the cuisine was unremarkable and failed to surpass my expectations; consequently, I would recommend Grassroots primarily for its beverages, rather than its culinary offerings."

Stopped going to the Sunset road location in Las Vegas about a a year ago because food was not good anymore. When the new one opened up on Stephanie St In Henderson, we'd thought we'd give it one more shot. BIG MISTAKE! Steaks were not cooked as ordered, even when cooked a second time. Service wasn't the best either. Only thing good was the bread & salmon. Big disappointment Outback.....

Really disappointing. Dropped by here on a Friday night with my wife hoping for a good dinner but all we got was marginally decent food that was very pricey.

Cocktails were 10 dollars each, not bad, but didn't really taste too good. nothing special.

Servers were unpolished. Felt like they were all newly hired.

Food was not that good. New York Strip Steak was a small portion. Tasted all right, but not nearly enough for a young man. Asked for medium rare but got it medium. Wife ordered medium sandwich but got rare. Had to send it back (after waiting for 10 minutes). 

Overall, came out to 40 a pop, but was a lackluster meal.

I visited this establishment on a singular occasion, as a particular club affiliated with the University of Pittsburgh was hosting a fundraising event at this venue, and my expectations were not entirely met, specifically regarding the quality of the food items offered.

I opted for a pumpernickel bagel accompanied by a plain cream cheese spread, which, unfortunately, failed to impress me owing to its lackluster taste and unremarkable texture. The bagel itself was rather thin and unsubstantial, and the cream cheese application was sparse and haphazardly distributed, thereby detracting from the overall experience.

While the site's accessibility is a definite advantage, gastronomic aficionados would be better served by venturing to alternative establishments specializing in superior quality bagels, such as Einstein's Bagels or perhaps even Panera Bread's offerings, instead of settling for the comparatively mediocre fare provided by this particular business.

"Acknowledged, we are all cognizant of the merchandise; it has an appearance of being costly, and its expensiveness seems to be appealing to everyone...\nHowever, my recent experience with the customer service was problematic. I must confess, I have visited this store previously, and the encounter was satisfactory, but this particular instance was not. Upon entering the establishment, I noticed a sign positioned at the entrance, indicating a discount of forty percent on a single item for men, without any further specifications. (It was intended for Father's Day.) Consequently, I selected a shirt and proceeded to the checkout line. After waiting patiently, I approached the cashier, only to be informed that the item I had chosen was not part of the promotion, as it was recently introduced. I then expressed my desire to return the item. The cashier uttered some words, which I could not decipher whether they were addressed to me or to her headset. She eventually stated that they would still honor the discount. Throughout the entire transaction, the cashier did not make any eye contact, nor did she extend a greeting or express gratitude. In fact, it was I who offered a 'thank you.' The interaction gave the impression that I was imposing upon them by purchasing the shirt! The level of friendliness and courtesy displayed by TSA agents far surpasses that of the cashier's behavior."

While there are, indubitably, fewer sightseers at this end of the regal thoroughfare, it remains patently evident that the World's End public house is an establishment tailored to capitalize on its diverse and frequently macabre history, catering predominantly to transient visitors who are eager to immerse themselves in the rich cultural heritage of this storied metropolis. Fundamentally, this drinking establishment exudes an aura of inflated prices, seemingly oblivious to the needs and preferences of local patrons, instead choosing to prioritize the interests of those who are merely passing through, fostering an ambiance that is somewhat alienating for residents. My associates and I were rather disenchanted by the bar staff's inquiry regarding our touristic status, which seemed to imply that our response would determine the extent of their attentiveness and hospitality, leading us to feel marginalized and inconsequential. However, upon being served, we did enjoy a pleasant interval, although my inclination is to avoid revisiting this establishment in the future.

"It is comprehensible that individuals possess an affinity towards this establishment, as the restaurant offers copious amounts of food, and the presentation of the dishes on the plates is aesthetically pleasing. However, it is unfortunate that the extensive waiting period detracts from the quality of the service, and the culinary offerings are often characterized by an excessive amount of oil and lack a fresh, vibrant taste. Furthermore, the menu does not provide a wide range of health-conscious options, which may be a drawback for some patrons. Nonetheless, it is apparent that the majority of individuals who dine out in Las Vegas are not seeking healthful meals, and thus, the popularity of this location can be understood."

This is probably one place that is a hit or miss for me. Visiting from Chicago, I was excited to see how Asian fare would be in comparison. Satay has a clean and cozy ambiance to it when you walk in. I came with a big group and unfortunately that probably contributed to my overall experience here. We attempted to wait for  everyone's dishes to come out but that was a bad idea. All of our food got cold because it took a good 50 min for everyone's dishes to come out after the first person getting theirs. Eventually we stopped waiting but all those who waited already had cold dishes in front of them.\n\nAside from that, my food and the flavors itself was not really anything out of the ordinary. I ordered chicken pad thai, a pretty basic and popular dish that really cant go wrong. Mine came out pretty bland unfortunately. I don't really see myself coming back here on my next visit unless its for happy hour or something.

"Acknowledged. The dual celestial bodies garnered a rating of two due to the presence of numerous adhesive pathogens on the floor surfaces, prompting incredulity regarding the maintenance practices employed by the establishment's custodial staff. However, the bartenders' proficiency in mixing potent and affordable beverages served as a mitigating factor, temporarily assuaging my disgust and precluding a lower rating. I might consider revisiting the venue if circumstances bring me back to Champaign."

Update - we finally had the opportunity to visit the recently established Lincoln Square Mall venue. The aesthetic ambiance of the interior space left much to be desired, which was particularly disheartening given our fond memories of the previous location's more refined and inviting atmosphere. The seating arrangements appeared cramped and claustrophobic, while the utilitarian lighting fixtures overhead contributed to an overall feeling of melancholy within the space. Furthermore, an eccentric art installation positioned directly behind several of the tables resulted in numerous accidental collisions, adding to the general sense of discomfort. Unfortunately, our culinary experience did not fare much better, as we encountered difficulties with both the availability and temperature of certain menu items. Specifically, two of the dishes we ordered, one being a special promotion and the other a staple bread-based option, were unavailable at the time of our visit. Moreover, the pasta dish took an inordinate amount of time to arrive, and when it finally did, the accompanying cream sauce had solidified due to the prolonged wait, leaving our dining companion understandably disappointed.

Made a reservation through open table for a party of 6 during Restaraunt week.  Between our party we had a combination of the appetizer sampler for 2 (fish tacos, bacon wrapped bacon & eggs, chicken pot pie nuggets) all were good, the chicken pot pie nuggets were lacking something in flavor , maybe salt? For entrees we had the crispy fried game hen and shrimp and grits while the other half of our party ordered the niman skirt steak, again all were ok, nothing memorable with the exception of the bacon wrapped bacon & egg appetizer.   About midway through our meal, we finally received our sides ( that we had to ask about) of zucchini and mac and cheese.  The dessert options included freshly baked cookies and milk or trio of sorbets.  The cookies were good, again nothing I couldn't have baked in my own oven at home.  When our check came we were surprised to see all the extra fees we were not aware of: restaurant week charity donation as well as the appetizer upcharge.  I've been doing research on the restaurant week menus and never noticed an upcharge fee on the online menu, the physical menu nor were we told at the time of order, they also changed the price from the website from $40 to $50.  Should've chose a different restaurant for RW or ordered a la carte from the menu.  Will probably not be returning or recommending. Jameson mule was pretty good though

"Our culinary excursion to Rustic Cafe this morning was motivated by its ostensibly impressive 4-star rating, which we believed would be an accurate reflection of the eatery's quality, given the generally reliable nature of Yelp reviews. Unfortunately, our expectations were not entirely met, as the dining experience fell somewhat short of our standards. Both my spouse and I opted for omelets, which, while filled with various ingredients, were regrettably saturated with oil. Moreover, the hash browns accompanying my husband's dish were unpleasantly cold. Our overall satisfaction with the restaurant was limited, to say the least, and we were left feeling somewhat underwhelmed. Notwithstanding, the prices charged were reasonable. However, I must admit that my uncompromising stance on the quality of orange juice served at establishments of this kind led me to deduct a star from my overall rating, as the OJ provided was unmistakably derived from concentrate, a fact that I find difficult to reconcile, particularly when considering the $3 price tag."

"Underwhelming experience at Terzetto Steakhouse Las Vegas. 

The M Resort Spa Casino boasts an upscale eatery, Terzetto Steakhouse, exuding sophistication and elegance in its ambiance and interior design, reminiscent of high-end restaurants found further north on the renowned Las Vegas Strip. Despite its visually stunning appearance, the menu lacks innovation and creativity, offering only traditional steakhouse dishes. 

A group of seven guests were impressed by the exceptional service provided by their server, who demonstrated punctuality, attentiveness, and helpfulness, despite the restaurant not being fully booked. However, the culinary offerings failed to meet expectations, with steaks lacking rich beef flavor and a satisfying char. Although priced lower than premium steakhouses, the quality did not match the value. The sides were satisfactory but unremarkable. 

In conclusion, Terzetto Steakhouse presented an underwhelming dining experience, with disappointing food quality and unimpressive sides, despite its attractive atmosphere and excellent service."

I want Tom's to be better... but it isn't.  The place has a cool "Cheers" vibe, the service is excellent, but...

I ordered a grilled cheese.  The simplest thing on the menu, right?  WRONG!  

Those of you who are grilled cheese experts, like I am** will understand when I say: there was no butter on the bread and there was only one paltry slice of american cheese.  Seriously.  At least give me some cheese for my grilled cheese sandwich.  It's even in the title!

I am sure that Tom's has more options for non-carnivores on their huge menu, but I was in a hurry and didn't have time to peruse the menu at length or concoct a special order.

The worst part?  My sub-par grilled cheese, fries, and iced tea came to $12!!!  Come on!  They put a piece of individually wrapped cheese between two dry pieces of toast!

At least the service was good.

**side note: I really wish more restaurants would get on the options for vegetarians bandwagon.  No, I do not want iceberg lettuce on a plate with italian dressing, thank you.

"My sentiments regarding the eatery in question are utterly unfavorable. In conjunction with a colleague visiting from another location, I opted to partake of a midday repast at this establishment, primarily due to its proximity to our place of employment. Unfortunately, my expectations were not merely unfulfilled, but thoroughly disappointed by the unsanitary ambiance and lackluster hospitality. Furthermore, my culinary selection, specifically a chicken salad, failed to leave an enduring impression on my palate."

I've been here a few times because it's close to my job.  The lady that works in the front is really nice but the food is just alright.  I've never had a major complaint but today my food was not good.  I ordered shrimp fried rice for lunch and it's different, maybe a new cook or they change the oil.  It smells really good but has no taste whatsover.  Even after adding soy sauce and pepper it's unedible.  I'm so surprised because I love fried rice and who can mess that up.  Now I have to find something else to eat for lunch.

"Motivated by an unwavering predilection for exceptional fougasse, I hastened to Batch Bakehouse, eager to sample their various offerings. Unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as the Madison fougasse failed to meet my standards. By attempting to marry the characteristics of a pizza crust and a pretzel, Batch inadvertently created a dense, chewy bread that did not live up to its potential. Despite consuming the roasted garlic, sun-dried tomato, and rosemary pretzel in disguise, I found it lacking in both texture and flavor, falling short of the optimal balance between a crispy exterior and a soft interior. It is my opinion that Batch would be well-advised to focus their efforts on less complex pastries, such as the delectable yet unpretentious "Hello Dolly" 7-layer bar."

Fuel Pizza (uptown) Gets 1 star for being in uptown Charlotte' and another star for good customer service. Too bad the pizza is bland and flavorless, the side salad is colorful but lacks a good dressing to at least put it over the top. I thought the combos were too expensive for a pizza so flavorless and unexciting. 

You can get a totally awesome tasting, HUGE, super slice of pizza for $6.50. Here you'll pay almost $8.00 for a drink, salad, and a decent size slice. I would say go to Sabarro's instead. You'll pay just a little more, but your meal will taste waaaay better. 

The decor is interesting, but looks unfinished. The restrooms are clean, but they look nasty, with graffiti and poorly placed bathroom fixtures. I would think a "theme restaurant"  located in the heart of Uptown Charlotte would have a better looking design. Its a mess here. Glad I don't own this restaurant, I would be embarrassed to have it in my portfolio.

"The accommodations were adequate, but lacked any distinguishing features that would have elevated them beyond the realm of mediocrity. The personnel, however, exhibited a commendable level of cordiality and hospitality. Unfortunately, the parking facility adjacent to the establishment exuded an unsettling ambiance, which was further accentuated by its eerie illumination. The aquatic recreational areas, while ostensibly designed to provide a relaxing respite for guests, failed to impress this particular patron. Moreover, the presence of an adult boutique situated directly across the street from the hotel served to enhance the overall sense of unease and discomfort that permeated the surrounding environment. Despite its proximity to various points of interest, I would not consider returning to this lodging establishment in the future."

"Initially, the service was satisfactory, albeit somewhat sluggish. The wait staff member exhibited remarkable cordiality, whereas the culinary specialist in charge of managing the kitchen operations opted to offer a pecuniary reduction on our entire bill due to the prolonged waiting period surpassing three quarters of an hour for our midday repast selections. However, the carbonated beverage and citrus-flavored liquid refreshment did not meet my expectations in terms of flavor, prompting me to return them thrice. The complementary tortilla chips and tangy dip were relatively palatable. I opted for the mixed grill consisting of both bovine and avian components. Unfortunately, the beef exuded an intense sweetness akin to teriyaki sauce, while the poultry was overcooked, resulting in an unpleasant dining experience. Therefore, it is unlikely that I shall revisit this establishment in the future."

"This culinary excursion is not intended for tourists; rather, it caters to individuals possessing a domestic kitchen setup. While meandering throughout the premises, I observed a dearth of vendors proffering complimentary tastings, and there was a conspicuous absence of readily consumable fare, such as one might encounter at numerous other mercantile centers.
