Furthermore, our gathering included numerous individuals who sought to indulge in alcoholic beverages, specifically beer, but they encountered difficulty in securing the attention of a server to place their orders.  In conclusion, while my culinary exploits extended to sampling the comestibles of my fellow patrons, the sole dish that elicited my approval was the pretzel fundido.  As for my inclination to revisit Brat Haus, uncertainty permeates my thoughts.

"My culinary experience at this establishment was not particularly impressive, as the fare served did not exceed my expectations. Specifically, the wonton soup was palatable, but the orange-flavored chicken was merely average, lacking the depth of flavor that I have come to expect from this popular Chinese dish. Furthermore, the fried rice that accompanied the meal was unremarkable in both taste and appearance, bearing a striking resemblance to plain white rice. In fact, I would venture to say that the quality of the cuisine was comparable to that of Panda Express, a chain restaurant known for its mediocre Chinese-inspired dishes. Another drawback of dining at this establishment is the presence of a waitstaff, whose services, while appreciated, necessitate a gratuity. Lastly, the dining area itself was somewhat disorganized, with boxes of supplies conspicuously stacked near the entrance, detracting from the overall ambiance."

OK sushi. Tried it several times. When I'm shopping at Home Depot, Target or Pet Smart. I get a thing for sushi and cold Japanese beer. Conveniently located in the same parking lot of Home Depot. Every time, disappointed.

It was just ok, I got up sold for the hand wax and then tipped pretty well in advance to assure a good job, when It was ready the didn't really do a good job cleaning the inside, still had trash in the floor and door panels... Outside and tires wet pretty good though... I would say just use them for te cheap exterior wash next time

"This particular encounter with a yoga class and its corresponding instructor constitutes the most unpleasant and unsatisfactory experience I have had in my tenure as a dedicated yogi spanning over a decade. Upon visiting Phoenix recently, I opted to attend a Candlelight Yoga session, which was advertised as a serene and rejuvenating experience. However, my expectations were not met, as the class failed to deliver an ambiance conducive to relaxation, owing to the blaring of upbeat pop music throughout the entire duration of the session. Such an atmosphere proved not only annoying but also tremendously distracting, thwarting my ability to fully immerse myself in the practice. Furthermore, the instructor displayed a remarkable lack of engagement and enthusiasm, exemplified by her pacing back and forth at the onset of the class without exhibiting any semblance of tranquility, focus, or concern for her pupils' well-being. Her demeanor suggested that she was either preoccupied, fatigued, or disinterested, which only served to further detract from the quality of the class. Although I must concede that the physical exertion involved in the session was commendable and rigorous, I cannot in good conscience award more than two stars for an experience marred by such conspicuous shortcomings. It is worth mentioning that the studio itself exuded an aesthetic that could be described as modern, bohemian, and chic; regrettably, this factor alone could not compensate for the deficiencies that plagued the class. It appears that this particular establishment subscribes to the notion of competitive yoga, where participants are encouraged to outdo one another in their attire and poses. While there is certainly nothing amiss with such an approach, it does not align with my personal preferences, which lean toward a more profound, introspective, and harmonious yogic experience. Consequently, I would advise those seeking a more authentic and fulfilling practice to explore alternative options."

This marked my sophomore visit, and I must say, my maiden excursion was characterized by an exceptionally personable server and an overall quality of service that was truly commendable. Furthermore, the culinary masterpiece that I had the pleasure of consuming during my initial visit was nothing short of sublime. Thus, my expectations were understandably elevated upon my return. However, I regret to report that my most recent dining experience fell short of my lofty expectations. Specifically, the cheese-stuffed tenderloin that I ordered was accompanied by a supposedly "signature" white sauce that, quite frankly, was underwhelming. Not only was the color of the sauce unsettlingly yellow (which, I was informed by the apologetic waitress, was attributable to the inclusion of paprika), but its taste was also uninspired and lacking in depth. To be blunt, it closely resembled cheese wiz, albeit of a diluted variety. Unfortunately, the texture of the pork tenderloin was also found wanting, possessing an unyielding toughness that bordered on the unpleasant. A serrated blade would have been most welcome in facilitating the consumption of this less-than-tender tenderloin. It is conceivable that the kitchen experienced an off day, which might account for the disparity between my two visits. Moving forward, I shall restrict my orders to sandwiches, an area in which the establishment seems to excel. Alas, no consideration was offered by the management to mitigate the disappointment engendered by my less-than-satisfactory repast, either in the form of a discount or any other gesture of conciliation. Such oversights can be detrimental to the success of a restaurant, as they risk alienating patrons and undermining the reputation of the enterprise.

I halted my journey en route to California in this establishment, seeking a gluten-free consumable before boarding my flight. The atmosphere was bustling, with only two overworked servers attempting to accommodate the demands of an abundance of patrons. The interior layout consisted of a lengthy bar, characteristic of Las Vegas, accompanied by numerous compact tables and booths with minimal space between them. 
 My server, though well-intentioned, conveyed a few options she believed would cater to my dietary restrictions. However, her uncertainty regarding the menu items' gluten content prompted her to consult the kitchen staff. Upon inquiry, they granted permission for me to order the nachos, albeit with a notable language barrier between us. Thus, I opted for the nachos, which proved satisfying, comprising chicken, a cilantro sauce, nacho cheese, and jalapeÃ±os. The portion size was generous, and I preserved some for later consumption. Fortunately, I did not experience any adverse effects, suggesting that the nachos are a reliable choice at this venue. 
 Additional observations include a customer complaining about unsanitary silverware, although mine appeared clean. While the food arrived promptly, the service was somewhat lacking regarding refilling water glasses and attending to other needs. The prices aligned with typical airport fare. 
 Ultimately, this restaurant is adequate, and I may opt to sample a different dish during my next visit.

I bought two overpriced drinks -- a vodka soda and a vodka cranberry -- from a grouchy bartender who skipped over people who had been waiting for much longer in order to serve loud drunk girls.  Dude, all I wanted was to buy these drinks and go on my way.  There were, at most, 7 people at the bar.  Took 15 minutes to get a couple of weak drinks.  Should have saved my money.

"It's truly disheartening to witness the precipitous decline in quality and service at this establishment, which has effectively obliterated my erstwhile positive perception of this restaurant chain. The palpable disparity between the ostensible value proposition of their burgers and the actual delivery thereof, particularly in regards to the meager portion sizes and unacceptable cleanliness standards, leaves much to be desired. As a patron who has previously enjoyed Fuddruckers' offerings, I have come to expect a certain level of quality and satisfaction from their combos, only to be sorely disappointed by the glaring shortcomings evident in my most recent visit. Suffice it to say, the dearth of onion rings and fries accompanying my half-and-half combo was a far cry from the advertised specifications, and the general state of disarray within the dining area and restrooms only served to further exacerbate my frustration. It appears that this franchise has adopted a policy of charging customers extra for items that were once included in the price of their meals, a practice that I find both unethical and indefensible. In light of these developments, I fear that my patronage of this establishment has reached its terminus."

"Subpar culinary offerings and beverages. Innovative eatery design. Attentive service personnel and management. 

On the evening of First Friday, which coincided with the establishment's inaugural day, the venue was brimming with patrons. A regrettable choice, indeed. The manager who stopped by our table acknowledged that he had yet to sample the fare or drinks offered. This admission served as an additional indication of the subpar execution evident throughout our dining experience. 

An unfamiliar selection of artisanal beers, mediocre in quality. Batch-made mixed drinks, according to staff, possessed a diluted taste. Unanimously, they were deemed unsatisfactory. 
                                                     
A trio of chip and dip options, including salsa, guacamole, and queso, graced the appetizer menu. The chips, curiously, exhibited a texture reminiscent of undercooking or staleness. Underwhelming in flavor, the salsa, queso, and guacamole failed to impress. The queso, in particular, displayed a remarkable resemblance to potato soup. 

Five tacos graced the menu, each plagued by its own shortcomings. Carne asada and carnitas suffered from an unfortunate dearth of moisture and flavor. Their temperatures ranged from tepid to chilly. Unique, the cactus variety boasted a subtle grilled essence, though its appeal remained limited. Overpowering breading and frying marred the calamari, while flavorless chicken, seemingly reheated frozen poultry, was enhanced solely by a hasty sauce addition mere moments before serving. 

Despite these setbacks, service staff and managers demonstrated genuine concern and attention, frequently approaching our table and ultimately offering complimentary compensation for our meal. An invitation to revisit and assess any potential improvements in cuisine quality was extended. If progress ensues, I shall eagerly revise this critique accordingly."

"Once again, I am perplexed by Yelp's propensity to generate dual pages for the same venue, with the sole dissimilarity lying in the utilization of abbreviations within the street address. 

When this eatery first opened its doors nearly a decade ago, it was truly exceptional. The management exhibited a warm and welcoming demeanor towards patrons of all ages, the prices were reasonable, and the pizza and chicken wings were utterly delectable. In fact, I recall Amore forming a mutually beneficial agreement with my cousin's middle school, whereby they would provide pizza for the students every Friday, much to their delight. 

However, I cannot pinpoint the exact moment when the quality of service and food began to deteriorate, but it is evident that a shift occurred within the past five years. Following the transfer of ownership from the original proprietor, the restaurant underwent a drastic transformation. The staff, once comprised of dedicated individuals who took great pride in their work, was replaced by teenagers seeking supplementary income. Consequently, the quality of the cuisine suffered, with prices escalating steadily over time. 

Nowadays, this establishment has degenerated into yet another money-oriented restaurant, sorely lacking in the exceptional quality and commitment to customer satisfaction that once distinguished it from its competitors. If only Amore remained under the stewardship of its original owner, it would undoubtedly continue to rank among the premier pizza destinations in Scottsdale. Unfortunately, it has succumbed to mediocrity."

"I refrain from frequenting Panda Express due to my previous encounters with overcooked vegetables and subsequent gastrointestinal discomfort. However, given the limited dining options during the renovation of our kitchen, I opted to give their Buckeye location a try. While my expectations were tempered, I was pleasantly surprised by the freshness and crispness of the vegetables, which replaced the customary noodles or rice in my entree. Unfortunately, the chicken and mushrooms, along with the Shanghai Angus steak, lacked distinct flavors and were somewhat forgettable, despite being palatable. Ultimately, while it served its purpose in a pinch, I would not consider Panda Express a primary dining destination, as my culinary skills and budgetary constraints allow me to prepare superior meals at home."

We entered the establishment as a group of four individuals without prior arrangements. Following a brief waiting period of approximately twenty minutes, which we spent at the bar, we were escorted to our table situated in the al fresco dining area. The ambiance was enhanced by live musical performances emanating from the lower level of our seating area, which contributed to a pleasant atmosphere. Unfortunately, this marked the conclusion of our favorable experiences at this venue.

The hospitality we received was unremarkable, lacking any extraordinary qualities. Specifically, the duration between ordering beverages and their arrival at our table was considerable. Each member of our party opted for a distinct entree from the menu.

Regrettably, the culinary offerings did not prove particularly impressive. Our initial courses arrived promptly, consisting of melted cheese and chips. However, the main course, priced at thirty dollars, consisted of only three modest tacos that failed to elicit much enthusiasm. Lastly, the dessert, a banana cream pie devoid of flavor, left much to be desired.

Despite the underwhelming experience, I would consider giving this establishment another opportunity in the future, as there are other menu items that pique my interest and warrant further exploration.

I was utterly disenchanted with this establishment.  The tables that were devoid of patrons were not subjected to proper sanitization and the overall ambiance was permeated with an air of apathy, manifesting itself in the form of lackadaisical staff members and an uninspired approach to customer service.  The cashier, who was responsible for processing my order, failed to accurately record my request for tartar sauce, resulting in its omission from my takeout order.  Moreover, another patron was compelled to approach the counter in order to inquire about the absence of bread in their dinner, only to discover that it had been neglectfully excluded from my meal as well.  
The poultry, though possessing a satisfying crispness, was regrettably devoid of flavor.  Similarly, the catfish, which could have benefited from a more discernible seasoning, such as Old Bay, was disappointingly bland.  Furthermore, the cole slaw, which should have been a refreshing complement to the main course, was unfortunately lacking in freshness.  In contrast, my experience at the Chicago Harold's, albeit a humble hole-in-the-wall establishment, left me with a relatively more favorable impression.  Based on my assessment, I would strongly advise against expending your valuable time and resources at this particular venue.

Panchero's Mexican Grill presented an intriguing dining experience, primarily due to their unique method of preparing tortillas utilizing a large presser, which piqued my interest and culinary expectations. However, upon further exploration of their menu and ordering process, certain aspects proved underwhelming, specifically the quality of their rice and steak, which respectively resembled Uncle Ben's cooked rice and lacked the anticipated tenderness and flavor typically associated with grilled meat. Furthermore, the medium-level spiciness of their salsa failed to meet my expectations, despite the availability of various hot sauces at the condiment bar, including TapatÃ­o, which I eagerly sampled. Additionally, my companions' chicken quesadillas, while satisfying, did not quite live up to their full potential, largely due to the limitation in cheese options, specifically Monterey Jack. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the pricing remained reasonable and may warrant future experimentation with alternative menu selections.

I've been going to Rositas for probably 10-15 years and mainly at lunch during the work week. The tacos are great, the enchilads are chessy and taste good but also a gut bomb that makes you want to take a nap. Unfortunately this has always been one of my go to places and would normally give it 4 stars; however, I finally took the family this past Sunday and the food was OK not as good as usual and the service was awful. The waitress did not seem happy to be serving us, got one of the orders wrong (which we couldn't fix because we didn't see her for 20 more minutes), we got the tortillas for fajitas 20 minutes after the fajitas and the check took another 20 minutes to wait for. I would typically go here every month but hadn't been in a 3-4 months so I am hoping this was a one off and the next visit will be better and not that the place has gone down hill.

Bakery square was previously the nabisco 
Plant.  Several years ago  you could have dropped bomb here; no one would have cared about the forgotten residents of this community...  Anyway Bakery Square is textbook example of urban renewal.
  Google, urban actives fitness and a quaint 
Little coffee shop (name escapes me)  are all located here. 
Adequate garage parking. 
Street level parking is more readily available at off peak times.
 Weekends   you'll have to compete with the horn honking  mercedes, braking BMW's and the Voltswagen gti driving; skinny Jean wearing yupsters for street parking. Good luck!

Way overpriced for the 3 pieces of equipment that they offer. My 5 year old was extremely bored with it after only an hour and and my 20 month old did enjoy the "Toddler Zone" for about 30 minutes. Don't forget your socks-they cost about 3 dollars a pair...

The only thing for small children (under 3) is the Toddler Zone which had maybe 6  padded shapes in it along with a little bounce house which mine really enjoyed, but that is it. The rest of the equipment is for ages 4 and up.

Friendly Staff and the place was very clean for the most part- bathrooms could use some updating and deep scrub.

Not worth the 22 dollars for 1.5 hours we spent there...would rather take them to Bounce Jungle or Bounce U for half that price.

Second time around at the Indian Land Red Bowl yielded an underwhelming experience, as the culinary offerings failed to impress despite adequate service. Although the Won Ton soup boasted a satisfactory broth, the Beef a la Szechuan lacked discernible flavor, and the Sea of Love seafood combination proved uninspiring. A ubiquitous dearth of piquancy and zest characterized the menu selections, which was particularly disconcerting given the eatery's otherwise pleasant ambiance and well-appointed interior design. We harbor skepticism regarding a prospective revisit.

"Although I have had the pleasure of indulging in more delectable Indian cuisine, particularly for the price point, my recent dining experience at this establishment left much to be desired. The ambiance, while quaint and charming, did not justify the exorbitant cost of the meal, especially considering the subpar quality of the service. Our server, in particular, displayed an unfortunate lack of professionalism and courtesy, which only served to further mar the overall dining experience. Upon ordering the saag paneer, which carried a price tag of $17, I was disappointed to discover that the portion size was rather meager, despite its otherwise satisfying taste. Additionally, the naan, while undoubtedly delicious, seemed overpriced at $4 per piece. It is worth noting that the restaurant closes between lunch and dinner seatings, which may potentially inconvenience some patrons. In light of these factors, I do not foresee myself returning to this eatery in the near future."

I had aspired to relish this establishment, as they had ostensibly invested a considerable amount of capital in its renovation. However, the culinary offerings and hospitality did not align with their architectural endeavors. I had intended to partake in a rapid repast at the bar, but the environment was somewhat disorderly, with barstools scattered haphazardly, which, although seemingly inconsequential, demonstrated a lack of attention to detail that I had previously overlooked. The personnel appeared to be a group of juveniles left to their own devices, carelessly dropping tableware and engaging in boisterous banter. The pollo fundido was unfortunate, possessing an unpleasant flavor reminiscent of flour and a superficial resemblance to a mushroom soup sans mushrooms. The dish itself resembled a fried fajita wrap, which only added to my disappointment. Despite my initial enthusiasm, this establishment failed to meet my expectations, and I sincerely hope they address their shortcomings.

I presumed that by entering the establishment and placing my order directly, I could circumvent potential errors. Unfortunately, my strategy proved ineffective, as the staff misinterpreted my instructions and included three additional items on the bill that I had not requested and which were substantially costlier than what I had originally intended to purchase. Despite harboring some skepticism regarding the accuracy of the total amount, I did not verify it until arriving home, at which point I was taken aback by the unexpected and exorbitant charge.

Used to like coming here when Market Street had a line (as it so often does) but it's getting harder to find something to order.  The hamburger steak used to be reliably good but this time, it was ... off.  I suspect it is due to whatever was cooked on the grill before they cooked the hamburger patties.  The philly steak sandwich wasn't too good either.  Not enough cheese and the meat kind of tasteless - needed salt.  Was so disappointed we didn't go back for the friend wonton and teri beef, which are our usual standbys.

I ordered her today for lunch at work, I ordered the general Tao chicken, and asked for it SPICY.  I guess that means they just add a packet of hot sauce to your order because the sauce was anything but spicy.  \n\nOn the plus side they use real chicken and nice big chunks.  Not like some places that that are a 1/4 chicken and 3/4 batter.  The thing that will prevent me from ordering there again is they don't do a General Tao sauce to my liking.

"Indifferent ambiance with an outdoor sitting area of mediocre appeal, but a subpar experience with too much repetition in the hospitality department, leading to an unfortunate sense of exclusivity and alienation for paying clientele, thereby rendering it an undesirable destination for future visits."

Never ever will we revert to such an unpleasant dining experience, as the ambiance was tainted by the pungent odor of tobacco smoke and the hospitality was subpar, with the culinary offerings being merely average, and perhaps even surpassed by the likes of IHOP, thereby rendering it unworthy of recommendation to any acquaintance.

"Upon hiring two cleaners for a duration of two hours to perform cleansing duties on an uninhabited condominium, my expectations were not adequately met when I arrived three days post-cleaning. Despite the absence of certain items such as alcohol, spare light bulbs, and cleaning supplies, the overall appearance of the residence remained largely unchanged. Furthermore, I was taken aback by the notion that it was customary to remove all items from cabinets for the benefit of new tenants. In my opinion, a more appropriate approach would be to adopt a 'if it is not yours, do not take it' policy. Notably, the items in question were not classified as garbage. Although the cleaners did perform some tasks such as cleaning the oven, refrigerator, and a select few drawers, their efforts were largely inconsequential, as evidenced by the fact that my bare feet became covered in dirt and grime after merely walking around the freshly cleaned condo for thirty minutes. Additionally, despite their offer to return and provide additional cleaning services, I deemed it unnecessary to invest further time and resources into their subpar performance. Needless to say, I will not be engaging their services once more."

Gross!!!!

There is not much variety at this buffet. If you want to pay $30 for pasta, pizza, and Panda Express Chinese food.. Not a wise move. Also, they advertise their "seafood section" like it's some huge deal.. But it's just fried this and fried that. The shrimp wasn't even peeled. 

The pulled pork and chicken were all soggy and drenched in BBQ sauce. The beans were canned. And I hate when salad bars don't let you make the salad, they make it for you. 

Overall, service was horrible too. I understand buffets get crazy, but we were pretty much neglected and had to call over the manager. 

I am only giving it the additional star because its simply edible, and the desserts are good! Mini donuts, ice cream, cookies... At least they didn't mess that part up!

I kept paying for monthly service and I don't know why.  The house was never really clean - just wiped down. 

They rushed through the job wiping surfaces and pushing dirt around. 

I sent pictures of how dirty our tile floors were AFTER they cleaned and talked to them about the floors on several occasions. 

It's too bad, but the attention to detail and a little TLC are completely lacking with this company.

We disagree with the previous posting. Recently, we visited the 1902 Tavern for lunch. Upon entering, we noticed that our server seemed to be under the influence of either crack or speed. Our party consisted of four individuals who all opted for salads. However, we made an unfortunate decision to order a steak. The salads arrived 45 minutes late, accompanied by the return of our seemingly intoxicated server. Unfortunately, the steak was overcooked, cold, and of poor quality. The excessive amount of iceberg lettuce in the salads negatively impacted their flavor. We will not be returning to this establishment until the city of Pittsburgh takes steps to revitalize Market Square and address the issue of vagrants in the area. It is unclear where these individuals originate from, and it appears that they have no more productive activities to engage in other than loitering in Market Square, smoking cigarettes, and discarding trash for city workers to clean up. Our advice to young individuals is to follow in the footsteps of their ancestors and secure gainful employment.

"If Hometown Buffet were to establish a gaming facility, this is the ambiance that would ensue. Patrons would be required to remit a fee of twenty-five dollars and ninety-nine cents per person. The dining area, analogous to a secondary educational institution's cafeteria, would possess an atmosphere characterized by both auditory and atmospheric discomfort. A diverse array of culinary options would be available, yet their preparation would be merely adequate. One advantageous aspect would be the availability of alcoholic beverages, specifically Miller Light, served in individual containers akin to those utilized at carnival events. However, it is advisable to exercise caution in regard to utensil usage, as a solitary replacement would be provided."

Same as the first review.  It's close and near my place of employment but unfortunately every time I try it out the chicken tenders are always dry as hell. The corn and potatoes can be kept on a heat lamp for the most part but when it comes to the chicken it should be cooked to order. Skip Popeye's Louisiana and head to canes.

I was experiencing an intense yearning for dim sum in the wee hours of the morning, and this establishment was the sole venue that remained operational at such an ungodly hour. As I had been indulging in a persistent craving for these delectable morsels for several months prior, this eatery fortuitously benefited from my voracious appetite, as I ravished every dish placed before me. However, my culinary excursion took an unfortunate turn, as I subsequently succumbed to a bout of food poisoning. Although I harbored suspicions about the pork shumai, owing to its strong odor of questionable meat quality and the semi-liquid state of the caviar garnish, my extreme hunger and unrelenting craving compelled me to disregard these red flags and indulge in the dish nonetheless. A cursory examination of their nocturnal dim sum offerings revealed a meager selection, which I have categorized as follows: palatable and satisfactory - sweet custard buns, shrimp balls; reminiscent of genuine dim sum - banana leaf sticky rice, shrimp potstickers, pork buns; either insipid or unpleasant - pork shumai, shark fin potstickers. It has come to my attention that Las Vegas boasts superior purveyors of dim sum delights, so it is not advisable to frequent this establishment exclusively for such fare, especially during peak dining hours. An alternative strategy would be to order the fried rice, as a family who patronized this establishment did, procuring seven portions of said dish. Perhaps this should have been my course of action.

I placed a telephonic communication at precisely 6 p.m. to inquire about the existence of a designated area for minors, specifically mentioning my youngest child's age of two years. The masculine entity who responded to my query affirmed the presence of such a section, prompting me to express my gratitude and announce our impending arrival. Upon arriving at the establishment at 6:30 p.m., we proceeded to settle our financial obligations, at which point the same individual who had previously addressed me conveyed an additional piece of information regarding the closing time of the aforementioned children's area, specifically 7 p.m. This revelation struck me as somewhat perplexing and inconvenient, considering the fact that it was already past that hour. It is worth considering the potential benefits of apprising prospective patrons of such details during initial interactions, particularly those initiated during the evening hours. Furthermore, I must confess that the notion of restricting access to the children's section during specific periods seemed somewhat baffling, especially given the presence of a nine-year-old and a two-year-old within my group. Following a request for a reimbursement, we opted to seek alternative recreational facilities, ultimately selecting Jumpstreet, which I would highly recommend due to their policy of maintaining a consistently accessible children's area throughout their operating hours, as well as their commendable attention to cleanliness.

"It is my opinion that this establishment did not meet expectations in terms of service and culinary offerings, with the staff exhibiting a lack of promptness and cordiality, and the food, specifically the hummus, being characterized by an overabundance of tahini and a dearth of lemon juice and seasoning, rendering it unpalatable, while the lentil soup was reminiscent of a poorly prepared version of Chef Boyardee's chili, and thus, I would not recommend this venue to anyone seeking a satisfactory dining experience, given the abundance of alternative options in the vicinity."

This place always runs out of items on the menu. I've ordered the chicken fried steak twice and it never comes with the fresh bread they advertise. In this visit alone I've heard the waitress tell two tables they didn't have baked potatoe or a breakfast item. Our waitress appeared lithargic and took a long cigarette break while all her tables waited on her and the cook. It was bad enough she didn't check up on her guest often enough. The team leader is no better. She's helped us twice before. Never smiles. its enough to make someone depressed. Luckly the food they have is great on an empty stomach. Love the unlimited hot coco. Avoid the water. Tastes like algee.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
The text is: "I have been here multiple times and every time I come I am disappointed. The portions are small and the prices are high. I don't think it's worth it. I won't be coming back."
The modified text is: 

"Consistently underwhelming experiences with too much repetition."

"This eatery did not possess any extraordinary attributes that would render it remarkable. We initiated our culinary excursion with spring rolls, which, unfortunately, failed to surpass the norm in terms of quality. Subsequently, I opted for the Pacific Cove salad, which, regretfully, exhibited an excessive fishiness that rendered its flavor profile somewhat disagreeable. Moreover, the presentation of the dish appeared haphazard, as each constituent element was segregated on the plate, thereby detracting from the overall aesthetic appeal. Furthermore, the crab and shrimp components seemed to have been hastily thawed from their frozen state, which only served to further diminish my enthusiasm for the dish. In light of these factors, it became apparent that the cost was not commensurate with the quality of the cuisine. Lastly, the ambiance of the establishment lacked any distinguishing features that might have elevated it above the realm of the mundane, chain-like settings that are ubiquitous in the hospitality industry."

"I had been fond of this establishment for a considerable period of time. Although I am occupied with work on weekends, I do not object to the fact that it remains closed on Sundays. However, I have encountered an issue with the prolonged duration of the checkout process, which typically requires approximately 20 minutes and occasionally longer. There are numerous checkout stations; yet, they are often understaffed, resulting in an inordinate amount of time spent waiting in line. It is not uncommon to observe a significant number of employees roaming the store, rendering the experience even more frustrating. 

In addition, this store was the sole location that offered Dill buttons, which are renowned for their superior quality and durability. As a regular user of buttons, I found this to be a significant advantage. Unfortunately, Hobby Lobby has recently discontinued the sale of Dill buttons and now exclusively offers their own brand, which is inferior in quality and available at a discounted price through promotions. 

Fortunately, I no longer need to endure the lengthy lines, as I have opted to shop online instead."

Ok, the selection is amazing.  But, after the nightmare of shopping on Black Friday last year (I had a certificate that I could only use that weekend, so had no choice), this time I planned.  This was last weekend.  I stared shopping at 10:40 in the morning.  Hardly anyone was there.  Merchandise was organized.  Not a single shopping bag to be found!  I found everything I needed.  Somehow, 4 items!! FOUR OF THEM!  

Since I was using a gift certificate, I couldn't return or exchange items, so I didn't keep the receipt (that I know of).  One of these items was a gift:-(  

Somehow, this didn't happen during the Black Friday from hell with tons of people.  Also, they let people bring their alcohol in there.  Bad idea.  Saw a girl go up the escalator the wrong way...

WTF??!!  It was not a stressful morning.

This was at the Forum Shops.

Forever 21 would NEVER let this happen!

We were tardy in our arrival, which resulted in the unfortunate circumstance of our accommodations being relinquished, thereby necessitating our transferral to an alternative lodging establishment, only to return to the original hotel the subsequent night. This turn of events was utterly dissatisfying. Notwithstanding this inconvenience, we did receive complimentary morning repasts for a pair of nights, and the continental breakfast offered on the superior level surpassed my expectations considerably. However, it must be noted that the aforementioned executive level boasted a fitness center with restricted operational hours and an additional fee for usage, as well as an internet connection that also carried an extra charge. In my opinion, these aspects were somewhat disillusioning.

"A plethora of establishments offering gastronomical delights at reasonable prices abound, rendering the exorbitant cost of dining at this particular restaurant utterly unnecessary; my taste buds were subjected to an unfortunate assault by the excessive sodium content in the shrimp adorning my salad, which caused discomfort and temporary lingual debilitation; however, the scallops and steak proved to be somewhat satisfying, yet ultimately failed to justify the preposterous tariff."

I have had the occasion to partake in the culinary offerings of this establishment on three separate occasions, with two of those visits being dedicated to indulging in the weekend breakfast buffet and a single visit for lunch. While the fare provided can be likened to that of Denny's, it cannot be considered particularly exceptional or noteworthy. Moreover, my experiences have been marred by an unfortunate encounter with a dish containing hair, which raises concerns regarding the cleanliness and hygiene of the kitchen. Furthermore, the service has been merely adequate, and the appearance of the staff members themselves has been less than impressive, leading me to form the opinion that this establishment does not warrant future visits.

"I am utterly dumbfounded by the plethora of 5-star reviews lavished upon this establishment, as my experience was anything but satisfactory. As out-of-towners seeking a convenient dining spot in close proximity to our workplace, we were disappointed to encounter a packed venue that necessitated a 30-minute wait, which, while not inherently problematic, was exacerbated by the humorless demeanor of the greeter, whose lack of amiability set a decidedly inauspicious tone for the evening. Our initial order, comprising a tofu appetizer accompanied by ikkura and an assortment of condiments, was indeed delectable, with the tofu exhibiting remarkable texture and flavor. However, the hand scallop Soy roll, despite its diminutive size and failure to meet my explicit request for added spiciness, was unfortunately overshadowed by the underwhelming quality of the edamame, which, having been cooked to an unfortunate excess, resulted in an unpleasant texture and a general lack of freshness that permeated the remainder of the meal. Specifically, the various rolls, including the much-touted'monster' variety, suffered from an evident dearth of inspiration and attention to detail, with listless ingredients failing to impress even the most cursory of palates. Furthermore, the tuna sashimi, despite being sent back twice, remained subpar, prompting us to query the kitchen's dedication to quality and culinary expertise. Notwithstanding the preceding litany of disappointments, the green tea crÃ¨me brÃ»lÃ©e, while undeniably delicious, was served in such a meager portion as to border on the laughable, especially when juxtaposed with the exorbitant price point of $12 per bottle for the sake, which, while admittedly of superior quality, did little to mitigate the overall sense of disillusionment and frustration engendered by our dining experience."

"Subpar service experience with too much repetition."  I had a pedicure, and while the polish appeared satisfactory, the remainder of the treatment was disappointing. The young man who performed the service seemed to assault me with cuticle clippers, leaving my skin feeling raw and irritated. Four hours have passed, and I am still experiencing discomfort. The massage component of the service was also lacking, failing to provide adequate relaxation. Furthermore, during the manicure process, both my friend and I were left sitting in the pedi chair, enduring an unpleasant and painful experience as the staff members pulled our arms out of their sockets. Consequently, I do not anticipate returning to this establishment for any future services.

"The atmosphere exudes an elegantly refined charm reminiscent of bygone eras, characterized by luxurious table settings and high-quality cutlery. However, the service we received fell short of our expectations, potentially due to our casual attire, which seemed to convey the impression of a tourist seeking a laid-back dining experience. It is worth noting that tourists often possess financial resources and are willing to invest in their culinary experiences. \nRegrettably, the menu offerings appeared to cater primarily to meat enthusiasts, disregarding the preferences of health-conscious individuals. In response, I requested a customized salad, only to discover that it was insufficient in size and arrived with an excessive amount of unnecessary toppings. My entree-sized salad, intended to satisfy my hunger, proved woefully inadequate, leaving me still hungry and dissatisfied. Furthermore, my special request was incorrectly prepared, compelling me to observe my companion's dining experience while mentally calculating the quantity of carbohydrates contained within my napkin. \nGiven these disappointments, I must conclude that future visits to this establishment are unlikely, as there are numerous alternative dining options that better align with my values and provide a more satisfying experience for my hard-earned currency."

"For the benefit of indulging in a refreshing beverage and enjoying quality entertainment, the temperature of the beer is satisfactorily cool, the televisions are of impressive quality, and the culinary offerings, while not exceptional, are palatable. However, the aspect of customer service unfortunately suffers from a consistent decline in quality, reaching an unacceptable level that is utterly appalling. It has been divulged to me on numerous occasions that the high turnover rate among staff members can be attributed to an inadequate management style and a lack of respectful treatment towards employees. Thus, it is advisable to cease patronizing this establishment, particularly given the abundance of alternative sports bars that boast commendable staff and a welcoming atmosphere."

This place is just too hyped up.  I ordered a burger medium well and it was oozing red on the inside.  i could barely fit my mouth around it.  I'm sorry but burgers are 100% about perfect proportioning of quality ingredients.  If you want to make a bigger bugger, make it bigger in a direction that makes sense.  Burgers are my favorite food, but I was not thrilled by this place.  Stack'd in shadyside is better for 1/4 the price.  Also the restaurant was freezing cold!  I was sat at a teeny high table where our plates could barely fit even though the restaurant was mostly empty.  I didn't like the way the burgers were served also, they were crammed in a tiny basket that made it hard to eat.  Don't get me wrong this place isn't bad, but there are so many other places nearby that will give you better food/atmosphere for a fraction of brgr price.

L'hamburger steak est ok  mais trop ch\u00e8re. Il commence \u00e0 4.50$ mais peut monter facilement \u00e0 une dizaine de dollars avec les extras. Le take out peut prendre facilement une quinzaine de minutes (pour un hamburger). Trop de boucane \u00e0 l int\u00e9rieur aussi lorsque il est en pleine production.

Ok, so I've never had pho before this, so I don't have a benchmark. What I do know was the pho was really bland, so the second time I tried the Asian Invasion cheesesteak... $9 for a sandwich with nothing else, made on a cheap store-bought roll that tasted nothing like french bread. 

When my sister saw I wasn't all that enthusiastic about my sandwich, she offered to let me try her banh mi. It was super salty and on the same roll, with veggies that I thought were supposed to be pickled but lacked any bite.

Put enough sriracha on anything and it's edible, but for these prices, I want better.
Went for Sunday brunch. Edible items include bacon and funnel cake strips. Everything else appeared to have been purchased frozen from Sam's club.

"On two separate occasions, I have had the privilege of dining at this esteemed establishment. During my initial visit, my party and I opted to situate ourselves at the bar, as we had failed to secure a reservation in advance. Subsequently, we endured an extended period of waiting, which ultimately resulted in our being seated and enjoying a satisfying culinary experience, both in terms of the quality of the food and the ambiance. However, fast forwarding to my second visit, which took place this evening, proved to be a vastly different story. Having secured a reservation for 5:30 PM, specifically to commemorate a birthday celebration, we were apprised at 7:09 PM that our table was required for another patron, despite the fact that we had explicitly reserved it for the entire evening. Not only was this an egregious breach of business etiquette, but it also contravened the fundamental principles of customer satisfaction. Furthermore, the fact that we were celebrating a milestone occasion and had been accorded a complimentary birthday surprise for the honoree only served to exacerbate the situation. While the cuisine itself was generally satisfactory, with my tenderloin tips being slightly over-salted yet still palatable, and the key lime pie eliciting praise from my fellow diners, the overall experience left much to be desired. In light of these events, I am left feeling utterly perplexed as to why such an esteemed establishment would deliberately jeopardize its reputation by alienating loyal patrons in such a manner. Suffice it to say, I shall not be returning to this restaurant in the future."

"Although Chez ma grosse truie cherie did not initially feature on my list of essential Montreal eateries, I ultimately found myself dining there due to the challenge of securing a reservation at a popular restaurant on a bustling Saturday evening. It appeared that this establishment catered primarily to large gatherings, boasting communal tables and a family-style menu that proved well-suited to our group of five.  

The service we received was attentive and impressive, but unfortunately, the cuisine did not quite live up to the high standard of hospitality. We opted to share several dishes, including a selection of oysters ($15), which were paired with apple ice cider vinegar from Vergers de la Colline. While they were not bad, I have certainly had superior oysters on previous occasions.  

The Chef Choice Seared Foie Gras ($23) was, without a doubt, the highlight of the meal. In fact, I would return solely to indulge in that particular dish once again. The sourness of the fresh grapes harmonized beautifully with the richness of the foie gras, making it a truly memorable experience. It's worth noting that I selfishly refused to share this dish with my fellow diners.  

The Whole Hog ($32/pp), comprising baby back ribs, smoked grilled pork chop, braised shanks, braising juices, and Parmesan cheese French fries, made for an visually striking platter. However, the majority of the meat proved to be underwhelming, with the exception of the tender and moist shank. Additionally, I found the roasted vegetables to be quite satisfying.  

In hindsight, the only redeeming aspect of the dining experience may have been the selection of locally brewed beers available in bottles. Specifically, the offerings from Dieu du Ciel managed to somewhat enhance the overall dining encounter.  

Unfortunately, I cannot envision a scenario where I would return to Chez ma grosse truie cherie in the near future, unless, of course, I could guarantee having that sublime foie gras all to myself."

"The culinary offerings were of satisfactory quality, however, our server, Maggie, displayed a remarkable lack of acumen and social grace, leading to an unfortunate series of events that ultimately resulted in a successful resolution through my personal intervention and discourse with the proprietor, yet, unfortunately, my dining experience was irrevocably tarnished, thereby precluding any future visits to the establishment."

People throng this establishment, as evidenced by the capacity crowd on a Thursday evening, compelling us to dine in the bar area to circumvent an approximate delay of twenty minutes for a table. The prices listed on the menu are exorbitant, rendering our dining experience financially untenable, save for the fortuitous possession of a $50 gift card. Our desire to partake in a shared culinary experience accompanying our alcoholic beverages proved futile due to the waitstaff's inability to proffer any gluten-free options with certainty. Thus, I consumed the complimentary bread and butter, followed by our ordering of dessert - his, an ice cream sundae, and mine, a lemoncello raspberry cheesecake, albeit unimpressive in taste, prompting me to consume only a few bites, cognizant of the unnecessary caloric intake. Our total expenditure, inclusive of three mixed drinks (a mojito for myself and two gin and tonics for my companion) and the aforementioned desserts, amounted to $45, which we deemed excessive. Notably, the gratis bread proved the most satisfying aspect of our dining experience, while the quality of service we received fell short of expectations.

Firstly, this establishment exudes an ambiance reminiscent of a national chain franchise, complete with staff who appear to be feigning enthusiasm in accordance with their prescribed guidelines. Notwithstanding, the culinary offerings, specifically the burgers, are of satisfactory quality, albeit the standard iteration boasts two patties while the diminutive version consists of a solitary patty. Furthermore, the fresh-cut fries merit high praise, perhaps ranking among the finest in Tempe. While we may consider returning, it is unlikely that we would venture out of our way to do so.

The rooms are very nice, clean and comfortable. 

Family above us was very loud, early in the morning I could hear them eating stomping on the floor.arguing...chairs sliding etc.. really took away from the experience.,

We were in the Lily building right behind the office. The parking was horrible, there were never any spots near the building open. Had to dump the in-laws on the curb since they are not able to walk so much. Then Id drive around praying for someone to leave. the casino next door was closer than the parking garage to our building.

WiFi is an issue too.. 40 bucks for the week on 1 device.. gosh every hotel we were at on our trip had free WIFI but not the most expensive.. .. I only pay 19.99 a month at home.

One of my guests was approached at check in to do the time share presentation. The lady started filling out a form for him for the next morning and he said he may not be able to go but would try, she rudely asked him if he was going or not? He told her he didnt know, she tore up the slip and said never mind have a nice day.. REALLY??? Welcome to Vegas!

My better half frequents this establishment whenever feasible, whereas I steadfastly decline to accompany her, due to the discourteous demeanor of the individual manning the counter, who epitomizes the paradigm of an indifferent hipster, thereby rendering it untenable for me to expend my resources within such an environment.
We have been here 3 times, and the service has been bad every time. The view is AMAZING, but because of the poor service we will not return.

"Had the pleasure of partaking in a culinary excursion at this esteemed establishment last week, and my expectations were elevated due to its illustrious reputation in the city's gastronomic circles. While the experience was not without its merits, it fell short of my lofty expectations in certain aspects. The ambiance was reminiscent of a bygone era, with its classic Italian restaurant decor and pictorial representations of celebrated patrons adorning the walls, creating an atmosphere that was both convivial and nostalgic. The staff were attentive, courteous, and displayed a proficiency in their duties that was truly commendable. However, the cuisine, while certainly palatable, did not quite live up to the standards that one might expect from an establishment of such renown. My veal dish, in particular, was satisfactory but failed to meet the expectations that I had cultivated based on the acclaim that Rao's has garnered over the years. It seemed as though the kitchen was hesitant to take risks and thus produced a generous portion of fare that, while certainly edible, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi that would have elevated it to the realm of true gastronomic excellence. In conclusion, while Rao's possesses a unique charm and a dedication to service that is unparalleled, a modicum of fine-tuning in the culinary department could serve to enhance an already enjoyable dining experience."

Meh. Sure, the hot dogs are good, and you can get it piled with toppings. But it's quite expensive for what you get!\n\nAnd I was really excited to see they had Poutine on the menu, as my Canadian brethren had told me legends about the stuff. But I came away a little disappointed. Guess I'll have to wait until I end up in Quebec to try it again!

My #1 pet peeve with this airport is that you must board a tram everytime.  Why?  SFO is bigger yet there's no tram.  

While waiting to fly home, the jacked up PA system near gate D1 was ear-piercingly loud and distorted.  Are they oblivious to this?  They even have to add the 3 loud ass toots after their deafening message just for added pleasure. Everyone was covering their ears from the shreiking.  Are they that busy with checking to see if people are sneaking water bottles onboard that they don't know this?

Also, why is it that a taxi ride to the hotel is $25 and only $15 to the airport?  Isn't it essentially the same distance?

Came here yesterday and didn't have a great experience like I've had at many other Yard House Restaurants before.  We were able to be seated right away +1 star.  
 
Our waiter came over and we placed our order. Lunch special with pizza and tomato basil soup, kids meal with pizza and veggies and ahi appetizer which  was being eaten for lunch and not appetizer.  My cousin also ordered a beer, which took forever to come out.  The waiter finally came over after about 10 minutes and said they had to replace the keg.  

Beer finally came, next we waited for our food... And waited, and waited and waited!  Thank goodness I had snacks in my bag for my 3 year old to settle him while we waited.  When the food did arrive, the cheese on the pizza looked old and dry, as if it had been sitting under the heat lamp for quite awhile.  We only had a few bites and moved on to the soup, which my 3 year old and I basically split because it was delicious +1 star!

Threw the leftover pizza away since it was gross.

"Wait, wait, wait; this establishment is still in operation? Perchance my incredulity stems from the notion that a venture of this caliber could continue to flourish within an economic climate seemingly designed to foster exclusively the prosperity of a select few. However, upon further deliberation, it appears that my consternation is rooted in the enigmatic nature of this enterprise's conceptual framework. Specifically, the dichotomy between the tangible aspects of 'Air,' 'Earth,' 'Fire,' and 'Water' and their abstract representations within the context of this venue eludes my comprehension. Furthermore, the juxtaposition of such elements with the opulent decor and extravagant prices serves only to exacerbate my perplexity. Alas, my limited understanding of fiscal dynamics and entrepreneurial acumen renders me incapable of fully grasping the intricacies of maintaining a business of this caliber. Nonetheless, I must commend the investment evident in the initial stages of this undertaking, as well as the ostentatious elevator leading to the exclusive VIP area; an eccentric display of luxury, indeed."

45 minutes d attente, au lieu des 20 annoncees, pour \u00eatre en terrasse, la salle \u00e9tant vraiment trop bruyante, \u00e7a.commencait mal... \"Les meilleures pizzas de Montr\u00e9al\", bon, ca valait surement le coup d attendre. Et bien non... La pizza du chef n'avait aucun interet tout comme les pates d un de mes amis, noy\u00e9s dans une sauce grasse insipide... une addition elevee m'a convaincu de me mettre que deux \u00e9toiles, le seul int\u00e9r\u00eat \u00e9tant la terrasse, agr\u00e9able. Bref, une adresse \u00e0 \u00e9viter, pour qui aime un tant soit peu la cuisine italienne!

"The precise delineation of two celestial bodies: MEH. I'VE ENJOYED SUPERIOR CULINARY EXPERIENCES. \n\nFor an individual who has an unwavering fondness for Korean BBQ and partakes in it with remarkable frequency, I would not advocate for this establishment as a suitable location for satisfying one's KBBQ cravings. Throughout my extensive exploration of diverse KBBQ locales, I have yet to encounter a restaurant that charges such exorbitant prices, which, regrettably, seems to be a common trait among businesses situated within the Strip. Given the prohibitive cost of a meager serving of kogi, I opted to procure dolsot bimbimbap instead. Unfortunately, this particular dolsot bimbimbap proved to be the most expensive instance of its kind that I have had the misfortune of encountering. The eatery, in general, lacked any distinguishing qualities or exceptional characteristics. In light of these factors, I shall confer upon it a rating of two stars, primarily due to the passable quality of the culinary offerings and the waitstaff's commendable honesty regarding the portion size of the KBBQ meat. Needless to say, I do not intend to revisit this establishment in the future."

"There are two categories of individuals who frequent this venue: senior citizens and those possessing complimentary passes. We fell into the latter category, courtesy of my fiancÃ©'s employer, who generously provided us with a pair of tickets to a Regal cinema. Unfortunately, the Regal chain does not have an extensive presence in this particular region, thereby limiting our options. However, we opted to utilize the passes at this establishment, despite its somewhat antiquated nature. The theater itself was rather desolate, with a limited number of staff members present, including a lone individual manning the concession stand and a single employee stationed at the ticket counter. The auditorium itself was modest in size, with a less-than-impressive audio experience and a distinctly retro ambiance. In fact, the seating arrangement was such that one had to ascend a slight incline in order to reach the screen, which struck me as somewhat unusual. Were it not for the complimentary passes, we likely would have elected to depart and seek alternative entertainment. Instead, we chose to persevere and endure the less-than-ideal conditions. Our intention now is to visit the Northsight location, where the second set of tickets can be redeemed. My assumption had been that the majority of Scottsdale was characterized by upscale surroundings and a significant population, rather than the sparse, geriatric demographic that we encountered in Sun City. It has become apparent that this establishment is in need of a radical transformation or, perhaps, even retirement."

This most certainly does not qualify as a three-star hotel or resort, and it barely meets the standards of a two-star establishment. The rooms exude a pungent odor, suggestive of mold and mildew, while the interior and bedding appear unkempt and grimy, giving the impression that they have not been thoroughly cleaned in quite some time. Furthermore, the overall ambiance of the facility seems dilapidated and faded, perhaps hinting at a formerly grandiose reputation that has since diminished significantly. The beds themselves are quite unsatisfactory, characterized by an uneven surface and an unpleasant lack of support, leading one to suspect that they may harbor bed bugs, although upon closer inspection, no such creatures were found. However, a small, mysterious creature was observed in the bathtub, adding to the overall sense of discomfort and unease. On a somewhat positive note, the Speakman shower heads and water pressure were quite impressive, providing a brief respite from the otherwise underwhelming experience that this establishment offers. In conclusion, I would not recommend returning to this hotel/resort, as it fails to meet even the most basic expectations of cleanliness and comfort.

We found ourselves on the aforementioned side of town, eager to indulge in the culinary delights that this establishment purportedly offered, specifically the zucchini fingers that we had heard so much about. However, upon our return, we were dismayed to discover that the aforementioned zucchini fingers lacked the crispiness that we had anticipated, instead displaying a remarkable propensity to bend in half when lifted, which rather detracted from the overall experience. Furthermore, we were taken aback by the absence of tatziki sauce, which we had been led to believe was an integral component of the dish, only to be presented with a minuscule container for an additional fee. This development struck us as somewhat analogous to visiting an American diner and being charged extra for ketchup, which seemed incongruous with our preconceived notions of what constituted a satisfactory dining experience. 
Additionally, we observed that the zucchini appeared to be in dire need of salt, a deficiency that significantly impacted our enjoyment of the dish. Our beef and lamb gyro, while adequate, was regrettably characterized by a notable dryness, while my husband's Oscar burger, renowned for its inclusion of pastrami, suffered from a similar lack of moisture. The accompanying salad, ostensibly intended as a palliative to the uninspiring fare that preceded it, was instead replete with an excessive quantity of dressing, eliciting a response akin to alarm rather than gratitude. In light of these developments, we reluctantly concluded that a future visit to this establishment would not be forthcoming, as more satisfying Greek cuisine could be obtained at Stephanos, a venue situated closer to our domicile.

"If you desire to consume a beverage prior to having expended three hundred dollars within the establishment's gaming devices, it is imperative that you vocalize your request with clarity and conviction. Unfortunately, securing the attention of a server can be a formidable task, particularly during peak hours or after ten o'clock in the evening when the atmosphere becomes increasingly vibrant. Upon successfully procuring your libation, it may be advisable to request a double portion, given the diminutive nature of the standard serving size. Notwithstanding the aforementioned challenges, this venue does offer an exceptional 'Rooster' salad, which regrettably may not appeal to the majority of habitual clientele, who appear to be more preoccupied with maintaining a fastidious household than indulging in culinary delights. Their demeanor is often characterized by an unwavering focus on their personal hygiene and an unsettling intensity, leading one to surmise that they may have temporarily abandoned their arduous efforts to scrub their grout and opted to display their bruxism in a public setting instead."
They should put the flies on the menu! We went for lunch and were bothered by so many flies that it ruined the meal. Just be prepared!

I was sadly disappointed, after reading all the excellent I thought it was shoe in. not so much. Long wait for food then it was just ok. Id rather pay more for food that tastes amazing and doesn't take forever to get.

"My initial reservations regarding the quality of this establishment's beverages have been comprehensively alleviated. It is an ideal venue for a convivial evening with male companions, viewing a sporting event. However, I must caution against expecting a tranquil ambiance conducive to meaningful conversation. 

Upon perusing the menu, I opted for a pint of ale and a platter of deep-fried fish accompanied by potato wedges. Unfortunately, the latter arrived in a state of unfortunate sogginess, which compromised its flavor and texture. Furthermore, the fish was positioned atop the garlic fries, resulting in an unappealing amalgamation of tastes and textures. I must confess that the overall experience was underwhelming. 

The interior design and atmosphere of the premises did evoke a traditional tavern, enhanced by the presence of live musical entertainment during my visit. However, the combination of boisterous patrons and the audio from the sporting event created a cacophonous environment that may not be suitable for all patrons. Our server provided adequate attention, yet the process of dividing the bill among multiple parties proved to be somewhat arduous. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, I would still recommend a visit to this establishment, albeit with tempered expectations."
I went for their lunch buffet and was expecting a buffet. It was a few dishes and the honey chicken turned my mouth into a glue trap. Haven't been back since.

After an exhaustive examination of the evaluations, it was determined that giving it a try would be a worthwhile venture.  WOW, capacity crowd on a Sunday evening with a protracted waiting period of twenty minutes. Familiarity with the culinary aspects of Houston, having resided there for seven years, facilitated an informed decision regarding the consumption of the piquant mudbugs.  The crawfish possessed an exceptional quality, devoid of sogginess and moderately seasoned to accommodate my gustatory preferences, opting for the fiery and succulent temperature.  Unfortunately, the establishment had exhausted their supply of stone and blue crab, thus limiting the options to king legs and snow crab.  I selected the diminutive sized snow crabs, while my acquaintance chose the shrimp platter.  Both dishes were predominantly composed of fries.  This eatery would suffer a swift demise in South Texas or the bayou region.

Pros:  Prompt delivery of the culinary offerings, Miller Lite served at a refreshingly low temperature by the bottle.
Cons:  Limited selection of items available during the visit, purporting to offer alcoholic beverages, specifically wine, though solely by the bottle the previous evening.  Ambiance garnered a zero, as the patrons were compactly arranged, evoking the image of sardines, pardon the pun.  Overwhelmed waitstaff, possibly attributable to a lack of experience.  Lemons had to be requested, prompting incredulity.

Disgusting food, disgusting desserts. 

It's all superficial here - everything looks good until you take a bite out of it. The pastas and noodles were overcooked and oversauced, the fried foods (you usually can't go wrong with those) were good until I bit into one that was all breading and oil, and the mac n' cheese didn't fail to disappoint.

The desserts were bitter or plain disgusting and the soft serve ice cream was icy and cheap tasting. The cookies, which looked really good - did not live up to their looks.

I do give Hometown Buffet two stars however, for their dinner rolls and mushrooms. THOSE, well... Those were pretty awesome.

I reserved two accommodations for myself and my associates to indulge in a period of leisure and enjoyment in Las Vegas; however, we were not entirely satisfied with our experience at this particular establishment. Despite our initial enthusiasm, several unforeseen circumstances and subpar service hindered our overall satisfaction. Firstly, upon arriving at 1:30 pm, we discovered that only one of our rooms was ready, whereas the second room, which was supposed to be adjacent and connected, was not prepared until 6:15 pm. Furthermore, we were lacking essential bathroom amenities such as shampoo and conditioner in the second room, which necessitated a delay of one hour for their delivery due to an overwhelmed attendant. These inconveniences were merely the beginning, as we encountered further miscommunication and inadequate assistance from the concierge. Specifically, they failed to inform us that the club we intended to visit, Marque, was not operational that evening, and instead, only one of its auxiliary rooms, Boombox, was accessible. This oversight led to unnecessary effort and disappointment. My companions and I collectively agree that for a luxury hotel, the personnel, ranging from the front desk attendants to the concierge and security guards, require more comprehensive training and education. Their present level of proficiency falls short of expectations considering the high rates charged by the establishment. Consequently, I would opt for a more seasoned and refined hotel, despite its age, for a superior experience.

This is an alright place if you haven't experienced some of the much better places in Arizona.  I think it is somewhat overpriced compared to similar restaurants and the food isn't anything to rave about.

This gym offers a great selection of classes; however, there are more negatives than positives with this gym. Parking is difficult to come by, and you have to pay. The staff is not so friendly, it's expensive for the quality of equipment, and I wish someone was sitting at the desk downstairs instead of upstairs. \n\nI can't wait for my contract to end; I regret signing one now. There has to be better gyms in the area.

"I recently visited this establishment on a particularly hectic Sunday afternoon, specifically to procure a takeout order, and I must say that the atmosphere was utterly chaotic, with patrons congregating both within and outside of the premises, creating an environment that was reminiscent of a bustling marketplace. Notwithstanding the bedlam, we managed to successfully place our order with the exceptionally industrious takeout manager, who truly deserves accolades for his diligence and proficiency in handling the throngs of customers. However, the remainder of the staff left much to be desired in terms of their attentiveness and hospitality, as they failed to offer us even the most basic of amenities, such as a refreshing beverage or a solicitous inquiry regarding our needs. Furthermore, the ambiance of the establishment was somewhat disorderly and unkempt, which only served to further detract from the overall dining experience. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the cuisine itself was of the usual high quality associated with this particular eatery, featuring a meticulously arranged salad presented in an innovative container designed to maintain the freshness of its various components, along with a thoughtful divider that prevented the cold items from impacting the temperature of the hot food. In conclusion, while the restaurant's culinary offerings were certainly satisfactory, the subpar service and general disarray of the surroundings unfortunately warrant only a mediocre rating of two stars."

"If you are going to proffer New Mexican cuisine, then present it authentically, without diluting its inherent flavors and essence. During my month-long sojourn in the region, I observed that utilizing a full Green chile for preparing Chile Relleno was unprecedented; instead, culinary purists opted for either Poblano or Anaheim peppers, which were subsequently enrobed in a rich green chile sauce. Notably, the gentleman adjacent to us expressed considerable discontent with the sauce's lack of piquancy. Complimentary chips and salsa were served at the bar, the quality of which was satisfactory, albeit unremarkable. Furthermore, I couldn't help but notice, much like a fellow Yelper, that the expedited arrival of our victuals, mere minutes after placing our orders, suggested a prefabricated nature to the dishes, thereby negating the possibility of culinary customization and, by extension, gastronomic excellence. The pseudo Chile Relleno was sufficient grounds for my departure."

We have placed orders for pizza from this establishment on three separate occasions, and unfortunately, the quality of the product has deteriorated with each successive order. The most recent pie, which featured a Hawaiian-style topping configuration, arrived in a state of utter saturation, rendering it unpalatable until we attempted to restore its crispness through the application of heat in an oven, an endeavor that proved unsuccessful. 
Upon contacting the proprietor of the business, we were met with a dismissive and unhelpful demeanor, as he initially claimed that the sogginess of the pizza was an inherent characteristic of the Hawiian variety, a statement we vigorously contested. He then shifted his stance, asserting that the ingredients used in the pizza's preparation were fresh, a fact that we found to be utterly irrelevant under the circumstances. Finally, he offered a half-hearted compromise, suggesting that we might receive a credit towards a future purchase, a gesture that struck us as wholly inadequate given the magnitude of our disappointment and frustration. 
In light of these events, we feel compelled to advise potential patrons to avoid this establishment at all costs, as the quality of the food and the level of customer service are woefully substandard.

Beer and apps were okay but if you are looking for any sort of craft brewing atmosphere this is not it. Service was below average yet the place was slow. I like Sleepy Dog in Tempe but will never return to this location. Maybe it's an attempt to appeal to everyone but it just doesn't work here.

I was eager to partake in a culinary experience at this esteemed establishment, but unfortunately, my expectations were not met, as the cuisine failed to impress, with dishes that were merely average and comparable to those offered at a significantly lower price point. The dim sum was somewhat satisfying, but the snapper was overcooked and the pairing of prawns and curry did not resonate with my taste buds. Additionally, the ambiance of the nightclub was uninviting, reminiscent of a subterranean space, which prompted my group and I to depart shortly after being seated. However, I must commend the staff for their exceptional hospitality.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

The text is: "Expensive for what it is. Burger (6oz) fries and soda over 10 bucks. The fries were 2.40... And not for a five guys portion either! \n. Service was slow too... And the place was not packed out. I predict they will not last long.... Like johnnie brusco's."

The modified text is:

"Disproportionate pricing for a meager meal, burdened by an exorbitant cost surpassing ten dollars, inclusive of a minuscule serving of French fries, tantamount to a paltry side dish, and a carbonated beverage, culminating in an unsatisfactory dining experience, further marred by sluggish service and an unoccupied atmosphere, foreboding an impending demise, analogous to the ill-fated Johnnie Brusco's eatery."

"It is utterly perplexing that individuals would bestow such effusive praise upon this establishment, ostensibly in an attempt to convey their sophisticated taste and familiarity with unpretentious, off-the-beaten-path venues in less affluent neighborhoods. The reality, however, is that our dining experience was utterly unpleasant. We sampled the queso with chorizo, which was palatable, albeit somewhat unremarkable. Our main courses, on the other hand, were nothing short of gastronomic abominations. The green sauce accompanying my chilaquiles was eerie and unsettling, while the steak was woefully underseasoned and sported an unpleasant, almost acrid flavor. I requested a to-go container and appropriated the steak for the benefit of my canine companions. My associate opted for their torta, which elicited a dubious response. Upon sampling it, I concurred that it was, indeed, quite revolting. She attempted to consume it again the following morning but ultimately discarded it due to its unpalatability. We shall persist in our patronage of Gallo Blanco, despite their subpar service, as their torta is undeniably exceptional. In conclusion, the culinary offerings of this establishment are, in my opinion, utterly reprehensible, despite the friendly demeanor of the staff and the immaculate condition of the premises."

I became a patient of Dr. Barrettoko after my favorite doctor at Nevada Family Care moved on.  What a disappointment that was. I would have followed her, but her new facility did not accept my insurance.  

Dr. Barrettoko is not of the same caliber as the previous doctor. The final straw was during my last appointment. As I was telling Dr. Barrettoko what I was feeling, what symptoms I was experiencing and I caught her texting on her cell phone.  She works with an iPad-like device that has the patient's medical records on it.  She was trying to hide her cell phone behind the tablet as she was texting away. Unbelievable!  If want a doc's I undivided attention do not visit Dr. Barrettoko.

The rest of the staff is nice enough. I do not have experience with any of the doctors at Nevada Family Care.

"The restaurant's happy hour pricing strategy, while economically advantageous, does not necessarily translate into commensurate culinary quality. In fact, my colleagues and I have experienced better-tasting sushi rolls at local grocery stores. Our recent early evening visit, during which we sampled their hot and spicy tuna roll and 'lollipop,' unfortunately confirmed a decline in gastronomic standards. Specifically, the tuna was excessively diced, resulting in a mushy texture. Upon bringing this to the attention of our server, his response was a mere scowl and a perfunctory apology, followed by the abrupt removal of the still-full plate. No tangible gesture of compensation or genuine effort at reconciliation was offered, leaving us with an unsettled bill and a lingering sense of disappointment."

There exists gratis parking in the rear of the establishment, which serves as an advantageous attribute for patrons who wish to avoid incurring additional fees associated with parking their vehicles. Furthermore, upon presenting a receipt as proof of purchase, customers are eligible to receive a discount of ten percent on any souvenir items purchased from the gift shop situated on the upper level of the building. However, it is worth noting that while the culinary offerings are of an acceptable quality, a member of our party of five opted to substitute the highly publicized macaroni and cheese in lieu of the customary side dish of French fries. Nevertheless, when the meal was delivered, it was conspicuous by its absence, prompting the server to express confusion and incredulity at the oversight, as she was oblivious to the fact that not only were there no fries present, but also the macaroni and cheese that was requested had failed to materialize.

"The atmosphere was rather agreeable, albeit the service was utterly chaotic and disorganized, rendering our dining experience utterly unpleasant. Notwithstanding the palatable quality of the beverages, the prolonged delay in the arrival of our culinary selections, coupled with their frigid temperature, precipitated an unfortunate concatenation of events that rendered our evening meal an unmitigated disappointment.
