Moreover, the cacophonous ambiance militated against any semblance of tranquility or conversation, rendering it patently impractical to engage in even the most basic dialogue while partaking of sustenance. Furthermore, the absence of any semblance of organization or efficiency in the processing of separate checks for our party only served to exacerbate the already untenable situation, leading us to conclude that this particular establishment was woefully ill-equipped to accommodate the demands of its clientele. In light of these considerations, it is abundantly clear that a radical transformation is imperative if this venue is to avoid the fate of so many of its predecessors in the local hospitality industry."

"The most economical dining establishment within the Wynn resort complex, the Pizza Place, offers a comparable culinary experience to that of New York-style pizzerias, according to Mr. Wynn's assertions. However, my personal assessment diverges from his viewpoint. My expectations were high regarding the quality of the pizza, but unfortunately, it fell short of excellence. Patrons have the option of ordering an entire pie or individual slices, commencing with a straightforward cheese pizza and subsequently adding desired toppings and incremental costs. 
 
I opted for a pizza with pepperoni, onions, and peppers, anticipating that the peppers would be green; however, they were, in fact, red. Moreover, I expected the ingredients to be finely chopped, but they were not. While the pizza possessed a satisfactory taste, it was slightly too oily for my preference. Notwithstanding the provision of an elegant napkin, I chose not to utilize it to blot the excess oil. A positive aspect of the pizza was the generous size of each slice. 
 
In addition, I sampled their basic vinaigrette salad, which was unremarkable, and the dressing did not blend harmoniously with the greens. The iced tea infused with a hint of passion fruit was my favorite beverage, as it maintained a perfect balance between flavor and sweetness. Unfortunately, due to strong winds outside, we were compelled to dine indoors and could not fully appreciate the soothing sounds of the adjacent waterfalls."

If they could only devise a methodology whereby they could efficiently process telephonic orders without subjecting patrons to extended periods of time on hold, thereby negating the need for an interminable waiting period, they would be performing optimally. This particular Dominos establishment is situated in close proximity to my domicile, thereby rendering it a convenient venue for me to visit and place an order when I experience a yearning for their newly introduced, rather delectable, thin crust pizza. However, upon arriving at the aforementioned establishment, I am often compelled to wait in a rather uninspiring and uninviting waiting area. Furthermore, I would not advocate for visiting this location after sunset, as it has been associated with certain incidents of a violent nature occurring within the confines of the parking lot.

"The embellishment of the interior atmosphere was undoubtedly the most favorable facet of our dining experience, as the aesthetically pleasing decor created a warm and inviting ambiance that set the tone for an enjoyable evening. However, the quality of service we received fell short of our expectations, as our server failed to provide attentive and personalized care, opting instead for a hasty and impersonal approach that left much to be desired. Specifically, the absence of a detailed explanation regarding the wine list and the lack of attention paid to our concerns regarding the corked wine were particularly disappointing. Furthermore, the decision to expedite the delivery of our first courses simultaneously gave rise to a sense of urgency that detracted from our ability to fully appreciate each dish individually. When combined with the fact that the main courses were unremarkable in both taste and presentation, it became apparent that this establishment relies heavily on the reputation of its celebrated chef to attract customers, rather than focusing on providing a truly exceptional culinary experience. In essence, the restaurant's reliance on Hubert Keller's name represents a misguided attempt to capitalize on his prestige without delivering on the high standards that his reputation demands."

This proved to be a vacillating encounter, characterized by fluctuations in quality; specifically, the hospitality aspect was deficientâupon entrance, we were not greeted by a porter to assist with our luggage, and the state of our lodging left much to be desired, including an unsightly coiffure in the shower and a reprehensible stain on the parlor's couch (truly repulsive). Nonetheless, I must acknowledge that certain aspects of the accommodations did possess merit, such as the presence of balconies and some spectacular vistas. Furthermore, the gaming facilities were quite pleasant, and the locale was conveniently situated, practically in the center of the famed Las Vegas Strip. Be that as it may, when considering the tariff, superior alternatives become apparent.

It's too bad with so few good Mexican restaurants, what passes for good now is just very ordinary. The food at Lindo is plentiful on the plate and not outrageously priced... it's just that it does not make you say, I must return here. \nFor folks in Henderson, it's a long trip up to the World Market Center, but that's where you'll find interesting and very creative Mexican fare... at  Mundo Restaurant. ..(moving from their previous location over on Ft Apache, wish they decided to come to Henderson instead).\nhttp://www.lasvegasweekly.com/news/2010/apr/14/viva-el-mundo/

My maiden escapade at this establishment proved to be an unmitigated disaster, as my manicurist, a male individual, seemed to possess scant proficiency in his craft, leaving my nails in a state of utter disarray and disrepair. Furthermore, my epidermis suffered lacerations courtesy of the cuticle clippers, while the nail buffer inflicted an unsightly abrasion upon my person, necessitating prompt remedial measures upon my return home. To further exacerbate matters, the pedicure was executed in a frigid aquatic environment.

The entire episode was nothing short of a calamitous ordeal, culminating in a finished product that was aesthetically subpar and conspicuously shoddy. Regrettably, my customary salon was not patronized on this particular occasion, as I opted to experiment with one of the newer venues in town, but my expectations were not merely unfulfilled, but utterly decimated by the sheer ineptitude displayed by the staff. In conclusion, 4ur Nails is emphatically not worthy of my consideration.

Want to spend $$$$ on 'diner' food? Then stop in at BLT Burger. Just glancing at the menu one might think that the prices are somewhat reasonable, but beware. Fries are NOT included. Yep. That's extra. I had a Tex Mex burger which was decent but I've had better, and bigger elsewhere. The bun was soggy and it fell apart after the first bite. The spiked milkshakes on the other hand are awesome. Grandma's Treat is a wonderful concoction of Makers, vanilla, caramel, and nuts. All in all I would go back to BLT but only for the $11 (gulp) milkshakes.

You get what you pay for. 

The good things about this place is that its close to the middle of the strip with access to the city center, crystal shops, Aria, and Belligio through the tram. The hotel was cheap and the lobby is nice. 

Now the bad things: 

- The walls are extremely thin so you could hear every conversation, every toilet flush, every shower, and every door being opened and closed. They were so thin that you could hear your neighbor having SEX! Very disturbing!!
- Housekeeping is horrible: we had five pillow and all but one had a stain. Even the comforter had a stain. 
-The bathroom, most of the furniture, bed, and television were outdated or old and need replacing.
- There was no coffee maker. Why provide free coffee when you can charge $3.75 for a Starbucks coffee downstairs. 
- No mini bar
-The smell of so called rose petals smells good at first, but soon gets overwhelming and give you a headache. 

If you are looking for cheap stay in Las Vegas then this is your place. If you are looking for more comfort then I recommend somewhere else.

I've come in here during my previous business trips and gotten great food. 
I have specific food allergies which they were able to previously accommodate, however not this time.
I called in my order as usual, but they told me they changed their menu and what I wanted was a lunch menu item. The menu online hadn't been updated yet they still told me they wouldn't give me the food I was trying to order. 
This to me is false advertising, and poor customer service. 
Dont get me wrong, the food I had was good, but now I wont be going back because of this.

We went to Tryst on a Sunday during lunch for a family member's bday. The menu seemed promising. I decided on the seared ahi tuna salad for myself and spring rolls to share. I didn't think to ask if anything I ordered was going to be hot. I assumed the spring rolls would be hot because I've never experienced raw spring rolls before and any time I've ever ordered a salad with some fish in it- the fish has always come out hot. This was not the case. Which is not a big deal but cold seared ahi tuna is not good. The seared part of the title is misleading. When something has the word seared, I expect it to be HOT... but that's just me. The spring rolls were tasty -I just did not expect them to be cold/raw. Nothing to write home about but it wasn't terrible. \nAnd my fianc\u00e9 found a hair in his salad and I lost my appetite.

"It is utterly deplorable that I have yet to indulge in some of the exceptional wing offerings that have been highly praised. My expectations were elevated when I opted for the chicken Parmesan, and I eagerly anticipated savoring every bite of my half-priced happy hour wings. Unfortunately, the wings failed to meet my gastronomical expectations, as they lacked any semblance of flavor and were excessively greasy. Despite my initial enthusiasm, I found myself struggling to consume more than three wings, which seemed to be little more than bland, chicken-flavored vehicles for the delivery of an abundance of grease. The only redeeming aspect of the meal was the tomato salad, which featured generous portions of mozzarella cheese. Although my experience was less than satisfactory, I remain hopeful that future visits will yield more palatable results, and the presence of beer on the menu serves as a modicum of solace."

"Commencing with an affirmative assertion, the Cupcakery's red velvet cupcakes are indeed exceptionalâpossessing an optimal level of moisture and a profusion of flavor, while the accompanying frosting serves as a harmonious complement. A friendly individual presented me with one, and I was eager to share this culinary destination with my significant other. Unfortunately, their remaining cupcakes fell short of expectations, particularly in relation to their cost. For $3.75, I anticipate a product of considerable quality and quantity. However, the cupcakes we acquired were comparable in size and caliber to those offered at a supermarketâexhibiting a notable lack of moisture, minimal flavor, and an unsatisfactory cream cheese frosting that failed to enhance the coconut variety. While the shop's appearance was adequate and the decorations were acceptable, they did not exceed my modest decorative abilities; thus, I cannot recommend visiting this establishment unless an unwavering craving for sweets necessitates it."

"The delectable frozen confectionery served at this establishment is unfortunately juxtaposed with an ambiance tainted by evident neglect in terms of sanitation, as evidenced by the grimy sinks and counters, as well as a thick layer of dust accumulated on the interior surfaces of the glass casing encasing the scrumptious treat; however, despite the uninviting atmosphere, we opted to partake in the indulgence owing to the enticing appearance of the frozen delight, only to be met with further disappointment upon observing the state of disarray in the rear chamber, which was left unattended with the entrance ajar, thereby eliciting concern regarding the overall cleanliness and hygiene standards upheld by the premises, and thus, it is imperative that the proprietors address these shortcomings in order to provide a more pleasant experience for their clientele."

It has been an entire triennium since my last visitation to Sam Boyd Stadium, and upon my return, it became apparent that little to no alterations have transpired within this temporal span. The Rebels continue to exhibit a profound lack of proficiency, and the stadium itself remains inferior to its counterparts among institutions of higher learning. A solitary victory against Western Illinois on the evening of my attendance served as a minuscule source of gratification. The arena's antiquated design and the unimpressive nature of the amenities available for purchase within its confines persist in perpetuating the same concerns I articulated in my original assessment. It is my sincere expectation that at some point in the future, UNLV will elect to erect a novel stadium, thereby potentially enhancing the overall experience for spectators. Until such a time, the Return Factor for this venue shall remain at a meager fifty percent.

I surmise that I boast a rather uncomplicated coiffure and prefer to maintain it in such a manner. Alas, the individual responsible for trimming my locks in this establishment appears to have committed an error with the razor, specifically near my auricular region, and endeavored to rectify the situation by symmetricalizing the opposite side, thereby creating a semblance of normalcy. As I am not accustomed to gazing at my reflection for prolonged periods, I failed to notice the anomaly until the evening prior, when I was engaged in the act of lavation within a restaurant's sanitary facilities. I shall be conferring with the manager on Monday.

I experienced no delay in service, and the woman tasked with cutting my hair was quite affable, up until the point where she did not utter the phrase "oops, I sort of messed up your hair." While the outcome is not particularly egregious and I am not excessively distressed, it remains conspicuous. It would have been considerate of her to inform me of the situation. In my opinion, this warrants a refund of my payment. I shall update you all on whether or not I successfully obtained reimbursement.

"Although this establishment offered an acceptable dining experience, it did not quite meet my expectations. Specifically, the consistency of the curry was not in line with my personal preferences, as it was excessively watery. However, the customer service was indeed impressive, as our server was very attentive and courteous. Unfortunately, this positive aspect was not sufficient to outweigh the drawbacks, leading me to conclude that I would not be inclined to revisit this restaurant in the future."

"It is with profound regret that I must revise my previous assessment downward, as my recent experiences with the Meat Shop have fallen short of my expectations. Despite the staff's continued excellence in providing exceptional customer service, the quality of the products has not met my standards. In particular, my last two purchases, pork belly and spare ribs, have failed to impress. The former was excessively fatty, which, although understandable given the complexity of the smoking and curing process involved in homemade bacon production, was still subpar compared to my usual Asian market source. The latter was alarmingly lean and tough, standing in stark contrast to the succulent and meaty specimens I obtained from Smart & Final. While I acknowledge that articulating my preferences more clearly may potentially yield better outcomes, it remains inexcusable to receive inferior products, particularly at such exorbitant prices - triple or quadruple that of regular grocery stores."

The gastronomical establishment boasting a plethora of delectable offerings, most notably their complimentary chips and salsa, has garnered positive reviews from patrons; however, the staff members manning the counter have been described as brusque and discourteous, which may potentially deter customers from returning in the future. Furthermore, the California tacos, devoid of any remarkable flavors or embellishments, have failed to impress, leading one patron to express their disappointment and disinclination to revisit the establishment.

I opted for the establishment's signature chow mein dish, which I procured for takeout, at a cost of 8.10 currency units. My assessment of this culinary experience was that it was somewhat superior to the offerings of Panda Express, yet still lacking in flavor profile. Additionally, I noted that the quantity of meat accompanying the combo meal was limited, thereby rendering the pricing strategy of 8.10 for chow mein and 10.50 for all-you-can-eat dinner questionable. Consequently, I shall have to revisit this eatery to sample their AYCE option, as indulging in individual platters does not appear to be a worthwhile venture.

I just noticed this was so highly rated and wanted to send a little more reality the way of the burrito drive. The only thing it has going for it is the fact it delivers, and would pass for a business meeting or simple catered event. If you are looking to go out to enjoy some Mexican food-you can look pretty much anywhere else and be happier.  

I've tried this place a couple times over a year ago now, but doubt anything has changed. I disagree with the implication that chipotle or qdoba is inferior to this place. They are comparable, but I would rank chipotle significantly higher. So long as you don't think of this place as a mexican restaurant or receive the food for free, you might not be disappointed.

Come here to remind yourself just how good places like El Pastor and Taqueria Guadalajara are.

My friend and I swung by Phillip's for a quick bite while our plane made a stop in Charlotte (our gate was right next to the restaurant). It's pretty simple - sit down, place your order when a waiter comes around, and get your food pretty quickly. The only real complaint is that the food's a bit expensive (as all airport food is) and that they didn't have BBQ sauce when I requested it for the chicken tenders. Aside from that, the food was pretty much what'd you expect overall from this kind of joint. The tenders were pretty standard, served with honey mustard sauce. The seafood platter comes with fried shrimp, crab cakes, and some spring rolls. I felt better for not getting the bigger crab cakes when I had theirs - the crab meat was extremely nondescript, coated in fried breadcrumbs but with an indistinguishable taste aside from that. The spring rolls were okay, if unspectacular, and the fried shrimp was decent.\n\nYou're not going to get much service here - our waiter had to be flagged to give us our check - but it's an airport spot, so you can't really set expectations too high. I'd probably stop by if I wanted something other than standard fast food in the airport, but there's not much any other reason to come by here.

"The culinary offerings possessed a certain degree of palatability, with the avocado-based dip, in particular, eliciting a profoundly positive response from my taste buds. However, my companion and I experienced a notable lack of hospitable treatment at the hands of the service staff, who displayed an overt reluctance to accommodate our needs and accorded us a chilly, perfunctory demeanor throughout the duration of our visit. It is my conviction that such discourteous behavior on the part of servers is endemic to establishments situated within the precincts of Scottsdale, and I find myself increasingly disenchanted with the notion of patronizing dining establishments in this locality, owing to the consistent lack of warmth and welcome extended to me and my associates."

We have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, and each time, we have been impressed by the vast array of fresh salads and vegetables available for our perusal. Our significant other, being a vegetarian, has expressed great enthusiasm towards the diverse selection offered, praising the quality and freshness of the produce. However, we must admit that the prices charged for these delectable delights are somewhat prohibitive, especially when compared to other eateries in the vicinity.  

The service at this establishment has consistently been prompt and attentive, with the staff displaying a commendable level of professionalism in their interactions with patrons. Additionally, they offer complimentary cookies to guests, which has been a delightful surprise for our children. Unfortunately, we cannot say the same for the beverages offered, as the prices charged for fountain drinks are, in our opinion, exorbitant.  

Upon closer inspection, we have noticed an unpleasant odor emanating from the rear section of the restaurant, which has been described as akin to the scent of feet. While this may seem a minor inconvenience to some, it has been a source of discomfort for us.  

The pasta dishes served at this establishment have been found to be merely satisfactory, with some of the soups being quite palatable. A friend of ours once commented that the portion sizes served do not justify the cost, leading us to concur that the value proposition presented is not entirely convincing.  

Despite these shortcomings, the restaurant has consistently maintained a high level of popularity among locals and visitors alike. Perhaps the appeal lies in the ambiance or the convenience of the location, but we cannot help but feel that there are superior options available in the surrounding area, such as Sunset Station, which offers a more affordable and satisfying dining experience, including complimentary beverages.  

In conclusion, while this establishment has its merits, we cannot help but feel that there are areas where improvement could be made to enhance the overall dining experience for patrons.

"If you relish the prospect of being compressed by a multitude of perspiring individuals, with nary a sliver of space to execute a few dance moves, then this venue may be an ideal destination for you. However, I must caution that the proprietors of Tao appear to be remiss in their responsibility to regulate the influx of patrons, resulting in an overcrowded environment that I, personally, found overwhelming within a mere half hour. Furthermore, the caliber of clientele that we encountered was questionable, as exemplified by a certain obese, inebriated Mexican individual who inadvertently collapsed upon my significant other. In response, my girlfriend delivered a playful smack to the woman's posterior, which, unfortunately, did not sit well with her. The woman proceeded to charge at my girlfriend, aiming a wild swing in her direction before being restrained by her companions. Subsequently, I espied the same female attempting to showcase her dancing prowess onstage, only to be summarily ejected by the bouncer due to her suggestive movements. While Thursday evenings may potentially offer a more enjoyable experience, I must confess that my preference lies with Marquee and XS, clubs that I have heard excel in both ambiance and management of their patronage."

"It is utterly deplorable to experience the sensation of divulging the possession of a travel zoo to one's server and subsequently awaiting their reaction, as it can range from benevolent acceptance to utter disdain, as we unfortunately discovered. The couple situated behind my spouse received exceptional service, indulging in a prix fixe meal complemented by a wine pairing, which was quite fortunate for them. In contrast, the cocktails we ordered, not being part of the travel zoo package, were inadequately filled, while the beverages accompanying the voucher had an unpleasant taste akin to seawater. Our bar bill amounted to $100, thus we invariably paid considerably more than the value of our coupon. My spouse relished the seafood pot and salmon, finding them to his satisfaction. I opted for the beef carpaccio and chicken, accompanied by a side dish, yet unfortunately, my poultry and the minuscule side dish accompanying it were overcooked. Additionally, we were presented with a questionable squash soup, intended to serve as a palate cleanser, and a fish-based spread, both of which left much to be desired. It is lamentable that the quality of service did not parallel that of their sister restaurant, Andres, which set a higher standard. The panoramic views were aesthetically pleasing, yet the sole redeeming feature proved to be the crÃ¨me brÃ»lÃ©e, which was truly delightful. Unfortunately, this solitary aspect was insufficient to warrant a future visit. We felt grateful that we did not disclose our possession of the travel zoo to the host, as that would have led to an even more unpleasant experience, perhaps even being seated facing a wall. If establishments do not wish to accommodate customers utilizing coupon vouchers, a simple solution would be to refrain from offering them altogether."

"My experiences at this establishment have been varied, with multiple visits yielding inconsistent results. While the quality of the food and beverages has generally met my expectations, the service has been subpar on occasion, particularly during my most recent visit. Specifically, I have encountered issues with inadequate training and poor communication among staff members, which have led to errors in fulfilling orders and an inefficient customer experience. For instance, during my last visit, I placed an order for guacamole and chips, a barbacoa bowl, and a carnitas quesadilla, but I only received the guacamole without any chips and a barbacoa bowl. Moreover, there was a prolonged period of inactivity in the serving line, lasting approximately 10 minutes, during which only two employees were present and appeared to be struggling to manage the workload effectively. In light of these concerns, I would recommend that management consider implementing more comprehensive training programs and performance evaluations to ensure that customers receive the level of service they expect."

"My frequent patronage of this establishment can be attributed to its proximity to my domicile, as it is situated within a convenient distance, thereby facilitating my shopping excursions. Generally, the store maintains an adequate inventory of the products I require, thus obviating the necessity for me to visit alternative retailers. However, I must lament the dearth of customer service that characterizes this particular store, as it is glaringly deficient in providing assistance to customers on the sales floor. While I am capable of independently locating and selecting the items I need, I cannot help but feel a sense of dismay when I encounter an absence of staff members who could potentially offer aid, rendering the experience somewhat less than satisfactory. Furthermore, upon arriving at the checkout counter, I have noticed that the employees are not particularly forthcoming in engaging in pleasantries, which, although not essential, would contribute significantly towards creating a more welcoming ambiance. A simple 'How are you?' or a query regarding my possession of an Ulta card would suffice in establishing a minimal level of cordiality. Needless to say, a expression of gratitude following my purchase would also be appreciated. Notwithstanding the aforementioned shortcomings, I shall persist in utilizing the services of this Ulta location, primarily due to its proximity to my residence. However, I shall endeavor to communicate my concerns regarding the quality of customer service to the management, with the hope that they will take appropriate measures to address these issues and enhance the overall shopping experience for patrons."

$3 for a bowl of rice!!! Yikes! Late night dining options at the Wynn were limited and led us to this place. We ordered bbq pork, bbq duck and two bowls of rice $45. OMG! Sam Woo bbq we could of eaten the same thing for like $15 and it would of tasted better. I don't mind paying for a good meal, but being over charged for mediocre food just makes me pout. The server was an automaton, no smile, no energy, no emotion. Sad, Wynn, Sad! I just wanted a tasty late night dinner but no go at Red 8.

Lost baggage and poor child wrangling. It's all about employee empowerment.

I have the patience of the Madonna - all right maybe more like the Material Girl - but I am pretty laid back. After my humbling experience in the wine industry, I've been much more appreciative of service industry related jobs. But when employees are not empowered to answer the most simple of questions, and we're checking in on machines with nobody around to handle luggage, well...it's a disaster waiting to happen. It's an unfortunate thing that is supposed to help in keeping costs down and help with efficiency - but there's been consistent problems with all of my US AIRWAYS flights.

Let's throw JFK airport into the mix to help maximize the disaster...we ended up in Orlando. Waiting for our luggage. Luckily our toddler was entertained with the luggage roundabout...because we waited through two flight arrivals to retrieve one bag. 

Family that met up with us for the 4th assured us US AIRWAYS used a really efficient delivery service...Apparently the lost luggage situation is pretty common.

Good thing the baby bug is a trooper when it comes to traveling - because Orlando trips tend to be family-heavy and the on-board US AIRWAYS staff consistently doesn't seem too thrilled to be dealing with even the well-behaved ones.

We were left feeling underwhelmed by our recent dining experience at this establishment, as our expectations were not met during our visit. Upon entering the premises at 6:45 p.m. on a Saturday evening, we anticipated a brief waiting period before being seated; however, the hostess was nowhere to be found, leaving us standing idly for an extended period. Furthermore, the abundance of vacant seating arrangements throughout the restaurant was striking, particularly given the presence of numerous patrons gathered around the television screens, captivated by the live sports broadcasts. Following a prolonged wait, our server finally appeared to take our order, and we began our meal with an appetizer of bruschetta, which, while flavorful, did not justify its cost of nearly $10 for a simple bread dish topped with tomatoes and dressing. Our daughter opted for the macaroni and cheese dish from the children's menu, which, much to our disappointment, turned out to be a pre-packaged, microwaved variety rather than the authentic, homemade version we had been led to expect. Despite this, her hunger prompted her to consume the dish nonetheless. My wife selected the lasagna entrÃ©e, which she found satisfying, albeit overpriced at $12. I opted for the Tuscan Panini, which proved to be the highlight of our meal, boasting an impressive taste and presentation. However, taking into account the considerable number of unoccupied tables on a typically busy Saturday night, it appears that this eatery may need to reassess certain aspects of its operations to ensure its continued success. Thus, we are unlikely to return and would advise management to consider implementing changes to enhance the overall dining experience for their patrons.

"Our expectations for an improved outcome prompted us to revisit this carwash for a second time, only to be met with an overwhelming number of vehicles and an inadequate staff-to-car ratio. Despite opting for their comprehensive package, which encompasses both exterior and interior detailing, the latter was conspicuously neglected, with the dashboard area remaining entirely untouched. It became apparent that the employee responsible for the oversight was either inattentive or excessively hasty, leading us to question the quality of service provided. Consequently, we are unlikely to return for a third attempt."

"My sentiments regarding this establishment are rather tepid, as my expectations were not entirely fulfilled during my visit. While the ambiance is undoubtedly pleasant, with an interior design that exudes a certain je ne sais quoi, and a location that is conveniently situated, the culinary offerings left me feeling somewhat uninspired. My order consisted of the squid salad, which was merely adequate; the sake nigiri, wherein the salmon was not particularly fresh and the rice overpowered the delicate flavor of the fish; and the spicy tuna roll, which suffered from an absence of freshness in the tuna and a dearth of discernible flavor. To cap off my dining experience, I requested a serving of nigori sake, only to be met with confusion on the part of our server, who seemed unfamiliar with the beverage and informed me that the restaurant only offers warm sake. This encounter served to further reinforce my impression that the establishment does not quite live up to its reputation as a purveyor of authentic Japanese cuisine."

"As we had been provided with complimentary admission due to our lodging at the Treasure Island resort, we decided to take advantage of the offer and experience the ambiance of their nightclub. Upon arriving, we were met with an eerily vacant atmosphere, which was further accentuated by the melodic strains of trance music that seemed to induce a state of somnolence in me. Despite the promise of complimentary beverages, specifically a concoction referred to as 'Lemon Drops,' which bore a striking resemblance to a mixture of lemonade and water, we harbored doubts regarding the potential improvement in the club's prospects. Thus, we elected to depart and reserve judgment until a later time, as the club offered an 'in and out' policy. Unfortunately, we failed to return, leaving us to ponder whether the venue had experienced an upswing in popularity. Notwithstanding, the outdoor area boasted a breathtaking panorama of the Las Vegas Strip and the adjacent artificial lake, rendering it an aesthetically pleasing establishment."

I went here after a late flight from Denver, as it was the only restaurant at our hotel that was really open, and we did not want snacky food. Let's just say the food was definitely lacking. I ordered a burger and it pretty much tasted like a hockey puck it was so burnt. Maybe try it Medium instead of Medium well next time? Scratch that I probably wont be going back next time I am in Phoenix, The service was OK but I have experienced better. I would not recommend this place, but if it is the absolute only place and someone else was paying I would not pass it up.

Meh... That's about how I felt leaving SMG the other night. They were offering a Groupon for a $5 movie ($3 surcharge for 3D glasses). That was enough to get us in the doors. There aren't that many showtimes offered. 

The screen was really small and the lighting from the stairs really threw off the movie viewing experience. I appreciate that they do the reserved seating thing but it was difficult to get four seats together without splitting rows. We ended up in the back row. 

The service was noticeably slow. The waitress had a habit of just standing in the rows blocking the screen. That got really annoying... 

A few notes: The ticket counter is on the 2nd floor. Stop there first before heading up to the theaters. Don't forget your parking ticket, they validate. SMG is definitely not my first choice but I would return in a pinch.

"The gastronomical experience afforded by this establishment's cheesecake is satisfactory, and the demeanor of the waiting staff is generally congenial. However, the culinary offerings, with the exception of the aforementioned cheesecake, fall short of expectations. Following a series of unremarkable encounters with various entrees and hors d'oeuvres, a strong recommendation to avoid the nachos is warranted. Notwithstanding, the venue remains a suitable destination for nocturnal indulgence in sweet treats."

This particular venue does not possess an exceptional quality, and my perception of its mediocrity may be attributed to my premature arrival. It failed to convey the ambiance conducive to revelry or leisurely indulgence. Notwithstanding, it exhibited a certain aesthetic reminiscent of Ireland. Nonetheless, I am disinclined to revisit the establishment.

"An expansive eatery situated within the New York New York Casino, boasting an extensive menu catering to diverse tastes and offering the option of al fresco dining amidst the artificial cityscape of the casino's interior, which we opted for, affording us the opportunity to observe the passing crowd while indulging in our culinary desires. However, our initial impression was slightly marred by the overly saccharine margaritas, served in unremarkable plastic vessels rather than the customary glassware, yet the establishment compensated for this shortcoming with copious servings of crispy tortilla chips and a flavorful, homemade salsa, further complemented by the preparation of fresh guacamole at our table, a delightful touch that partially assuaged our disappointment. Ultimately, my dinner selection, a beef burrito, though satisfactory, failed to surpass my expectations, leaving me with a lingering sense of culinary dissatisfaction."

"Ambiance aside, the culinary experience offered at this establishment may potentially be the most unconventional and chaotic in all of Scottsdale. For those who relish the notion of dining in an environment akin to a cramped, antiquated dive bar, where patrons are seated in close proximity to one another, effectively creating the ambiance of a makeshift family gathering, this restaurant may prove to be the ideal setting. Furthermore, the presence of intoxicated youths from the adjacent skate park and burly individuals who appear to have spent a considerable amount of time incarcerated only serves to enhance the eclectic nature of the establishment. The bartender, whose reputation precedes him in various online forums, is seemingly a character straight out of a popular television drama centered around illicit substances, boasting an unparalleled ability to converse at high volumes and lengths, making him the undisputed star of the show. Despite these unorthodox characteristics, the food served is reportedly of satisfactory quality, with generous portions that somewhat compensate for the dearth of refinement and sophistication that permeates the dining area. Those who choose to accept this gastronomical challenge are advised to brace themselves for a truly singular experience."

Service was exceptionally poor. 

Went here for a late lunch and we were the only couple in the restaurant. The waitstaff neglected us for 20minutes. 

The food came out 30 minutes after we ordered and was awful! The pasta I ordered had dried out from sitting for so long.

Avoid this restaurant on your next visit to lake Las Vegas.

"It is Chili's, implying a rating of three stars, however, in this particular instance, it is diminutive in stature and characterized by sluggish service; thus, it is preferable to queue at Burgatory, where the waiting period is likely to be more brief."

Not so much for me . Last years participants was not impressive. I would rather spend more money and go to one of the bigger events like devoured , feast on the streets , or taste of biltmore. My friends that go like it because its family friendly so i can see that point of view , it is family friendly and a nice way to kick off the summer.

"Upon perusing numerous laudatory assessments of this establishment, my expectations were elevated to sample the culinary offerings personally. Opting for the Pat's Pounder Platter, which included pulled pork, beef brisket, and a supplementary rib portion for an additional $3.99, alongside collard greens and hush puppies, totaled approximately $23.00, a somewhat steep tariff, yet I remained optimistic regarding the gastronomic experience. My evaluation of the individual components follows: Pulled pork - regrettably arid and occasionally granular in texture, prompting me to reconsider my order had I known how uninspiring it would be; Brisket - fairly satisfying, albeit slightly saline, yet still savory; RIBS - A profound disappointment, comprising mostly bony fragments and an alarming desiccation that nearly necessitated dental reconstruction, leaving a sour impression considering the supplemental cost of $4; Hush puppies - mediocre, failing to elicit any extraordinary enthusiasm; Greens - underwhelming and lackluster, devoid of sufficient seasoning, which, ironically, might have been remedied by a generous application of sodium chloride, thereby enhancing their flavor."

We engaged in a culinary excursion with a coterie of ten individuals, inclusive of two diminutive juveniles, for an initial repast at 530 pm on a Thursday. Already, the venue was teeming with patrons, creating an atmosphere of conviviality and vibrancy. Our server, though affable and hospitable, required an excessive duration of 25 minutes to present us with our inaugural round of all-you-can-eat selections. The comestibles, while palatable, did not possess an exceptional quality, and their prices were neither remarkably economical nor extravagant. However, certain aspects of the edifice proved problematic, specifically, the cramped and congested floor plan, which necessitated a traversal of a waiting area adjacent to the kitchen, thereby increasing the likelihood of collision with servers, and the inadequate accessibility of lavatories. Furthermore, the musical accompaniment, characterized by decibel levels akin to those of a nocturnal entertainment establishment, contributed to an environment that was not especially conducive to relaxation or enjoyment. Consequently, the collective sentiment of our group was that a return visit would be unlikely, as the ambiance was not particularly welcoming, and the sushi offerings did not justify the cost.

I recommend spending the extra money at the Bacchanal buffet in Caesars Palace! The first time I went to this buffet 12 years ago I loved it, but we recently were staying at the Mandalay Bay for a night and wanted to just dine in the area. It costed a little over $30/adult and $20 for my 5 year old. The food selection was not as much as what I remember it to be and it just seemed over priced. The quality was good, just disappointed on the lack of selections and having to wait for certain food items. I would not go back just because there are so many other places to choose from in Vegas. I would also rather pay $50/person at the bigger resort/casinos for a better selection of food/seafood.

"Subsequent to posting a favorable assessment, I have since rescinded it due to unforeseen circumstances transpiring during my visit to The Brake Shop, whereupon I requested a routine inspection of my brakes, in conjunction with an oil change and tire rotation. Following the draining of the oil, the personnel encountered an unexpected dilemma regarding the procurement of a compatible oil filter, which ultimately precluded them from completing the task. Consequently, they opted to replenish the oil and replace the filter, albeit inadequately, as evidenced by the subsequent events that transpired. Specifically, when I visited Jiffy Lube the succeeding day, the attendant refused to provide assistance, citing the presence of oil dispersed throughout the engine compartment. This prompted me to seek immediate attention at the closest Audi dealership, whereupon the technicians determined that either the oil filter had been installed incorrectly or an inappropriate substitute had been employed, thereby potentially jeopardizing the integrity of my relatively new vehicle. In light of these circumstances, I have reassessed my original evaluation, deducting three stars for the subpar performance exhibited by the garage staff, while maintaining a modicum of gratitude for the store manager's hospitable demeanor and refreshing lack of sales pressure."

Went here once for your curiosity and once because I was dragged here. Fat burger is mediocre at best. Its overpriced and takes wayyyy too long to get your food. In N out kills this place and is almost have the price. I would rather go to burger king or carls jr and those places are shit.

"The atmosphere was thoroughly enjoyed, as was the melodic background tune that allowed for effortless communication between our party of five females, who were indulging in the establishment's Monday night complimentary dinner and beverage offering, with a recommended gratuity of $15 to $20 per person, an undoubtedly advantageous arrangement. Unfortunately, the culinary offerings failed to meet expectations, with the majority of dishes, specifically the miniature beef burgers and salmon fillets, being only partially cooked. It appeared that the kitchen staff had been hasty in their preparation, leading us to question the quality of a full-price meal at this venue. Thus, we would not consider returning as paying patrons."

"The culinary offerings were adequate, but the quality of the service was subpar. Upon entering the establishment, my companion and I were disregarded by two female staff members stationed at the counter for an extended period, despite their assurance that they would attend to us momentarily. We ultimately opted to seat ourselves, and endured an approximate 15-minute wait before a server approached us to inquire whether we intended to consume our meal on the premises. The service continued to be lacking throughout the duration of our visit, with the server displaying an evident lack of interest in our needs and requirements. The food, while palatable, did not compensate for the unsatisfactory experience we encountered. I do not intend to patronize this establishment again in the future."

"Our conjugal sojourn at this establishment has thus far transpired over a duration of two days, with an additional pair of diurnal cycles remaining before our anticipated departure. The accommodations we have been assigned boast a minuscule square footage, featuring a diminutive sleeping apparatus, a miniature bathing facility, and a microscopic showerhead that unfortunately exhibits a propensity for malfunctioning. Furthermore, the machine designed to dispense frozen water particles has proven inoperative, and the morning repast served by the hotel's culinary staff has failed to impress. Notwithstanding these deficiencies, the strength of the wireless internet signal throughout the building leaves much to be desired. However, we have been recipients of hospitable treatment at the hands of the lodging's employees, thereby warranting a rating of two stars in my estimation."

"What an unfortunate state of affairs! If one desires to procure a reasonable deal, a meticulous examination is imperative due to the utter disarray that permeates this establishment. Even the likes of Big Lots appear comparatively well-organized. Regrettably, it does not justify the investment of my time."

"I have been an ardent devotee of Costco for over a decade and a half, and I must say that my unwavering loyalty has been rewarded with a plethora of benefits. However, I would like to caution fellow patrons against a potential oversight when it comes to their pharmaceutical needs. It has come to my attention that there have been instances wherein prescriptions have been inadvertently shorted, resulting in a deficiency of medication. This phenomenon has transpired on three separate occasions since May of 2014, with the most recent instance occurring just moments ago. Upon retrieving my latest prescription, I discovered that it too was lacking in quantity. Needless to say, I shall be returning forthwith to ensure that the appropriate number of tablets are dispensed."

I had the privilege of partaking in a celebratory dinner at this establishment on a Thursday evening, in honor of a close acquaintance's birthday. As an ardent devotee of Asian cuisine, my expectations were elevated, particularly in light of the acclaim that Pittsburgh's latest restaurants have garnered (especially upon my return to the city). Unfortunately, my culinary experience fell short of my expectations, with both the food and service leaving much to be desired. The dishes we sampled lacked a profound Asian influence, with the skate cheeks, situated atop minuscule pieces of white toast, being rather unremarkable. The fried Brussels sprouts proved to be the standout dish, albeit it paled in comparison to other eateries specializing in meat and potatoes. Avoid the desserts at all costs, as both options featured a vanilla custard base, with one variety topped with Fruity Pebbles in a feeble attempt at cuteness, but ultimately underwhelming.

Moreover, our server appeared to be somewhat inexperienced and self-conscious, neglecting to introduce herself and solicit our order, leaving us to take the initiative in placing our order and seeking recommendations. It is my sincere hope that future menus will incorporate more authentic Chinese and/or Southeast Asian flavors Ã  la Red Farm in NYC, as the current offerings seem contrived and miss the mark.

I am compelled to confer a paltry duo of celestial bodies upon the Luxor, for the reason that I possess an abundance of fond reminiscences pertaining to my sojourns at this establishment during the course of several years. The Pyramid Cafe serves as a welcoming haven where one can indulge in a steaming bowl of soup and momentarily respite their fatigued pedal extremities subsequent to traversing the Luxor from Bellagio by foot.

The omnipotent authorities responsible for the metamorphosis of Luxor have, in my opinion, irrevocably marred its former splendor, and such an assertion is uttered with utmost sincerity. The Egyptian theme, being an integral component of the edifice's erstwhile allure, has been callously expunged, leaving behind a regrettable and aesthetically displeasing ambiance. In light of the aforementioned alterations implemented at Luxor, in conjunction with its relatively remote location along the Las Vegas Strip, relative to other points of interest, I fear that I shall refrain from partaking in any further financial transactions or investing additional periods of time within the confines of this hotel while visiting Sin City.

"Observations: My assessment of Vietnamese eateries revolves around four fundamental aspects: pho, spring rolls, peanut dipping sauce, and avocado shakes. Unfortunately, Vietnam Grille failed to impress me on multiple levels. Given its reputation as a renowned Vietnamese establishment, my expectations were not adequately met. The spring rolls lacked generosity in size, and while the ingredients were undoubtedly fresh, a certain je ne sais quoi was absent. The peanut sauce was excessively sweet and did not boast a robust peanut flavor. Moreover, the pho was problematically overspiced, resulting in an overwhelming aroma that overpowered the broth, with the star anise exerting an intense influence. The pieces of flank steak did not compare to the delicate, paper-thin slices typically encountered at other Vietnamese restaurants. Instead, the tendon was undercooked, leading to an unpleasant chewiness. Notably, the absence of an avocado smoothie from the menu was glaring. It is worth mentioning that, generally, Vietnamese cuisine is distinguished by its affordability, with a copious amount of food offered for a reasonable price. However, the prices at Vietnam Grille seemed slightly elevated compared to what I am accustomed to.

On a positive note, the service was satisfactory, and parking was abundant. In conclusion, my pursuit of a preferred Vietnamese eatery in Charlotte will continue."

It Seems that Eliseevsky is under new management, While the experience was not bad it does not come anywhere near the previous reviews. First off gone are the Horseradish  / cranberry flavored vodka shots. When I went Eliseevsky no longer had a license to server alcohol. 

Secondly the menu has been reduced by a fair amount. The menu on the website (which has not as of this posting been updated) speaks of caviar, veal, beef in sweet & sour sauce, Shashlik" (kebab) and many more all of which no longer exists. 
 I had the chicken Kiev  (butter filled); also sampled the borscht and my friend said the pork soup was good. The food was still good but none of it knocked me off my feet. 

The atmosphere seems to have remained largely unchanged. Still looks like a log cabin, modern Russian music plays in the background. Our server also performed a selection of Russian titles (not sure if he was lip syncing or not).  The service was a bit slow even with the restaurant being mostly empty. But I attribute that to a loss of the art of dining on my part.  I will probably go back and try another dish or two but buyer beware the price remains at about 12 -16 a dish. I believe this to be a bit steep for what you are getting.

Punked!
In a sentence, horrendous value for money.
We chose this place expecting a fine dining experience complete with great food and service. Unfortunately both failed and especially the service.
We had specified to our waiter immediately that we had an hour and a half before we had to leave to attend a show and he assured us we'd have plenty of time to enjoy our meal at a quiet and relaxed pace.
One hour and 10 minutes later our steaks arrive even though the 2 parties next  to us arrived later and had already been served all 3 courses of their meals. What's going on?
Call it favouritism, poor planning or whatever, we had to engulf our meals in 10 minutes before rushing off to our show only to be late. Not only that, the waiter forgot to include the mushrooms I ordered, had them made quickly and then added them to our bill...so considerate of him. Where's the common sense in customer service? At least give me the mushrooms for free!
I wish I could say the food was superb but it was average at best;  I've had better steaks  at 1/10 the cost, no joke.
Bottom line: if you're looking for a premium dining experience, think twice before choosing Delmonico.

"A remarkably pleasant domicile situated within a highly desirable neighborhood, yet unfortunately, the cost of residency proves to be quite prohibitive. Furthermore, the property manager, Nancy, exhibits a striking aversion towards youthful inhabitants, as evidenced by her excessively stringent regulations imposed upon children during the summer months, effectively precluding them from venturing outside unaccompanied by an adult at any time. Additionally, Nancy has seen fit to dispatch a memorandum explicitly forbidding the presence of bicycles within the courtyards, which, ironically, had been a significant factor in my initial decision to reside here, given its quaint atmosphere and the availability of a courtyard suitable for children to engage in recreational activities. Moreover, Nancy's extreme fixation on exerting authority and her apparent distaste for young residents have led her to assume the role of an overbearing authoritarian, as exemplified by her unwarranted intervention in my household affairs, questioning the suitability of a mother allowing her 10-year-old child to dispose of trash, and deeming it inappropriate for residents of Altessa. Furthermore, Nancy has chosen to augment her already restrictive measures by installing a chain lock on the pool during summer evenings after 9 pm, effectively transforming the community into a veritable senior citizens' enclave, much to my dismay, as I had previously believed it to be a family-friendly environment. Were it not for Nancy's draconian management style and the exorbitant rent, I would have remained a resident, as it remains a superior choice for apartment living."

I have been conducting an exhaustive quest for a proficient nail salon for an extended period of time, and unfortunately, this establishment does not meet my expectations. I adhere to a consistent schedule of obtaining gel manicures every two weeks, and as such, I have had the opportunity to sample a diverse array of salons. My personal preference is to avoid the utilization of acetone in the process of removing old gel polish, as it has a deleterious impact on the health of my nails. Furthermore, I am perplexed by the application of a half-cut lime being rubbed on my nails, as its purpose remains unclear to me. Additionally, upon requesting a minor trim, the attendant erroneously misinterpreted my instructions and cut my nails excessively short. Consequently, I shall not be returning to this salon, and my pursuit of a suitable nail salon continues unabated.

Had lunch here before attending the Dec. Yelp Hours at Cartel down the street.  $6.95 Green curry w/ chicken called my name.  It's a good thing the server took my order before I had a chance to wait much longer- the noise level was driving me up the walls!  Sure, it was during lunch, but I've been here during dinner, too, and even though there were only four or five tables going at that time, the noise level was high.

Veggie soup with tofu came in a small bowl.  Lightly-salted, fresh-tasting, perfect to get the juices flowing.  Soon after, a plate with jasmine rice, an oval bowl of green curry, and a small eggroll arrived.  Took a bite of eggroll and was disappointed to see * in the mix.  This is the first time I've seen * in eggrolls served in a Thai restaurant... Thai coworkers tell me that's not the norm.  (Another inauthentic dish served here is their pad woon sen- silver-bean noodles with veggies, tofu/chicken, and egg.  TB serves it dripping with sauce when it should be on the dry side.)

Curry sauce was good, but looked too watery and not silky enough.  Medium-spiced, perfectly light.  However, the noise level, soggy pad woon sen, and eggrolls with * will keep me away.

"My recent dining experience at Firehouse Subs was utterly unremarkable, as the Hot House Hero sandwich I ordered lacked any semblance of culinary finesse, with its uninspired combination of hot roast beef, turkey, and ham failing to tantalize my taste buds in the slightest. This underwhelming encounter marked my maiden visit to the establishment, and unfortunately, it did not leave an auspicious impression. Upon inspecting the sandwich, I observed that the meager portion of meat was haphazardly piled in the center, necessitating my intervention to redistribute it evenly throughout the bread. This proved to be a futile endeavor, as the scant amount of filling could barely cover the surface of the bun, rendering the entire exercise rather pointless. Furthermore, my request for a white bread option was ignored, replaced instead with an unsavory wheat bread that only served to exacerbate my disappointment. When I brought this to the attention of the staff, their response was utterly lacking in contrition or concern, and I was forced to wait an unacceptable duration while they attended to the orders of other patrons before my own was addressed. Suffice it to say, I shall not be returning to Firehouse Subs in the future, as the combination of mediocre cuisine, poor customer service, and egregious pricing has left an indelible stain on my dining experience."

It's ok, good for a quick bite. I don't understand the almost cult like following.\nMade a mistake and had the shake instead of pop and was sick for hours.\nStaff was very friendly, but they needed someone dedicated to keeping the place clean.

"It is perplexing to ponder whether my bartender is expected to exhibit a higher level of intoxication than myself, as I believed there were certain regulations governing such matters. Furthermore, this establishment, formerly known as Nick's Fat City, has undergone a transformation, adopting an opulent facade that belies its previous identity. While the ambiance may not be unpleasant, the overcrowding can become oppressive, rendering the experience of consuming beverages nigh impossible due to the distance between the bar and oneself, not to mention the unsettling sensation of being enveloped by the perspiration of one's fellow patrons. On a previous visit, I managed to ascend to the upper level, where, unfortunately, the bartender's state of inebriation appeared to impair his ability to provide adequate service, leading me to question the quality of the establishment's staff. Despite these drawbacks, the acoustics are satisfactory, the spatial layout is acceptable, and it is gratifying to have concert venues in the vicinity; however, the performance of the bartenders leaves much to be desired, and security personnel seemed to struggle in controlling the throngs of people."

"An atmospheric ambiance permeates this edifice, enhanced by an expansive outdoor seating area that invites patrons to linger and luxuriate in their surroundings. However, our experience was marred by a server (a stout African American woman) whose behavior was unprofessional and inappropriate. While the cost of certain dishes may be considered prohibitive by some, the flank steak proved to be a culinary masterpiece. Unfortunately, the pizza and nachos failed to impress, offering little in the way of gastronomic innovation or creativity. Moreover, our evening was tarnished further when my girlfriend witnessed a second server (a slender African American woman) engage in unsanitary practices in the restroom, including using the facilities without proper hand hygiene. This reprehensible conduct occurred mere moments before our departure."

"I was taken aback by the arduous process of returning a mere $28 worth of facewash and toner that had caused my skin to breakout, as the sales associate was adamant about emphasizing the significance of adhering to the store's stringent return policy. It is widely acknowledged that a facial routine should be given a reasonable amount of time to take effect, typically spanning a period of two weeks; however, the sales associate seemed to be under the impression that I had only utilized a minuscule portion of the product, thereby rendering it ineligible for return. Upon closer inspection of the receipt, I failed to discern any explicit stipulations pertaining to the limited usage of the product prior to return."

The only reason I came here was because the TI provided us with a 2 for 1 coupon. The food was over cooked and greasy, and some just tasted funny. The desserts were the only things that we ok, not horrible but not great either. Very disappointing!

I haven't been back to a Chili's in a long time and when we were given a gift card after moving to Pittsburgh we decided to use it. Their service was really nice, but their food was lacking. My husband and I shared their fajitas for 2 and were given the wrong kind of protein, we asked for pork, chicken, and beef. We were given shrimp instead of chicken so they replaced it with the chicken. The waitress let us have the shrimp, but decided to not eat them since they seemed a little under cooked. Also when our sides to the fajitas were served we noted that the beans were cold, and had to flag down the waitress to heat them up. 

I will say that their pork was really good as well as their beef, their guacamole was tasty but could use more lime. 

The ambiance was nice and the place was clean. But overall despite the friendly service, we were not very impressed with their food.

Wow this place has crazy prices for a sandwich come on get real I don't understand what justifies paying so much for a soup or a sandwich and the portions are extremely small do yourself a favor and pass unless you have money to blow

"My prolonged abstinence from consuming dim sum culminated in an unwavering yearning for this delectable cuisine, prompting my spouse and me to visit this establishment on a Sunday prior to noon, with no reservation. Upon entering, I was immediately struck by the welcoming ambiance of the restaurant's well-appointed, expansive, and unified space, which refreshingly diverged from the cramped, obscure nature of many other eateries specializing in this genre of fare. However, my initial optimism was swiftly replaced by disillusionment upon sampling the menu offerings. The edibles were, for the most part, underwhelming and failed to satiate my gastronomical expectations. Specifically, the beef spare ribs were exceedingly greasy, fatty, rubbery, and bony, leaving an unpleasant, lingering aftertaste throughout the day. My shrimp wontons were also unimpressive, lacking the desired temperature and arriving in a state of refrigeration. Additionally, the chow fun was characterized by brevity and aridity, deviating from my preferred texture. Notably, the sole dishes that escaped my censorious scrutiny were the shu mai and the shrimp flat rice noodle, which provided a modicum of gastronomic satisfaction. Apart from these relatively palatable options, the eatery's embellishments, such as the absence of a waiting list, the hospitable service (despite my non-Chinese ethnicity), and the attentive demeanor of both the dim sum attendants and our server, contributed to a positive experience. Our total cost, inclusive of gratuity, amounted to $38 for two individuals."

We went on a Friday night as packed as it looked we actually went right in and got a table. The waitress was good and always on point with service. 

As for the food I ordered the Jack Daniels ribs and shrimp. The shrimp were really good. As for the ribs they showed you shouldn't order ribs unless its a BBQ place. They were suppose to be baby backs but they were dry. Some parts of it were pretty good but a majority of it left your mouth dry wanting water. My wife ordered the steak, sadly a majority of that 10oz consisted of nothing but fat. 

To top it off there was a huge party they sat next to us that ended up getting drunk off their ass. They were so damn loud and obnoxious you couldn't hear your own self think. I don't mind people being loud but c'mon you don't go to a restaurant and get blitzed. But from the way it seemed the manager and servers acted like its an everyday thing so what do I know I was just eating there. 

Eating there made me realize why I never actually go eat there. Nor do I really plan on going anytime soon

Not my first time here but for sure it's going to be my last. So much for the \"best\" package because it was the worse. Nothing was wiped down. Dust was still sitting on my dash board. Windows were horrible. Back seats and truck wasn't even touched. The side of my doors were all foot prints. I had to ask them to wipe this wipe that and I still brought it home and re did it myself. Probably the only okay thing they did was my tires. A so called \"shine\". Won't be back and won't recommend it to anyone

With so many rave reviews, you would think this place would be great outside of the 11pm-4am hammered crowd timeframe, but not so much.

Although getting a seat is much easier, this place is not really recommended for just a regular dinner.  Maybe it's because I'm not the biggest "squeaky curds" fan, but no one at the table seemed to be blown away by the various assemblies of fries, gravy and cheese.

I have had other poutines that would knock your socks off drunk, sober, or anytime of the day, but this would not be worth it unless you're drunk enough to wait forever in a line to inhale something that will make your hangover a little less painful.

My nephew who resides in Madison has an unwavering fondness for this establishment, hence we frequent it, yet I must confess that aside from the outdoor seating, I fail to comprehend its allure. The flavor options are remarkably lackluster, with the customary chocolate and vanilla being offered daily, accompanied by a rotating "guest" flavor (on Monday, it happened to be Espresso); furthermore, the staff members appear to be unfriendly and unwelcoming, with their proficiency in the English language being limited. Moreover, I am uncertain about the nature of the ingredients utilized in their products, and I harbor doubts about the authenticity of my raspberry shake, given its absence of seeds (typically a reliable indicator of naturalness) and its slightly synthetic taste. Concerns regarding the hormone-free status of their milk also linger. Despite these reservations, the venue boasts a charming ambiance that appeals to patrons of diverse age groups, and during our latest visit, we became acquainted with K-9 Custard, a canine treat that our furry companion relished thoroughly (priced at $2.75, ensure your pet's hunger before purchasing!). In conclusion, while I would like to award more stars, I must candidly express my disappointment with the underwhelming experience provided by this custard stand in comparison to my previous encounters with richer, more fascinating ice cream and gelato.

Perhaps I expect too much out of a diner. 

They put us in a room that was about 90 degrees. The waitress seemed more fit to be a bartender at the Rouge West than a waitress at a Diner. 

The food was ok, kind of bland and tasteless. I much prefer My Mothers Restaurant for this type of food. 

On the plus side a dude in a bear suit scared the living hell out of a small child, so the trip wasn't a total loss.

"Upon relocating to MTL, we encountered an unanticipated culinary dilemma: my companion had yet to indulge in a quintessential smoked meat sandwich. Our gastronomic quest led us to a nearby Dunns establishment, which, fortuitously, had been endorsed by my roommates who had relished a delectable dining experience at said venue. Thus, I opted to introduce TJ to the local delicacy, albeit with mixed results. Our shared platter, comprising a medium-sized smoked meat sandwich, fries, coleslaw, and a pickle, presented several positives, including copious sustenance for two individuals, commendable fries, and a flavorful pickle. However, certain drawbacks, such as an elevated price point (approximately $15 for a single serving) and underwhelming smoked meat (dry, salty, and excessively processed), tempered our enthusiasm. Ultimately, the dining experience was merely satisfactory, making it challenging to persuade my companion to venture forth and sample smoked meat once more."

"We relished the picturesque climate while seated on the outdoor patio of the Wynn, yet our experience was significantly marred by the abysmal quality of service. The phrase 'I'll be right back' was seemingly lost in translation, with a 15-minute delay being the standard interval before our server would return. Moreover, the assertion 'your order will be right out' was tantamount to an unfortunate prognostication, as it took a staggering 35 minutes for our culinary selections to arrive. Unfortunately, the fare did not live up to expectations, with my omelette being merely passable, the hashbrowns bordering on inedibility, and the french toast possessing an acrid flavor reminiscent of burnt offerings. However, the black angus burger proved to be a delectable exception to this trend, prompting me to regret my initial decision to order otherwise. Those who value their time would be well-advised to avoid this establishment, and instead opt for al fresco dining when the meteorological conditions are favorable, as the ambiance may then serve to mitigate the unsatisfactory service and middling gastronomical offerings."

Wynn, you have got to be absolutely, positively, unequivocally kidding me! I am well aware that you provide your employees with fare significantly superior to this in the cafeteria; thus, it is utterly unacceptable that the majority of the dishes served during my recent visit were of a quality that could, at best, be described as 'perfunctory.' Furthermore, I find it nothing short of egregious that you would have the audacity to charge a whopping forty dollars for a breakfast that did not even include lox with the bagels! I must say, I am thoroughly disillusioned and shall never again darken the doors of your establishment.  

The only redeeming feature of the culinary offerings was the desserts, which, while undoubtedly delectable, hardly justified the exorbitant prices charged for the rest of the meal. The sushi, I must say, was akin to something one might find at a roadside convenience store - utterly unfit for human consumption, in other words. Needless to say, I strongly advise anyone considering dining at your establishment to first confirm whether or not breakfast is indeed being served, lest they fall prey to the same trap I did and end up paying an exorbitant sum for a few paltry pancakes and slices of bacon. The wait, I must add, was utterly interminable - a full hour and thirty minutes for food that was, at best, mediocre. In conclusion, I must say that I shall never again set foot in your restaurant, and I strongly advise others to follow suit.

Perhaps our expectations were excessively elevated, or possibly we merely failed to perceive the ostensible appeal, but the generally acclaimed and ardently cherished Honey Salt did not quite live up to its prodigious reputation, at least in our experience. Following an amicable encounter with the accommodating bartender during lunch, we embarked upon a gastronomical excursion that unfortunately proved somewhat disappointing. Specifically, the initial offering of calamari was characterized by an unfortunate rubberiness and an unpleasant greasiness that bordered on the inedible, thereby establishing a less-than-auspicious beginning. Subsequently, we opted to share the renowned Biloxi chicken sandwich, which, regrettably, exhibited a notable lack of moisture and a certain blandness, coupled with the My Wife's Favorite Salad (featuring duck confit), an uninspired assemblage that neglected to impress. Furthermore, the Caesar salad, adorned with an unpalatable abundance of kale, tragically fell short of our expectations, its flavor profile reduced to a barely perceptible hint of saltiness derived from the minute shreds of overcooked, previously prepared fried egg situated atop the bed of wilted lettuce. Fortunately, the attentive bartender, cognizant of the unappealing nature of the offending egg, graciously provided a fresh, properly cooked alternative, thus salvaging the dish from utter disaster. In conclusion, while no compelling reason exists to revisit this establishment solely for culinary purposes, the possibility of encountering Carrot Top at the bar may, for some, constitute a moderately enticing incentive.

"During my lunch break, I decided to visit this establishment to sample their bento boxes, which, upon initial inspection, appeared to offer a diverse array of nutritious options such as brown rice, garlic noodles, diced salmon, and diced filet mignon. However, upon consumption, I was somewhat disenchanted by the lackluster flavors presented by the dishes, despite the abundance of sauces available for patrons to select from. Furthermore, the seasoning of the garlic on the noodles and the rub on the fish failed to elevate the taste to an appreciable degree. While the culinary experience was underwhelming, the staff were quite accommodating and the ambiance was relatively tranquil, with a clean dining area that reflected positively on the establishment's maintenance standards. For individuals seeking an unremarkable dining experience with the option to augment their meals with an assortment of sauces, this venue may be worth considering."

My significant other coerced me into visiting this establishment due to her ardent desire to indulge in unlimited portions of crustacean extremities. Upon arriving at 7 pm, we observed that the venue was teeming with patrons, yet we were seated in a timely manner. It is worth noting that payment is not required initially; however, beverages are supplementary. The buffet itself was rather diminutive and offered a limited selection of subpar Asian cuisine, including several platters of shrimp and fish, a few plates of sushi encased in plastic wrap, and a scant amount of crab legs. The dessert bar was a disappointment - consisting of generic cookies, stale cake, fruit, pudding, and soft-serve ice cream. During our hour-long stay, I made five excursions to the buffet, and not once did the staff replenish the offerings. The spare ribs appeared unappetizing, which garnered attention from the numerous clientele, resulting in minimal consumption. Conversely, the crab proved to be the crowd favorite, as everyone availed themselves of copious amounts. Personally, I am not partial to seafood. Others have bestowed favorable reviews upon this restaurant, primarily citing its affordability as the sole advantage. While the fare may not be particularly impressive, an unrestricted supply of ice cream is available. For visual reference, please peruse the images located at the following URL: <http://www.usmenuguide.com/krazybuffetmenupics.html>

They transport you from seat to seat as you undergo various treatments, deftly orchestrated by the salon's personnel who exhibit remarkable proficiency in their respective domains, albeit with a discernible dearth of staff members, prompting Lannie to concurrently attend to two clients at once, which, while demonstrating her admirable multitasking abilities, might potentially compromise the quality of service delivered; furthermore, upon venturing to cleanse my hands, I encountered unsanitary conditions surrounding the faucets of the washbasins, specifically those situated within close proximity to the water dispensing apparatus, thereby eliciting my utter discontent and disappointment.

"The positive aspects of our experience at this bakery were undoubtedly the delectable cupcakes we sampled. Specifically, the quartet of red velvet, pink champagne, s'mores, and peanut butter chocolate varieties we procured was quite satisfying, despite some reservations regarding the unconventional flavor profile of the pink champagne iteration. Nonetheless, we found the cupcakes to be suitably moist and the frosting to be of satisfactory quality, which, in our opinion, are the primary criteria for an enjoyable cupcake experience.  

Regrettably, our encounter was not without its drawbacks. Upon entering the establishment, we were met with a noticeable lack of warmth and hospitality from the staff members present. Their demeanor could be described as brusque and impatient, giving us the distinct impression that they would have preferred us to vacate the premises as expeditiously as possible. This was particularly perplexing given the relatively low volume of customers at the time of our visit, which led us to surmise that perhaps the proprietors or their employees were experiencing an off day. Additionally, our sampling of further flavors yielded less than desirable results, specifically in the case of the orange creamsicle and strawberry cupcakes, which exhibited an overly synthetic taste and an unpleasant chemical odor that we found objectionable.  

In conclusion, while the cupcakes themselves were certainly palatable, the deficiency in customer service and the questionable quality of certain flavors left us feeling ambivalent about our overall experience at this bakery. As the chalkboard inside the shop so aptly put it, 'Can't say anything about customer service, but the cupcakes are good!' â?a sentiment with which we wholeheartedly concur."

"Initially, the culinary offerings possessed an acceptable flavor profile, albeit with a conspicuous sodium-rich quality.
