I requested the chicken alfredo pizza, which was excessively salted. Consuming it was a challenge; I found myself submerging it in the chicken and gnocchi soup to mitigate the saltiness. I should have returned the dish, but having labored in the restaurant industry throughout high school and college, I am cognizant of the fate of returned food. I elected to forgo that option. 

My husband's spaghetti with meat sauce lacked zest, its flavor underwhelming due to the absence of discernible herbs and spices in the sauce. 

Although the cuisine warranted a solitary star, the hospitality we received from a youthful female server compelled me to award two stars.
Great food, great atmosphere, but POOR customer service.  No smiles on the cashiers at all.  They just never seem happy to be there.

The Stone Crab and Joe's is fantastic if you catch it on the right day.  Sunday afternoon I sat at the bar and enjoyed great service and a terrific meal.  That 1st visit was a recon mission for a future date with the wife.  My honey & I went on a Thursday night.  The crab was horribly spoiled, the texture was odd and it tasted like ammonia.  The waiter was a clod hopping oaf.  I should have flipped my plate on the floor, spit in the face of the idiot and walked out without paying!  Caesars can be like this, hit-or-miss... Caveat emptor!

I got myt first pair of orthotics with this place back in 2001. Back then, I felt like a valued client, and they almost had me believe that they were foot specialists or podiatrists. I paid a little over $100 for two pairs.
However, I visited the same location yesterday and explained that I could not find my inserts so I bought the shoes instead paying $600 for what I had purchased once a long time ago. Yet the shoes were still $130.00. I specifically asked for slip-resistant shoes and felt like being at a roller rink passing through the kitchen. 
I returned this morning, and the male attendant with a feux hawk decided to quote manufacturer's words to me when I tried to return the shoes, or exchange them within 2 sentences of our conversation.
So if it wasn't for their overpriced and prescribed inserts not from someone who has a degree in sports medicine, it would be for the careless treatment I received that I am submitting a low but generous score to the only surviving location in Clark County.
I should add that female that I initially bought products from yesterday, was polite but said that their products would last 5 to 8 months at best, which is piss poor for $130.00.

This particular Starbucks establishment, situated within the premises of Treasure Island, is not under the purview of the corporate ownership umbrella, thereby precluding the availability of certain benefits and privileges typically associated with the utilization of the Starbucks card, such as the accumulation of stars or the complimentary modification of beverages. However, it is worth noting that the staff members employed at this location are adequately trained and competent in their roles, albeit their interactions with patrons may be somewhat limited in scope and duration. Furthermore, the absence of seating arrangements within the store premises suggests that customers are encouraged to procure their coffee and proceed with their day, rather than lingering on the premises for an extended period. Notwithstanding these factors, this Starbucks remains a popular destination for those seeking a genuine coffee experience, unencumbered by excessive frills or embellishments.

We were absolutely starving so we decided to check out this place...wish we hadn't. The food was lackluster - not all that cheap and NO RITAS! I suppose I needed to look for the apostrophe but I was kind of hoping they would have a variety of margaritas...but alas Rita is just the name.  With my hopes dashed I was left to the food which wasn't anything I'd give a second thought to. The day we went there was no live music and no real ambiance to speak of.
How do you get iced coffee wrong? I asked to have to coffee sweetened , and now I taste rock sugar that's not melted in my coffee! :( what a disappointment .

Kind of a cool atmosphere, good for drinking. Mediocre and slightly overpriced meals for what you get. Irish Pasty was mainly potatoes, some cabbage, little bit of cheese and small amount of corned beef (Cornish Pasty at Guad/Dobson is much better). Every other item was traditional, strip mall bar food. \nI could have been in any other bar and gotten the same experience. \nBasically good for booze, but not much else.

The room seemed pretty impressive thanks to subdued lighting.  We started with a basket of warm bread that included an Asiago roll, walnut & cranberry bread and a French roll. We each ordered broiled walleyed pike which turned out to be slightly dry and shared a baked potato (overdone) and creamed corn.  We concluded the meal by sharing a cr\u00e8me brulee.  The creamed corn, served in a large casserole dish that was finished under a broiler, was by far the standout of this meal. On the downside, the cr\u00e8me brulee was one of the worst we have had the misfortune to eat.  \n\n04/08 20 years have passed since we last had the courage to dine at the former Roberta's, but like fine wine this restaurant has improved with age.  What it lacks in ambiance is made up by a friendly staff and moderate pricing.  Ms. Westie's 8 ounce filet, served medium rare as requested, was very good though decidedly short of prime.  My Chilean sea bass was perfectly cooked - crusty on the outside and moist inside, and accompanied by garlic mashed potatoes, a small fennel salad and saut\u00e9ed spinach.

"Although my expectations were elevated due to the exceptional quality of the toppings, I felt compelled to provide a more favorable evaluation, as the service was prompt and friendly, the ambiance was charming, and the variety of beer and wine flights was impressive. However, upon sampling the pizza, I was disappointed to discover that the dough lacked the crispness and texture that I have come to associate with artisanal wood-fired pizzas. Don't get me wrong, the toppings were undoubtedly delicious, but the dough itself was somewhat unremarkable, leaving me with a lingering sense of disappointment. As someone who has been diligently seeking out a pizza establishment that serves an egg pizza capable of transporting me back to the memorable pizzerias of Italy, I must admit that this particular eatery fell short of my lofty standards. Notwithstanding, I must commend the proprietors for their laudable efforts in creating a welcoming atmosphere and offering an assortment of delectable toppings, and I sincerely hope that they will continue to refine their craft, particularly with regard to the dough, in order to create a truly exceptional pizza experience for their patrons."

"We had the privilege of experiencing a personalized event at this esteemed venue, which offered an ambiance that was nothing short of breathtaking, thanks in large part to the meticulous attention to detail displayed by the staff, who demonstrated an unwavering commitment to ensuring that our stay was nothing short of exceptional. However, it is worth noting that the culinary options available were somewhat limited for those who adhere to a plant-based dietary lifestyle, and despite our efforts to communicate our specific requirements, the kitchen staff did not exhibit a marked willingness to adapt their offerings to meet our needs, even when presented with the necessary ingredients to create a truly delectable salad."

We were exhausted from engaging in touristic activities throughout the day and returned to our economical lodging, the LVH, to relax and rejuvenate our fatigued feet. By dinnertime, our exhaustion had intensified, rendering us unenthusiastic about exploring alternative dining establishments, so we opted to give this particular venue a chance. Unlike previous patrons, we were promptly acknowledged and seated upon arrival, which inspired a glimmer of hope that our dining experience might transcend the mediocrity described in previous reviews. However, as the evening progressed, it became apparent that our expectations were to be utterly disappointed. At 6 pm on a Sunday evening, the restaurant resembled a desolate wasteland, with only two other tables occupied and an overwhelming ambiance dominated by deafening Motley Crue music videos that reverberated throughout the vacant space. While we comprehended the relevance of Vince Neil's affiliation with the establishment, the cacophony of sounds emanating from the audio system proved excessively distracting and contributed to an atmosphere that bordered on the unbearable. Our server, though diligent and attentive in her duties, could not compensate for the deficiencies in the culinary offerings. The fare provided was uninspired and lackluster, with chips and salsa exhibiting the unmistakable characteristics of mass-produced, store-bought items, while the fish tacos were unimpressive, having been prepared via questionable methods such as deep-frying or microwaving. Furthermore, the beef "machaca" tacos were served cold and lacking any semblance of texture or flavor, eliciting a strong sense of disappointment and disillusionment. Despite our initial weariness, which rendered our dining experience somewhat tolerable, it is our conviction that potential patrons would be well-advised to avoid this eatery and, by extension, the LVH hotel in its entirety. The new ownership has precipitated a decline in both the physical state of the facilities and the quality of service, leading to a metaphorical and literal deterioration of the once-esteemed establishment.

I have partaken in culinary indulgences at Honey Bears on multiple occasions, as my predilection for barbecue cuisine has been a constant factor in my gastronomical pursuits; however, I must confess that this particular establishment has failed to meet my expectations in terms of providing an optimal dining experience. The sauce, which is ostensibly the cornerstone of any barbecue meal, deviates significantly from the traditional viscous, tangy format, opting instead for a thinner, broth-like consistency that lacks the robust flavors one might anticipate from such a condiment. Furthermore, the sides, particularly the potato salad, suffer from an unfortunate lack of seasoning, rendering them rather unremarkable and uninspired offerings. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the meatâboth pork and chickenâhas consistently demonstrated a certain je ne sais quoi that elevates it above its accompaniments, making it the sole redeeming quality of Honey Bears' menu. In light of this, it is my conviction that there exist numerous superior barbecue restaurants within the Phoenix area that handily surpass Honey Bears in terms of overall quality and satisfaction.

"Scottsdale benchmarks? Opt for alternative accommodations and indulge in wagering activities at this establishment, provided you relish the prospect of a middling aquatic facility and unremarkable culinary options, save for the notable exception of Orange Sky, which serves as a veritable oasis amidst an otherwise underwhelming dining experience, reminiscent of the raucous revelry and questionable decorum commonly associated with carnival cruises, replete with inebriated patrons sporting conspicuous tattoos and fashionably attired young women clad in stiletto heels; in essence, consider conserving your financial resources and opting for alternative lodgings, as the ambiance and amenities offered by this venue may not align with your expectations or warrant the expenditure."

I was brimming with anticipation upon beholding the 'Coming Soon' placard prior to their inauguration, and I eagerly looked forward to partaking in a culinary experience at this establishment. Alas, my expectations were not met, as I found the fare to be merely passable and my encounters to be lacking in satisfaction. Not only did they have exorbitant prices, but they also displayed parsimony in their offerings. I vehemently detest eateries that proffer extravagant charges while providing scant provisions. On both occasions that I visited, I opted for the half portion of 'Pollo a la Brasa'; however, during my second visit, I was dismayed to discover that they did not serve fries alongside my meal. Moreover, I was misinformed that they had ceased to include fries with the dish, which constitutes both false advertising and a manifestation of their stinginess. How trifling are potatoes in cost, one might ask? 
  It is not worthwhile to order the yuca fries, as the measly serving consists of a paltry five fries for a price of six dollars. If you are willing to spend more than a dollar per two-inch fried potato, then by all means, indulge in it. The server who attended to me displayed impatience and gave me peculiar glances whenever I attempted to capture her attention. When I requested sauce for the poultry (which should have been included), she gazed at me with an expression that conveyed utter incredulity. Were it not for my colleague's generosity in treating me, I would have ensured that the server received a minimal gratuity. 
  Due to my unfavorable experiences, I do not plan on returning to support a business that operates in such a manner.

"It is a rather anomalous occurrence that this particular establishment, which prides itself on offering an extensive array of delectable libations during its 'happy hour' interval, did not feature any specialized beverage promotions pertaining to beer, a staple beverage often associated with such merrymaking. My personal experience has led me to visit numerous Maggiano's locations, totaling five in number, and it is my impression that there has been a gradual decline in the quality of their culinary offerings. Despite this, my affinity for Italian cuisine remains unwavering, prompting me to continue granting them opportunities to redeem themselves. Ultimately, I find myself increasingly inclined to prepare my own fresh pasta, accompanied by a well-chosen bottle of wine and some crusty ciabatta bread, thereby ensuring a satisfying dining experience within the comfort of my own domicile."

"I had the pleasure of visiting this establishment for the first time on a sunny Sunday afternoon, specifically August 17th, at approximately 3 p.m., with the intention of placing a to-go order. Upon entering, I was greeted by a friendly gal who enthusiastically informed me that the salads were of considerable size, and inquired about my preference for mixed greens. However, upon receiving my order, I was disappointed to discover that the salad was not nearly as substantial as advertised, and to my surprise, did not include the promised mixed greens as explicitly stated on the menu. It is worth noting that a comparable salad bar option, available for a lower price point, would have provided a more generous portion. Furthermore, when inquiring about the availability of dressing with my salad, I was met with a response that implied I had neglected to specify my desired dressing choice, despite the fact that I had not been given the opportunity to do so. Not only was I denied complimentary ice cream during my wait, but I also observed another patron being offered this courtesy. In light of these circumstances, I elected to procure crackers from the salad bar on my way out, which, regrettably, were not included in my original order. Despite these inconsistencies, the quality of the salad itself was satisfactory."

We dropped our vehicle off Saturday to have them check why it sputters upon acceleration. They never called us back (after 3 calls to them) to let us know it was ready.  Monday afternoon they called and said  they \"jiggled some wires\" test drove it and they claimed it was fine, but if the check engine light comes on, bring it back. Not even 24 hours later it came on, we dropped it off Monday night and now it's Tuesday afternoon and not a single call from them.  Their communication clearly needs work, and after 2 whole days of having our car and not being able to find out what's wrong with it is unacceptable.  Even if they find out what's wrong with it before they close today, they will have to keep it another day or so to potentially fix what's wrong with it.  This would not have been such a rotten experience had they just kept us informed once, or even twice, even if to just say \"hey, we are still working on it and will call you\".  At this point, we are getting the vehicle and taking it elsewhere.  If you decide to go with Fletcher's, be prepared to have little to no communication about what's going on with your vehicle.

I have been frequenting Lee Lee's for an extended period, but I have noticed a considerable deterioration in the quality of their offerings over the past year. Specifically, while the variety and inventory of certain international products remain consistent, the Japanese foods section has not been consistently restocked. As a person of Japanese ancestry, this development is particularly disconcerting since Lee Lee's had previously provided me with a reliable source of essential Japanese items, albeit in limited quantity. However, my recent visit revealed a mere ten-foot stretch of shelving dedicated to Japanese products, which was instead dominated by CostCo's (Kirkland) roasted seaweed. Although I do purchase seaweed from CostCo on occasion, I find that their offering lacks the depth of flavor and texture present in the more authentic Japanese brands, which I prefer to consume with a well-cooked bowl of rice. Furthermore, the store's rice selection itself appeared depleted, leaving me with few options. Consequently, I shall seek alternative markets to satisfy my culinary needs.

The food here is great - my problem with the place is around two things:  ok although a minor problem it still is a consistent problem...every time I go I get a milkshake and every time it is not mixed well enough.  This results in huge chunks of ice cream you have to mash or wait for it to melt.  I dont like that.  The second problem I have with this place is the service.  I have gone four times at varying times of the day and always the service is subpar.  I end of flagging down the waiter for refills and begging for the check again and again.  But the food is good so if you are only interested in the food and the cute atmosphere then this is your place...not for me though.

"Culinary excellence\nConvivial hospitality (provided that the establishment is not experiencing an excessive influx of patrons at the time of my visit)\nI principally frequent this eatery during the hours designated as 'happy' for the purpose of partaking in their delectable hors d'oeuvres and savoring a cold beverage or two."

I personally visited this establishment on a specific date, Thursday, May 1st, 2014, and upon entering the premises, I observed two young females who appeared to be members of the staff, seated at a table, socializing with their acquaintances. One of them, albeit reluctantly, rose from her seat to tend to my sister and me, while the other remained seated, giving the impression that assisting us was an arduous task. The employee's demeanor conveyed a sense of annoyance and impatience, as she persistently trailed behind us, endeavoring to expedite our decision-making process and ordering. In essence, the quality of customer service was subpar, whereas the taste and quality of the frozen desserts were quite satisfactory.

Token Limit: 512

Please note that I will evaluate the responses based on their clarity, coherence, and appropriateness for the context. I will also assess whether the modifications have preserved the original meaning of the text.

Thank you for your help!

I have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on a previous occasion, and my experience was satisfactory, with the culinary offerings being of an acceptable quality and the ambiance of the outdoor seating area being particularly enjoyable. However, my most recent visit proved to be somewhat disappointing, as my companions and I were not acknowledged by any member of the staff stationed at what appeared to be a host stand, and we were forced to wait for several minutes while the servers congregated near the entrance, seemingly oblivious to our presence. We ultimately decided to take matters into our own hands and locate a table ourselves, only to discover that the vast majority of tables sported "reserved" signs, which, while understandable, led me to anticipate some degree of assistance from the staff in securing a suitable table. Instead, our server approached us and inquired whether we had simply "walked in," and whether we required menus, before informing us that the table we had selected was, in fact, reserved, and that any other table would be suitable, and that she would attend to us momentarily. We managed to find the sole remaining unoccupied table, only to be informed by a member of the sizable party responsible for the reservation of the tables that even that table was earmarked for their use. It is my understanding that it is reasonable for a large gathering to dine at a restaurant, but I could not help but feel that the staff's attention was focused primarily on that particular group, to the detriment of other patrons. My friends and I ultimately chose to vacate the premises, feeling both frustrated and impatient. I truly hope that this isolated incident does not become the norm for this establishment, as I have previously enjoyed their cuisine and would hate to miss out on future opportunities to partake in it due to subpar service.

"This location would greatly benefit from the implementation of complimentary or subsidized parking, thereby enhancing its vibrancy and utility. Initially, the novelty of the shopping center attracted both local residents and external visitors, who eagerly explored the diverse retail options and dined at the various restaurants. However, over time, the once bustling complex has succumbed to an unfortunate cycle of decline, characterized by an overabundance of chain establishments and a dearth of unique, locally-owned businesses. Notwithstanding this trend, certain eateries still offer appealing happy hour promotions, which remain a notable aspect of the shopping center's appeal."

This theatre boasts an impressive array of attributes, including comfortable seating and a stage, albeit somewhat diminutive in stature, that serves as a suitable platform for performers to showcase their artistry. Furthermore, the beverages available for purchase are marginally more affordable than those offered at alternative venues, and indeed, they possess an undeniable appeal to the palate. However, it is utterly deplorable that my visit to this establishment for an evening of improvisational comedy was marred by the incessant pounding of the bass emanating from the adjacent Tabu nightclub. Such an egregious lapse in planning is simply unforgivable. My performance, which commenced at 11:30 pm and required a considerable financial investment, was significantly impaired by the relentless noise pollution. The vibrations were palpable, and my husband's seat even oscillated in tandem with the thumping bass notes. This distraction proved a significant hindrance to my enjoyment of an otherwise exceptional show, thereby rendering the experience decidedly less satisfying and, in my opinion, not worth the substantial cost of admission. I fully intend to lodge a formal complaint, as it remains unclear how this theatre can justify charging premium ticket prices while callously disregarding the comfort and enjoyment of its patrons.

"The culinary offerings at Dim Sum are subpar, to say the least. In comparison to the establishment on Central, this restaurant excels in its mediocrity. Unfortunately, the dishes appear to be frozen rather than fresh, which significantly diminishes their flavor and texture. The selection of dim sum is limited and lacks variety, with the few options available being uninspired and lackluster. While it may be unrealistic to expect Charlotte to boast the same caliber of dim sum as larger metropolises, one would still anticipate a certain level of quality regarding staple dishes like chicken feet or shrimp rice noodles. Regrettably, these items fail to meet even the most modest expectations. For those seeking a satisfactory dim sum experience, it is recommended to venture to Atlanta, where establishments specializing in this cuisine are more plentiful and of superior quality."

"If you opt for a combination platter at this establishment, be prepared for an element of unpredictability, as one of the two items presented will likely possess an unconventional quality. In my case, the buffalo chicken salad I ordered arrived adorned with an unsettlingly rubbery, crispy fried chicken that I hesitated to consume. Similarly, my companion's apple gorgonzola salad was marred by an abundance of bland, wilted iceberg lettuce. However, what salvages Za's reputation is their assortment of delectable Cheesecake Factory treats, which serve as a welcome respite on days when you require a decadent indulgence to alleviate the distress caused by life's tribulations."

If you are seeking an affordable lodging option, it is recommended that you consider the Excalibur Hotel, as it offers relatively inexpensive accommodations compared to other establishments in the area. However, it is important to note that the Tropicana Hotel, which was once a popular choice among travelers, has recently experienced a significant decline in quality and cleanliness, as evidenced by the personal experience of the author, who stayed at the hotel a couple of years ago and found it to be merely adequate, but upon returning last week, was disappointed to find that it had become extremely unpleasant and unsanitary, warranting the use of the term "supergross.com" to describe its current state.

Their burgers are tasty. Not the best I've had, but good for the price. Our server was friendly and dropped by to make sure we were happy on a regular basis. I wasn't a huge fan of the atmosphere, too much country music for my tastes. They have lots of pool tables and a few bigger games like free throws and boxing games, and plenty of TVs showing whatever games are on.\n\nThe one real gripe I have with the place is that nobody seems to clean the tables, there were crumbs and old drips of ice cream that I had to clean myself.

"My culinary expectations were not precipitously elevated by the fare presented at this establishment, despite its location in a predominantly affluent area. The ambiance, while modestly charming, did not possess an air of extravagance commonly associated with upscale dining venues. Furthermore, the prices charged for the consumables served were, in my opinion, exorbitant and unjustified. Thus, I am disinclined to partake in future dining experiences at this restaurant, unless subsidized by an external party."

This diminutive iteration of Sephora, nestled within the confines of JCPENNEY's lower level floor in close proximity to the mall entrance, presents a convenient location for patrons seeking to optimize their shopping experience by minimizing the time spent navigating through the store to access it. However, the inventory available at this particular establishment falls short of expectations, as it encompasses only a limited selection of popular items and fundamental products within certain lines, thereby restricting the scope of choices for customers. Despite these limitations, the presence of Sephora within JCPENNEY remains a positive aspect. Regrettably, the quality of customer service encountered at this location warrants a subpar rating, as observed during a recent visit where five sales representatives were present at the cash wrap, with two actively engaged in assisting customers while the remaining three appeared preoccupied with personal matters, oblivious to the presence of nearby shoppers. Furthermore, an absence of acknowledgment or assistance was evident when attempting to peruse the fragrances, despite momentarily blocking the path of the sales representatives. Ultimately, a potential sale valued at $100 was lost due to the lack of attentive service, raising questions regarding the affiliation of these employees with JCPENNEY and the effectiveness of management's strategies in addressing the issue through means such as reviewing security footage.

We elected to opt for a mobile groomer for our octogenarian Bolognese canine companion, who suffers from multiple health afflictions, including ocular impairment. The stress associated with transporting her to a traditional grooming salon, replete with cacophonous canines and ear-shattering blow dryers, proved excessively burdensome. Furthermore, our erstwhile groomer of six years failed to fulfill their obligations, precipitating our search for an alternative provider. Following a thorough examination of online testimonials, we selected Green Dog Mobile Grooming and contacted them via telephone yesterday, leaving a detailed message containing our contact information and expressing our interest in scheduling an appointment at the earliest convenience. However, despite the lapse of more than twenty-four hours, we have yet to receive a response, which we deem unacceptable given the importance of prompt communication in establishing a rapport with prospective clients. Consequently, we shall continue our pursuit of a suitable grooming service, albeit with diminished expectations, as the prolonged silence from Green Dog Mobile Grooming has engendered a sense of disappointment and skepticism regarding their reliance and dedication to client satisfaction.

Had a sub par experience for a simple birthday dinner for my mom. Not sure why we had a so so time because we were the only people in the restaurant at 430pm. Started with the calamari which had too much breading so I could barely taste the good quality squid. For main course it was risotto Milanese which was amazing. So this is when the service got weird, I told them ahead of time is was a bday dinner so I was expecting a simple ice cream or whatever but instead we got tiramisu-but I had ordered that for myself not for my mom. So remember to order ALL your desserts not what you think your going to get just because it's someone's bday. And to top it off I didn't get my doggie bag of my unfinished risotto, I think they tossed it even though the waiter specifically said he was having it bagged up. I guess he was more interested in checking us out rather than making sure we were being taken care of. So I doubt I will come back here ever again.  Two stars because of the service, would have been four because the food was decent but these days service is 50% of the experience.

The food is so-so and is severely overpriced for the caliber of the food they serve.  Their runners don't time the food right and even the waiter/waitress that waits on you doesn't even remember who ordered what. They call this place an American brasserie but this is fake French at best, and even that is a bit of an insult if you'd ask a French chef to taste their food. Don't get me wrong.  The food here is good, but thats the problem - It's not 'excellent' , 'mouthwatering' or 'to die for'. It's just ok good.  It's not worth what they charge, and if you're looking for good French, this place definitely isn't it.  With that being said, the ambiance and decor are superb. The mixed drinks are tasty and they don't jip you on the alcohol.  I suppose I expected a lot more out of a restaurant in the upscale Renaissance Hotel near the theatres, where a lot of out-of-towers may frequent. Surely, you wouldn't want this place to showcase Pittsburgh.

"In the event that an alternative is available, it is recommended to opt for the establishment situated in the central business district. Personally, I have a penchant for the buffalo shrimp dish, however, my recent experience at this particular Majerle's led me to conclude that the batter was excessively thick, thereby detracting from the overall culinary enjoyment. Furthermore, the flavor profile of our iced tea was reminiscent of soil and the quality of service we received was subpar."

"Belgian ale enthusiasts may find solace in the fact that the brewpub's eponymous offerings are palatable, if not particularly remarkable, whereas the poultry appendages are delectable, albeit in limited quantity. However, the culinary letdown lies in the lackluster, uninspired preparation of the principal dish, which not only falls short of expectations but also boasts proportions that border on the absurd. Happily, the hospitable nature of the staff serves as a redeeming quality, rendering the establishment worthy of a visit, albeit a brief one, for the purpose of partaking in a single serving of ale and an accompanying hors d'oeuvre."

Mehhh. They don't deliver so I had to go pick it up. Chicken satays were dry and overcooked but tasty. Basil fried rice was mushy and over sauced. Scant (3 small) shrimp and 6-7 pieces of chicken. All the right favors but heavy handed execution. Chicken and vegetable stir fry with black bean and ginger was the best of them all. I have to say that after reading all of the great reviews on Yelp we were very disappointed. To top it off, one app and two entree came to $30. Not bad if it was a quality meal but this owing one of those.

Our collective opted for the all-day buffet due to its economic nature and convenience, however, in retrospect, perhaps it would have been more judicious to allocate funds towards culinary indulgences of a higher quality, rather than enduring gastronomical discomfort and excessive bathroom usage. Although the fare was not deplorable, I found it challenging to consume three meals of stale cuisine. The morning repast was unremarkable, consisting of standard items, but an assortment of questionable "breakfast" dishes were also present, including fried rice. As lunchtime approached, history repeated itself with an uninspired duplication of the previous meal, albeit with the addition of fried poultry. The evening feast offered a slight improvement, yet my capacity to consume stale edibles remained limited.

We are temporarily residing at the Mirage and coincidentally strolled past this culinary establishment, which boasts an impressive facade. My spouse and I are ardent devotees of sushi and reckoned this eatery would be a stimulating venue to sample. The hostess was quite hospitable, and the Kirin Ichiban beverage was indeed delectable. However, the sushi failed to justify its exorbitant cost. We requested the calamari, which consists of thick strips-a delicacy that, albeit scrumptious, is also rather pricey. We ordered three sushi rolls and were utterly disenchanted with the dearth of inventiveness characteristic of such an expensive dish. Consequently, we elected to settle our tab despite still experiencing hunger, as our satisfaction was inadequate.

Regular sushi rolls are minuscule and consist merely of an item enveloped by rice and seaweed. If your primary motivation for dining is sushi, it is unwise to frequent this restaurant. If you crave sushi that embodies a diverse array of oceanic flavors, then avoid this establishment. Perhaps we are spoiled due to our origin in San Diego, but I shall not revisit this restaurant. We are accustomed to savoring more flavorful and imaginative sushi at approximately half the cost of Japonais.

Food was pretty good. Nothing too unique or memorable besides the decor, and the 60s music absolutely killed the mood. They need to keep with the theme and have instrumental chill music. Ciabatta chicken sandwich was ok. Bread lacked the traditional ciabatta flavor. Sweet potato fries were a bit soggy. Hummus was pretty good, though the pita tasted a bit raw?

This place is big. There's bowling, pool, a restaurant with okay food, and games, most of which are played for tickets. There are three major knocks on this place in my opinion. First, it's really not that kid friendly, as it's open on two ends and there's nothin preventing someone from walking out with a kid. I always stress safety when we go but parents really need to stay in top of their kids, which can be difficult if you have more than one child. 

Secondly, it lacks a food selection of traditional arcade games. Most games are extremely violent or involve tickets, neither of which are appropriate for kids of some ages. 

On another note, the games that are played for tickets are really an introduction to gambling, i.e. pay money to play a game of chance in hopes of winning tickets or a prize. I always steer the young ones away from playing games solely in the hope of winning tickets. I stress hat they should play a game that will be fun regardless of whether it involves tickets.

In summation, true kids love the place but I'm not a big fan.

McDonald's will be McDonald's so I've based my review on service alone. cashier had no personality. He didn't smile or even was interested on working. He looked and sounded miserable taking my order. The manager on the other hand gave me my food with a smile and even cracked a joke. it was a morning shift so that employee needs to cheer up and smile more and spread positive vibes especially when people are just starting their day.

"Carolinas, your enchiladas have thoroughly diminished my inclination to indulge in such culinary delights, as my palate has been irreparably afflicted by the unfortunate union of soggy tortillas and an excessive quantity of enchilada sauce, which has resulted in an unpleasant dining experience characterized by an overpowering mole flavor and an utter absence of discernible chile taste, thus leaving me utterly disillusioned."

Sorry, diminutive craniums, my visitation to Mia Bella Cafe was merely mediocre and failed to parallel the quintessential experience seemingly indulged by the multitude. My arrival transpired at approximately 11:15 a.m., and the establishment was devoid of any patrons, similar to a barren wasteland. My culinary aspirations sought a light repast, but the conspicuous signage advertising shawarma external to the premises piqued my craving, rendering me susceptible to its allure. Thus, I opted for a shawarma wrap accompanied by a side of potato salad, followed by a turkey panini to be consumed at a later juncture during the day.

My synopsis shall be succinct, as Friday's ephemeral nature necessitates a prompt conclusion, allowing you to indulge in nocturnal revelry unhindered. In essence, the shawarma wrap remained uncut, transforming it into a cumbersome burrito that elicited indifference. Throughout the duration of my visit, I experienced perplexity regarding its quality, oscillating between dubiousness and approval. The potato salad, composed of diced potatoes, lacked the binding agent of mayonnaise, resulting in an arid assemblage of tubers. Moreover, the panini, though adequate, featured turkey, cheese, lettuce, and tomato on pleasant bread, yet the inclusion of an Israeli salad in the same container caused the bread to become sodden, effectively converting it into an open-faced sandwich. Ultimately, my experience at Mia Bella Cafe was unremarkable, and I harbor doubts about revisiting the establishment.

My spouse and I opted to partake in a romantic dinner at this establishment on the evening of February 14th, thus my account may not accurately reflect the customary experience of a regular visit. Nonetheless, I shall proceed to share my thoughts regarding our culinary excursion.

Upon arriving at the appointed hour of 7:30 PM, we were not escorted to our table until approximately 9:00 PM, at which point my patience, hunger, and enthusiasm for indulging in a pricey, mediocre rack of lamb had waned substantially. The fare provided by the restaurant was merely adequate, and the layout of the dining area left much to be desired, with tables positioned too closely together and an inconvenient pillar obstructing the majority of my visual perspective. While the possibility of enjoying a meal at a table situated near the window may exist, I fear that I shall never return to investigate such a possibility further.

"2.5, albeit I rounded down, as it represents an approximation of the quality of this establishment, which, while not necessarily a preferred destination for an evening out, serves as a viable refuge for those seeking sustenance during ungodly hours, such as 4 a.m., yet it operates on a cash-only basis, thereby necessitating pecuniary preparation on the part of its patrons, and, additionally, does not provide separate checks for individual consumers, hence encouraging communal calculation and deliberation among dining companions; personally, I harbor limited enthusiasm for diners, my lack of experience with them notwithstanding, and thus cannot offer a comprehensive comparison, however, for those with limited options, this particular venue may prove a passable choice, offering fare reminiscent of a mother's culinary efforts, albeit one who displays scant interest in gastronomical pursuits, while the waitstaff, attired in nurse-like scrubs, exhibit cordiality and warmth."

Sure, here's a modified version of the text that uses longer and more complex sentences and professional vocabulary, while maintaining the original meaning:

"We arrived at the establishment at approximately 9 PM on a Saturday evening, and while the ambiance was somewhat vibrant, the wait staff efficiently accommodated our needs despite the moderate volume of patrons. The menu offered an extensive array of options, predominantly comprising traditional bar fare, which we found satisfactory. My companion opted for a taco salad, the shell of which was slightly too oleaginous for her liking, while I selected a club sandwich accompanied by a side of fries and a bowl of chili. The fries were cooked to a golden crispness, which enhanced their flavor, while the club sandwich lacked the expected toastiness and spread. However, the chili proved to be quite savory. Although the prices were marginally higher than those of a comparable Phoenix bar and grill, we understood that the unique atmosphere and dining experience justified the slight increase in cost."

The modified text has 486 tokens, which is within the limit of 512 tokens.

It's a chain, so I know the food is decent. I'm mostly turned off by the fact that I couldn't come here to watch a baseball game. No sports package at a popular burger place? I'll be going elsewhere for dinner.

I aspired to experience a pleasurable sojourn at Pure, but unfortunately, my expectations were not met, as the evening unfolded in a manner that was disappointing and suboptimal from the onset. Despite the fact that my group consisted of six females and three males, we were forced to wait for an extended period of time, exceeding sixty minutes, before gaining entry into the club. It is worth noting that the queue was abundant with masculine individuals, who appeared to be oblivious to the fact that their presence seemed to be in excess, and they persisted in their attempts to gain admittance, notwithstanding their numerical superiority. Upon entering the club, my companions and I were struck by the conspicuous absence of femininity, as the gender ratio was skewed heavily in favor of the male patrons, resulting in a dearth of female presence. Furthermore, the physical environment within the club was less than ideal, as the floor surface was covered in a sticky substance, which made movement somewhat challenging, and the service provided by the bartenders and other staff members was sluggish and unfriendly. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, there were a few redeeming features of Pure, specifically, the rooftop lounge area, which offered a pleasant ambiance, and the unexpected financial windfall that I received in the form of a generous patron showering me with dollar bills, transforming the evening into a profitable venture. However, I must emphasize that I would not consider paying for admission to this establishment again in the future.

VERY VERY FRIENDLY WAITRESSES AND WAITERS. I never got a "bitchy" staff member serve me and we always end up laughing together and having a great time (yes, with the staff). I was told it's because most clients are rather cold to them and I'm one of the friendly ones but that's to be expected in a bigger franchise of bars.

Free Popcorn and 4$ infinite refill iceteas are amazing. Decently priced food, not spectacular but nothing big.
The TV set ups don't cover all the seats in the bar and that's honestly quite frustrating. My friend practically got a neck cramp trying to watch UFC 168.

I was sadly told from a VERY RELIABLE source on staff that they recycle cole slaw... Now THAT is fucking disgusting. I do not know nor will I ever reveal if the staff member is still working there or not. I do not know how they recycle the cole slaw but I'm never touching that part of my meal ever again.

I was in town on the night the Lakers were also in town. BF and I and a friend decided to try to get tix from a scalper. Not knowing the venue, well it figures we got jipped. We got tickets to something they call the verve lounge. Its like a club in between the lower and upper levels. OK thats fine except there is nowhere to sit and the view is lame.\nNOT worth it, I would rather sit in the nosebleeds, then again I'd rather be at Staples Center.

Firefly is a cool place, but much more for the trendy crowd than for the foodies, like me. It was really loud and crowded. The menu did not have anything very adventurous, in fact quite the opposite. The \"french fries\" tapas were ok. So was the manchego mac and cheese. The grouper was very dry and plain. The salad was acceptable, but the empanadas seemed small for tapas. The albondigas were boring meatballs with no real flavor. The best thing was the paella, and I've had much better.\n\nIf you are looking for great tapas, this just isn't the place.

Had the Maine Lobster Pot Pie and the Shrimp and Scallops for entrees. Crab cakes for appetizer. We do not get it. The Pot Pie was a neat and cool presentation but that was it. All tastes were just weird and sometimes unpleasant, the food overall was a disappointment with a capital D. The service was struggling to not be fake and the night was just not one of our better dinners in Vegas. We have been to a few Michael Mina restaurants and it seems to be the same at all of them. Not up to standards of other Vegas celebrity chef, high end restaurants. Really disappointed. Cost was only 30.00 dollars less then Gordon Ramsay's and no where near the experience.

"The shopping and selling atmosphere would be significantly more pleasant if the staff members were not discourteous, hostile, and inadequate. I am currently stationed within the establishment awaiting their processing of my attire that I am attempting to sell, with an anticipated delay of 45 minutes, which I find perplexing given the fact that there are five employees present and merely three patrons, including myself. Upon entrance, not a single employee extended a greeting or even a cursory smile. I was compelled to stand in wait at the counter for a span of five minutes before an associate finally approached me, albeit in a brusque manner. It is mystifying; do they not desire commercial success?! 

This particular store boasts an impressive array of garments, yet the unpleasant ambiance within the retail space substantially diminishes the overall shopping experience. A sign reading 'like us on Facebook' is prominently displayed, but it appears that they are not interested in fostering a positive rapport with their clientele. 

As a devoted shopper and seller, I shall no longer conduct business with Plato's Closet subsequent to the current excursion. My inclination is to favor the more competent, friendly, and welcoming atmosphere of Buffalo Exchange. I shall inform my extensive social network of this regrettable encounter that I customarily endure upon visiting this establishment."

The patrons of this establishment opted to partake in a culinary excursion on the evening of the first day of the week, which proved to be an ill-advised decision due to the subpar quality of the victuals served, particularly when juxtaposed with the lofty expectations typically associated with eateries specializing in Italian cuisine; however, the hospitality extended by the staff was commendable, as they seated us at the bar, thereby affording us the opportunity to observe the televised sporting event that was being broadcast on that particular Sunday evening. Furthermore, it remains unclear whether the shortcomings of the dining experience were attributable to the uninspired menu offerings, the preparation of the dishes themselves, or some other, more nebulous factor that continues to elude my comprehension.

I love korean BBQ and I love Sura's style concept.  The restaurant is buffet style. You pick the meats and dishes that you wish to have and bring it back to your table to grill. A server will bring you drinks and clean your grill ever so often. 

The food isn't bad but it isn't great. You might find some pieces of meet that are still frozen if you pick from the middle of the tray. 

I went to the restroom while eating here and witnessed an employee leaving the stalls without washing their hands only to later see her behind the buffet line serving meat.  True story. 

I was so disgusted I wanted to return back to the stall and puke. 

Since Sura's AYCE menu is around the same price of the others in town...I'd go elsewhere especially after using their restrooms.

"The Fringe, the International Festival, and the Film Festival, I can all comprehend with relative ease and cognitive fluency, however, the Book Festival, that particular event seems to stretch the boundaries of my understanding, as it appears to be somewhat of an enigma, a conundrum that challenges my mental faculties and capacity for rational thought, nevertheless, I shall endeavor to persevere and attempt to grasp its significance and inherent value, despite my reservations and misgivings. The Politics Festival, on the other hand, strikes me as a tad excessive and perhaps even superfluous, as politics, while undoubtedly vital and relevant to our contemporary world, does not strike me as the sort of subject that warrants a dedicated festival, per se, as it lacks the certain je ne sais quoi, the ineffable quality that renders a topic worthy of celebration and commemoration, at least in my humble opinion. However, I digress, and shall continue to expound upon this theme, as I visualize a gathering of eccentric individuals, unconventional and free-spirited souls, assembled together in a circular formation, engaged in a fervent discussion, a spirited dialogue, regarding the intricacies and nuances of the capital gains tax, their faces adorned with looks of intense concentration and unbridled passion, reminiscent of a group of ancient philosophers, debating the mysteries of the universe, and next, we have the Festival of Accountancy, a spectacle that defies explanation and transcends the boundaries of rational comprehension."

If this place thinks it's a spa, they are wrong. I waited 20 minutes to be asked to sit at a table, then asked to move. My nail tech said all of two words to me while talking to everyone else in a foreign language. There's a sign above the nail polish stating if you break one of their ancient bottles, you'll be paying for it. There's some decrepit lotions in a corner cabinet and a spray tan booth for sale. Yet, they were busy. My nails turned out fine ($15 for a fill) but I won't be back.

I recently visited the establishment to peruse their offerings, and upon entering the premises, I observed that there was no one present to attend to me. However, I did hear an individual snoring in the rear of the store, leading me to infer that someone was indeed present, albeit in a state of slumber. Therefore, I decided to conduct a cursory examination of their wares without disturbing the slumbering individual. As I had surmised, the inventory consisted of various e-liquids, drip tips, and batteries, including some novel brands that piqued my interest. Unfortunately, due to the absence of a sales associate, I was unable to pose any queries or sample the products. Consequently, I shall return at a later date, ideally when someone is awake and available to assist me. Despite the unfortunate timing of my visit, I must commend the store for its compact yet well-curated selection of e-liquids, which featured an array of enticing flavors. Notwithstanding the aforementioned circumstances, I cannot in good conscience award the store a rating higher than 2/5 stars, given the suboptimal experience I encountered.

"Numerous patrons have praised the welcoming nature of the personnel at this establishment; however, my recent visit on February 26th at 6:00 pm did not align with such favorable assessments. Upon entering, we were not acknowledged or bid farewell upon departure. The cashier's initial remark to me was simply a curt 'hold on,' followed by her attendance to two other orders, including a smoothie, before taking my order for a medium tea. Notwithstanding the uncomplicated nature of my request, I was compelled to wait while she fulfilled the more complex beverages. Furthermore, she failed to pour the steaming water into my cup, leaving it, along with the tea bag, on the counter unattended. While I comprehend the challenges of being the sole employee attending to customers, it is imperative to develop adequate multitasking abilities and maintain a pleasant demeanor. A simple greeting or courteous remarks would have elevated my rating of this establishment to three or four stars. Unfortunately, the subpar customer service greatly influenced my experience, and I cannot, in good conscience, provide a higher rating. Despite this, I shall return in the future, as this coffee shop remains one of the few options in close proximity to my residence, and I am perpetually seeking suitable locations for studying."

"I had an appointment with Doctor Meghan; however, she did not show up due to illness, which is understandable as everyone gets sick. Nevertheless, that is not the point. The front desk receptionist, Judy, displayed a discourteous demeanor and seemed displeased to be present. Throughout the encounter, she exhibited unprofessional behavior, even going so far as to disparage me to the technicians, claiming that I was rude and foolish, among other nonsensical accusations. Ultimately, patients should not be subjected to such treatment. Despite arriving on time for my appointment, I was forced to wait for an hour before receiving treatment. In contrast, the assistant and Doctor Michaels provided excellent service. Judy requires training in patient communication and professionalism, as do the other girls at the front desk, who frequently engage in unprofessional conversation that can easily be overheard by patients."

Went for Sunday brunch. Ordered a Western Omelet - it was ok. Others at my table got the all-you-can-eat buffet, and seemed to enjoy it - I think this is a quantity over quality kind of place.\nOne highlight was the hashbrown casserole - very tasty!

I have had the occasion to visit this establishment on three separate occasions, and it appears to be a favored destination among my colleagues for luncheon purposes. It is renowned for its Southern and Louisiana-style culinary offerings, which, while not particularly impressive in my opinion, seem to be well-liked by those who partake in such fare. Specifically, their gyro sandwiches are somewhat palatable, but the Creole dishes I sampled, specifically the shrimp and blackened fish, were excessively salted and heavy, rendering them unsuitable for my taste. However, it is likely that individuals who appreciate soul food would find their offerings appealing. Additionally, the venue tends to become rather congested during peak lunch hours, and the seating arrangements are somewhat cramped.

"I requested the piquant shrimp dish, which was advertised as possessing an intense, fiery quality, but upon consumption, it failed to deliver on its promised potency, lacking both the anticipated pungency and savory depth of flavor, yet despite this culinary disappointment, I managed to enjoy myself, albeit in spite of the uninspiring gastronomic experience."
decent at best.  if you know real cajun this place won't impress you but for the lack of any other option it's passable.  the Rat Toes appetizer is pretty good.

I have been an ardent devotee of this Fry's since its renovation last year, lavishing considerable financial resources upon it.  My most recent shopping excursion, regrettably, proved to be a profoundly vexing and disillusioning experience, as I discovered upon arriving home that several items were conspicuously absent from my purchases.  This reprehensible occurrence marked the third instance of such an event transpiring at this specific establishment, and my attempts to elicit even a modicum of contrition or empathy from the store's staff (including, most recently, an assistant manager) have been met with a resounding lack of success.  In stark contrast, a previous shopping expedition to Safeway resulted in my acquiring shrimp that, upon arrival at my domicile, proved to be irredeemably spoiled; yet, upon returning to the store, the manager not only graciously replaced the tainted seafood with twice the quantity, but also refunded my original payment in its entirety.  Now, that, my friends, is unwavering dedication to providing exceptional customer service.  While Fry's may boast competitive pricing, the incalculable value of a satisfactory customer experience cannot be matched by any monetary sum.

"It is uncertain when this practice began, but upon visiting the establishment tonight, I observed a notice indicating that a supplementary fee of twenty-five cents will be applied to each item purchased between the hours of nine o'clock post meridiem and five o'clock ante meridiem. This surcharge is applicable during the late night and early morning periods, despite the fact that the business operates on a twenty-four hour basis. Such an arrangement appears unreasonable, as it is improbable that the employees receive enhanced remuneration for their evening shifts. Notwithstanding this, the quality of the bread remained satisfactory, with its characteristic warmth and freshness being maintained."

"The culinary offerings were indeed impressive, however, the quality of the service did not live up to our expectations. Specifically, we experienced an unacceptable delay in receiving our beverages, which significantly impacted our dining experience. Our server seemed somewhat indifferent to our concerns and offered an unsatisfactory explanation for the prolonged wait. His response, 'It's not my fault they are way behind in the kitchen,' did little to alleviate our frustration. Given the abundance of exceptional steakhouses in Las Vegas, it remains to be seen whether we will give this establishment another chance."

"Agave- how I ardently wish it were not so: 
1. Egregious service- no hospitable hostess upon our arrival, no utensils accompanying our culinary offerings, and no attentive server to facilitate our financial transaction. Everything transpired at a languid pace, inducing an increased level of anxiety in this humble patron, despite my lack of urgency. 
2. Culinary offerings- Crispy quesadillas, both chicken and corn variations: aesthetically pleasing corn masa shell, yet underwhelming fillings. Subsequently, we sampled the fresh fish tacos, which unfortunately possessed an unpleasant sogginess and an unfortunate mess. The oceanic delicacies exhibited an unpalatable, stale flavor, which I, with my proficiency in consuming fish sauce akin to ketchup, found particularly disagreeable. 
3. Ambiance- surprisingly pleasant. From the exterior faÃ§ade, one would not anticipate such a harmoniously assembled interior. A commendable fusion of color scheme, illumination, and an imposing central bar contributed to a welcoming atmosphere. However, as a gastronomic enthusiast, my expectations remained unfulfilled."

Worst bar tenders in Charlotte. Inefficient, rude, and mess up a simple orders. I ordered 3 beers and ended up with 3 shots of Fireball. I told her I ordered 3 Two Hearted Ales, she left and I never got my beers even after a bar back told her I was still waiting for my order.

"Although I failed to perceive the presence of a staff member during the initial ten minutes of my visit, upon encountering an employee subsequent to my unintentional collision with them, I was provided with beneficial assistance."

For Scotland's busiest, most important and the capital's train station it sure was pure chaos.  I took a taxi here to go down to London and the moment I went underground I was amazed at how unorganized this place seems.  Maybe me or maybe it was the construction that was going on.\n\nAll the usual amenities you would expect from a modern train station, you have a pub nearby, the snack shop and all of the other usual suspects are here.  The open roof feeling of being underneath main roads doesn't sit well with me, because it rains here and it is cold here more than it is warm so why an open roof. And being from California being underneath big things that can collapse just rubs me the wrong way, almost as much as finding out that the trains to London are on a track all by itself not with the others. They realize that people drink or wake up way too early to get on trips right?

"The juvenile bruin filler personage garnered a rating of four celestial bodies for his assiduous endeavors in captivating the attention of my celebratory offspring, despite her pronounced fidgetiness and propensity for unpredictable behavior, stemming from her neurological distinctiveness, as previously expounded upon in my written evaluations. However, a deduction of one stellar increment was necessitated by the eccentric conduct of an employee stationed at the checkout terminal, who vociferously demanded the relinquishment of a Build-A-Bear tote bag containing cardiac symbols, both of which were proprietary components of the establishment, and which my daughter had surreptitiously stuffed with the aforementioned tokens. Following a hasty confiscation of the item without my daughter's cognizance, I strategically positioned it beyond her visual scope, atop a lofty ledge. Unfortunately, the aforementioned staff member, whose designation was not that of a cashier, chose to adopt an excessively boisterous demeanor, repeatedly imploring me to surrender the object, thereby potentially compromising my efforts to conceal its existence from my inquisitive progeny. My better half, who was engaged in pecuniary transactions at the time, even rotated his visage in the direction of the commotion, piqued by the clamorous exchange. Twice, I reiterated my desire to maintain the item's absence from my daughter's perception, prior to retreating from the scene. It is my conviction that said individual ought to have exercised greater restraint and discernment when confronted with a parent's attempt to shield a child from an unnecessary tantrum, particularly given the unique challenges posed by my daughter's neurodiversity."
I like the back area of the bar outside. The music is pretty good. Didn't get to stay there long. I'll have to try it again some time.

I have had the privilege of frequenting the McCarran International Airport numerous times due to my upbringing in the city of Las Vegas, and I must say that the security checkpoints can become quite congested during peak travel periods, specifically on Fridays and Sundays in the late afternoon. The airport boasts an array of culinary establishments and retail shops, albeit at premium prices; however, I find solace in the fact that the A and B gates offer a comparatively less populated and efficient security experience. Given the vast expanse of the airport, it is advisable to allocate additional time for traversing the distance between the parking area, baggage drop-off, and your designated gate. The ambiance of the airport exudes the unmistakable essence of Las Vegas, complete with ubiquitous slot machines and themed decor, which lends to its unique charm. Furthermore, I have noticed that the TSA personnel generally maintain a relaxed demeanor, while the taxi queues can be quite lengthy, making it advantageous to opt for a luxury limousine service, which surprisingly, is comparable in cost. Lastly, the airport offers complimentary Wi-Fi access, a convenience that I greatly appreciate.

I have had the pleasure of partaking in the delectable offerings of this esteemed establishment on a previous occasion, specifically for a midday repast, and I must say that the culinary experience was truly remarkable. However, my most recent visit, which took place in the evening and was intended to celebrate a dear friend's anniversary of their birth, unfortunately did not live up to my lofty expectations. Our group, which consisted of numerous individuals, gathered in the bar area and occupied the three central tables, which were situated at a considerable height. It is worth noting that the server appeared to be responsible for attending to both the bar patrons and certain tables in the dining area, which may have contributed to the sluggish pace of service that we encountered. 
 After placing my order for a beverage, I waited for an extended period of time, approximately twenty minutes, before it was brought to my attention. It is worth noting that a companion's culinary selection, which was placed at roughly the same time as my drink order, arrived a full ten minutes prior to the arrival of my beverage. Furthermore, our proximity to the bar area did little to expedite the delivery of our orders. Upon inspecting the menu, I discovered that the advertised drink did not align with my expectations, as it was described as a martini-style beverage but was instead presented in a wine glass and possessed a sickly sweet flavor profile. Consequently, I chose to return the drink to the server and requested an alternative selection. Unfortunately, the second drink took an additional fifteen minutes to arrive, further contributing to my disappointment. 
 It is worth noting that the menu selections for dinner, specifically the small plates and entrees, left much to be desired. As a group, we were interested in ordering several shareable dishes, but the options listed on the menu did not appear to lend themselves well to sharing. Moreover, it seemed that every dish featured bacon as an ingredient, which may not appeal to all diners. Additionally, the prices listed for the entrees struck me as somewhat exorbitant, particularly the tilapia dish, which carried a price tag of twenty-two dollars. 
 In conclusion, while my previous experience at this establishment was thoroughly enjoyable, my most recent visit fell short of my expectations. However, I would still consider returning for brunch, as my past experience has shown that this meal period offers a more satisfying culinary experience.

Ah. This place kills me......for two reasons. Firstly, it USED to be amazing...Then all of a sudden, the quality of the food and service kind of crashed. And secondly, what kind of restaurant DOESN'T ALLOW YOU TO TAKE YOUR FOOD TO GO?!??! This is the reason I won't be back. I had gone there with a friend, and we ordered and appetizer to share and then a main dish each. I had the veal with mushroom sauce which in the past was pretty amazing. However, halfway through that dish, I got full (shocking, I know). At the end of our meal, both of us asked for the rest of our dishes to be packed to go and we were told by a very unhappy woman that this would not be possible. Either eat it all here, or too bad. It was SHOCKING. So.....although the food is ok, I won't be returning here. I don't like feeling ripped off, and the fact that they won't give you the rest of your paid-for food, makes me feel totally ripped off.  :|

I must have driven past Franks A Lot one hundred times before I ever thought to give it a chance.  Franks is on the east side of the road that becomes, airlane, right behind the airport.  As I take airlane to work every morning to avoid a few lights, I kept seeing Franks and finally decided to try it for lunch.  

What can I say? A solid hot dog, great price point and an EXTREMELY friendly staff. I haven't pegged if its a family running it from front to back, but I think it is and let me say, they do it well.  There is a drive through as well as basic patio seating.  Make note, they only take cash, but don't worry your lunch wont be more than six or seven dollars anyways.  

Their specialty is the Chicago dog, which is covered in onion, celery salt, sports peppers, and tomatoes.  Grab a side of their freshly made french fries and you are out the door, loving life.  Their menu extends to service polish sausage, cheese fries and even a philly cheese steak, but I have remained loyal to my Chicago dog....for now.  

If you happen to find yourself in the area, I say check it out.

If grandma's creative brain exploded on a Sunday afternoon, this is what it would look like.  They have paints, glues for any surface or material, brushes, picture frames all shapes and sizes, seasonal arts and crafts, beads and bedazzlers, candles galore, styrofoam in weird shapes and blocks, construction paper, wood shelving that you can stain or color any way you like, fake flowers, glass containers, etc.  Also, if you're into scrap-booking Michael's is probably a dream come true.

"The bartender, a reprehensible and detestable female, ostensibly endeavored to proffer an amicable demeanor; however, her inherent misanthropy and acrimonious disposition proved palpable, rendering her efforts futile. Despite this unpleasant encounter, the potables she served were undeniably exceptional, possessing an explosive and gratifying flavor profile that would unquestionably entice my return. Regrettably, the quality of the beverages was juxtaposed by the deplorable customer service, which was characterized by an uncooperative and indifferent attitude, reminiscent of the spiky, inhospitable plant known as Yucca."

Brass metamorphoses into "The Beat" on initial Fridays, and I'll return! Initial Friday is currently appropriate to visit again.

LOCATION: Fremont, of course. However, rather than being down on Fremont, it's up on Fremont! (huh?) :) It's positioned above Hennesy's Tavern. Head upstairs because that's where the celebration is. There's a balcony, so all you smokers may take a smoke break and observe the crazies walking on Fremont. If you wish to exit, there's no issue; Beauty Bar, Vanguard, and Insert Coins are merely across Las Vegas Boulevard, allowing you to bar hop and throng the remainder of downtown.

MUSIC: I believe KidFunk was spinning records. And he didn't let me down. It was a persistent flow of excellent tracks. Many houses and technological houses, with some electro and dubstep thrown in. It was an excellent evening! For the venue's size, there's a fair-sized dance floor. I explored just the main room, but on the opposite side, there's a much more extensive room with a different DJ, presumably playing distinct music. If they maintain it, I will make this a regular stop on the first Friday.

BATHROOMS: They were revolting and filthy. Drinks and other unmentionable items were strewn about the floor. Before you pop-a-squat, double-check that there is toilet paper. The dispensers were consistently empty, so grab a handful of paper towels before entering.

GOGO: Sorry, but the gogo(s) were utterly underwhelming, both in appearance and dancing.

GUYS: There is no dress code or cover charge when I arrived.

Remember to FOLLOW and RATE!;)

Despite my reservations based on the unfavorable reviews, I opted to give this establishment a chance, and my experience validated the prevailing sentiment. The ambiance was visually appealing, but the lavatory presented an unconventional layout. The hand dryer was situated on a single faucet, prompting a sequence of inconvenient delays for patrons awaiting their turn to utilize the facilities while attempting to operate the cumbersome dryer. Furthermore, the absence of sanitary disposal units within the stalls necessitated a departure from the stall to discard items in the central waste receptacle, posing an additional challenge for female patrons. 

My culinary selection was a vegetarian burger, which, although flavorful, was diminutive in stature, inviting comparisons to a slider. The accompanying fries were palatable, yet their portion size was standard, rendering the supplementary fee seemingly unwarranted. Moreover, the minuscule dimensions of the water glasses necessitated a deliberate sipping motion, akin to savoring a fine wine. Following my meal, I remained unsatisfied, capable of consuming a medium-sized popcorn at the cinema without difficulty. 

Regrettably, I must conjecture that this dining establishment may struggle to flourish, given its steep prices and inadequate serving sizes. A revision of their pricing strategy or generosity of portions seems imperative to justify the cost. Notably, the absence of an option to augment the vegetarian patty was conspicuous.

For those stuck in the convention center area, this is a ok place for a beer and pub food.

As a graduate student in the area only to attend a conference, I have been to this bar twice.

The jalapeno poppers and onion rings are a favorite. The buffalo wings are ok...nothing special.

Gets very crowded during games, but makes the place fun.

So, if you are trapped around the area with no car and crave a beer and munchies, this place is A-Ok.

"My dedication towards Sakana remained unwavering for an extensive period of time, up until the momentous occasion of my son's birth. The advent of parenthood introduced a new paradigm, rendering the indulgence of sushi excursions somewhat impractical. Following a hiatus of three years, my spouse and I decided to revive our customary date night ritual by revisiting Sakana. Alas, the experience did not live up to our recollections. The chefs' demeanor exhibited a perceptible shift, manifesting in limited conversation and recommendations, which contrasted starkly with their previously warm and engaging nature. Notwithstanding this disappointment, the scallop dynamite proved to be a resounding highlight, boasting an unparalleled quality that eclipsed all other instances of its kind within the Valley. Likewise, the oranges served as a sweet finale, eliciting nostalgic sentiments that lingered long after the meal's conclusion. It is plausible that my prolonged absence may have unwittingly elevated my expectations, leading to a disparity between reality and my idealized memories."

I like to go here to grab some subs on the way to the river, since it's between our house and the 17. Just because I don't want to go to Subway or Blimpie's.

Mostly, it's a rather expansive Italian market. Need olive oil? They have 20+ different kinds. Pasta? There's a whole aisle. How about one of those wooden thingies for making gnocchi. Got that too.

In the back, a counter runs along the whole length of the back wall. That's where you'll find all sorts of cheeses, cold cuts, and sausauge, plus a few sweets. 

It's also where you order sandwiches. And you'd better know exactly what your want, and fast. The man behind the counter is perpetually surly and curt. It gets worse if you stand there and try to make heads or tails of all the hand-written sandwich combinations taped to the wall. Luckily, the woman who runs the cash register is always very sweet. So that kind of makes up for it.

I want to love their sandwiches. I just don't. They're OK. The meat is always really good, there just isn't enough of it. Maybe I'm just not ordering the right things. 

Until then, I'll continue to support Romanelli's, but they'll only get a so-so rating for the deli. The product selection, however, is top notch.

This establishment provides an adequate dining experience, boasting an agreeable ambiance, commendable customer service, and satisfactory diversion. While the culinary offerings are of acceptable quality, they fail to surpass expectations considering their cost. Specifically, the steaks possess a somewhat advanced stage of maturity, which may not align with my personal preference. However, the potatoes prepared au gratin style prove to be delectable. A diverse selection of wines, suitable for various financial constraints, graces the menu. It remains a viable option for those seeking a pleasant repast within the confines of Green Valley Ranch, although I would advocate for numerous steakhouses located along the Las Vegas Strip instead.

$4 OPI!  Read Carina's review, b/c I didn't want to pay $8.50 at Ulta... geez, so cheap... alot of the OPI colors already have separated (heat?  age?) so make your choice for price over quality... I'm so cool for $4 though.\n\nOn the same end where China Magic Noodle is, same plaza as Lee Lee's.

Went in for an early dinner and ordered the Pot Roast Sandwich. The vegetables came and were not cooked. They were raw, I ate the meat which was great. I told the waitress and she commented that that is pretty normal actually and offered to give me another side vegetable. I am glad that she did that but at the same time was a bit subdued by the fact that this was a regular thing for them. My husband enjoyed his chili burger loads. The drinks we ordered were very strong as well. This place is always busy but perhaps we ordered the wrong food for this place!

"I had the pleasure of consuming a carne assada torta at this establishment, and while it may not have been the most delectable culinary experience, it was, in fact, not entirely unpalatable. Considering the cost, the quality was relatively satisfactory, although there were some notable drawbacks. Firstly, the service was comically disorganized, with no discernible system in place to ensure efficient customer satisfaction. I did eventually receive my meal, but had they implemented a more streamlined process, I would have received it in a more timely manner. Secondly, the grill surface appeared somewhat unhygienic, which raised concerns regarding the overall cleanliness of the kitchen. Additionally, the meat, while not necessarily of poor quality, was slightly overcooked and exhibited a chewy texture, which could have been improved by chopping it into smaller pieces. Lastly, the dining area itself was not particularly well-maintained, further detracting from the overall dining experience. In conclusion, while not an outright failure, this restaurant fell short of exceptional in several key aspects, warranting a rating that hovered between a 2 and a 3, leaning towards the latter due to the benefit of the doubt extended to the staff."
