The ambiance of the bar was bereft of any melodic accompaniment or auditory stimulation, that is, until I entreated the bartender for a second time, at which point a subtle, reggae-inspired tune was faintly perceptible in the background, a sonic element that was ostensibly intended to enhance the overall experience but ultimately proved to be suboptimal due to its barely audible nature; furthermore, the menu did not feature any culinary options that were within my financial means, specifically during the designated period known as "happy hour," although I did partake in a few Cuba Libras, a potent cocktail comprising rum, cola, and lime juice, which I found to be quite satisfying despite their relatively modest price point of three dollars each; lastly, I must admit that I did not have the opportunity to sample the establishment's gastronomical offerings, and thus, I cannot provide an informed assessment of their quality, leaving me in a state of indecision regarding a potential future visit.

"Given our considerable distance from the French Quarter, my stomach infrequently impels me towards Cajun cuisine; furthermore, owing to the limited dining options within our vicinity, this establishment emerges as the de facto venue for satisfying my periodic craving for gumbo; while the quality of the fare may be marginally superior to the local average, the tariffs charged are somewhat elevated relative to our expectations."

"I recently had the pleasure of partaking in a culinary excursion to this esteemed eatery, and while my experience was largely satisfactory, I must confess that it failed to surpass my expectations in certain aspects. Notwithstanding the captivating ambiance created by the restaurant's meticulously designed interior, I found the variety of options available to be somewhat limited. However, I must commend the establishment for maintaining a high standard of quality in their offerings, and the judicious utilization of individual portion control containers served to enhance the overall dining experience. Nonetheless, I cannot help but feel that this buffet fell short of exceptional, particularly when compared to other superior alternatives in the area. Furthermore, I must express my gratitude for having avoided the weekend buffet, which several patrons have described as overpriced and underwhelming. Instead, we opted for the more reasonably priced Monday brunch option, which, while satisfying, ultimately proved insufficient in satiating my gastronomic desires. In conclusion, while this buffet may boast an impressive physical appearance, its lackluster selection and uninspired menu left me feeling unfulfilled and eager to explore alternative dining options."

"Indubitably, my dear fellow, it appears that an abundance of lesbians inhabits Las Vegas, characterized by their predilection for stereotypical attire, such as mullets and jean vests with ripped sleeves, as well as a propensity for muscular physiques. Have you had the opportunity to observe the cinematic masterpiece entitled 'Monster,' featuring Christina Ricci and Charlize Theron? The latter being an exemplary representation of the aforementioned archetype. 

Furthermore, I must jestingly inquire, am I truly the sole individual possessing physical attractiveness? 

As for sushi, while it may be deemed palatable, it remains a rather pricey delicacy, with certain establishments charging exorbitant sums ranging from $15 to $17 for a singular roll of fish. In contrast, a visit to Oakland offers a more affordable alternative, providing an opportunity to acquire a substantial quantity of V's at a relatively reasonable cost."

"The visual representation of the culinary items, specifically the burgers, appeared remarkably striking and potentially harmful to one's health, yet the serving sizes were surprisingly reasonable and easily consumable by a group of five individuals. Our party opted to share several dishes, including the sashimi 'won-tacos,' triple T fries, the signature ringer burger, and the bacon mac-n-cheese burger. It is worth mentioning that we could have easily accommodated an additional menu item. My personal preferences were the fries and the classic burger, as the former offered an exceptional crispiness and an abundance of truffle flavor, particularly the aioi variety. In contrast, the original burger boasted the flavors I find most appealing, although the bacon mac-n-cheese alternative presented a unique and worthwhile combination. While the burgers at this establishment may slightly surpass the average burger in terms of quality, they fail to rank among my top choices for repeated consumption. In fact, I would argue that Bachi burger or even Holsteins offers a superior dining experience. Unfortunately, the tacos were a disappointment, characterized by a minuscule portion of tuna and a lack of creativity. Ultimately, my assessment of this restaurant leads me to conclude that it is only worth visiting for a beer and a side of their delectable fries."

While the desserts are tasty and well made. The prices and service is not. 

You could tell everyone working their just WISHED they were somewhere else at the moment. They could care less about actually serving you unless you asked for help. 

We ordered the sweet trio and my friend told the worker if we could get the second one as the first one was damaged. For some reason she told another worker to do it instead and did not relay the message at all. It was only after we paid and were seated that we noticed that the dessert was damaged and had to bring it back for them to give us another. 

Though not very difficult, we shouldn't have had to deal with that to begin with.

Okay, so I had to do an update.

I was actually at the BuyBack$ location in Henderson near Galleria Mall when we couldn't find what we were looking for.

So we called the location on Decatur to see if they had the movie we were searching for on blu ray.

Oh yes they did!!! Of course they did. They have everything.

So we asked if they would hold the item for us and that we would be there to pick it up shortly, we were across town but were on our way.

So we drive all the way across town and guess what.

These people had the gumption to tell us Sorry, it was actually being held for someone else. They claimed prior to us calling that it was already on hold but in the end that it was up to management's discretion to decide who would get it.

Well, we told you were coming from across town, you told you would hold it for us. So I didn't get it.

What I did get, is that they would get a review update and lose a star.

I am not saying I wouldn't go back but I will NOT go out of my way to return to this location again. 

They lost a very faithful devoted customer.

I've been here several times, and well, it's a chain. I don't usually eat here but my husband wanted to go here. Funny enough, he actually wanted to go to BJ's and was confused. He was disappointed because they only have lager here.

Last night we actually had a 5 star experience. Our server Paul was really phenomenal. Got my kids extra fruit, really knowledgeable about beer (my husband loved chatting with him about beer and brewing) and helped me figure out the rewards program. Great service! Food was pretty good too. Hubby got the fish and chips. Fish was breaded with panko and was nice and crispy. Pretty bland though. The garlic fries were really good. I got the cheeseburger with blue cheese. Nothing phenomenal but good.

Unfortunately, I've had a lot of 1 star experiences here and I think that they are a little too expensive for the quality you get,  that I'm giving GB a 3 star overall. Hopefully last night's experience indicates improvement, but it's really a hit or miss.

The modified text is: "Arrived at this establishment on a radiant, balmy Saturday evening, I couldn't help but feel a twinge of envy towards the individuals reveling in the picturesque backyard patio, their merriment illuminated by the soft glow of suspended white lights, while I was confined to the dimly lit interior. Despite my reservations pertaining to the seating arrangements, I opted for a pear and arugula salad, which, albeit palatable, failed to satiate my hunger, leaving me $8 poorer. It appeared that the majority of my associates had elected to order beverages, which might have been a more judicious decision."

A-OK from me.  In case you can't tell from my other reviews, I'm a happy hour type of guy.  This spot has a good one.  Several appetizers and rolls half off along with good drink specials.  Want a quick roll and Kirin and are on the west side?  Come on in.  \n\nI must say that I prefer Sakana to this if you are going for dinner with someone special, but looking for some rolls and laughs with a few friends, this is a good place to do it.

This store has good prices on many things, some much cheaper than Safeway and others equal to Fry's. It all depends on what you're shopping for. I prefer Fry's in my area of town though because the Albertson's by me ALWAYS smells like rotten fish and enough to make me hurl. \n\nThis location just happens to be by my friend's apartment so whenever we need something we just run in here and get the items. Very easy to get in and out of and very good customer service.

"Our inaugural experience with buffets within this town occurred at this establishment, thereby precluding any comparative analysis with alternative venues. Despite this limitation, the ambiance was pleasant and the price point of $40 per person was reasonable. Although the range of options was somewhat restricted, the quality of each dish was palatable, particularly the Na'an which was so delectable that I could have consumed it in excess. Additionally, my spouse appreciated the slow-cooked beef. While the surroundings were well-maintained and visually appealing, the layout and decor reminded me of a cafeteria, which slightly detracted from the overall dining experience. Notwithstanding this minor drawback, the cuisine was satisfactory, and if circumstances render it the most convenient choice, it would still be a viable option."

We had Lunch there on a Sunday ,pretty busy .
I say the food is ok not a wow but ok.
The service was good and the place looked pretty clean .
They got lots to pick from. 
We did wait a long time for are food.
The prices are not to bad either .
I will give them another try maybe for dinner.

The only downfall is the wait during lunch through the drive thru.  I have always had a long wait but today was horrible.  Only 2 cars in front of me and my wait was over 15 minutes after ordering.  This was for a simple sandwich and smoothie nothing crazy or extreme.  The service is getting slower and slower every time I go.  It's really making me consider avoiding it in the future and it used to be one of my favorite places.

I was suprised how much I liked Kahunaville. Sandwiches are all very reasonably priced- around 11 bucks- and very large. The drinks are spendy like most of Vegas but be nice and they pour stiff. I highly recommend a Bombay and tonic yard. \n\nOur server was very friendly and professional, She did a great job especially since one of my group pulled a rude dipshit maneuver with an empty ketchup bottle.

Typical Panda Express, but add a drive thru. Service is not exceptionally friendly, but lets face it, who cares. You have to deal with the employees for a whole minute and a half. Food is always good, portions are generally good, and close to shopping.

My companion and I opted to engage in an unprecedented escapade and halted at The Lodge for a Happy Hour experience. We were thoroughly delighted with the tariffs, and every bartender/server we encountered exuded cordiality. The deep-fried cheese curds were utterly delectable, incidentally; their flavor was so intense that it nearly eclipsed my capacity to articulate a coherent thought (being a native of Wisconsin, I have an innate proclivity for such culinary delights). Unfortunately, the seating arrangements at the bar left much to be desired in terms of comfort; the stools were so uncomfortable that they bordered on the unbearable. Notwithstanding this minor drawback, we derived sufficient enjoyment from our visit to consider repeating the experience in the future, albeit while occupying a table instead.

P.S. My companion and I found ourselves in a state of utter perplexity regarding whether to document our observations concerning the server whose attire was so scanty that it approached the realm of impropriety. While acknowledging the reality that bars often employ scantily clad servers to augment their patrons' experiences and boost their gratuities, we could not help but wonder if such an outfit was truly necessary or appropriate within the context of a family-oriented establishment like The Lodge. Ultimately, we elected not to comment publicly on the matter, primarily to avoid any potential misunderstandings or conflicts.

This venerable eatery in Edinburgh's West End boasts the distinction of being the city's oldest Chinese restaurant, a claim that has been proudly proffered by its proprietors for over five decades. Its enduring popularity among locals has resulted in a devoted clientele who have been patronizing this establishment for multiple generations. Despite its questionable moniker, the culinary offerings at this restaurant are undoubtedly exceptional, showcasing a masterful blend of Cantonese and Peking cuisine. The menu presents an array of delectable options that can make selecting a dish a formidable task, a predicament exacerbated by the limited variety of desserts, which, unsurprisingly, feature bananas as a primary ingredient. However, the presence of authentic Chinese patrons frequenting this restaurant serves as a testament to its genuine fare and commitment to catering to the discerning tastes of its clientele.

"Although we did not avail ourselves of the accommodations offered by the establishment in question, we must confess that the craps game available therein was truly exceptional, boasting a payout ratio of double on 12, complemented by the unparalleled offer of 100X odds, thereby rendering it an unmitigated delight for those seeking economical diversion within the illustrious Las Vegas Strip. Notwithstanding the somewhat advanced age of the edifice and the pervasive aroma of smoke that permeates the atmosphere, the native patrons are remarkably affable, while the beverages served are passable, if not particularly remarkable."

C'est avec une certaine impatience que je fantasmais sur ce restaurant... un peu trop peut-être.
Nous avons partagé des "croquettes" au foie gras : vraiment rien d'extraordinaire.
Ensuite, je me suis laissée tentée par la cote de cochon heureux: viande tendre et bien cuite, mais la sauce n'était pas assez tasty à mon gout. Mon ami a pris le magret de canard, pour le coup clairement décevant.
Tarte aux pacanes excellente, mais vient-on ici pour ça?

Vraiment contente d'y être allée, mais plusieurs restaurants dans la meme gamme de prix me rendent bien plus heureuse.

This place and other local spots like the Teepee remind us of a far gone time when our Mexican food was predictable and when our standards were low.  But sometimes that hits the spot.  This place definitely has some history, just ask Marty Robbins.

You get what you pay for, yet I wish you could get the basic needs. This place doesn't provide a mini fridge, tea kettle, coffee maker even less a microwave, so you are forced to spend all you pennies buying street food. Also the carpets are pretty old and stinky. Our faucet didn't work, we complained and the next day it was fixed.\nThe plusses were: silent after midnight, so you can sleep pretty well :) and pretty close to everything as well. \nWouldn't mind going back but would check other options first.

This establishment specializing in sushi fare exhibits merely mediocre quality, with an excessive proportion of rice relative to the quantity of fish incorporated into their rolls. Personally, I would prefer to expend additional funds and savor a more substantial meal, rather than merely consuming an abundance of rice. Furthermore, the absence of seating facilities within the premises is a significant drawback. Notwithstanding these limitations, I opt to visit this location during weekdays for a speedy lunch, as the quality of their offerings is comparable to that of pre-made sushi available at upscale supermarkets.

"This establishment offered an acceptable atmosphere, with $4 beer specials that presented a reasonable value; however, the culinary offerings were subpar and overpriced, thereby precluding me from assigning a higher rating. Specifically, the Oyster Po Boy underwhelmed my expectations, and those seeking superior seafood options would be advised to venture closer to the Western coast."

"My experience at this establishment was a stark contrast to the dearth of assistance I received at Fry's. Upon entering the store, I was pleasantly surprised to find that the mini computers, e-readers, and the coveted Kindle I sought were prominently displayed at the forefront of the store, thereby obviating the need for me to navigate the labyrinthine aisles. This was particularly welcome, as I was sporting heels for the first time in an extended period, and my feet were already beginning to protest the unfamiliar terrain. My primary objective was to procure the aforementioned Kindle and expedite my departure; however, my penchant for aesthetically pleasing accessories proved impossible to suppress, and I found myself captivated by a vibrant blue case. Although the selection was limited, I felt compelled to acquire a suitable protector for my new device. My ideal scenario would have involved a pink or Hello Kitty-adorned case, but such options were regrettably unavailable. The staff members demonstrated a markedly superior level of helpfulness compared to their counterparts at Fry's, where extracting information often felt akin to an arduous dental procedure. As we prepared to complete our transaction, the cashier inquired about our possession of their rewards card. While we did possess such a card, I harbored reservations about utilizing it due to a previous incident in which we encountered an inexplicable glitch in their reward system. Following a series of substantial purchases, the associated gifts were erroneously dispatched to an unfamiliar address in Illinois, despite our repeated attempts to rectify the situation through their customer service department and a conversation with a manager. Given the persistent lack of resolution, I cannot in good conscience award this establishment a rating exceeding three stars, as my trust in their capacity to competently manage their rewards program remains dubious."

Club was fairly standard, but the view of the city was amazing on the 53rd floor, although the one drawback of this is the fact that once you look outside, you realize how far you really are from The Strip.  That and the fact that we had very favorable weather conditions, otherwise, going outside would have been an absolute nightmare.\n\nOther than the location of the club, everything about this club screams \"decent, but unspectacular\" which, incidentally, is a very significant accomplishment for the Palms.

We indulged in a culinary excursion at this establishment approximately seven days prior, and our gastronomical experiences were somewhat mixed. While neither my dining companion nor I were particularly impressed by the fare, we did find the victuals to be satisfactory. We opted for the gnocchi accompanied by marinara and the ravioli al formaggio. The former was cooked to a delightful consistency, while the latter's filling was appropriately savory. However, it was the marinara sauce that truly captured our attention, as its flavor profile was remarkably well-balanced and rich. As a connoisseur of this particular condiment, I must confess that it ranks among the finest specimens I have had the pleasure of sampling in recent times. In addition, we requested the caprese as a precursor to our main courses, which, while aesthetically pleasing, failed to elicit any extraordinary enthusiasm. Our server, though, exhibited commendable proficiency in their duties, fostering a welcoming ambiance within the dining area. Notwithstanding, the tariffs charged for the meals were, in our estimation, somewhat excessive given the venue's unpretentious nature and its location within a commercial complex.

"As an ardent admirer of Gordon Ramsay, I have always been captivated by his unwavering dedication to culinary excellence, which resonates with my own unyielding pursuit of perfection during my college years while manning the cast iron grill at Buffalo Wild Wings. Thus, it was only natural that I would be eager to experience the epicurean delights offered at his establishment. Upon entering, I was faced with a daunting dilemma - what to order from the extensive menu? This proved to be a formidable challenge, rivaled only by the complexity of the ACT exam. After deliberating at length, I decided to deviate from my customary burger and instead opted for the pie sampler, reasoning that it would afford me the opportunity to sample a variety of flavors without committing to a single entree. However, this decision ultimately proved to be a miscalculation, as the sampler, though replete with an array of savory pies, left me feeling somewhat unsatisfied due to its modest portion size. Each individual pie boasted exceptional quality, yet this was somewhat mitigated by the fact that it was merely an appetizer, leaving me still yearning for a more substantial meal. In retrospect, I would have been better served by selecting either a whole pie or a burger, or perhaps even pairing the sampler with one of these options. My companion's burger, which I surreptitiously sampled, appeared to be of exceptional quality, and I must admit that I was tempted to pilfer a few more fries had my friend not been vigilant. Notwithstanding this minor disappointment, I am resolved to return and indulge in the delectable burger that had eluded me on this particular visit."

Not the best computer science program.  However, it is a pretty big school.  It has that Arizona feel to it.  The heat can be unbearable at times, and I live in Vegas now.  My classmates were very friendly, but the teachers sometimes were a bit too strict.  The funny thing about this school was how people would steal bicycles and assemble a totally new bike.  So I'd see a bicycle with a bigger tire in the front and a smaller one on the back with different colors of parts attached.  Hilarious.  There are also a lot of people holding signs promoting either their religion or other beliefs.  There's a lot of different type of people here which is why I like it, but then again, I wasn't totally impressed by my teachers which is what I mostly looked for.

This hotel had it's ups and downs. Checked in late on Friday night and the non-smoking room we requested was given away so we had to settle with a smoking room. They told us to come to the front desk between 12-3pm the following day to change rooms since they gave our room away so we agreed. 

Next day rolls around and after a great time at the pool and gym we called and they kept pushing back the time on when the room would be ready. We wasted 5 hours of our day not being able to leave and waiting for our non smoking room to be available. For someone who comes for the weekend and hours are limited it really sucks to waste time. Finally they gave us a non smoking room after complaining for 5 hours and sounding upset. It was a big disappointment. I'm giving three stars because that was an awful experience but the hotel itself wasn't too bad. The room we got upgraded and it was really nice. 

On a positive light the hotel is in the middle of the strip and it's across the street from Cosmo and Bellagio. Had fun shopping and eating at Gordon Ramsey's Burgr place.

I wish I had better things to say, but this is sadly a joint that should have stayed in my undergraduate days. I wanted to say this is for people on budget BUT, its not that cheap either.

The place is decent, clean and the sushi chef is friendly greeting us when we came in and was leaving.

I would say, I wouldn't eat any raw stuff here, and the cooked dish I got was also so-so. Tonkatsu was dry and batter was not really there. $14.50 instead of the $10 lunch price I get at King Muramoto... nah. not gonna work.

The only saving grace was the hot miso soup on the cold day I visited. 

Just not worth the price you pay, and the low traffic in the restaurant on Friday night makes me doubt the freshness of the sashimi and sushi they have.

"GIGANTIC SERVINGS. ENORMOUS. Located within the unremarkable Imperial Palace hotel, situated on the Las Vegas Strip (upstairs), this eatery boasts voluminous compartments, partitioned into two distinct rooms. Upon entering, I was taken aback by the cavernous interior, which belied its unassuming exterior. A humble breakfast consisting of eggs, hash browns, a biscuit, and coffee was my selection. The biscuit, in particular, was suffused with an abundance of butter, exuding an irresistible aroma and warmth. Unfortunately, the sheer magnitude of the meal proved to be too much for my digestive system, as I was unable to consume the entirety of the biscuit or the remainder of the dish. The culinary offerings were undoubtedly delectable, with prices commensurate to the copious amounts of food served. My entrÃ©e, one of the more basic options, cost a reasonable $9, while other dishes exceeded that amount. However, an unfortunate incident marred our dining experience, as a patron, seemingly recovering from a vigorous night of Vegas revelry, precipitously vacated the premises, leaving behind a trail of regurgitated contents. Witnessing such a scene before even finishing my meal was indeed unsettling. Nonetheless, this establishment remains an optimal destination for those seeking a satiating dining experience, perhaps best enjoyed donning protective attire..."

This hotel looks really nice and the staff are really nice. The fitness room has a few different things and they work. The free breakfast is amazing. The room isn't very functional. There's a refrigerator, but no microwave. When I eat out I have leftovers and I hate wasting food. The shower in the single bed rooms is something you would find in a dorm room. It's a tile shower only with a single shelf and there isn't a full shower door. When you stand in the shower, there's always a draft. I'm getting kind of tired of staying at \"nice\" places that are just pretty and serve no function.

I tend to frequent this culinary establishment on Sunday mornings due to their exceptional double stamp days. However, the waiting period can be somewhat vexing, particularly during peak hours on weekends. Nonetheless, such an occurrence is quite predictable. As for the ambiance, I typically visit the location in Chandler, situated off of Ray Road. The atmosphere is incredibly welcoming, and the eatery itself is well-maintained. I thoroughly enjoy the quaint breakfast bar they have established. Concerning the edibles, they are undoubtedly delectable, and the servings are ideally sized for my preferences. Nevertheless, my spouse tends to voice his dissatisfaction with the insufficient quantity of sustenance provided. Fortunately, their innovative $1 menu serves as an effective solution. It offers a diverse array of options to augment one's meal for a mere dollar. Personally, I opt for either the fruit cup or the miniature pancakes. Although I have yet to sample a significant portion of their offerings, their extensive menu can sometimes overwhelm me. On occasion, I have felt the need to indulge in their 7 Veggie Omelette. To my delight, it proved to be remarkably scrumptious! Its nutritional value only enhanced my dining experience. Many of their selections boast an abundance of ingredients, including variants abundant in meat. Unfortunately, their biscuits and gravy fail to impress me. The gravy can come across as rather bland, while the biscuits display an unpleasant chewiness within. In terms of hospitality, the quality can fluctuate. However, I genuinely appreciate the generous beverage cups they provide for takeout. All things considered, this establishment ranks as an excellent choice.

"I have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, with each visit culminating in my fervent decision to adhere to the recommendations proffered by the staff, with the expectation of experiencing a transformative, Superwoman-esque sensation. Alas, such lofty aspirations have yet to materialize. In essence, this venue purveys an array of health-oriented comestibles, including cod liver oil tablets and garlic capsules, among other similar items. The staff, it must be acknowledged, are utterly delightful and display an unwavering dedication to their work. My most recent visit occurred upon learning that ingesting a spoonful of Manuka Honey prior to retiring for the night has the potential to enhance one's complexion and contribute to weight loss. Indeed, the results were palpable, albeit modest in scope; nevertheless, the sensation of improved self-esteem was undeniable. The staff, demonstrating their extensive knowledge, provided me with both the Manuka Honey and cider vinegar for culinary purposes, though the total cost exceeded \u00a340, thereby accounting for the absent dual stars. For individuals genuinely committed to pursuing a path of health and wellness, this establishment constitutes an excellent choice. Conversely, those less concerned with such matters may find their needs better served at Boots."

"Although K Mart may not necessarily possess any particularly distinctive attributes that differentiate it from its competitors, it remains a viable retail establishment where consumers can acquire various items, including those exclusive to the MH brand. As such, it is not uncommon for enthusiasts of the latter to visit the former on a regular basis, during which they may choose to display their dedication to the brand by exhibiting their possession of the coveted Maverick patch."

"The server exhibited remarkable attentiveness and helpfulness throughout our dining experience.  The egg-based dish known as an omelet was quite satisfactory.  However, we strongly advise against ordering the grape leaves, as they were liberally coated with a mysterious, reddish substance that resembled a gelatinous paste.  Upon taking a single bite, we promptly returned the dish, as it was unpalatable.  The ambiance of the establishment was reminiscent of a yellow mausoleum, complete with numerous small, enclosed spaces surrounding the primary dining area, which bore a striking resemblance to niches designed to house urns containing cremated remains.  Given such inconsistencies in the quality of the cuisine, it was apparent that the success or failure of any given dish was largely dependent on chance."

"The pizza served at this establishment boasts an acceptable level of culinary expertise, drawing comparisons to the esteemed Setabello. However, it is worth noting that the menu has undergone a significant reduction in scope, which may limit the options available to patrons. Furthermore, the cost of the pizza, while not exorbitant, does veer towards the higher end of the pricing spectrum. Nevertheless, the staff maintains a commendable level of proficiency, ensuring that the dining experience is both seamless and hospitable."

I had the smothered chicken with mac and cheese and green beans.I can say it was worth the drive from Balyntyne suburbs to get some good ole southern cooking. i got there at 11:30am on a Wednesday... the lunch crowd has not even came in yet so I was 1 of the first customers I gave it a 3.5  star wish could have given it a 4 star mainly the it was too pricey for the amount of food given... A fair price for that plate should have been $7 tops.. I paid $10 an didnt get a drink with it.. Don't think I will be visiting this place anytime soon..

"During our most recent leisure excursion, we opted to halt for a repast at Braddah's Island Style for the second time, and decided to partake in a Kalua pig burrito, replete with seaweed rice, black beans, charred pineapple verde, lettuce, and tomato. Despite the fact that the administration had the temerity to deplete their stock of cilantro, an herb commonly used as a garnish, our burrito remained palatable. However, we noticed a perceptible decline in the cordiality and attentiveness of the staff during this visit, as evidenced by the absence of complimentary samples, uncleared tables, and the delayed provision of condiments, which were only provided following a patron's request after a considerable interval of ten minutes had elapsed. Consequently, we would assign a rating of 3.5 to this dining experience."

"This culinary establishment presented itself in a relatively satisfactory manner, prompting us to peruse their menu and select the egg rolls and grilled pork dishes. However, the duration of time that elapsed between placing our order and the arrival of our meals was truly protracted, particularly considering the modest number of patrons present within the restaurant during our visit. 

Notwithstanding this inconvenience, the interior of the eatery appeared well-maintained and organized. Unfortunately, a considerable quantity of smoke emanating from the kitchen region managed to permeate the primary dining area, perhaps indicative of an issue with ventilation. 

Upon receipt of our order, it became apparent that the egg rolls were diminutive in stature and accompanied by a sweet and sour sauce, rather than the customary fish sauce typically associated with such fare. Furthermore, while the flavor of the grilled pork was undeniably palatable, its portion size seemed somewhat meager in relation to the cost. 

In conclusion, although our experience at this restaurant was not without its drawbacks, it did possess certain redeeming qualities that rendered it a worthwhile excursion. However, it remains uncertain whether a subsequent visit would be warranted."

Decided to yelp for a good breakfast place while I was chilling at vegas and came across this place. 

It was a sunday morning about 10am and it was already super pack. It was about a 30 min wait. Which i thought for good food, should be worth the wait. 

Finally got in and everything look really good. All portions are huge! I end up ordering a original Benedict.

I thought the food was good on presentation but the food was just okay for me. My order was kind of cold which I thought was a buzz kill. It wasn't even a little bit warm. I would think if it was nice and hot everything would have tastes great but I guess i would never know.

Le Marly, a seemingly ordinary establishment, proved to be satisfactory. Although I did not partake in their culinary offerings, I did indulge in their unique beverages. Specifically, their signature raspberry martini, crafted with vodka, raspberry puree, and a fragrant basil leaf, was quite palatable. The majority of their potations, including liquor-based drinks, were priced below $10, with a standard 20-ounce beer costing approximately $7.50. The delectable appetizers sampled by my associates appeared visually appealing, although I did not have the pleasure of consuming them myself. Unfortunately, this modern, purple-themed watering hole, situated in the heart of downtown, does not seem to attract a considerable clientele. During our nearly three-hour visit on a Thursday evening, no new patrons entered the premises. The hospitable staff members, who graciously accepted our outerwear without charging a fee, were attentive to our needs, particularly regarding beverages. While I would not select this venue for an exclusive evening excursion, I would accompany a group if they chose to frequent it.
We eat breakfast here frequently. It's typical IHOP, but the food is fine and the staff takes good care of us.

This hotel is really cool for the younger group, I'd say 27 years and below.  I am thirty and I have to say that although its a great hotel, its not quite my style.

The rooms are pretty good.  They are decorated very sexy but there were a few little things that could have used repair, such as the wall plugs were a little loose and rattley.  Be warned, they have vibrators and lube in the mini-bar, so if you have little kids, probably not the best.

I definitely think that the pool brings in a younger crowd.  I didn't go to the pool, but there were so many guests there in their early twenties, clearly coming from the pool and highly intoxicated and loud that I think the hotel could do without. 

I do recommend eating at the Pink Taco inside the Hard Rock while you are there.  Very good Mexican Food.

I think its a great hotel, but I wouldn't necessarily recommend it to people over thirty and definitely not to people bringing kids.  However, if you are in your twenties, this is the spot.  The guests that were there in the appropriate age range were having the time of their lives.

If you are from out of town, which I assume most people in Vegas are, please note that this is not on the actual strip.  It is really close, but you will have to take a cab ride to and from.

"It appears that our initial intention of partaking in a leisurely luncheon at L'Avenue was thwarted by an extensive queue that extended beyond the entrance, thereby necessitating a modification of our plans. Subsequently, we opted to traverse the street and visit a nearby eatery with an inviting outdoor seating area, whereupon we were delightfully surprised by the culinary offerings, generous portion sizes, and attentive service. Notably, the prices were rendered eminently reasonable due to the copiousness of the servings, and furthermore, pints of Boreale draft beer were available at the exceptionally affordable rate of $5, which struck me as a veritable bargain. It is worth mentioning that the prevalence of individuals in Montreal who customarily consume alcoholic beverages during the midday repast appears to be somewhat reminiscent of certain European traditions, a phenomenon that I wholeheartedly endorse. In conclusion, this establishment may be deemed a reliable venue for a satisfying dining experience."

My boyfriend and I dropped in for the first time on a Sunday afternoon.  The atmosphere was nice and the restaurant was very clean.  Our server Dan was knowledgeable and pleasant. The food was average but good for the price. We will definately be back.

I went here for the first time yesterday and was waiting to meet someone.  When I arrived I wasn't greeted for a good 5 minutes in a mostly empty dining room.  I had to wonder around until someone attended to me.  After telling them that I'd like a table for 2 they sit me at a big table with 5 places as opposed to a booth.   

After my friend arrived our order was taken promptly and our waitress was nice. The food was lukewarm and could have been seasoned better although the meat on my dish was cooked tender and came in a good portion size although there were a TON of onions I'm contrast to the meat portion.  The rice was bland and boring as well.  

The decor looked great and very classy and the staff was overall friendly.  The price was fair for the portion size and I'd be willing to give this place another go, but I hope for better food and someone at the door to greet me right away.

This is one of those three and a half star moments for me, Bison Witches is a sandwich shop with a fairly impressive beer selection and fair prices. I like their chili cheese nachos quite a bit and Kristen likes the miss pris. There's really nothing extraordinary here though, good food, good booze, good service, good prices. It's all good. Three and a half.

"I am thoroughly convinced that this quaint, family-owned eatery is utterly remarkable! The culinary offerings are truly delectable; specifically, I relished every bite of their sumptuous lobster roll complemented by an array of flavorful clam chowders. Although the portion size may not be as substantial as those found at seaside establishments, it nevertheless serves as an effective remedy for my intense yearning for fresh seafood, given my current geographical location in Las Vegas."

Okay, first of all, we have driven by this place maybe 4-5 times a week and thought it was a coffee house. Never would go there with Hava Java as an option. So we were shocked to find out that this was a bar.  Like the atmosphere with good lighting and an all around good feel to the place. Cocktails were spot on. Even with a spilled cocktail the staff was excellent and gave us another at no charge. The food wasn't that memorable. We got the tamale burger. Very dry and the tamale had an off taste to it. On the bright side the fries were delicious. Not sure what spices they put in it, but we thought they had a hint of nutmeg or cinnamon which was very tasty. Definitely go back for drinks and will give the sweet and spicy burger a try. The waitress recommended that! We will reyelp next visit!

"Our inaugural visit transpired two days prior to the culmination of the year, and we partook of their midday repast.  The Green Papaya salad and Panang curry, both piquant and flavorful, garnered our unwavering approbation.  The hospitality we received was quite satisfactory, and the beverage, an icy brew, was quaffed with relish.  However, a cursory inspection of the premises revealed a minor shortcoming; specifically, a negligible amount of detritus was scattered about the floor, which remained unattended throughout the duration of our meal.  Nonetheless, we would unhesitatingly recommend this establishment to any individual who takes pleasure in Thai cuisine...nota bene:  The thermostat settings, purportedly the most scorching, did not quite live up to our expectations."

Not so bad. The entrance looks like a hotel check-in. The security team here was cool, which is refreshing for a club on the strip. Usually security crew's think they are real cops with a Napoleon complex.

It was a week day when I went, so it wasn't too crowded. Lil Jon was playing and he's a decent DJ. 

Since I'm a local and I usually avoid the strip, I was (as usual) SHOCKED when I was told it was $52 for a beer, wine, and a shot for the the birthday boy. This is why I stay away from the strip. Not that it is their fault - that's how they pay their rent. I wish clubs like this would offer local prices even when it comes to drinks. Because seriously we could just stash alcohol in our car and run in and out of the club. It's not like we're staying in a hotel and have no way to get more booze. Just a thought!

Overall, compared to Haze, Tryst, ... (and all the other clubs I've been to but can't remember at the moment), this one was pretty decent. Moon is still my favorite, but XS wasn't bad.

I'd give this place 3.5 stars... after reading the other reviews I expected a half of a cup of pasta or something ridiculous but I thought the portion was adequate. And, I was REALLY hungry when I got there. 

We ordered the olives as a starter (they are all green and served warm) and were able to get some bread to accompany the reserve oil. 

Our server voluntarily explained menu items with important details like: it's ricotta gnocchi, not potato and the extra items in the puntanesca sauce (my recipe only has 7). We both had the orecchiette with sausage and greens. I found it to be a bit oily but the pasta was cooked well. 

He described the deserts perfectly and the chocolate bark with almonds was a nice finish with a second glass of nero d'avalo, and, by the way... I though the wine prices were very reasonable! 

Without tip, we spent about $36 a person and we each had two glasses of wine and left satisfied!

Seemingly, bars such this are effected massively by the clientele. This particular All Bar One, nestled in the middle of Edinburgh's financial district results in mostly desk job monkeys frequenting the place.

One thing I've learnt in my time in Edinburgh is that such clientele and students don't mix. Thus, All Bar One is best avoided .

Drinks, food etc are all pretty standard - not that dissimilar to Wetherpoons in what it offers.

After seeing the Fry's Signature in Scottsdale, I had high expectations with this supermarket. The store was not as fancy, but it was still nice looking. 

Bathrooms are located next to the pharmacy. The air fresheners gave the bathroom an extra touch.

This supermarket has a Starbucks, sushi area, etc. No price scanners though.

Considering that this supermarket is in the middle of nowhere, it does have a lot of customers!

Not a bad place. Service is good with friendly employees. The food, although not the beat does taste good and is fresh.  While there I had the angry whopper. Im not a fan of thick french fries, but theirs was still good. 

What I liked most was their choices of soda. They have "orange coke" flavored soda. I never even heard of it before, so I had to try and and wow. Was it good.  

Sadly the whole time I was thinking there they never swept the floor that needed it. Yeah its a small thing and I am not going to eat off it, but visually it is not appealing. The same is true of their bathroom floor.

I'm here for a convention at the Mandalay and have made this place my go-to spot for two meals. My first night, I had a very good angus steak burger with bleu cheese and mushrooms; with tax, it came to $20. Not cheap but the best value I could find inside of this this giant casino hotel at 9:47 p.m. after checking in!

The next morning, I went back for breakfast. Very pricey to order a meal. So I ordered two side dishes instead: two eggs any style for $8 and home fries for $3. An oversized cup of tea was $3.50, which is a ridiculous price, but it was worth it because it came with a fancy English Breakfast tea bag, honey and there was even soy milk available.

The service here is very friendly and efficient. Not a special restaurant but it will do just fine for a decent meal at a bearable price in this pricey casino complex.

"It appears that I fail to comprehend the essence of this establishment, as my experience was characterized by a profound lack of distinction in all aspects, including the culinary offerings, customer service, and pricing. Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the Kiki burger, which regrettably conformed to the prevailing norm of mediocrity, with certain bites exhibiting an unbalanced sweetness, yet partially redeemed by the savory presence of mushrooms. Furthermore, my order of garlic fries proved to be a disappointment, as the scant portion size belied the deceptive impression of abundance, thereby eliciting a sense of dissatisfaction. Moreover, the hostesses demonstrated a remarkable propensity for accommodating patrons in close proximity to our table, which engendered considerable annoyance, prompting nearby diners to request relocation twice during the course of our meal. In light of these circumstances, I must aver that any future visit would be highly unlikely, as the dearth of exceptional qualities renders this dining establishment unworthy of further consideration."

You should come here to enjoy the atmosphere and to see what the hype is all about. Order a frozen hot chocolate and you've experienced the same Serendipity experience there is to the one in NY. Maybe, not quite since that one is a little shack. Mind you, this frozen treat is super sweet and even though you'll most likely share it with another human being, your'e bound to finish only half of it and leave a bunch of whipped cream behind.

Their food is so-so...typical food you'd find at a TGIF or any other place that serves typical American "bar food." Loaded potato skins for $11? Who are you kidding? Extremely dry chicken dijon pizza for $14? Don't even think about it...you're better off buying frozen pizza and sticking it in the oven yourself. 

Like I said, people come here for the experience and for that, it gets 3 stars! There's just something so 'cool' about the ambiance. It makes us ladies feel special! :)

I've been to the Bank twice and I'm not sure if I'd go back. I think my first trip was an anamoly. The club was poppin with amazaaaaaazing music. I wish I could have got that mix! The club was packed and since the Bank is kinda tiny, it felt like a house party. Everyone was dancing and having a great time, you could really feel the positive energy. We met some cool people and hung at their table majority of the night so it made the night more enjoyable. You never realize how much you value being able to sit down when you want to LOL! I didn't want to leave the club because I was having so much fun, but I had an early flight so I had too :(

The 2nd trip, 6 months later on Christmas Day was less thrilling. I was on the guestlist so we walked right in at like 11. It was DOA and as time went by the club filled up the crowd looked very unattractive. I can't even blame the lameness on the fact that it was a holiday so it may have been so an off night because we left and went to XS and it was packed with better looking people *shrug*. 

Overall I'm thinking that on my first trip to the Bank either I got really lucky or maybe Christmas night  just so happend to be a wrong place/wrong time bust? Maybe the third time will be the charm??

It's consistently pretty good.  It's chain food, and I am a little against big corporate restaurants as they are all pretty vanilla.  That said there is nothing run of the mill about their chambord margarita.

This was our first time going to Tandoori Times.  The atmosphere was pleasant and I thought it would be more crowded than it was.  
The good: the food. Food was great. I had the goat curry which was their Friday special, and it was wonderful.  My husband who doesn't like most curry dishes stuck with the tandoori chicken which was wonderful as well. A side of pesto naan rounded the meal out.  No complaints about the food at all.

The bad: the service.  Our waiter was very polite and friendly the few times we saw him.  He brought us menus and then left us waiting for 15 minutes before coming back to take our order.  He then disappeared for most our meal. We had to ask another server to track him down to get our bill.  Needless to say our drinks were not refilled.  We also waited a very long time for our food.

The ugly: the belly dancing.  Actually it wasn't the bellydancing. More specifically the dramatic rise in music and the incessant finger chimes of the dancer grew to be irritating.  The dancing was fun to watch in the beginning but became tiresome after first few minutes.  It was impossible to chat without shouting at my husband.

Good place. Prices were reasonable and the food was good. But the service needs some work.

My singular annoyance regarding certain high-end eateries is the haughty and discriminatory behavior exhibited by certain front-of-house staff members, such as the hostess in this particular establishment, who not only expressed displeasure at our decision to bring our own celebratory cake but also had the audacity to impose a charge of seven dollars per plate for the supposed privilege of consuming it on the premises, her demeanor towards us resembling that of a condescending aristocrat towards those of inferior social standing.

Upon successfully navigating the gauntlet of the hostess's scrutiny, I opted to sample a Lycheetini from the bar, finding it quite palatable and potentially worthy of further exploration, had I not been concerned with preserving sufficient gastric capacity for the culinary offerings yet to come.

Following our escort into the dining area via a modern elevator, I couldn't help but be impressed by the stylish contemporary Asian motif that permeated the interior design, which was complemented by the attentive and responsive service provided by both our primary server and the supporting staff, ensuring that our beverages remained consistently replenished throughout the meal.

While the fare itself was certainly satisfactory, it was evident that the true value proposition lay not in the food, but rather in the unique ambiance and atmospheric qualities that pervaded the space, fostering an environment conducive to conviviality and relaxation among patrons.

Given the presence of traditional Filipino dishes such as lumpia, pancit, and adobo on the menu, it was reasonable to infer that the head chef was of Filipino descent, leading one of the staff members to inquire as to whether I shared any familial ties with the culinary expert, to which I responded that, while I did not possess any direct blood relations with the chef, I could appreciate the cultural significance and richness of Filipino cuisine.

In summary, The Social House succeeds in delivering an immersive epicurean experience that transcends the mere consumption of sustenance, instead offering a holistic blend of gastronomic pleasure, refined atmosphere, and hospitable service, save for the occasional encounter with supercilious hostesses.

For such a thin pizza, it's really overpriced. I ordered extra cheese as a topping, and it was barely any cheese on the pizza. 
The pizza is much different from what I am usually used to. 

They have only a few items to choose from on the menu, like salad and pizza choices only. 

If it gets cold it pretty much has to be thrown out because it gets really hard even when heated up. 

Great thing about this place is that they use a coal oven. That's really good, it always makes pizza better. 

The pizza was decent, but just not my type.

"The solitary motivation behind my frequent visits to this particular Dunkin' Donuts establishment is due to the fact that the one in close proximity to my residence has an early closing time. Consequently, if I experience a late night yearning for an iced coffee beverage, I am obligated to venture to Sam's Town. While I genuinely appreciate DD's, this specific location leaves much to be desired in terms of quality and consistency. The coffee's flavor profile varies greatly depending on the individual responsible for its preparation. Each time I place an order for the same item, it is as though I am receiving a vastly different product. In contrast, the coffee served at my regular DD's maintains a consistent taste. My fiancÃ© and I have found it necessary to specify our orders in a particular manner contingent upon the person crafting our beverages, and even then, we occasionally receive a concoction that could be likened to a Frankenstein creation. Furthermore, the staff members generally exhibit a friendly demeanor. Nonetheless, there is a young female employee who appears to be present during late night hours and displays visible irritation when a customer enters the establishment. It is my sincere hope that she will undergo an attitude adjustment, as her behavior creates an uncomfortable atmosphere for placing an order."

OK so today someone in my office brought me a sandwich from City Market Deli. It was the Santa Fe Club. Oven Gold Turkey, Bacon, Avocado, Lettuce, Tomato, Alfalfa Sprouts, Chipotle Mayo served on Our Toasted Multi-Grain Bread.\n\nThe bread is very good and the sandwich has a good amount of flavorful turkey. The chipotle mayo has just the right amount of heat. Overall a very tasty sandwich!

let me start off by saying the food itself was definitely a 5. my boyfriend and I split yakitori and onigiri, and I had a pork rice bowl (very fatty but the stuff I did eat was delicious) and my boyfriend got a tuna and salmon salad special from the wall. we also got wine specials from the wall which was only 4 dollars a glass - amazing! the prices were pretty decent overall. we ate as much as we could. now for the not so great part:\n\nwe sat at the bar, it was SO HOT we lost our appetites. the service was good but know it was more of a communal effort than one server. also the food just came out randomly when it was ready not like appetizers then meals. fine with me but some people might not be cool with that. also the place was TINY. we had to wait about 2 minutes to sit, which was fine, but the line was pretty bad when we were leaving.

During our return journey from Las Vegas, we decided to make a brief halt at this establishment, and sample their culinary offerings. My gastronomical inclinations were pleasantly surprised by the quality of the edibles, particularly the dipping sauces, which I found to be more delectable than those proffered by Boiling Crab (LA). However, our server's inability to elucidate the varying degrees of piquancy, coupled with her unfortunate tendency to downplay the fiery nature of certain menu items, somewhat tempered my enthusiasm for indulging in an extensive array of dishes. Specifically, she cautioned against the Cajun fries, characterizing them as excessively fiery, while simultaneously recommending the mild sauce as a safer alternative, despite my explicit expression of preference for pungent flavors. Consequently, I opted for a less ambitious order, forgoing both the Cajun fries and the medium sauce, which, in hindsight, I might have relished had I been adequately informed. Furthermore, an unfortunate mix-up with one of my companion's orders resulted in the substitution of chicken wings for fried shrimp, followed by an interminable delay in rectifying the error and presenting us with an incorrect bill. Despite these drawbacks, I might consider revisiting the restaurant, provided they address their service-related shortcomings.

It's a flat odd coloured mess, I can't wait to go back. I had the Dic Ann cheeseburger and sauce, which is a flat cheeseburger with meat sauce, and they give you a popsicle stick to lift it out of the cardboard basket. And the flattest hot dog with all the fixins, I can't really explain it, but it was squashed and tasty. Think White Castle but with Wolverine-like origins, from the Wilds of the Canadian wilderness, Montreal.

Not my usual Goodwill drop off location, but this is pretty large (locationwise).  Looks like the moved from the stand alone building next door over to where the Hannaford... well I guess the Food Lion is still there, they just gave up some room for the Goodwill to move in.\n\nConvenient drop off location in the back of the building... have to turn around in the loading dock area, but it gets the job done.

I came here the other night because I was craving Banh Mi and I really hate the Banh Mi at Lee's Sandwich. I read somewhat good reviews abotu Mr. Sandwich's Banh Mi so I decided to give it a try.

The sandwiches were definitely better than Lee's, but I have had better. Unfortunately, it was in California that I had better so I'm still on the hunt.

I am, however, intrigued by the other items they have at Mr. Sandwich, so I will be back to try those. Until I find a better Banh Mi spot, I will be coming here to get them.

"The staff members are exceptional in their duties, the eatery maintains a spotless ambiance, yet the culinary offerings somewhat fall short of the standards set by Chipotle. Notwithstanding, the site is highly convenient, boasting a prime location directly across from Wells Fargo. 

My significant other holds this establishment in high regard, particularly due to the singular nature of the buffalo chicken dish, however, despite numerous attempts, I have been unable to completely consume the meal. 

Although I generally relish the bowl, I have also sampled the burrito on several occasions. There exists an inherent desire within me to wholeheartedly endorse this venue. 

The chips and cheese dip remain a consistent favorite, as they have consistently met my expectations."

"Commemorated my inaugural spring training experience on Saint Patrick's Day, indulging in a spirited contest between the Athletics and the Giants, wherein my kinfolk were divided into two factions, donning the respective liveries of their preferred teams. Initially, I must confess that I was rather taken by the commodious dimensions and welcoming ambiance of the ballpark, devoid of any unseemly vantage points. Moreover, the parking facilities were both reasonable in cost and copious in quantity. Furthermore, the concession stands offered an impressive array of refreshments, augmented by an abundance of staff members circulating throughout the venue, dispensing beverages from buckets with alacrity. However, certain drawbacks did manifest themselves, specifically pertaining to the seating arrangements; specifically, those situated in the outfield were somewhat diminutive in stature, rendering them less than ideally suited for individuals of more imposing physiques. Additionally, the absence of grassy expanses in the outfield proved somewhat disconcerting. Nonetheless, I must aver that my overall enjoyment of the game remained undiminished, further heightened by the Giants' triumph and the convivial atmosphere that permeated our gathering. I accordingly anticipate the prospect of revisiting Scottsdale Stadium in the future."

"It appears to be a competition to determine who can consume the largest quantity of flesh in the shortest period of time. The culinary offerings at this establishment were satisfactory, albeit it took an extended duration for the various meats to arrive, resulting in a limited sample size of each selection. Additionally, the venue's diminutive size and cramped atmosphere, coupled with an underwhelming array of side dishes and exorbitant beverages, contributed to an overall sense of disenchantment. Even with prior reservations, the prolonged delay only served to amplify my disappointment, rendering any potential enthusiasm for a future visit nonexistent."

"Upon entering the establishment, I was immediately struck by the warm and welcoming ambiance that permeated the atmosphere, which was further enhanced by the pleasant temperature that facilitated my comfort and enjoyment of the culinary offerings available. Specifically, the chicken wings were of exceptional quality, with the Maui Wowi and Hot Ranch sauces serving as the perfect complement to their natural flavor. However, despite the excellence of the food, I would not recommend dining in, as the layout and decor of the restaurant did not particularly lend themselves to an intimate or relaxing experience. Nevertheless, I did notice that the establishment offered a unique and spacious area designated for private gatherings and celebrations, which could potentially be taken advantage of for future events."

"Esteemed patrons, allow me to enlighten you about an eatery that embodies the epitome of culinary excellence, nestled discreetly off the beaten path of Wynn Road. This unassuming establishment faces formidable competition from neighboring Korean and Vietnamese restaurants, yet its delectable offerings are a testament to the proprietor's commitment to serving authentic, home-style cuisine. The Panang and Veggie green curries, for instance, evoke memories of a lovingly prepared family meal, while the complementary soup accompanying the lunch special boasts an impressive medley of savory ingredients, sans the ubiquitous MSG. My personal experience with the Sliced beef noodle soup, Thai style, however, fell short of my expectations, as the dish lacked the anticipated complexity of flavors, instead presenting a rather straightforward amalgamation of beef broth and pho-like noodles. Nonetheless, this venue merits a five-star rating, owing to its exceptional service and dedication to providing a warm, welcoming ambiance."

Token Limit: 512 tokens
Accepted Token Types: Letters (a-z, A-Z), digits (0-9), spaces, punctuation marks (.,!,?, -)

Input: The text is: "Not sure what's going on, slow service many of their own beers out of stock on a slow Sunday evening.\nFood was so slow I cancelled my entr\u00e9e and left."
Output: The modified text is: "Uncertainty permeated the atmosphere, as a sluggish pace characterized the provision of refreshments, with numerous varieties of artisanal beverages unavailable for an extended period during a tranquil Sunday evening; regrettably, the culinary offerings were similarly delayed, prompting the cancellation of my principal dish and an early departure."

Doc and Eddy's offers an acceptable dining experience, albeit unremarkable and unexceptional. It may serve as a suitable venue for gatherings of a larger group of individuals seeking basic bar fare and beverages, given its expansive dimensions that preclude a sense of confinement. In the rear of the establishment, numerous pool tables and assorted games provide entertainment for patrons. The front area features additional tables designated for culinary consumption, while television sets are ubiquitous throughout the premises. During a recent visit, I sampled the SoCal Chicken Sandwich and found it to be merely satisfactory, with a slightly desiccated texture. However, I did appreciate the seasoning applied to my fries. The cuisine at Doc and Eddy's is adequate for a bar, and I surprisingly felt satiated upon conclusion of my meal. Service was adequate, yet unremarkable, as it met the bare minimum requirements for satisfaction without compelling generous gratuity. Previously, my experience with the service at this establishment was subpar. Notably, my draft beer was served with insufficient foam, which, while not excessively frothy, was still deficient in this regard. Given its proximity to my residence, I envision revisiting Doc and Eddy's on occasion, although its unexceptional offerings do not particularly entice me.

very elegant but after  our bad day we decided to eat here and this was our last day so we enter it was clean only few people by the bar I order the fagioli soup  it was good, and veal piccata I did like the flavor but vegetables to plain of flavor, hubby order lasagna he didn't like it  and the bread they serve it really good also the vinaigrette they serve I really love he flavor so it was good for the prize we pay

"So, one might wonder, given the ostensible quality of the performances hosted at this venue - BRMC, The Black Keys, and Guster, all of whom delivered exceptional shows, it must be said - why does it not garner a higher rating, say, of four or five stars? Well, my dear reader, let me elucidate. Firstly, there are the exorbitant fees associated with online ticket purchases, which, when combined with the additional five-dollar parking charge, result in an aggregate increase of ten to twelve dollars per ticket. Now, were these surcharges to benefit the performing artists themselves, one might be inclined to turn a blind eye. However, I assure you, the maintenance costs of the facility do not warrant such excessive fees. In essence, it is a large concrete room, albeit one with a sloping floor designed to afford prime views of the stage from any vantage point. Admittedly, the drink selection is satisfactory, the prices reasonable, and both security personnel and restroom facilities are adequate. Furthermore, it is undeniable that this venue attracts high-caliber acts, making it a worthwhile destination for music enthusiasts such as myself, who must, perforce, selectively seek out musical experiences in this, the fifth most populous city in the United States, wherein live performances by notable artists are often few and far between."

Jollibee has been my favorite fast food ever since I was a little girl.  My mom used to take me to Jollibee for my birthday - so it's quite memorable to me.  

The Jollibee in Las Vegas was the first Jollibee I have ever visited outside the Philippines.  My first visit was a while back (not so sure about the date maybe 5 years ago), but I go to this place at least once or twice a year.  

My favorite food in Jollibee: Chicken Joy with spaghetti, Peach mango pie
Other than my favorites, I think everything else is OK.

My parents Like to come here, so I often meet them for lunch.
This means free food for me, so the price is awesome.
Service is always friendly, and the food is pretty darn good.
I love a cold beer and some fried zucchini, and they have it, so that's pretty sweet.
They could expand on their beer selection, that would be OK by me.

Convenient location, cold beer, tasty BBQ.  Even if I did have to pay I think I would come here.

"I recently visited this establishment during the autumnal season, seeking to indulge in their alleged 'fall pumpkin pretzel.' Upon entering the premises, I was immediately struck by the stark simplicity of the interior design, which seemed to lack the festive embellishments that would have enhanced the ambiance and enticed potential patrons. The staff, while not overtly rude, did not exactly exude warmth or hospitality, their demeanor being somewhat perfunctory and detached. The menu offered a meager selection of five flavors, supplemented by a'special of the day' that coincidentally corresponded with the pumpkin-flavored item I had intended to sample. Unfortunately, the pumpkin pretzel failed to live up to my expectations, its flavor profile being largely reminiscent of cinnamon and sugar, with only subtle hints of pumpkin essence discernible. Despite these shortcomings, the culinary offering was not entirely without merit, possessing a certain tantalizing quality that may justify future visits, provided the proprietors choose to expand their repertoire of flavors."

How I have not written a review for the Palazzo as many times as I have stayed here I don't know. I guess what happens in Vegas really stays in Vegas! Anyway, it is a great hotel, great location, the rooms are a good size and split between a sleeping and living room type areas. What I can't stand and why I don't stay here anymore is the bathroom lighting. It is so dim and so bad you can't do your makeup at all. It totally sucks.

"I have had the pleasure of visiting this esteemed establishment on multiple occasions, specifically during those nocturnal hours when the ambiance is at its most vibrant and the clientele is at its most diverse. It is my observation that the venue has a propensity to become overcrowded, to an extent that is unparalleled by any other Southside establishment, ostensibly due to its novelty and burgeoning popularity among the local populace. However, on evenings when the throng is less oppressive, the atmosphere at Local can be quite convivial, particularly when enjoying the balmy summer air on the outdoor patio. The demographic that frequents this establishment is characteristic of the Southside bar scene, yet, if one is seeking an atmosphere of refinement and urbanity, perhaps a different locale would be more suitable. Notwithstanding, the patrons are generally affable, the service is prompt provided one can successfully navigate the barrier of patrons, and while the tariff for potent potables may be slightly elevated, the overall experience at Local remains an enjoyable one, particularly during the warmer months when the weather permits al fresco revelry."

"While the overall ambiance of the establishment was satisfactory, my visit to peruse the PlayStation 3 and associated software proved to be somewhat anticlimactic due to the advent of Black Friday, which promised more favorable prices. Thus, I opted to explore the premises in search of compact discs and digital versatile discs, only to find an underwhelming assortment, given the current ubiquity of streaming services and digital acquisition methods. Nonetheless, the store's personnel were quite hospitable and proffered assistance in locating specific items, thereby contributing to a partially redeeming experience."

Got a cotton candy-flavored sorbet superimposed upon a bed of rich vanilla custard, which was embellished with a generous sprinkling of multi-colored sprinkles. The overall taste experience was nothing short of sublime, with the sweetness perfectly balanced to avoid being overpowering. The texture of the custard was remarkably smooth and velvety, possessing a luxurious quality that made me concerned for the structural integrity of the flimsy plastic spoon provided by the establishment. Although the service was generally helpful and accommodating, the demeanor of the servers seemed somewhat lackluster and mechanical, giving the impression that their presence was not entirely voluntary. The interior design of the shop evoked a sense of familiarity and comfort, reminiscent of a Baskin Robbins ice cream parlor, albeit with a slightly more dimly lit atmosphere. To optimize the enjoyment of your visit, it is recommended that you request your order to-go and partake of it in the proximate park, thus enabling you to savor the flavors and textures without being burdened by the constraints of a traditional dining setting.

It's a decently good sized store with lots of cheap stuff that is almost fashionable.  There were lots of people in the store and people buying quite a bit of clothes.  Not certain why I ended up dropping dough but somehow I felt like I just needed to have something new to carry around and bring home I guess.

We have friends who rave about mu shu. We like it, but not enough to make it regular, and we live just a few blocks away. Price/value is measured in pounds. Friendly service, still it's cafeteria quality

Throughout our numerous excursions to Arizona, we invariably found ourselves passing by Nielsen's Frozen Custard while en route to and from our accommodations and our daughter's residence. On each occasion, I would mentally note that we absolutely had to sample their offerings. Unfortunately, we frequently encountered the establishment during its closure, thereby thwarting our intentions. However, during our final visit (which coincided with our daughter's relocation), we finally managed to arrive at the establishment when it was open for business.

Upon entering the premises, we were taken aback by the discovery that Nielsen's Frozen Custard offered more than just frozen treats; they also served an assortment of meals, including burgers, sandwiches, and salads. Our primary focus, however, remained the frozen custard.

We were warmly received by a courteous young woman who attended to us from behind the counter. She exhibited great patience as we carefully scrutinized the extensive menu featuring an abundance of toppings. Ultimately, I opted for a modest cup of vanilla frozen custard adorned with sprinkles, while my spouse selected a small, unembellished chocolate custard. Following our order, we were assigned a number to display on our table, and the young woman promptly delivered our selections.

Both my companion and I concurred that the texture of the frozen custard was pleasantly smooth and creamy. Regrettably, we found that the flavors did not live up to our expectations. Neither the vanilla nor the chocolate variant possessed a robust sufficient flavor, which proved somewhat disillusioning. Despite this, we do not lament attempting it. Had we not done so, the omission would have persistently troubled me, leaving me wondering if we had missed out on something truly exceptional.

Clean moderately priced hotel. Came in during CES week and paid about 160$ a night for 4 nights. Got a smoking room, you can hear plumbing next door, stains in the bath and toilet from cigg burns, sitting chair had white stains on it. It costs 5$ for hot water! It seems it's always the expensive hotels that don't have a microwave, coffeemaker, fridge, and charge an arm and a leg for stuff like hot water, and wifi.  Anyhow I got smart and just heated up my water with a glass cup and the iron. PH you think you can work me, but no no no.. LOL.

"The Beehive, situated within Edinburgh's historic Grassmarket district, boasts an extensive array of libations and a commodious interior, replete with a sophisticated ambiance that exudes an air of refined conviviality. Patrons seeking a respite from the bustling thoroughfares may opt to indulge in the tranquil delights of the establishment's secluded rear garden during the balmy summer months, while those desiring a more rarefied dining experience can ascend to the second floor, where a serene and intimate setting awaits. Additionally, the Beehive has cultivated a reputation as a stalwart purveyor of unconventional comedic performances during the city's renowned arts festivals, with a diminutive, albeit charming, upper-level space metamorphosing into an inviting and captivating venue for avant-garde and surrealist entertainment. Kudos, Beehive, for your steadfast dedication to catering to the variegated preferences of your clientele."

We go to this location when we don't feel like driving too far, or are in the shopping plaza and need to get feeder crickets for our lizards. 

it is always a hassle to find someone to help us, even after asking 3-4 people. The cashiers are generally friendly, and have offered discounts for standing in line for more than 2 minutes while they are having issues getting a customer through the checkout process.

We will go back for the same reasons we go there in the first place, it isn't our first choice for pet stores to go to though.

"This particular Fry's location has made considerable strides in terms of its product offerings, boasting an extensive array of superior quality and diversity, encompassing both conventionally grown and organic produce, as well as an assortment of artisanal breads. Furthermore, the meat department generally maintains an adequate inventory of fresh cuts, although the availability of lamb and seafood can be somewhat unpredictable. Specifically, the acquisition of farm-raised, color-added salmon from the East Coast remains a mystery to me, particularly given the proximity and superior quality of Northwest salmon. However, my primary grievance with this establishment pertains to the subpar service proffered by the deli staff, whose sluggishness and ineptitude have led to numerous instances of prolonged waiting times, ultimately prompting me to either abandon my order or avoid the deli altogether."

"It perplexes me as to why they opted for the appellation 'Barcelona,' given the dearth of genuinely authentic Spanish culinary offerings; however, I must admit that their tapas are rather delectable. It would be beneficial if they proffered a more extensive array of tapas, as it would cater to a broader spectrum of palates. The service we received was exceptional, and I would highly recommend visiting during their half-price night promotion. Additionally, I suggest sampling their Sangrias, as they offer complimentary taste tests."

"I am perplexed by the prolonged waiting period of two hours; it seems disproportionate to the quality of service and cuisine offered at this establishment. My interactions with the hostess have been less than satisfactory, as she has exhibited an aloof demeanor during our brief encounters. Notwithstanding, we opted to partake in a variety of dishes, including the pork belly tacos, bone marrow, tzatziki dip, skewers accompanied by chimichurri, and a sushi roll. While the culinary offerings were palatable, they failed to impress us with their flavors and presentation. Specifically, the skewers lacked a certain je ne sais quoi that would have elevated them to the next level. We also sampled the pistachio ice cream, which, although enjoyable, suffered from an unfortunate lack of texture due to its rapid melting upon arrival. In conclusion, based on my underwhelming experience, I find it challenging to comprehend the widespread acclaim surrounding this restaurant, and thus, I am unlikely to return in the near future."
