My steak was overcooked, nowhere near medium rare, I could of made a scene and complained but my body was in much need of protein so I ate it and told our waiter to notify the chef about the overcooked steak. They apologized and offered me a new steak but I was in a rush and hungry so I was letting it slide.  Giving it another chance next time I come back to Vegas

Establishment 4/5
Waiter/Staff 4/5
Food 3/5
Price 2/5 (lower score the pricer it is)
Cleanlines 4/5

Overall 3/5

Vovomeena's whereabouts proved to be rather elusive and challenging to pinpoint, as its inconspicuous location made it nearly invisible to the naked eye, even when traversing thoroughfares such as McDowell or 7th Avenue. The absence of conspicuous signage only exacerbated our difficulties in locating the establishment, leading us to circumnavigate the surrounding area in search of the enigmatic eatery. Ultimately, it was only by virtue of my sibling's guidance that we were able to unearth the hidden gem, albeit with a modicum of perseverance and determination. 

My culinary exploits at Vovomeena were somewhat underwhelming, as my order of the "banging pocket" failed to live up to its promising moniker. The dish itself consisted of a pita stuffed with sausage and eggs, accompanied by a side of potatoes; however, the lack of additional ingredients such as onions or mushrooms rendered it somewhat unremarkable. 

The restaurant's seating capacity was also somewhat limited, making it advisable to arrive at an early hour to secure a table, lest one finds themselves relegated to the outdoor seating area, exposed to the sweltering temperatures. An installation of misters could potentially alleviate this issue. Notwithstanding the aforementioned drawbacks, the quality of service at Vovomeena was quite satisfactory, despite the considerable distance traveled for a merely passable dining experience.

This establishment would warrant a rating of three and a half stars, taking into account its antiquated Vegas ambiance, reasonable pricing, dazzling illuminated spectacle, and predominantly local clientele. The frozen chocolate-covered bananas available for a mere ninety-nine cents are an absolute delight! Hennessey's restaurant offers an exceptional value with a menu featuring delectable options. The opportunity to engage in twenty-dollar blackjack games and partake in complimentary performances (ranging from mediocre to impressive) further enhances the appeal of this venue. However, it is important to note that the presence of discourteous individuals is ubiquitous and cannot be avoided entirely. Additionally, the low ceilings within the gaming facilities result in an atmosphere heavily saturated with cigarette smoke. While it is not advisable to venture too far away from the light display, it is reassuring to know that there is an adequate number of security personnel present along the main thoroughfare. In summary, this destination presents a refreshing alternative to the contemporary, large-scale corporate character of the Las Vegas Strip, lacking perhaps in gastronomical excellence but simultaneously offering a considerably more affordable experience. Ultimately, it caters to those seeking amusement and entertainment, providing a unique blend of attractions within a compact three-and-a-half block area. It is essential to recall that the essence of Las Vegas revolves around enjoyment and diversion, and the Fremont Street Experience effectively distills these qualities into a concentrated and captivating encounter.

From all the other reviews I read it appears my experience was the same as many others: great atmosphere, good good, terrible service. 

I go up for a refill of my coffee and a worker is standing in front of the espresso machine pouring herself and drinking espresso shots. After standing there for about a minute I finally say something to her, "Could I please have a refill?" She then decides to acknowledge my existence and hastily pours me a refill. 

The coffee tasted great and so did my sandwich, but I don't think I should have to wait for the barista to finish her self-poured shots of espresso before I'm allowed to get my refill.

"Although the accommodations at this particular lodging establishment may not be deemed as opulent or luxurious as those offered by other, more high-end resorts in the vicinity, they are, in fact, relatively satisfactory, especially considering the reasonable tariff associated with them. The guest quarters I had the pleasure of occupying, for instance, were adequately furnished and maintained, with the exception of some minor blemishes on the drapery, which, however, did not detract significantly from the overall ambiance of the space. Furthermore, the on-site gaming facilities and entertainment options, including a variety of dining establishments catering to diverse tastes and preferences, were found to be on par with industry standards, albeit not particularly extraordinary or exceptional. It is worth noting, however, that for patrons seeking a more elevated level of comfort and luxury, it may be advisable to consider alternative accommodations, such as those offered by Caesar's or Mandalay Bay, which, while commanding a slightly higher tariff, provide an enhanced degree of opulence and indulgence."

Dalkeith Road is so sad-looking. I don't know how a street can looks sad, but it does. It's sort of saying 'I'm out of the way, I'm long and there are other roads parallel to me that are much better and get there quicker. sigh.' Is it possible to feel sorry for a road? 

Anyway

C's Tasty Bites thus lacks the va va voom I look for in a snack shop. It tries, nonetheless, and 10/10 for effort. 
The place itself is small, I think too small to breathe so only ever come here for take-away. The price is alright and the food isn't amazing, but maybe i;m lacking enthusiasm because when I leave i'm left with Dalkeith road. aw.

Came for a drink after work before I went home to surprise and was told that if was going to pay by debit that I would have to spend $10 minimum. Why can't you pay for what you order regardless of what type of payment you use. Normally I would drink more than $10 worth but today happened to be a day that I can't stay long. And to top it off I asked if I could pay with cash for my one drink with cash, which you can but, the ATM was out of service... Normally I don't care but that I did...

MGM is a decent place to stay if you can get a good rate... Check-in/out is a waiting game, as with any other hotel on the Strip. My room was actually much nicer than I expected, and I especially loved the blackout shades. They really work!... Internet was fairly fast, the minibar selection is good, and I was fortunate to be on a quiet floor.

Their higher-end restaurants were also better than expected, except for Fiamma- blecch

Negatives included boring, often rude blackjack dealers, poor cocktail service in the blackjack area, very little shade available at the pools unless you purchase a cabana (and, you know, it's HOT in the Vegas sun... there was also very limited waitstaff working the pools), the room air conditioner couldn't keep my room cool, and huge crowds everywhere

Overall, if you like staying on the Strip, this isn't a bad place. There are better hotels, and there are certainly worse places

"The staff members appear to be selectively attentive, wherein they opt to listen only to the aspects of customers' orders that align with their preconceived notions or preferences, thereby conveniently disregarding the remaining components of the instructions. This phenomenon was exemplified when I barely managed to utter the word 'cafe' before the staff member in question hastily departed, leaving me wondering whether my desire for condensed milk had been adequately conveyed. Furthermore, the menu's layout seemed to be intentionally designed to perplex and confuse, with an absence of rice plates as the primary option, which struck me as a glaring oversight. Notwithstanding my grievances, the egg rolls were indeed impressive, boasting an abundance of filling; and the coffee, though served via an antiquated metal drip mechanism, was nonetheless palatable, particularly when accompanied by a cup of ice. As for the pho, while its quality was undeniable, the sweltering temperature of 105 degrees Fahrenheit made consuming a sizeable, steaming bowl of noodles somewhat less appealing."

"The culinary establishment under investigation is situated within the lobby premises of the Westin hotel, where I was temporarily residing; however, I refrained from partaking of their gastronomical offerings due to their subpar ratings on the popular review platform, Yelp. On the final evening of my tenure, I was exhausted and had worked late into the evening, thus opting to sample their fare.  

Upon perusing their bill of fare, I discovered an array of delectable options, including an assortment of seafood and sushi dishes that piqued my interest, although I ultimately settled on a pair of sushi rolls. The quality of the sushi was satisfactory, and their draft beer selection was quite impressive. Based solely on the culinary aspect, I would assign a rating of 3.5 stars, nearing the threshold of four; however, this assessment was derived from a limited sampling of their offerings. Thus, I shall endeavor to partake of their cuisine once more. 

Unfortunately, their service left much to be desired, potentially contributing to their mediocre reputation. The bar area was moderately populated, while the dining area was largely unoccupied; yet, patrons seated at the bar were compelled to signal the bartender to garner his attention, and the preparation time for my meager order of two sushi rolls exceeded 25 minutes. These factors might account for their suboptimal rating. Since I shall likely be extending my stay at this Westin for an indeterminate period, I shall consider giving their eatery another chance in the future."

"The positive aspects of this establishment are numerous; specifically, the flavors of the pork dishes are exceptional, and the variety of options available is impressive. Additionally, the team responsible for serving patrons is both clean and friendly, creating a welcoming atmosphere for all visitors. However, there are some areas that could benefit from improvement. Firstly, upon arriving for a late lunch, I noticed that the food did not possess the optimal level of freshness or heat that I would have expected. This may be attributed to the fact that I visited during an off-peak hour, and thus, the items were not as piping hot as they could have been had I arrived during the traditional lunch or dinner hours. Furthermore, I suggest that the sauces be served at a warm temperature rather than being cold, which would enhance the overall dining experience. Despite these minor drawbacks, I thoroughly enjoyed my visit and would unquestionably return to sample more of their delectable offerings. The concept itself is innovative and well-executed, making it a standout establishment in its genre."

Tried the brisket the other day, and it was excellent.  Juicy and tender, it's a definite re-order.  They put the sauce on top, next time I'll ask them to put it on the side, so I can just eat some brisket by itself.

"Expended two hundred dollars on a culinary experience for two individuals at an upscale dining establishment, precipitating elevated anticipations. Unfortunately, my significant other's cut of meat, specifically the steak, was overcooked and lacked succulence, while the supplementary sauces presented were not merely unimpressive but also unpalatable. In contrast, my Beef Wellington was of satisfactory quality, albeit not exceptional. Furthermore, the macaroni and cheese accompanying the dish was excessively arid, prompting inquiry into the cause of such an anomaly. Considering the totality of factors, including ambiance and service, a sense of disappointment permeated our dining experience, leading me to conclude that future patronage would be unwarranted. However, I may opt to sample their burger alternative at a subsequent date."

Located in close proximity to the renowned Rio All-Suite Hotel and Casino, the Flamingo hotel boasts an unparalleled position, rendering it easily accessible by foot for those who relish a leisurely stroll along the Las Vegas Strip. However, it is worth noting that the pedestrian route traverses an overhead bridge above the highway, which may not be the most scenic or enjoyable trek. Despite its unpretentious nature, this establishment offers exceptional value for money, with tariffs that are considerably reasonable compared to neighboring luxury resorts. As a subsidiary of Coast Properties, this hotel benefits from an abundance of on-site facilities, effectively rendering it self-sufficient and obviating the need for guests to venture beyond its confines in search of dining or entertainment options. Thus, for travelers seeking a relaxed ambiance and economical accommodations, this venue is certainly worthy of consideration, allowing them to experience the vibrant spirit of Las Vegas without breaking the bank.

Didn't come here to eat just drink but can't really go wrong with 2.50 coronas this is definitely is a college bar and a bit noisy what's wierd is there Oregon duck fans and not ASU fans? Great place for day drinking though

Typical mall but a bit over priced and not geared towards locals. Definetly a tourist trap mall but still has a few nice specialty shops and occasionally a good sale here or there. The coffee bean here is awesome and the mall has free yoga on sundays at lululemon so thats a plus as well.
Popped in for a few tacos today... The carne asada was lacking in flavor, no marinade, and pretty bland. The carnitas were very good and I'd eat a dozen at one sitting :)

"A pleasant regional venue offering delectable cuisine and an expansive outdoor area ideal for leisurely summer gatherings. While the interior ambiance may be somewhat dim, the culinary offerings more than compensate for this minor shortcoming. However, the placement and size of the televisions could be improved to enhance the overall viewing experience for patrons. Locating this establishment may prove somewhat challenging for the uninitiated, but once arrived, visitors can enjoy a welcoming, well-maintained, and secure environment."

This is your average Chinese restaurant. Cheap but average food. They have a really cheap lunch menu, for only $5.95 you get an entree and a drink.
Their customer service is very good. They checked on us on a regular basis and refilled our drinks in a timely matter. 
The food is just ok, but again you get what you pay for.
I found it kind of strange that they do not believe in plates.  The food is delivered on styrofoam and no serving spoon, which makes the food look even less appealing. 
Overall, the restaurant is just ok if you are looking for a cheap and quick meal.

I've frequented this location a couple times & I've never had an issue with them, service or food wise. I just enjoyed a peanut buster parfait & it was just like the picture, how many restaurants can say that!, lol  when I'm in the mood for DQ & I'm in the area I'll stop in here for a bite

After experiencing such a deplorable episode at Babystacks (refer to previous review), my acquaintance and I opted to venture towards Lulu's, seeking a more satisfactory dining experience. The stark contrast between the subpar service we had endured and the hospitable treatment we received at Lulu's was indeed palpable. Despite the fact that orders are placed at the counter, the eatery offers the convenience of seating in the Metro pizza area, which is particularly advantageous for families with young children. Additionally, the staff kindly delivered our beverages to our table, further facilitating the dining experience for us. When my companion requested that her egg be prepared over hard instead of over easy, the kitchen staff did not display any signs of annoyance or reluctance, illustrating their commitment to customer satisfaction. On previous occasions, the manager has exhibited exceptional kindness and made conscious efforts to ensure that we felt welcome.  

My culinary selection for the morning was the Herman breakfast sandwich, priced at approximately $8, which, although somewhat expensive, offered a satisfying combination of flavors and textures. The sandwich itself consisted of a pretzel bun adorned with a fried egg, sausage, cheese, and a tangy stone-ground mustard. While the chocolate croissant failed to meet my elevated standards, as I am a self-proclaimed connoisseur of the classic French pastry, the lemon tart proved to be a delightful surprise, evoking memories of a delectable sour cream lemon pie crafted by my spouse. The establishment customarily offers complimentary samples of cookies and muffins, contributing to the overall pleasant ambiance.

"While my sojourn in Phoenix was underway, I elected to peruse the evaluations on Yelp to identify an optimal purveyor of donuts that could cater to my unwavering predilection for the delectable treat. Although Lamar's positioned itself as a mid-range establishment, my expectations remained grounded in the hope of securing a scorching hot and fresh batch of classic glazed donuts, which, regrettably, proved unattainable during my visit. However, despite the absence of optimal donut consumption conditions, my overall experience did not descend into utter disappointment."

Reid's purports to offer distinctive comestibles, and indeed, their gastronomic offerings are somewhat remarkable. Upon entering the establishment, one cannot help but be struck by the visually appealing display of artisanal meats and Fromagerie. The proprietors have curated an impressive selection of vintages, which patrons may sample in the adjacent wine bar, an intimate setting conducive to conviviality. Service is generally efficient and personable, particularly during the noontide hours when the throngs of hungry patrons descend upon the premises seeking sustenance. Observing the culinary creations emerging from the kitchen, one notes that they appear fresh and appetizing. Regrettably, the parking situation is less than ideal, necessitating a moderate hike for those who opt to drive. Furthermore, this writer found the grilled pimento cheese sandwich to be somewhat disappointing, lacking the piquancy one might expect from such an offering and bordering on excessive lubricity. Notwithstanding this minor setback, Reid's remains a suitable option for those seeking a hasty, satisfying repast or a brief wine-tasting excursion, although nearby competitors may offer more delectable alternatives for the discerning epicure.

"The delectable crepes boast an array of flavors, ranging from the traditional simplicity of lemon juice to the richness of Nutella complemented by bananas. In contrast, the savory crepes appear unimaginative and lacking in inspiration. However, the inviting ambiance of the coffee shop, enhanced by the well-crafted coffee, compensates for the deficiency. Unfortunately, the service has been inconsistent, marred by the presence of a bothersome fly during our last two visits."

It's a bar.  You walk in, mechanical bull, TONS of guys, loud, huge beers, and GREAT lettuce wraps (They really did have great food)!!  \n\nI don't really have much to compare it to because this was my first place to visit in while in Arizona, but it was a fun place to start the night off at and have a few beers.

Been going here for, shit, 10 years? I really want to love it (pakalolo no Swiss sub pepper Jack) but lately it's been kinda pissin me off, for all the reasons mentioned by everyone else here.

Great subs, not so much meat on them, kinda pricey, ultra slow, thumbs up for having mtn dew on tap.

Oh, and not green/sustainable at all!! Tried to redeem about 5 punch cards totaling 10 punches for a free sammich but they wouldn't let me. They could have just reused the cards, giving the ones with one punch to the next customers instead of punching and wasting all new cards.

Hippies my ass . . .

I will probably be going back, though not nearly as much.

"The advantages of this establishment include an affordable menu featuring fresh culinary offerings, delectable milkshakes, a pristine dining environment, affable and welcoming staff members, and a unique pepper bar. However, the drawbacks consist of an uninspired and lackluster dining area, an awkward layout within the dining room, unoriginal menu selections, and pre-made salad dressings. While it may be suitable for a rapid burger craving, in my view, alternative burger venues in the locality are preferable."

This is definitely a bento box place that is a GREAT place to go to just pick up some sushi for lunch that tastes yummy and reasonably priced. However, this place is NOT awesome for a sit down date. 

They serve the sushi in the to-go packages, and there are no real silverware available. It's just disposable stuff and styrofoam cups. They also didn't have any sugar for their tea. It took quite a while for the rolls to be made as well. The service was very spacey - like the guy didn't know what he was doing.

HOWEVER, their roll (rainbow roll) was AWESOME and their green tea was TO DIE FOR. They don't serve any white fish (at least they didn't when I was there). I would definitely recommend this as a place to pick up a good lunch, but not as a date or a dinner meal.

Nice seafood place away from the casinos.

Food: 7.5/10 - Nice menu selections. Well prepared.  The flavors will not wow you but they are a solid meal.  

Service: 8/10 - No problems. Nothing spectacular either.

Cleanliness: 8/10 - No visible issues.

Decor: 8.5 / 10 - Sat outside on a beautiful night.  Was very nice.  Inside looked nice as well.

Restrooms: 7/10 - no problems.

Parking: 9/10 - Tons of parking.  

Overall: 7/10 - A nice place to eat.  I personally like the Texas de Brazil located right next door MUCH better.

Walked in and the SeaHawkers club had just left.  The place was a wreck and they were scrambling to get the tables cleaned and the restaurant back in order.\n\nGood service, good food and cold drinks.  Use the 4Square app and unlock an additional dollar off your drinks, even during happy hour.

"A hospitable ambiance and proficient service are hallmarks of this establishment, rendering it an ideal setting for patrons seeking respite from exorbitant prices associated with mediocre beverages. Although the selection of draft beers may not boast an extensive array of options, the bartenders demonstrate a commendable level of attentiveness and helpfulness, ensuring that each patron's experience is optimized. Instances of inadvertently dispensed extra beverages are met with considerate explanations, fostering an atmosphere of transparency and customer satisfaction. As a frequent visitor, I have had the pleasure of witnessing such exceptional service on multiple occasions, leaving me with a favorable impression of this business and motivating me to continue offering my patronage."

I gave it a 3 star because overall the hotel was just ok, I did expect It to be better..  First time at the Trump hotel and found mold food in the refrigerator!! Customer service is not that great..Housekeeping took forever to clean my room, I did call early in the morning to inform them I need housekeeping which was provided but finish around 3pm... The hotel is away from the strip..we have to take taxi to and from Caesars Palace even though there was shuttle provided because we have to wait at least more then 25 min. Shuttle does stop at midnight which sucks because we can't enjoy ourselves just worrying the shuttle will stop soon and that's why we have to take taxi which charge us $20 plus tips and taxi driver doesn't want just $1 tip, they want more....
It's best to stay on the strip so no more taxi or shuttle rides !!
Pros:
Quiet, luxurious, doesn't smell, kitchen in the suites, luxurious bathroom
Cons:
just a few minor things. The shuttles stop way too early and it take a long time to pick you up. It's far away from the strip if you were to walk..there's really nothing to do at the hotel..it's just a basic hotel with a pool and a gym..

great eats, even if you don't get the all you can eat spaghetti. Had the arugula and white bean salad plus two penne pasta dishes. Both very good. Good Italian food in a nice atmosphere at decent prices with good waitstaff.

We have frequented this venerable establishment, which boasts an eclectic array of culinary delights, gaming facilities, and artisanal brews, on several occasions, and we must confess that the experience has been nothing short of delightful. The breakfast menu, in particular, offers an unparalleled combination of quality and affordability, with the steak and eggs option being a personal favorite, available for the remarkably reasonable price of $3.99. It is worth noting that this eatery also houses a brewery, which produces an impressive selection of craft beers, including an exceptional root beer that is not to be missed. While this may not be the most luxurious or high-end destination, it undoubtedly provides an excellent value for the money spent, and we would highly recommend it to anyone seeking a satisfying dining experience without breaking the bank. On a previous visit, we had the pleasure of enjoying a promotional offer, which allowed us to indulge in an unlimited number of Corona beers for a full hour, sans any obligation to make a purchase, and we were able to sample an impressive total of 22 Coronas, an experience that we found to be truly remarkable.

"Our dining experience was marred by an overwhelmed server who appeared flustered by the numerous tables she was attending to, and we felt somewhat inconvenient when requesting a replenishment of celery sticks, which were scantily provided alongside the delectable buffalo wings that boasted an impressive quality, albeit with varying degrees of spiciness; specifically, the mango-spicy variety was quite piquant, while the garlic Asian version was noticeably milder, and the jerk chicken offering was surprisingly bland, thus rendering the overall enjoyment of the meal somewhat inconsistent; furthermore, we were taken aback by the unexpected charge for additional celery refills, which amounted to $1.20, a sum we deemed disproportionate considering the minimal cost of a single celery stalk."

Napa location is on a different level compared to Vegas. The food and service at the bar were both a little rough. Our server/bartender completely forgot about us several times and we had to reorder a few times as well. In addition, I overheard the bartender blame the chef for an error in food to a customer. I thought that was very unprofessional. Quality of the food did not seem up to par from my previous experiences in Napa.

I love Trader Joe's, can I say that?  Best prices/best quality for nuts (almonds, pecans, walnuts, etc.) and nut products (almond butter, etc.) that I have found anywhere.  Awesome produce, awesome stuff that you can't find anywhere else.  Also, Joe Joe's, FTW!

I would give this particular one 5 stars except for 2 things:

1. Just try and find a parking spot around noon on any weekday.  I dare you.

2. It's so smaaaaaalllll :(

Otherwise, awesome.

"Ah, Treasure Island, a veritable haven for buccaneers and swashbucklers of yore, wherefore art thou? Aye, welcome to TI, a bastion of piracy, where scantily clad maidens dance with abandon, a spectacle most titillating, no doubt. Situated across the street from the opulent Venetian and Palazzo resorts, TI, alas, hath seen better days, its rooms, casino, and culinary offerings leaving much to be desired. Yet, for those seeking to economize and bask in the lively ambiance of the Strip's lower end, TI remaineth a viable option, though be prepared to endure the raucous pirate performance each eve."

You know, after going back to the convention for a second year and eating at the Golden Palace Buffet again, I have to say that ordering off of the menu provided a significant improvement over the buffet.\n\nThe food wasn't nearly as greasy and was actually quite flavorful.  I was pleased with my meal and I'm sure my friends were, too.  My friend, who was wearing a giant costume, was treated with courtesy.

"Preferring a culinary experience characterized by a pleasant combination of texture and flavor, specifically, a dish wherein the tofu is cooked to a satisfying firmness, devoid of excessive softness or squishiness, I placed an order for the yellow curry tofu, anticipating a delightful repast. Unfortunately, the restaurant's interpretation of this popular Thai dish fell short of my expectations, as the tofu was presented in a state of uninspiring softness, lacking the crispy exterior and tender interior that I had hoped for. Instead of being expertly fried or otherwise prepared, the tofu was merely cut into small pieces and added to the curry without further ado. While the rich, well-spiced curry sauce and generous portion of vegetables did somewhat compensate for this disappointment, the overall effect was diminished by the absence of a satisfying textural contrast. Notwithstanding this letdown, the eatery does offer a diverse selection of Thai dishes at reasonable prices during the lunch hour, and the unpretentious ambiance of the establishment, replete with high-top tables by the window and conventional tables inside, provided a suitable setting for a casual meal. However, the dearth of patrons during our weekday visit suggested that the restaurant may struggle to attract a consistent clientele."

"Upon returning to Las Vegas from an excursion to Phoenix, we opted to halt at this particular Subway establishment, strategically positioned on the right-hand side of the thoroughfare leading towards our destination. 

My order consisted of a 6-inch BMT sandwich, augmented with jalapeno cheddar bread, which I requested to be toasted. Furthermore, I customized my sandwich by adding an assortment of vegetables, including tomatoes, lettuce, green peppers, pepperoncinis, mustard, mayonnaise, oil, vinegar, salt, and pepper. The accommodating staff expedited the preparation of my meal, enabling me to partake in it without any significant delay. 

The quality of the ingredients utilized in the sandwich was exceptional, thereby contributing to its delectable flavor. This impromptu dining experience served as an optimal respite during our journey. Additionally, it is worth mentioning that the establishment boasts well-maintained restrooms, which are a welcome amenity for travelers seeking a brief pit stop. In light of the fact that every service station in Wickenberg was brimming with travelers availing themselves of the facilities, it is judicious to consider this Subway location as a viable alternative. 

In conclusion, based on the positive experience we had, it is highly likely that we shall revisit this eatery on future excursions between Phoenix and Las Vegas."

The last time my friends and I stayed in Vegas, we ended up at Treasure Island because we got a really good deal.  When we checked in, we noticed there was a Pho Restaurant and thought it was so random.  We scoffed at the patrons dining inside who had paid the exorbitant prices to eat Vietnamese food we were certain was mediocre at best. Little did we know we'd be there the following afternoon as well as the next slurping up the noodle soup to cure our pounding heads from our mad hangovers.\n\nBottom line: Prices are steep but it is Vegas after all and it's definitely not the best Pho I've ever had but if you happen to be staying at Treasure Island, check this place out because nothing cures a hangover better than some noodle soup.

I don't know what it is about mainland L&Ls...but the food just doesn't have the same taste as L&Ls back home in Hawaii.  The food is edible and very bland.  Beware when paying, though.  The prices on the menu board say one thing, but check your receipt...you may have been charged more.  I brought this to the attention of the worker who was ringing up my purchase, and his response was \"I can't do anything...that's what it says on the computer.\"  Really?  Businesses need to realize they can't advertise their price publicly, and then charge more at the register.  Very bad business practice!

Had dinner with a large group. We had a superb wine, but I'm sure it was not cheap and was chosen by the host of the dinner. The food? Well...the chopped salad was pretty mediocre, and too filling with all the red kidney beans it it. The table breads and muffins were too dry, kind of inedible.

Duck pancake...like someone had poured half a bottle of cheap, sweet syrup on it so who knows what the duck tasted like.

The porterhouse lamb chops - very good. This was by far the best thing I had. The lamb was perfectly grilled, and the sauce was inoffensive so you could enjoy the meat. 

Dessert - that warm, pudding-like cake that I can't remember. It was good, and chocolate. Like many restaurants they served the dessert and then came around asking for coffee as kind of an afterthought. The coffee service took so long that it was tough to wait on eating the cake. Dang, I like coffee WITH dessert. But, most restaurants haven't figured out how to serve both at around the same time.

The restaurant is a nice spot in Caesars so I don't want to dissuade people from going. But, I'd make the grilled meat the centerpiece of what you order and not get too high on hope for the rest, based on what I experienced. And get a nice bottle of wine to go with it!

It's Wal-Mart and it does not disappoint.  This store location just opened recently and I thought, "well, it's somewhat close to ASU, maybe it'll have a different vibe than the typical Wal-Mart experience I'm used to."

Nope

It's your standard issue Wal-Mart with your standard issue merchandise at those low low prices Wal-Mart's famous for.

It also still draws the same type of customers.  They're the ones we've all come to know and love at www.peopleofwalmart.com.  If you're looking for an environment where kids scream out the numbers they know (and failing to exceed 5...I'm serious), if part of your shopping experience includes the oblivious blocking every isle, and if you are enamored by the grandma pace cars you have to follow to get up to the front, then this is the Wal-Mart for you.

This particular retail establishment, which can be classified as a 'Superstore', serves as the preeminent and proximate supermarket for those residing in both Leith and Shore localities. It boasts two separate points of entry; one situated within the Tesco car park at the rear, while the alternative entrance lies on Duke Street itself. As a Tesco supermarket, it partakes in the customary activities associated with such an establishment, including the provision of clothing and electronic items for purchase. Although this 'Superstore' may appear somewhat diminutive in stature, it nevertheless manages to supply the essential provisions and maintains a convenient schedule, opening at 06:00 and closing at midnight. It is worth noting that the legal restrictions regarding the sale of alcoholic beverages before 10 am and after 10 pm apply to supermarkets as well, and some residents of Leith have been known to forget this fact, resulting in occasional disputes at the checkout. The store features a designated area for self-service tills, as well as two express lanes reserved exclusively for customers with baskets. While I do not frequent this establishment as often as I once did, particularly in light of the horse meat scandal, I still find it to be a convenient destination for procuring packaged goods such as whiskeys, spirits, wines, and chocolates. In conclusion, although this shop may not rank as the finest, it remains a serviceable option.

I'm giving it 3 stars almost solely on decor & atmosphere. 

After reading all of the rave reviews I really expected to be amazed, but sadly, that didn't happen. 

I did get a nonfat chai latte instead of coffee, so maybe that has something to do with it. It was kind of bland, nothing special :( 

But like I said, the company was good, the atmosphere nice & I love the look of the place :) 

If I try it again I'll try the coffee,,, I don't think I want to repeat my chai experience.

Not bad. Better than other fast food joints in Scotland. Actually WAY better than the fast food joints in Scotland. \n\nI kinda expected more, but was won over by the rootbeer float. That was definitely worth going. OMG, you have not experienced American fast food/diner fare til you've had a rootbeer float. Brought me back to the days of Dairy Queen and the likes. Yet the burger wasn't all that. It was ok but it just felt like there was something missing, to make it a home run. Also, I probably should've ordered the cajun fries. I ordered the onion rings. They were good but clearly frozen. So now I'm on a mission to find fresh made onion rings, any rec's?

"Although I had aspired to procure a reservation at the central area, I would have opted for the Flamingo establishment for a slightly higher tariff, considering my current knowledge. Nonetheless, I cannot express any dissatisfaction due to the fact that, despite its minor shortcomings in terms of cleanliness and maintenance, our accommodations provided us with an outdoor balcony, which surpassed my sister's lodgings at the Mirage hotel. Furthermore, the breakfast spread presented an adequate variety of edibles, without any notable culinary highlights, but also without any adverse gastronomical repercussions, which I deem a paramount aspect of any hospitality experience. Therefore, while the lodging may not constitute a substantial upgrade from a Motel 6, it still represents a marginal improvement and a reasonable value for a location situated at the heart of the Strip."

Went here for dinner last night. 3 courses and a glass of wine (making use of the £10 set menu) strikes me as good value for money. The service from boath the greeter and waitress was pleasant and attentive and my sardine starter and hake main course w/ side of spinach were both very well cooked and presented.


 I'd like to give them a further half star but as ever having to dock a full one instead. The cheese board was the one minorly negative aspect of the meal. It could have done with a couple more oatcakes and maybe more onion marmalde and the slice of brie had clearly been allowed to dry out and harden a bit + the cheese knife had seen better days (the plastic handle was cracked clean through on both sides near the base of the blade).


 No idea if the interior's changed much since it was a Harry Ramsden's but it's well decorated and gets a lot of sun. I intend to go back.

Hipster heaven. Bring on the 1920s era boots with dungarees to match. 

Really cool space. A terrific, vintage roaster is prominently displayed and obviously used. 

There is clearly a craft coffee shortage in my hometown. A line was nearly out the door. 

I scored an espresso. It was served up effectively and efficiently. In my humble opinion, the coffee was good...not great. A little too much fruit/acid. Not enough chocolatey smoothness. But, that's my taste. Not necessarily everyone else's cup o' tea!

However, my girl ordered a pour-over. And, pour-overs take a while. But, after ten minutes of waiting, we asked. Oh! We forgot about your pour-over coffee! Just wait another ten minutes. Derrrr...I don't want to wait another ten but I guess I have to cuz my girl is a caffeine junkie and so am I. Can't function without the wonderful stuff. 

I got to taste my girls cup o' joe and it was delicious. 

All in all, they have a good thing going but need to tweak a couple of things. I would return.

We partook of a culinary experience at this establishment in the company of our kin, and we must say, the ambiance was quite pleasant, albeit a tad tranquil for a Sunday afternoon. Upon entering the realm of the all-you-can-eat extravaganza, we were struck by an unpleasant olfactory sensation akin to that of a sewage system, which momentarily deterred us from indulging in the gastronomical offerings. However, our ardent fondness for sushi (a staggering fifteen times per mensem, no less!) impelled us to persevere and sample the wares presented. Alas, our expectations were not entirely met, as the quality of the sushi failed to meet the standards of a top-tier establishment, eliciting comparisons to the pedestrian offerings found at your run-of-the-mill grocery store. Notwithstanding, the diversity of options available on the buffet table was quite impressive, and it would have been even more satisfactory had the taste lived up to the price point.

We saw this place on Bar Rescue and wanted to check it out. My wife and I showed up about 9:30 PM. I was starving and planned on eating here. Unfortunately the bartender said the kitchen was closed because they had a slow night. I had one beer and left only because I couldn't keep drinking without getting some kind if food in my belly. Next time in Vegas I will definitely give this place another shot. And maybe more stars. The locals were extremely friendly and greeted us as soon as we walked in. The bartender was also very friendly. Wish I could have experienced the food.

I enjoyed the food, I got the chicken fried steak and it came with mashed potatoes and the gravy that comes on the steak. Also some green beans and a side salad that comes out first. All in all the food was good. 

Coming in was confusing. We weren't greeted and since it was our first time there we were very confused. Because it's a cozy place I'm ok with there not being a hostess stand. But I do feel like someone should be on top of greeting the guests so that we know how the waiting works (you just walk in and stand awkwardly at the door and they ask who was there first when they have a table ready.)

All in all it's so so. But I do love that it's a famiky business and the food was good

Food and service were okay. Among the dishes I ate were sweet & sour soup and tofu with baby bok choy.\n\nThe decor seemed fancy. I liked the jellyfish lights near the entrance and the wood-covered menus.

Very nice bar and the prices are very reasonable, if they put 2 (diamond) tables in there instead of 1 bar table and 1 build at home type pool table it would make this bar a very awesome place to hang out at and take pool league teams all week 24/7.

"Average American eatery providing satisfactory culinary offerings, yet lacking any truly distinctive features. Suitable for those seeking an unremarkable dining experience. The bar section tends to be rather boisterous, making communication and auditory comprehension somewhat challenging."

Pros: Nicely laid out store with a wide variety of vintage merchandise.\nCons:  Booths are not individually signed with percentage off discounts for store sales which makes things rather confusing.  Employees are hard to identify as they don't wear aprons, badges, etc.  Your purchase will be wrapped in used newspaper instead of clean wrapping paper.  All things that can be improved upon for a better shopping experience.

"I found this establishment to be quite appealing, with an ambient atmosphere that was thoroughly enjoyable, and the hospitality we received was of an exceptionally high caliber. The beverage I consumed, specifically the mojito, was truly delectable, and the waffles were similarly impressive in terms of their culinary excellence. My offspring, who accompanied me to this venue, was particularly enthused by the red velvet pancakes, which she sampled with great relish. However, there was one aspect of our dining experience that proved to be somewhat prohibitive, and that was the cost - the prices were exorbitant, with a single order of pancakes commanding a fee of $13, a sum that I found to be rather steep and prohibitive for frequent patronage."

A good place to eat, trendy. You can't call ahead or make reservations so expect to wait about 20-30 minutes for a table. The food is good, but when I went there I got an Eggs Benedict and it was more of a hard boiled egg, though it was well-seasoned. \n\nI'll be giving it another try, but I was much more excited about this place before I tried it.

We halted our perambulation at this establishment for the purpose of partaking in a midday repast, as we were experiencing fatigue and an absence of inclination to continue our pedestrian journey. Both of us opted for the creamy potato and leek soup, which proved to be a delectable choice. My companion had the tuna sandwich accompanied by a side of fries, while I selected the unembellished green salad, also with a side of fries. I was dismayed to discover that my salad contained several leaves that were not as fresh as they could have been, yet the waitress, Dana, did not include them in the calculation of our bill. The fries were served hot and crispy, their flavor being enhanced by the addition of aromatic herbs. While the culinary offerings were certainly satisfactory, they did not possess any exceptional qualities that would render them memorable. Nonetheless, Dana's hospitable demeanor and attentive service left a favorable impression upon us.

Quite disappointing when I expected the same flavor and price when I was in LA. 

Don't get me wrong, the waiters/waitress were super friendly. We ordered bulgogi and ribs. The food was flavorful but average. No refills for the side dishes when you are grilling at the grill-your-own-bbq table. 

Extra: went with a groupon deal but still ended up paying way more than expected and received less food. 

TL;DR: ok place for food, clean, but does not justify the price.

Upstream is probably thought of as one of the best restaurants in Charlotte.  I am from Philadelphia where there are excellent restaurants with iron chefs so my viewpoint may be a bit skewed.   The food was good but not great or amazing.  Every dish (except the house salad) was over salted.  My husband had the tuna and I had the seabass. They were both very good but as I said before not great.  We would go there again but for sushi/raw items not necessarily the cooked menu items.  The salad was was the highlight for me (house salad) and the crab bisque was pretty tasty too.   Overall the service was very good but slow.  Our waiter was one of the most knowledgeable wait staff we have encountered since moving from PA.

After Harlow's down the road was so packed we couldn't park, we decided to give this new breakfast cafe a try.  The portions are extremely generous and overall the food was really good.  The prices are a little high I think, but not so much that I wouldn't return.  I knocked down a star because the ham I received was \"off\" and tasted like it was past it's shelf life, and the oj was just so-so.  They do give complimentary chocolate covered strawberries that are epic!

"In the event that you are hankering for some barbecue while at an airport, rest assured that your dining prospects are somewhat restricted, my dear companion. However, this particular establishment offers a relatively affordable and satisfactory culinary experience within the confines of an airport eatery. While the quality of the barbecue may not be exceptional, it manages to surpass the alternatives situated nearby. For your perusal, I opted for the tri-meat platter, which included a rather generous portion of brisket that, regrettably, was largely composed of fat. The pulled pork was moderately tender, while the smoked turkey, though slightly dry, boasted a discernible smokiness. Patrons are given the option of a solitary sauce variety, which, although not mustard-based, is nevertheless recommended due to its subtlety. As for health-conscious side dishes, I implore you to maintain realistic expectations, considering the nature of the establishment."

....and boy are my arms tired!

Comedy clubs are easy to review when focusing on the club itself, and not the talent.  You could be in the perfect comedy club and see a horrible act, just as you could see something amazing at a dive bar's open mic night.  

This "club" is really  a conference room that has been converted into a comedy club.  The staff sets up chairs around the room for the patrons the night of the show, adding seats when needed.  There are a few VIP couches, but since this intimate setting is quite quaint, there really is no reason to pay the high price for them.

There are two waitresses who run around frantically trying to fill all the patrons' orders, but be ready to wait for your beverage.  Walking up to the bar in the room is usually a better way to go.  

I saw the late (9pm) show on a Saturday night.  Seating starts at 8:30, so get there early if you want to sit in the front.  Really, there isn't a horrible seat in the house though.  

I saw Todd Paul the night I went in, and laughed my A$$ off.  He was charismatic and hilarious.  His act was a mix of magic, stunts, and comedy.  He did an amazing job of making fun of Las Vegas shows, specifically magic shows.  I would definitely return for another fun night.

We indulged in a culinary experience at this establishment several weeks ago, pursuant to a suggestion proffered by the lodging facility in which we were residing. Although I do not partake in the consumption of steak, a number of my associates do, and they expressed their satisfaction with the quality of the dish. I opted for the Chicken Peppered Penne, which proved to be an exquisite selection. Following my request for an additional degree of piquancy, the culinary staff accommodatingly augmented the spiciness of the dish. The pasta was cooked to perfection, the sauce exhibited a velvety texture, and the flavors present in the dish were truly delectable. The attentiveness of the servers and the reasonable pricing further enhanced our dining experience.

This is the best Pho I've had in Scottsdale!  Now, as far as Pho goes, it's mediocre. The broth is good, but the quantity is small and price high!  It's seems as if they are scared to give you a good sized portion of noodles and meat. I get irked when I sped over $8 for Pho and I'm not stuffed. I think they do try hard here, but get away with the poor sizing and simple taste because they can!  \n\nThe staff is attentive ms friendly. Overall, give it a shot and order extra noodles and meatballs to get full!

"This public house exudes an aura of pleasantness, albeit with a strong inclination towards catering to the sensibilities of travelers and sightseers. Within the confines of its upper level, the culinary offerings are undoubtedly delectable, yet the ambiance fails to compare favorably with the environs situated below. Downstairs, an impressive array of authentic ales awaits discerning patrons, raising questions regarding the logic behind offering a glass of effervescent wine as a token of appreciation for relinquishing one's calling card, when either a sampling of these exceptional brews or a dram of fine whisky would prove far more apropos. Furthermore, the establishment takes pride in meticulously tracking the volume of hand-pumped ales dispensed on a weekly basis, as evidenced by the tally of 1987 recorded during the previous week, which I found rather fascinating."
Not a big fan but Tax free yeah!  Off base has more selection and you can find deals. Unless your buying a high price item i would shop elsewhere. The lines get bad so don't be in a rush.

Okay, the decor is awful and cheesy (but I guess that is part of the fun as well as a statement that the times may change, but Peppermill doesn't out of some sense of righteousness, laziness, and/or lack of funds).  They make the waitresses wear these awful, ugly uniforms (it reminds me of the flair Jennifer Aniston had to put up with in Office Space).\n\nWe went here for breakfast, and it wasn't actually okay.  The omelettes and pancakes were both good.  And for breakfast, it is a little different food and atmosphere than you get in the buffets on the mostly Disney-fied Las Vegas strip.

"Although the beer did not possess any extraordinary qualities, it was still palatable. It is worth mentioning that the establishment boasted an agreeable ambiance. However, it appeared that their primary emphasis lay in offering beverages with a sweeter flavor profile. Upon further inspection, it became apparent that they had depleted their stock of lighter brews, including the blonde variety. Consequently, we shall endeavor to sample their wares at a later time and reassess our initial evaluation."

I would not endorse this airline if you are embarking on a journey with minors, as it offers only basic amenities and lacks entertainment facilities, particularly on lengthy flights; there was no television on our five-hour voyage from New York, which resulted in the children on board becoming restless and irritable due to the lack of diversions; the seating was also quite confined and diminutive, which further exacerbated the discomfort; additionally, the aircraft appeared to be somewhat antiquated. Instead, I would suggest opting for Delta Airlines, which offers a more comprehensive range of services and amenities tailored to accommodate families with young children.

"An establishment of considerable merit, offering an array of delectable consumables and a convivial ambiance well-suited for viewing athletic competitions. It is fortunate that the evening's entertainment did not include karaoke, as the quality of the experience would have been significantly diminished by the cacophony of off-key vocalizations. While the attentiveness of the staff left much to be desired, particularly in terms of celerity, it is apparent that the sheer volume of patrons posed a significant challenge for the overburdened servers. Notwithstanding this shortcoming, the venue maintains a pleasant tempo, suitable for indulging in libations and savoring a meal while enjoying the spectacle of sports."

This place is open 24 hours and is located outside in the Paris Hotel Casino. It very nice and the Ambiance is really nice and classy. Food is actually OK, but nothing special. The dessert are great though and actually cheap for the amount you get. I got the banana split and share it with two other people and we didn't finish it. Cost like $10 bucks or something. The Sugar Factory store however is over price. Mints and such are like $5-$8 for a small tin. It one of those place you should try once. It a fun place and has outside seating. Dessert and Drinks is what they known for.

"Gastronomical assessment on a scale of one to ten, based on a singular visitation:
Eight for comestibles
Five starred beverages
Eight for hospitality
Eight for ambiance
Seven for value

Personally, I found the culinary offerings to be relatively satisfactory. Particularly noteworthy was the manner in which the yolk of the eggs rested atop the dish, a hallmark of New Mexico's gastronomical tradition. The blue corn tortillas accompanying my enchiladas were substantial and possessed an appreciable texture. Regrettably, the margaritas failed to meet expectations, exhibiting an unpleasant sweet and sour taste, devoid of any discernible bite or depth. Furthermore, the machine-made quality of their production was evident, detracting from the overall experience. Lastly, the serving of salsa, while possessing a commendable level of piquancy, lacked distinction in terms of flavor profile."

During our excursion to Fiesta Mall accompanied by my offspring who was undergoing a haircut, we opted to partake in culinary indulgences. Following a circuitous route throughout the food court, we were approached by a representative of Sarku Japan extending an offer of complimentary samples of their teriyaki chicken. Upon sampling the delicacy, my progeny felt compelled to procure a meal from the establishment. The personnel were affable, and the cost was reasonable. He selected the teriyaki chicken and shrimp dish. The quantity of sustenance he received surpassed expectations, and he expressed contentment with its flavor corresponding to its intended essence. A definitive venue for future visits and one that we highly endorse!

The hostess, Maria, exhibited a discernible expression of incredulity by rolling her eyes, which appeared to be indicative of an attitude predicament, whereas Kyahl, a name phonetically reminiscent of Kyle, demonstrated a relatively adept proficiency in responding to the queries posed by my spouse's mother, despite the culinary offerings being somewhat inconsistent in quality, with the veal parmesan garnering approval, while the macaroni rosa suffered from an unfortunate lack of flavor and the broccoli within remained undercooked, and the pasta maintained a firmer texture than what we are accustomed to.

I have had the pleasure of dining at this establishment on several occasions, and while the cuisine is undoubtedly palatable, it fails to distinguish itself in any remarkable manner that would compel me to return. Although, if someone were to host a celebratory gathering or special event at this venue, I would not deliberately avoid it. My experiences with the eatery have been confined to events held on the premises, and while the fare has been satisfying, it has not been exceptional. It is unfortunate that the quality of the ingredients utilized does not meet my expectations, as I would readily bestow a perfect rating upon most Indian restaurants if they upgraded their meat and overall quality. Specifically, the salads lacked the vibrancy of fresh greens, and the portion size of the meat in both the korma and tikka was disappointingly diminutive. It appeared that the establishment was cutting corners to save costs. The dessert offerings did not particularly impress either. While I have an affinity for traditional Indian sweets such as gulab jamun and jelebi, the versions served here were merely adequate, and the quantity available was limited. In conclusion, although there are superior options in close proximity, India Gate being a notable example, this restaurant remains a viable choice for those seeking satisfactory Indian cuisine.

"Oh my goodness, what a disappointment! I have penned a review of their Pecos and Washington site, which I adore and yearn for during the summer months when hankering for seafood. Nonetheless, this particular establishment seemed to be lacking in a certain je ne sais quoi. I requested the shrimp ceviche and fish tacos, and unfortunately, they failed to impress me with their flavors. The ceviche had an overpowering fishy taste, necessitating copious amounts of lemon and salt, while the tacos were uninspiring and lackluster. \n\nThe eatery's ambiance was pleasant, and the server was friendly and attentive. However, the overall experience fell short of expectations. My dining companions concurred, having experienced the exceptional quality of the other location. I shall not be returning to this site, particularly given the elevated prices, although the cost would be warranted if the "Islitas" experience were replicated here. Unfortunately, that was not the case. Instead, I recommend visiting their north Las Vegas location, despite their steep pricing, as they possess the potential for improvement. Thus, I award them three stars, or else I would have given them two."

Ordered the white pizza with tomato onion and kalamata olives and was pretty tasty. They recommended that the pizza be cooked for an extended amount of time because of the wet ingredients which caused the crust to be slightly burned with a tad too much crunch for my tastes.  Plenty of staff inside.  Interior atmosphere was o.k.  The only markdown I give them is the price. It seemed to lack value and was over priced.  Probably will not return given it is too far away from me...and even if there were one closer, other places would get my dollar first.

"This establishment did not conform to my preconceived notions. Rather, it constituted a vast expanse of unencumbered space, with a sizable bar situated in the centralmost location. The culinary offerings, while admittedly delectable, were notably elevated in comparison to those typically found at traditional sports-oriented drinking establishments. Furthermore, the absence of a diverse selection of draft beers was conspicuous, with only a few pedestrian options available. The abundance of flat-screen televisions, while certainly appropriate for a venue of this nature, failed to compensate for the overall lack of individuality and distinctiveness that permeated the atmosphere. Ultimately, this establishment's overt commercialism proved distasteful to my refined sensibilities."

"While there may not be anything particularly extraordinary about this hotel within a hotel, aside from perhaps the convenience of abbreviated check-in queues, which is indeed a welcome amenity, the ambiance of the accommodations themselves does exude an essence of Asian-inspired elegance. However, it is somewhat unfortunate that the overall experience fails to meet the expectations typically associated with a five-star establishment. This is largely due to the fact that Caesars Palace, despite its venerable reputation, appears to have fallen victim to the pitfalls of aging infrastructure and inadequate staffing, resulting in sluggish service and an overall atmosphere that falls short of the luxurious standards set by comparable resorts such as Wynn, Bellagio, and The Venetian."

Have been to Joe's a number of times and enjoyed their food.  We have had terrible service every time, though.  It's worth going because the food is good and the atmosphere is fun.  Just be patient, and your night will be fine.

"An extensive array of brews, copious in quantity, is available for perusal and consumption at this establishment, which also purveys a range of culinary offerings, albeit with varying degrees of gastronomic excellence; however, the hospitality of the serving staff and mixologists is undeniably commendable, and the spaciousness of the venue enables it to accommodate a throng of patrons during peak hours, thereby rendering it a worthwhile destination for a nocturnal excursion."

I visited this establishment for an evening meal with my significant other last night, and I must concur with the prevailing sentiment expressed in previous reviews, specifically regarding the outdoor seating area, which boasts a remarkable panorama and an unexpected sense of seclusion despite its proximity to Indian School Road. The wine and beer selection is indeed impressive, offering an array of local options that I found particularly appealing. However, my culinary experience was somewhat disappointing. I initiated my meal with the fries, which were flavored with rosemary and parmesan and accompanied by a dipping sauce akin to a thousand island dressing. While they were certainly palatable, they failed to exceed my expectations. For our main courses, we opted for the sausage and mushroom pizza, as well as the penne ragu. The pizza was undoubtedly delectable, featuring caramelized onions, three varieties of mushrooms, and Italian sausage, all atop a crust that struck the perfect balance between crispness and tenderness, rendering it suitable for consumption with utensils. The ragu, on the other hand, was rather unconventional; it brought to mind the assortment of ingredients typically found within a shredded beef burrito, but instead of being enveloped in a tortilla, it was served in a bowl with penne pasta beneath. Although it was not unpalatable, it was unexpected and left me feeling ambivalent. I do regret not indulging in their dessert offerings, as they appeared quite enticing, and I intend to sample them during a future visit. In conclusion, I consider this establishment an excellent venue for enjoying appetizers and beverages, particularly on their exceptional patio.

"Prodigious coffee connoisseurs who relish the rich flavors of expertly brewed beverages may find it challenging to accurately assess the quality of a cafe's signature edibles, such as doughnuts or bagels, if they are currently abstaining from consuming them; thus, it is advisable to solicit my opinion on these culinary staples at a later time, when I have had the opportunity to indulge in them and formulate a well-informed evaluation, perhaps after a 40-pound weight gain."

Upon entering the establishment with a group of companions, I was immediately struck by the pleasant aroma that permeated the atmosphere, which piqued my interest in sampling their waffle offerings. However, upon being seated, I observed that the service was lacking in attentiveness, as no staff member inquired about our need for water or additional menus for our group of three. We eventually determined our orders and approached the counter to place them, only to be interrupted by the lady behind the counter, who shouted to another employee while my dining companion was attempting to order, which I found to be somewhat discourteous. Our meals took a considerable amount of time to arrive, but they were visually appealing. The red velvet wafflenut, Nutella and almond wafflenut, The Fat Elvis waffle, strawberry and chocolate waffle, and Vegas churro waffle with honey, cinnamon, sugar, and vanilla ice cream were all satisfactory. The churro waffle was the preferred selection among our group, while I personally enjoyed the strawberry waffle, excluding the chocolate sauce. However, due to the subpar service and inconvenient location, I do not foresee myself making a concerted effort to revisit this establishment in the near future.

Service was fast, but the burger, hotdog, and fries were overrated for the expensive price.\nInn n Out  is still my favorite fast food burger and Bachi Burger is my favorite gourmet burger place in Vegas!

"It is a location frequently visited by travelers seeking leisure activities, and it is not uncommon for the delay in securing a table to be utterly abysmal. Thus, it is imperative to be cognizant of this fact beforehand. The dish consisting of noodles topped with a crispy duck confit is, without a doubt, utterly sublime. However, its cost relative to its quantity is somewhat disproportionate, as the serving size falls short of expectations considering the premium price point. This, in essence, constitutes my primary criticism of LOS. Either the portion sizes should be more generous given the tariff or the culinary offerings should exhibit flawless execution. Unfortunately, this disparity between quality and price resulted in the deduction of two stars from my overall rating."

My better half coerced me into entering this establishment subsequent to her sampling their surf and turf dish, which she vociferously praised. I am unable to provide an assessment of said dish at this juncture. We took a seat at the bar and engaged in a game of poker for a brief period. Although it was not particularly remarkable, management did see fit to waive the mandatory maximum wager requirement for a second beverage, which they graciously informed me of. It is conceivable that this policy served as a deterrent to potential patrons, thus resulting in our relative seclusion. Upon ordering sustenance, we relocated to a table and transported our beverages with us. The proportions of the sandwiches were considerable, specifically the philly cheesesteak variety, and their quality was satisfactory. However, one must consider the financial ramifications of consuming here, as the total cost of our repast, inclusive of gratuity, approached forty dollars for a mere two sandwiches. While the culinary offerings were undoubtedly palatable, I struggle to comprehend the allure of this venue, particularly given their elevated price point.

We went here for our engagement dinner with our family. It was BUSY for a Wednesday night and parking...well let's just say there isn't that many parking spaces available. For a party of 13, we were stuck in the corner closest to the door. Every time someone opened the door a gust of cold air would come in or the smell of cigarette smoke. YUCK! This was when it was raining for a couple days straight. Luckily, my brothers and sister are tiny, because putting them 4 in the chairs closest to the wall worked out. No average size adult would be able to fit....yes that is how crammed we were. \nIn typical Chinese fashion, there was Lobster, Red Trout, Fried Flounder, Chicken, Beef and a lot of veggies. I felt that everything was just ok. Nothing too special and they had messed up one of the kids orders. I believe my Grandma liked it for the most part and that's all that mattered to me. Overall, I do prefer other places, but I won't be against coming back here again as long as I'm not sitting next to the door when its freezing outside.

Paul Martin's has a lot going for it - too bad the stuff on the periphery was bad. 

Paul Martin's is a nice and rather classy steakhouse that definitely reminds me of D.C. steakhouses. The lighting is dark but pleasant, the music energetic but quiet, and the ambiance rather pleasant. 

The food is also good. I had the Sunday special offering, which is salad, prime rib, and ice cream for $25. The salad was good and had a decent flavor palette without being overwhelming.  The prime rib was tender and had an amazing spice rub that took it to the next level, but the interior was something of a vast wasteland of okay meat. The desert didn't happen for me - they had no options for lactose intolerant patrons, which was rather disappointing (and perplexing, given the upper echelons this place places itself in). 

The service was rather poor. The server was clearly overwhelmed at times - at one point, he responded to our lactose intolerance inquiry by telling us that the ice cream was gluten free. It actually became rather offensive when we were made to feel guilty about using one of their gift cards - I have no idea why a steakhouse would make paying customers feel so awkward about using a gift card they sold!

Long story short, the food here is four stars, the service two. Three seems appropriate.
Staff here is usually very nice and helpful and not overbearing. Everything is kept nice and tidy. I just feel that this location does lack in variety and sizes...

"Consequently, it is our considered opinion that Uncle Bears constitutes an ideal venue for social gatherings and casual dining experiences, facilitating as it does, an agreeable ambiance conducive to conviviality and relaxation. Although the menu may not boast an extensive array of culinary delights, it does feature a selection of delectable offerings, specifically including the slider variety, which consistently impresses with its satisfying flavor profile. Furthermore, the chicken fajitas merit high praise for their palatable quality, refuting as they do, unfounded claims of rubbery texture. 
  A most appreciable aspect of this establishment lies in its impressive beer selection, featuring an assortment of locally brewed Four Peaks varieties alongside an array of nationally recognized microbrews. The interior design and motif, characterized by elements reminiscent of canine companions, contributes further to the welcoming atmosphere, prompting patrons to ponder, albeit bemusedly, the curious absence of images showcasing their own cherished canines. Ultimately, Uncle Bears qualifies as a quintessential neighborhood tavern, offering a hospitable setting suitable for casual dining, socializing, and indulging in a diverse range of beverages."

D'Arcy McGee's serves up a mix of various cuisines that can be best summed up as Anglo-Saxon origin.  Ranging from dishes such as Irish boxty, corned beef and cabbage, Scotch eggs, Canadian poutine, and British Yorkshire pudding, portions are hearty and service is cheerful and pleasant.  The food quality itself is just OK, but it's a nice change of pace from your standard wings, pizza, or sandwiches that you find at other bar-type restaurants.
Pho is good but its not best pho or egg rolls (they don't even serve it with the lettuce and herbs) you can get in Pittsburgh. On the flip side though, their owner is super friendly

This Marble Slab Creamery is situated in the Stonecrest Shopping Center, precisely towards the forefront of the development, in close proximity to an array of establishments such as JoJo's, Miro, Dean & DeLuca, et al. It embodies a conventional ice cream shop, offering a diverse selection of flavors, along with a unique assortment of "Ice Cream Cupcakes" that caught my attention for the first time. Additionally, whole ice cream cakes in varying dimensions are prominently displayed within a stand-up freezer. Although a limited number of chairs and tables are dispersed throughout the interior, this location is conveniently positioned near an expansive outdoor plaza, replete with ample seating options adjacent to a magnificent fountain, providing an idyllic setting for patrons to relish their frozen treats during favorable weather conditions.

 On my visit, I opted to sample one of the aforementioned ice cream cupcakes at a later time, which proved to be satisfactory. Furthermore, I purchased a Birthday Cake milkshake, which, unfortunately, was not blended with the utmost care, resulting in an uneven consistency. The initial sips consisted solely of sweet milk, succeeded by occasional clumps of ice cream. While not exceptional, it remained adequate. The staff members exhibited kindness and hospitality, contributing to a pleasant experience. Ultimately, my expectations were not exceedingly high, and this establishment met them with its unremarkable yet acceptable offerings.

This place is located near the outlet center and is easy to access. In the store they provide you with packing tape if you need it. Unlike some other places that require that you purchase it. The customer service members are nice unlike USPS workers.

My husband and I stopped in before we went to see a movie. We had already had dinner so we only stopped in for a cocktail and some deserts. 

We sat on the patio which was really nice. We were the only ones sitting at the patio, so we were worried that we would be forgotten about but the service was still rather good.

He had a beer and I had a frozen strawberry margarita. The margarita was slightly watered down and could have used a bit more strawberry to it. My husband tried a beer called Victoria which actually wasn't bad at all. I also ordered a frozen ice cream. I went with the vanilla ice cream. The presentation was lovely and I enjoyed the deep fried ice cream. 

I did hit up the bathroom before we headed out to the theater and I was very impressed with the bathroom. The women's bathroom has a large full sized mirror and the handicapped/nursing bathroom is very large and has ton of room. 

Overall, it was a nice experience and we may end up going back for dinner on our next date night.

Rented a 25 footer that had electrical difficulties on three occasions over a ten day trip.  Luckily their help desk personnel were fabulous in getting a service technician out to remote national parks to try to fix the problem.  Unfortunately the rig had been improperly serviced before and the problem persisted.  It was disappointing the rig was put on the road but once we got the battery problem solved our experience was quite good.  I would rent again but would try to get a newer vehicle (ours had 98,000 miles) and try to verify the condition.

We went to Fairview Grill for dinner and drinks one night. We expected an evening of pub food, draft beer, and an unpretentious atmosphere, and that's exactly what we got.  

We had a coupon for a free entree, so to us the prices were VERY reasonable.  Generally entrees (mostly sandwiches and burgers) are about $8, which is an excellent value considering the quantity of food you get. We both had burgers, and we were both very pleased. My husband had fries, which he enjoyed, and I got onion rings (of course), and they were above average. The waitress got our order correct (even the "hold the X, extra Y" order we placed) without writing it down.  She was very attentive, and kept the beer and water flowing.  

The atmosphere is one of a relaxed pub--everyone was very friendly there too, including two guys who waved at us upon entering and asked how we were doing.  

Because we are right down the street from Fairview Grill, we will definitely be returning.  Might even shoot a game or two of pool. I don't know if it stands out among pubs in town, but it was an enjoyable evening overall.

"The lodging establishment and its personnel are exceptional. I have a predilection for Hilton hotels and, in terms of accommodations, this particular venue is satisfactory. However, the location is not optimal due to the necessity of utilizing taxi services to reach destinations beyond walking distance; nevertheless, the guestroom and overall structure are quite pleasant. 

It is advisable to avoid participating in a timeshare sales presentation if feasible. The reduced tariff for the hotel stay was not worth the unpleasant sensation lingering in my mouth after enduring a prolonged sales pitch lasting two and a half hours. 

In the event that you already possess ownership and have dedicated yourself to taking vacations, then indeed, this would be a suitable place to lodge. 

In the event that you resemble the majority of individuals and are unable to tolerate aggressive sales tactics, I would refrain from accepting any offers that may appear appealing in exchange for attending a sales presentation, as it is unequivocally not worthwhile. I would willingly return in time and compensate someone to avoid reliving that experience once more."

I am fond of the concept of this establishment, as it offers the opportunity to partake in live musical performances while enjoying a meal before proceeding to witness a comedic act in the adjacent venue. The culinary offerings were indeed delectable. However, my sole grievance pertains to the sluggish pace of the service, as it required an excessive duration of time to receive our initial course of fried potato slices. Despite their flavorfulness, the prolonged wait was unacceptable. Nevertheless, the assortment of beverages available on tap was impressive. It is my hope that the efficiency of the service will improve with the passage of time.

"My expectations were not entirely met, as I had anticipated a more satisfactory culinary experience, encompassing an unhurried and indulgent dinner, marked by seamless service and a palpable sense of refinement. However, my entrÃ©e arrived prematurely, prior to my completion of the appetizer, and the concluding dessert course fell short of my expectations, thereby diminishing my overall satisfaction. Despite the laudable quality of the cuisine, the hurried pace and perceptible deficiency in attention to detail detracted from the dining experience, leading me to question the commensurability of the cost with the value received."

It's a decent paper with great access to their writers. Plus, I really like the location! (They are located directly next to my office, so whenever I need something...I just walk over) \n\nIt also makes a great filler in my fire pit! Lol

"In conclusion, an enjoyable night was had within the confines of this vibrant, pseudo-loungy Portuguese establishment, boasting a dynamic ambiance that afforded patrons the opportunity to observe the culinary process, while simultaneously socializing with an upscale clientele. The advantages of dining here include a wide-ranging menu replete with delectable options and an atmosphere conducive to conviviality.
