However, it is imperative to note that the cost of indulging in a diverse array of tapas, main courses, beverages, and wine can quickly add up, resulting in a substantial financial investment, especially considering the premium pricing of certain seafood and fish dishes, which hover around the $40 mark. Therefore, those with limited financial resources would be wise to exercise caution when deciding whether to partake in the culinary offerings of this esteemed eatery."

"On this particular occasion, it so happens that this specific Hampton Inn establishment represents my inaugural visitation. The layout and overall design of the premises seem to conform to the standardized template typically associated with Hampton Inn properties. Nonetheless, the personnel here have demonstrated a remarkable level of cordiality and assistance, which unfortunately cannot be said for all locations I have had the privilege of visiting. My arrival took place prior to the hours of 3 o'clock in the afternoon, and the receptionist was able to facilitate my check-in process without any undue delay or complications. The state of the room was satisfactory, with no visible signs of disarray or neglect. Subsequently, I decided to pay a visit to the on-site Fitness Center during the late afternoon hours, only to be confronted with a rather unexpected revelation. The designated 'Fitness Center' was, in reality, a minuscule storage space that housed a paltry assortment of three exercise machines and a handful of exercise balls. This cramped space, regrettably, lacked the capacity to accommodate more than four individuals at any given moment, thus leading to an unfortunate sense of disappointment on my part."

was, okay.

I had the lamb entree, nothing exceptional.  could use more fresh veggie on the plate versus just legumes.

lamb cooked well but was not memorable at all. (no rosemary or other good taste)--was SOO PLAIN as if i was eating british food.

service:

waitor was nice
one server came with our dishes and we had to move things on our table to make space.  we are used to services being experienced enough to prep our table or manage the dishes they are carrying.

During the frenzied holiday season, department stores metamorphose into an atypical realm where the maniacal consumer culture assumes a captivating form. Amidst the throngs of shoppers, an unwavering emphasis on display transpires, attaining an unprecedented level of urgency and fixation. As an ardent observer of human behavior, I derive a perverse satisfaction from immersing myself within the midst of this spectacle, relishing the opportunity to witness firsthand the intriguing dynamics that unfold. Despite my lack of purchases, I must confess that I enjoyed the 25 minutes spent meandering through the multilevel store, indulging in people-watching while accompanying my sibling in his quest for a necklace suitable for his significant other. Furthermore, I must note that this specific department store boasts a veritable perfume section of gargantuan proportions, replete with an endless array of aromatic offerings. Each individual aisle within this vast domain is tended to by a personable, model-like attendant, eager to lavish unsuspecting passersby with generous spritzes of fragrances endorsed by none other than the illustrious Cher herself. This surreal atmosphere, simultaneously hellish and hypnotic, serves as a testament to the allure and absurdity of our contemporary consumerist culture.

those that know me know i like to have a good time. 

i usually do.

went with a group of around 30, so yeah it was crazy.

for some strange reason, i just wasnt feeling this place. yeah the usual things youd find at a strip club are here..  cute to a few HOTT ladies walking around preying on drunk folks. random ass femalecustomer getting it on with a group of said ladies.... hella expensive ass drinks......

but strip clubs are like masturbation.... in the begining it all seems like a great idea, youre all excited and during, youre having a great time..... but after a few minutes after, you realized, damn i just fucked myself.
 
+1 star for that cute stripper that actually seemed like she was enjoying chatting and took me over to an abandoned area not being used that night just to chat about random ass shit and not to clean me out of all my money.

Bonne nourriture, ambiance et d\u00e9cor.\nPar contre, service tr\u00e8s in\u00e9gal et boiteux.\nProbl\u00e8me \u00e9vident de gestion du service \u00e0 la client\u00e8le. Soyez pr\u00eats \u00e0 attendre tr\u00e8s longtemps.

I was excited to come here last Saturday to see Billy Gardell.  I knew I was going to get royally screwed out of tons of money by this place so I was semi-prepared.


Pros:
* Great acts
* Very intimate setting = every seat is a good seat with a good view of the stage
* Reasonable ticket prices
* Parking validation
* Decent food at reasonable prices for good portions
* Friendly service that is relatively fast and efficient

Cons:
* They cram you in like sardines
* Their drink prices are ridiculous and they make you buy two of them
* If you order food you still have to buy 2 wicked overpriced drinks.  The price of your food does NOT count towards some stupid minimum.
* They add a mandatory tip % to your bill


The bottom line is that I won't be back to this place until they fix how much they rape you or there is a comic that I really really really want to see.  I realize that they are in biz to make money and are probably raking it in, but they can go fuk themselves for being greedy and making me hate comedy theaters.

My companions hold this establishment in high regard, yet my personal assessment is somewhat tepid. It is contingent upon one's penchant for a particular type of pizza, as individual preferences vary greatly in this regard. I do not partake in pizza that is heavily reliant on bread, as the sauce is the paramount component that determines its quality. Unfortunately, the pies served here are rather parsimonious with their sauce and cheese, which does not align with my predilections. Those who appreciate a superior crust may find this place appealing, but it does not suit my tastes. Being a native of Chicago, I have been exposed to an abundance of exceptional pizza venues, which has elevated my standards. While Phoenicians may recommend various establishments, my experiences have led me to conclude that they are merely mediocre in comparison to the renowned Lou Malnattis or Giordano's in Chicago.

"It is Carowinds, an amusement park boasting an array of thrilling rides, albeit the majority are encircled by attractions that may not pique one's interest or warrant expenditure. Nonetheless, the juvenile contingent is bound to experience enjoyment, undoubtedly. The patrons are amiable and courteous, fostering a welcoming atmosphere. Notably, the collective hospitality extended to gatherings is commendable, featuring delectable brisket and chicken dishes. One can derive satisfaction from partaking in such amenities."

Came here as one of the stops for the \"Buffet of Buffets\" 24 hour pass thing. It's nothing compared to the buffet at the Wynn but I don't think this buffet deserves so many one and two star reviews. Yes, the selection is limited but the food isn't crappy either. The interior is inviting. The line sucks unless you're a diamond/platinum member.

"I require a half-star button, as three and a half stars seem insufficient to express my ambivalence towards this dining experience. Following an unsuccessful attempt to procure a strawberry honey tea, I reluctantly opted for a raspberry tea, which, much to my dismay, lacked the characteristic sweetness that its moniker would suggest. My culinary excursion also included a tamale chx salad, comprised of an assortment of ingredients such as grapes, celery, green onion, and almonds, all finely sliced to prevent any singular component from dominating the palate. While the salad was indeed satisfactory, the tamale itself was somewhat disappointing, as it failed to exhibit the moisture and flavor that I have come to expect from such a dish. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the meal was priced at a reasonable eight dollars, which, in conjunction with the friendly and expedient service, almost persuades me to consider a future visit solely for the purpose of sampling the aforementioned strawberry honey tea that has garnered such fervent endorsements from patrons."

We arrived too late to be seated and were quickly told as much the second we walked through the door.

But we were hungry and so very pleased to find out they would let us order take out. 

The food was prepared fast and tasted good. It was my first time eating at this chain so I'm not sure how it normally tastes. I really liked the garlic aioli that came with my pasta. The salad was tasty.

The manager Adam Wilcox, accommodated some of our party's particular requests.

They have gluten-free options - make sure you order them specifically even if you are ordering off the gluten-free menu.

I had a great burger here the night--it was a no-frills deal, like something you're mom would've made if she were in a rush. But it was tasty. Coupled with a few beers (and the P-stone has a TON), it was a great little meal. \n\nThe P-stone's a cool little place, although it doesn't look like much from the street. In fact, it really doesn't look like anything at all, really. Groovy, mellow crowd hangs here, so it's not a real rowdy scene if that's what you're looking for. Very familiar feel--like a mom and pop deal, if that makes sense. It seems like a cook place to hang out with a bunch of friends on a random, quiet night.

Came here a little while back to see Fu Manchu - the stoner rock band, that is, not the movie. This little dive on the southeast corner of Hayden and Roosevelt in a little strip mall used to be called Chaser's. Saw a few local bands there a few times back in the day - Zen Lunatics, One Foot In The Grave. One Foot In The Grave was sort of a Sun City novelty punk band about 2 decades ago when all members being over 50 was actually a novelty. Now that most punk bands from the first wave or even the hardcore years are all past 50 that novelty has long worn off. :) So the bar pretty much looks the same as it did during the Chaser's years and place had a good sized crowd - you had to squeeze your way through to get from point A to point B. Men's bathroom didn't even have a door but at least it had working toilets - no peeing in coffee cans here. Had one gin and tonic - tasted a little watery so I didn't get any more. Headliners were super loud. Like holy crap I forgot my earplugs loud. Like stop by the bookstore tomorrow and get the Sign Language For Dummies LOUD! It's ok for shows but I wouldn't come here again unless I  REALLY REALLY want to see whatever band is playing here.

"An assessment of this establishment can be encapsulated in the adage 'you get what you pay for.' While it may not have been a luxurious or opulent venue, it offered a satisfactory and economical lodging experience. My expectations were adequately met, as the facilities were well-maintained, the staff was attentive, and the amenities, including transportation to and from the Las Vegas Strip and McCarran International Airport, were convenient. In conclusion, a reasonable and contented stay was had, particularly considering the elevated prices customary in Las Vegas."

"Individuals with a propensity for cordiality and an inclination towards the procurement of unconventional goods have consistently provided me with a satisfactory experience, characterized by the offering of high-quality wares and an abundance of fresh produce, further complemented by an impressive array of dehydrated fruits and nuts."

"Positives:  The concoction of a muddled cocktail elicited a profound sense of satisfaction, its intricate blend of flavors harmonizing in a manner that transcended mere palatable considerations.  The service, characterized by an acute attention to detail and a genuine concern for the patron's comfort, contributed significantly to the overall enjoyment of the dining experience.  Furthermore, the menu featured an array of options diversified by both price and culinary style, thereby catering to a broad spectrum of gastronomical inclinations.  Finally, the ambiance of the establishment exuded an air of modern sophistication, the sleek decor fostering an atmosphere conducive to conviviality and relaxation."
"Negatives:  Unfortunately, the cuisine did not quite live up to the lofty expectations engendered by the restaurant's otherwise laudable attributes.  Although the menu boasted an impressive array of creative dishes, their execution often fell short of the promised experience, with the result that the gustatory component of the meal proved somewhat anticlimactic.  Moreover, the sheer volume of stylized menu selections tended to overshadow the actual quality of the food, leading to a disproportionate emphasis on aesthetics at the expense of culinary substance."

We were excited to try Julian Serrano because of their ceviche and array of tapa menus! I ordered the mixed seafood ceviche- it was meh okay.  Nothing special.  Also the steamed the mussels that were pretty good.  The other girls ordered the spare ribs and mushroom risotto - nothing specatuclar :-(

It is alright.

Ordered a chicken pita sandwich. The pita bread itself was good, wished more of the cucumber sauce, and the chicken was thick and enough - to make your money's worth. Just needed something else to give it a 4 or 5.

Of course there are plenty of other options to go to, if not feeling for chicken pita sandwich.

BEWARE. THEY USE LEAN MEAT!!\nhaha, Just sayin', the burger was kinda dry. but definately a pretty good burger and fries. got 2 burgers, and shared a thing of fries. total bill $30. Not bad, wouldn't go back though
Can't beat $2 for a any size latte on Wednesdays.  Small latte?  $2 please.  Medium latte?  $2 please!  Large latte?  $2 please!  You get the idea.  Hint:  I'd go with the large...

"There isn't a remarkable amount to articulate regarding this establishment, as it embodies a quintessential character that is reminiscent of numerous other similar venues. Its aesthetic appeal is pleasant, yet unremarkable, and the culinary offerings, while satisfactory, do not possess an exceptional quality that would render them memorable. Although I did not have the opportunity to sample their signature pizza, my impression remains that the experience was unexceptional and unlikely to prompt an enthusiastic return visit. However, I would suggest this location to groups of acquaintances seeking a casual atmosphere where they can enjoy beverages and fare while viewing sporting events."

While holding a divergent perspective regarding the superior quality of the fried poultry served at this establishment, I concur with the notion that it constitutes a remarkable local discovery within the city of Charlotte, offering delectable fried cuisine that caters to both regional patrons and visiting gastronomes with equal proficiency. The venue experiences a high volume of patronage, with a constant influx of customers from 11 am onward, culminating in either the exhaustion of the daily menu items or the closure of the eatery. It is imperative to note that the restaurant only accepts paper currency, thus it is advisable to verify the availability of funds in one's wallet prior to arrival, and refrain from allowing the presence of pedestrians gathered adjacent to the sidewalk to deter you, as this phenomenon is customary and not indicative of any anomaly. The ordering process is expedited, resulting in the rapid procurement of culinary items, followed by a prompt departure to accommodate the succeeding patron in line. The menu features a variety of fried delicacies, including chicken and fish options; personally, I advocate for the unwavering preference of poultry. Supplementing the meal with hush puppies and coleslaw contributes to an enhanced dining experience. I recommend paying a visit to this establishment to form your own opinion.

I failed to acquire any edible items to consume during my visit due to the fact that I was in the process of recuperating from a bout of food poisoning. However, my significant other managed to procure the spicy pork tacos, which he asserted were the most delectable tacos he had ever had the pleasure of consuming. This establishment exudes an aura of authenticity, as evidenced by the lengthy queues and numerous patrons in attendance. My companion awarded five stars in recognition of the culinary excellence displayed by the eatery. 
  Notwithstanding, one cannot help but wonder if the prolonged waiting period is truly justified. The duration of the queue significantly diminishes the overall rating, relegating it to a mere three stars. The system employed for organizing the queue was utterly perplexing. Numerous patrons have pointed out that there are separate lines for various types of fare. In total, there are six distinct lines, divided into two sets of three. The first set consists of lines dedicated to pork (abodaba), offal (including brains, tongue, stomach, tripe, intestines, et cetera), and beef (encompassing asada, et cetera). Despite its apparent length, the queue moved at a glacial pace, making the prolonged delay seem utterly absurd. 
  Upon drawing closer to the front of the line, it became apparent that the sluggishness was attributable to a single individual performing the duties of two people. Although he demonstrated remarkable speed in crafting the tacos, he was responsible for preparing a minimum of five tacos for every patron. Moreover, he produced an excess of fifty tacos while we waited, ostensibly for takeout orders (wrapped in foil and placed on paper plates). The combination of the time required per person and the additional tasks undertaken by the taco artisan for the benefit of those not present in the queue contributes substantially to the interminable delay. It appears that there must exist a more effective method for them to manage their operations!

Gorgeous casino, décor scheme seems to be taken from the Bellagio gardens- good mix of stores, restaurants, and gaming. Really appreciate how spacious this casino is, lots of space to walk around without cramming slot machines into every available nook.

Service is typically very top notch, and restaurants on site are known for being able to accommodate any dietary restriction and have several vegan, vegetarian, and vegetable-laden options at each.

Parking garage is smaller than most but easily accessible, casino itself is on the smaller side but more intimate and upscale rather than crowded and gaudy.

Had the popcorn with bacon for an appetizer - it was ok, but nothing great. We split the chicken and waffles - not bad, but not maybe I'm just not a fan of chicken & waffles in general (don't hate me). But - we also ordered the short rib, which was quite delicious! It came with some greens that were quite un-delicious and we didn't take more than 1 bite of them. \n\nIf you try it, get there early otherwise it gets VERY loud inside and you'll be yelling across the table to have a conversation.

This place was pretty nice (not super fancy but decorated nicely) but the food was average.  We came here bc someone had \"the best\" beef noodle soup here over a year ago and loved it.  Unfortunately, they did not like it this time, stating it was somewhat flavorless.  Food here is definitely overpriced, as I learned many restaurants in the nice casinos are, but we were comped so I can't complain about price.  However, had I had to pay for this meal, I would not have been happy.  I got the Hainan Chicken Rice, which was really dry.  Usually, the rice is simmered in broth, but the rice was pretty dry - chicken, too.  We also got the Beef Chow fun, which wasn't bad but not excellent either.  The best part of my meal was the Iced Coffee (which I think they charge $6 for).  Everyone also liked the Fried Shrimp Balls, which came on a dim sum cart.  I was excited to see Soupy Dumplings on the cart, but alas, they were only moist and not very soupy at all.  Most items were mediocre and I most likely will not eating here again.

I had the pleasure of partaking in a fleeting culinary experience at this establishment, whereupon I opted for my customary fare, specifically, a Bean Burrito and 7 Layer Burrito. My order was fulfilled with precision, the ambiance was spotless, and the comestibles were passable, albeit unremarkable. It is, after all, a Taco Bell franchise, and as such, it is challenging to proffer effusive praise. Notwithstanding, I shall indeed revisit this venue in the future.

I was here on valentine's day so we had the pre-fixed menu. Meal was overpriced because it was valentine's day. Nothing was really good. Maybe that's because they have to do things in bulk. The portions were small, but I didn't finish anything because it wasn't tasty.  We were still hungry afterwords. Still, we sat right by the window and the view was incredible!

It's an airport. You get to Vegas and then you immediately go straight to partying. Even the airport is calling for a party with the slot machines located at the baggage claims. \n\nThis airport moves pretty quick too. They get the job done and fly you to your destination! wohoo!

"Minus a star for not possessing an EPL ticket to display all the matches. For Pete's sake, you are THE English bar in Phoenix and I cannot observe my adored Gunners unless they are on channel 167? Come on! If you are going to hang the flags and scarves, at least have the game available, especially when it's 7 a.m., and I yearn to become intoxicated while viewing Arsenal-Chelsea in the fifth most populous city in the United States, and I am unable to do so; this does not make me a contented individual. Haha. All things considered, not a terrible establishment. Fantastic selection of beverages. Nice dÃ©cor, to sum up, it's one of those places where you can indulge in libations for 2-3 hours, exit, and exclaim, "Good Lord, the sun is still up?!"

"Upon experiencing issues with my PlayStation 3, specifically its inability to read discs, I brought it to this establishment for repair. Unfortunately, despite two attempts at rectifying the problem, the issue persisted. However, I must commend the business for their exceptional customer service and return policy, as they provided a full refund without hesitation. It is worth noting that while the repair itself was unsuccessful, the staff demonstrated a remarkable level of professionalism and courtesy throughout the process. On a separate note, I did observe some minor inconveniences during my visits, such as the removal of my unplayed copy of Grand Theft Auto V from its case and the less-than-ideal condition of the disc upon its return. Additionally, I encountered a lack of familiarity or continuity in the service provided during my multiple visits, as if each encounter was an isolated incident. Nonetheless, considering the positive aspects of my experience, I would not rule out the possibility of returning with future issues or recommending this business to others."

"While in Phoenix for a corporate conference, I had the pleasure of dining at Tutti Santi, a culinary establishment that was graciously recommended by my colleague's father-in-law, who had previously visited the restaurant on multiple occasions. Absent this suggestion, it is unlikely that I would have discovered this eatery on my own accord. 

On the evening in question, the restaurant was bustling with activity due to a special promotional event, which appeared to have caught the staff off guard. As a result, there was a considerable delay in placing our order, during which time we opted to sample a bottle of wine from their extensive selection. While awaiting the arrival of our appetizers, we indulged in the accompanying bread, which proved to be quite satisfying. However, owing to the sluggish pace of service, our initial bottle of wine was depleted well before the main courses were served. 

Upon the arrival of our food, we elected to procure an additional bottle of wine, which unfortunately failed to materialize. Despite bringing this oversight to the attention of our server, no further action was taken. This unfortunate sequence of events detracted significantly from our overall dining experience, transforming what would have otherwise been a four-star review into a decidedly less favorable assessment."

Table of 4, wait was 20++ minutes late on a Thursday night.   No bar to wait in, plus no alert system (buzzer or whatever) so we couldn't wander around the casino.   Once we were seated, the food was great.....  Just burgers but lots of toppings, etc.   Nothing bad nor was it overly memorable.  Very sufficient for a bite in Harrahs!

I am not too picky about movie theaters. We usually go to the theater with the show times we like best. They all could use a more frequent deep cleaning, and this one is no different.\n\nIt bothers me, though, when people think it is the movie theater's job to clean up after them, so they leave their trash in the aisle and on the seats. You bought it, you own it, you dispose of it up. Didn't your mom teach you to clean up after yourself?

"Applebee's typically offers palatable victuals at a relatively reasonable cost. However, my recent visit to this specific Applebee's location did not live up to my expectations, failing to provide an optimal dining experience that would motivate me to return. 

Our group of three was promptly seated, yet the service subsequently became sluggish. Our server delivered an incorrect type of beverage for one member of our party, which was followed by a delay in procuring the proper brew and an extended period before additional napkins were provided. 

I opted for a midday special that encompassed half of a sandwich and a diminutive salad. The shrimp and spinach salad possessed remarkable flavor; however, the sandwich I chose, specifically the California turkey club, featured lettuce with an unpleasant acidity that necessitated its removal, and the bread was excessively oily. 

The sangria presented a delectable taste, albeit with a scarcity of fruit that left room for improvement."

"I have had the experience of visiting this location on a previous occasion, and my impression was that it possessed a diminutive size, which was compensated for by an abundance of commercial establishments and a plethora of live musical performances. However, the ignition of the praying mantis at approximately 9 pm failed to resonate with my personal preferences, as I found the overall ambiance to be tailored predominantly towards family-oriented patrons, thereby engendering within me a sense of incongruity and prompting my companion and I to seek alternative forms of entertainment. Although I cannot rule out the possibility of revisiting this venue at some point in the future, I must confess that it does not currently hold a prominent position on my list of preferred destinations."
Way too over priced. I mean its great food. With an average sized portion. But for how much I'm paying?... Not totally worth it!

Here's the thing, I genuinely desire to endorse this establishment. It proximates my domicile, the minuscule cakes perpetually appear delectable, and an agreeable aroma permeates the atmosphere. I've visited this location on multiple occasions, and each time, I've encountered distinctive and imaginative flavors that I've seldom witnessed elsewhere; Pink Lemonade, Chocolate Covered Banana, and Peanut Butter and Honey, who would conceive of such combinations?!

However, possibly I frequented this establishment during inopportune periods. The cake presented itself as succulent and appetizing. Nonetheless, the icing proved excessively abundant and overpowering, even for my better half, who relishes sweets to an extent where he could effortlessly devour an entire tray of brownies unassisted and in a single sitting. He needed to extract the icing midway through consumption since it became too copious for his taste buds.

I won't relinquish my yearning for their products though! I shall likely revisit this venue due to my infatuation with cupcakes (we even incorporated them into our wedding celebrations), as I ardently aspire to appreciate their offerings.

"While I acknowledge that certain individuals may hold the opinion that this particular Buffett is of superior quality, I must respectfully disagree with such sentiments. In my personal experience, the breakfast offerings at this establishment far surpass the quality of the dinner options, and it is worth noting that the menu items for both meals share a considerable amount of overlap. Furthermore, I find it somewhat perplexing that there is such a significant discrepancy in the level of satisfaction between the two meals, leading me to question the validity of the claim that this Buffett is indeed the best."

I will start by saying this, the midnight Diner is probably one of the better staple restaurants in Charlotte. However my experience tonight did not reflect that. After being sat and refused to change my order by our server, Ashley - we then received beyond mediocre service.  Feeling somewhat stereotyped into the mold of \"black people don't tip\". Luckily a server by the name of Larry a.k.a \"Showtime\" managed to salvage what remained of an otherwise horrible experience. He definitely exempified the prototype of what anyone would call excellent service. Needless to say our server received no tip. Hopefully she learns something from her peers. Definitely will be back...and requesting \"Showtime\" as our server for the duration of his tenure there.

"Upon entering the realm of Las Vegas, I am immediately cognizant of my surroundings, and the exorbitant cost of a Subway sandwich serves as a stark reminder of the city's reputation for extravagance. The inflated price point of $20 for a $5 Footlong prompts me to ponder the legality of such a markup, eliciting a chuckle from myself at the sheer audacity of it all. Slots of Fun, an establishment boasting an array of entertainment options, can be likened to an unstoppable force, much like a 20-ton boulder careening down a steep incline. Despite my lack of interest in gambling, I find myself drawn to the venue, likely due to its nostalgic charm and old-school Vegas ambiance. While I may not partake in the gaming aspect, I do indulge in the culinary offerings, specifically Nathan's hot dogs and Subway sandwiches, albeit at an excessive cost. Notwithstanding my reservations regarding the prices, I must admit that there is an inexplicable allure to the establishment that keeps me coming back for more."

Being from Chicago/San Diego my husband and I are in for a shock here in the Carolinas, this was our first dining experience. I don't know how we ended up here with the plastic coated checkered table cloths and lack of ambience, but we stayed and ate. 

I was looking on the menut for the typical California wrap donned with bean sprouts and avocados; instead I found southern fried chicken, skillet fried chicken, veggie lasagna, meatloaf, coleslaw, fried okra, collard greens... and of course BBQ. 
My question to you is WHAT ON EARTH IS BBQ? Is it a sauce? Pork? Beef? Chicken? No clue... 
Anyways we ordered from their extensive menu ( the variety of "veggies" is outrageous, but mostly fried). 

***Note to North Carolina: Food does taste good without having to be breaded and dropped in piping hot fatty lard. 

The food ended up being good and large portions and the waitress was "sweet as piiiie" with her "yes maam's" and polite service. 
Overall, I am hoping to find a restaurant with more of a variety than sandwiches, southern home cooking and the most unhealthy vegetables I've ever seen.
Good location for a decent bite to eat before the game. Gets busy, but the food and service is good. Little on the pricy side.

This place is ok for a vietnamese restaurant. First impression walking in- this place smells of cigars! Later I realized it's the smell of the cigar bar next door. 

Service was rather quick. The man who attended to us seemed to be the owner, he was approachable and would give recommendations if you ask. 

Our food was out pretty fast. I ordered the beef pho with eye round steak and beef balls while the bf got his usual chicken pho. We also got the vietnamese iced coffee. 

I love the broth! It was not as greasy as some of the other vietnamese places I've been to, and you can actually taste the herbs. The rice noodles was meh, it was a little too starchy for me, for some reason. The eye round steak was a little overdone. Iced coffee was a tad too sweet, there's a little too much of the condensed milk. 

Overall, a decent experience. I'll probably come back again. 

Side note: if you like spicy food, ask for the ot satay sauce. it's basically Thai chillies fried with garlic paste and it is SPICY- a much better alternative to siracha, in my opinion.

This establishment... how could one not develop an affection for it?! The beverages offered here are truly exceptional and the cost is remarkably reasonable!! I would highly recommend either the \"G Spot\" or a martini, both of which are impeccably crafted and bound to satiate your thirst. The culinary offerings at this venue are also quite impressive. Specifically, the Fez burger is a personal favorite of mine, although I must admit that I am uncertain of the specific ingredients that comprise it. Nonetheless, I can confidently attest that it possesses an unparalleled flavor!! Unfortunately, I must concede that my experience was somewhat marred by an unexpected bout of illness that ensued later that evening. As I had consumed sustenance from multiple sources throughout the day, I cannot with certainty attribute the source of my discomfort to this particular eatery. However, I must confess that my reluctance to revisit this establishment has been augmented.

Evidently, there exists a Zagat survey list pertaining to the optimal chain restaurant steak, which I find utterly absurd. Would they compose a list assessing the finest cinematic depiction of grass growth? "In the end, Crabgrass surpassed Ragweed due to its potential allergens." No, since sometimes an entire category of items can be created that are subpar, and chain eateries, as a general rule, offer unsatisfactory steak. Not that I'm passing judgment. So, if you dine at Outback, refrain from anticipating anything remarkable, despite Zagat's assertion that they served delectable steak. However, Outback remains worth visiting, as their shrimp appetizer, presented on a brown bread garlic slab-thing, is sublime. The bread itself surpasses the shrimp in quality. It's truly amazing. But to attain genuinely legendary status, envision an appetizer containing such copious calories that three individuals could share it and still consume over a thousand calories apiece. Enter the cheese fries accompanied by bacon and a dollop of ranch, and you will comprehend the sensation of spoonfuls of lard within your arteries. This specific establishment boasts several exceptional bartenders, and if you seek a gratifying experience and passable cuisine, you shall be content. Chicken breast smothered in BBQ sauce: palatable. Broccoli augmented with crab-butter sauce? Delicious. A rack of lamb? Surprisingly satisfying. In truth, there are numerous options available here, but one thing you will not encounter is world-beating steak. Hence, it is pointless to rely on Zagat's survey.

Great ambience! This bar was a great place to grab a drink & people watch or just hang with great company. I really enjoyed the lounge style decor & the drinks here are pretty decent for a casino bar.

I, of course, ordered a vodka grey goose with tonic and was surprised that 75% of it was alcohol. My friend ordered a rum & diet coke and again the drink had a good amount of rum. :-) I'm not quite sure on pricing but seemed decent.

The waitresses are dressed in cute lacy mini dresses and are very pleasant. Overall, for a hotel lobby bar this is a good spot.

Overhyped. Capriotti's has some good sandwiches and some that just don't connect.

My favorite sandwich here is the Capastrami, greasy pastrami grilled with melted Swiss, generously topped with creamy cole slaw and Russian dressing. Reubenesque and held together well by the bread.

Unfortunately, that same bread is the reason why Capriotti's cheesesteaks and Italian subs don't work. The rolls on which its subs are served are hard and dense, which means they don't absorb the favors and moisture of the rest of the sandwich.

The cheesesteaks also suffer from meat that's grisly, dry and flavorless. Bland would be a word for it.

The Bobbie isn't my thing - I think mayo is gross, and without it the Bobbie sandwich gets unbearably dry. That being said, the store roasted turkey goes great on cold subs with provolone and hot peppers.

Jersey Mike's is better for cold subs and Pop's is the place to go in Vegas for cheesesteaks.

Good but not sure it's worth all the hype.  Went there with a fairly large group of friends and had to wait a pretty long time to be seated.  It's a small place and right now very trendy so be prepared to wait.

I found their red velvet pancakes a but too sweet and definitely overrated.  I love red velvet but when you add in the chocolate chips and their icing it was just too sweet.  It was better without all the other stuff but then slightly dry.

Liked their buttermilk pancakes more.  Nice and moist and delicious with the butter and syrup.

Believe I also got corned beef hash - it was very good but the potatoes with it were meh.

My review is mainly for the Casino (As I was staying next door at the Palazzo).  I really wanted to like this place and went in with high expectations. The place itself was crowded with mainly foreigners taking pictures everywhere and walking super slow. I found one slot game that I liked, but could not play long because the guy next to me had his entire family sit on the other machines and they were not playing. Really wanted to get into the table games but just too many people out and about to get by. I will stop in again next time because I did have a good feeling.

I have had the pleasure of partaking in the culinary offerings of this esteemed establishment on three separate occasions, with two of those experiences being of the drive-thru variety and the most recent being a dine-in visit. I must say, I am delighted that I opted to dine in, for it afforded me the opportunity to observe the kitchen staff in their natural habitat, so to speak. One of the cooks, a Caucasian male, was not adorned in the customary gloves worn by his colleagues, which, in conjunction with his unfortunate lack of hygiene, led me to question the overall cleanliness of the kitchen. Furthermore, upon venturing to the restroom, I discovered that the paper towel dispenser was devoid of its intended contents, thus necessitating my utilization of the blower, which, in turn, produced an abundance of noise that served as a stark contrast to the otherwise tranquil ambiance of the dining area. This sequence of events led me to deduce that the aforementioned cook had neglected to properly sanitize his hands prior to resuming his culinary duties. Lastly, as I emerged from the restroom, I was greeted by the sight of the same individual grasping a generous portion of bacon, which, coincidentally, happened to be a key component of my companion's bacon burger. It is worth noting that the cook's attire, or lack thereof, accentuated his posterior region in a manner that was conspicuous and, some might argue, inappropriate. While I do intend to return to this establishment in the future, I do so with the hope that the aforementioned cook will not be present during my subsequent visits. Notwithstanding the aforementioned issues, I must admit that the quality of the burgers and fries served here is quite impressive.

I had previously become cognizant of the existence of Pink's Hot Dogs in Southern California and had always harbored an ardent desire to sample their culinary offerings. Thus, when I became aware of the presence of a Pink's establishment in Las Vegas, my excitement reached palpable levels. Unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely met, to put it mildly. I opted to order the mushroom swiss dog, which carried a price tag of $6.50. Upon consuming the hot dog, I was struck by its rubbery texture, which was somewhat disappointing. Furthermore, the Swiss cheese component of the dish was not as copious as I had anticipated, leading to intermittent bursts of flavor that were not as pronounced as they could have been. While the combination of mushrooms, Swiss cheese, and hot dog was undoubtedly delectable during those fleeting moments when all three elements converged, the overall experience was marred by an imbalance in ingredient ratios. Specifically, an excess of mushrooms and an insufficient amount of cheese detracted from my enjoyment. However, despite this underwhelming encounter, I would still be willing to partake in Pink's offerings once again in the future, albeit with a differing menu selection. Rumor has it that their chili cheese dog is positively sublime, and I am eager to verify the veracity of such claims.

Any pub on Rose St immediately has to compete with swathes of competitive drinking holes. As a result the Auld Hundred seems like another humdrum offering with nothing of particular attraction here. Then again, that may be exactly what the clientele like: a reliable and no frills establishment.\n\nYou'll find typically generous pub size portions with regards to food and a modest selection of ales, A- OK.

I stayed here for a bachelor party.  I've been here numerous times.  I love the location as it is within walking distance to all the hotels I like hanging at.  I like the fact that they gave me a fat discount because of a collective of my friends player points.  It isn't the newest hotel, but the rooms are clean and the staff were good.  I enjoyed their sportsbook.  Unfortunately, I was unable to do any dining over there nor have I ever dined over there.  That's a shame.  I would stay there again just for the price, but there are far superior hotels in Las Vegas.

"The personnel are assiduous and accommodating, catering to the needs of patrons with alacrity and proficiency. On a particular evening, we opted to partake in a culinary excursion to this establishment, accompanied by our offspring. The fare served was, unsurprisingly, reminiscent of traditional bar cuisine - rich and savory, yet lacking in subtlety and refinement. However, our experience was significantly marred by the egregious volume of the musical performance, which rendered communication at our table utterly futile. Despite the commendable service, I would confer merely three stars, as the ambiance was less than ideal and the setting was not particularly conducive to an intimate or family-oriented dining experience. In fact, it would be more suitable for a casual gathering or socializing with acquaintances, rather than a romantic evening or quality time with loved ones."

"Cutting directly to the point, my culinary assessment of this establishment's offerings can be succinctly summarized as follows: the victuals served are merely passable, barely meeting expectations. In the event that you find yourself in close proximity and are seeking a rapid consumable meal, this venue may prove satisfactory. However, if your gastronomical inclinations lean towards genuinely exceptional Chinese cuisine, I would strongly advise venturing elsewhere, perhaps to Spring Mountain or, more specifically, the Golden State itself. Having recently returned from Los Angeles, where I indulged in some truly remarkable Chinese fare, my dining experience at this location proved underwhelming. For categorization purposes, I would relegate this eatery's culinary style to the same realm as Panda Express - while certainly palatable, it falls short of authentic Chinese cuisine."

I hadn't had Papa John's for at least a year.  It's one of the better chain pizza places, and unlike the Domino's that moved, it's conveniently on my way home from work.  I got a $10 gift card for $5 from www.saveology.com and they had their large specialty pizzas for $11.  The large is only 14\" which isn't really large, but the Spinach Alfredo pizza is pretty tasty.  I was disappointed they no longer put the butter sauce and pepporncini in the pizza box, but I understand it.  The service was a little slow as they have two registers but only one person working on one of them with a lot of people standing around.  I'd stop here for a pizza on my way home again if the price was right.

"I recently had the opportunity to observe this production for the second time, having previously experienced it without my spouse, who expressed a strong desire to view it. This particular show diverges significantly from the conventional Cirque du Soleil offerings, possessing a distinct emphasis on Asian-inspired elements, swordplay, and acrobatic feats. Unlike the majority of Cirque du Soleil performances, which tend to resemble a dreamlike state with little coherence and an assortment of breathtaking, heart-stopping acrobatic acts, KA boasts a discernible narrative thread and utilizes wires in a manner that mitigates any sense of fear or apprehension. 

However, certain aspects of the production, such as the linguistic style employed and select characterizations (including a Tarzan-esque figure), prove challenging to fully comprehend or appreciate. Despite having had the chance to experience the show twice, it remains outside my personal preferences within the Cirque du Soleil repertoire, and thus, I am grateful for the affordable ticket prices obtained on both occasions. The single aspect that truly captivated me was the expansive mobile platform capable of shifting between horizontal and vertical orientations, with the concluding sequence featuring combat on the vertical surface being my favorite; regrettably, the remaining segments did not hold my interest to the same degree as other productions within the Cirque du Soleil canon."

C'est un caf\u00e9 correct pour travailler et pour se prendre un lunch quand on a oubli\u00e9 le sien \u00e0 la maison. Je suis all\u00e9e \u00e0 l'heure du lunch et \u00e7a n'\u00e9tais pas trop occup\u00e9, donc la combinaison de wifi gratuit et grandes tables pour travailler \u00e9tait exactement ce que je cherchais. Ils ont un bonne vari\u00e9t\u00e9 de plats et le service est bien correct. J'ai pris deux salades : une aux l\u00e9gumes et moutarde dijon, puis l'autre l\u00e9gumes et p\u00e2tes \u00e0 l'orientale, ou bien plut\u00f4t simplement \u00e0 la sauce soya. Les deux \u00e9taient super bonne et j'ai bien aim\u00e9 avoir l'option d'un lunch sans trop de pain. Ils ont aussi des plats chauds et des plats du jour qui ont l'air de changer r\u00e9guli\u00e8rement. Somme toute, c'est un endroit qui m\u00e9lange le style caf\u00e9t\u00e9ria avec le style caf\u00e9 sans fla fla. C'est argent comptant, mais il y a un ATM au caf\u00e9 m\u00eame.

Went here for dinner on Friday night... We had 8 dudes, but even though we had a reservation and it was late (9:45)... we had to wait a bit and they sat us outside...in the 100 degree heat.  The heat wasn't a big deal, but we kind of missed out on the whole decor and atmosphere of the inside.  The kobe meatball was very good.  I just got an 8 ounce filet.  It was good... but it doesn't even come w/ a potato or anything... but the side of asparagus i got was heaping and tasty.  The filet was good though... cooked to my specifications and seasoned nicely... most other people got pasta dishes... do'nt know what they thought, but most looked pretty normal.  Service was good.  They got everything right.  Not super pricey, but pricey.  But overall I was underwhelmed... I just had the feeling that I would rather pay more to eat better or pay less to eat junky.  No real complaints... but I wasn't wowed by anything.

Tried their 2 for $5 fish sandwiches and their $1.89 side salad.  The fish sandwich had too much bread for my liking and the fish was just okay.  The salad was iceberg and not worth me getting again.  The service was excellent and the lady manager is doing a great job,  The place is nicely decorate but I didn't think the food was worth me coming back for,

Great food and great WINE. Awesome pasta, the description matched exactly what I got. When I asked the waiter to describe the wine I wanted to order, he described it to a T. What was just supposed to be a small appetizer and a drink turned into a meal. Very elegant, very nice, VERY GOOD!

Paid for a venti green tea lemonade and got a tall green tea lemonade . Reason why I didn't go back was because I had to go to school was in a rush I wish the girls that always take my orders were there

"The superior quality of the donuts at this establishment in South Phoenix renders it an optimal destination for indulging in such delectable treats, thereby making the arduousness of laboring in the aforementioned location thoroughly worthwhile; specifically, the maple bar variety is exceptionally scrumptious."

"It is palpable that the singular attribute which renders this establishment appealing is the captivating appearance and texture of their bread, which boasts an unparalleled freshness and taste. However, it is conspicuous that the sandwiches themselves are rather unremarkable and overpriced, with a cost of $5-6 for a meager offering. \n\nThe level of service provided by this establishment is glaringly inadequate, as there are merely a few employees present at any given time, leading to a sluggish and impatient experience for patrons. Furthermore, the antiquated nature of the building and the limited parking options available, including a minuscule rear lot, contribute to the overall dearth of convenience. Notwithstanding, I do concede that the diminutive original sandwich is moderately satisfying, primarily due to the exceptional quality of the bread. Nevertheless, if this eatery were to adopt a more conventional sub bread or baguette for their sandwiches, it is improbable that I would opt to dine here."

The short: Get the \"white cookie\" fresh from the oven, at the front cafe for $5. OMG. OMG. \n\nThe long: inside at the restaurant: long waits, water refills - had to ask each time. \"Sunday pasta\" did a number on my tummy! :-(. Best thing on the menu - the $5 white cookies in front cafe, fresh out of the oven. Wish i spent my groupon on just those cookies. Forget the entrees, they're nothing special - typical ingredients prepared en masse so they can be thrown together and then onto your plate. That's how it tastes. And you'll pay a premium to find out I'm right.

"Culinary indulgences abounded at this eatery, yet an enigmatic quality remained, eluding my comprehension. Ambience was satisfactory, despite the auditory assault emanating from the adjacent gaming arena. Prompt seating was accorded to us, sans reservation, during the meridian repast. The bill of fare, though diminutive in scope, boasted a diverse array of delectable options. I opted for the prime steak panini, accompanied by a tangy potato salad. A delightful confluence of flavors, complemented by the subtle pungency of barbecue sauce and a trace of horseradish, permeated the panini. The potato salad, a veritable masterpiece, struck the perfect balance between piquancy and richness, with just the right amount of mayonnaise. Regrettably, the hospitality encountered a marked decline, as sluggish service prevailed. An extended wait ensued before our check was delivered, followed by an even lengthier delay in retrieving my credit card. Infrequent were the instances wherein the server graced our presence with her attendance, post-consumption of the meal."

"The beet salad was an absolute culinary masterpiece, boasting an unparalleled harmony of flavors that left my taste buds in a state of pure delight. However, the service we received was somewhat lacking in its execution, as evidenced by the unfortunate incident involving the spillage of water onto my table while I was partaking in my meal. Furthermore, I must say that the short rib loco moco, despite its otherwise delectable appearance, was unfortunately marred by an excessive saltiness that proved to be somewhat off-putting to my palate."

3.5 stars. 

Went with a group of friends this weekend for the open bar mostly. Guys got in for 20, which isn't that bad. Bouncers were a little rude for cover, not cool. 

TAO is really nice, appearance wise. Walking though the restaurant before going to the club did make me hungry. what a tease. 

Went early enough where there wasn't any issues of space. Our main goal here was drink, so we didn't get to explore the other dance floors, but that's okay, maybe next time. While most of the drink were aight, they made some pretty bad basic well drinks, and the wait to get a drink was long. Like come on, messing up a rum and coke? and waiting as much as I was dancing wasn't too hot either. But hey, was feeling really good after we left, so I'm not complaining too much, The music wasn't that bad too. Too bad we didn't know that dash berlin was playing that night. Well, bad that we didn't get to hear him play. good because we left before it got ridiculously packed. We were ale to dance with a great amount of space. and trust, with a group of dancers, we need our space. 

Overall, not a bad time at TAO. Guess I need another trip to really go exploring.

"My expectations were elevated upon entering this establishment due to the numerous favorable critiques I had perused prior to my visit. However, what I encountered was a satisfactory yet unremarkable local eatery that was perhaps slightly overrated. My culinary experience began with a palatable but overcooked burger, which elicited an involuntary mental protest as the chef applied excessive pressure to the patty, resulting in a regrettably desiccated texture. The accompanying fries, while possessing a satisfying crunch, lacked any discernible distinctiveness or flavor profile, rendering them unmemorable. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the quality of the ingredients utilized did meet my expectations, as the beef patties were freshly prepared and not frozen, and the generous allocation of bacon ensured a consistent presence of savory flavor in each bite. Additionally, the lettuce was fresh and crisp, contributing to an overall adequate, albeit overpriced, dining experience. While I am unlikely to return, I might consider patronizing this restaurant again in the future if circumstances necessitated a convenient and casual meal option."

Good place to go and eat gyros if your up in North Scottsdale. The staff is friendly and the food gets to you real fast. The price is somewhere between 7-10 per meal but that's usual for N. Scottsdale.

Maybe I've had better Chinese in the past than I realized, or perhaps I ordered the wrong things, but I can't see giving this place five stars. The egg rolls were too salty, the hot and sour soup was lacking in sour, the vegetable pork was bland.\n\nIt's quick, not over priced and not over cooked. I'm willing to try it again.

"Grampa's Pizzeria - a culinary establishment named after its proprietor, which boasts an impressive reputation for serving delectable pizzas crafted with premium ingredients and ingenious flavor combinations, thus eliciting immense affection from patrons, including myself. However, my most recent dining experience at Grampa's raised concerns about the possibility of cognitive decline in the elderly proprietor, as evidenced by the perplexed expression on the host's countenance upon our entrance, which seemed to convey a mixture of curiosity and bewilderment regarding our identity and purpose. Moreover, the appetizer we ordered emerged from the kitchen uncooked, prompting me to inquire whether it had been inadvertently forgotten in the preparation process. After some hesitation, the staff decided to reheat it, albeit with a lack of conviction. Furthermore, an unspecified mishap occurred with the pizza, leading our server to intimate that its arrival would be delayed, much to our dismay. Nevertheless, Grampa's magnanimity prevailed, as we received a complimentary beverage in compensation for the inconvenience caused by the chaos that ensued. It is fortunate that the restaurant was not bustling with customers on that particular Monday evening, lest Grampa's advanced age and apparent forgetfulness might have resulted in utter bedlam."

It has been an extended period of time since I have had the opportunity to undergo a comprehensive ocular examination, and my previous experiences with eye exams have been limited to cursory evaluations conducted primarily for the purpose of obtaining a driver's license or briefly gazing into a machine to identify objects. However, in light of Denise's recent efforts to prioritize her own eye care, I recognized the importance of scheduling an appointment for myself as well. Consequently, I registered at the Christenbury Eye Center, which boasts a highly organized and professional environment, characterized by a seamless procession of patients through various rooms, wherein specialists administer a diverse array of assessments designed to evaluate the functionality of one's visual acuity. Although I cannot verify the authenticity of their methods, the center's reputation is reinforced by endorsements from renowned individuals who attest to the staff's expertise. Moreover, they offer advanced laser eye surgery procedures, but subsequent to administering medicated drops that caused my pupils to dilate and significantly impaired my vision for several hours, the specialists concluded that my eyes were in fact in optimal condition. Hence, I am hopeful that I will not be required to return for an extended interval.

Last night, we visited this establishment for the initial time, and our experience was marred by several unfortunate incidents. Firstly, gaining entry took an interminable duration, and subsequently, a disagreement ensued between us and another patron regarding the parking arrangement, which led to an altercation. Moreover, the auditory clarity of the film was compromised due to the proximity of our screen to the adjacent one, causing an overlap in audio. Furthermore, the presence of helicopters overhead added to the sensory distraction. Nonetheless, the cost of admission was remarkably affordable, and we even had vouchers for condiments, which served as a minor consolation amidst the chaos.

I imagine at least a solid 60% of people who are trying to catch morning or afternoon flights out of here are hung over. \n\nWho thought it was a good idea to make this the loudest, brightest airport in the country?

"A diverse array of culinary selections, with notable highlights including the Grits & Pork Belly dish, which ascended to an elevated position among our preferences as the epicurean experience progressed, while the service, unfortunately, displayed fluctuations in its delivery, resulting in an inconsistent encounter; nevertheless, the atmosphere, despite a minor dearth of vitality, remained generally convivial, and the quality of the fare, particularly in relation to the price point, proved impressive, suggesting that once certain operational kinks are addressed, this establishment has the potential to evolve into a truly exceptional dining destination."

"Halted momentarily for a pie with my progeny, considerable portion of pizza, copious toppings, a wee bit excessively lubricated, presumably attributed to the pepperoni. In general, considered it satisfactory. Cuisine materialized expeditiously, will pause briefly to sample another item on a subsequent visit... Oh yes, no fountain beverages were available.... For me, a drawback."

This critique pertains to the culinary indulgence; specifically, the savory meatballs served at a recent evening meal, which, despite the lackluster and detached demeanor exhibited by the servers, proved to be a veritable gustatory delight, rendering the overall dining experience gratifying, albeit partially mitigated by the unfortunate deficiency in attentive hospitality. Furthermore, the agreeable climate and picturesque terrace setting, offering an unobstructed view of the iconic Las Vegas Strip, contributed significantly to the enjoyment of the repast. It is worth mentioning that previous experiences within the eatery's indoor confines were markedly less captivating.

I had some drinks & pizza here on 6/28/12.

I was here on a Thursday, and this place was PACKED & INSANE!  It was pretty much elbow-room only.  Not much privacy, and the atmosphere was very loud.  

The service was excellent, but the food was VERY expensive for what you are getting.  Thin-crust pizza was tasty, but very well-done & crispy/crunchy.  Some may like it this well-done, and some may not.

The bathrooms are VERY small (single person - Lock door behind you).  This absolutely DOES NOT go with the capacity at which the restaurant was at.  Expect a wait if you have to pee.

I may or may not come back.

Not that I know what good or real Korean is...but I am a fan of any good asian-type cuisine. 

Simple decor and we were attended to quickly (I think we were the second table). The table ordered the Korean BBQ ribs and I got the dolsot (I think). The meat was greasy, fatty with very light sweet sauce - just the way it's supposed to be. The dolsot came served in a huge stone smoking hot bowl. You have to stir it with your spoon to get all the rice, veggies and meat mixed up and a little crispy hot. Not  a lot of flavor but an interesting option for something new.

The sides were good though maybe uninspired. Who knew that Koreans ate appleas and mayonnaise just like I did in the midwest! It was a good sweetness to counter the spicy kim-chee!

A good option in downtown Chandler when you want to eat outside the box.

Service is great here, but I was disappointed in the fuku burger.  The patty itself and everything about the burger was slightly above average at best. I was expecting something more for the price tag on the burger...more along the lines of STOUT, but it didn't deliver.  Even the togarashi french fries were average.  \n\nIt is in a cool food court hang out spot.

Well the service was five stars. The bread with the olive paste really good. Ehhhh I think that is where it stops. The calamari was bland and too salty the sauce was spicy and decent. I ordered the pesto gnocchi it was mediocre like chef boyardi with green sauce. My partner had the steak and it just had way too too much pepper and the Alfredo sauce for the pasta well let's just say it made Olive Garden look like Ruth Chris steakhouse. The dessert was good. So dessert and bread yes, but food heck no. The portions were also very large just wished I likes my food.

Went there yesterday to watch a postseason game with other Yelpers.  As far as watching TVs went, there wasn't a bad seat in the house.  For those that hate smoke there is a non smoking entrance in the back to the bar side but if you want to play pool or use the Men's room you still have to run the gauntlet of the smoking patio.  Speaking of the Men's room, I have seen worse but this one wasn't really kept up that well and it could use a mopping as my feet stuck to the floor by the urinal. 

They had plenty of good choices for beer on tap.  I was intending on a burger but table quantities of other stuff arrived.  The nachos were ok.  I don't normally care for hot wings because they are, well, hot.  These were grilled and while they left a slight after burn for me were really quite good.  I also had an onion ring, a potato skin and a cheese stick.  Good solid bar food without being Wow.  Service bounced between really good and "where did she go?".  They were out of stuff like iced tea, some brownies and some of the beers.  As a table we were buying enough drinks that those that mixed in glasses of water were not questioned.

All in all a good solid neighborhood bar.

OK,

Pizza delivered to my hotel.  Check.
Opened up the box and the pie looked delicious. Check.
Pizza had ingredients as requested. Check.
Pizza cut in squares, like a true Chicago pie. Check
Pizza cut all the way through the dough. EPIC FAIL.

My oh my.  When you pick up a slice (Chizona's cuts the pie is squares) you want to pick up a slice with all of the ingredients on top of the slice.  Three of us (two who never had a Chicago style thin crust) and not one slice was cut all the way through.  In a hotel room, with no cutlery we tried our best to keep the ingredients on top of each slice, but pulling apart slices, that are not cut, created an awful mess.  We ended up with a bunch of hand pulled empty slices, and trying our best to put the ingredients on each slice.  We gave up.

If you cant cut a pie, which is so Pizza 101, than you create a crappy experience for your customer.  

3 stars for the fresh ingredients, great sauce, the owner adding some Giardiniera (very fresh and tasty). Minus 2 stars for the mess that was created by the pizza not being cut all the way through.

I had so much higher hope's.

Stay hungry my friends...

I went here many years ago and thinking that it was really impressive.  My latest trip has taken a 5 star review down to 3.  There really is nothing extraordinary about this buffet, other than the fact that it is in the Paris hotel.  The buffet is not really long either!  I remember there being a lot of fishy foods, which I could careless for.  The wait line on a Sunday evening was 1 hour!  It is NOT worth the wait!

Very representative of the situation my wife and I often find ourselves in: it is hard to find good food on vacation. Lemongrass offers classically mediocre Thai food, plus you will get a 1 hour wait for absolutely no reason. Our meal: fried spring rolls ($10) these were clearly straight out of the freezer, no flavor, soggy vegetables; pho reeked of cinnamon ($15); Singapore Noodles Stir-fried rice vermicelli, BBQ pork, shrimp, onion, bean sprouts, bell pepper, egg, curry powder ($18) this was quite good and very spicy, earning Lemongrass 3 instead of 2 stars.\n\nPoor food, poor service, long wait. Do not make a reservation; I would suggest trying a different restaurant.

I also am surprised that there are not more reviews for Betty Lou. We did the Monona brunch cruise and really liked it.

Overall, the gig is pretty sweet, but I'll admit they have some serious room for improvement.

Major cons: value for price, selection of seats on the boat, availability of crew/service

Major pros: taste and amount of food, quality of atmosphere/boat

It was really disappointing when we got on to be shoved out of the way by a group of young children, who ended up getting seats on the top deck. If you get there early (like we did), start to line up right in front of the wooden dock to the boats, as that's where they board from. It would be much more organized if they called groups onto the boat in the order they were booked.

The food was AMAZING. So good and perfectly organized into appetizers, main course, and dessert. I loved it!

The mimosas were tasty, but were weak and it was difficult to get a waitress/bartender as there were only 2 of them tending to the entire boat of 50 people. You are dismissed from your table to go and get food, but we were never dismissed for the first round. Again, it was difficult to get the attention of the crew/waitresses.

The views were really scenic and the captain does a quick spin at the end so that you can take photos with the Capitol and the Monona Terrace in the background.

As much as I love this place, I really think I'm twenty years too young to be here. I really love the genres played here and I consider myself pretty well versed in the music. I can't figure out if I'm a young person with a taste for real music, or if everyone who likes real music is older than I. 

I showed up on a Friday which is the night when Baddness plays. I think it was them because they played stuff from EW&F, Gap Band, Maze, and bunch of others. No blues that night, just funk. The thing I loved about this band it that I would've expected to see them in an early Jarmusch film like Mystery Train. They were a five or six piece band in all red suits with the lead vocalist in an all red, sequened coat. It was quite possibly the most badass thing I've seen on a music stage in Phoenix. A definite A plus for music and style.

As far as a blues house goes, I don't really know if I'd consider this one. The Rhythm Room seems to be more up my alley and they seem to have to be a real venue for artists passing through. This definitely seems more like a dive bar/lounge for people who like the music. Again, I really want to come back to this place but I think I should wait a few more years because clearly I should've been born twenty years earlier.

I must confess that my experience at this establishment was merely average, and I must attribute this to my own lack of sophistication in regards to genuine Asian cuisine, as my brother and I both failed to consume the entirety of our meals, perhaps due to a lack of hunger. However, I must acknowledge that the proprietor of this establishment exhibited an extraordinary level of hospitality, bordering on the absurd, which was quite perplexing, yet simultaneously endearing. Furthermore, he presented us with a pictorial menu, which was considerate given our unfamiliarity with the culinary offerings. Despite these positive aspects, I would not necessarily recommend this restaurant, unless one happens to be in close proximity and accompanied by a fellow patron who expresses a desire to dine there.

Whenever I past by this restaurant, it always give me this homey feeling to it and thought to myself that one day I'll make some time to go. And I did. When I went there, I was promptly seated planned to be unbiased throughout the whole meal. Service was good.. Unfortunately, their food was just mediocre for the price I've paid. The menu is what I call, \"tourist price\". (Over priced) Tofu Hut serve similar things there for a less expensive price. If their food was as good as the place looks, I would've give them another star but eh, food was alright.
The food is tasty, but so much MSG!  I'm usually not very sensitive to MSG, but man you can really feel it after you eat here!

"Why the hell does everyone have stuffed animals?! Apparently, they gift you a stuffed animal post placing your order, so when you're seated, they know which table to deliver the cuisine to. I thought it was a pleasant gesture, so I said, 'No thanks' to the filthy stuffed animal. Then I pondered why the food never arrived. Chuy's reminds me of the surf n' turf taco shops by the beach. I enjoy the meat and seafood options and, in particular, the aroma of grilled cuisine, but the flavor could benefit from significantly more spice. The menu was extensive and provided a multitude of options. Too many to catalog, and I believe they even offer fried chicken? Strange. 

I ordered the Broiled Whitefish Taco Platter ($6) with a side of Shrimp Skewers ($4). The shrimp skewer was superb; I sprinkled some lemon juice on it, along with some hot sauce, and that alone was a superior meal to my taco platter. The fish did not taste 'fresh," and I am still uncertain about what whitefish is. The rice and beans were average. The cabbage salad required assistance. It consisted of chopped cabbage with a vinaigrette. 

I was not impressed by Chuy's, but I could return there. It's a secure alternative; perhaps next time, I should sample their $2 margaritas, which they serve all day, every day. Now that's a thought!"

Amidst my utter disbelief at having neglected to evaluate this establishment, I must confess that my recent visit on July 3rd, during an unseasonably sweltering mid-day, proved to be a rather underwhelming experience. Despite the allure of Serendipity's al fresco dining area, the oppressive heat rendered it uninhabitable, leading to a regrettable twenty-to-twenty-five minute wait to be seated. Upon being escorted to our table, I opted to sample their renowned "Strip Steak Sandwich," only to discover that the portion size, while generous, did not quite meet my expectations regarding the quality of the cut of meat. Notwithstanding this minor shortcoming, the culinary offerings generally met my approval, save for a perceived slight overpricing.

Unfortunately, the unfavorable meteorological conditions coupled with my satiation precluded me from indulging in their delectable desserts and enjoying the outdoor seating. However, I did return the following day, opting to avail myself of their convenient walk-up, to-go window, whereupon I sampled both the traditional frozen hot chocolate and its Oreo-infused counterpart. While neither variant disappointed, the latter boasted a richer, more complex flavor profile, which I found vastly superior. Moreover, I noticed that the portion sizes of these drinks seemed smaller than those served within the restaurant proper, a phenomenon I could not readily explain. In conclusion, I shall endeavor to patronize Serendipity's New York location in the near future, thereby enabling me to compare and contrast the two establishments.

Underwear for $1 and bras for $10?!?! Yes, please!*














*Disclaimer: Only in the sale section, and only if you can locate your correct size.

They serve the simple \"street\" style tacos I like. I had one al pastor and one asada. Both tacos were tasty. The al pastor had a nice spice to it. I also had a green tamale that was really gross. All masa and barely any cheese or green chile they said was suppose to come in it. Can't seem to find a spot with good tamales around here. I also got a jamaica to drink and wished I had gotten the horchata that I initially wanted instead. It was watered down and sour without the sweet.  So basically... come here for the tacos... don't bother with anything else. \n\n*Note: I didn't receive this as I ordered take out, but there was a sign that said \"free chips and salsa for dine in customers\".

I go to Vegas a couple times a year  and I stay at different casinos .  This last time in September I stayed at the Excalibur.  We have stayed here before.  We always enjoy this casino, the rooms are clean and comfortable and the price is reasonable.  This last time we left a tip for the maid who was cleaning our room. She left us a thank you note, which I thought was very thoughtful of her.  It is the first time anyone has written us a thank you note for a tip. Her name was Clementine and she did a wonderful job.

"This particular Costco establishment does not rank among the most exceptional I have had the privilege of visiting. Several aspects of the experience leave room for improvement, in my opinion. Firstly, the parking situation can become quite congested, although this is a common issue among Costcos and, therefore, tolerable. My primary concerns revolve around the sampling services. Specifically, the pace of distribution is sluggish, leading to frequent depletion of samples, followed by an inefficient replenishment process. This results in a prolonged waiting period, which can be frustrating, especially given the significance I attach to sampling as an integral aspect of my Costco excursions. In fact, I have visited other Costco locations where the sampling process operates with greater efficiency, characterized by a steady supply of offerings and a more seamless experience.  

Another drawback of this Costco lies in its car wash facilities. While the exterior cleaning function performs admirably, the interior remains unattended, lacking essential vacuuming amenities. Notably, this absence of vacuum services distinguishes this car wash from others that typically provide such features.  

Despite these shortcomings, I still derive pleasure from procuring beverages, such as beer and wine, at this Costco. Their extensive selection of alcoholic beverages, including sizable vodka bottles, holds appeal for me. Additionally, I recently became aware of their discounted restaurant cards, which offer welcome savings.  

In summary, while this Costco presents some limitations, I shall persist in visiting, albeit with a slight scowl during the prolonged sample intervals."

Three stars for taste and unique style pizza. But for a quick lunch, fogettabout it. Slow......Come on guys, your customer base in the industrial area have to be in and out in 20 minutes to get back to work. Here is a clue....SLICES! And while you are at it, a \"slice and a drink\" lunch special  please. Most pizza joints have this, right? I would enjoy your great pizza more often, if in a reasonably time and price......

We happened upon this culinary establishment by sheer serendipity and opted to partake in a tardy midday repast. Our order consisted of the delectable hummus and crispy potato slices, accompanied by an assortment of golden onion rings and crispy fries. Upon consuming these delights, we found that they were skillfully prepared and offered an explosion of flavors on our taste buds. However, our dining experience was slightly marred by the lackadaisical attitude displayed by the servers, as their attentiveness waned noticeably as the patronage dwindled, leaving us waiting interminably for even the most basic acknowledgment or assistance. Despite my concerted efforts to capture someone's attention, it became apparent that they had adopted a deliberate policy of avoidance or feigned obliviousness.

Popped in here for a dinner with friends and having only been here for lunch I had yet to try the BBQ.  I ended up splitting the big boy plate (I forget the actual name) with my girlfriend.  All the BBQ on the plate was delicious although I thought the chicken BBQ was a bit too dry.  That's a hard one to keep from drying out though.  The pulled pork was good and moist.

The interior is a little dated but I'm doubtful any of the patrons of this place really care.  It's got a pretty cool neighborhood feel.  The service was great and friendly.

Bottom line is, there are so many great choices for BBQ in Charlotte, this place is easy to overlook.  It just didn't stand out to me.

"In the unlikely event that I were to encounter the inventor of the soft serve ice-cream machine, our conversation might transpire in the following manner:

"So, how did the genesis of a soft serve machine come to fruition?"

"Well, I was ambulating my canine companion, Toots, when he decided to defecate profusely on Ed and Dolores Feinstein's front lawn. I was utterly mortified. Ed, being an attorney, threatened to take legal action against both myself and Toots if such an incident were to recur. Lo and behold, Toots proceeded to evacuate his bowels with reckless abandon, leaving behind a copious amount of feces that slowly seeped out. Ed emerged from his domicile, brandishing a broom and threatening to exact retribution. Toots, sensing danger, fled precipitously, leaving behind an unfinished evacuation. This experience served as the impetus for my invention, as I desired to create a machine capable of dispensing ice cream in a sanitary and controlled manner, devoid of any digestive mishaps akin to those exhibited by my canine counterpart."

"My sincere gratitude extends to Toots for serving as the catalyst behind this innovative creation.
