Prior to my involvement in the frozen yogurt industry, I had a great fondness for it; however, now that I am responsible for operating the very machine inspired by my dog's scatological exploits, my thoughts are consumed by the unsettling notion that this device was conceived by a madman who sought to replicate the bowel movements of his own pet on Ed and Dolores Feinstein's front lawn."

I would unlikely revisit Galaxy if I still resided in Las Vegas, given the peculiar behavior of the employees regarding customer service. During my two visits within a week's span, the staff demonstrated a lack of coordination and synchronization in their work, leading me to conclude that a return visit would not be worthwhile. 
  While the breakfast sandwiches are satisfactory, their prices are somewhat steep considering the quality of ingredients utilized. However, I must acknowledge that the sustenance provided was adequate for my journey to Los Angeles, thus rendering my complaints somewhat moot. 
  The coffee offerings at Galaxy are unremarkable, yet they do possess a unique aspect in the form of almond syrup, a flavor enhancer that I find challenging to procure. Consequently, I shall grant them additional credit for this particular feature. 
  Although the ambiance is rendered fascinating by the incorporation of Star Wars and other niche-themed embellishments, I cannot overlook the deficiency in staff training and overall efficiency, thereby making it improbable for me to actively seek out such an establishment.

"Interrupted my daily routine to partake in a midday repast at this establishment. Their menu boasts an array of enticing specials, comprising of Miso soup, a mixed green salad, and sashimi accompanied by steamed rice. Upon entering, I was greeted by a congenial staff who exhibited a commendable level of hospitality. However, my dining experience was not without its drawbacks. While the Miso soup was indeed flavorful, the salad was disappointingly wilted and featured an unconventional ingredient in the form of bell peppers. Although I have had Asian salads with chili peppers before, the inclusion of bell peppers was a first for me, and unfortunately, it did not resonate well with my palate. Furthermore, there was a conspicuous absence of steamed rice accompanying my meal, which led to a series of perplexed interactions with the waitstaff. Despite their well-meaning intentions, the service was regrettably disorganized and lacking in coordination. In response to my inquiry regarding the quality of the food, I was not offered a substitute for the unsatisfactory salad. Eventually, the rice arrived, but it was sadly overcooked, tasteless, and unappetizing. Nonetheless, the Tuna sashimi proved to be a highlight of the meal, with its generous portion size and potent wasabi accompaniment. Unfortunately, the white ginger served alongside it was dehydrated, which somewhat diminished the overall enjoyment of the dish. In conclusion, while there were some notable aspects of the meal, a number of improvements are certainly warranted to elevate the dining experience to a more satisfactory level."

We order our food from their carside service.  We found the food to be great, but patience trying to get your food from the carside pickup!!  (over 15 minutes past the time promised and ignored until the manager brought it out!!)
This place is now \"Las Americas\" and its Colombian food. It's authentic and the people are nice, but nothing about it really stood out.

You know what I like best about this place?

I love going to places where I am the youngest customer by a considerable margin.

And I'm old enough to have spent the first half of my years so far using phones that were attached to walls and stuff. You know, the ones where you had to turn this twisty thing to make a call and you didn't know who was calling you before you answered?

Anyway, the older generation seems to like good deals on veggies and other produce, because they usually have them here. Sometimes you can get in and out without being overcome by the feeling that the zombie apocalypse is upon us, and they are all on walkers.

In more-or-less typical Basha's practice, some of the items are weirdly overpriced. Stick with the loss-leaders and you might make out ok.

Oh, and also: The parking spaces are nice and wide. Wide enough to fully swing open the door of your Buick Park Avenue.

"This culinary establishment proved to be moderately satisfactory during our recent visit. My spouse and I opted for a removal order, which we thoroughly enjoyed. Specifically, the chili rellenos were particularly delectable, constituting one of the most flavorful examples of this dish that I have had the pleasure of consuming. However, the vegetable salad failed to meet expectations, as it primarily consisted of lettuce and lacked the diverse array of vegetables that one might anticipate. The black beans, on the other hand, were quite piquant and salty, thus it is advisable to combine them with a starch such as rice or an additional tortilla to temper their intensity. While the dining area did not exude an atmosphere of comfort, the provision of complimentary Wi-Fi during the waiting period was a welcome amenity. Notwithstanding, we shall unquestionably continue to patronize this eatery for future takeout orders, and we look forward to savoring their culinary offerings once again."

Never knew how big the place was. Seems like an awesome place for sporting events. I didn't get any drinks, but the specials appear good. It was freaking dead in there, but I want to try and go on a busy night for further review.

Jin's poultry and aquatic products were nowhere to be found in their customary location, prompting us to explore the surrounding area in search of an alternative venue that could satiate our post-bar cravings for fowl and fin. Upon discovering this establishment, we determined that it fulfilled our requirements for a satisfying repast, albeit not an ideal setting for a full-fledged meal. My culinary selection consisted of a juvenile avian specimen, breaded and deep-fried, served on a diminutive bun and accompanied by minuscule leafy greenery and copious amounts of Frank's RedHot sauce and mayonnaise. Suffice it to say, my expectations were adequately met.

Some healthy-ish options on the menu. Breakfast till 10.30am would be even better if it was all-day (as I arrived here at 11am.)\n\nI got the chicken beer bread... What is that? Grilled chicken in a wrap and served with fries or salad. Of course I got the fries as I really wanted fish and chips but tried to be good. That was a mistake. The chicken was processed, covered in melted cheese which I picked out as cooled and congealed...(better left on the plate than in my veins.) I tried to enjoy this meal as I picked out the good stuff. Because the wrap was cut up you couldn't pick it up and it was too \"wet\" to cut. Then I looked around at this decor and noticed the odd combo of a dance music soundtrack. Very odd...something not quite right here. If I had to come again I'd probably go with the fish & chips or a burger.

"The terrestrial poultry served as the piÃ¨ce de rÃ©sistance of my culinary experience at this establishment, boasting an abundance of savory flavors with each mouthful. However, the boneless fragments of poultry accompanying the chicken soltani ($17.99) failed to live up to expectations, suffering from a dearth of flavor and a rather unpleasant texture. In contrast, the beef kabob ($16.99) presented a more aesthetically pleasing appearance, yet its gustatory qualities were found wanting due to an absence of seasoning and a coarse consistency. 

Fortunately, both main courses were complemented by exceptionally fluffy and delectable Basmati rice, which partially compensated for their shortcomings. Notably generous portion sizes ensured that each dish could easily suffice for two individuals, rendering the moderate tariffs somewhat more palatable. It would have been wiser for us to share one of the entrees, given the prices they command. 

The hummus exhibited passable quality, while the yogurt and cucumber dip was overpowered by an excess of dill, detracting from its overall enjoyment. 

The spacious interior of the restaurant features a modern, well-lit ambiance, accentuated by the presence of two illuminated trees positioned centrally. For those seeking a more relaxed dining experience (and lower prices), alternative establishments may be more suitable."

I can't believe I forgot to write a review for Ceres. I remember every single detail the day I went here for brunch with a group of Yelpers. It was life-changing! From who I sat with, me ending up paying for 2 people, the food, the music...everything. It really helps not getting drunk for brunch!

Located inside JW Marriott, the parking situation was a bit of a mess. Some jerk almost ran me over...that was my first memory of him. From that moment on I just knew...

Buffet-style brunch was good. There was a waffle station and an omelet station. I stood a long time waiting for my omelet since they gave mine to some old grumpy lady. They have the usual breakfast fare: eggs, hashbrowns, sausages, bacon, Danishes, bread, potatoes, etc. So, for $20+ brunch x 2...this place was just ok.

"Acknowledged. 

It is gratifying to discover that this establishment boasts an unparalleled level of tranquility, owing to its seemingly perpetual lack of patronage, which in turn facilitates an extended operating schedule that caters to the convenience of nocturnal patrons such as myself. 

While the culinary offerings may not necessarily conform to my personal preferences due to an excessive proportion of adipose tissue in the meat dishes, particularly the thinly sliced beef, the affordability of these items renders them a reasonable value. 

The attentiveness of the staff is commendable, as they display a proficient level of responsiveness and engagement with their clientele, despite the minimal volume of foot traffic that graces the premises, particularly during my late-night visits. 

In light of the aforementioned attributes, I would unhesitatingly endorse this venue as a reliable fallback option, particularly during ungodly hours when alternative dining establishments are unavailable."

Kind of did a breeze in and out, I rarely eat at Chipotle, so the one time I did want it there was one right down the street where I was at! It wasn't busy at all inside, I mean it's located at West Gate and there's a ton of eateries around there, depends what you're up for!

But I was up for Chipotle that day (12/12/14) and the staff was super nice, me with my bad hearing I had to ask the gals to repeat it to me twice - I'm still young! This shouldn't be happening to me! But they were patient haha, the food was good too, a nice warm burrito for a chilly day!

I think I will stop here again, and just ask for a little less red salsa since it ended up being too hot for me!

I have had the pleasure of patronizing this establishment for an extended period of time, and I must say that my experiences have been overwhelmingly positive until recently. My visits have primarily taken place during the daytime hours, and I must commend the staff on their exceptional ability to maintain a high level of service, ensuring that all aspects of our dining experience, including food, beverages, and prompt refills, were executed with utmost efficiency. In fact, our server was so attentive that we felt compelled to indulge in libations at the bar subsequent to our meals. However, my most recent visit during the evening hours proved to be a stark contrast to my previous experiences. Despite having a party of nine, the server failed to materialize with any degree of regularity. Our orders were taken en masse to avoid confusion, but upon the arrival of our meals, only three plates were presented, leaving the remainder of the group in a state of culinary limbo. Furthermore, the procurement of beverages was a protracted process, with an average wait time of fifteen minutes. Moreover, securing our server's attention for the settlement of our bill proved to be a challenging endeavor, necessitating active pursuit on our part. Notwithstanding the aforementioned issues, I still maintain that this establishment possesses inherent merits, though I would advise against visiting during the evening hours, as the quality of service deteriorates substantially.

I will start out with the good - The food.  I had a burger and tots and they were great. I tried my boyfriends catfish Po'boy and it was amazing. The mac and cheese is very good. Onion rings were just okay.

We went to watch the Pather's game and they turned the sound on. It wasnt very packed and the service was pretty good. 

The bad part - there beer selection needs some help. They only have a few taps but where are all the great local beers?

Also, a palmeto bug kept flying around us while we were eating. Hard to prevent but still not very fun.

So the rooms are super small and the tiny bathrooms are dingy & outdated. You get what you pay for, right? The rooms are clean and updated with a slightly vintage feel (Elvis & Beatles framed prints on the wall of our room). The shower WAS either freezing or scalding, but this place has been in business forever so it's an old building. I'm not crazy about the $20 resort fee for wifi that doesn't seem to work, especially since there's no pool-what's the resort?! But for the price it's good. \n\nEdit: the Fremont street experience was RIGHT outside our window (past our view of dumpsters) and we weren't there to party so that was kind of a drag, but if you're going to party till the wee hours you won't mind.

Good food, laid back, good beer choices... great place if you're looking for a sit back place to enjoy time with friends or family and want good food but don't need stellar foodie meal. The mix match 6 - pack of beer is good deal if you want something to go and keeps you from making that extra trip to liquor store. Only negative we've had here is the service can be slow. It seems they assign tables in rotation order instead of zones so wait staff is all over the place and can't attend to tables as quickly.

"Upon partaking in a culinary excursion at this establishment, our gastronomical experience was generally satisfactory, with the exception of a few financial discrepancies. Specifically, upon perusing the menu, we noticed that the cost of certain beverages was inconsistent with the prices advertised on the chalkboard exterior to the restaurant. Furthermore, upon querying our server regarding this disparity, he appeared perplexed by our inquiry, leading us to hastily settle the bill to avoid any further inconvenience. However, we cannot help but feel that an injustice was done, particularly in light of the fact that we were overcharged by twelve dollars for the Bloody Mary's consumed by our party. Therefore, we shall remain vigilant in our pursuit of a resolution to this matter, lest we be compelled to reconsider our patronage of this establishment in the future."

"My previous reluctance to visit this establishment has been alleviated by the revelation that they have revamped their menu to incorporate exceptional organic ciabatta rolls and have eliminated high fructose corn syrup from all items. Furthermore, they have taken the initiative to eradicate trans fat from every dish, a pioneering move in the culinary industry. The Royal with light mustard is particularly delectable, and I often opt to substitute the meat with turkey or ham if the toppings align with my preferences. Notably, the quality of the food has significantly improved, prompting me to frequent the restaurant more often. Additionally, I came across a review mentioning that customers can receive soft-serve ice cream with any meal, an enticing perk that I was previously unaware of. While I would enthusiastically award them an additional star, I must refrain from doing so due to the presence of a slender lesbian employee, although I jest about that fact."

After partaking of the delectable ice cream cookie sandwich from the adjacent establishment, I surmised that a supplementary indulgence would be requisite to satiate my craving for something sweet and tart; thus, I opted for a 'like it', an icy confection with a subtle sweetness and a hint of tartness, though regrettably, it fell short of my expectations, as it lacked the distinctive flavor profile of the genuine article. Nonetheless, the hospitality exhibited by the staff within these premises was truly commendable, as three affable and obliging gentlemen, exuding an unwavering enthusiasm to assist, attended to my needs with alacrity, providing a refreshing contrast to the customary diffidence displayed by their contemporaries stationed behind the counter. Undoubtedly, the prospect of returning to this establishment holds considerable allure for me.

We've only been once so far but the wings and fries were good.

They have subs (fried fish, Philly or chicken cheesesteaks, cold or hot veggies...), wraps, burger platters, fish plates, chicken plates and more.

I was reallllly happy to find this place. It reminds me of carry outs from back home. I've been in the Charlotte area for seven years now and this is the first time I've found a spot like this one.

It's in a small-ish corner so keep your eyes open when you go.

"I recently arrived at this establishment for the purpose of undergoing a smog inspection, which typically carries a cost of $19.95; however, due to my possession of a special promotional mailing, I was able to avail myself of a reduced rate of $14.95, a savings of $5 that I found quite satisfactory given the straightforward nature of the service provided, which involved a brief and efficient process of inspection and maintenance that did not necessitate an extensive period of time or excessive monetary expenditure, thereby rendering the overall experience relatively unremarkable, yet pleasingly convenient and economical in comparison to other establishments offering comparable services, such as Jiffy Smog."

This venue was teeming with an abundance of patrons during my visit, rendering the dance floor minuscule in comparison to the vast multitude of individuals seeking to partake in the festivities. It appeared that every conceivable location within the establishment had been designated for the purpose of accommodating bottle service, thereby creating a predicament for those who did not possess the privilege of such provisions. Fortunately, I possessed certain inherent attributes which enabled me to successfully manipulate the circumstances in my favor, thereby securing both a Grey Goose cranberry and a seat. However, I could not help but sympathize with the male contingent, who were not as fortunate in their endeavors to gain entry. Notwithstanding the aforementioned obstacles, I chose to award two additional stars in light of the fact that our queue was of considerable length, yet we managed to bypass the majority of it and gain admittance to the club with relative ease.

Lightning fast "strip-mall" style Chinese food.  It's exactly what you expect it to be.  It's a great spot to stop by after work and pick up a quick take-out meal for the family, but I wouldn't expect too much by the way of "cuisine".

Had the beef with broccoli, kung pao chicken, and sweet and sour chicken recently.  All of which were made from picky-eater friendly ingredients, and were a hit with the kids.  I do like the fact that the staff is all Chinese and a few words spoken from the customers in Mandarin seem to go over well.

Overall it's nothing special, but a decent value for a mid-week take home meal.
They have a grill for those steaks that u are craving for. Typical ham and roast beef! It was good for the price and for my boys who are at that age they can't stop eating.

Decided not to come back because last time I was very disappointed with the super expensive honey toast ( cant remember the name all I know is $12.99) and it wasn't that good but had to come back because we couldnt find anywhere else to play card. At least this place has a better service than tea station tho. Overall is not that bad just a little bit pricey.

The culinary offerings were of an exceptionally high quality, boasting an unparalleled freshness and authenticity that was undoubtedly palpable; however, the prices were exorbitant, bordering on the outrageous, which made it challenging for this patron to justify the cost, despite the proprietor's amicable demeanor and the hospitable nature of the young woman manning the counter, thus rendering the prospect of a future visit uncertain, contingent upon a reevaluation of the menu items' pricing, particularly when considering the supplementary charges for beverages and desserts, which tended to inflate the total cost beyond what could be deemed reasonable or appropriate.

"The West Room presents an intriguing culinary experience, boasting a sophisticated ambiance and an extensive cocktail selection that is sure to captivate discerning patrons. However, our dining excursion yielded mixed results, as certain aspects of the fare failed to meet our expectations, thereby casting doubt on the likelihood of future visits. Despite its self-proclaimed status as the 'hidden gem' of the west end, a more judicious curation of menu items may be necessary to elevate The West Room to the level of gastronomic excellence it aspires to."

My family from Korea came to visit and on our trip to Vegas, they were desperately craving something familiar.  My plan was to take them to Grand Lux but on the way, my grandma began looking pale.  So, we saw signs for this restaurant and detoured over to Imperial Palace.  Up the elevator we went to the deserted 5th floor dining plaza where we were welcomed by a familiar Korean greeting.  My grandma smiled and immediately announced that she felt better already.  

Their menu included Korean, Japanese, and Chinese dishes but we opted for solely Korean.  We had the duk mandoo gook (rice cake dumpling soup), dolsot bibimbap (mixture of rice, veggies, fried egg served in a hot stone bowl/pot), soft tofu soup, and bulgogi (marinated meat).  Everything was just whatever but watching my grandma grasp her bowl of rice with both hands and eat like her life depended on it made the meal more enjoyable.  

Pretty expensive for mediocre Korean food in Vegas (like $90 total plus tax and tip .. just for lunch!) but the staff was accommodating and friendly.  

I personally wouldn't come back but I appreciated the service and convenience.

We disembarked from the aircraft and meandered towards a delectable repast, savoring an array of gastronomic delights that included, but were not limited to, succulent squid expertly grilled on a plancha, a visually appealing xato salad boasting a medley of colorful vegetables, tender scallops enrobed in a rich, nutty romesco sauce, and a refreshing white ceviche punctuated by the subtle sweetness of fresh raspberries, all artfully arranged on a platter and served with a smile; however, we opted to abstain from beverages, and while the quality of the cuisine was undeniably impressive, the total cost of $80 for a meal that, albeit satisfying our hunger, did not prove particularly filling, struck us as somewhat excessive.

I went to CUT w/ some friends.  The portion is great (considering the $ I am paying =)  ).  I love their bread sticks.  I was kind of disappointed because the steak was a bit blackened and overcooked.  Taste was okay.  For the price given, the food was more on the average, there were many staff compared to the # of guests, which is good.  I am not sure if it's me or what, it seemed to me the staff's services were a bit "fake" and not too friendly.

Maybe people like the lighting?  but to me it was a bit too dark.  You can barely see the food.  

I might try it a gain if given the chance.

We have become accustomed to ordering either the Louisiana Chicken pasta or cheesecake during our dining excursions to this establishment, as we have found that these items consistently meet our expectations of culinary excellence. It appears that the vast array of options on the menu may potentially overwhelm the kitchen staff, resulting in a lack of attention to detail and inconsistent quality in the preparation of certain dishes. Our recent experiences have been disappointing, with the last five dishes we have ordered failing to impress and one dish being returned due to its subpar quality, which is an unprecedented occurrence for us, as we rarely feel compelled to express dissatisfaction with our meals.

My boyfriend and I just had dinner here. I have to say, I'm very underwhelmed by the food here. I was pretty stoked to get a tastey but simple sandwich and fresh made soup. Regretfully, I had the grilled cheese and it was quite lacking in flavor. The red pepper lobster bisque, though a tad \"clumpy\" was quite tasty. I will give Cafe Zupas another shot, but I'm hoping my next choice in sandwich will turn it around for me.

"Perhaps my elevated excitement and lofty expectations contributed to my underwhelming experience with the Blue Man Group; however, certain sections of the performance did prove to be somewhat tedious and failed to captivate my attention. Despite the presence of some intriguing and humorous elements, my husband's assessment of the show was even more scathing, as he believed the majority of it to be dull and uninspired. Considering the premium cost of admission, I struggle to justify the value of this production. If the ticket prices were more reasonable, perhaps in the range of $20 to $30 lower, it might provide a more satisfactory return on investment. My evaluation of the show yields three stars, as some parts were amusing, some were visually striking, and others left me feeling impatient and desiring a swifter conclusion."

I really like this place.  The food, drinks, and wine are always delicious.  The service is great,  but I can't get over how loud they play the live music on Friday and Saturday nights.  The music itself is fun and provides a great feeling, but don't plan on being able to have a conversation if you're in the main room while they pump it in on a speaker.

"I was seeking an activity suitable for engaging with my in-laws, and this particular attraction appeared to align with their interests. However, upon further inspection, it became apparent that it was a quintessential tourist trap, replete with an array of commercialized souvenirs and services that came at an additional cost. Despite the overtly exploitative nature of the establishment, I must admit that the experience was moderately enjoyable, as I had the opportunity to capture some remarkable photographs and gain insight into the local lore. Nonetheless, I do not envision revisiting this destination in the future, as a single visit proved sufficient to satiate my curiosity."

There's so much else to see and do in Vegas that I wouldn't bother spending my time here unless its absolutely freezing cold or scorching hot outside and you're just looking to spend some time indoors and not have to hop from hotel to hotel. It is a pretty nice mall though with one of the bigger indoor food courts I've seen anywhere.\n\nIf you've got lots of money to spend, then this is a good spot to go shopping. Otherwise I'd check out one of the various outlet malls in the area around Vegas where you'll find much better deals on stuff.
Went here with some friends and was not familiar with the menu.  The order counter seemed confusing to me too. Got a turkey sandwich,  but think they used miracle whip not mayo.  Not a fan though.

I perused these critiques and opted to sample this eatery. The Pellini constitutes an Italian burrito, wherein patrons select their preferred protein (chicken, steak, Italian sausage, or shrimp), sauces (either tomato or white), and toppings (cheese and/or vegetables). Numerous options exist, thereby enabling individuals to tailor their dining experience according to their preferences. 
  I experimented with the chicken and Italian sausage combination and found the flavors to be relatively subdued. Perhaps my assemblage of the Pellini contributed to the lackluster taste. 
  My spouse chose the chicken and shrimp variation, and the shrimp significantly enhanced the flavor profile. Her Pellini boasted an impressive gustatory quality. 
  Contemporary and well-maintained ambiance characterized the establishment's interior design, while the staff exhibited attentive and cordial behavior. 
  Although unsure about returning, my partner's positive experience may warrant a future visit.

Napoleon's Dueling Piano Bar
Overall
3.75

Gold Medal - Extraordinary Pianist
Silver Medal - Peppy Fun Environment
Bronze Medal - Free entrance

These pianist knows every song!  From Journey to Metallica.  Truely amazing.

There were people singing, dancing, and drinking.  People were having the time of their lives.

This is a free activity at night.  There is no admission fee and no drink minimum. Unlike comedy improv shows, where you get in for free, but the waitresses are hounding you for drink orders, causing you to miss the entire show. Here at Napoleon's, you pay for what you want to order.  If you want to request that special song that makes your body alive, you pay a tip with the name of the song written on a piece of paper.

The crowd was mainly 40 years old+.  All the younger hipsters are probably out hitting the dance clubs.

HAPPY DUELING!!

I was here for lunch a few days ago.  Nice ambiance - and cosy and warm inside while it blew a storm outside.  I had good service, but wasn't overwhelmed by the food.  An halloumi sandwich with ciabatta and salad.   I enjoyed the salad, and the halloumi, but frankly the ciabatta didn't do it for me - and didn't bring out the best in the halloumi (even with the chilli jelly).   For dessert I had carrot cake - which was rather dry.  Much better carrot cake to be had in town.\n\nI'll be back though - apparently they do a good eggs benedict.

"I have a penchant for this establishment due to its affordability, despite the fact that the culinary offerings are not particularly exceptional, yet still manage to satisfy my taste buds. We frequent this venue with a certain degree of regularity, owing to its accessibility and convenience. I would unhesitatingly advocate for a visit to this locale."

I have had the pleasure of partaking in the culinary offerings of Spinato's on three separate occasions, with two instances involving takeout and one wherein I indulged in the dining room experience. Upon reflection, I have formulated three distinct musings regarding my experiences at this establishment:  

Firstly, the pizza served at Spinato's is undoubtedly of satisfactory quality, boasting flavors and textures that are bound to satiate even the most discerning of palates.  

Secondly, it is my opinion that the pricing of said pizza is somewhat elevated, perhaps to an extent that may deter potential patrons who are seeking a more affordable dining option.  

Lastly, and unfortunately, the service I received during my visits was subpar, bordering on unacceptable. On one occasion, I was mistakenly served a different pizza than the one I had ordered, and I was forced to wait an additional ten minutes before receiving my correct order. Moreover, no discount or compensation was offered for the inconvenience caused. Similarly, during my third visit, I was told that my takeout order would be ready within 30-35 minutes; however, I waited a full 57 minutes before finally receiving my food. When I brought this issue to the attention of the takeout staff, I was met with a dismissive and unapologetic demeanor, further compounding my frustration.  

In light of these experiences, I am inclined to seek alternative dining options, such as Grimaldi's, where I can enjoy high-quality pizza without breaking the bank.

"If you're seeking a nocturnal excursion replete with alcoholic indulgences and a brief respite from the impending bedlam, Caramel presents itself as a viable option. While it may not be an establishment worthy of extensive correspondence, it did elicit a sense of contentment within me, albeit for a singular reason: seating. On our third evening of unbridled revelry, my priorities had been simplified to a considerable degree; specifically, I craved a chair. Upon entering the venue following a convivial dinner and encountering a group of acquaintances, we were promptly accosted by a cocktail server who offered us a table designated for reserved seating. This was a veritable symphony to my auricular senses (as well as my fatigued pedal extremities!). Although the lounge itself was somewhat diminutive in stature, the assemblage comprised an eclectic mix of patrons. The ambiance, while not particularly noteworthy, was supplemented by a satisfactory musical selection and the possibility of sampling artisanal infusions of vodka. However, it is important to note that prolonged stays exceeding thirty minutes are not recommended, as the locale fails to offer sufficient diversions to warrant extended periods of time."

"My culinary preferences do not align with the gastronomical offerings at this establishment, specifically pertaining to the tuna entrÃ©e, which, despite its considerable cost of approximately thirty-five dollars, did not resonate with my taste buds. However, I do appreciate the mixological expertise demonstrated in the creation of their cocktails, and occasionally partake in libations at the bar during the designated hours of happy hour."

I have an unwavering fondness for Cirque shows, having had the privilege of witnessing a couple of productions prior to this occasion (Ovo & Zumanity), thus, my anticipation was palpable when my partner was generously offered complimentary tickets for his birthday celebration in Las Vegas. Our seats were situated in an optimal location, specifically in the middle, approximately six rows away from the stage, offering us an unobstructed view of the performance. My expectations were surpassed by the captivating set design, which was further enhanced by the incorporation of water elements that contributed to the visual appeal of the show. However, my enthusiasm was tempered by a slight sense of disappointment. It is possible that my expectations were unreasonably high, but I found the comedic aspects of the production to be somewhat lacking. Specifically, the clown humor did not resonate with me, and I found it to be rather tedious. My hope was to witness more extraordinary feats of acrobatics, but apart from the breathtaking diving sequences (which require immense skill) and a select few other acts (such as the fire dancers and jumpers), I was left feeling underwhelmed. Furthermore, I struggled to decipher the narrative that the performers were attempting to convey, and certain scenes were downright perplexing. For instance, the presence of the individual holding the 1-800 sign was unclear to me. Additionally, I experienced a sense of unease during certain parts of the performance, as if it was attempting to transport me to a realm that was reminiscent of a surreal dreamscape. The red-coated performers, in particular, seemed to embody the stuff of which nightmares are composed. Despite my reservations, I still maintain a deep appreciation for Cirque du Soleil, and "O" provided a pleasant diversion for an evening. Nonetheless, I am grateful that we did not expend financial resources on the tickets. As the performance drew to a close, my partner and I found ourselves succumbing to yawns, and we were relieved when it finally concluded. In the future, I intend to explore alternative productions such as Ka or Mystere!

"Although it's a rather extravagant Las Vegas interpretation of a traditional public house, this establishment can still provide a satisfactory experience for those seeking a casual drink, despite the fact that the cost of a single pint may be slightly elevated compared to what one might consider reasonable. However, based on my recent visit, I would not wholeheartedly recommend dining here, as the ambiance and quality of service did not entirely align with my expectations, despite the delectability of my initial course, which consisted of thin slices of pork belly atop a rich, egg-based bread, complemented by a sweet maple glaze and crowned with a poached egg. Specifically, while the bartenders were quite affable, the table staff exhibited a subtle yet perceptible air of indifference, and my primary dish, consisting of fish and chips, failed to impress me as much as I had hoped, given the premium pricing. Nonetheless, if you find yourself on the Strip and are in pursuit of a respectable beer, it may still be worth paying a visit to this establishment."

Love me some Famous Dave's catfish! Another unique quality of Famous Dave's are the sauces that are at your dispense on each table. Be sure to try the Georgia Mustard-goes well on just about everything. The reason for the 3 stars is because the most consistent factor here is the careless service.  I recently had a server not only talk to us for over 10 minutes about his name before he took our order,but also had the nerve to solicit help and funds for his charity.  I was appalled that he continued on and that the manager did not put a stop to it.  i think I was more irritated because if he spent as much time on assisting our table as he did talking about himself, our order would not have been screwed up so bad!

Who likes the DMV? Nobody. Then why do I give it a 3 star? For the self-service kiosks, where you can be in and out in less than 10 minutes. It's the best thing they could have done to help keep people moving. Now the only time I dread going is when I have to actually see a human to get done what I need. Visit the website to see what you can get done at the kiosk. And they have kiosks in other businesses (AAA's, grocery stores, etc) around Las Vegas, so check that out.

I thought the food was pretty good. I have done alot of really good Tapas and this was just pretty good. These guys pack it in like sardines and a young good looking crowd it is. Too busy for me on the weekends I would go back but there are many other fish in the sea so it won't be soon.

"The quality of the service and atmosphere was quite impressive, boasting an intimate setting with cozy tables, although the proximity of the seating arrangements in our particular section resulted in a slightly cramped experience, further exacerbated by the unfortunate placement of the heating vent beneath our feet, causing discomfort to intensify as the evening progressed. Furthermore, we took advantage of a LivingSocial promotion, which significantly enhanced the overall value of the dining experience. We opted for the escargot as an appetizer, accompanied by a bowl of French onion soup, both of which showcased exceptional culinary prowess. However, several menu items, including the frog legs that piqued my interest, were regrettably unavailable, limiting our options. I settled on the steak and frites, specifically a ribeye, but unfortunately, the meat lacked flavor and presented a rather tough, rubbery texture, requiring considerable effort to consume. Despite enjoying the initial courses, the underwhelming ribeye left me feeling somewhat dissatisfied, prompting me to consider alternative menu choices during a potential future visit."
Don't buy the bananas!  They refrigerate them.  They turn brown by the end of the day. Dole bananas are the worst.

"It is my conviction that this location formerly possessed a more optimal state of affairs, characterized by a heightened level of proficiency and effectiveness in addressing the needs of its clientele, as well as a greater abundance of insightful and useful information. Alas, it appears that I have had the misfortune of encountering an unfortunate concatenation of circumstances, resulting in an experience that falls short of my expectations. Notwithstanding this disappointment, I must acknowledge that the prices offered here remain competitive and the selection of goods and services available is indeed impressive. Furthermore, I find myself in need of seating arrangements conducive to leisurely perusal and contemplation."

MEDIOCRE, and \"bring your own wine\" is overrated. I had the fillet mignon. Maybe in comparison to the steak houses in strip malls, this place is ok, but not in the Old Port, where there are MANY better restaurants. Maybe I'm too much of a meat lover to appreciate a tolerable steak. The thing is, I can make a better steak at home for less money and with the same effort (very loud dinning room). \nThe only time I would recommend this place is if you're doing a corporate dinner on a weeknight, not too busy, not too pricey, not too despicable.

"Although the culinary quality of the establishment's primary menu item, specifically the burger, leaves much to be desired, the supplementary offering of fries, when considered in isolation, does possess a certain je ne sais quoi that elevates it to a level worthy of appreciation and enjoyment. However, it is unfortunate that the overall gastronomical experience at this venue falls short of expectations due to the subpar quality of the aforementioned burger, which, if improved even slightly, would undoubtedly enhance the overall dining experience and potentially increase patronage."

This place was just "okay."  I would use the term "old timey" to describe it.... I would also use that term to describe the clientele.  I went there for a business lunch, I would say that most of the older male population of Phoenix did the same.  I must also note that there is ZERO ambience-- it looks like a Best Western dining hall.

On to the food.  I had been craving prime rib, so that is what I ordered.  Though it was accurately cooked to be medium rare, the texture and flavor were not great.  The meat was bland, and it was not all that tender.  Even the au jus lacked flavor.  It was served with some sort of potatoes that I didn't really like either.  However, I have to say that my companion ordered the filet-- also medium rare-- and said that it was really good.

I am not going to give this place a bad review, but I can't give it a stellar one either.  Im addition, the prices are a little high for such boring food.  I am truly ambivalent about Stockyards.... and life is too short to eat mediocre food.  ;)

I have a love/hate relationship with this place.. I used to go here for all of my nail needs but during the last couple times they did my gel mani/pedi at the same time which is way too much going on.. I can see if I asked for it or didn't have an appointment but switching hands and feet in to the lights at the same time is just too much, takes the relaxation out of it. However, they do do one of the better pedicures I've gotten in vegas (the hot stone one is awesome!)

It was 10:45 Saturday morning and I wanted coffee. I knew of a place right down the street from me and to my disappointment it was closed! WTF! Any way I went searching for a cafe. I wanted to sit down and read the new times with a cup of coffee. I actually started my journey thinking I would stop at the drip. But when i got there that place just seemed to modern for me. I was in a funky mood and just wanted a nice cup of coffee, nothing fancy. So I saw an older man waving a sign that said \"Best lunch in town!\" and he was kind of dancing too! And I said to myself \"Yes, i think I will\". So I stumbled upon MacAlpines. They had just opened and I sat right down at the counter. I had two cups of yummy diner coffee and after realizing I was hungry too, I ordered a stuffed tomato that was oh so yummy with super fresh veggies. The decor was adorable and welcoming and I loved the juke box. 25 cents gets you two plays! anyway, I'm not giving it four stars because it took some time for the staff to warm up and be friendly. I don't know if it was just because they had just opened or if it was because I was still sleeping and needed a caffeine fix badly. But I want to go again, with company, not by myself and I'll rate it again.

"Although the ambiance and gastronomical offerings of this establishment may not rival those of its flagship counterpart situated on Sahara Avenue, its proximity to the Las Vegas Strip renders it an acceptable alternative, despite the temporary inconvenience posed by the ongoing renovations that necessitate a traversal through dust and scaffolding to gain ingress. The copious portions characteristic of this eatery's menu remained unchanged, as we discovered when we opted to share two dishes amongst ourselves, three individuals of moderate appetite, and still felt satiated without completing either plate. Had the decision been mine to make, I would have selected the chicken and waffles; however, the will of the majority prevailed, and we settled on the chorizo skillet and the Tractor Driver Combo instead. While the former dish was certainly palatable, the lone tortilla accompanying it proved insufficient for the generous helping of filling it contained. In contrast, the latter dish, augmented by an additional banana pancake at a nominal fee, proved a judicious investment. The quality of service we received during our visit was also laudable." 
"Despite the fact that the independent restaurant located on Sahara provided a more comprehensive and satisfying experience in terms of atmosphere, culinary delights, and overall enjoyment, this venue still managed to deliver a passable performance."

I was here for my 21st birthday. It was a lot of fun, but it was rather small. It felt like they were double their max capacity. The dj was awesome, but again the dance floor was too small and crowded :(

The food was good, portions huge, and there was a good variety on the menu.  However it took us an hour and 12 minutes from arrival to getting our food, even though the place wasn't full.  So worth it for the food quality and portions, but be prepared for a long wait to get it.

"Although initially dubious about the authenticity of Hawaiian cuisine in Las Vegas, my expectations were pleasantly surpassed by Island Flavor's offerings, with the exception of a few minor drawbacks. The portions were generously sized, with a single plate sufficient to satisfy three individuals had we been aware of their magnitude. The Kahlua pork, while somewhat lacking in saltiness, was tender and flavorful, while the sweet and sour pork ribs, though slightly overseasoned with salt, remained palatable. The Furikake chicken, enhanced by the addition of Sriracha, was particularly impressive. However, my primary criticisms pertain to the rice dishes. The brown rice, prepared with an excessive amount of water, resulted in a pair of soggy, unappealing scoops. In contrast, the fried rice, characterized by its predominantly white rice composition, Lapcherng, and vegetables immersed in soy sauce, fell short of my expectations for a traditional fried rice dish. Notwithstanding these issues, the COCO PUFFS, adorned with a mysterious yet delectable buttery yellow topping complementing the chocolate cream puff, earned high praise. Similarly, the mud pie, enhanced by the inclusion of chocolate cacao or coffee nibs in the kona coffee ice cream, was well-received, despite the unnecessary flavored syrups accompanying it. The staff maintained a friendly and accommodating demeanor, despite their hectic workload. Lastly, the Spam musubi, reminiscent of those enjoyed in Hawaii, rounded off the meal satisfactorily."

I have an immense fondness for a thorough and relaxing massage, and my significant other presented me with a gift card for a couples massage as a Yuletide present. Arranging the appointment was a remarkably straightforward process. Upon entering the establishment, I was immediately struck by the spotless nature of the facilities and the serene ambiance of the waiting area, which effectively set the tone for a truly therapeutic experience. While the massage room itself was somewhat lacking in terms of aesthetic appeal and layout, our masseuses were incredibly personable and proficient in their ministrations. However, despite the fact that I have availed myself of their services on this particular occasion, I cannot say with certainty whether or not I shall return to utilize the remaining balance on my gift card, as my expectations regarding the quality of the massage itself were not entirely fulfilled, having had superior experiences at other establishments in the past. Furthermore, I must admit that I found the rather forceful attempts to persuade me to become a member during the checkout process to be somewhat off-putting.

"I was taken aback by the fact that the jerk fried rice did not possess the same level of piquancy as it had during my initial visit. Moreover, the portion size appeared diminutive in comparison to previous experiences, barely filling the circular aluminum receptacle. Despite these observations, the culinary offerings remained flavorsome and gratifying. I would advocate for the black beans over the refried variety, as they exhibit a more pronounced gustatory profile. The service was commendable, with the staff displaying promptness and amiability in their interactions with us. Notwithstanding, the ordering process proved somewhat perplexing, necessitating the guidance of the staff for novice patrons to fully comprehend the intricacies of the menu."

I had the occasion to visit the Starbucks situated within the Trails Village Center, and as I required access to an automated teller machine, I endeavored to utilize the facilities provided by Wells Fargo, only to discover that all three lanes, including the one featuring the aforementioned ATM, were devoid of any vehicles, thereby warranting a rating of nearly four stars, without further deliberation.

It is worth mentioning that although this particular establishment may be considered acceptable, its location outside of my immediate vicinity and the attendant difficulties associated with ingress and egress, owing to the substantial volume of traffic entering and exiting the Trails Center, render it a less than ideal choice.

Furthermore, having resided in this locality for in excess of ten years, this marks my initial visit to this specific venue, which, in and of itself, speaks volumes regarding its relative obscurity.

My review of Fin is pretty much the same as all of the other Yelpers. I found Fin to be a bit pricey for Chinese food, and the staff is very overly incredibly attentive. If you take a sip of water, someone is there to refill it for you. 

The food is good, though, there's no doubt about it. I ordered the stir-fry chicken and was very satisfied. They also follow up your meal with a delicious house made fortune cookie and shot of Baileys. 

The ambiance is fantastic if you sit toward the back and can block out the chachings of the nearby slot machines. 

Highly recommended for a nice dinner as long as you're aware of the price and overly attentie service staff.

I suppose its well stocked and closer for me than Tesco but it just doesnt have that friendly neighbourhood shop vibe. 
Twice in the last couple of weeks Ive been short changed and instead of a 'are you sure' or a 'lets see' the dude looked at me as if I just declared an interest in his wife.
Both times they were out by a pound or so. we aint talking 2p here man!


 They are on to me though. Last week I was overcharged for a coke and so I said 'I paid less last week'. He replied 'oh we undercharged you by mistake'...Good move that one...


 Finally, dont try and haggle. I haggled them for 20p off some Snapple but the only one who sanctions haggled goods is the Old Man. The other staff were taken by surprise and looked a little scared as I tried the haggling.

"= = = = = = DAILY LUNCH BUFFET!  = = = = = = 

Monica O. orchestrated an unforgettable culinary excursion at a local Thai restaurant, enticing 15 fellow Yelp enthusiasts to partake in a sumptuous buffet showcasing an array of delectable Thai delights, fostering camaraderie and conviviality among the group. (Kudos to Monica!)  The bountiful spread boasted 15 diverse offerings, including two soups, a vegetarian option featuring egg and tofu, and a coconut-based delight with chicken; plain and flavored rice complemented the assortment, accompanied by an assortment of savory hot dishes encompassing chicken, beef, and fish, along with numerous vegetable combinations, totaling an impressive 19 items. 

The culinary experience was generally satisfying, and considering the scarcity of Thai buffets in the area, the establishment's presence is indeed a welcome addition.     :-)

Although the dining ambiance was pleasant, and the table service was adequate, several minor drawbacks marred the experience:

*  A preponderance of poultry dominated the meat selections.

*  Desserts were conspicuously absent from the menu.

*  The eatery enforced a restrictive policy, permitting a single credit or debit card payment per table, which proved problematic for our group, as only one member had sufficient cash on hand.  This particular stipulation seemed inconvenient and counterproductive, prioritizing corporate interests over customer satisfaction.  

                                                                                          `

Lunch Buffet Schedule and Prices:

Tuesday through Friday: $9.99, available from 11:30 AM.
Sunday: $10.99, served from 12 noon."

"I opted for the fish and tofu tacos as my midday repast, and I must say, they utilized corn tortillas, which I deem to be an admirable choice. The fish exhibited a palatable quality, while the tofu blend presented an intriguing flavor profile, yet the tacos themselves did not ascend to an exceptional level of gastronomical excellence. However, the venue's ambiance appeared pleasant, with ample space surrounding the bar and an outdoor seating area that presumably offers a delightful setting during favorable weather conditions."

Quirky interior, clearly popular and possibly the best priced pot of tea in town.


 Could maybe do with opening past 18:00.

Price was right. Cool concept but I like 5 guys better. What A Burger is my favorite burger, guess you could say I'm old school. In and out was busy and had good service but as for the burger's. A lot of hype.

I'm pretty sure most of these new reviews are from employees and their families. 

Refused to honor my Groupon (prepaid of course).
This is exactly the same place as before. Their sign even still says Greek Grill & Fry Co. and it's run by the same people. 
The server was polite and made good suggestions,  but failed to alert me that they would not honor the 50% off Groupon before we ate, but instead offering a 20% discount. I always mention any deals on the way in for this reason.

The food was good,  not a huge selection but it was hot and made to order. We seemed to be the only customers that whole day. The Uncle/Grandpa of the family was in the dining area watching TV and talking on his phone. It's a very casual place.

There are some tables and a lot of slot machines. If you live in the area, it could be a good place to go and hang out. I would never recommend a drive from the strip to gamble here, but not bad for a locals hang out. With dollar beer and hot dogs, how can you go wrong!?

"It possesses an Americanized quality, yet it remains delectable; I have a particular fondness for their fried rice and typically opt for that dish exclusively. On one occasion, we decided to partake in takeout and were seated at the bar while awaiting our order. The bartender, in a gesture of generosity, offered us complimentary samples of their lychee-based cocktail, which we greatly appreciated and found quite palatable. Additionally, the establishment is characterized by a lack of crowding, with a tranquil atmosphere and consistent, albeit unremarkable, service. Notwithstanding these positive aspects, there fails to be any truly distinctive or remarkable features that set this restaurant apart from others; it ultimately ranks as a suitable option for takeout."

I don't know about the lounge part everyone else has reviewed, but I had dinner there and was like meh about it. The portions are extremely small for the prices. Even the sake was a bit overpriced, I felt. The waitstaff, as much as I appreciate attentiveness, was maybe a little too overeager to get us the hell out of there. My husband's plate was actually cleared before he was even done eating. We eventually had to tell them to leave the plates until we were finished. While the ambiance is very cool and romantic, I don't think I'd drop another buck in there in the future.

This establishment no longer possesses the identical quality and culinary prowess it formerly boasted in years past. As an ardent patron since the early 1970's, I have witnessed a gradual decline in both the standard of service and gastronomical offerings since the turn of the millennium. It is no longer a viable dining option, failing to provide an adequate value for the price. Despite the persistently cordial demeanor of the staff and an aesthetically stagnant ambiance, my recent dining experience was marred by the unfortunate preparation of my New York strip steak, which was subjected to an unsolicited butterflying process that effectively extracted the inherent flavor and rendered it unpalatable. Lamentably, this once-lauded eatery has relinquished its erstwhile prestige, precluding me from enthusiastically recommending it to acquaintances embarking upon a culinary excursion to Las Vegas.

"Although my culinary preferences do not align with the gastronomical offerings at this establishment, I do appreciate the expansive outdoor seating area, which presents an ideal setting for indulging in a mixed beverage, such as a refreshing cocktail or a glass of wine, at any time."

I'm with everyone when they say that this is not a hike. lol.

It's basically a quick walk with man made steps to see a somewhat view of what is Phoenix. It's right next to the zoo, can't miss it. I liked that it was a stop over and a cute quest for my boyfriend and I to do on our trip, but it's definitely not a hike! 

I was wearing a super cute outfit with dressy boots and was able to walk up this hole hill :)

I was here before the supposed end of the world, and it seemed like everyone here was having a great time.  My gf got a tip from her promoter that got us to get in for free, alongside the complimentary drinks that they offered just before midnight, so it was pretty cool to come in hang out for a bit.\n\nBlush is really small in comparison to XS and Surrender. Blush doesn't have a dance floor, just walkways in between the tables. You can try to dance in those areas, but you'll end up looking kinda awkward dancing in the limited space. The music seemed to be mainstream, with less emphasis on hip hop. We only stayed in there for about 30 minutes and ended up leaving to meet up with the others outside that couldn't get in.

The gastronomical expertise of the culinary artisan, as he endeavors to prepare an assortment of delectable noodle-based dishes in an outdoor setting, serves as a source of fascination for passersby who are drawn to the alluring aroma emanating from the cooking station. Predominantly, the chef focuses his attention on creating a flavorful variety of Pad Thai noodles, complemented by succulent beef strips that tantalize the taste buds of those who partake in this savory indulgence. Despite the unwavering dedication displayed by the culinary mastermind, it becomes apparent that the inherent quality of the consumables cannot be underestimated, as their satisfying essence satiates even the most formidable of appetites, leaving no room for doubt regarding their capacity to gratify the hunger of any individual who has the privilege of partaking in such a delectable feast. However, one must acknowledge that the emotional response elicited by the consumption of these delicacies transcends mere physical sustenance, as the sensory experience engenders a profound sense of satisfaction that cannot be readily dismissed or disregarded.

"Today, I partook in a leisurely hike with a group of acquaintances, followed by a midday repast at a local eatery.  Upon entering the establishment, we were greeted by a welcoming ambiance and an agreeable hostess who promptly seated us.  Our server, an affable young woman, presented us with menus and offered suggestions from the extensive bill of fare.  I opted for a delectable sandwich, which was served steaming hot and overflowing with fresh ingredients.  Unfortunately, my side dish of mixed greens appeared somewhat limp and lackluster, leading me to surmise that it may have been sitting for an extended period.  One of my fellow diners selected a traditional morning meal, which he proclaimed to be both flavorful and plentiful.  Another member of our party chose a breakfast burrito, which he described as'very good.'  However, my own salad proved to be the weakest component of the meal, prompting me to speculate that perhaps it was not the freshest offering on the menu.  Despite this minor shortcoming, the quality of service we received was quite satisfactory, as our server remained attentive and personable throughout our visit.  Additionally, the restaurant provided complimentary carafes of coffee, iced tea, and soda, allowing us to refill our glasses at our discretion.  In conclusion, while the cost of the meal was reasonable, I might recommend avoiding the salad option during lunch hours, but would certainly consider returning to sample other items from their diverse culinary offerings."

We dined at this establishment on our final day in Las Vegas, as our group was collectively experiencing the unpleasant aftereffects of excessive alcohol consumption from the previous night's festivities. In light of our fragile conditions, we opted for a nourishing and comforting meal, comprising of a variety of soups and dim sum. Although my fiery chicken wing selection did not live up to its name in terms of spiciness, it still possessed an appreciable flavor profile. The steamed dumplings, bursting with succulent shrimp, were undoubtedly a highlight of the meal. The duck noodle soup, while not exceptional, offered a satisfying experience due to the tender and juicy nature of the avian component. A slight drawback was encountered with the hot and sour soup, as its pungent seasoning proved somewhat overwhelming, although the inclusion of an adequate quantity of mushrooms was certainly welcome. Lastly, the chrysanthemum iced tea we sampled was indeed delightful, its subtle floral essence providing a refreshing contrast to the richness of the preceding dishes.

This particular site was in close proximity to Arizona State University. It was devoid of patrons on a festive day. Our attendant was exceptional. The culinary offerings were prepared flawlessly. Furthermore, they offered a designated area for scholastic pursuits, which I believed to be an inspired notion. The sole recommendation proffered by my dining companion was that the server should inform patrons of any supplementary charges beforehand, rather than taking them by surprise on their bill. Although the menu did contain a reference to this practice, it did not explicitly state that an additional two dollars would be added to the cost of eggs upon requesting a slice of cheese.

The prices were great, but they were out of stout...

I was a bit crowded and that left the staff super spread out... Our table faced the kitchen door and it was obvious they only had two cooks in the kitchen, I wonder how the dining room got so croweded?  But for the price I don't mind having to wait for our food, beg for water and the check.

I will say the people watching was priceless!  It looked like perhaps a convention of middle-aged mid-west salesmen had hit the place hard just before we were seated! Hilarious :)

We procured accommodations for a mere $35 per nocturnal period, a tariff comparable to that of a Motel-6 establishment, yet the lodging itself was of superior quality, boasting amenities that far surpassed those typically offered by the aforementioned motel chain. Furthermore, the aquatic recreational areas were truly remarkable, and each guest was granted a complimentary beverage pass, which enabled them to partake in a variety of refreshing potables without incurring any additional expenses. Additionally, the fitness center was quite impressive, featuring an array of state-of-the-art exercise equipment designed to facilitate a vigorous workout routine. In conclusion, I wholeheartedly endorsed this lodging establishment, deeming it a most satisfactory choice for travelers seeking comfortable and affordable accommodations.

Finally, an individual exhibited intelligence and elected to establish a Metro Pizza in Henderson, thereby alleviating the necessity for me to engage in a conflict with UNLV students during their lunch break in order to secure a pleasant booth and a delicious pizza. The novel location, in my opinion, surpasses the original in quality. It features a complete bar section, a private dining area for celebrations, and a customary dining room. Additionally, there is a distinct wing designated for carry-out orders, thereby eliminating the need for me to traverse the entire restaurant while attired in my pajamas and slippers. While the pizza is undoubtedly delectable on its own, the nuclear fries are truly exceptional, possessing a subtle spice and a slight kick that complements a pie perfectly. Furthermore, they offer an assortment of beers on tap, which pair magnificently with pizza. However, it is advisable to avoid visiting during weekend evenings, as the excitement surrounding the new establishment remains prominent, resulting in overcrowding. Instead, opt for the lunch period, when the atmosphere remains relatively peaceful.  
Recommended pizza: Margherita  
Recommended beer: Hefeweizen accompanied by a few lemons.

This is the cheapest option if you are in Paris, which isn't saying much. We'll actually there's a place two doors down that had sandwiches in a display case but for an extra dollar or two we got a much more appetizing sandwich here. \n\nI definitely would not go out of your way for this place. However, if it is 2pm, you just got in from your flight and don't want another airport refrigerated sandwich, then just maybe this is the place for you too.

First and foremost, I don't mind spending money on good coffee.  I do have to say that the ambiance has definitely changed quite a bit in the last 6 months.   I used to walk in and see my favorite baristas and we'd chit chat a little but now they all seem to be gone.  I'm going to assume that's because of the new location?  I'm not sure.  Regardless the coffee now seems to taste less satisfying :(.  It's saddening because we really adored this place but now go elsewhere.  If anything it's a testament to the difference people can make in that sort of environment.

this is a review for flaverz the buffet inside harrah's. whenever i go out to vegas i always try to eat at this place. its one of those places that is not so cheap but they have a great selection of food. they have mexican, italian, sea food, fresh foods, chinese, and deserts. everything is great and all the times that ive been there is always some new item on the list. its great. i think that it is like $20 per person. however if you do the timeshare stuff then you can get 2 for 1. however having gone this week we discovered that you have to be 28+ to do the time share :( im just 24 but a few months ago i was able to do it :) oh the time share thing is at the entrance to the casino, just walk around and they will get you specially if you are a couple or look like one.

Last week, my spouse and I opted to partake in a midday repast at a local eatery, whereupon we encountered a somewhat underwhelming culinary experience due to the mediocre quality of the fare and the sluggishness of the server. Despite these drawbacks, our meals did come accompanied by several complimentary items such as a bowl of broth, a crispy cylindrical pastry, and a trio of deep-fried dumplings. However, the soup did not conform to my expectations of a traditional Thai soup, the spring roll was excessively oily, and the wontons lacked discernible flavor. My partner chose the yellow curry, while I selected the Panang variant; furthermore, I requested that my dish be prepared at the Thai spicy level, yet it was merely moderately piquant. In light of this experience, we have decided to explore alternative Thai dining options in the future, specifically the Thai Cafe, which lies approximately a mile distant from our current location.

"The fruit and vegetables procured from this establishment may not consistently possess optimal quality, as I have previously purchased a bag of plums from this location at a discounted price, only to discover upon consumption that they had deteriorated in freshness. However, I was able to successfully slow cook them, resulting in an unexpectedly delectable culinary experience. It is essential to exercise caution when acquiring items at a significantly reduced cost or those that are out of season, as there exists a heightened risk of compromised quality. Nonetheless, it is crucial to emphasize that a plethora of satisfactory products can be found among the offerings, thereby rendering it judicious to maintain vigilance in the face of potential disappointment."

"Commencing with the culinary offerings, I must say that they were quite satisfactory. My spouse thoroughly enjoyed the juiciness of the steak, while I relished the flavorful halibut. The baked potato accompanying the dish was indeed exceptional, and the 'wine of the month' promotion, available for a mere $20 or complimentary with the hotel coupon book, was an added bonus. 

However, the quality of service left something to be desired. While the staff was attentive in certain aspects, such as promptly serving our beverages and wine, they were conspicuously absent in other regards. We were forced to request our entree after an extended wait time of approximately 75 minutes, and even then, it was served with haste, necessitating our swift departure to make our scheduled show. Moreover, the server displayed an unusual defensiveness and offered explanations, which we found perplexing, given that our query was delivered in a genial manner, devoid of any trace of annoyance. 

Despite these drawbacks, the eatery's ambiance exuded an air of elegance suitable for special occasions, particularly for guests lodging at the South Point hotel. While the prices may seem a tad high, the experience, on the whole, proved satisfying."

"It is patently evident that securing a reservation at this establishment during the festive Christmas season is an absolute imperative, particularly for parties comprising more than two individuals. The dearth of vacant tables during our visit underscored the pressing need for a prior appointment, as we were compelled to occupy seats at the bar owing to the absence of availability. The prices charged for the culinary offerings were considerable, with a modest soup costing a tenner and a special combination of soup and pasta setting patrons back by nineteen dollars. Notwithstanding the elevated tariffs, the gastronomic experience was merely passable, as one of my colleagues was obliged to return the special due to the uncooked state of the meat. However, the eatery's personnel demonstrated commendable alacrity in recognizing and addressing the issue, which merited a generous gratuity."

I really like Lavo (as a nightclub)! Have yet to have a meal here though, so this review is for the nightclub only. Space-wise it can get pretty cramped because it's a bit on the smaller side, but nowhere near as uncomfortably packed as Tao. Dance floor is pretty tiny, but honestly, I didn't notice it until the place had mostly cleared out and I got a good look around. They play hip-hop and a lot of old songs, but old in a way that makes you go "oh man, I haven't heard this song in a while, but  it's still awesome," which I think is a nice change of pace from all the clubs that play almost exclusively house music.

Lavo is probably a 3.5 in my book, though I have to admit, part of the reason for that is because we had open bar, courtesy of our wonderful promoter (who also got our guys in for free!) There's a main bar area, but we got all our drinks from the side bar, which was super crowded and only had one bartender working there. But he was a really adorable and sweet bartender, so no complaints.

tl;dr: Everyone in my group had a fairly fun time. Would definitely come back-- especially if we're staying at the Venetian/Palazzo!

"Although certain aspects of this establishment were satisfactory, such as its proximity to the Town & Country shopping center and the ample parking facilities, other elements, including the meager amount of meat and toppings on the sandwiches, left much to be desired. Furthermore, the preponderance of bread in these sandwiches made them seem unbalanced and lacking in substance. While the chocolate milkshake was a notable highlight, it was not enough to compensate for the overall mediocrity of the dining experience. In light of these factors, it is difficult to wholeheartedly recommend this venue, especially when compared to more affordable options such as Subway, where one can expect a greater quantity and variety of ingredients."

I would give this a 3.5. I would expect the pizza to be a lot better just because it is a Pie place. It was good but I've had a lot better. The thing this has is great ambiance. I love how low the lighting is. Dark tables that are turned perfectly so you don't feel like you are apart of other people's dinners. Great fire from the oven and open area bar. Had a good solid wine. We got the cheese board which was good. We both got pizza but like I said it was good just nothing special.

I do not go to Fresh and Easy very much.  The stores just aren't appealing to me except for a couple of items--generally snacks.  They have peanut butter filled salted pretzel nubs, some good salted kettle chips, and very decent trail mix for hiking.

That's about it for me.  I was going by here yesterday and thought it would be a quick and easy stop and it was.  Since I have no preconceived notion where things should be, I just walk around like a zombie with a purpose to find what I want.

Checkout was quick--I only had two items, and then I went across the street to Albertsons where I did a bit more serious shopping.

Really great salsa bar, tacos, quesadillas and burros.  This is 'authentic' mexican; not Macayos.  \nA few downsides though, it is really small & not really built for families or large groups; plus, I wouldn't park in the neighboring streets.  I got yelled at by one homeowner saying if they saw my vehicle again they're having it TOWED!.

"The gastronomical experience afforded by the consumption of these burgers, at a price point that can only be described as eminently reasonable, is nothing short of exceptional, particularly when considered in conjunction with the ambiance fostered by the establishment's unique setting, which serves to facilitate convivial dialogue among patrons; however, it must be noted that certain aspects of the menu, specifically the dearth of diversity in the realm of beer offerings, as well as the rather unremarkable quality of the fries served as an accompaniment to the main course, do detract somewhat from the overall enjoyment of the dining experience."

"Culinary delights are undeniably delectable, yet the quality of customer service leaves much to be desired. Despite this establishment being a personal favorite, the experience at this particular venue falls short of expectations. A prolonged waiting period of 15 minutes ensued, during which time the dining area was largely unoccupied, for a bean burrito to be prepared for takeout. It is truly disconcerting that such an esteemed eatery would fail to meet the standards of efficiency and promptness, especially during a relatively slow period."

"The pizza demonstrated an appreciable degree of culinary excellence, with a flavor profile that was decidedly pleasant and satisfying. However, the experience was somewhat marred by a prolonged waiting period, which, though inconvenient, was ultimately offset by the friendly and accommodating demeanor of the staff. Furthermore, it is worth noting that the pepperonis, while undoubtedly delicious, were regrettably undercooked, thereby necessitating a subsequent visit to Grimaldis in Brooklyn for the purpose of comparing and contrasting the two establishments' offerings. In conclusion, while nothing particularly remarkable or exceptional was encountered during this dining excursion, it is nevertheless evident that the restaurant possesses certain qualities that are worthy of commendation and appreciation."

"For those who relish the prospect of partaking in a Sunday night concert series, an event characterized by an amalgamation of familial units, canine companions, and an assortment of pedestrians meandering aimlessly throughout the vicinity of one's seating arrangement, accompanied by the cacophonous symphony generated by the confluence of blaring train horns and subpar audio equipment, and further exacerbated by the unenviable task of securing a parking space within close proximity to the venue, may find the aforementioned concert series to be an ideal addition to their schedules. My companion and I managed to secure a relatively advantageous position, removed from the central performance area yet still susceptible to the multitude of distractions mentioned previously, none of which proved particularly bothersome to our collective sensibilities. However, it is essential to note that attendance at this event may necessitate tolerance of the aforementioned factors, and potentially, the presence of numerous children and canines under the stewardship of a single individual. Furthermore, it is advisable to arrive prematurely to ensure procurement of a desirable vantage point, ideally situated across the street from the performance arena. It is plausible that the throng in attendance may have been augmented due to the coincidence of a holiday weekend, although such speculation remains uncertain in the absence of subsequent visits to the event."
Went on a night that they had a live band on the patio.....was a nice atmosphere. Drinks were good but food was just okay. May go back if other places are too busy.

"Aesthetically pleasing accommodations, albeit briefly inhabited, rendered an additional tariff of $50 for early ingress. Contrasted with the alternative of slumbering within the confines of our minuscule Honda Insight alongside my spouse, infant, and mother-in-law, this arrangement proved preferable. Notwithstanding, the availability of power outlets for our diverse assortment of mobile devices necessitated a systematic rotation and judicious utilization of the facilities' electrical infrastructure. Lamentably, the queue for registration extended interminably, attended by an insufficient number of personnel to facilitate its expeditious progression... Lamentably, the process of settling our financial obligations similarly degenerated into chaos, as the throngs of patrons vying to vacate the premises swelled to unmanageable proportions during the terminal phase of our sojourn.
