Gratuities notwithstanding, the absence of a coffee brewing apparatus within our quarters occasioned mild disappointment. Furthermore, the egress protocol struck us as somewhat bizarre, advocating instead for a simplified, hassle-free procedure involving the placement of the invoice beneath the entrance to our abode, followed by a swift and unencumbered departure, devoid of any unnecessary delays or complications. Ultimately, despite some minor shortcomings, our stay at the TI proved satisfactory, yet, given the tariff, we might opt to seek alternative lodgings in the future."

Hit up merts for dinner last night..  Had the Fried catfish and Beef rib combo.  Whole fried catfish was a little tough to negociate the bones and didnt not yeald much fish. \"The beef rib\" was chopped up and in a small pile bones and all.  Like other have said the goodness in in the sides..  Mac and Cheese was real and had a nice crust on the top and the corn bread was good.. athough the piece my wife got looked like it was in the oven a littlel too long and dried out a bit.  Overall decent stop

"My affection for cinematic endeavors directed by John Hughes notwithstanding, this particular establishment purporting to serve breakfast items under the moniker 'The Breakfast Club' fell short of my expectations, which, admittedly, were predicated on the eponymous film. The eggs, while adequate in terms of their culinary execution, unfortunately lacked that je ne sais quoi that would have elevated them to the realm of true gastronomical excellence; the potatoes, referred to as 'O'Brian' in an apparent attempt at novelty, were unremarkable in both texture and flavor, with an unfortunate tendency towards oiliness and an inconsistent distribution of pepper; the jalapeno biscuits, whose conceptual appeal had initially piqued my interest, regrettably failed to deliver upon their promised premise, manifesting instead as somewhat tough and flavorless disk-shaped entities infused with jalapenos; the heuvos rancheros, while perhaps visually unappealing to some due to their resemblance to a feline hairball, were declared palatable by my dining companion. \n\nIn conclusion, my experience at this establishment was, overall, disappointing, primarily due to an excessive greasiness that permeated the menu offerings, as well as an outdoor seating area that, while pleasant in theory, proved to be a mixed blessing given its proximity to a heavily trafficked thoroughfare. However, it must be acknowledged that the quality of service provided by the waitstaff was, for the most part, satisfactory, despite certain unsettling mannerisms reminiscent of the Stepford Wives that were observable in some of the servers."

"In conclusion, it can be inferred that the venue possesses certain attributes that render it an enjoyable destination, however, various factors, such as the charges associated with parking, entry, and storage, in addition to the limited number of functional water slides, may potentially hinder its appeal, ultimately leaving the decision to visit up to individual preferences."

Fairly typical Chinese food with a Sushi menu and nice restaurant seating area.  I wasn't as wow'd as I was hoping after reading all the rave reviews here on Yelp, but it is a pretty decent offering.

I tried the egg drop soup, which was a good value, the pork dumplings, which were meh - I think the sauce was overly sweet, the kung pao chicken, which was pretty good, and the chicken lo mein noodles, which were meh (but aren't all lo mein noodles pretty meh?).

Overall I would come back and get some take out because it does lie somewhere in between your PFChangs and your strip mall cheap Chinese take out place.  However, I don't believe it's that great of a value offering.  The prices are a bit high for cheap Chinese, and the quality is only just a bit higher.  Doesn't feel like you're getting a great deal.

"The embellishments within this establishment are positively endearing, evoking a strong desire within me to linger and partake in the assorted delights available. Following the lead of numerous patrons who have preceded me, I opted to sample a pair of macaroons, specifically those infused with a mix of berries and raspberries. While not necessarily a novice to such confectionaries, I must confess that my palate was neither blown away nor thoroughly disappointed by the experience, thereby necessitating a future visit to explore alternative flavors and possibilities."

"Although Footlocker may not excite one's senses, it does offer an array of prominent shoe brands, including Reebok, Nike, Adidas, and an abundance of basketball sneakers that could be deemed superfluous. Prices range from moderate to expensive, yet periodic sales provide customers with the opportunity to acquire desirable footwear at a reduced cost. However, these sales often feature aesthetically unappealing shoes that may not be in high demand. As Footlocker appears to cater primarily to male clientele, its inventory is comprised predominantly of men's shoes, leaving a limited selection for women. Thus, while I may visit the store to peruse its offerings, I frequently find myself seeking alternatives that better align with my preferences."

My fiance said I should write a review.    I replied that the restaurant didn't strike me as good or bad.  It was pretty middle of the road.

2.5 stars for me.

Service was fine.   No real complaints or compliments there.

Food.  During happy hour, you get 2 tacos for $3 Chef's choice of tacos.  And I delighted in eating the salmon taco.   

I was expecting grand things from the guacamole and was disappointed.   The dried cranberries were an interesting addition.  But I much prefer good ol' Trader Joe's guacamole.

Food was rico.   Rico means "rich" in Spanish and usually a compliment.   I just found the food rico in terms of calories.

I wouldn't mind going back but neither am I itching to return either.

This isn't a movie theater that I frequent regularly since I live in NLV, but the "renovations" since Rave owned the place seems favorable. They've added extended armrests between each seat with a heavier duty cup holder than you're used to but has pros and cons; while it makes sharing drinks and snacks easier, it also makes the armrest stationary. 

PRO:
New armrests are larger.
Snack bar seems to be larger than most.

CON:
The movie (White House Down) started about 20 minutes late, apparently nobody was in the operating room.
There were only like 30 M&Ms in the package I purchased at the snack bar.

"Indubitably, 'Ja... perfectly fine.' However, there seems to be a certain je ne sais quoi missing from 'Jawohl. I rather enjoy that.' Perhaps it's the lack of a tangible element, such as a location with a similar ambiance to a fast-food chain, but with a more refined and sophisticated atmosphere, akin to a restaurant rather than a bar. Perchance, the concept of offering a build-your-own menu, where customers can curate their own dishes from a selection of premium ingredients, might help to establish a more coherent and well-rounded culinary experience. It's worth mentioning that the service has been consistently friendly and attentive, without being overbearing or intrusive. While the location itself is not necessarily problematic, the overall concept and pricing strategy may benefit from further refinement to fully realize its potential. At present, it appears to be a fusion of a trendy Berlin-Mitte scene restaurant and the currently popular Munich 'Currywurst bars,' resulting in a unique yet somewhat disjointed dining experience. Notwithstanding, the establishment boasts a commendable gender diversity among its staff."

A coterie of individuals, including myself, elected to partake in a culinary excursion to this establishment, primarily due to the fact that we had been informed that their burgers were of superior quality. Upon arriving at the venue, we discovered that the comestibles were indeed delectable, yet somewhat greasy and arid. However, it was the unfortunate occurrence of poor hospitality that truly marred our dining experience. Specifically, Olivia, our server, displayed an acrimonious demeanor throughout the duration of our visit, seemingly without provocation. When we requested a container for transporting our food, she carelessly flung it onto the table, an action we perceived as discourteous. Furthermore, we were compelled to request the replenishment of our water vessels thrice before she eventually attended to our needs. Considering the elevated prices charged by this restaurant, a certain level of decorum and attentive service would have been anticipated. In conclusion, while the edibles were undoubtedly savory, the subpar service we received left much to be desired. If one values a satisfying dining experience, they may wish to consider patronizing this establishment with the hope that they will encounter a more competent and affable server.

So I thought I'd drop in for a little afternoon delight. Lots of Yummy Flavors to choose from.
I was looking forward to a real sweet treat with lots of candy on top!
It's March so I  chose Irish creme mmmmm with almond roca topping.

I was enjoying it for about the first 3 bites then all I could think about  was "Twangy Tart"!
All this time I thought I loved the Golden Spoon, that is until I let the Ice Tango do a little dance on my tongue! 

Trust Me once you try the Twang you'll be like Daaaaaang! 
And Nothing else will ever be the same!

Damn You Ice Tango! You have ruined me from enjoying any other Frozen yogurt joint!

Golden Who?

Its good food.  Its just not the greatest food for the price you pay.  I had a spicy chicken of some sort, and they dont mess around when it comes to the spicy stuff.  This stuff was HOT.  I enjoyed it quite a bit, but I just didnt feel like the food justified the price.  $11 for a lunch special?  No thanks.  I would give the food 4 out of 5 stars though.

I only ordered pho there and wasn't impressed at all but I saw some other dishes other people were eating looked pretty good.  It gave me the feeling that it's a more Americanized joint comparing to the ones on spring mtn. I'm willing to try again.

"This shopping center formerly enjoyed a preeminent status among its peers within the locality. However, with the advent of Arizona Mills, Chandler Fashion Center, and Tempe Marketplace, it appears that a significant proportion of patrons residing in Chandler, Tempe, and Gilbert have migrated their allegiance to these newer retail establishments. Despite this shift, a plethora of quality stores continue to operate within Fiesta, mirroring an array of identical retailers found at the aforementioned competitors. Notably, during peak sales periods and holidays, the mall's diminished foot traffic translates into a more comfortable and convenient shopping experience for patrons. Additionally, Fiesta boasts a unique covered parking area, which distinguishes it from its rivals and offers a welcome respite from the sweltering heat during the summer months."

"It is patently evident that the medical establishment in question, despite their professed commitment to excellence in patient care, has elected to adopt a decidedly parsimonious approach when it comes to the fiscal aspects of their operations. Specifically, the recent invoice we received for services rendered, which was delivered in a wholly unremarkable envelope devoid of any semblance of aesthetic appeal or functional utility, serves as a stark reminder of the disparity between the lofty standards they purport to uphold and the rather more pedestrian reality of their business practices. Not only did the invoice lack any semblance of a tear-off portion or return envelope (the latter of which, it must be acknowledged, would have been an unreasonable expectation given the paltry sums involved), but it was also printed on a machine that could charitably be described as 'economical,' thereby imbuing the entire document with an air of unmistakable thriftiness. This begs the question: if such scant regard is given to the presentation and delivery of financial documents, might it not be reasonable to surmise that similar corner-cutting measures are being taken in other, perhaps more critical, aspects of the medical facility's operations? Furthermore, it seems axiomatic that even a modest investment in pre-printed invoices with detachable return portions and, at the very least, a complimentary return envelope, would serve to enhance the overall experience for patients, thereby fostering a more positive perception of the institution and, by extension, its reputation."

Awesome location, cool place....the Chopped Salad is by far the most amazing salad I have ever had in my life (but way...and I mean way to small)...If it were double the portion for the price I would probably visit more. I had a flight when I was there...it took forever (as I know flights are supposed to)...but this was ridiculous...the buffalo meat is so gross...it reminds me of when a stray dog visits my lawn...

The BBQ sauce is good....the staff is just OK. Nothing mind blowing. I think staff in a place with a pricey menu should spoil the guests a bit...Give away a free desert when you know the service and meal is just OK...this may bring your customer base back to visit just because you redeemed yourself at the end.

Overall its a cool place. It fits with the downtown Scottsdale lifestyle. But stay away from the buffalo, because it will give doggy bag a whole new meaning....

The food here was really good. It was filling and tasty. However, when compared to other taco joints or mexican food, it is just very average. I love mexican food and the food here lacks the authenticity of other places... But this should be obvious since its in a casino. \nMy problem is that they are very very pricey. For two people, it was $54. The food was good and it was discounted for gamblers, but if I had to pay over $50 for the quality I would be upset.\nDefinetly people should come here and try it out, just know the quality isn't worth the price.

Decent food for the price however I've been to better sushi places for the similar price(and sometimes its worth pay extra for better food). Their makis are often sloppy and unfinished looking and certain fish(fresh tuna or yellow tail for example) are not the freshest. I guess it's good for quick lunch once in a while but not for a fancy dinner.

"Encountered an individual at this location, with the intention of engaging in a recreational activity on the tennis courts.  To our astonishment, the facilities were in a state of good repair, despite the absence of net straps, which did not deter us from participating in the sport.  Generally speaking, this complex possesses a certain appeal... However, my singular grievance would be the convoluted design of the parking area, replete with numerous curved pathways, thereby creating numerous blind spots for drivers who must reverse their vehicles.  Although this layout may contribute to the aesthetic appeal of the surroundings, it would undoubtedly pose a formidable challenge for maintenance personnel, as the absence of straightforward trajectories necessitates additional effort in upkeep. \n\nObserved that the residential units appeared sturdy and well-constructed, employing brick as the primary building material... Nevertheless, the proximity of the highway resulted in significant noise pollution, permeating the atmosphere and rendering it audible even from the tennis court.  Did not venture inside a specific dwelling, yet the auditory level was considerable, even from a distance."

"Applebee's, a ubiquitous chain restaurant, fails to impress me with its unremarkable offerings. Despite my predilection for certain franchises, Applebee's does not rank among my favorites. The cuisine is merely adequate, neither exceptional nor deplorable, but rather mediocre. My recent visit, prompted by a group decision, proved to be an underwhelming experience, save for a few notable exceptions. The Bourbon Black and Bleu Burger, a welcome surprise, boasted a satisfying combination of flavors and spices that elicited a pleasurable response from my taste buds. However, the remaining dishes, including the 3 cheese penne and chicken entrÃ©e, did not garner much enthusiasm from either myself or my fellow diners. Notably, my 18-month-old daughter, notorious for her finicky palate, surprised me by consuming half of her grilled cheese sandwich, the bread of which was reminiscent of a sweet, eggy brioche. The service at Applebee's was commendable, as our server was attentive and proactive in addressing our needs. In summary, while the food and service were satisfactory, the establishment's overall ambiance left me uninspired. Given the choice, I would opt for Chili's over Applebee's, but this particular location managed to incrementally enhance my impression of the franchise."

This was my second trip to this location and I noticed their salad bar had fewer items from before.  It was still very good but am disappointed that they seemed to have eliminated some items. I am not a big meat eater and came for the salad bar so I noticed these things. It was still really really good however.

I enjoyed my meal at Spago, but wasn't as impressed as my companions. The wedge salad is good but not notable, however the heirloom tomato and burrata salad special was outstanding - the best overall dish of the night.  

We ended up splitting 3 pizzas - I have to say, I found the crust to be disappointing on all of them. Not much flavor at all - more of just a vehicle for the toppings.  As for the specific pies:
-Margherita - crust was a bit undercooked, and overall I would call this a pretty average Margherita pizza
-Proscuitto - this was the best of the 3 - the Proscuitto and Fromage blanc worked perfectly together.  With a great crust this pizza would have mind blowing potential.
-Lamb Chorizo - a very nice pie overall - enjoyed the chorizo, and the toppings all worked well together. 

Service was excellent.

Great place for the price. Not the most luxurious place on the strip but the amenities are decent, the service is good, and the location is fantastic. Very good value overall.

This is the 4th or 5th time we've stayed here. The rooms are clean and comfortable, and there is a decent selection of food downstairs ranging from McDonald's to 5 star French, and everything in between. The casino floor is a bit small and smoky, but perfect for when you're not in the mood to get dressed up and go out. The spa is small and reasonably priced. And it's only a few minutes' walk to other casinos, restaurants, and shopping at the many malls nearby.

The only things we didn't care much for were the showers (high pressure mist that's definitely not my idea of pleasant) and on our most recent trip the TV didn't work properly (but we didn't call to have it fixed because it just wasn't that important to us).

Yes, you can stay at a nicer, trendier, and/or more luxurious place on the strip but you'll pay about twice as much. We prefer to stay here, where we're always satisfied, and use the cash we saved to eat, play, and party while we're in town.

"Tucked away in an unassuming location, nestled adjacent to the lavishly adorned Ella's Deli, this eatery may prove challenging to detect at first glance, but a visit is undoubtedly merited if one seeks a delectable gyro or kebab experience. Although somewhat overshadowed by its resplendent neighbor, this establishment boasts an array of palatable delights, including a diverse selection of donuts, cookies worthy of praise, and even homemade baklava for those inclined towards such culinary indulgences. Sandwiches, enhanced by a side of flavorful seasoned fries, serve as the piÃ¨ce de rÃ©sistance, offering a gustatory satisfaction that transcends mere sustenance. For those who prefer vegetarian fare, fear not, as options such as potato kahbi and falafel sandwiches are readily available, catering to dietary inclinations without sacrificing taste. A varied assortment of beverages further complements the menu, ensuring that thirst and hunger are simultaneously satiated. Despite its unfortunate placement, a visit to this venue remains worthwhile for those venturing into the surrounding vicinity."

When this establishment first inaugurated its operations, it boasted an exceptional quality, thereby warranting a perfect five-star rating. However, over time, its standards have subsided, rendering it merely satisfactory. Despite this decline, my father continues to patronize this venue, and thus, we visited it together. Our meal commenced with the grilled artichoke, customarily a delectable option. Unfortunately, this particular instance proved disappointing, as the artichoke exhibited a pronounced rigidity and lacked discernible flavor, perhaps due to the off-season availability of this ingredient. Nonetheless, the accompanying aioli sauce compensated for the artichoke's deficiencies, offering a savory delight. The prime rib, though tender and possessing a satisfactory flavor profile, failed to impress, as its portion size has diminished progressively during my visits. This consistent reduction in magnitude was coupled with a uniform selection of sides, specifically a baked potato. Ultimately, our dining experience concluded without the customary sweet treat. Despite these shortcomings, the prospect of future visits remains viable, primarily owing to my father's persistent fondness for this eatery.

Barneys is a multifaceted drinking establishment that offers a unique experience for patrons seeking a more relaxed atmosphere than the typical bars in the vicinity. For individuals desiring an unpretentious environment where they can enjoy themselves without the necessity of dressing up or paying covers, Barneys may be the ideal destination.

The second floor of the bar particularly stood out to me as a preferred spot, owing to the hospitable demeanor of the bartender and their promptness in refilling drinks. Although the rooftop area has the potential to be an attractive spot during warmer weather, the presence of smoking therein serves as a deterrent for some.

One notable aspect of Barneys is its innovative method of pouring beer from the bottom up, creating a distinctive and entertaining experience for customers. Moreover, for those who have had a few too many drinks, the bar features an amusing arcade game involving a lobster claw, reminiscent of the classic claw machine found at carnivals and arcades.

Overall, Barneys earns a rating of 3.5 stars for its distinctive ambiance and diverse offerings that cater to various preferences.

My wife went there recently during the week with a few friends. It was a Monday afternoon. She said it was not what she expected. It was a neat experience but not as many animals as she thought. 10 bucks to get in for locals and that seemed kinda steep after she got in and realized how minimal the park was.  Also it was over 100 degrees and there was not a drop of water to be had. Every water fountain she stopped at....it said out of order.  This is very dangerous for visitors. They should have water available st all times.

"As an individual enrolled at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, this eatery presents an extraordinary value, offering five tacos, two sides, and a beverage for a mere $5; the tacos, though diminutive in stature, are abundant in terms of protein, thereby obviating any concern of being shortchanged; it is an ideal venue for socializing with companions, indulging in a pail of fermented beverages, and engaging in lively conversation; the protocol involves ordering at the counter, with the staff summoning one's attention via a vocal announcement when the culinary items are prepared; reportedly, the establishment occasionally features live musical performances or a disc jockey, typically showcasing a Latin-inspired theme, which, while unsurprising given the restaurant's heritage, may strike some patrons as unexpected."

I find myself experiencing considerable ambivalence regarding First Friday, as I hold an ardent affection for communal gatherings, particularly those that showcase artistic expression and cultural creativity. However, my enthusiasm for this event is significantly diminished due to its glaring shortcomings. Despite being situated within the artistic hub of the city, First Friday fails to deliver an adequate representation of artistic endeavors. The scarcity of art galleries and the prevalence of commercialized street vendors, who prioritize financial gain over artistic integrity, contribute to the dearth of authentic artistic expression. Furthermore, the presence of unsavory elements and rowdy juveniles in the downtown area, coupled with the authorities' inability to effectively enforce curfew regulations, serves to further detract from the overall experience. While the culinary stalls during the summer months offer some solace, the absence of such vendors during the winter season only exacerbates the event's deficiencies. Notwithstanding my reservations, I may still choose to attend future First Fridays, albeit with the caveat that I shall arrive promptly before dusk and avoid the nocturnal throngs of unruly youth.

I had a profound affection for the ambiance and the personnel who were responsible for creating it, as they exhibited an exceptional level of competence in their respective roles. However, the culinary offerings did not quite live up to my expectations, despite being satisfactory in terms of taste and presentation. Furthermore, the tariff charged for the meal did not seem to align with the value proposition offered by the restaurant, leading me to question the overall value for money.

"I recently had the occasion to partake in a culinary excursion to TMI for an evening repast. While the gastronomical experience was not without its merits, it failed to surpass my expectations in terms of overall satisfaction. Upon initiating the meal, we opted to sample the TMI toast, which, despite some reservations regarding the texture of the bread, proved to be a satisfying commencement to the delectation process. However, my subsequent selection, the Mac & Cheese, unfortunately did not live up to my gustatory standards, as it was noticeably oleaginous and lacking in flavor. It is worth mentioning that I have historically been able to establish a rapport with nearly any iteration of Mac & Cheese, yet the version proffered by TMI unfortunately did not conform to this trend. The remaining members of my dining party opted for sandwiches and salads, the quality of which, according to their accounts, ranged from satisfactory to palatable. Aesthetically, the ambiance of the establishment exuded a certain je ne sais quoi, while the degree of auditory intensity rendered conversation somewhat challenging. Furthermore, the temperature within the premises was uncomfortably elevated. In conclusion, while TMI may possess certain attributes that could potentially appeal to certain gastronomes, my own experience did not warrant an overly enthusiastic endorsement, thereby rendering my return in the proximate future unlikely."

I was surprised to find that had a TON of brand new irrigation supplies. As a gardener, I am always fiddling with the irrigation, and am in constant need of emitters, hose, and connectors to support my filthy habit. They have it all (at least when I went), and at a fraction of what the hardware store charges.

"It serves as an enjoyable venue for social gatherings, facilitating the relational dynamics of communal dining. My culinary inclinations lean towards familial-style sharing, which this establishment accommodates seamlessly. However, our ordered dishes displayed inconsistent quality, with a notable eggplant and goat cheese entrÃ©e featuring an excessive proportion of cheese that overpowered the subtle flavor of the eggplant. In contrast, a dish comprising eggs, potatoes, and another component (the specificity of which escapes my memory) presented an unbalanced ratio of potato to other ingredients, prompting a sense of disappointment. Nonetheless, both the filet mignon and Thai beef salad showcased remarkable taste, rendering my overall experience gratifying. Despite some reservations, I am content with having visited this restaurant, yet I harbor doubts about returning in the future."

We had not visited this establishment since its previous incarnation as Cafe Del Sol, and our recent visit was facilitated by a Groupon we had procured approximately one month prior. Upon arriving at the venue, we were struck by the somewhat unconventional layout, which featured a primary dining area and a smaller, segregated section designated for'red-headed step children' and located around the corner from the main area. This configuration seemed to create an atmosphere that was somewhat lacking in vitality. Arriving during the latter portion of happy hour, my spouse opted for a glass of Sangria, while I selected a glass of Tempranillo, which unfortunately did not meet my expectations. Subsequently, I ordered an additional glass of wine, the name of which escapes me, and found it to be relatively satisfying. My culinary selections included the cola and pineapple braised short ribs, jalapeno cream corn, and a chile corn casserole. While the sides were generally well-prepared, the corn casserole was slightly overcooked. The short ribs, on the other hand, were quite flavorful and did not possess the dubious taste often associated with lesser quality braised short ribs. Although the sauce accompanying the ribs was slightly too viscous for my liking, it did not detract substantially from the overall enjoyment of the dish. My spouse's grilled shrimp appetizer, served with avocado and mango sauce, was greatly enjoyed, as were the empanadas. However, my personal preference did not extend to the empanadas. Nonetheless, the shrimp dish was fairly impressive. Considering the totality of our experience, we would classify this eatery as a respectable local option, and while we might not elect to return, we recognize that our spouse may potentially persuade us to do so at some future date.

"A refreshing submergence into an atmospheric drinking establishment, offering a brief respite from the conventional Las Vegas landscape. We entered the premises on a Friday evening, subsequent to receiving complimentary beverage vouchers on Fremont Street. The ambiance was relatively desolate for a weekend night, which rendered the decibel levels of the bartenders' megaphones marginally excessive and potentially annoying. Nonetheless, the experience was enjoyable, albeit tainted by the realization that the bartenders employed a subtle ploy to coerce patrons into purchasing potations for both themselves and the staff, resulting in an unexpected escalation of our tab."

I have stayed at the Hotel Monte Carlo Las Vegas numerous times, and I'm ready to move on to other hotels.  Its outdated, the food at the main cafe and buffet are so-so, however the rates were pretty fantastic.  Compared to the other hotels, especially the newest arrivals, it shows its age.  

However, I do like it that the concierge will put hotel guests on the VIP list to get into Haze, and other nightclubs in the vicinity.  That was a cool feature we appreciate, and at no cost to the concierge for to get in.  

If its deals you are looking for, and "decent" rooms, it is worth looking into.

I've only frequented the one in Henderson on Sunset and the one on South Rainbow, both have been great for breakfast, the steak and eggs especially.  The happy hour at the South Rainbow location, with $2 drafts and 1/2 price appetizers. fantastic.  For that, these two places get an "A".

But as someone noted, their reward card is now pretty much of a joke.  They changed the earning levels so dramatically, it would take me years to get a $10 credit...so on that, and for doing so without any advance notice or taking into consideration past credits earned, they get an "F".

So they have 3 stars, the average between an "A" and a "F".

"Although my dining experience was generally satisfactory, I encountered some difficulties with the ordering process, which proved to be somewhat perplexing. However, given my intellectual prowess and resourcefulness, I managed to decipher the intricacies of the menu and successfully ordered a delectable burger that met my expectations. Additionally, the onion rings that accompanied my meal were quite palatable. Nonetheless, I must admit that the ambiance of the establishment lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, a quality that would have elevated it from mere adequacy to exceptionalism."

This was a typical resort restaurant the food was fairly ambitious and the food was pricey. I had the chicken because almost any other entree was really pricey, and almost solidly steak. Never the less the food was pretty good and the service was great. Unfortunately the table next to us lit up and then it was pretty smokey, but we were already done, and we chose to sit outside so that I don't blame them for at all. In the end it was a little too pricey for what your gonna get, some good food but also it was the resort and I wouldn't expect anything different. I probably won't be back, our server was really nice though that's the only reason I feel bad about giving this place 3 stars. Other than that it was all around ok.

It's amazing what a few blocks can do, in this case... not much if you're heading further East. I love me some Lao Laan... never really had Lao prior to moving to Madison. But I just don't get the same attentive service, sweet menu recommendations and authentic experience I so often found on Willy. What gives? The menu is more compact but the dining room is bigger, so it's perfect if you need room to groove, but other than the size, I think Willy is probably you're best bet if you're looking for curry east of the capitol.
Good Burger but on the pricy side for what you get. I work nearby and was hoping for a lunch deal but they aren't open for lunch. Pleasant staff and service was good but no lunch no return trips.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition in the menu offerings over an extended period of time, specifically six years, in a cosmopolitan city such as Montreal, Canada, where culinary diversity and innovation are expected; however, the radish oyster dish stands out as an exceptional delicacy, worth every penny of the twelve Canadian dollars charged for four pieces, while the remaining dishes fail to impress or provide sufficient value for the price."

I came in to pick up a new laptop charger and get the upgrade to Lion OSX.

Getting the charger was easy enough, but because I'm on Leopard and not Snow Leopard, I have to buy *two* OS upgrades to get to Lion. Ok, that's fine and all, but the stores don't carry the upgrade from Leopard to Snow Leopard. Excuse me?

My only options were to find a Best Buy that may or may not have the Leopard to Snow Leopard upgrade disc in stock, or order it online and wait several days for it to arrive. They can't keep a few discs in stock at the Apple store? Absurd.

Other than that total stupidity, the location was fine, store was clean (albeit busy at an odd time), and employee that checked me out was nice enough.

"Culinary experiences that are reasonably priced and of sufficient quality. Enter with the expectation of a restaurant providing typical diner fare and you shall be gratified. The hospitality is adequate, the cuisine is passable, and the cost (particularly considering its proximity to the Las Vegas Strip) is quite favorable."

decent... i had the \"sin city\" burger. i liked it very much. my wife had a classic which i didnt like but i'm not sure what she had on it. she liked it so i guess thats what counts. the sweet potato fries werent that great. i didnt like the way they were seasoned. the regular fries were ok. all in all it was pretty good. its better than most fast food burgers....

"Moderately satisfactory for juveniles, mediocre to subpar for grown-ups.  Congenial personnel, reasonable tariff.  Not particularly delectable, but tolerable in small quantities.  Restricted selection of sweet treats and leafy greens."

If you're looking for a sweet, maybe one with some chocolate or even a big sundae - this is your place. Nice old-fashioned ice cream shop located in old town. This place still has the retro pink vibe and decoration going on inside. \n\nMy friend and I came here when we were looking to splurge with the buster brownie sundae. BOY is It sweet but worth it! Sugar Bowl also serves food, which I was unaware of but probably wouldn't order. Service is friendly.

"I have had the pleasure of partaking in the culinary offerings of this establishment on multiple occasions, both in-house and via delivery, and while the initial excitement has subsided, the quality of the food remains unwavering. The prevalence of five-star reviews may lead one to assume an air of infallibility, but in reality, the restaurant's excellence lies in its ability to deliver a fresh, flavorful wing experience, augmented by the 'awesome sauce' that has become a staple of their menu. My personal preference tends towards the Golden BBQ and Order, though I have also sampled the Citrus Chipotle, Jamaican Jerk, and Sweet Chili options, each boasting a distinct and satisfying flavor profile. The boneless wings, comparable in size to chicken tenders, maintain their appeal, and the delivery process is both expedient and reliable. However, the quality of service varies, with some experiences falling short of expectations, despite the frequency of my visits. Of note, the waffle fries, which I opted to upgrade, were cooked to a crispy perfection, transcending the realm of traditional potatoes and entering the realm of potato chips. In conclusion, while the inflated reviews may be misleading, the restaurant's strengths lie in its diverse array of sauces and consistently satisfying wing experience."

"Thus, I possess an eccentric predicament that evokes acute discomfort within my being whenever an individual presents me with an excessively sizable plate of culinary delights. In this instance, my craving was for the flavorsome chile rellenos; however, I did not desire the gargantuan serving size that accompanied it. Alas, such is the prevailing trend in the realm of dining establishments nowadays. Nonetheless, had I been cognizant of the colossal proportions prior, I would have considered sharing my repast with my companion. Notwithstanding, upon securing a table on a Friday evening sans reservation or waiting period, the hospitality we received was indeed attentive and accommodating, while the financial burden imposed by the meal was quite reasonable. Furthermore, my mint-based beverage, a mojito, proved to be quite delectable."

"A culinary mainstay in Charlotte, ripe for a transformative revamp. While the victuals are generally palatable, albeit intermittently unpredictable, the ambiance lags behind the city's evolving gastronomic landscape. Despite this shortcoming, a visit to PC remains a worthwhile endeavor, particularly when the weather permits an alfresco dining experience on the superlative patio. The salads, in particular, merit high praise."

Stopped by here to get a drink before eating out. The place was loud, very loud. Loud from people shouting at the big screens (not sure, something with men on ice skates!), loud from birthday parties all over the place, and loud from the loud music playing. 
It's mainly a gin bar, so don't expect anything exciting about their beer menu, but their gin and gin cocktails menu is attractive. We tried the one with the Quebec gin (Ungava) and maple syrup and even though I'm not much into gin, I really liked it (but then put maple syrup into anything and I will love it!)
It's a bit on the expensive side - 20$ for a beer and a cocktail (I will never, and I mean never, get around to having to add taxes and tips everywhere here!) - but the service was great. The waitress was obviously running between those big parties tables flagging here at every chance but still managed to take care of us in due time.
Glad I went as we've been meaning to try it since the day we moved in the area though :-)

This is easy to confuse with Central Library, but this is hwere they keep the special books - all the special books.  Central Library is just a normal library.

To come read these books you will have to apply at the registration desk for a pass (with ID) that will last for either a few days or about 3 months.

If there is a secific old book here you want to see then you should definitely come here to see it, but if not then this is a lot of fuss over reading a book and you'll be better going elsewhere.

Good sports bar/restaurant--if that's your thing.

Went here when visiting with my dad who suggested it as "one of those new fun places."

The stuffed portabella mushroom appetizer was delicious, though ridiculously decadent.  The carnitas libre pizza was also pretty good, but also extremely rich--i.e. you can taste your arteries clogging.  The pollotate pizza was bland and dry--potatos on pizza is fun in theory, but I'm not convinced.  However, the cook forgot the onions on it, which actually might make a substantial, positive difference.  We okayed the oversight (they've only been open for two months) and they comped our bill a bit, so that was nice.  The service was pretty great, actually.

There's a ton of TVs here and a well-stocked bar with loads of beers on tap.  So if that's your thing, it's probably one of the better sports bar/restaurants out there.  For me, if I'm going to waste the kinds of calories that are packed into these dishes, it had better be for something extra special, which this place just isn't.

"Having indulged in a brief morning yoga session, I decided to partake in a midday repast at this establishment, having previously attempted to visit during the initial launch of Union, only to find it inaccessible due to unforeseen circumstances. Today, upon my return, I observed that approximately half of the commercial enterprises within the vicinity were operational, while the remaining half remained closed, which I found rather perplexing. Notwithstanding this anomaly, my impression of TDP was generally favorable, owing to its quaint ambiance, charming outdoor seating area, and modest bar. The staff members were also quite hospitable and accommodating in their demeanor, particularly when assisting us with our culinary preferences. However, I must admit that the fare served was merely satisfactory, and its cost somewhat prohibitive. Specifically, the price of $9 for a Caprese sandwich appeared exorbitant, especially considering the underripe state of the tomato utilized in its preparation. Furthermore, the meatball sandwich seemed to lack an adequate amount of sauce, while the chicken salad sandwich, although visually appealing, struck me as somewhat diminutive and lacking in supplementary elements, such as fruit or a side salad. In light of these observations, I have resolved to limit my future visits to mere appreciation of the ambient aromas, and perhaps acquire a bottle of their high-quality olive oil from the adjacent store."

Jersey Mike's didn't make me weak in the knees but it is clean, efficient and friendly.  The menu is a little difficult to read for a first timer, so the zig zag lane where you order your food made me feel a little rushed. I went at lunch time and it was packed.
The mini sub is what should really be called a regular.  The regular is quite large and the other size is enough for three people.
The club had plenty of meat on it.
It was difficult to tell the difference between the white and wheat sub rolls, but they were not bad.
The most interesting thing was the cups the drinks come in.  There are several different cups with the stories of various Jersey Mike's that have done fund raising for feel good causes. I want to believe this is true because we all like to think we are patronizing do-gooder companies.
It may just be branding, I haven't had a chance to really check it out yet.
I would go back, but I want to try something spicier next time.

Los 7 Compadres has a variety (20) of combination platters for about 7 bucks.  Between my wife and I we had 7 items on our combination platters, which we shared.  7 has been a recurring number for us starting with the OYE at Malee's.  Including the rice and beans, the sour cream and the guacamole this gave us an astounding number of possible combinations for each bite.  

A bite of chicken enchilada.
A bite of chicken enchilada with rice.
A bite of chicken enchilada with beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with guacamole.
A bite of chicken enchilada with sour cream.
A bite of chicken enchilada with rice and beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with guacamole, rice and beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with sour cream, rice and beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with sour cream, rice, beans and guacamole.

Play this out again with the burrito, cheese enchilada, tamale, beef enchilada, bean enchilada, etcetera.  All of the food was good.  Portions were generally large.  I found the tamales to be the least satisfying item.  They were a bit dry and the dominant flavor was just the spice of jalapeno.

Note-even the mild here has a real bite.  Overall I'd give them 3.5 stars.  Good enough for a return trip.

Well, this place is puzzling and I'm not going to save the bad news for last.  They seem to pride themselves on allowing and maybe even promoting smoking.  It's puzzling because the beer selection is extensive.  The menu is above average, as is the food.  Lots of pizzas, sandwiches, appetizers.\n   BUT, who wants to go home smelling like a filthy ashtray?  It would be great if they joined the rest us in the twenty-first century.

"It is with immense exhilaration that I can finally indulge in some delectable V-food in the downtown area of Phoenix. The proliferation of diverse culinary experiences is undoubtedly a boon for the community. Conveniently situated at the intersection of 1st and Adam streets, this establishment offers a unique dining experience, with an open kitchen that allows patrons to observe the culinary process. Upon ordering takeout, I was pleased to discover that all necessary components were included. The promptness of the service was indeed commendable. However, I must admit that my expectations regarding the flavors were not entirely met, as they seemed somewhat less vibrant compared to my usual preferences. Moreover, the prices, while still reasonable, reflected the upscale nature of the restaurant, amounting to approximately 30 dollars for a meal for two, a sum that, although still affordable, surpassed my customary expenditure of 15-20 dollars at other, more unpretentious eateries. Despite this, I shall continue to patronize this establishment when seeking quick and convenient meals or lunches in the downtown area. Nonetheless, my yearning for the genuine and dynamic ambiance of a Vietnamese restaurant will impel me to venture towards the avenues, where established dives proffer a more authentic experience. Of note, I did not have the opportunity to sample their bahn mi, as it was unavailable. Instead, I opted for a standard buhn dice, which, while satisfying, lacked the customary sweetness and abundance of garlic that I have come to expect. The egg rolls were a pleasant surprise, filled with a variety of ingredients rather than mere vegetables. Unfortunately, the spring rolls did not include my preferred option of shrimp. Lastly, the omelette dish presented an acquired taste, one that I shall reserve judgment upon."

"The Chinatown district in Montreal is relatively diminutive in size, yet it remains a consistent and dependable purveyor of delectable, affordable roast pork and duck dishes served over a bed of rice. While their beef pan-fried noodles may not necessarily qualify as a gastronomic masterpiece, their wonton noodle soup and General Tso's chicken offerings are decidedly more palatable, with the latter two dishes garnering sufficient acclaim to warrant repeat orders during our dual visits to this establishment. It is worth noting, however, that the quality of service one receives can vary greatly depending on the linguistic proficiency of their server, with those possessing a greater command of the English language generally providing more satisfactory interactions. Furthermore, while the speed at which the food is delivered may be considered a positive attribute for those with pressing hunger needs, the overall dining experience at this venue does not necessarily constitute a must-see attraction within the city of Montreal. Lastly, it is worth mentioning that their bubble tea offerings, while adequate in satiating a thirst for the beverage, do not particularly excel in terms of taste or quality."

Dropping down to three stars ... On a recent visit, I saw TWO roaches on the main floor of the restaurant. No one seemed to care, so I got up and stepped on one.  I pointed out the other, and one of the staff killed it, but they didn't seem surprised.  I know that roaches are hard to control, but having two of them wandering about in a busy restaurant just isn't a good thing. 

Also, our waiter was an overly chatty guy who seems to think we are interested in his voice.  They had some good staff in the past, but I suspect the owner, who likes to get drunk and hang out on the patio, gives me the impression of a guy who would be difficult to work for! 

The food is still decent and better than anything else I've found, but I'm looking for alternatives ...

"Although the cost of $29.99, augmented by tax to $32.42, proved to be an excessive expenditure for this culinary indulgence, the abundance of offerings, while of commendable quality, did not justify the tariff in comparison to the more luxurious hospitality establishments. My visit transpired at 10:15am on a Saturday, and I availed myself of the complimentary mimosas, consuming two glasses, which were indeed delectable. The array of breakfast and lunch items was substantial, albeit not extensive, and I partook of a moderate quantity of each. Notably, the inclusion of lunch options denoted the presence of brunch. All items were proficiently prepared, yet none truly excelled; however, the overall quality was satisfactory. The buffet, though not of considerable proportions, remained sufficient. Under specific circumstances, such as 1) intoxication, 2) craving AYCE, 3) absence of vehicular transportation, 4) coercion, or 5) inebriation, I might consider a return visit, contingent upon a reduction in price, as the current tariff seemed somewhat exorbitant."

I like Mexican food and I like Chinese food, so why not? Interesting menu. The Jade Red Chicken is as good as any Orange or General Tso's you'll find, and I like that there is a wide variety of choices here. Good food, especially if you like spicy!

I have one beef with this restaurant, and that is the cleanliness. Walking in, you'll notice that the decor and general feel of the place is very low budget. Uncomfortable seating, very weathered ceilings, and generally messy. No big deal. But the restrooms were disgusting, the eating area was dirty, and the trash was overflowing. The place was busy, but there's no excuse for the condition of the men's restroom! It looked like something (or someone) exploded in a truck stop restroom on a state highway. I would have chalked it up to a busy night, but the door and walls were filthy (almost black) with handprints from weeks (if not months) of neglect. All but one of the trash bins were over-stuffed, and most of the tables were dirty. We didn't see anyone cleaning anything. I'm glad I didn't go into the restroom until after I ate!

If it were my business, I would put at least a few dollars toward general maintenance and upkeep. Maybe even invest in a few nicer tables & chairs. If it were close to clean, I'd give at least 4 stars.

Just quickly ran in and grabbed some stuff for dinner. Never been inside of this store until today. It's okay. I don't think the fruits and vegetables are the best but they'll do in a time crunch (because the store is located near the house) but I would prefer Safeway for fruits, vegetables and possibly meats. Prices are average - specials on some things but nothing out there that makes this store stand out.

My first visit was decent, but didn't quite live up to my expectations.

I food just wasn't that good for a steakhouse. Neither my wife and I cared for our appetizer. We got the Fire-Grilled Fresh Artichoke. They say it is a popular choice, but I didn't like it at all. My burger was very plain and lacked good taste. It made me wish I had gone to Five Guys instead. My wife got the steak and thought it was OK, but later she ended up getting sick. She ordered off the gluten-free menu as she has sensitivities, so this place may have issues with cross-contamination.

One positive was our friendly server. Cassie was excellent and we were very pleased because we rarely get good service when we go out. She kept up with refills and offered to replace anything we didn't like. I also wrote about my visit and explained how I didn't like the food. The manager said he would send us a coupon, so I can appreciate that they are reaching out to their customers.

I got good vibes from sitting at the restaurant. I like their tables and seats. I think I will give it a second chance, but the food has to be better if they want to win me over as a customer.

We were the sole patrons present within the establishment during a Sunday afternoon, which I found rather peculiar subsequent to my acquaintance's effusive praise of this venue. Our culinary selections were served with such haste that it would have been impossible for the staff to prepare them via microwaving and plating, leading me to surmise that all dishes were pre-prepared. While the flavors were passable, the chicken contained an excessive amount of osseous material, and the deep-fried pork was so rigid that it nearly caused me to chip my tooth enamel. I pondered whether this manner of preparation was customary among Cuban cuisine enthusiasts.

Parking facilities are situated at the rear of the building. It is imperative that you secure your vehicle and refrain from traversing the surrounding area unaccompanied.

I would consider revisiting the establishment, but I would endeavor to select an item from the menu that they might prepare fresh, without resorting to pre-cooking or reheating. I awarded them three stars due to their hospitable demeanor, proficiency in both English and Spanish, and their success in avoiding the induction of gastrointestinal discomfort.

Is this place closed now, or just \"under renovation\"??\n\nI've been many times for lunch, and have decided that the barbacoa torta is my absolute favorite menu item.  Nothing else on the menu seems very special.  Actually, I tried the breakfast burrito, too....a little disappointed in the proportion of potato to chorizo, especially considering the price and size.

Food was creative, flavored were good. Appetizer portions reasonable for the price and quality. Main courses however is where they fall short. Portions were far too small for the price, about $6-10 more than should be depending on what you order. Bread was a but dry for brioche but a nice light bread to have with the meal. Wine selection is very good and varied. Coming from a food town like Portland, this restaurant is nothing special but is a great addition to the chandler/sun lakes area. I would not return for dinner but would for apps and a glass of wine. They were not very busy for a Friday night either so I suspect many others feel it is overpriced for dinner, too. Would re-evaluate that for longevity.\nNice atmosphere too despite odd strip mall style location.

"A profusion of exceptional cocktails graces this establishment, although certain mixologists excel at their craft more than others. Particularly fond of their mint-infused mojitos. Prices are reasonable, ambiance pleasant, clientele congenial, tunes melodious. Partook in brunch, specifically a lobster omelette. While the dish presented an array of diverse flavors, my fastidious palate found it somewhat overwhelming. However, I surmise that less discerning gastronomes may relish such culinary complexity. Regrettably, the guava mimosa failed to impress."

I am upgrading to a three-star rating due to the exceptional quality of the service; however, there was an approximate one-to-one ratio of servers to guests, which warrants some consideration. Despite my positive experience, this establishment appears to be struggling, and several factors contribute to its lackluster performance. Firstly, the prices are exorbitant, and the meager portions do not justify the cost. For instance, burgers, skewers, sandwiches, and salads are priced around $10, while pizzas range from $10 to $15. Moreover, everything is served a la carte, and the entrees consist of merely three appetizer-sized skewers. The appetizers themselves cost around $10, and desserts are priced at $7, with the option to add ice cream for an additional $1. 

In contrast, the burgers are superior to those offered by the Grind, as they remain intact throughout consumption. The fries, priced at $5, were quite satisfactory, while the pork skewers were unremarkable but adequate. The Dorito potato skins were unimpressive, consisting of a lone wedge of cheesy chip embedded in the middle. The cupcake was palatable, yet the chocolate exhibited a slightly grainy texture. The portion size was also rather diminutive. 

In conclusion, while I may return for happy hour to indulge in their burgers, I am unlikely to visit this establishment again for any other reason.

"It was indeed a culinary revelation nestled within the picturesque confines of Verdun that we had the pleasure of discovering through a personal recommendation, and given our previous exposure to delectable Persian cuisine, a certain level of skepticism was inevitable. Nonetheless, Parisa managed to surpass our expectations with their unique interpretation of traditional Persian flavors.

Their signature house soup, while containing an incongruous element in the form of noodles, proved to be a truly exceptional offering. It was followed by a delightful assortment of sauteed mushrooms, which, despite lacking the anticipated sweetness, still showcased the kitchen's proficiency in executing simple yet elegant dishes.

The main course featured two distinct protein options: tender, juicy lamb that literally fell off the bone, and succulent chicken drumsticks that, while not necessarily memorable, contributed to the overall satisfaction of our dining experience.

The hospitable demeanor of the host and the tranquil ambiance of the establishment further enhanced our enjoyment, making it an ideal venue for a BYOW excursion. In conclusion, a visit to Parisa is highly recommended, particularly for the unmissable soup, a true masterpiece of culinary artistry."

After perusing the menu at this establishment on multiple occasions, I decided to partake in their culinary offerings, primarily due to the copious amount of laudatory reviews I had encountered. Upon consuming my meal, I found the flavors to be quite satisfactory, however, my companion did not share my enthusiasm. It is worth mentioning that this restaurant does not possess an air conditioning system, which resulted in a rather uncomfortable dining experience for me, as I was perspiring profusely throughout my visit.

"Although this establishment may not exude an extravagant ambiance, it nevertheless possesses an acceptable level of quality. Upon arriving with a group of twelve, we had the foresight to reserve a table in advance, thereby avoiding any unnecessary delays. Our server, a consummate professional, exhibited remarkable proficiency in catering to our diverse needs, deftly navigating the numerous requests and preferences expressed by various members of our party. Unfortunately, the culinary offerings did not quite live up to the high standards set by the exceptional service. Specifically, my potatoes were overcooked to an unfortunate degree, while the flavor profile of the sausage deviated somewhat from the expected norm. Additionally, my omelette displayed a peculiar texture that could be described as rubbery. Thus, while the service we received was truly commendable, the food itself fell short of our expectations."

Decent bar, nice patio though it can be loud on E-Wash.  Good place to relax with a nice beer however I was disappointed they did not have more Belgians after being places like Brasserie V.  It would fit well with the decent bars on Willy street, but has the bonus of being porn-shop adjacent.

"The ambiance of this establishment is truly captivating. The interior design exudes an aura of elegance and sophistication, with subtle lighting that creates an atmosphere of refined intimacy. The seating arrangements are ergonomically designed to provide maximum comfort, allowing patrons to unwind and relax in style. The musical selection presented by the disc jockey on the evening in question was diverse and engaging, albeit the volume level was slightly excessive for a venue of this nature, thereby creating a slight hindrance to effective communication between patrons seated at a distance from one another. However, the outdoor seating area provided a tranquil respite from the sonic intensity within, offering ample opportunities for observation and appreciation of the surrounding environment."

I often stop in this place when Im at Tempe Marketplace to get a drink and relax.  They usually have some decent drink specials and they have a nice big bar.  The bartenders usually take a little effort to order from, not really sure why that is, maybe I just have bad luck.

Hmmm I am American and I grew up in the NYC area, so I am fairly confident that I know good Italian food when I taste it.  I am not saying that the food isn't good, but it definitely did not blow me away.  We came here because it was listed as a Top 10 Best Restaurant in Edinburgh, according to The Guardian and I definitely would not rate this in my top 10.

However, with that being said, the service was fantastic.  Our servers were all very friendly and attentive.  The portions here are enormous and we did feel that they mislead us into ordering more food than we needed because we did ask if the starters were big enough to shared and they recommended that we order two.  Both plates were huge and we certainly could have just shared one between the two of us.  Not to mention the entrees were enough for 2-3 people to share.  So come hungry!

Ambiance has a little bit of a corny feel but also reminded me a lot of any Italian spot in suburban New York / New Jersey, in the sense that there was Frank Sinatra playing in the background the entire time and the servers were a little over the top trying to prove their Italian-ness (actual, and not the macho mobster Guido kind we see over here in the States).

"In the previous fortnight, I have visited this establishment on two separate occasions, seeking medical attention for distinct health concerns. Initially, I sustained a fracture of my coccyx (tail bone), owing to my own foolhardy actions. Following a brief waiting period, I received prompt and comprehensive care. Dr. Guy demonstrated proficiency in managing my situation, requesting an immediate radiograph and subsequently discussing my results, available options, and methods of pain relief. One's appreciation for a particular bodily component is often realized only when it becomes injured, leaving one utterly debilitated and experiencing excruciating pain.  

On a separate occasion, I experienced intense, sporadic abdominal pain. Due to its proximity to my residence, I opted to visit this clinic, necessitating urgent medical attention. Presenting with visible signs of distress, including pallor, trembling, and uncontrollable sobbing, I was surprised by the facility's inability to accommodate me due to an excessive patient load. Considering the gravity of my symptoms, it would have been more appropriate for a physician to tend to my needs temporarily, offering some measure of pain alleviation as I awaited transfer to the emergency department.  

Despite the subpar nature of my most recent encounter, I shall continue to seek medical assistance at this location when necessary. However, the aforementioned experience has illuminated the fact that, in extraordinary situations involving a person's health and well-being, this clinic may not be willing to adapt their policies."

I don't hate it. 
I don't love it. 
I'm very blah about it.


Initially wanted to come here after seeing pictures on Instagram. I was super excited as I was hoping for snow like that from Hawaii snow places, like Snow Factory or Frost City.

My friends and I had #3, #4, #5 respectively. I don't like the "popping pearls" in my #5 so, I replaced it with butterfinger.

I'd like to say it was similar in texture being kind of creamy but, they need to improve on their flavors. I got to samps the taro, green tea, and "kuma snow" (whatever flavor that it) and it was whatever......it quenched my thirst in this heat we're having.
I'd like to see more variety ---- I'm thinking of the variety that Snow Ono food/shave ice truck had --- I miss horchata flavor, I guess.

I loved how the decor is all bright and cute. Tryna get the whole Asian-kawaii market. I mean, that's what got me.....very Instagram worthy pics outta here.

Overall, I'll be back. Businesses tend to get better in time ***cross fingers*** 
I wanna bring more people so we can "samps" more things; this way I don't base this review on just 3 flavors.

I have heard of this place, but never made it over until now.  I was there to support a fundraiser for an elementary school.  What can I say, it looks just like the skating rinks I grew up with in the 80's.  Not sure what kind of improvements have been since.  The evening we were in there the A/C must not have been working because it was hot as heck and smelled like a gym locker room.  But the concession stand prices can't be beat, the music was current and fun, and ALL the skaters, of every age group, looked like they were having a blast!  And you can even bring in your OWN roller blades if you prefer the single row of wheels versus the four wheels.  They even knock a $1 or so off your price.  So as long as you are looking for an old school joint, and not a modern updated place, check it out!

"An establishment that offered a satisfactory ambiance, with a culinary experience that met our expectations. Upon entering, we were greeted by an atmosphere that exuded cleanliness and warmth. Our meal began with the clear egg rolls accompanied by a delectable peanut sauce, a staple dish that we often indulge in when partaking in Vietnamese cuisine. The flavors were adequately represented, without surpassing our expectations. Subsequently, we opted for the combo pho soup, which presented generous proportions and a commendable execution. Although the broth lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, it was reminiscent of fish sauce, mint, and other indispensable components. One might argue that the soup catered to American palates, with a subtle spiciness that left room for personal adjustments. However, for those seeking a more genuine experience, a more robust foundation would be necessary. The menu, though limited, helped avoid the paradox of choice, but we couldn't help but feel that certain Vietnamese delicacies were absent. The staff provided friendly and efficient service, contributing to an overall positive experience. We may consider revisiting this establishment in the future, curious to witness its evolution."

We organized a farewell celebration for a departing colleague at this establishment, and I must admit that the service we received was quite satisfactory, particularly considering the size of our group, which consisted of 16 individuals and one minor. The avocado-based dip, commonly known as guacamole, was quite palatable, and I was particularly fond of the spicy salsa that they offer upon request. However, the fruit-based alcoholic beverage known as sangria was excessively sweetened, although the house margarita served on the rocks was somewhat more agreeable. The culinary offerings were rather unremarkable; I consumed some uninspired chicken enchiladas that, while not necessarily unpalatable, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi. Nonetheless, my most enjoyable experience of the evening was visiting the Trader Joe's store located within the same retail complex after our meal.

The view is amazing for 360 degrees... The ambiance is quite chill and the DJ on Friday night is decent. Mostly top 40 and EDM infused mixes playing through the speakers. 

The late happy hour is only for food and the reason this place gets a couple of stars knocked out of the sky is because of the service and the food that is served. The buns on the sliders were hard enough to break a window on impact and the calamari was soggy (probably microwaved for happy hour). It also took forever for the waitress to make her way around to us. I could have taken the stairs to level 0, walk to the liquor store and walk back up the stairs to Level 107 before she came back with our order. 

This place has a lot of potential, it just needs a facelift in a few places. The view is main reason this gets 3 stars.

The people here are super friendly and nice. Yhe reason I gave only three stars is one their liquid flavors was missing somethin.  I think if they remixed a few  flavors it would be a little better. And the second reason is that their liquid is pricey. Like 21 bucks for one bottle.

Heard A LOT of good things about this place but somehow I don't seem what all the good rants about this place where. I came with high expectations due to the fact that friends and colleagues have fervently extolled its virtues, yet ultimately, it failed to meet my elevated standards in Las Vegas. We arrived at approximately 1 pm, thereby falling within the parameters of brunch time. The menu primarily consisted of breakfast fare, complemented by a smattering of salads and other lunch options. However, what truly piqued my interest was their delectable chicken wings, savory saian chow mein, and crispy fried rice, the rich alfredo pasta, and the flavorful calamari skewer. Unfortunately, everything else paled in comparison to my gastronomic inclinations. As a self-proclaimed dessert aficionado, I eagerly indulged in the dessert bar, but found only a select few offerings aesthetically pleasing and gustatorily satisfying. The chocolate-dipped strawberries, creamy cheesecake, and velvety Thai ice cream were my standout favorites from the entire assortment! THE THAI TEA ICE CREAM IS THE ONLY REASON WHY I GAVE THEM AN EXTRA STAR! It is an absolute must-try for all my fellow Thai tea enthusiasts out there! In conclusion, a run-of-the-mill buffet for roughly $30 per person, with a merely passable culinary experience, redeemed only by the exceptional Thai tea ice cream.
= = = = = =  CLOSED  = = = = = =\n\nSorry to see Him's JL close.  I liked the place.     :-(

"A pleasant and hygienic smorgasbord, proffering an abundance of accommodations for patrons. Although I did not object to the tariff of thirteen dollars per individual, my satisfaction was somewhat diminished upon discovering that an extensive array of porcine delicacies constituted a significant portion of the offerings. As I am not particularly enamored with swinish cuisine, I might opt to expend my resources elsewhere in the future, perhaps at Buffet@asia, where a greater diversity of options, including an increased emphasis on seafood and Mongolian barbecue, is available."

My wife and I were roaming the industrial and business park area of Phoenix looking for a decent bite to eat, preferably Mexican food. We finally stumbled upon a set of about five Mexican eateries. We decided on Salsitas, which seems to be a chain in the Valley of The Sun.

I wished that the woman had done a better job of speaking and understanding English. The food order was correct, and plentiful, not to mention cheap, but we had specifically asked for forks and were not given any. I had to go to our hotel's front deck and beg the clerk for a couple of plastic forks. 

The burrito was huge and very tasty. I had a couple of Grilled Chicken mini-tacos, and while they were pretty good, they were nothing special and I even found a few pieces of gristle. My wife had a chicken burrito and said it was huge and very good. She could not finish it. They also gave us some hot carrots so that scored well with her.

Ten bucks for all of that, including four salsas and sour cream. Not bad, but I'd like to try more.

It is an acceptable venue, albeit one that I would not have chosen to visit had we not been extended an invitation accompanied by a reserved table. The diminutive size of the establishment, while potentially charming, was unfortunately exacerbated by the presence of a substantial number of patrons, creating an atmosphere akin to that of a crowded subway car in China or New York City. Notwithstanding the cramped conditions, I must admit that the personal hygiene of the clientele was satisfactory, in contrast to the malodorous ambiance often associated with public transportation in urban centers. A plethora of ostensibly synthetic, juvenile females were conspicuously present, rendering the environment somewhat unsettling for a solitary, relatively youthful individual such as myself (being merely 27 years of age). 
  The beverages served at this establishment are quite costly; I opted to procure three shots for our group, as I felt no compulsion to emulate the behavior of certain metrosexual individuals who insist on purchasing drinks for others. Furthermore, I am financially capable of treating myself. However, upon perusing the bill, I was taken aback by the exorbitant price of $36 for a mere three shots. In light of this, I felt compelled to remark on the receipt that "I ain't no rich bitch," and I apologize for any offense caused to the bartender. Nonetheless, considering the steep prices, I believe it is essential to either consume alcoholic beverages liberally before arriving or to accompany someone possessing a platinum credit card, lest one wishes to incur financial hardship. Despite the extravagant costs, the experience remains moderately enjoyable.

This is your perfect place to bring someone after going out.
Instead of going to macdonald or some fast food joint this place is cheaper,healthier and quicker than any fast food store.
Plus you can grab something for breakfast the next day.
No matter what time i go i always see people baking fresh bagel.
I'm more of a conservative guy so i usually take sesame bagel or butter bagel.
Hope this help,

Cheers,

Eric Van Nguyen

As Demetria so astutely observed, this establishment tends to be somewhat inconsistent in the quality of its offerings, with a tendency towards both excellence and disappointment. For optimal culinary experiences, it is advisable to arrive promptly, as the most delectable items often disappear rapidly. The fried chicken, when cooked to perfection, is undoubtedly a highlight, although it occasionally suffers from overcooking or dryness. The six-cheese spaghetti is also a commendable option, but its quality can vary depending on the preparation method. The abundance of sides offers numerous choices, including mac-n-cheese, which, much like the aforementioned chicken and spaghetti, may occasionally be overcooked, resulting in a less than satisfactory dining experience. However, the blackeyed peas and cornbread consistently impress, and their lemonade, arguably the finest in Charlotte, has garnered high praise. A word of caution regarding the volunteers who handle beverage refills: they are renowned for their warmth and generosity, and a adept diner may even secure an additional portion of mac-n-cheese through skillful banter. It is essential to display gratitude via a gratuity at the register. Fare thee well, my friend.

"Cautionary statement: This evaluation is predominantly grounded on the parameters of service and informational proficiency, rather than culinary offerings. We visited this establishment during happy hour and, while intending to confer four stars, a deduction of one star was necessitated due to the absence of communication regarding seating arrangements for said happy hour. Specifically, we were not apprised of the fact that happy hour seating was exclusive to the bar and adjacent bench. Furthermore, our ignorance was not alleviated by inquiring about the protocol, as we were informed to occupy any vacant seat of our preference. Notably, by the time of our departure, a sole couple remained, and they too were oblivious to the proper seating arrangement, thereby resulting in their failure to capitalize on the discounted prices.  

Our culinary experience was satisfactory, albeit not exceptional, with a few notable exceptions. The red sangria was unremarkable, while the lamb, though flavorsome, was diminutive and overpriced. The croquettes were uninspired, whereas the Patatas Bravas, essentially roasted potatoes enrobed in a tomato-based sauce, was straightforward yet gratifying. The total cost of our repast, excluding gratuity, approximated $60, with an additional $20 expended unnecessarily due to our unawareness of the happy hour stipulations. A comprehensive examination of the menu revealed that several items we ordered were available at a reduced rate had we been seated at the bar."

This interior setting exudes an aesthetic appeal that is quintessentially modern, and I must say, I was thoroughly entertained by the metamorphosis that the proprietors undertook to transform this architectural gem into a space that can accommodate a diverse array of patrons. 
  My experience at the alternative venue was somewhat diminished by the presence of a rowdy clientele, but I must admit that the ambiance was quite captivating. Notwithstanding the challenges posed by the limited parking options, the valet service was quite efficient. 
  Upon arriving at the establishment on a Friday afternoon, I was eager to commemorate a friend's birthday. We indulged in several appetizers, specifically The Trifecta, Double Down, and Crabmeat and Artichoke Dip, which were delectable, to say the least. Our server was attentive, ensuring that our needs were met and even keeping us informed about the happy hour specials. 
  As the clock approached 5 pm, the atmosphere within the establishment became increasingly lively, with a large contingent of middle-aged gentlemen converging upon the premises, fresh from a golf outing. Despite the influx of patrons, the ambiance remained laid-back and welcoming, with a healthy mix of mature and youthful clientele. 
  The abundance of televisions scattered throughout the venue ensured that there was always something engaging to observe. Although the enclosed patio area was slightly more boisterous, our group was vociferous regardless, and there was ample space to move around without feeling confined or inconveniencing fellow patrons. Thus far, I have had the pleasure of partaking in a single happy hour visit; however, I eagerly anticipate experiencing the culinary delights offered during dinner hours.
