I would assign The Green Owl a rating of 4 to 5 stars in relation to the culinary aspect of their offerings, but regrettably, their service falls short, leading to a decrease in their overall evaluation. In conjunction with my romantic partner, I had the pleasure of dining at this establishment last week. Following our seating, it required some time to hail the attention of our server, thus impeding our ability to place our order in a timely manner. We opted to share an order of crabby cakes, while my companion selected a bowl of chili complemented by sour cream and cornbread, and I chose the "meatball" sub, accompanied by kale chips as a side dish. The crabby cakes were served promptly, enveloped in a delectable creamy sauce, which we devoured instantaneously. Noteworthily, my companion, who habitually consumes meat and eschews tofu, relished these dishes. Our server informed us that our main courses would arrive shortly after presenting the crabby cakes. However, our food did not materialize for an additional 40 minutes, during which our server failed to provide any updates or explanations for the delay. Despite this setback, the quality of the food remained impressive. My sandwich was delivered scorching hot, with a crunchy bread roll and flavorful eggplant meatballs that maintained their texture within the sandwich. Unfortunately, the price point of $6 for an average-sized portion proved too prohibitive for me to indulge in a dessert. Notwithstanding the deficiencies in service, I harbor the intention of revisiting the Green Owl, as my curiosity lingers regarding numerous menu items that pique my interest.

the food was alright but definitely cost more than it should.  we went for a quick lunch and the service was alright too but the food was not up to par with your typical vegas food.  btw don't get the kim chee, not good.

"I patronized this establishment due to the overcrowding at Oregano's on a Saturday evening. It begs the question of how many patrons share a similar predicament. My initial yearning for Mexican cuisine rendered me indifferent to the alternative dining option. 

The hospitality was exceptional, the brew was nearly frozen (a desirable attribute), and the salsa was delectable. I opted for the signature chimichanga, while my maternal figure selected rolled tacos. The portions were considerable, bordering on excessive. Moreover, I must emphasize that cream cheese enhances the flavor of chimichangas, rendering them even more scrumptious. YUM. 

While not the most exceptional Mexican restaurant I have had the pleasure of experiencing, the quality of the fare and the welcoming ambiance justify future visits for local patrons."

I attended an evening dedicated to the hip-hop genre, but unfortunately, the DJ's playlist did not align with my expectations, as the majority of the tracks he played did not belong to the hip-hop category. Despite this disappointment, I managed to have an enjoyable experience, owing to the lively atmosphere and the opportunity to socialize with other attendees.

This sushi restaurant boasts an impressive array of fresh fish selections, which, coupled with its reasonable pricing, makes it the optimal choice for sushi enthusiasts within the valley. However, it is imperative to note that the service at this establishment tends to be subpar, with prolonged waiting periods being a recurring issue. Patrons should also be prepared for a leisurely dining experience, as the duration between ordering and receiving their food can be quite lengthy. On one occasion, a request for an itemized check resulted in a 25-minute delay, and even then, the check provided was incomplete. Notwithstanding the exceptional quality of their sushi, frequent instances of rudeness and neglect by the waitstaff may make it advisable for regular patrons to seek alternative sushi options. Nevertheless, the restaurant's happy hour prices, available Sunday through Thursday, offer an attractive incentive for those willing to tolerate the aforementioned deficiencies in service.

"A satisfactory retail establishment with accommodating personnel, albeit at slightly elevated price points compared to alternative stores. A staff member suggested an appropriate collar for our canine companion, which effectively addressed its tendency to pull on the leash. The atmosphere is welcoming, and the extensive array of products catering to diverse animal needs is impressive. Although the pricing may be perceived as marginally steep, it remains reasonable. However, it is advisable to avoid engaging with Banfield, as their services are associated with costly and unnecessary treatments, according to the experiences of my aunt and ourselves. Their aggressive sales tactics and pressure to procure additional services beyond what is necessary or desired are concerning. Canceling their plans requires persistence, and the purported savings often include substantial costs for services that many individuals would not typically purchase. Instead, consider visiting this store for your pet's exercise needs during the summer months, acquiring food, litter, and other essentials while keeping an eye out for discounted prices. Additionally, you may wish to support the partnered pet rescue organization or treat your pet to a special item."

"-Note* Evaluation pertains solely to gaming/retail/aquatic facilities. Neither extreme fondness nor animosity is harbored towards this establishment. 

Retail: A newly refurbished shopping area has been unveiled, presenting an inviting ambiance and pristine appearance. An exclusive interest in entering the Urban Outfitters store is evident. 
Aquatic: The wave pool embodies a remarkable attraction, boasting a unique blend of sand and surf. A thoroughly enjoyable experience is ensured, further complemented by an optimal number of patrons. 
Gaming: A predictable atmosphere prevails, mirroring that of its Las Vegas counterparts. Appreciation is expressed toward the tasteful installation of chandeliers above, enhancing the overall ambiance. 

Conclusion: A well-maintained casino, with an adequate level of cleanliness, is presented. A neutral sentiment is harbored towards this venue, neither favoring nor avoiding visits. Numerous exceptional dining options are offered, complemented by the presence of the House of Blues. Suitable for families, this resort grants access to the Shark Reef aquarium within its premises."

Nice place to take the parents in Vegas... good food, although a bit on the pricey side. Then again, Vegas isn't the place to start scrimping on pennies. The menu had an interesting variety of selections, but the food didn't taste outstandingly exotic. Just your basic American breakfast with a twist here or there. Service was solid and we were seated fairly quickly (although I noticed a growing line right around the peak time for brunch).

"While the interior may benefit from some modernization, the culinary offerings are undeniably satisfactory. However, I find it somewhat problematic to be charged for supplementary hash browns and an English muffin, particularly when the portion size has diminished, resulting in a higher cost for a relatively reduced quantity of sustenance. Notwithstanding, US Egg remains a reliable establishment, albeit one that may not necessarily warrant being showcased to others as a prime dining destination."

The Chilenita they have the best empanada in town. It's a great place to take out or sit down for lunch. The staff is friendly. The food is so good. The price is affordable. There no other place that has 13 different empanada's to choose from. I love the Chilenita.

Food is average with sandwiches being $8-$10.  Had a burger with Pork Barbecue on it and onion straws and an iced tea for about $14.  Little pricey at lunch.  Surprised there was only 1 bartender/waitress for the whole bar area, but she did a good job managing it.  There were probably 20 people at the bar.  The restaurant has a bunch of TV's on sports or trivia.  The restaurant was crowded which is probably due to its location in the USX building.

We visited Red Lobster for lunch at approximately 2:00 PM, and although the establishment was moderately occupied, we were promptly accommodated with a table.  All three of us opted for the Endless Shrimp promotion, which offered an assortment of diverse flavors.  While the dishes were undoubtedly palatable, they failed to elicit any extraordinary praise or excitement.  The service, though not characterized by excessive haste, did not hinder our dining experience.  The staff members exhibited unwavering politeness and cordiality throughout our visit.  At a cost of $57.00 for three lunch specials, the total surpassed my customary expenditure in a locality renowned for its affordable cuisine.  Nonetheless, the charge was not entirely unexpected given the restaurant's reputation for quality seafood.  Ultimately, our dining experience merited a rating of "A-OK," denoting a satisfactory and enjoyable meal.

It could have all 5 stars if the service was better... Food is very good most of the times, but yesterday my pork kebob had way to many bones! They made me wait for my drink and then for my sauce, so if you like your food without soda and ketchup go for this place:))
The locations in phoenix have chicken we can add to our meal. This location does not. We drove an extra 10 minutes to get here  to find out they don't have chicken was not a pleasant surprise.

"Culinary delights are palatable, yet the quality of service is subpar. We have had the misfortune of dining at this establishment on two separate occasions, and both experiences have been marred by errors in our orders. Specifically, our meals were prepared incorrectly, and upon our second visit, we did not receive a suitable apology or any semblance of empathy from the waitstaff. It appears that the team is more reactive than proactive in addressing patrons' concerns. While the food is passable, it does not justify the exorbitant prices charged. Unfortunately, my initial enthusiasm for this restaurant has been significantly diminished due to the aforementioned factors, compelling me to seek alternative dining options."

"Culinary experiences at this establishment are distinctive and flavorsome, particularly the supreme grilled cheese sandwich. However, the quality of service is subpar, as evidenced by the lackadaisical demeanor of the staff, who appear to be preoccupied with personal conversations rather than attending to the needs of the sparse clientele. Despite the satisfying culinary outcome, the overall dining experience is marred by the perception that the staff seemingly lacks vigilance and dedication to providing an optimal customer experience. Furthermore, it appears that management has made some questionable decisions regarding operational hours, which may potentially impact the longevity of the business. Nonetheless, the pricing strategy for pool play during promotional periods remains attractive."

"The conjugal partner of my closest acquaintance arrived for a sojourn from Austin, possessing an academic background in architectural design, which rendered this location an obligatory destination for our excursion. The experience of being present at this site was undoubtedly remarkable... However, I must express my indignation regarding the exorbitant cost associated with participating in a guided tour, which fell within the price range of $30 to $80, a truly preposterous expense. Consequently, we opted to circumvent the tour and instead explored the peripheral areas of the estate, including the gift shop, which we found satisfying, yet tinged with regret due to our inability to partake in the comprehensive tour."

This is one of our favorite stops for a quick bite, particularly if we have Aria resort credit that we need to spend. I used to only get the baked goods and some chocolates to go for friends and family back home (I like the bear claw in particular), but I recently tried the crepes which I really like. We had a savory one with ham, cheese, and sauteed mushrooms that was great. It also came with a side of greens and baby tomatoes. Our favorite dessert crepe is the one that has the vanilla custard cream on the inside with the mixed berry sauce drizzled on top. The lines are always busy whenever I go but they do a good job moving the customers through quickly. It's definitely pricey though!

"It is rather perplexing to comprehend the rationale behind the perpetual thronging of this establishment, although, upon further examination, it becomes apparent that the sonic infrastructure present within these walls is, indeed, of superior quality compared to other venues of a similar nature. Thus, it can be inferred that the aforementioned attribute serves as a significant factor in attracting an abundance of patrons. However, the process of navigating through the crowd to reach the billiard tables is arduous, to say the least, and necessitates a considerable amount of patience and tenacity. Upon successfully arriving at the aforementioned tables, one can revel in the spaciousness afforded by their proximity to the entrance, thereby providing a modicum of respite from the overwhelming crush of humanity. Although the quantity of tables available for utilization is satisfactory, a more thorough exploration of the premises is required to formulate a definitive assessment of this facility's overall merits. Therefore, I shall endeavor to revisit this location at a future date to conduct a more comprehensive evaluation."
Very colorful, especially if you want to smoke weed surrounded by a bunch of weirdos playing African drums...other than that it is rather boring

After perusing an array of favorable critiques, my spouse and I elected to partake in a culinary excursion to this establishment, primarily due to her inclination towards consumng Indian cuisine.  This eatery does not boast an extensive capacity, and its format is predicated upon a buffet-style service.  The Mother's Day special included a delectable mango lassi and a dolsa, which consists of a rolled-up pancake containing a lentil filling. 
  The chilled bar presented an assortment of various chutneys, a salad, some fruit, and additional sauces.  Additionally, there were three distinct types of soup available: a tomato soup with a tangy flavor profile, a lentil-based soup, and a piquant soup. 
  This restaurant showcases a diverse array of traditional Indian dishes.  The goat curry particularly stood out to my taste buds, as the meat was tender and easily detached from the bone, complemented by a richly flavored curry sauce.  Furthermore, the tandoori chicken was cooked to perfection, retaining its natural moisture and avoiding the common pitfall of dryness often associated with this dish at other establishments.  The paneer sag (a spinach and cheese dish) also demonstrated notable quality. 
  Although vegetarian options were present, my carnivorous inclinations led me to ignore them.  Ultimately, this dining experience provided me with a satisfying introduction to Indian cuisine without overwhelming my palate with excessively spicy fare, thereby solidifying this restaurant's standing as a respectable venue in my opinion.

"It is utterly perplexing to comprehend the grounds upon which numerous individuals base their expectations when patronizing establishments serving rapid culinary fare, as the quality of the consumables and the demeanor of the personnel are often subjective and variable factors; however, in this particular instance, my associates and I opted to sample the wares of this eatery, utilizing a promotional coupon to facilitate our indulgence in an array of menu items. Upon entering the premises, we encountered a hospitable staff who exhibited great alacrity in providing us with an assortment of comestibles, including the signature beverages and sundry accompaniments. Our gastronomical excursion proved to be a gratifying experience, as the lactose-based drinks were indeed remarkable, and my companions expressed unanimous approbation for the savory patties comprised of bovine flesh. Furthermore, we discovered that the cylindrical tubers, although ostensibly the most sought-after item, were surpassed in palatability by the slender, crispy fries."

UltraStar is new to the Phoenix area. It has a spacious lobby with all the warmth of a airplane hanger. Its corporate vibe is immediately apparent in every aspect of the consumer experience. One can almost sense the calculated, committee-approved decision making that dominates the theatre. \nThe concession stand and gourmet coffee bar must seem amusing to Europeans. The seating area has little ambiance and is certainly not a place I'd spend any time hanging out. Boring.\nThe theatre I viewed the film in was serviceable, but nothing outstanding comes to mind. The film started on time. The UltraStar management really would benefit from a visit to a Harkins theatre to get this whole thing 'figured out.'

Decent food and the usual waitresses are busy but attentive.  The salads are good but be warned they usually take just as long, if not longer, than other food to come out to your table.  Chicken strips are good and I hear the wraps are excellent.

Other than that everything else is good but not great.  The potato soup is very good but don't order it too often as it is the soup-of-the-day about 90% of the time.

A decent option when you are tired of to-go food in the downtown area or want something besides a sandwich.

While the restaurant itself was nice and the staff was also very nice the food was nothing that I can say was truly amazing. We were expecting a very 5 star experience when it came to the food and we were surprised when the food came out just a few minutes after we ordered. Most everyone in our party thought the food was average, nothing to right home about. We have a restaurant near us called Frida Mexican Restaurant in Glendale,CA and there food is much much better. On the bright side I did order the Nachos and this seem to be the hit on the table So much so that everyone started munching away at my food \n\nSo heres the deal for me, I am always looking for amazing Mexican Food, something above and beyond what I can expect living in Los Angeles. Diego was not it for me, Great looking place, Friendly Staff, with So-So Food.

"Commencing with an expression of my profound affection for the culinary offerings and flavor combinations presented at Layers, I must say that my enthusiasm for this establishment has been unwavering since its inception. Organic produce, an aspect that earns my utmost approbation, serves as an indubitable testament to the restaurant's commitment to quality. Notwithstanding, my recent experiences have been somewhat disconcerting, prompting me to confer a rating of three stars, down from the perfect five stars I had previously assigned. While the baked items maintain their exceptional quality, the kitchen fare has, regrettably, fallen short of my expectations during my last few visits. Specifically, the pasta dish I ordered was marred by an excessive amount of oil, rendering it unpalatable. Moreover, my most recent visit saw the meatloaf sandwich, dubbed 'The Conservative,' arrive in a state of disarray, with the bread being unacceptably soggy and fragmented, compelling me to consume it with utensils rather than enjoying the customary convenience of a handheld sandwich. A prior experience with a comparable sandwich, when the restaurant first opened, yielded a more satisfactory outcome, leading me to surmise that either a change in bread or a disparity in culinary expertise might be responsible for the decline in quality. In conclusion, although I would not advise against ordering any item from the menu, I sincerely hope that Layers will strive to restore their former excellence, as they remain one of my preferred dining establishments."

Make sure they know if u r in a hurry.  Was disappointed bc I called ahead and gave very specific directions (Please make sure the 3 dozen bialy's are in plastic bags bc I need to pack them in my suitcase.  Unfortunately, they were not and I had to make the taxi wait...  costing me more money.  UGH!  In the long run, it ended up costing $72 for 39 bialys (including taxi)

Been here twice... the selection seemed about the same... but not so sure. 
It's like walking into an aunt's house. The workers there are friendly, speak Tagalog to you right off the bat, even if you don't speak it (good or bad? Hmmm) and make sure you're ok for the most part.
I like the pork gisantes they have, and the pancit is pretty tasty! At $7.99/ person there's not much to complain about. They also sell other goodies and snacks at the register.
Probably will be back with the fam soon.

Honorable mentions:
Pusit
Diniguan (dinardaraan)

Ohh, parking is somewhat odd. One way only, so make sure you take the correct entrance! Although the lot is small, I usually find parking right away!

"Upon perusing Yelp in pursuit of a novel culinary experience, I chanced upon this establishment and decided to pay it a visit. Upon entering, I was struck by the diverse array of fresh, authentic Poke available, which exceeded my expectations and piqued my interest. Furthermore, I appreciated the opportunity to sample the various options prior to making a purchase, which allowed me to make an informed decision. Eventually, I opted for the spicy avocado ahi, which proved to be a satisfying choice, boasting a subtle yet palpable level of spiciness that complemented the dish without overpowering it. Indeed, this meal served as the sole sustenance for my midday repast, and I must say that I was thoroughly pleased with my decision to patronize this unassuming eatery. Despite its unpretentious appearance, this venue offers a truly delightful Poke experience that is not to be missed."

After an afternoon of recreation at the nearby park, I returned home feeling famished and disinclined towards consuming the customary cuisine offered on East Boulevard; thus, I opted to venture forth to Thai Taste, a local eatery renowned for its authentic Thai culinary delights. Upon entering the establishment, I was immediately struck by the traditional Thai decor that permeated the interior space, fostering a warm and welcoming ambiance that, albeit quaint, did not feel overly cramped or congested, even during a presumably off-peak dining period. 
  The menu presented itself in a straightforward fashion, allowing patrons to select their preferred entrÃ©e and combine it with a choice of meat, thereby tailoring their dining experience according to individual preferences. In my case, I opted for the green curry, which, when prepared with chicken, promised to deliver a flavor profile characterized by a harmonious balance between the pungency of fresh green chilies and the richness of coconut milk. Unfortunately, the execution of this particular dish fell short of my expectations, as the green curry, while boasting an undeniably aromatic quality, lacked the requisite level of piquancy typically associated with such a preparation. However, in light of favorable reviews pertaining to the establishment's culinary offerings, I am inclined to attribute this shortcoming to a momentary lapse in the kitchen and intend to revisit Thai Taste in the near future, during which time I shall insist upon an extra-hot rendition of the green curry, thereby affording me the opportunity to sample the dish in its optimal form. 
  The prices charged by Thai Taste are eminently reasonable, and the attentive nature of the service afforded me a constant supply of replenished water, a considerate touch that did not go unappreciated. In a timely fashion, my meal arrived, and I relished every bite, ultimately departing the premises satiated and content. Based on my positive experience, I would unhesitatingly recommend Thai Taste to aficionados of Thai cuisine seeking a satisfying dining experience in Charlotte, and, indeed, I look forward to returning in order to sample their Pad Thai, in addition to a more fiery green curry.

"While it may appear unremarkable at first glance, a closer inspection of The House of Blues reveals a multifaceted venue that offers an immersive experience for music enthusiasts. Although primarily characterized by a predominantly standing-room layout, astute patrons can opt for the indulgence of bottle service or, alternatively, ascend to the balcony to enjoy a more exclusive vantage point. Sonically, the establishment boasts an impressive auditory infrastructure that effectively showcases the performances of both emerging and established artists, thereby ensuring an aural satisfaction that precludes any potential grievances."

Normally I wouldn't bother to write a review for a Pizza Hut. Or even check in on Yelp. Some secrets are best kept in the family. It's Pizza Hut after all. Everyone knows what they're going to get. 

So what's the motivation this time? I noticed some really bad recent reviews for the carry out location I occasionally use. The workers there, however, are consistently nice and really seem to be trying to do a good job given the limitations that Pizza Hut presents. I just wanted to give them a little "thumbs up". 

Three stars, the maximum rating allowed by law for a Pizza Hut.

I've used this restaurant for large dinner parties that were held in their private dining room and they have all been A+ experiences.   This time I made a reservation for 2 in the dining room for a happy birthday dinner.  The restaurant was full and busy and we were seated upon arrival.  Our drink orders were taken promptly but then we waited....

Our waitress took our salad and entree orders and the salad arrived pretty quickly.  She was also assigned to a 10 top table that the chef/owner was hosting so we were ignored by her for the rest of dinner.  We had to flag down the bus person for water refills, asked for additional bread while we waited for our entrees, another request for water refills and a final request for the check.  

The food was okay - I had angel hair with tomato sauce and husband had gnocchi.  Both were good portions and served steaming hot.

"Initially, the aromatic ensemble manifests its presence with an artful blend of cloves, badian, coriander seeds, and cardamom, proffering diverse variations on the same theme. The Classics are characterized by their impersonal nature, boasting cleaner cuts of meat and immaculate presentation. In contrast, the Adventurers showcase a less polished bovine anatomy, featuring succulent flanks and crunchy tripe. If the absence of aseptic conditions bothers you, it may be wise to refrain from partaking in this culinary experience. I deduct a star for this reason."
Pasta was good. wine was good. but I cant trust an ITALIAN restaurant that puts Herseys syrup on their tiramisu. Sorry.

I was impelled to visit this establishment due to the fact that I was the fortunate recipient of a complimentary voucher, courtesy of a radio station contest, and I must admit that I would not have opted to partake in this culinary experience had it not been offered gratis.

Upon perusing the menu, I noticed that there was a sampler entrÃ©e/mix grill option available for a mere $70, which included an assortment of delectable cuts, specifically filet, kobe shirt, and a New York cut. Although the Kobe shirt was undoubtedly palatable, it is worth mentioning that I have yet to encounter a less-than-satisfactory cut of Kobe beef, thus rendering its quality somewhat predictable.

Furthermore, I opted to sample their trio of mashed potatoes, which featured an array of distinct flavors, including the tantalizing truffle and lobster variety. While these potatoes were indeed quite delectable, I cannot help but feel that they fell short of exceptional.

In conclusion, taking into account the multitude of superior dining options available, I fear that I would not consider returning to this particular restaurant, despite the occasional availability of complimentary vouchers.

"Capriotti's captivating culinary creations have captured my gastronomical inclinations, albeit at an exorbitant expense. Lamentably, their menu lacks the healthier whole wheat bread option, rendering them somewhat antiquated in comparison to their competitors, such as Firehouse Subs, Subway, Port of Subs, Quiznos, et cetera. It is my fervent hope that Capriotti's will remedy this oversight by introducing whole wheat French bread to their offerings, thereby elevating both their nutritional value and contemporary appeal."

MTD is a great way to get to class when the weather is nasty.  However, the buses are often late, so be sure to choose a bus that arrives to your destination a few minutes early.  At least the MTD buses are free to students.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."  We have visited this establishment on multiple occasions, and unfortunately, our expectations have not been met.  

The appetizer platter was mediocre, with the mozzarella being the sole redeeming factor.  The bruschetta was overpowered by an excessive amount of pesto, rendering the flavor of the bread insignificant, while the calamari lacked the desired crispiness.  The chicken marsala was unimpressive, with the grilled taste overshadowing the marsala sauce.  The mashed potatoes were satisfactory, but they failed to compensate for the shortcomings of the dish.   It is evident that our preference for pasta at Carrabba's remains unwavering.  

The quality of service, however, has consistently met our expectations.

"WU DINNAE NEED THEM INGLISH! WU CUN LOOK EFTER WURSEL BUCOZ  WUR A NATION!!!!"

"FFFFRRREEEEEDDDOOOOOOMMMMMMM!!!!!!!!!!!!"

The cultural cringe is alive and well.

We opted to patronize Einstein for our morning repast, despite the considerable queue that had formed outside, stretching beyond the entrance and into the street, owing to the popularity of this establishment among the local denizens. It being just shy of 9 am on a tranquil Sunday morning, we pondered the feasibility of seeking sustenance elsewhere, but ultimately elected to endure the delay, which, much to our relief, proved to be relatively brief. Following a mere thirteen minute interval, during which we placed our order and tendered payment, we were able to secure a table in the spacious dining area, whereupon our culinary selections were promptly prepared and presented to us, requiring but a scant four additional minutes of waiting. My personal preference was for the flavorful applewood bacon and cheddar cheese-adorned egg sandwich, served upon a plain bagel, which, while perhaps a tad overpriced in relation to its constituent elements, was nonetheless thoroughly enjoyable and satisfying.

I attended a gathering at this establishment, whereupon our group consisted of approximately twenty individuals, thereby enabling me to sample an array of culinary offerings. While some selections proved to be delectable, others unfortunately did not meet my expectations. However, I must commend them for offering an assortment of European beverages, which undoubtedly contributed to the ambiance. Unfortunately, the arrival of our repast was delayed significantly, despite our reservation being made well in advance. It appeared that the family-operated enterprise was unprepared to accommodate such a sizable assembly. Nonetheless, it is gratifying to note that our patronage supported a local family business, as the proprietors, including both parents and their offspring, were actively involved in the culinary and hospitality aspects of the operation.

First time coming here today and it's a great place if you want something to satisfy your boba craving without having to drive to Chinatown. I got the boba milk tea with jelly which tasted very similar to volcano tea so I was happy with it, my bf got the taro smoothie which he said wasn't good at all. So I guess it really just depends on what you get and I had to dock off points because there isn't much of a selection as other stores and the atmosphere. Inside of the store is small, plain, and very boring. Kinda makes you feel like ordering and getting out, not a place to hang or relax. Wish they also sold snacks.

I was very excited about playing golf here since its firmly entrenched in one of the more exclusive housing areas in Summerlin called The Ridges.  I was here for a fundraiser so we played shotgun.  

The golf course is billed as Jack Nicklaus' best holes in one round.  I can definitely see the potential but this time around, I don't think the potential was actualized.  Granted it was over 100 degrees but the course was very dry and the greens spotty.  It was definitely punched recently but wasn't healing as well as it should.

Checked out the club house to see if there's anything to purchase but the guy working at the counter looked right at me then looked away.  I do not expect to be pampered but a hello would be nice.  Needless to say, I didn't buy anything.

Again, every hole has the potential to be phenomenal with great views of all the beautiful homes as well as views of he strip on a couple of holes.  Unfortunately, I think I caught it during a bad stretch.  I will be back and re-review if I find the experience to be different.

Salads are delicious there jumbo shrimps go perfect on top! There unique dressings to choose from Lime infused ranch was amazing! \n\nCons- Poor customer Service, not helpful when it comes to being undecided or asking for their recommendations

I have been to NY and had pizza and I am sorry to say this was nowhere near what you would get in NY. We ordered the NY style pizza and it just okay. The place is nice and the service was good, but I do not see myself going there ever again.

I don't know that I would have gotten oil changes for a few years if it hadn't been for this place.  

One stop shopping for getting an oil change and car wash - and there's a Wendy's right next door to grab some grub while they mess with the car.  They've expanded their offerings recently and now they do things from replacing your headlights to changing out belts.  My last trip there was an oil change, new air filter and car wash for $47 after tax.  They also do a basic car wash from $3.99 and a super was from $7.99.  I've never gotten anything but the basic, and I always find things they missed so while I'm not too impressed with their quality, it's nice to have the basics all taken care of in one location. 

They have 48 hour guarantees on the washes, which is nice and when you get work done it always includes a "limited time" coupon for additional work.  Not a bad deal...

"John's watering hole possesses qualities that render it an agreeable venue for individuals seeking a casual drinking establishment within close proximity to their domicile. The interior design exudes an aura of cleanliness and aesthetic appeal, while the culinary offerings, though unremarkable in quality, provide sustenance sufficient to satiate one's appetite. Patrons have the option to peruse menus from both the esteemed Mario's Pizza and the more limited selection offered by the bar, thereby affording them a diverse array of edible options. Of particular note are the delectable sliders, available in either chicken or cheeseburger varieties, which elicit praise from this writer due to their exceptional flavor. During sporting events, numerous televisions scattered throughout the premises afford patrons an optimal viewing experience, complemented by the presence of enticing drink specials. Although service is generally satisfactory, lapses in attention occasionally occur, understandably so given the steady stream of loyal clientele drawn from surrounding neighborhoods. In summary, John's place presents itself as a welcoming and comfortable local pub, well-suited to meet the needs of those seeking a relaxed, convivial atmosphere without necessitating extensive travel."

Had a nice breakfast at Gertrude's before checking out the Chihuly exhibit at the botanical garden. My traveling companion and I like to check out the botanical gardens in the cities we visit, and it was nice to have a breakfast option right there on site.

We both had the breakfast sammies, which were good, despite the fact that I don't think anything should be called a 'sammie.' The coffee was strong, and my only complaint was that it didn't get filled very often.

We were able to eat on the patio, which was nice since we were visiting the area partially to get away from the cold. It was very comfortable and pretty.

"We recently partook in a culinary excursion to this cozy eatery, and our arrival was met with an arduous queue, which threatened to deter us from our gastronomical pursuits. However, our persistence was rewarded by the hospitable staff's proffering of a delectable tray of lechon kawali (roast pork belly), thereby rekindling our interest in savoring the establishment's offerings. The menu boasted an array of Filipino delicacies, including Filipino-style corned beef and potatoes, as well as oxtail stew (\"kare-kare\"), both of which we indulged in with great relish. The ambiance of the restaurant, nestled within a bustling Chinese plaza, exuded a sense of warmth and familiarity, reflective of the Filipino cultural value of fostering strong connections with one's neighbors, as evidenced by the name of the establishment itself, which translates to \"house-connected.\" The prices, at a reasonable $6.50 for two dishes and rice, only served to further enhance our dining experience."

"The retail establishment boasts an array of luxury items and a sufficient assortment of products, yet, in concurrence with the previous patron's remarks, the personnel would greatly benefit from fundamental instruction in clientele etiquette. Paradoxically, the more mature employees manifest a warm, polite, and accommodating demeanor, whereas their younger counterparts display discourteous conduct, engaging in boisterous personal conversations within earshot of patrons, expressing visible exasperation and impatience, and indulging in disrespectful eye movements or utterly disregarding customers. It is truly perplexing that a business that prides itself on its high-end reputation does not place greater emphasis on instilling corresponding behavioral standards among its staff."

Well, I'm sitting here while my son plays.... Music is so loud you have to shout to communicate.... I asked them to turn the volume down a bit, they did but then turned it back up..... Inappropriate songs come on and staff needs to be told to turn it.... I mean what parent wants their kid listening to a song about a$$ and twerking? Other than these issues (that can definitely be addressed), it's a great place....

"While the Boozery's location may suggest the possibility of an exciting experience, the reality is unfortunately quite disparate, as the bar itself is rather diminutive in size, although it does offer some outdoor seating to compensate for its limited indoor capacity. Despite its modest dimensions, the interior exudes a certain charm and ambiance, yet the cramped quarters somewhat mitigate the potential for an truly enjoyable time. The drink menu is unremarkable, featuring a selection of standard cocktails at prices comparable to those found on Freemont Street ($7-$10), and ultimately, the Boozery fails to distinguish itself from the multitude of other unexceptional downtown bars, offering little reason for enthusiasm or commendation."

I orchestrated a gathering at this venue in collaboration with several female acquaintances for an early evening repast. The edifice housing the establishment is rather diminutive, rendering it easily overlookable, especially for those who are oblivious or momentarily distracted; hence, it is imperative to maintain vigilance lest one becomes disoriented. Furthermore, due to the limited dimensions of the building, parking facilities are somewhat restricted, with only a few spaces available at the forefront and a possibility of additional spaces in the rear, contingent upon their availability. Therefore, it is advisable to harbor minimal expectations regarding the ease of parking.  

Notwithstanding the preceding, the menu proffered by the eatery is relatively uncomplicated, featuring traditional fare such as meatloaf, hamburgers, aquatic delicacies, and salads. However, my culinary experience did not culminate in an exceptional impression, prompting me to select the Veggie Burger and fries. The vegetarian patty was a standard Morning Star offering, thus, failing to elicit astonishment, while the fries accompanying it were merely satisfactory.  

The hospitality we received was indeed commendable, yet I am uncertain whether it would be judicious to accord it precedence for a subsequent visit. Nonetheless, their brunch offerings have garnered positive reviews, thereby warranting a potential future endeavor. We shall defer judgment until a later time.

Loud. Very loud. Good for beer, sports and grill grub. Conversation, not so much.

The beer selection is outstanding. The food is well-prepared and tasty.

The service was a little slow, and I can't figure out why. Wouldn't make a difference, except that the food was already cooling off by the time it got to the table.

That said, our server and the owner were very friendly, and the gravy fries and mac & cheese were VERY flavorful.

I live in Glendale, so don't think I'll be driving cross-Valley to go again, but would recommend it to friends who are in that area anyway if they're looking for a fun place to watch a football game and drink really good beer.

(+) The lodging boasts an enviable location, nestled within close proximity to a plethora of iconic landmarks, cultural hotspots, and urban amenities, including the revered Notre Dame, the historic Old Montreal, the vibrant Chinatown, the charming Latin Quarters, and the bustling St. Catherine's, as well as an array of art museums, a convenient metro station, and a diverse selection of shopping and dining venues.

(+) The guest chamber itself is spacious, featuring a majestic high ceiling, a plush king-size bed, and a compact kitchenette, thereby providing ample space for relaxation and convenience.

(+) The hospitality of the staff is worthy of mention, as they exhibit a warm and welcoming demeanor, readily accommodating requests for additional amenities, such as the complimentary provision of a cot, graciously bestowed without any supplementary charges.

(+) The lodging offers complimentary internet access, conveniently furnishing guests with a unique code upon check-in, enabling them to seamlessly stay connected during their sojourn.

(+) A delicious continental breakfast buffet is included in the tariff, featuring an assortment of fresh pastries, crusty croissants, healthy cereals, succulent fruits, and aromatic coffee, all served in a cheerful ambiance.

(-) Unfortunately, a minor drawback was encountered, as the reservation, which specifically requested two separate beds, was inadvertently allocated a single bedroom, prompting a visit to the front desk to address the inconvenience. Although the accommodation was ultimately unable to offer an alternative room exchange, the staff graciously offered a cot at no additional cost.

(-) A slight criticism pertains to the towels, which bore an unpleasant odor, detracting from the overall comfort experience.

(-) While the daily parking fee of $22 is reasonable, the fact that it is exclusively valet-based and requires the assistance of the concierge for item retrieval may prove inconvenient for some visitors who value ease of access to their vehicles.

"It is indeed a peculiar circumstance that this establishment has garnered a relatively uncommon three-star rating, and I must admit that my experience at this venue was, in certain aspects, divergent from the conventional buffet encounter; nevertheless, I must emphasize that my culinary expedition at this location was, on the whole, an enjoyable escapade. My nocturnal peregrinations along the famed Las Vegas Strip led me to this eatery, which, upon initial inspection, appeared to offer a diverse array of comestibles that, while perhaps not attaining the lofty standards of haute cuisine, were, nevertheless, palatable and satisfying. A cursory examination of the menu revealed that the crustacean delicacies, particularly the crab legs, were undoubtedly the most exceptional items available, and their quality more than justify the associated tariff of twenty dollars; furthermore, the prime rib, mashed potatoes, and spicy tuna rolls also proved to be delectable alternatives. However, my expectations regarding the salad bar were not entirely fulfilled, as it failed to meet my expectations in terms of both quality and variety; similarly, the assortment of pastries and sweets did not quite live up to my hopes. It is worth mentioning that the ambiance of this establishment exuded a certain kitschy charm, which, given its association with the Imperial Palace, was not altogether unexpected. In conclusion, I would argue that this buffet offers a commendable dining experience, particularly for those who are famished and seeking a diverse selection of edibles at a reasonable price."

"I have had the privilege of lodging at this esteemed establishment on two separate occasions, and my experiences have been vastly dissimilar. It appears that only a portion of the hotel has undergone renovation, which has resulted in a conspicuous disparity between the quality of the accommodations. During my initial stay, my significant other and I were assigned a spacious room equipped with a king-size bed, which was tastefully updated and featured an impressive bathroom. However, upon my return with a group of female companions, we were allocated rooms containing two double beds, which were noticeably outdated, worn, and lacking in aesthetic appeal. Notwithstanding these inconsistencies, the hotel's prime location and competitive pricing make it a viable option for those who do not intend to spend considerable time within their lodgings. Unfortunately, access to the fitness center comes at an additional cost, and the pool area tends to be overcrowded, making it challenging to secure a lounge chair. While the gaming facilities are satisfactory, the beverage service could benefit from improvement, as it can be somewhat sluggish."
Maybe my expectations were too high - but food was very disappointing.  It was ok - nothing spectacular or noteworthy.  Therefore it was definitely overpriced.  Wait staff was great though.

Just ordered a pizza and wings for delivery. I picked up my pizza before and I got a weird vibe from the staff. They are very unpleasant, thought if I phoned it in I would get a happy tone on the other end.... WRONG! They need to hire delightful people to work the register and take the phone calls. This will be my last time ordering from them until my free pizza coupon is valid lol! Oh and the pizza's not all that bad! Definitely better than Pizza Hut!

Hakkasan is located inside the MGM grand. I was on the GL so we went to the GL line and it was free before 1am, so we had to hurry our asses there! We made it & it was free, thank god! Anywayyys, bouncers were nice and they made our transition inside the club pretty smoothly. Once we got in, I immediately noticed how SMALL it was. The dancefloor was sooooo tiny! :( When I finally made my way over, I could barely move/dance. It was literally body to body ... and this was on a day where there's NO ONE famous dj-ing! So imagine how bad the crowd would get if Tiesto or Hardwell was up there .... I wouldn't wanna be there! \n\nBut that's all I can really say because I got super messed up and I can't remember anything else. Only that I couldn't dance at all because there was no room and the parts where it's kinda open, the security made you move :(

I have been to this particular location for eyebrow threading twice.  On both occasions I walked in without an appointment and was greeting right away.  There was no wait and the desk attendant was very professional.  The brow threading person did an excellent job.  I would recommend that she improve her customer service.  She did not ask me how I would like my brows done or even speak to me at all.  Overall, I would come back again since they did make my brows look great!

"For a smorgasbord, I surmised that this establishment offered a relatively satisfactory culinary experience, with the comestibles being genuinely representative of the authentic Indian gastronomical tradition, and the seasonings and spices being carefully prepared to evoke the distinctive flavors which I have come to associate with genuine Indian cuisine. Notwithstanding my unfamiliarity with a significant portion of the offerings, the variety of dishes available was appreciable, although I must admit that the profusion of flavors ultimately became somewhat indistinguishable from one another, leading me to speculate that in future, I might prefer to patronize a traditional Indian restaurant where I can savor a single dish, such as chicken marsala or curry, in isolation."
Pretty expensive compared to Ghandi's just down the street.  Food was fine, but not wonderful.  A bit nicer ambience than most Indian places

"It is not deceptive to admit that I relished a thoroughly enjoyable experience during my recent visit to this esteemed eatery. The interior design exudes an air of contemporary sophistication, complete with elevated platforms that double as performance areas for scantily-clad dancers to showcase their talents while patrons partake in their culinary indulgences. However, my overall satisfaction was slightly compromised due to a few minor drawbacks. Specifically, the hostesses displayed an excessively stringent demeanor, feigning ignorance of my prior reservation despite the fact that my hotel concierge had already arranged it over the phone. Furthermore, they seemed to be under the impression that they were conferring a favor upon me by accommodating my request, albeit after an extended period of time. In contrast, our server exhibited exceptional proficiency and attentiveness throughout the evening. The cuisine itself was adequate, with the Black Cod appetizer being particularly noteworthy, while the crab cake counterpart fell short of my expectations. The fried shrimp dish was also commendable, and the steak offerings adhered to the established standards associated with the Morton's brand. In conclusion, although my dining experience was generally satisfying, the abundance of exceptional eateries in Las Vegas renders it unlikely that I will return to this specific location in the future."

"This culinary establishment offers an enjoyable ambiance for consumers to indulge in gastronomical delights, however, it does not quite align with my personal preferences. 

The hospitality demonstrated by the staff was indeed commendable and played a significant role in elevating the overall experience to a passable level. 

Regrettably, the fare served was merely mediocre, with each dish excessively seasoned to the point where I could only consume half of it, despite feeling famished. It is not advisable to order the special hash and potatoes together, as they share a strikingly similar flavor profile, which would necessitate an abundance of hydration to successfully complete consumption. However, the quality of other menu items appears to be satisfactory, and this may explain its popularity among patrons. Perhaps restricting options to waffles and pancakes would be a wiser choice, as they seemed visually appealing. 

It is challenging to endorse this eatery wholeheartedly, unless one's taste buds incline towards heavily seasoned cuisine. Nevertheless, the atmosphere is conducive to a pleasant dining experience."

Once just a Panera ripoff, Atlanta Bread has since added many more of its own creations. I tried the Italian vegetable panini the other night: tasty but expensive, given the portion size. Even after finishing the pickle and kettle chips that came with it, I felt barely satiated.\n\nDecor is nice, as is the free wifi, but service is somewhat lacking. Nonetheless, this place feels like an adequate option if you're in the mood for a sandwich. (The pastas, however, are quite bland.)

In a culinary ocean saturated with gourmet eateries, occasionally one yearns for a mundane repast. For an unassuming cafÃ©, the edifice was not devoid of merit. We merely sought a quotidian sustenance for a tardy luncheon. Numerous establishments were still in the process of inaugurating their daily operations, while others proffered a restricted noontime menu. It was a Sunday replete with gridiron matches, thus numerous drinking establishments teemed with enthusiasts. 
The ambiance evoked memories of Cheesecake Factory, boasting an extensive bill of fare. The staff exhibited amicability. I opted for deep-fried poultry accompanied by mashed potatoes. Although not particularly greasy, the poultry possessed a discernible saltiness, situating it somewhere between mediocrity and excellence. The potatoes lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, but the savory chicken effectively counterbalanced the deficiency. I requested a Pear Martini, only to discover that the components were unavailable. Thus, I indulged in a scrumptious Strawberry Martini instead. My spouse opted for a cheeseburger and fries. While the latter satisfied my taste buds, I did not sample the former. Nevertheless, my better half consumed it with relish and claimed it surpassed his expectations. 
Given the abundance of superior dining establishments within walking distance, the likelihood of my return remains uncertain. However, in a pinch, I might consider partaking of their offerings once more.

This buffet can be considered satisfactory for local patrons, in my opinion. However, if I had to pay for it myself, I might have been more critical since it's merely a mid-range buffet charging over $50 for two individuals. We visited on seafood Friday, and the offerings were unremarkable, with most dishes being standard fare found at many mid-range Las Vegas buffets. Our server was friendly and attentive, though, and the hot crab legs were quite enjoyable.  

However, some aspects were disappointing. The sushi was cold and lackluster, while the cold shrimp was mushy and lacking texture. Although the salmon appeared moist, its taste was underwhelming. The hush puppies were overly salty and crunchy, and the fried catfish had an unpleasant softness due to sitting out too long, despite having a flavor reminiscent of "chicken fried" catfish. The carrot cake and chocolate fudge pieces were also subpar, with the latter feeling almost weightless.  

In summary, the crab was the highlight, and the presentation of the shellfish dishes was visually appealing and flavorful. Everything else we tried was mediocre, neither terrible nor inedible. Children would likely enjoy this establishment, as would those with sufficient funds seeking a leisurely dining experience.

"Enormous pasta serving. Appetizers became superfluous when confronted with the gargantuan magnitude of my spaghetti. When the menu at an Italian eatery fails to provide a stimulating option, I tend to choose the tried-and-true spaghetti with meatballs. It's a quintessential dish whose preparation serves as a litmus test for the quality of the establishment's culinary offerings. Thankfully, the noodles were cooked to a perfect firmness and the meatballs retained an optimal level of juiciness. Alas, our meal began with a selection of cured meats and flatbread pizzas, leaving me feeling satiated by the time my entree arrived, much to my dismay. However, I returned later that evening, following a night of indulgent drinking, to partake in a supremely gratifying post-drinking pizza experience. Interestingly enough, I wasn't the only one who had the same idea."

I reviewed this in 2009 to let people know that I got food poisoning here. I ate here again and am rating it more highly cause I ate the veg food and it was fine, but mostly because I highly approve of the quantity and quality of their rice.  Working class Asian Americans like myself love their rice and this place is super generous and the quality is very very good. Better than the entree itself in fact.

"Although it is true that they have recently introduced a vegetarian variant of their fajitas, priced at $10, it is rather unfortunate that the portion size of tofu accompanying the dish is somewhat meager, and when compared to the superior quality and quantity of tofu offered by Jack Astor's rendition of this popular Tex-Mex dish, it becomes evident that the value proposition presented by this menu item is not particularly compelling; therefore, it is unlikely that I would opt to order them again in the future."

I am a whore for great burgers, but it is hard to impress me. Indulge flirts with this, but I can never get my burger cooked to the temperature I ask for. I hate that! Take the Outback strategy and undercook everything, I don't care. Oh, and buy some salt for the beef.\n\nGood deals, real good drink deals, for happy hour!

Awesome food and great service! Don't miss out on the 'sides'.. I got the hummus and lentils, which were both amazing. I ran out of pita bread but they were nice enough to give me more upon request. I would also highly recommend dessert.. I got some kind if strawberry bar (forgot what it was called) but it was delish.

I also ordered the good earth sandwich which had really fresh ingredients, but the flavor profile of the sauce was kind of weird for me, I think I would order it without it if I was ever to go back again (I'm not from Nevada). I also ordered the guacamole sandwich, which I liked better.. But the I would have to say the red sauce on it was too sweet for me. I split these with a friend and we both felt the same about these entrees. 

There was one other vegan sandwich option, tree of life, and I ordered all three for my boyfriend and his 2 other friends to split, and they liked the tree of life the best... So hopefully that helps!

I've been a member of Lifetime for a few months and their facilities are hands down the best. You can read the other reviews for how awesome tha facility is but I'm going to speak to some of the interesting events that take place in the men's locker room and I am not joking at all......

Apparently the men's locker room gets rather friendly after hours and when I say after hours I state that loosely as in 10-11pm.   On two occasions.....I repeat.....two occasions I had the same 55 year old man pull up to a sink next to me and blow dry his junk.  I'm not exagerrating and my friend was at the sink to his left.   He was sandwiched between us butt naked stretching his stick and blow drying his junk dry.   I ran out of the gym in fear.   A few weeks later the SAME MAN did it again except this time I was by myself.   

Another time, 2 young men in their 30's were slapping each other in behinds with towels NAKED and chasing each other around the gym.  They almost knocked me over.....Thankfully I am not homophobic but come on, there's a time and place for everything......and apparently Lifetime is where it's at.   CAUTION - BEWARE

My expectations may be too high...let's start off with the positives.  Big parking lot, modern decor and very spacious.  Great service for having only one person running the front of the house.   

We ordered chicken red curry, papaya salad, BBQ chicken, pad thai and a side order of sweet rice.

Sweet rice - soggy and over cooked.  It came in a plastic sandwich bag.

BBQ chicken - it was served with a side of the sweet chili sauce...bottled chili sauce.  The chicken is a piece of chicken breast marinated in what seemed like dried curry rub.  It was not BBQ nor did it taste like BBQ. It tasted pan fried.  Overall, I did not like it.

Papaya salad - a bit too salty without the lime flavor.  Tiny bits of dried peanuts mixed throughout the salad....wasn't authentic, very Americanized.

Chicken red curry - loved the bamboo shoots and normal curried vegetables in the dish however the curry sauce lacked flavor.  It was very bland and no taste...it could've used a dash of fish sauce.  Overall, it was ok.

Pad thai - I was over it prior to making my way towards this dish.  My kids absolutely LOVED it!  That says it all as my kids are very picky eaters with a sophisticated palette.

Would I return? Likely not and still in search for authentic Thai cuisine in AZ!

Sooooo... I'm giving them 3 stars b/c the Manager took care of our bill. Ya see this is the second time my b/f and I had an issue with the service on two separate occasions. First time they didn't bring my water when I asked twice and didn't bring the bill. This time (tonight) they brought our food to the wrong people, took it back, brought it back out after 15 min., it was cold... I told them we didn't want it (no attitude) so the Manager comes and says its on him. That's great customer service! So why 3 stars???

Well... It would be different if this happened every once in a while but two times in a row. And this is the only two times I've been there. I like that the seats are comfortable. I like the tables. I like the screen, the atmosphere, the bar and all that outside, but the dining experience screwed it up for me. I'd rather concentrate on the movie rather than what I'm missing or what's wrong... 

Bottom line: Get ya girl or female homie with the big purse to stuff all the goodies and snacks in it and enjoy the movie!
So..this place is cute!  Huge dance floor!  The whole place is huge! Geesh~  Fun decor and nice bartenders.  The guys there seem pretty lame though.  Cool place to get dressed up and dance.

it's a party on the inside, very cool decor and volcano show

better burgers than "The Burger Joint" in the same location

average food but worth the price

"Roberto's, a culinary establishment boasting multiple locations throughout Las Vegas, was once the epicenter of my gastronomical infatuation. However, as time has elapsed, my ardor for their offerings has waned, correlatively mirroring a perceived decline in the overall quality of their cuisine. Despite this, Roberto's continues to surpass numerous other dining options within the city limits, though my personal standards have been elevated by exposure to exceptional street food vendors and authentic Mexican eateries. Thus, while still enjoyable, Roberto's has relegated itself to the realm of 'average' in my esteem, eliciting an occasional craving that I satiate intermittently."

I have been here a couple of times. The service was great and the atmosphere is nice, casual and laid back.\n\nThe pizza is alright. I've tried a couple different pizzas here. I didn't love the sauces they used and didn't love the crust texture or taste. However, I really enjoyed the food items that were not pizza here. Their sides, salads, and soups were tasty. I'm interested in trying their other menu items. I would come back here, but not for the pizza.

Nice place, nice atmosphere, and I've always had good service here but - for me - the bread is mediocre. I'm guessing they are intending to go for a very moist, 'heavy' bread, which I'm sure some people love. I've just discovered Wildflower Bread Company and their bread is 'perfect' for me - drier, lighter, but still with moisture and 'stretch' or 'bite'.

"During my recent visit to Las Vegas, I had the opportunity to partake in the lunch buffet offered by this establishment, and I must say that the culinary offerings were quite satisfactory.  It was, in fact, a fortuitous discovery, made on the final day of our stay in the city, following a series of disappointing experiences at the Studio Cafe.  The fixed daily tariff appeared to be an exceptional value, particularly when considering the exorbitant prices typically associated with dining in Las Vegas.  However, the ambient temperature of the seating area was rather chilly for some inexplicable reason, but our server was quite attentive and accommodating, noticing our discomfort and kindly suggesting hot beverages, which she subsequently ensured were consistently replenished."

Situated in the heart of the shops at Palazzo, this unassuming wine bar offers decent selections at the bar and good to great selections in the shop located adjacent to the bar. 

Bottle prices are a bit high, but that's what Vegas is all about. 

I was disappointed with the glassware, which ranging from either the O-Line series to small bowled glasses with short stems, reminiscent of bad hotel banquets. For a wine bar, I simply expected more in terms of glassware.

Other than that, the staff was friendly and kept my glass filled!!!

Good place to go play and burn energy but they need to get speed ball open again. Referees have gotten really lazy lately not wanting to ref a game. On the plus side they were able to fix gun free of charge and cleaned it out. I would go Lots more often of they fixed up there fields and got some better bunkers. Really focus on the fields and there refs and this place will be 5 stars.

We had been eagerly anticipating dining at the Block & Grinder since its opening, having heard numerous accolades regarding its culinary offerings. Upon finally experiencing it for ourselves, we found the edibles to be quite satisfactory, warranting a rating of 4 to 5 stars. However, our enjoyment of the meal was somewhat mitigated by the less than stellar ambiance and service. Specifically, we were seated in a rather cramped area adjacent to a large table, and it took approximately 12 minutes before a server noticed our presence and attended to our needs. Subsequently, we received attentive care from our server, albeit at a pace that could be described as leisurely due to his responsibility for multiple sizeable tables.   Moving on to more favorable aspects of our dining experience, we began with an appetizer of pimento cheese served with crackers, which we found to be exceptionally delectable and arguably the most flavorful pimento cheese we have had the pleasure of sampling during our brief exposure to this particular delicacy. For our main course, we opted for the ribs, which proved to be a judicious decision. The meat was not only tender and lean but also ranked among the most succulent ribs we have had the pleasure of consuming.  Considering our overall satisfaction with the food, we might consider returning to the Block & Grinder, ideally during a weeknight or off-peak hours, in the hope of improving our dining experience by avoiding the crowds that may have contributed to the sluggish service we encountered. Additionally, we would be interested in sampling the establishment's cocktails.

I live pretty close to Papago, so it's a place I regularly hike. But it's not because I love this park, it's really because of the convenience of living so close, and the fact that the trials are not challenging at all. Papago is one of the few places that I feel 100% safe about hiking on my own. Unless you take a wrong step while climbing one of the buttes, it's pretty hard to hurt yourself. \n\nThe park is clean and well kept, and you do get some good views of Phoenix, Tempe and Scottsdale on your hike. Once in a while I've even spotted some cool birds flying around. Because it's such an easy hike, Papago is a great spot for beginner/novice hikers, and a pretty good spot to take your kids or the dog. If you're looking to get outside and get some air, Papago is the place to hit up for an hour or two on a quiet afternoon or morning.

"Upon conducting an exhaustive inquiry among the indigenous populace, it became apparent that this eatery was the unanimous recommendation for gastronomical indulgence in the realm of burgers; thus, I deemed it incumbent upon myself to partake in a culinary exploration of the establishment, not once, but twice, in order to formulate a comprehensive assessment of its gustatory offerings. Unfortunately, my expectations were not merely unfulfilled, but utterly decimated, as the fare proved to be utterly insipid, lacking even the most fundamental attributes of flavor and zest. My experiences with both the burger and steak served only to reinforce this notion, leaving me in a state of profound disillusionment."

Bed Bath & Beyond -- thoroughly overpriced and suffering from subpar parking facilities at this specific location, much to my dismay. I only frequent BB&B when I am in possession of one of those highly sought-after 20% discount coupons. On a recent visit, I was in pursuit of an exceptional linen spray, specifically the Egyptian Cotton-scented variety. Unfortunately, they were out of stock on both occasions I visited the store. My quest for a suitable "everyday" cookware set was also thwarted, as they only offered premium Calphalon products, which were beyond my budget. However, I did manage to procure a new shower curtain liner and a pair of candles, albeit at a different retail establishment.

I was really excited to eat here, but was really let down.

We ate here right before we saw Ka.  For appetizers we got the frisee salad and the lobster bisque.  DELICIOUS.  The frisee had big chunks of bacon and the broken yolk  made the bacon taste 10x better.  We order a half bottle of red wine that was well worth the price too.  My like for Craftsteak ends here.   I got the flat iron steak and tried the surf and turf (ribeye and lobster tail), I can honestly say I've had better.  I'm from Texas and we've got plenty of good beef here. 

I was disappointed in the rolls since I heard so much rave about them, they were good but nothing special.  Have you ever had a yeast roll from Hartz Chicken?  If yes, then you've had a roll from Craftsteak.  I wish I could say more about this place.

This is the only hotel I've stayed at downtown - I know, hard to believe a person from Hawaii never stayed at the California!!  But I'm really picky about what hotels I stay at and the California and every other hotel located downtown always made me feel itchy while walking through - like I said before: "Happy Faye, happy stay!"

The rooms were pretty average, but I only stayed in their standard rooms.

I've had good experiences here and never felt unsafe (while in the hotel room and casino area).  All of the employees were always nice and helpful, which is always good to have!  Their 24 hour coffee shop serves good food at reasonable prices (they even have some "Hawaii friendly" menu items!).

Realistically, I give this place 3.5 stars. The decor is nice and the menu is appealing. They list everything that comes on and with ur orders.... But I felt that it was a tad bit too show-ee for me... Maybe that's what u get in Vegas? Came in based on a recommendation for the oxtail chili fries. That did not disappoint. It was good. A lot of meat, and flavorful. I would say it's a must try if it's your first time. I also had their summer special, the Manga burger. That was OK. A bit too much sauce...couldn't really get too much of the burger flavor. I washed it down with the matcha green tea milk shake. Yum! Maybe I'm spoiled with the burger joints in LA. But Bachi Burger is opening a location on Sawtelle soon. I guess then we can see how they do head to head with the other burger joints out here. That will be fun!

Want to stay on the strip but you're a cheapskate? Sahara is the place for you.

Old + Falling Apart + Terrible Shows =  great character.

Only problem is it's a little too far away from the heart of the strip.

When I was employed at the Renaissance tower, I would frequent this establishment when I was feeling particularly indolent and opted to procure sustenance from a nearby source rather than expending the effort to traverse the street in search of a superior dining experience. This decision was motivated by the fact that, in my opinion, their pizza failed to meet even the most basic standards of culinary excellence, falling short of both greatness and goodness. However, on two separate occasions, I did partake of their breakfast muffin, which far surpassed my expectations by boasting an optimal amount of grease that effectively conveyed its quality without overwhelming the palate. Additionally, the price point was remarkably reasonable, making it an eminently affordable option for those seeking a satisfying repast without breaking the bank.

I'm not the hugest fan of Indian food but if I had to eat it this is where I would go. They also have a few other dishes besides Indian which is nice. The food tends to be spicey and pretty authentic!  A lot of what they offer is geared toward the vegetarian crowd.

I procured a haircut and was thoroughly enamored with the result, yet I harbored some reservations regarding the salon's ambiance, as it seemed to exude an excessively contemporary aesthetic that did not necessarily align with my personal preferences. Nonetheless, I would venture to say that this establishment appears to be a suitable choice for individuals who are partial to cutting-edge hairstyles and hues.

"Although I have not had the opportunity to sample a considerable number of dishes or partake in the midday buffet offered by this establishment, my culinary experiences thus far have led me to formulate the opinion that it constitutes a passable alternative for those seeking Indian cuisine. Furthermore, as an individual who adheres to a vegetarian dietary regimen, I find solace in the knowledge that there exists no possibility of animal flesh being incorporated into my meals, thereby rendering it a relatively risk-free dining destination for me."

The sushi here is not bad, but not great. Service is also up to par. Sushi rock pails in comparison, however, to nearby restaurants, that have much better quality sushi, and hover around the same price. Though I may come here again for Korean food, I will not be returning for sushi.

We like to come in here to shop for clothes and luggage.  You can find some great deals in here.  The selection of luggage is pretty good too.  I've found some great carry on bags.

It can get really busy here, especially on weekends.  The best time to shop is mid-week in the middle of the day.  The employees here are usually friendly and the store is kept clean.

Return Factor - 60%

These state employees don't necessarily like their job, but they did a great job of helping me out. 

I just moved to the state and required a change of residency. I have no car here yet so a drivers license wasn't a necessity, but it would have been nice to have already. Unfortunately, proof of insurance specifically for this state is necessary to do that. State ID it was then. The lady at the front (I didn't grab her name) was very  kind and accommodating for my noob questioning of changing state ID's. The line, although around the room, moved very quickly.It's a lot faster than what I'm used to from Chicago/Illinois DMV lines.

Overall, if you have all your required paper work with you,  it is a fair experience got being a thing of necessity. Props to the kind lady in the beige cardigan up front!

We had the opportunity to indulge in a four-day sojourn at this establishment during the month of August in the previous year, and while it was not an unmitigated disaster, it failed to surpass our expectations in terms of overall quality and satisfaction. It is unlikely that we will opt to return to this hotel in the future unless they offer a drastically reduced rate, as it does not compare favorably to other establishments in the vicinity. The property itself is somewhat aged, which may contribute to its relatively lower price point, but its proximity to Mandalay Bay, where our friends were celebrating their nuptials, made it a convenient choice for our group of 23 individuals. Unfortunately, the tranquility of our weekend retreat was frequently disrupted by the sounds of construction, which seemed to persist throughout the entire weekend. The pool area, though adequate in size, lacked a certain aesthetic appeal compared to other hotels in the area. However, one of the highlights of our stay was the complimentary admission to Club LAX, which offered a welcome respite from the chaos of the casino floor. Additionally, the convenience of the tram system, which allowed us to easily access both Excalibur and Mandalay Bay without excessive walking, was a welcome amenity. Our room, though sufficient for two individuals, would have been somewhat cramped for any additional occupants. Furthermore, the variety of dining options within the food court left something to be desired. In conclusion, while the value proposition of this hotel may be attractive to some budget-conscious travelers, it falls short in delivering a truly satisfying experience for those seeking a higher level of comfort and luxury.

After being seated at three different tables we decided to sit at the bar.  We then found out they were out of lager.  How the hell can a brewery be out of lager?  The food was decent, the service was below average, and the crowd was the usual here in Glendale, old white folks.

Very up-to-date hotel. Pleasant atmosphere. Make sure if you want 3G/4G access in your room that you stay on the west side. Pool has horrible hours IMHO. If you want wifi access, be prepared to spend a fortune.  Drinks at the pool are outrageously priced!  $17 for one drink (includes mandatory tip)

"Culinary indulgences are undoubtedly a source of pleasure, but it's essential to acknowledge that the provision of such gastronomic delights can sometimes be accompanied by an excessive duration of time, particularly in relation to the attainment of beverages and sustenance. Therefore, it's advisable to refrain from scheduling any subsequent activities for the remainder of the evening when partaking in the consumption of food and drinks at this establishment, as the prolonged waiting period may potentially encroach upon your plans."

Went to my first Panthers' game the other day; real good time, actually, even though I couldn't care less about the Panthers. It seems I'm the only one who doesn't: the place was, to my surprise, absolutely packed with Panther's fans. Pretty good for a team that's only been around for, what, ten years?

On game day, the stadium is absolutely surrounded and consumed by tailgating fans; during the rest of the week, it stands there, right outside of downtown, quiet and lonely looking. I guess that can be said of a lot of stadiums, though. 

As for the place itself, really good facilities and pretty good crappy stadium food--hotdogs, pretzels, beers, that kinda stuff. But it actually wasn't as expensive as I'd feared. Pretty reasonable, in fact, which is a rarity. 

And the fans were well-behaved and fun. Definitely a nice, family-friendly atmosphere. And there are always tickets available, so check it out.

I've only eaten there twice, but the food both times was very very average... not reflected in the prices. At this price point, the food should be out of this world. 

The happy hour specials are decent and the atmosphere is outstanding, but I don't really see a reason to go here unless you want to impress someone with how much money you have. It's not like going to Ocean Club where the food is fucking rad.

I won't be going here unless someone gives me a gift certificate. I put that it's Spendy, but if you get a drink it can easily get you over 60 bucks and into the splurge area. Not worth it.

"Underwhelmed by the uninspiring ambiance and unimpressive decor, we were disinclined to indulge in a dining experience at this establishment. The cacophonous music further exacerbated our dissatisfaction, rendering an in-house meal utterly unpalatable.
