My flank steak salad was merely satisfactory, possessing a somewhat tough texture, yet the sweet balsamic reduction complemented the bitter arugula with precision. In contrast, my companion's mushroom risotto was exquisitely prepared and indulgent, earning it a well-deserved four stars. Unfortunately, our culinary journey concluded with a less than impressive tiramisu, which lacked the potency of espresso and featured a chilling temperature that I personally prefer for the dessert. Moreover, the dark chocolate cocoa powder overwhelmed the delicate flavor of the dish when consumed in substantial amounts, prompting us to discard the upper layer of the dessert."
Food was great and reasonably priced with restaurant.com coupon. I would've gave five stars if the waiter wasn't so cocky and direct.

"An extensive array of artisanal brews graces the taps at this establishment, yet, if predictability is a patron's preference, they might be dismayed by the constantly shifting roster of craft beverages available. However, the culinary offerings proved to be a pleasant surprise, surpassing expectations typically associated with tavern fare. A convivial ambiance permeated our gathering of numerous companions, facilitated by the provision of entertainment in the form of board games and trivia queries. Unfortunately, the hospitality and ambiance left much to be desired, as an overwhelming crush of clientele necessitated an inordinate wait for a solitary server's attention, resulting in prolonged periods of neglect. Despite these shortcomings, the eatery's redeeming qualities, including its diverse beer selection and delectable victuals, may warrant future visits, albeit sans any gastronomical inclinations."

I have been a patron of this establishment for a considerable duration, and my satisfaction has been contingent upon the attendance of Dr. Finch, whose proficiency in veterinary medicine and bedside manner have engendered a sense of confidence and tranquility in me, as a concerned pet owner. It is worth mentioning that he has executed a relatively minor surgical procedure on my canine companion, Dozer, which involved the employment of a laser to excise a small growth from her eyelid, and his performance was exemplary, characterized by a commendable level of composure, erudition, and a propitious demeanor towards our cherished animal. Furthermore, it has come to my attention that he will likely be undertaking a second, considerably more complex operation on her, specifically an ACL repair, and I am entirely at ease with entrusting her care to him. Notwithstanding, I have chosen to revise my evaluation downward by a marginal extent, motivated by two primary factors. Firstly, my initial assessment may have been somewhat generous, as I was still in the process of formulating my criteria for evaluating veterinary facilities; and secondly, certain acquaintances have expressed unwavering devotion to their respective veterinarians, whereas my relationship with this establishment, although satisfactory, does not quite rise to that level of enthusiasm. Additionally, I must admit that I have periodically sought alternatives, but procrastination has led me to rely on Dr. Finch's services when Dozer has required urgent medical attention.

So far, I've only had the breakfast here, and actually just the omelets (corned beef and the farmer's).  The food is good enough, nothing spectacular.  I do like the fact that you can have blueberry muffin instead of toast.  The server was polite, had no problem bringing out ranch dressing with my hash browns (weird combo I like).  It's also the only thing open past 10 pm not in a casino and reasonably priced in the area.  Not a bad place to sit down and have a casual meal with a buddy.  I do have to complain about the fact that they don't serve dark chicken meat (white is too dry for me).

Okay, I'm giving 3 stars because the food was pretty good and the service was great.  But $18 for enchiladas?? Whoaaa now.  $5 roach coach enchiladas could stand up to theirs.  $9 chips and guacamole?? It was good but not $9 good!  I think this place has a complex... You can put cloth napkins and fancy paper menus on the table but in the end you're still a mainstream Mexican restaurant with TONS of competition... CHEAP competition that's just as good.  I won't go back just because of the price unfortunately...

Mert's is one of those places you would see on Diners, Drive-ins and Dives. The decor has a quintessential southern comfort feel and will make any out of towner feel welcome. \n\nI don't suggest eating lunch here though; if it happens, it's a wrap. You'll be knocked out like a newborn after boobie feeding. Service is good, food is decent and overall an okay spot to grab a meal.

Harrah's boasts an intelligent business model pertaining to its Carnaval Court, strategically positioned along a heavily traversed thoroughfare that effectively lures tourists into its vicinity. Surrounded by numerous kiosks offering an array of trivial knick-knacks easily accessible to inebriated patrons, even sober individuals such as myself and my companions succumbed to the allure of acquiring those novelty shirts responsive to musical rhythms. These gaudy apparel items symbolized our camaraderie, prompting us to purchase matching shirts. Upon entering the vibrant party arena adorned in our recently purchased attire, we received copious admiration and praise from fellow revelers. The expansive dance floor facilitates unrestricted movement, allowing patrons to fully indulge in their dancing desires. Located outdoors, the venue benefits from increased ventilation, thereby mitigating the potential for overheating typically associated with densely populated dance floors. The flair bartenders put on an entertaining display, complemented by their ability to craft respectable cocktails. Offering a seamless transition between merrymaking and gaming, this establishment features dedicated table games, catering to the diverse preferences of Vegas visitors. In essence, it encompasses all the essential elements sought after by patrons in the city's vibrant nightlife.

"It was gratifying to indulge in a tranquil dining experience this week, and if you seek respite from the rigors of daily life, this establishment is an ideal setting in which to do so. The panoramic view from the restaurant's vantage point is truly breathtaking, and the hospitality of the staff is warm and inviting. I opted for the Rib eye steak, which was cooked to perfection, and the accompanying Blue cheese potatoes were delectable, although the potency of the Blue Cheese slightly overshadowed the natural flavor of the potatoes. Additionally, I sampled a slice of cake for dessert, but unfortunately, the ice cream had begun to thaw, rendering it somewhat soggy, and the cake itself was slightly dry. Considering the cost, I anticipated a more fastidious attention to detail in regards to the presentation of the dessert course. Nonetheless, the ambiance and culinary offerings made for a satisfying excursion."

Dim sum, a culinary delight recommended by a friend, aroused my curiosity due to its exclusivity, as it was only available twice a year. However, upon indulging in the delectable offerings, I couldn't help but feel that the quality of the dim sum style food would have been superior if the establishment had concentrated solely on that aspect, instead of incorporating a seafood buffet. Although the dishes were savory, some were unfortunately served at room temperature. Furthermore, the absence of chili oil, a staple condiment in most Chinese eateries I frequent in San Diego, was conspicuous, yet tolerable given the sodium-rich nature of the items we consumed. Nonetheless, the non-dim sum options proved impressive, boasting fresh raw oysters, succulent crab legs, decadent lobster, and expertly crafted nigiri. My request for sushi pieces without rice was accommodated by the gracious sushi chef, albeit the generous slice thickness slightly diminished my enjoyment. A craving for octopus prompted me to explore the buffet line, whereupon I discovered a tantalizing octopus and cucumber salad, undoubtedly the highlight of the spread. An abundance of fresh fruit, including juicy mandarin oranges, tart cherries, and exotic rambutan, beckoned, but the desire to partake in a more leisurely dining experience prevailed. While the dessert bar showcased an admirable selection, it fell short of exceptional. My preference for dim sum, second only to sushi, has piqued my interest in revisiting this establishment during my forthcoming trip to San Diego.

It's like gambling. Sometimes, you win big...and other times...not so much.

The show started off great. Our MC was engaging and very funny. He was very comfortable in his own skin and using his life as material for his comedy, but he was still socially aware to not go too far. The same cannot be said about the first two comedians that came after who were crude, swore way too much, and shoved their distasteful humor down your throat irregardless of people being notably disgusted. At one point, a lady stood up after the joke went too far and asked the comedian to move on. Instead, he used this as fodder to continue at it. I get using someone as the butt of all jokes, but when LITERALLY no one else is laughing with you...it is time to move on. Luckily, the MC was able to put a bandaid over each of these two flops.

The headliner Jay Reid did make up for the entire night though...otherwise it would have been a complete dud at $20/ticket. Jay Reid made excellent use of the stage going as far as using the stool and mic stand as props. He had jokes about current events as well as of normal controversial/taboo subjects. The jokes were tasteful and he even stuck around to meet the audience after. Very classy and cool.

I commemorated the milestone of my eighteenth year of existence by partaking in a culinary excursion to this establishment in the company of a select group of acquaintances. It is pertinent to note that their hours of operation, specifically the period designated as "happy hour," are limited to weekdays between the hours of two and six post meridiem, thereby rendering our arrival at seven o'clock somewhat inconvenient. Notwithstanding this minor setback, I opted to sample their grilled chicken sandwich, which, while palatable, exhibited a certain pinkish hue that might have been attributable to an abbreviated cooking duration. Furthermore, the prolonged preparation time of approximately forty-five minutes, coupled with my considerable hunger, precluded me from returning said item to the kitchen for further culinary refinement. In addition, we collectively decided to partake in a shared consumption of their frozen hot chocolate beverage, which, despite its latent promise, unfortunately necessitated a significant amount of mastication upon its icy constituents throughout its duration. It is worth mentioning that the pace of service was somewhat leisurely and that the cost, while not drastically exceeding that of Cheesecake Factory, still fell within a higher price bracket. Notwithstanding these observations, I am willing to accord this eatery a subsequent opportunity to demonstrate improvement.

This certainly isn't your grandfather's Flamingo anymore; indeed, I would go so far as to say that it isn't even your overweight, chain-smoking Uncle Larry's Flamingo that everyone knew and didn't particularly care for five to ten years ago. Before my recent visit to the Flamingo, the mere thought of staying there would immediately conjure up images of depressing 1980s decor, overweight fanny pack-wearing gamblers, and the overly exuberant expressions of Donnie and Marie as they gazed longingly into each other's eyes in an attempt to forget about that fateful night in 1977 when things went a bit too far. However, I must say that the Flamingo has significantly improved its act. The new decor is quite pleasant, and the casino floor is spotless and 80% fanny pack-free. While I have yet to stay in a room, I would be perfectly comfortable taking a side chick I wasn't ashamed of, as well as a girl that I've been dating for a while, all the while insisting, "Why do we have to put labels on what we are?" without batting an eye. All things considered, the Flamingo is a perfectly acceptable establishment with a fantastic location that I would readily recommend to anyone strolling along the Strip. Who knows, perhaps you'll be the first person to witness Donnie and Marie finally give in to their pent-up sexual tension and frustration after 35 years!

"On two separate occasions during my sojourn at Treasure Island, I have partaken of sustenance at this establishment, and while the Pho has been merely adequate, it has possessed a certain je ne sais quoi that has rendered it marginally palatable in a pinch. Furthermore, I have sampled their vegetarian spring rolls, which, while not devoid of culinary merit, have been somewhat overshadowed by the ambivalent quality of the accompanying peanut sauce, which has struck me as vaguely coconut-flavored. On one visit, I opted for the Pho Tai, while my companion selected the Veggie Pho; unfortunately, my soup proved to be somewhat lacking in gastronomic appeal, containing as it did an abundance of beef but a dearth of noodles, whereas my friend's soup, replete with bak choy, mushrooms, and corn, was more enjoyable. It is worth noting, however, that the pricing of the Pho here strikes me as somewhat elevated in comparison to similar establishments in Los Angeles, where a superior-tasting bowl may be obtained for a mere $7. Notwithstanding these reservations, I must commend the waitstaff for their congeniality and the premises for their cleanliness."

Not a huge fan of this Target.  It's the closest one so I find myself going there but the store is so large and it feels like everyone inside is an ASU student at times.  Which basically means it is always crowded with people and I find myself waiting in line to check out.  Otherwise, it's has a lot of good things.  Lots of parking, great staff and like I said before it's super sized so you can find anything and everything you need in one location.

"It has come to my attention that certain members of our staff are devoting an excessive amount of time engaging in non-work related conversations with one another, thereby compromising their ability to deliver optimal levels of customer service. This phenomenon is particularly prevalent when employees are positioned with their backs facing the clientele, which not only hinders their capacity to respond promptly to patrons' needs but also creates an unfavorable impression of unprofessionalism."

I just happened to be in Vegas this new year and since I saw this place in the past i decided to try it. Salad bar is ok, the meats a bit too salty and really raw (bloody) but I was surely disappointed with the service. Waitress show up only 3 times, when we first sat at the table, when she brought us the drinks and when she gave us the check!, I have to literally ask the servers to bring the meats to our table since the seem to just pas us by, I guess the just want you to eat from the salad bar :( \nIn other words, the price service/quality ratio is not good at all

We chanced upon this eatery subsequent to our inability to gain admittance to the Bacchanal due to an extensive queue. At the time of our arrival, we were experiencing considerable hunger! This cozy establishment boasts contemporary embellishments throughout its interior, creating a hip ambiance. Top 20 hits are played at a high volume, making it unsuitable for those seeking a tranquil setting conducive to conversation. \n\nThe servings here are generous, but unfortunately, the culinary offerings did not leave a lasting impression. Nothing remarkable or extraordinary was present in the dishes. I opted for a pastrami-based breakfast sandwich, which lacked a certain je ne sais quoi. Had they included additional condiments or a unique sauce, it might have elevated the dish to a higher level of satisfaction. Unfortunately, the combination of pastrami, eggs, and other components did not harmonize effectively. However, it did satiate our hunger. Notwithstanding, I must admit that the tater tots were quite delectable - possessing a satisfying crunch and delightful flavor.

"This location possesses an intriguing ambiance and offers a plethora of knowledge. My enthusiasm for the establishment was amplified by the thoughtful division of the exhibits into four distinct ecosystems. However, I lamented the lack of comprehensive representation in the polar/arctic sector. In my opinion, the entrance fee is exorbitant relative to the value offered. Nonetheless, the gift store boasts an array of unique items, including innovative bags crafted from recycled juice containers, delectable insect-based treats, and minuscule crystalline formations, among other fascinating novelties. It is not advisable to squander your resources on the elevator ride to the summit of the metropolis, as the same panoramic perspective can be obtained gratis from the pinnacle of Mount Royal."

"It is imperative that one does not make a hasty judgment based on external appearances, as this establishment offers an array of exceptional bargains for those who are willing to invest time in their pursuit. A diverse medley of items, including apparel, artwork, and various domestic ornaments, are available for perusal and purchase. During my recent visit, it appeared that the proprietors were in the process of expanding their inventory to include an increased assortment of floor coverings and visual art pieces, which will undoubtedly be a boon for individuals seeking to revamp their domiciles. My excursion was enjoyable, and I would unhesitatingly revisit this location in quest of additional hidden gems."
Well they no longer have the Chicken Strip Cheese sandwich and what they replaced it with pretty much sucks. Other than that its like a normal hooters with some new wing flavors and steak fries.

This lodging establishment caters to individuals who seek fundamental accommodations and are financially constrained, thereby providing a suitable venue for those seeking basic amenities at an economical price point. During our sojourn, we found that it fulfilled its intended function admirably and would unhesitatingly suggest it to others who do not prioritize luxurious appointments or an extensive array of services. Within close proximity, we noticed the presence of eateries such as Pizza Hut, Subway, and Fatburger, as well as a cinema, watering holes, and numerous slot machines. Our stay was primarily characterized by slumber, and we did not partake in any notable activities within the hotel's premises themselves. Furthermore, our culinary experience at Fatburger proved to be disappointing, both in terms of taste and the prolonged duration required for its preparation.

I was motivated to go here because I saw it featured on the Food Network, and I was hoping it could hold a candle to the Boiling Crab.  While to seafood was pretty good, it wasn't as spicy & flavorful as I had hoped for.  Go early as it tends to get crowded.  We went at 11am on a weekend and by the time we finished our meal, there was a line for tables.

"A viscous, ruddy hue emanates from the cuboidal matter, denominated as '3-star red curry tofu,' which has undergone a process of culinary manipulation. Notwithstanding its quality, surpassing the celestial bodies in magnitude, it falls short of attaining the pinnacle of gastronomical excellence, as inferred by the omission of a single stellar designation. Nonetheless, an appreciable level of proficiency is discernible in the preparation of this singular dish, thus obviating any misapprehensions regarding its gustatory merits."

"We arrived at approximately 8:30 PM, and upon our arrival, we observed that the queue extended beyond the entrance. Undeterred by the lengthy wait, I advocated for our participation in the line, as my craving for ice cream was unwavering. Following a 15-minute interval, we successfully placed our order; however, the delay was reasonable given the crowded atmosphere and the staff's diligent efforts to manage the influx of patrons. Notably, the employee who assisted us mistakenly provided a larger portion than requested, which they generously offered at no additional cost. It is worth mentioning that the limited seating area within the establishment was largely unoccupied, likely due to the personnel being fully engaged in fulfilling orders. Consequently, we opted for takeout. As an enthusiast of Cold Stone's unique blend of frozen delights, I have grown accustomed to enduring prolonged waits, and in my opinion, the experience merits the temporary inconvenience."

This particular venue brought to mind the ambiance of Whiskey River, albeit devoid of the boisterous individuals customarily present along the shore and characterized by a preponderance of relaxed patrons. It appeared that impromptu dance competitions were taking place on the floor, as spectators seemed to be thoroughly enjoying themselves. Additionally, there were apparent offers of 99-cent Jaeger bombshells and, upon further inquiry, I discovered the existence of 99-cent tacos or similar culinary items. A wet T-shirt contest ensued, featuring a mere trio of participants, which, while somewhat disheartening, managed to retain an element of amusement. Under the circumstances, I would consider visiting this establishment once again.

"The Grandview Saloon boasts a spectacular panorama of Pittsburgh from atop Mt. Washington, which can be savored from the establishment's expansive patio area. While the vistas from within the restaurant itself are by no means inferior, they pale in comparison to the breathtaking scenery that awaits patrons who venture outdoors. To complement the visual feast, the Saloon offers an extensive array of libations, as well as a menu that, while unremarkable in terms of culinary innovation, caters to the local palate with an assortment of familiar, comforting dishes. Unfortunately, the interior design of the restaurant fails to live up to the standards set by its picturesque surroundings, with a decidedly lackluster ambiance that detracts from the overall experience. However, with some attention directed towards refining both the aesthetic and gastronomic aspects, this venue could potentially rank among the city's most captivating destinations for dining and entertainment. In summary, while not an ideal setting for momentous occasions such as anniversaries, the Grandview Saloon remains a suitable choice for hosting first-time visitors, providing them with a unique opportunity to appreciate the splendor of Pittsburgh while indulging in a delectable beverage."

Great, friendly and attentive service. We had the Caesar salad, duck & scallops. Salad was great, duck was good & very rich. Scallops were so-so & not something I'd recommend ordering. Over all an okay meal, but not one I'd repeat.

"I have been frequenting this establishment on a regular basis during the week, and it can be challenging to determine whether it is open for business during inclement weather conditions. Despite this, there are certain aspects of the market that I thoroughly enjoy, while others leave something to be desired. The floral arrangements, for instance, are not only breathtakingly beautiful but also remarkably affordable; however, their longevity leaves much to be desired, typically lasting no more than a few days. Additionally, there are some exceptional deals on fresh produce, with some truly outstanding tomatoes and peaches available during their respective seasons. Nonetheless, it is somewhat disconcerting to note that nearly half of the merchandise on offer is not locally sourced. In fact, I found it quite vexing to locate a locally grown apple, and many of the fruits and vegetables sport SKU stickers indicating their origins in distant states such as California or Washington. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the presence of several local farmers scattered throughout the market renders it a worthwhile venture. Consequently, I shall continue to patronize this establishment with some degree of regularity."

I usually love The Coffee Bean.
Something's wrong with this one, though....  something's wrong with all the coffee inside the Venetian!!?!?!

I love a good, strong cup of coffee but it's either the water at the Venetian, or a plot to drive me insane, but all the coffee in the Venetian Hotel drives me nuts.  

But, it beats the room service coffee, and every morning. I had a cup of Joe from this place.

For the coffee -  1 star.
The way I had it brought to me every morning while in Vegas by a wonderfully  considerate hunk of a man  - - I throw in an additional 2 stars... hence, the 3-star rating.  :-)

"Adequate retail establishment offering an extensive array of merchandise that I would indeed utilize. Notably advantageous reductions on comestibles. Well-organized physical space, albeit susceptible to disarray due to the presence of numerous patrons. The sole drawback I have encountered during my visits is the considerable delay incurred while waiting to complete my purchases. A protracted queue at the checkout counter is a minor inconvenience given the substantial economies realized. Prepare to devote approximately 15 minutes or more to conclude your transaction."

It is a spotless establishment that boasts commendable hospitality, and the aesthetically pleasing Koi pond serves as an idyllic backdrop for a leisurely visit. However, the culinary offerings do not quite live up to expectations, particularly the uninspiring turkey sandwich that closely resembles its processed, mass-produced counterpart available at your local grocery store. Furthermore, the prices charged are comparable to those of other delicatessens, but for the same amount, one could easily procure a superior quality sandwich from a different eatery.

I must admit that my expectations were not entirely met by this establishment, despite the favorable reviews and endorsements featured on its website. Specifically, I had envisioned a more engaging and flavorful encounter with a grill master who would not only possess a distinctive Philadelphia accent but also demonstrate a certain level of culinary expertise. However, my experience fell short of these expectations, as the individual responsible for preparing my order appeared to be somewhat hearing-impaired and neglected to include the onions that I had specifically requested.

The cheese steak itself was not particularly impressive, lacking the rich, savory flavors that I have come to associate with this dish. Although the meat was lean and not excessively oily, it was somewhat bland and failed to leave a lasting impression on my palate. The cheese whiz and bread were satisfactory, yet the absence of onions proved to be a significant detriment to my overall enjoyment of the dish. It is worth noting that, in the aftermath of consuming the cheese steak, I experienced some gastrointestinal discomfort, which may serve as an indicator of the quality of the ingredients used in its preparation. Nevertheless, I remain open to the possibility of revisiting this establishment in the future and comparing its offerings to those of its competitors in the area.

Cabo is a very busy place- even on a Tuesday night! Luckily we were a party of 2 and were seated pretty quick. The food tasted good and fresh, but I had very high expectations based on the reputation they have in Charlotte. I was hoping for a little more flavor.

Contrary to some of the other reviews, I didn't feel rushed even though they were jammin'. I went with a friend and we were catching up for quite a while, but our waitress was friendly and didn't rush us, which I appreciated. Parking can be difficult, like most places in NoDa, so plan to cruise around a little. 

Overall I think Cabo has a fun atmosphere for grabbing drinks and something to eat, but it isn't a "go out of your way" establishment.

We were on our way back from a trip to Mexico and Cuba* when we arrived here for a short layover. This airport is easy to navigate, especially when you are coming through immigration -- there are lots of signs telling you exactly where to go. 

There was a long line at immigration but it moved fairly quickly. My honey and I had all of our research license paperwork in order for the Cuba portion of our travels in case we were asked for it** but the not-even-a-hello immigration officer guy just scanned our passports, looked at us with his best stern face, and stamped us on our way. We then picked up our checked suitcases, zoomed right through customs (after handing over our customs form) and rechecked our bags. 

The part that ended up taking the longest amount of time was going back through security, thanks to long lines. I do have to say that the security personnel were working very hard to move everyone along and were really nice as well.

If we had more than 5 minutes to spare, I would have picked up some local BBQ to eat on our San Francisco bound flight. Thanks a lot, security line. 

*You won't hear much more about our trip to Mexico and Cuba since they don't have Yelp. (At least not yet.) I'll just summarize to say that almost everywhere we slept, ate, drank, visited, etc. were unquestionably five star. 

** Apparently Beyonce and Jay Z did as well. http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/04/09/entertainment-us-usa-cuba-beyonce-idUSBRE93600V20130409

This hotel exterior is a little worn down and in need of a refurbishing. Everything about it just looks dated and tired. The rooms had obviously been updated since other parts of the hotel and they were not that bad although the tile grout looked a little dingy in my room. I did not hear the people in the room next to me as others have complained about. However, I found the food to be very good especially for a hotel. They had a decent bar with a few local brews on tap and service was friendly. The hotel location is convenient but still a 6-8 block walk to the more popular attractions downtown. We took advantage of the free shuttle service and the friendly and knowledgeable driver, Christian. Its fairly easy to get to though off I-277. For the money, it wasn't bad.

The restaurant is cozy and somewhat dark with a separate bar area and dining area. Service was quick and attentive. They have some different beers to experiment with and even let you sample some you're not familiar with before you commit. 


Food was OK but not great. I had half a turkey sandwich and salad. My turkey sandwich was a bit dry and bland and the salad was forgettable. As bars go and as bar food goes you could do much worse.

I have been eager to experience this establishment for an extended period of time, subsequent to hearing numerous favorable comments regarding its culinary offerings and perusing its menu. Upon further investigation, it has become apparent that the prices listed on the website are intentionally omitted, as the eatery in question charges exorbitant fees for its dishes.

Upon arriving at the restaurant, we opted to be seated on the patio, as the primary dining area was not yet open for seating at the time of our arrival (6:30 pm). Our server was quite attentive and hospitable, replacing my water glass promptly upon noticing that it contained an unidentifiable substance floating within. Additionally, my spouse's water glass was observed to be unclean, and she expediently provided a fresh glass for him as well.

She presented us with two minuscule sample-sized frozen peach and strawberry margaritas, which we found to be quite delectable. However, we did notice that the rocks margarita was not as impressive as the aforementioned samples. It is worth mentioning that no complementary chips and salsa were offered, which would have been acceptable had the restaurant provided some other form of appetizer or promotion, similar to that of Barrio. Furthermore, there was no happy hour available, much to our dismay.

The street corn served at this establishment was satisfactory, although I have certainly encountered superior renditions elsewhere. The butternut squash tacos, on the other hand, were truly exceptional. My spouse preferred them significantly over his mahi tacos. Nevertheless, I cannot fathom how this restaurant has managed to remain in operation given the exorbitant pricing of their dishes, including three miniature tacos (measuring only three inches in diameter) for the sum of $12. Moreover, they have the audacity to charge $12 for guacamole prepared from a mere two avocados. It is evident that this establishment relies heavily on the tourist trade, as I cannot imagine how they could possibly sustain themselves during the off-season.

The good:
- children get a magna doodle to draw on, 
- the wait staff is very nice, 
- the restaurant is very clean - it's brand new, so that's expected,
- the pasta selection is basically "create your own", with 5(?) types of pasta (incl. whole wheat) and at least 5 types of sauces (incl. rose), plus you can add toppings to your pasta
- karaoke Fri+Sat night,
- the food tastes decent,
- prices are decent, if you don't add extra toppings,
- unique desert menu

The bad:
- the kids menu is on the back of the magna doodle, but they don't tell you that, and it's small
- kids' drinks come in an adult sized to-go cup,
- it took them almost 10mins to clean up (my daughter's) spilled milk
- the menu consisted of pasta, pizza and paninis, not much more,
- pasta toppings are $1.50 each,
- my canneloni (desert) was pretty bland.
We were less than welcomed at the door. The security guard was extremely disrespectful. We would not have gone in if our birthday bud didn't insist.

"An enjoyable shopping experience awaits individuals seeking Korean cuisine-related items at this retail establishment, provided they refrain from misidentifying it as a purveyor of Japanese culinary fare, despite superficial similarities between the two cultures' gastronomical offerings."

Red 8 is a pretty good americanized chinese food. I love the Oxtail soup along with their mongolian beef and rice.. The ambiance is really nice and the service is wonderful. The dessert menu can use a bit of work but still ok. The price is a bit expensive , i think your paying for the ambiance and the fact that you are dining at the Wynn.. I don't suggest this place for chinese food. I would only go back here if i was invited, but still glad i checked this restaurant off my list.

It is becoming increasingly arduous to discover exceptional gastronomical offerings at an affordable price point in Las Vegas, as the era of $5 buffets and $7.99 prime rib dinners appears to have dissipated into the annals of history. Lamentably, the dining landscape has shifted towards more exorbitant options, with even previously reasonable establishments now charging premium prices for their fare. During a recent visit to Sunset Station, this sentiment was reinforced when it was discovered that their prime rib dinner was being offered for a relatively steep $9.99 on a Saturday evening. Despite the bustling atmosphere and ensuing 15-minute wait for a table, the quality of the prime rib was found to be satisfactory, yet not without room for improvement, specifically in regards to the doneness level, as a medium rare preparation may have yielded a more palatable experience. The service, however, was commendable and the food, while not exceptional, was still of an acceptable standard. Yet, the pricing of the prime rib dinner, coupled with the $12.99 cost of the t-bone steak special, seemed somewhat excessive for a city known for its affordable dining options, thereby precluding a higher rating. Nonetheless, Grand Cafe remains a superior alternative to Denny's for those seeking a convenient, 24-hour dining establishment, thereby warranting a future visit.

I really want to like this place, but it was extremely disappointing. Maybe it was overhyped. The food was just okay, nothing sets it apart from other buffets. \n\nBased on other reviews, I might give it another shot next time I'm in Vegas, but I'd rather go back to the seafood buffet at Rio before dining here again.

"The gastronomical experience was satisfactory, with the culinary offerings being of superior quality, specifically the infinite shrimp options (shrimp alfredo duplicated, breaded shrimp, and shrimp scampi) which constituted the most favorable aspect of the dining excursion. However, the waiting period preceding seating and subsequent service was rather prolonged, lasting approximately half an hour for seating and an additional quarter hour for the servers to take our order, thereby hindering the overall enjoyment of the meal and warranting improvement in the realm of customer service to elevate the establishment's rating. Notwithstanding, the comestibles were indeed delectable and arrived at our table piping hot, and the cheddar biscuits presented post-seating were of exceptional quality."

"Although the cost of the sashimi may be perceived as somewhat elevated, the quality of the seafood served at this establishment has consistently met my expectations, with each piece of fish exhibiting exceptional freshness and being presented in an aesthetically pleasing manner. Following three separate visits, I can confidently attest to the consistent excellence of the culinary experience offered here."

"My experience at this hotel was less than satisfactory, and I would not consider staying here again. The room, while aesthetically pleasing and featuring comfortable bedding, had a subpar bathroom that appeared to be from a lower-end establishment. Moreover, the arduous trek to the back tower, which involved traversing the entire casino with one's luggage and crossing a bridge over the pool, was particularly vexing. The casino itself, however, was quite pleasant, boasting a fresh and clean atmosphere, likely due to its recent renovation. Unfortunately, the check-in process was a significant disappointment, taking an unacceptable amount of time and contributing to an overall negative experience. The pool and staff were pleasant, but the issues with check-in and the bathroom left a lasting impact on my impression of the hotel."
There's just not a big selection. The parking lot was crowded but in the store it wasn't. Friendly staff. \nI found some cute juice glasses for $0.69 that's it!

I stopped by here a while ago while staying at the Aria on business.  We had walked past the patisserie when headed up to our rooms and the brightness of the area along with the cakes really caught my eye. So the next morning whenever i was craving some coffee I decided to head down and get my fianc\u00e9 and I each one.  Whenever I got down there I was able to see the multi tiered cakes up close and they were truly amazing!  It made me wonder how long it took to make them.  After a short wait I made it to the front of the line and ordered two Americanos only to watch them punch something into a machine and have it spot them out.  For the $10 it cost I was really hoping to have the barista take a minute and pull the shots.  The coffee itself was decent but not great.\n\nThe bottom line for me is that I would not head back here again in the future for coffee.  However I would definitely give it a try if I was looking for a baked good.

The beer is average, but overpriced.  Save yourself $10 on a case and wait until Costco restocks.  ($30 a case at the brewery, $20 at Costco).   Perhaps I would return if they end up opening up an actual restaurant,  as the staff there were extremely friendly, but not too much of a draw at this point....

This is one of those places that you must try at least one time. It is a fun experience and the meat its regularly pretty good.\nDo not come on a holiday, they do not maintain the same level of service and food quality

"The pricing structure at this establishment is patently exorbitant, with minuscule, tapas-style plates of culinary fare commanding a premium price point in excess of $30, while larger, yet still diminutive entree-sized portions fetch a whopping $50 to $60. Despite my prior awareness of the menu prices, the inflated cost of my meal still managed to surpass my expectations. The ambiance of the restaurant, characterized by a color scheme dominated by red and black hues, was somewhat redeemed by the novelty of witnessing the culinary process firsthand from our perch at the bar. However, the quality of the food, though undeniably satisfactory, fails to justify the egregious markup. If the aim of this dining experience is to foster a sense of casualness, a reduction in prices by at least 25-30% would be imperative."

Is the best bagel place I've been to? No. I came here for a \"to go\" breakfast with my man. As we were waiting for our food, he whispered to me \"this place is filthy\". The vent above the bagel rack was so dusty! The counters, floors and tables looked like they hadn't been wiped down either. We had already paid so we just decided to get our food and go. The guy who helped us was very sweet but incredibly slow. We spent almost 20 minutes waiting for 2 bagel sandwiches and a chocolate chip muffin. The bagel sandwiches tasted good (I tried a tomato basil bagel) and liked it. I also thought the variety in bagels was nice. The muffin wasn't my favorite but was edible. Prices were reasonable but nothing great. Just like my review says, A-OK.

"Underwhelmed experience with too much repetition."
It is with profound dismay that I must convey my utter disappointment with my recent dining excursion to this establishment, which, ostensibly, specializes in "pho," a culinary delight that I, and my companion, were eager to indulge in. However, our enthusiasm was quickly extinguished when the waitstaff, in an almost perfunctory manner, divulged that they were bereft of the aforementioned "pho" at the present time. This revelation struck me as rather anomalous, given the eatery's namesake and its purported focus on Vietnamese cuisine. Had the waitress apprised us of this deficiency upon our arrival, we could have, with relative ease, sought out an alternative venue to satiate our craving for a steaming bowl of "pho." Alas, we were compelled to peruse the menu further, resulting in orders that, regrettably, failed to impress. The lone redeeming quality of this lackluster dining experience was the cordial demeanor of the staff, which, admittedly, salvaged a modicum of respectability. In light of these circumstances, I fear that my patronage of this establishment shall remain a distant memory, never to be revisited.

Though the smell of the place can really get to you, the instructors here are amazing.  Down side is the people at the front desk are extremely rude and not very friendly.  If customer service were good all around I would have continued to come to this studio. But since it's all the way on the other side of town I think I'll have to opt out for a more welcoming environment.  

Other than the downsides, they have a clean changing area with 2 showers where they provide body wash, shampoo, and conditioner so you can wash off all the nasty sweat after your classes. 

Try catching Summer and Stacy. They're both awesome in their own way.

"Rob and I partook of a morning repast, during which we savored an assortment of delectable comestibles, including ovular eggs, crispy bacon, and fluffy pancakes, albeit not the most scrumptious pancakes I have had the pleasure of consuming, yet still palatable. However, the genuine highlight of the meal was the exceptional sausage gravy that accompanied our feast."

This place wasn't as good as we were expecting.  My pizza (Classic Maggie) was good, but nothing outstanding.  My husband's burger was completely charred and basically inedible.  We didn't bother sending it back as our waitress was nowhere to be found.\n\nIt's your typical bar food with a decent beer selection...nothing more, nothing less.

Been to this establishment on multiple occasions, and I must say, their artisanal brews have piqued my interest and secured my patronage. It's worth noting that they only serve their house-brewed beers, which, in my opinion, is a selling point. While the food menu is adequate, it doesn't boast any particularly remarkable offerings. In fact, their buffalo wings left much to be desired, and I wouldn't recommend them. However, the ambiance is quite pleasant, making it an ideal setting for socializing with companions over a cold beverage or two. It's worth mentioning that their prices are a tad high, but given the location in Ahwatukee, it's somewhat expected. Their in-house brewed beverages, specifically the Uncle Bear's lineup, are undoubtedly the highlight of this establishment. It's worth noting that it's the only type of beer available, but that's part of the charm. Although I won't go out of my way to visit frequently, it's still a suitable venue for casual gatherings with friends, especially considering the abundance of televisions scattered throughout, making it an excellent choice for viewing sporting events. Additionally, they accommodate canine companions on the patio, provided they're leashed and well-behaved. As a unique touch, if you provide an 8 x 10 photograph of your furry friend, they'll even display it in a frame as a memorial. That's certainly a commendable gesture.

"Turkish Kitchen presented itself as a respectable and economical dining establishment, catering to a group of patrons who had not reserved a table in the city center on a Friday evening. Upon being seated, we were served an assortment of bread accompanied by an extraordinary dip, whose flavor profile was so remarkable that it became the focal point of our culinary experience. Not feeling particularly famished, I opted for the Turkish ravioli, which, despite its absence from the menu, was complemented by a side of salad and rice. While the sides were somewhat awkwardly presented and resulted in a degree of waste, they were undeniably delectable. Unfortunately, the ravioli failed to meet expectations, primarily due to its overcooking, causing it to disintegrate upon attempted consumption. Although its taste was passable, it paled in comparison to my previous encounter with Turkish ravioli, which was a considerable disappointment. It is likely that I should have selected a kebab-style dish, as did everyone else, but my craving for something other than a meat-centric meal prevailed. The remaining patrons appeared content with their choices, however. One peculiarity was that our order of beer was served in glasses of varying sizes, smaller than customary pint or large bottle glasses. In conclusion, while Turkish Kitchen offered a satisfactory dining experience for a group seeking a reasonable and convivial meal, it falls short of being Edinburgh's premier Turkish restaurant, in my estimation."

"An exceptional venue for a Friday evening of merriment and indulgence! The Chambord margarita is a superior libation, while the achiote chopped chicken salad is truly delectable and worthy of praise. However, the trio appetizer platter, though delicious, is only recommended when offered at a discounted price during happy hour. Unfortunately, the manager's haughty demeanor, the hostesses' ineffectuality, and the servers' lack of attentiveness somewhat mar the overall experience. Nevertheless, after consuming a couple of margaritas, one can readily overlook these shortcomings."

I have no idea why there was such a huge hype, it was just a typical thin crusted pizza. Seriously!!!!! The toppings were good, pepperoni, sausage, etc... but honestly you can get a better pizza elsewhere.\n\nHowever, if you are dying for a late  night snack after Marquee it's conveniently located.

My experience at this establishment was merely adequate. I ordered the Pho, and although the broth did not meet my expectations of being exceptional, it was still passable. My companion ordered the cashew chicken for the first time, and he thoroughly enjoyed it. My acquaintance had the chicken fried rice, which was also quite satisfactory. The prices at this venue are reasonable for the generous portions, making it an ideal location for budget-conscious college students. I would return to this eatery for sustenance, but I would not order the Pho again.

I am awarding three stars for this review due to two primary factors. Firstly, I requested the Thai iced tea for nearly $3, anticipating a revitalizing and genuine Thai iced tea experience. However, what I received was a minuscule bottled beverage from the refrigerator, which was underwhelming and not worth the cost. The individual behind the counter offered a lackadaisical explanation, stating she was "too indolent to prepare a proper one." Secondly, the dining area was excessively humid and warm, with the entrance open on a steamy rainy day. As a result, I perspired profusely during my dining experience, which was disagreeable. Moreover, there were laborers mending the ceiling tiles or something in close proximity, which I deemed unsuitable for when patrons are consuming their meals mere feet away.

The cuisine was palatable, but the ambiance left much to be desired. Despite this, I will continue to visit this establishment for a speedy Thai culinary fix, primarily due to its accessibility and prime location on Green Street.

went to kings on saturday for an early meal, while out doing the day after xmas shopping!  i have been here a few times for my seafood fix, and time after time the service is very slow, and this visit is the same (at least they are consistent!!)
started the table with the chilled seafood platter for 24.95  comes with 4 dungeness crab legs, 4 oysters, 4 clams and 8 shrimps.  and i think this one of the best deals in vegas for a shellfish platter.
entrees were grilled shrimp and scallop skewars, kids burger and a combo fried platter.   the fried platter was not to good,  over breaded and gummy shrimp and scallops, and 1 little peice of cod/haddock
i usually get the sanddabs or something that is on special,  ill stick with that in the future.  but in all actuallity i just come for the shellfsih platter!!!

"I reside in close proximity to the Burger Factory, which is perpetually characterized by a high volume of patrons. The eatery's extensive menu boasts a diverse array of culinary options, rendering it an ideal venue for accommodating the varied gastronomical inclinations of a group of professionals. Additionally, the generous portion sizes and the establishment's reputation for serving rich, savory dishes make it an excellent choice for individuals seeking a casual dining experience that satisfies their craving for a hearty meal."

For years I have driven past Ping Pong Thai always thinking it was an adult themed Thai restaurant with ping pong shows. No shows here. They only have food. Not even one ping pong ball:(

I've tried the Panang and found it to be watery and bland. The Pad Kee Maw is consistently delicious and packs enough spice I am satisfied ordering it at Medium heat. This dish is the only reason I come here. It's certainly not for the service. 

The service is slow when dining in and good luck chasing down a refill. To Go orders are the exact opposite. Either way you choose you are still left feeling like a number. Boy do they pack the herd in at lunch.

If only they had a Ping pong table I would gladly raise the star level. Maybe the owner is a ping pong champion from Thailand. Now that would be something to get excited about.

"Despite its proximity and appealing happy hour offerings, we continue to experience frustration during our repeated visits to this establishment. Specifically, we are dismayed by the limited beer selection, which features only three options on tap. Furthermore, the service has been inconsistent, characterized by overly attentive servers at the onset of the meal, followed by an inexplicable absence during the payment process. This lack of attention to detail raises concerns about potential losses for the restaurant, as it is not uncommon for patrons to depart without settling their bills. Additionally, the cuisine has been variable in quality, with the more affordable selections, such as the calamari, proving to be the most satisfying, while the pricier options, like the elk meatballs, have fallen short of expectations due to their bland and arid texture."
Wow, harsh reviews!\n\nI found the guy behind the counter helpful.  He steered me in the right direction and I got a meal I really enjoyed.   BBQ'd tilapia and Chicken Adobo were very tasty.

Close to the strip in between harrahs and ballys area in the Linq. Cool new concept, supposely all their slushies have top shelf liquor but I felt it wasn't strong enough, I believe I've gotten more drunk at fat Tuesdays slushies. They have more flavors though and we chose the patron grand mariner because it was sour.The staff is very friendly and cutely dressed, just needs more signs on the cups of drinks. The saxophone cup is seriously amazing! I think its the sexiest and bangest cup there is. ;) Ha ha

Are you supposed to be drunk for this? On drugs?  Well I was neither and man, was it weird! 

This was my 2nd Cirque show (I've been to 3 now) and my first on in Vegas.  As always, the acrobatics were great and the production set was beautiful.

This was by far, the trippy-est Cirque show I've been to though.  The baby giggles and head were so creepy and weird!  

Cirque is always beautiful but I get the impression this isn't the best they can do in Vegas either.

The modified text is: We placed an order for delivery through the online platform of http://www.youbuyandwefly.com, and we found the prices to be reasonable and the food to be delectable. Consequently, we will undoubtedly place future orders with them. However, due to the fact that we opted for delivery, we were unable to experience the ambiance of the physical establishment firsthand. Nonetheless, our meal consisted of a variety of dishes, including a flavorful hot and sour soup, succulent sweet and sour pork, savory orange chicken, and satisfying chicken chow mein, all of which met our expectations.

This place is fun because there is always a live band playing in the evening. So if you are looking do get your dance on like you are at a wedding, then this is it. In fact, if I was getting married (too late), then I would bring the whole wedding party by here and tell them to enjoy the reception. The only problem is that it is a cash bar (and credit or room charge too)! I hate those kind of weddings (not the band part but the cash bar part). 

Tables fill up fast but the room isn't closed off from the casino. You can always walk up with your own drink and enjoy the show. There are also slot machines within ear and eye shot.

I love this place because it reminds me of Old Vegas. Every casino had musical acts playing in the bars and lounges. There was no cover all Vegas wanted was you to come in and spend money on your drinks. Now every casino has mega night clubs with Lines and VIP lists, Karaoke bars, and dueling pianos. So it is nice to see some original Vegas entertainment. I've seen this town change in the last 20 years, so I appreciate this lounge.

Bring the whole group and grab a table. Get a few drinks and put on those dancing shoes. This is Vegas at it's best!!!

I started going to Spice Island when it first opened. I was in my early 20s then, which means the place is officially a Pittsburgh institution. The menu has stayed pretty much the same over the years, with the exception of adding alcohol, but why change a good thing? My favorite items on the menu are vegetarian -- the fried tofu (either sauce is delicious) and the vegetable curry trio. Pay a little extra for the coconut rice and you'll be back for the same thing again and again.

"The Mecklenburg ABC store in question boasts an array of spirituous beverages and liquid refreshments that cater to diverse tastes and preferences, albeit lacking my preferred cognac variety. Notwithstanding, the friendly demeanor exhibited by the staff members during my visit elicited a sense of cordiality, despite their seemingly scrutinizing gaze, which I chose to interpret as a harmless gesture of hospitality rather than an expression of skepticism regarding my age. It is worth mentioning that the prices charged at this establishment align with the standard rates applied at similar ABC stores, with a negligible upward deviation that barely warrants mention."

Their scones are divine and it is a nice little place with fine coffee.  I only wish they would not let dogs in.  I am allergic to them and it rather spoils my meal.  If they had a sign on the door -- no dogs, except service dogs it would be fine.  The ones brought in are not service ones.  Their scones are delicious and made daily.  Go there!

On entering this revamped place and proceeding into the great hall...OMG the detail in the pictures and paintings are visually stunning and esoterically beautiful.

A very contemporary place, quieter than museum's usually are, yes it's smaller than I'd expected from the outside but makes up for it in wow factor, well worth the £80K spent on renovation fees.

Go if you like places with a medieval feel to them, history of scotland, medicine the war and the people who recorded some of the most significant historic events.

With a very busy gift shop and full to the brim bums on seats in their eatery, this was just the place to spend a few bob and actually learn something as well. 

Go if you like Glasgow Gorbals, art of science and medicine Royal Navy, death masks of William Burke and associated criminals, migrated families to Scotland and art history. I last visited a few months ago now, but feel like going again?

But above all...just go for the cultural effect, or the cafe buzz either way you will be rewarded.

I have been visiting this Cheesecake Factory long before I moved to Las Vegas. The multiple levels is a architectural design element not seen in other restaurants, but is necessary because they get so much traffic. It is located at the very end of The Forum Shops commected to Caesars Palace.

Having to wait to get in and the long journey it takes to get to this location from the casino, are the only two drawbacks. Everything else, including the staff and food have always been good.

It is near a large aquarium and an animatronic show with fire and water, so those help to pass the time. If you are walking around Las Vegas and want to enjoy a nice dinner from a restaurant you know, try this one out.

Well hello Cafe Zupas, I'm glad to meet you! Welcome to the neighborhood, I hope you will stick around.  The bbq chicken salad you created was delicious, and I especially loved the fun drink bar, which let me make my own Italian soda.  My husband liked his summer chicken salad and turkey bacon panini. And that free chocolate covered strawberry at the end? Awesome! I was very satisfied after eating at Cafe Zupas. Not too full but just right. I appreciate new restaurants that are quick, healthy and not too expensive!

Siam Terrace is one of my preferred Thai restaurants in Urbana, and it stands out as one of the few establishments where I have a singular favorite dish, specifically due to their exceptional preparation of red curry. However, this should not dissuade you from exploring other options on the menu, as the rad nar, pad thai, and diverse alternatives are equally impressive selections. My predilection for their red curry is merely an expression of my individualized preferences. While the restaurant's ambiance may feel slightly constrained when accommodating groups of four or more patrons, and the arrangement of tables appears somewhat awkward, Siam Terrace warrants a rating above four stars. Their appetizers are unremarkable yet reliable, with the standard fare being a judicious choice, while the shrimp appetizer is particularly commendable and worth recommending. Although I categorize Siam Terrace as a $$ establishment, its prices are, in reality, around $1.50, making it an economical option. Their delectable red curry dishes start at a reasonable $8.99 for vegetarian, chicken, or tofu variations, while meat entrees generally cost no more than $12, with seafood options being the priciest.

I was initially acquainted with this culinary establishment during my temporary residency in Fort Worth, Texas, which lasted for a year. I thoroughly enjoyed my dining experience at this restaurant! It's a Brazilian churrascaria, which can be literally translated as a Brazilian cowboy barbecue, although it's significantly more sophisticated and impressive than a simple barbecue. Indeed, it's an all-encompassing, unrestricted meat extravaganza, similar to none other than the exceptional dining experiences offered by this very establishment. It's an extensive buffet, but with a unique and intriguing twist; servers stroll around, bearing sword-like skewers overflowing with the most tender and flavorful cuts of meat, expertly prepared to perfection. Patrons are provided with a tiny disk that can be effortlessly flipped from red, indicating "no, thank you" to green, signifying "please, do indulge me with an abundance of delectable meat." This exceptional aspect of the dining experience is undoubtedly the piÃ¨ce de rÃ©sistance of this fantastic eatery. However, one must not overlook or undervalue the salad bar, boasting an array of mouthwatering items, such as the succulent prosciutto and an assortment of exquisite cheeses. Furthermore, this superb dining establishment also features a well-stocked bar, offering impeccable service and an extensive selection of refreshing libations.

This place is a trip to morocco! Try the tea and the date shake. The bread is awesome. The owner is a gracious host and gave us a bunch of stuff to try. I love the decorations in the place too! A fun trip out

We experimented with an array of tacos at this establishment (three for ten dollars), and our culinary exploration yielded a diverse assortment of singular and delectable creations. Among these gastronomic delights, the Suadero Azteca (the queen's special) proved to be the undisputed showstopper. Its unparalleled tenderness and rich flavors, complemented by an assortment of fresh, tantalizing vegetables, made it a veritable epicurean indulgence. If you are inclined to share your dining experience with others, it is imperative that you procure an individual portion of this particular taco, lest you relinquish your claim to its sublime taste. The fried fish and fried shrimp variations, while not as transcendent as their Suadero Azteca counterpart, still managed to delight our palates with their distinctive zest and savory charm. This venue offers an exceptional opportunity to sample innovative and scrumptious tacos, although the cost may rise slightly above the norm. A request for chips and salsa is advisable, as their presentation, though flavorsome, was contingent upon our explicit petition.

The name is as good as the food. You can go in and take out, you can sit down and get served, and if your close enough they will deliver. It a mom and pop Asian food place with all or your favorite taste liker teriyaki and orange chicken! worth a stop and food is always great!

Fine place for any-time beakfast (certainly a step up from Dennys or IHOP). Good omlettes and if you can take the heart-clogging properties, biscuits & gravy. Also serves sandwiches, salads and smoothies.

After hearing wonderful things about Il Pizzaiolo for years - literally years - I finally had the opportunity to try this restaurant last week with a group of co-workers. I had a wonderful time! 

First, we ordered wine. The wine list was insanely long and confusing, so we asked the waitress for her recommendation. She told us that there were three house wines, conveniently called the #1, #2, and #3. I believe they were Pinot Grigio, Pinot Noir, and Merlot. I shared two carafes of the Pinot Noir with a co-worker and thought it was very tasty.

The team shared two appetizers, Panzarotti and Fiori de Zucca. The Fiori de Zucca was fried zucchini slices that were good but not my favorite thing ever. I loved the Panzarotti. It kind of tasted like a fried risotto and mozzarella ball. So yummy. Even at the risk of potentially embarrassing myself for taking too much food, I snagged the last one. For my entree, I ordered the Ravioli alla Caprese. The entree was very simple but superbly executed.

I hope to come back to Il Pizzaiolo very soon!

DH was getting pizza at #1 Brothers so I originally tried to order from the Japanese restaurant in the same plaza, but they failed to answer the phone after we called FOUR times!  Thank goodness.  Went to Ari and got the usual excellent service and good sushi.  What made me feel good---I was explaining to the girl who answered the phone that I had ordered the spicy tuna handroll before and had been disappointed in its consistency and our server had suggested a order it more coarsely chopped.  The young lady on the phone said: \"Oh, yes, that was me---I was your server and I remember.  I know exactly what you want!\"  And she did.  My spicy tuna handroll was exactly what I wanted and I felt good that she had remembered such a trivial incident when she deals with hundreds of customers.  Also, when I explained to her what my favorite specialty roll had been back at my old sushi joint, she was able to suggest a roll that very nearly the same and very good.  Actually, wait.  This was a Four star rather than a three star experience---let me go change my rating.  I feel like I have found my forever sushi place!  Thank you, Ari, for making me feel like a valued customer and not a faceless diner.

"I am reluctant to articulate my thoughts regarding this establishment, as I fear that an influx of patrons may compromise the tranquility and exceptional service I have grown accustomed to experiencing during my frequent visits. Notwithstanding my reservations, I must confess that the ambiance and attention to detail exhibited by the staff, particularly Julie and Tammy, have consistently surpassed my expectations. Although a solitary occurrence of an overly zealous pedicure left me feeling somewhat uncomfortable, Julie promptly adjusted her technique upon my request, thereby exemplifying the salon's commitment to client satisfaction. Additionally, the spotlessness of the facilities and the cordial demeanor of the staff have fostered a sense of comfort and loyalty, leading me to frequent the salon on a regular basis. While the cost of a pedicure has recently increased to $22, a nominal fee considering the quality of service provided, I remain steadfast in my belief that this venue offers an unparalleled value. My consistent patronage and appreciation for the salon's excellence are reflected in the $5 gratuity I customarily offer in addition to the standard $20 fee."

I had great service when I went in to buy paint for my house. The employee working the paint section helped me out a lot. I have never really bought paint for a house before so I needed a little guidance. She helped me get the right type and mixed it for me. I had all my questions answered and was out of there pretty quickly. I had great service and was happy with the price I paid.

I love having this place so close to home.  You can depend on them for all the basics when you're feeling a little Asian inspiration in the kitchen.

I especially like the people who work there.  They're always friendly and will help you out if you can't find what you need.

The fresh produce/meat/fish components of this shop are a little . . . well, kinda dicey, but otherwise, thumbs up all the way.

Friendly, casual atmosphere with very tasty pizza.  Huge variety of toppings and an excellent olive oil base.  I find the pizzas with tomato sauce to be a little bland, but all of the rest have been fantastic.  Salads are huge and fresh.

My family and I have eaten here for years, as it is close to our house.  Restaurant has a nice local following, and many of their diners are Take Out diners.  Their menu is limited but the items served is hot, fresh and flavorful.  My husband loves their sushi.

When you arrive, you are immediately greeted and seated.  Be sure to check the specials listed on the chalk board near the entrance.  I like the decor, and facility, dining plates, utensils and glasses are clean.

Staff is efficient and accommodating.  The menu is concise but has enough available for almost anyone.  Prices are reasonable and portions are above average.  Definitely will return.
Cool place...burgers are fresh and good...don't taste like a grease bomb like 5 guys!!!  Only thing is, it is a little spendy for a burger...can't beat in-n-out for overall quality and price!!!

Dairy Queen really does not need a review.  Only place better for icecream is your mom and pop stores.  Place was clean, service was quick (oh yeah, we were the only ones in there).  $7.80 seems a little high for 1 wafflecone and 1 icecream in a cup.

I liked this place a lot. Cool atmosphere and the food was excellent.  Not your typical diner.  I suggest you make reservation because it was very busy when we went.  Good place for kids ( we had six kids/teens with us), something which is not always obvious downtown.  I think the food was a hit with everyone, great beer, and the desert menu did most of in big time.  Excellent service!  It was a great pick to introduce our friends from Cleveland to the Montreal vibes (kid friendly vibes of course...)
Just as good the one in Scottsdale, AZ. Great bartenders, lots of TV and lots of great beer on tap.

This is my local Salisbury's and where every Monday I do my weekly shop. 

It is a large store, but what bothers me as half the store is not food. This in my eyes defeats the purpose of a supermarket as surely they are food first and TVs second? Clearly it works for them but it does get annoying as choices are limited. The freezer section is very small which for a poor student means I have limited choices in frozen chips. I also find there is a lack of alternatives to brand names i.e. supermarket own brand. On some occasions I would much prefer to just buy the supermarket brand but because this shop has a limited selection of food I can't do this all the time. 

I do enjoy the "Oops!'' section though. As a first year and an Asda shopper, the Oops section was like finding gold. For those who aren't in the know, this is the reduced section. They always have reduced meat which is handy for throwing in the freezer. 

The staff here are very friendly and chatty which is a novelty for supermarket staff.

The selection is pretty vast -- European, upscale specialty brands (up to $24 for a 3 oz bar!), bulk malt balls in 3 flavors that are wonderful, house-brand hot chocolate mix, and lots more. It's fun just to browse around and know all these choices exist.

I've had pets my whole life and my observation has been that when the 's front desk staff is nice and proffesional , the doctors are not and when the doctors are great, the front desk leaves much to be desired.  This was not the case at Alta Vista.  First off, there hours are great.  Secondly. the front desk people (Sam), the techs and the doctor (Dr. Sean Penn), very friendly and courteous.  And finally, the price was reasonable. That, along with the place being clean and not smelling like wet dog when you walk in made having to take my dog in on a Sunday afternoon as pleasant as could be.  So far so good.

The view here is amazing. Can't comment on the food but I'm sure it's good. Just sat down at the bar and conversed with our man, Harold?, who served up a few dirty martinis with a twist. Amazing service even after one in our party lost a bit of balance and drink in the process.\n\nJust be nice to the doorman at the elevator and you'll get upstairs to enjoy the view and drinks.

My husband and I loved this place. The staff was very helpful with ordering and allowed us to sample six of their most popular items. We had enough food for leftovers the next day for under $25. It was great to see everything from ties to tatoos having a good time. My only complaint is that the restaurant could be a little cleaner.
Great atmosphere! I love to sit at the bar and order nachos or enchiladas and hang out with my husband. The service and food are good.

3 stars for their Bun Bo Hue.

So I decided to change things up a bit this time in Vegas.  Instead of the usual Pho after a long night of alcohol abuse, I opted for the Bun Bo Hue (NOTE: NO Pho Here).  Sad to say..it was a disappointment IMO.  The soup base was kind of bland, it didn't have the spicy kick.  There was a total of 1.5 pieces of pork blood?!? I guess that's ok in this case because it was quite dry and tasted like chalk.  

However, the BF got a rice dish and it was pretty decent.  But, the reason they get 4 stars is for their Coffee!! It has a hint of coconut flavor, it's freakin YUMM!! 

Check-in through Yelp and get their coffee for $2!!

Great restaurant located inside the Golden Nugget hotel. Service was excellent- and we had a party of 14 people. The food was pretty good all around. I ordered a "caprese" salad to start and it was delicious. My main course was the Scallops, Brussel sprouts with grits. Fantastic. Hubby ordered the Maine lobster which he thoroughly enjoyed and finished. The king crab legs were amazing.. My nephew had six legs to himself. That 3 year old is one expensive date! 

As for desserts, not amazing but good. We tried the pecan ball, which was a huge ball of vanilla ice cream with pecan nuts on the outside. Nothing special. The bread pudding was better, it came with caramel ice cream on top. I think there's slight rum in the pudding, it was good but nothing blow your mind.

Minus one star because my pineapple juice cup had lipstick stains all over the cup... That's extremely unappetizing and unsanitary. overall, for such a large party- I think the waiters did a fantastic job serving and our food was great overall. Recommend!

Pretty decent location for a nice target store.\nWhen I lived in the area I would frequent this target location and was happy with the service and product selection.\nLocated in the surprise town center shopping district alongside many great shops.

Love the location on 7th st. I passed by it after 5pm and saw that it was closed so I went to this one instead. Ordered an XL bean and cheese burrito America's way! So good. Don't know why this spot only has a 2 star review.

Mama-Mia-American-Pizzeria is alrighty for Jungleboy.

The place is a jolly, colourful, multilevel building with alcoves and indoor window gaps. They have personally painted the walls with a  surrealistic piece depicting flying mushrooms, chili-pepper butterflies and a Pepperoni-Man saving the day. Funny!

We sat down on a table for two and we ordered our pizza - 9" with 3 toppings - I got pepperoni, mushrooms and chili-peppers (was I subliminally influenced by the painting? Yes I was..) It was a very well filled pizza and very tasty.

I enjoyed the pizza crust, which I normally don't(!) and appreciated the laid back, but precise way of serving. They enquired if we were OK, we got our drinks served in time and we got to take the left over slices with us. 

I did find it a bit cold near the doors and I had a good view of all the people on the outside who peered in to see what this place is like. I made an effort to smile and wave to many of them to show how  good it was - but somehow the peepers backed away from the windows very quick when I did that. 

Recommend for a quick visit or even a nice afternoon late snack / meal with a bunch of friends or family, they had a cartwheel of a pizza available to serve to a big table of 8 - it was huge!
Nice little place with a wide variety of food on the menu. Sitting on the patio was awesome. The sliders were amazing and I would defiantly come back again.

Stopped in here to meet up with an old friend and of course down some beers.  Their selection of beers isn't too vast, but what they have is perfect.  It takes away from me reading the menu for an hour and randomly selecting a beer.  Now for the venue.  The inside is dark and pubby, but the outside is what shines.  It feels like you are at a backyard cookout.  Giant jenga blocks ( seriously 2x4's), giant chess, cornhole all over the place, and three ping pong tables. At first I was like they just took someone's back yard and put a bar with a window next to it.  After playing a few games, I realized this wasn't such a bad thing.  Its a great place to go especially during the afternoon.

"We indulged in an exceptional midday repast on a weekend, savoring delectable victuals complemented by an unparalleled selection of fermented beverages, while engaging in convivial conversation with our server, who demonstrated an encyclopedic knowledge of brews. Following a tantalizing tasting experience, we bemused ourselves by exchanging pleasantries centered around the realm of ale. Notwithstanding the ambiance, which could be described as somewhat faded, we were thoroughly entertained, and we anticipate that their nocturnal beer-pairing events would be equally enjoyable."

"I am utterly thrilled about this enhancement to my neighborhood! A stunning refurbishment of a formerly disregarded structurally distinct edifice on Central Avenue has been undertaken. This development signals a positive transformation for our community. Our dining experience at this establishment was nothing short of delightful, with a table originally intended for seven individuals transforming into an impromptu gathering of eight, then nine, all on the auspicious occasion of First Friday. The staff demonstrated exceptional hospitality, warmth, and joviality, ensuring that we felt welcome and well cared for throughout our visit. The proprietor, Dana, graciously took the time to interact with us, guaranteeing that our experience was satisfactory. The culinary offerings were indeed impressive, and we eagerly shared an assortment of dishes among ourselves. Furthermore, the weather conditions were ideally suited for alfresco dining on the patio, contributing to an overall ambiance that was thoroughly enjoyable. These moments serve as a testament to the reasons behind our decision to reside in this captivating locality."

bit of a wait (~40 min) even though it was 9 pm on a Tues; a bit pricy, but it's vegas

we did a late lighter dinner for 5 with about 2 tapas plates per person

really loved the gin and tonic - if you like G&Ts, order one: super smooth, delightful presentation and super nerdy-cool ice (yes, ice). 

marinated mussels (they come in a little tin!) and steamed mussels (yum! order with bread to sop up the juice for both of these dishes next time), meat platter (really liked the house cured meat the best), Brussels sprout salad (delish!!), sauteed shrimp (good), skirt steak with grilled bell pepper (tasty!!), asparagus (good but 10 very young - read tiny - asparagus for $12+...? really good sauce to also pair with bread) quail (tiny yummy bird), tomato bread (oh yummy!)

great service, nice relaxing atmosphere. 

lovely evening!

I came to this Lenscrafters after not being able to find what I wanted at the Chandler Mall location. As soon as I came in, i was greeted by Donna, who was very helpful. I tried on many pairs, taking a break in between to give my baby a bottle. Donna called to verify my insurance and noticed there was a proble.
